site_title: BP returns to profit in second quarter
summary: BP has returned to profit in the second quarter, reporting a net profit of $144 million, compared to a loss of $1.4 billion in the same period last year. The company's profit was driven by firmer oil prices and lower charges related to the Gulf of Mexico spill. CEO Bob Dudley emphasized the importance of maintaining a "tight focus on costs, efficiency, and discipline in capital spending."

site_title: Australia's central bank keeps rate steady, dismayed at high-flying A$
summary: Australia's central bank kept interest rates steady at 1.5%, marking a full year without a rate change. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) expressed concern over a strong currency and weak inflation, with core inflation remaining below the target band since early 2016. The RBA expects a gradual pick-up in inflation and forecasts a 3% economic growth rate over the next couple of years. Economists predict rates may stay at record lows for another year, with only nine expecting a rate hike in the next year.

images.alt_text: Australia's central bank on Tuesday marked a full year without changing interest rates, and many economists suspect rates could stay at record lows of 1.5 per cent for yet another year as it wrestles with a strong currency and weak inflation.

site_title: Thai July headline consumer prices up 0.17% y-o-y, less than forecast
summary: Thai annual headline consumer prices rose 0.17% in July, slightly less than forecast, and remained below the central bank's target range. This leaves the Bank of Thailand with room to keep interest rates near record lows. The core CPI index, excluding raw food and energy prices, rose 0.48% in July, slightly above projections. The central bank expects inflation to return to its target band by early next year, with no expected changes in policy interest rate through 2017.

site_title: Does the crazy week in Washington signal end of Trump presidency?
summary: US President Donald Trump's recent week in Washington has sparked concerns that it may signal the end of his presidency. Trump's speech at a Boy Scout Jamboree was widely criticized for its tone and content, with many viewing it as a political campaign speech rather than an inspirational call to unity. The speech also included a threat to fire his secretary of health and human services if the Senate fails to repeal Obamacare. Additionally, Trump's attack on his Attorney-General Jeff Sessions has been seen as a betrayal of a loyal ally. The White House has also been plagued by internal power struggles, with Trump's chief of staff Reince Priebus being replaced by Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly.

images.alt_text: There are new signs of growing disenchantment with Mr Trump among some Republican lawmakers and, in particular, among centrist Republicans in the Senate.

site_title: Trump fires communications chief Scaramucci in new White House upheaval
summary: US President Donald Trump fired his communications director, Anthony Scaramucci, on Monday, amid a White House staff upheaval. The move came just over a week after Scaramucci's appointment and follows the hiring of new Chief of Staff John Kelly, who sought to impose order and discipline. Kelly reportedly requested Scaramucci's removal, leading Trump to tweet "A great day at the White House!" The firing is the latest in a series of staff changes in Trump's six-month-old administration.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump fired his communications director, Anthony Scaramucci, on Monday over an obscene tirade, just over a week after naming him to the job, sources familiar with the decision said, in the latest staff upheaval to hit the Republican's six-month-old administration.

site_title: City Harvest case: Kong Hee, with white hair and crew cut, in good spirits as criminal reference hearing begins
summary: Former City Harvest Church founder Kong Hee, 52, began his criminal reference hearing with a wide smile, appearing at ease in a purple prison jumpsuit. He looked at the packed public gallery, mouthing "hi" to some. Kong, with a crew cut and white hair, showed good spirits as he entered the dock. The hearing marks a significant step in the case, but no further details or conclusions were provided in this article.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.03% to 19,931.32, and the Topix index increasing 0.12% to 1,620.54. The gains were driven by firms showing favorable earnings, but were partially offset by a strong yen.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end July on back foot as earnings sentiment dampens
summary: European stocks ended July on a downtrend as earnings sentiment dampened, with the pan-European STOXX 600 index down 0.1% and euro zone stocks falling 0.3-0.4%. Tobacco stocks and broker downgrades weighed on the market, while mining firms were a boost due to rising copper prices. The European second-quarter earnings season is seen as underwhelming, with 59% of MSCI Europe firms beating or meeting analyst expectations, but consumer goods were the top drag on the benchmark.

site_title: Immigrant population hits new high in Germany
summary: Germany's immigrant population reached a record 18.6 million in 2016, a 8.5% increase, with 22.5% of the population having at least one parent born abroad. This growth is attributed to an increase in refugees, ahead of national elections in September. Chancellor Angela Merkel's challenger warned against a repeat of 2015's migration surge, when hundreds of thousands of migrants arrived.

site_title: Noble Group pays coupon on 2020 bond: market sources
summary: Noble Group, a Singapore-listed commodities trader, has paid the coupon on its 2020 bond, totaling around US$40 million, following asset sales and a potential quarterly loss of up to US$1.8 billion. The payment indicates Noble's ability to service debt, with its shares rising 12% and its 2020 bonds increasing in value. This comes after Noble deferred a payment on its perpetual bonds last month, triggering a sell-off.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks cheered by strong exports data, won edges up
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.1% in early trading on Tuesday, driven by strong exports data showing the longest stretch of expansion in five and a half years. Shipments of memory chips and electronic storage devices led the growth, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index reaching 2,428.44 points. This marks the eighth consecutive month of gains, reinforcing signs of a steady recovery for Asia's fourth-largest economy.

site_title: Any near-term correction in Asian markets is a good entry point
summary: Asian markets have seen a better-than-expected performance in 2017, driven by stronger earnings growth in technology stocks and a recovery in commodity prices. The US dollar bias, fueled by fiscal policy stimulus, is expected to fade as domestic priorities remain unchanged. President Trump's "America First" rhetoric has led to the withdrawal from the Transpacific Partnership and Paris climate agreement, but these actions are seen as a harbinger for the administration's future policies. The market views these decisions as a favorable entry point, with a weakening US dollar and potential for gradual interest rate normalization.

site_title: S&P 500 to exclude Snap after voting rights debate
summary: The S&P 500 will start excluding companies with multiple classes of shares, effectively barring Snap Inc. after its decision to offer stock with no voting rights. The change, effective Tuesday, reflects a tougher stance on corporate governance and takes a step against high-growth tech companies that resist offering full voting rights. Existing S&P index components with multiple share classes will not be affected, and Snap's exclusion may impact funds that track the index, such as the $243 billion SPDR S&P 500 ETF.

site_title: Australia shares upbeat as bank stocks gain, NZ market perks up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Tuesday, with the SS&P/ASX 200 index reaching 5,761 points, driven by a rebound in Commonwealth Bank of Australia and strong commodity prices. Materials stocks, particularly BHP Billiton, also surged. Gold miner Newcrest Mining gained 1.5% as spot gold prices approached seven-week highs. In New Zealand, the S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.2% to 7,710.93, marking its seventh straight monthly gain.

site_title: SPH-backed events startup raises S$0.68m in seed funding
summary: HAPZ, a Singapore-based event-tech startup, has raised S$0.68 million in seed funding led by Cocoon Capital and participated by SPH Media Fund and other investors. The company provides end-to-end services including event discovery, ticket sales, and customer support.

site_title: 1MDB said to have missed US$603m payment to Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund
summary: 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) failed to make a $603 million payment to Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund International Petroleum Investment Co (IPIC) as part of a settlement over a debt dispute. This payment was due on July 31 and is half of the agreed amount. 1MDB and the Malaysian finance ministry agreed to make this payment, with a second payment by the end of 2017. The non-payment may hurt investor sentiment and become a contingent liability for the government.

images.alt_text: 1Malaysia Development Bhd failed to make a US$603 million payment to Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund as part of a settlement over a debt dispute, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.

site_title: US hits 'dictator' Maduro with sanctions over disputed Venezuela vote
summary: The US has imposed direct sanctions on Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, labeling him a "dictator" over a disputed and deadly weekend vote that consolidated his power. The sanctions freeze any US assets Maduro might have and ban people under US jurisdiction from dealing with him. Maduro lashed out at the move, calling it "imperialism." The European Union, Colombia, Mexico, and Peru have also expressed concern over the election results, which appointed a new "Constituent Assembly" superseding Venezuela's legislative body. Maduro's government faces widespread international condemnation, with analysts predicting grave economic consequences and a loss of democracy in Venezuela.

images.alt_text: "Yesterday's illegitimate elections confirm that Maduro is a dictator who disregards the will of the Venezuelan people," US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin (centre) told reporters.

site_title: SBF leads business mission to Manila, Davao City
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) will lead a 22-member delegation to Manila and Davao City from August 1-4 to explore business opportunities. SBF council member and Keppel Corporation Limited CEO Loh Chin Hua will lead the mission, accompanied by International Enterprise (IE) Singapore and the Philippine Trade and Investment Centre. Two forums will be held to discuss the business climate and investment opportunities in the Philippines under its new leadership. The mission aims to foster business relationships and gain insights into the country's business environment.

images.alt_text: Leading the mission is SBF council member and CEO of Keppel Corporation Limited Loh Chin Hua, who also serves as co-chairman of the Philippines-Singapore Business Council (PSBC).

site_title: IMF says Japan needs more work for 'durable' deflation exit
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that Japan's economy needs further structural reform to exit years of deflation. Despite accelerating growth, concerns remain over price movements and public debt. The IMF's comments come as Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Abenomics plan faces a mixed record. The economy's growth has been driven by a stock market rally and increased corporate profits, but more work is needed to achieve a 'durable' exit from deflation.

site_title: What's left of Noble as it retreats to its Asian roots in effort to survive
summary: Noble Group Ltd, a Hong Kong-based commodity trader, is retreating to its Asian roots in a last-ditch effort to survive. The company is selling its North American gas & power unit to Mercuria Energy Group Ltd and seeking buyers for its global oil liquids business, resulting in significant losses of up to $1.8 billion in the second quarter. This move will leave Noble as an Asian trader of coal, iron ore, freight, and liquefied natural gas, with a market value of less than $400 million.

site_title: South Korea to announce fresh housing market measures on Aug 2: lawmaker
summary: South Korea's government is set to announce new measures to curb speculative investments in the housing market, particularly in Seoul, on August 2. Lawmaker Kim Tae-Nyeon stated that the measures will include increasing public housing supplies and targeting those with multiple homes. The aim is to address rising housing prices in Seoul.

site_title: Sony sets record with three-fold jump in Q1 operating profit
summary: Sony reported its highest-ever first-quarter operating profit, increasing 2.8 times to 157.61 billion yen (S$1.94 billion) in April-June. This surpasses the previous record set in 2007. Solid sales of image sensors contributed to the growth. The result exceeded analyst estimates of 129.14 billion yen.

images.alt_text: Japan's Sony Corp on Tuesday reported its highest-ever first-quarter operating profit, taking the electronics giant one step toward its highest annual profit in two decades on the back of solid sales of image sensors.

site_title: Thai ex-PM Yingluck defiant as verdict looms
summary: Thai ex-PM Yingluck Shinawatra is in a defiant mood ahead of her trial for negligence linked to a rice subsidy policy, which could lead to her imprisonment. Her supporters have gathered outside the Supreme Court, and her personal appeal has surged amid her legal troubles. Yingluck's government was toppled by the army in 2014, and she was retroactively impeached. The trial's outcome could impact her future in Thai politics, and her daughter's suspension as PM in an ethics case.

site_title: DBS, Xero launch banking initiative for SMEs
summary: DBS and cloud accounting platform Xero have launched a banking initiative to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore manage their finances more efficiently. The collaboration allows SMEs to instantly connect their DBS business banking accounts to Xero, eliminating the need for manual data entry and reducing the time spent on reconciling bank statements. This new arrangement aims to help SMEs make more informed business decisions, saving them 15.5 hours a month on manual tasks.

images.alt_text: A new arrangement to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) better manage their finances has been launched on Tuesday, DBS and cloud accounting platform Xero announced jointly.

site_title: Abe rallies support for stepped-up sanctions against North Korea
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe held a phone call with US President Donald Trump, seeking international support for stronger sanctions against North Korea following its launch of a new long-range intercontinental ballistic missile. Abe declared that Japan and the US would take concrete actions against North Korea, and the US reaffirmed its commitment to defend Japan and South Korea. China has been criticized for not doing enough to help solve the North Korea crisis, with the US Ambassador to the UN calling on China to back stronger UN sanctions.

site_title: Market cap up 1.5% in July
summary: The Singapore stock market saw a 1.5% monthly rise in July, driven by Catalist counters, with the market capitalisation reaching S$985.7 billion. Notable debuts on Catalist included NetLink Trust, which raised S$2.3 billion in its IPO, the largest since 2011. Meanwhile, OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, was named as Helen Wong's successor, while Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to S$3.1 million.

site_title: South Korea exports surge 20% for ninth straight monthly increase
summary: South Korea's exports surged 20% in July, the ninth consecutive monthly increase, exceeding economists' expectations. The trade surplus reached $10.6 billion, driven by strong global demand. Despite weak consumption, surging exports and investment have supported the nation's economic recovery. However, trade tensions with the US pose a risk, and the government's efforts to boost jobs and wages may be hindered by these tensions. The country's economy is expected to continue its uptrend, with an extra budget approved to sustain the growth.

site_title: 'Wait and see' start to the week
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.23 points to 3,329.52 at the start of the week, with average volume at 2.8 billion units worth S$1.4 billion. The market is in a "wait-and-see" mode following recent global events, including a US interest-rate hike, North Korea's missile test, and political upheaval in Washington. Second-liners, such as Rowsley, were the main play, with Rowsley rising 0.009 points to 0.119 on high volume.

site_title: Raffles Medical's Q2 earnings edge up
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 1% year-on-year growth in Q2 revenue to S$120.1 million, despite softer demand from foreign patients. Operating profit fell 1.9% to S$19.6 million, while net profit increased 0.5% to S$16.8 million. The company registered higher patient load and expanded its network of clinics, with new clinics set to open in Q3. The group's cash position was S$112.4 million as of June 30, and an interim dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent per share was announced.

site_title: Number of fintech deals in Q2 continues to decline in Singapore: KPMG
summary: Fintech investment in Singapore rose to US$61.5 million in Q2, despite a decline in the number of deals closed. KPMG attributes the decline to a shift towards partnership-oriented models. Variability in deal volume is common in developing venture ecosystems like Asia, according to the report.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Technics Oil and Gas receives SGX approval for time extension
summary: TECHNICS Oil and Gas received approval from the Singapore Exchange to extend its time to comply with judicial management orders. The company was initially set to be discharged on July 20, 2017, but can now delay until January 20, 2018. This extension allows for the release of financial statements for the 2016 financial year and subsequent years. The company also received an extension to hold its annual general meeting for the 2016 financial year and subsequent years.

site_title: Rolls-Royce first-half profit rises as it steps up production
summary: Rolls-Royce reported a 148% increase in underlying pretax profit to £287 million in the first half of 2017, driven by a 27% increase in large civil aerospace engines. Revenue rose 6% to £6.87 billion, with the company achieving restructuring savings ahead of plan. The company aims to double production of its large civil aircraft engines, targeting half of the market by 2020, following a two-year restructuring program.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks boosted by strong exports, won weaker
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.8% on Tuesday, boosted by strong exports growth, which has supported the domestic economy and corporate profits. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed at 2,422.96 points. Local institutions purchased 180.8 billion won worth of Kospi shares, offsetting foreign investors selling 36.4 billion won.

site_title: BP sees oil prices below US$50 a barrel in 2018
summary: BP expects global oil prices to remain between US$45-$50 a barrel in 2018 due to growing US shale production, which will cap prices. Global demand is forecast to grow 1.4-1.5 million barrels per day, and Brent crude oil prices are expected to average around US$45-$50 a barrel, with prices firming around current levels. This is despite the company's earlier second-quarter profit drop due to an exploration write-off in Angola.

site_title: Banks must face class action over interest rate swaps: US judge
summary: A US judge has ruled that 11 of the world's biggest banks, including Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase, must defend against claims that they conspired to rig the US$275 trillion interest rate swaps market by boycotting upstart electronic platforms. The judge dismissed claims against HSBC and said the complaint by investors had "rife with specifics" about alleged collusion. The banks are accused of preserving their 70% market share and boosting profits by making trading more costly. The case is part of a nationwide antitrust lawsuit accusing the banks of conspiring to rig the derivatives market.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.2 per cent down on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 0.2% lower on Tuesday, shedding 6.13 points to 3,323.39, following mixed US markets overnight. The Dow jumped to a fourth straight record close, while the Nasdaq retreated due to sharp declines in Amazon and Tesla. Despite this, about 61.4 million shares worth S$61.5 million changed hands, with Swee Hong being the most actively traded counter.

site_title: Mood brightens for services sector, softens for manufacturing
summary: Business sentiment in Singapore's services sector turned positive for the first time in seven quarters, with a net weighted balance of 5% of firms expecting more favorable business conditions in the second half of 2017. The manufacturing sector, however, showed a slight decline in optimism. The biomedical manufacturing cluster was the most upbeat within the sector, with a net weighted balance of 14%. Overall, economists expect a slight boost in business activity and hiring in the services sector, with headline GDP growth prospects tilting to the higher end of the 2-3% forecast range.

images.alt_text: Within the services sector, food and beverage services (net weighted balance of 41 per cent) are the most bullish about their business prospects for July to December 2017.

site_title: Oil sceptics pull out as market dispels gloom to flirt with US$50
summary: Oil prices have surged, flirting with $50 a barrel, as pessimism dissipates. Hedge funds, the most bullish about West Texas Intermediate crude in three months, increased their net-long position by 11% to 238,501 futures and options. Short-sellers are exiting, with shorts slipping 22% and standing at less than half their June level. US oil stockpiles fell to the lowest since January, and producers are slashing spending plans. Analysts expect the market to continue its rebound, with WTI closing at $49.71 a barrel, nearing $50 and above its 200-day moving average.

site_title: New Zealand opposition leader quits as election looms
summary: New Zealand's opposition leader, Andrew Little, quit as Labour Party leader just weeks before the September 23 general election, citing disappointing opinion polls that saw the party's support plunge to 20-year lows. Little stepped down immediately, backing his deputy Jacinda Ardern for the role. The National Party-led coalition, led by Prime Minister Bill English, comfortably leads in the polls and is seeking a fourth term.

site_title: Clooneys to help 3,000 Syrian refugees go to school in Lebanon
summary: George and Amal Clooney announced a $3.25 million donation to help 3,000 Syrian refugee children attend school in Lebanon through the "second shift" system, which provides additional afternoon classes exclusively for Syrian children. The Clooney Foundation for Justice, Google, and HP Inc are partnering with UNICEF and the Lebanese Ministry of Education to establish seven schools. The effort aims to prevent the loss of a generation due to lack of education and provide a chance for Syrian refugees to become productive members of society.

site_title: US dollar inches up from 2-1/2 year low vs euro; focus on US data
summary: The US dollar edged up from a 2-1/2 year low against the euro, reaching $1.1828, due to month-end portfolio adjustments and expectations for a hawkish European Central Bank. However, US political turmoil and doubts about another Federal Reserve rate hike this year continue to cloud the dollar's outlook. The euro is expected to remain higher, but may take a breather against the dollar as investors focus on US economic data this week.

site_title: Australia dollar firm in the face of RBA unease, NZ$ steady
summary: The Australian dollar remained steady on Tuesday, despite the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) warning that its strength could harm the economy. The Aussie rose 0.4% to US$0.8030, rebounding from a dip, while the New Zealand dollar also held steady at US$0.7511. The RBA left interest rates at 1.5% and downplayed the chance of a rate cut, citing concerns over a debt-driven housing bubble. Meanwhile, commodity prices, including iron ore, surged due to a weaker US dollar and improving economic news in China and Europe.

site_title: China e-commerce giants court luxury retailers with delivery
summary: China's e-commerce giants, such as Alibaba and JD.com, are courting luxury retailers to offer upscale services, including white-glove delivery, to attract high-end customers. The companies aim to capitalize on China's vast online shopping market, where consumers are increasingly turning to e-commerce for luxury purchases. Despite concerns about counterfeit and grey-market items, luxury brands are starting to invest in online platforms, with Burberry and Chow Tai Fook already selling on JD.com and Alibaba's Tmall. The goal is to replicate the in-store shopping experience online and tap into China's lucrative luxury market.

site_title: Swiber Holdings will default on upcoming coupon payment
summary: Swiber Holdings, a Singapore-listed offshore and marine group, will default on its upcoming coupon payment of S$150 million for its 6.5% trust certificates due 2018. The company has been under judicial management since October 2016 and has been granted an extension until October 21 to send a statement of proposals to creditors. This is the latest setback for the beleaguered company, which has been struggling financially.

site_title: 13 Holdings misses deadline to open Macau luxury hotel
summary: 13 Holdings Ltd, a developer of a luxury hotel in Macau, missed its deadline to open the hotel, which was a condition of a HK$3 billion loan from Bank of Communications Co. The project, valued at US$1.6 billion, aims to open before the end of the year, with 200 villas and 24-hour butler service. The company's shares dropped 2.9% after the announcement, amid concerns over the project's viability due to a downturn in the high-end market and changes in central government policy.

site_title: Heineken earnings bubble amid warm weather
summary: Heineken, a Dutch brewing giant, reported a 48.6% surge in first-half profits to 871m euros, driven by warm weather in Europe and its new zero-alcohol brand. Beer sales were boosted, while the company expressed optimism about its new product.

site_title: US: Dow ends at 4th straight record; Nasdaq dips
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended at a record high for the fourth straight session, closing at 21,891.12, while the Nasdaq Composite Index declined 0.4% due to sharp losses in tech stocks like Amazon and Tesla Motors. The S&P 500 slipped 0.1% to 2,470.30, despite the broader market reaching fresh records.

site_title: North Korea ICBM still facing technical hurdles: US expert
summary: North Korea's intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) development is nearing completion, with a US expert warning that the country could field a nuclear-capable missile capable of striking the US by next year. Despite recent tests showing the potential range to hit Alaska and possibly the US West Coast, technical hurdles remain, including a failed re-entry vehicle during the second test. Experts believe Pyongyang is learning quickly, with some assessments suggesting deployment by late this year or early next year is possible.

site_title: UK minister to meet Silicon Valley over online extremism
summary: Britain's interior minister Amber Rudd will meet with tech leaders in Silicon Valley to combat online extremism, following deadly terror attacks in London and Manchester. The government wants internet companies to develop tools to identify and remove harmful material, block users who post extremist content, and alert authorities. The move comes as the threat of extremist content shifts from the battlefield to the internet, with the Islamic State group losing ground in Iraq and Syria. Rudd's meeting aims to pressure social media sites and web giants to take action.

images.alt_text: Britain's interior minister Amber Rudd will meet with tech leaders in California's Silicon Valley this week to try and combat online content inciting extremism, the government said Monday.

site_title: Banks may be hit with US$50b capital needs after Brexit
summary: Banks may need an additional US$30 billion to US$50 billion in capital to support new European units following a hard Brexit, equivalent to 15% to 30% of current capital commitments, according to a report by Oliver Wyman Inc. Operating costs could also rise by US$1 billion as functions are duplicated on the continent. A hard Brexit would fragment the European wholesale-banking market, according to the report.

images.alt_text: The pressure for banks to boost their operations on the continent will likely build as the European Central Bank's desire for tougher banking supervision across the euro zone forces lenders to show they're self-sufficient and have strong governance, according to the report.

site_title: Japan's Aso says Tokyo to discuss frozen beef import tariffs in talks with US
summary: Japan's finance minister, Taro Aso, stated that Tokyo will discuss frozen beef import tariffs in talks with the US later this year. Japan recently increased tariffs on frozen beef imports from the US and other countries to 50% from 38.5% due to concerns over domestic farmers. The move was a "safeguard" mechanism, set to expire next March, unless the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal is implemented. Aso acknowledged US agriculture secretary's concerns and hinted at potential discussions on extending the tariff review period.

site_title: Greenpac's innovative packaging promotes sustainability
summary: Singapore-based company Greenpac, founded by CEO Susan Chong in 2002, specializes in innovative and environmentally friendly packaging solutions. The company helps industry reduce waste and promote sustainability through its re-engineered packaging processes. Greenpac has received various prestigious certifications and awards, including the WorldStar Packaging Award and Singapore Quality Award. The company's mission is to partner customers to create sustainable packaging solutions that achieve bottomline savings and boost supply chain efficiency. With its focus on sustainability, Greenpac aims to become a leader in the industry and contribute to a sustainable future economy.

images.alt_text: Ms Chong says that with Greenpac's installation of solar panels, the energy harvest powers up the premises and makes it a zero-energy office.
Ms Chong says that with Greenpac's installation of solar panels, the energy harvest powers up the premises and makes it a zero-energy office.

site_title: Oil at two-month high, ends above US$50 a barrel
summary: Oil prices rose to two-month highs, ending the strongest month of the year for crude futures, driven by US sanctions against Venezuela's oil sector and reduced supply concerns. Brent crude settled at $52.65 a barrel, while US light crude rose 1% to $50.17 a barrel. Opec and non-Opec members will meet on August 7-8 to assess production cuts. US crude inventories have fallen 10% from March peaks, but shale production remains strong.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose to two-month highs on Monday, ending the strongest month of the year for crude futures, boosted in part by expectations of US sanctions against Venezuela's oil sector and as supply concerns have waned in recent weeks.

site_title: Panasonic's Q1 gets boost from motoring sector
summary: Panasonic reported quarterly gains in profits and sales, driven by its vehicles-related sector. The Osaka-based company is shifting focus from electronics to other sectors, including energy and vehicles. This strong performance confirms Panasonic's recovery.

site_title: MAS clarifies regulatory position on offer of digital tokens in Singapore
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) clarified its regulatory position on digital tokens, stating they will be regulated if they constitute products under the Securities and Futures Act. Digital tokens are defined as cryptographically-secured representations of rights to receive benefits or perform functions, while virtual currencies are a type of digital token functioning as a medium of exchange. MAS aims to regulate money laundering and terrorist financing risks associated with digital tokens, requiring issuers to lodge prospectuses and comply with anti-money laundering and countering terrorist financing regulations.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) clarified on Tuesday that the offer or issue of digital tokens in Singapore will be regulated by the central bank if the digital tokens constitute products regulated under the Securities and Futures Act (Cap. 289) (SFA).
Angela Tan

site_title: US, North Korea to ease tensions, not China: diplomat
summary: US and North Korea are set to ease tensions, with the US and Pyongyang bearing primary responsibility for reducing tensions, according to China's UN ambassador Liu Jieyi. The US and North Korea have been engaged in a series of military actions, including US strategic bomber flights and North Korea's ICBM tests. China, North Korea's main trade partner and ally, has urged both sides to avoid exacerbating the situation. The US has imposed sanctions on North Korea, and China has urged dialogue, but Beijing insists that dualogue is the only practical way forward.

site_title: Global Yellow Pages restructures business; retrenches workers
summary: Global Yellow Pages Limited announced plans to restructure its business, focusing on real estate as its core business and ceasing print directory publication from 2018. The company will retrench workers but no figures were disclosed. A joint venture agreement with NewCo will handle digital directories, data, and online offerings. This restructuring aims to make the business more resilient and allow the group to participate in the growth of NewCo and PAH, its real estate-focused subsidiary.

images.alt_text: Stanley Tan, CEO and director of Global Yellow Pages, said: "With this painful but necessary revamp of our Yellow Pages business model and the group gaining increasing traction in property, we are building a business that is significantly more resilient; and we will continue to seek opportunities to further add value to the group."

site_title: Olympics: LA agrees to host 2028 Games, Paris set for 2024
summary: Los Angeles has formally announced its intent to host the 2028 Summer Olympics, agreeing to a deal with the International Olympic Committee (IOC) that paves the way for Paris to host in 2024. The "win-win-win" agreement includes a US$1.8 billion IOC contribution and the potential for additional funds from sponsor agreements and marketing deals. The Los Angeles City Council and United States Olympic Committee must still approve the agreement, with a decision expected in August. The IOC will confirm the host cities at its September 13 meeting in Lima, Peru.

site_title: Singtel, CapitaLand Mall Trust rank top in corporate governance
summary: Singtel topped the Singapore Governance and Transparency Index (SGTI) in the General Category, while CapitaLand Mall Trust ranked first in the Reit and Business Trust Category. The index, assessing corporate governance disclosure and practices, saw an all-time high average score of 52.3 in the General Category, up 2.6 points from 2016. However, room for improvement remains, particularly in stakeholder engagement, anti-corruption programs, and investor relations.

site_title: Bank lending's uptrend seen being sustained in H2
summary: Bank lending in Singapore rose 6% in the first half of 2017, reversing a 1.4% contraction in the same period last year, according to preliminary data. Loans through domestic banking units stood at S$636 billion in June, with business loans rising 10.4% and consumer loans increasing 3.7%. Analysts expect the growth momentum to sustain into the second half, with a forecast of 7% average annual growth for the full year, driven by improving domestic business sentiments and regional manufacturing and services PMIs.

images.alt_text: Bank lending in Singapore may sustain its momentum into the second half of the year amid an improving economic outlook.

site_title: New appointments in JTC, EDB, URA
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry and Ministry of National Development announced new appointments, including Ng Lang as CEO of JTC, effective Sept 1, and Chng Kai Fong as MD of EDB, effective Oct 1. Lim Eng Hwee will be appointed as CEO of URA on Sept 1, and Hwang Yu-Ning will serve as Acting Deputy CEO and chief planner, URA, from Oct 1. These changes will take effect on the specified dates, with current leaders stepping down or transitioning to new roles.

site_title: South Korea July inflation accelerates to 4-month high on fresh food costs
summary: South Korea's inflation accelerated to a 4-month high in July, rising 2.2% on-year, driven by soaring fresh food costs. The benchmark inflation index surpassed the median estimate of 2.1% and was the fastest rise since March. Consumer sentiment improved for a sixth straight month, reaching a six and a half-year high. However, economist Stephen Lee predicts inflation could slow again soon due to domestic demand improvement and potential slowing fresh food price increases.

images.alt_text: South Korean inflation accelerated to its fastest in four months on soaring fresh food costs and as consumer confidence improved in July.

site_title: Asian shares tick up as investors look for proof of 'goldilocks'
summary: Asian shares rose, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific index up 0.1% and Tokyo's Nikkei up 0.4%, as investors await economic data for signs of a 'goldilocks' global economy. US inflation softened, prompting expectations of a patient approach by the Federal Reserve. The dollar slipped to a 1-1/2-month low, while the euro gained 15% against the US dollar since January. Oil prices hit two-month highs due to US sanctions on Venezuela's oil sector.

site_title: HK home prices climb 0.69% in June to hit new peak
summary: Hong Kong's home prices rose 0.69% in June to a new peak, with prices increasing 21.6% from last year, making ownership a distant dream for many residents. The city's new leader, Carrie Lam, has pledged to make home prices more affordable, but analysts expect prices to continue to rise, albeit at a slower pace, and the government may impose further tightening measures. This comes amid concerns over income inequality and the impact on daily life, with Chinese President Xi Jinping also voicing concern over the city's property market.

site_title: Asahi Kasei expands capacity of Singapore synthetic rubber plant
summary: Asahi Kasei Chemicals is expanding the production capacity of its Singapore synthetic rubber plant from 100,000 tonnes to 130,000 tonnes a year, making it the group's largest S-SBR manufacturing site globally. The expansion aims to meet growing demand for tyres with enhanced fuel efficiency, driven by increasing motorization and environmental regulations. The project is expected to be completed by January 2019 and reflects Singapore's strategic importance as a gateway to Asia, according to the Economic Development Board.

site_title: Scotland just made it harder for Trump to expand golf empire
summary: Scotland's Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA) and Scottish Natural Heritage (SNH) have objected to the Trump Organization's expansion plan for its golf course, citing concerns over sewage, environmental protection, and groundwater conservation. The agency wants the company to connect the course and clubhouse to the public sewage system and pay for using public water supplies. The expansion plan is seen as crucial for the project's financial success, but officials are demanding significant changes before approving it.

site_title: China factory activity gathers steam in July: Caixin
summary: China's manufacturing activity surged in July, with the Caixin Purchasing Manager's Index reaching a four-month high of 51.1, up from 50.4 in June. The increase in production and new orders growth suggests sustained economic growth momentum, but analysts warn of a slowdown due to policy tightening and increasing financial regulatory headwinds. Experts caution that the growth momentum may not be sustainable, with some predicting a slowdown in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: China's manufacturing activity increased last month as both production and new order rates grew rapidly, independent figures showed Tuesday, but analysts warned the economy still faces headwinds from policy tightening.

site_title: India is said to block Fosun's US$1.3b Gland Pharma purchase
summary: India is set to block a $1.3 billion takeover of Gland Pharma by Shanghai Fosun Pharmaceutical Group Co, citing concerns amid escalating tensions between India and China. The decision, made by the Cabinet Committee on Economic Affairs chaired by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, comes as a major setback for the largest-ever Chinese acquisition in the country. The move is seen as a response to China's recent actions in the Himalayas, which have strained relations between the two nations.

site_title: TungLok expands overseas, woos younger diners in Singapore
summary: TungLok Restaurants, a Singapore-based Chinese restaurant chain, is expanding overseas, focusing on younger diners in Singapore and other markets. The company has opened its second Singapore Seafood by TungLok in Beijing and plans to roll out more quick-service restaurants and casual dining concepts in Singapore. TungLok aims to increase its services beyond food and beverage outlets, offering consultancy services and leveraging technology to promote productivity. The company has achieved a successful turnaround and strengthened its balance sheet, with a gearing ratio of 0.21 times.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 4.36 points to 1,764.39. Volume reached 66.6 million lots worth RM25.9 million, with 92 gainers outnumbering 45 losers.

site_title: Gum disease linked to higher cancer risk in women: study
summary: A US study published in Cancer Epidemiology, Biomarkers and Prevention found that women with a history of gum disease are at a higher risk of several types of cancer, including esophageal, lung, gallbladder, melanoma, and breast cancer. Researchers discovered a 14% increased risk of any cancer and a significantly higher risk of esophageal cancer, which was three times more likely in women with periodontal disease. The study suggests a link between gum disease and increased cancer risk, highlighting the importance of maintaining good oral health.

site_title: Many 'firsts' at the Award's 12th year
summary: The 12th Singapore Corporate Awards recognized excellence in corporate disclosures and governance, with several "firsts" recorded. DBS won top awards for Best Managed Board and Best Annual Report, while Singtel's Chua Sock Koong became the first woman to win Best CEO in the large-cap category. Other notable winners included Indofood Agri Resources' Mark Wakeford and Sunningdale Tech's Khoo Boo Hor for Best CEO in mid- and small-cap categories, respectively. The awards honored achievements in corporate governance and leadership.

site_title: S$12,500 raised for BT Budding Artists' Fund from Fashion Cows
summary: Singaporean organizations adopted five Fashion Cows as part of celebrations for 50 years of diplomatic relations between Singapore and Switzerland. The event raised S$12,500 for The Business Times Budding Artists' Fund, which supports young people from financially disadvantaged families in arts training. Ambassador Thomas Kupfer presented the Fashion Cows, and MP Liang Eng Hwa officiated the event alongside him. The funds will be used to nurture artistic talents of children aged six to nine.

site_title: Australia home prices jump anew in July, testing regulators
summary: Australia's major cities saw a 1.5% surge in home prices in July, driven by a 3.1% increase in Melbourne, with annual growth reaching 10.5%. This marks a return towards the peak of 12.9% set early in the year. Despite regulators' efforts to cool the market through tighter rules on leveraged investors, prices continue to rise, testing the attempts to curb debt-fuelled speculation.

site_title: New train service to replace S'pore-JB shuttle by 2024
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have agreed on a new train service, the Rapid Transit System (RTS) Link, to replace the current shuttle service between Singapore and Johor Baru by December 31, 2024. The line will carry up to 10,000 passengers per hour and improve transport connectivity between the two countries. Both governments have selected local metro operators to form a joint venture company to run and maintain the line's operating systems. The daily shuttle train service will cease operating after the RTS Link opens, and officials expect to sign a bilateral agreement on the cross-border line by the end of this year.

site_title: Armed robbery at Western Union branch in Ubi; suspect at large, no one injured
summary: An armed robbery occurred at a Western Union branch in Ubi, Singapore on August 1, 2017, at 10:50am. The suspect is at large, but no one was injured in the incident.

site_title: US now the hot spot for tech outsourcing
summary: The US is experiencing a resurgence in tech outsourcing, with companies like Nexient and Catalyte hiring developers in the same time zone to improve collaboration and efficiency. Rising salaries in South Asia have made outsourcing less cost-effective, while brands prioritize having developers in the same continent for better communication and project management. Domestic outsourcers are thriving, with IBM announcing plans to hire 25,000 US workers in the next four years, and analysts predicting rapid growth for onshore companies. The shift is driven by the need for nimble teams to create mobile apps and websites that require close collaboration with businesses and customers.

images.alt_text: Employees at the Techtonic Group in Boulder, Colorado. Once a committed offshore outsourcer, Techtonic has made nurturing homegrown talent the centrepiece of its business.

site_title: Hong Kong regulator scrutinises private funds, discretionary accounts
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) has launched an investigation into private equity funds and discretionary accounts with "irregular features" amid concerns over market misconduct. The regulator found concentrated, illiquid, and interconnected investments, including related-party acquisition and disposal of listed company shares. SFC executive director Julia Leung warned that asset managers will face action if they fail to comply with regulatory requirements and turn a blind eye to dubious arrangements. The move comes weeks after Hong Kong's second board hit record lows due to market scandals.

images.alt_text: "If private funds or discretionary accounts are found to be used to fund or conceal improper activities at the expense of investors, the SFC will not hesitate to take action against the asset managers and their senior management for failing to comply with regulatory requirements," said Julia Leung, the SFC's executive director of the Intermediaries Division.

site_title: 300 employers adopt leave, training benefits for term contract workers
summary: Nearly 300 Singaporean employers have adopted the Tripartite Standard, providing term contract workers with leave benefits and termination notice periods based on their cumulative length of service. The standard, rolled out on Monday, aims to improve employment practices and provide more inclusive benefits for term contract staff. Employers must recognize cumulative service when calculating leave entitlements and provide fair notice periods for early termination. The move is part of a push for progressive employment practices and aims to address concerns about term contract workers' lack of benefits and job security.

images.alt_text: Mrs Teo: "Third, and perhaps most significant of all, while the (current) term contract arrangement serves the employers well, they don't always serve the employees well."

site_title: Jive to java hotspots at this year's Coffee Festival
summary: The Singapore Coffee Festival (SCF) 2017 will take place at the Marina Bay Cruise Centre from August 3-6. The festival features 90 exhibitors, including coffee purveyors, equipment distributors, and cafes, offering various activities, workshops, and live entertainment. Highlights include "Coffee with the Boss" sessions, an interactive quiz, and a social enterprise market. The event also includes a lounge with activities such as an omakase experience, a recycling station, and a barter market.

site_title: Myanmar making steady progress in long game of economic development
summary: Myanmar's new government has made steady progress in economic development since taking office last year, following the country's first free and fair elections in over 50 years. The government aims to build a prosperous economy for all, with the right type of growth transforming the country into an inclusive society.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific's Q2 profit down 26% at S$14.7m
summary: Singapore property firm Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported a 26% decline in Q2 net profit to S$14.7m, due to weaker sales and revenue falling 21% to S$77.8m. The company attributed the decline to lower revenue recognition from completed projects and lower revenue per available room from its hotel segment. However, its expansion into Australia is expected to contribute positively to profits upon completion.

site_title: BRICS makes a case for globalisation
summary: The BRICS group of nations, comprising Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, is pushing for greater trade and investment to promote economic globalisation. China, a key driver of this agenda, aims to increase the bloc's influence in the face of rising protectionism, particularly from the Trump administration. The BRICS has accounted for 23% of global GDP and 16% of world trade, with China's economy now larger than the US on a purchasing power parity basis. The bloc's collective growth and large populations have lifted hundreds of millions of people out of poverty, contributing to a decline in global income inequality.

site_title: London megasubway could hit a Brexit bump
summary: London's US$20 billion Crossrail project, Europe's largest infrastructure project, is nearing completion despite uncertainty surrounding Brexit. The high-speed train line, which aims to cut travel times across the city by over half, may face reduced demand if the UK's economic prospects worsen. With the pound losing value and inflation rising, some companies are planning to move employees out of London. The project's completion may be hindered by the government's decision to pay half the cost upfront, and Brexit's impact on the UK's financial sector and connectivity to Europe.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Tuesday as earnings season picked up, with the Nikkei 225 index closing 0.30% higher at 19,985.79. Despite a strong yen, investors took heart from rising company profits. The Topix index also rose 0.61% to 1,628.50. This uptick in Tokyo stocks follows a 5-day rally in Singapore and fresh records in the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: Super penthouse at Sculptura Ardmore sold for over S$60m
summary: A super penthouse at Sculptura Ardmore in Singapore has sold for over S$60 million, with a price of more than S$6,000 per square foot. The 10,300 sq ft unit, located on levels 35 and 36, is the highest point in Ardmore Park and offers unparalleled privacy. The sale price surpasses the S$51 million paid by Alibaba co-founder Sun Tongyu for the sole penthouse at Le Nouvel Ardmore in 2015. This deal sets a record for the highest price ever achieved in the Ardmore Park locale.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Hot and cold: Eurozone grows but inflation falls
summary: The eurozone economy is expected to continue growing, with the IMF upgrading forecasts, following Greece's return to the debt market. However, inflation figures may slow down the European Central Bank's plans to tighten policy. The eurozone's growth outpaced the US and Britain in the first quarter, and the pace remained strong in the April-June period. Despite this, inflation concerns may temper ECB plans, as the single currency area's growth outstripped those of the US and Britain.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: OKP Holdings reported a net profit of S$4.95 million for its second quarter, doubling from a year ago, with revenue rising 43.2% to S$34.4 million. Heatec Jietong issued a profit warning due to a loss on liquidation of a subsidiary and lower work orders. IHH Healthcare acquired a 55% stake in Angsana Holdings for S$9.3 million. SPH Reit appointed Ng Yat Chung as a non-independent director, effective August 1, 2017.

site_title: 'Monkey Bikes' near extinction as Japan cuts tailpipe emissions
summary: Japan's motorcycle market is facing a significant decline with the retirement of iconic 50cc models, known as "Monkey Bikes," due to stricter emissions regulations. Honda, Yamaha, and Suzuki will phase out the small engines, which have been the backbone of Japan's estimated $1.5 billion motorcycle market. The decline in sales has been steady, with a 94% drop in 50cc bike sales last year, and manufacturers are turning to electrification as an alternative. The 50cc motorbike is an iconic part of Japanese motorcycle manufacturing, but its future looks uncertain.

site_title: Home-grown Clearbridge Medical Group opens first centre in Hong Kong
summary: Singapore-based Clearbridge Medical Group (CBMG) opened its first centre in Hong Kong, marking its regional expansion. The centre, part of Clearbridge Health, offers clinical patient care and precision medical technologies. This move is the company's first step overseas, following its success in Singapore with Clearbridge BioMedics.

images.alt_text: Singapore-based Clearbridge Medical Group (CBMG), whose parent company is also behind acclaimed Singapore medical start-up Clearbridge BioMedics, opened its first centre in Hong Kong on Friday as part of its regional expansion.

site_title: Exxon misses estimates as international production suffers
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp reported earnings that fell short of analyst estimates, with a US$10 billion loss in market value, due to a partial shutdown of a Dutch natural gas field and lingering effects of Canadian forest fires. The company's oil and gas production dropped by almost one percent, and profit from chemical plants fell 19 percent. Exxon's full-year drilling budget is expected to be shaved by 26 percent as the company prioritizes cash conservation amid a stagnant crude market.

site_title: Hong Kong opens higher, Shanghai flat
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.39% to 27,431.5, following a record close on Wall Street. Shanghai's benchmark index edged up 0.15% to 3,278.03, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.10%. The gains came despite uncertainty over US-China trade talks and new Trump threats.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Global Yellow Pages, Soilbuild, Roxy-Pacific, OKP Holdings
summary: Global Yellow Pages to restructure its business, focusing on real estate, and cease print directory publication from 2018. Soilbuild Construction Group reported a 70% fall in net profit to S$0.6 million for Q2. Roxy-Pacific Holdings' net profit tumbled 26% to S$14.7 million. OKP Holdings' second-quarter net profit doubled to S$4.95 million.

site_title: The great corn clash is coming as US and Brazil farmers face off
summary: US and Brazilian farmers are preparing for a competition in the global corn market, with Brazil's production forecast to surge 45% in 2016-17. The US is the world's biggest grower and exporter, but Brazilian exports are expected to rise, potentially squeezing US market share. Ample supplies and shifting weather patterns have led to a decline in US corn futures, but hedge funds are positioning for gains. The US is expected to remain the world's top supplier, but Brazil's success depends on factors such as local prices and the size of the US harvest.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages have issued updates on three Singapore-listed companies: Sembcorp Marine, iFast Corp, and CDL Hospitality Trusts. Sembcorp Marine has cut its target price to S$1.55 due to weaker-than-expected performance in H1 2017, while iFast Corp has been upgraded to a "buy" with a target price of S$1.26. CDL Hospitality Trusts has maintained its "buy" call with a target price of S$1.70, citing a potential recovery in the hospitality sector in 2018.

site_title: Eight China provinces report slower growth
summary: China's regional economies are experiencing divergence, with eight provinces reporting slower growth in the first half of the year. Despite the nation's overall 6.9% growth pace, regions like Tianjin and Liaoning struggled, with Tianjin's cooling property market and Liaoning's overcapacity in heavy industries contributing to the slowdown. In contrast, provinces like Shanxi, Hebei, and Xinjiang saw significant growth, driven by industrialization and infrastructure investments. Policymakers are increasingly focusing on environmental protection and debt management, potentially altering the competitive landscape among provinces.

site_title: RBI governor may try to spur growth with rate call
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is expected to lower the repurchase rate to 6% from 6.25% in a bid to spur growth, according to economists. This move would mark a U-turn from just six months ago and bring the benchmark rate to its lowest since 2010. The decision is seen as a response to India's record-low inflation and the impact of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's currency reforms last year.

site_title: New Wells Fargo scandal seen as proof controls still lacking
summary: Wells Fargo's disclosure of potentially pushing thousands of car buyers into loan defaults and repossessions due to unwanted insurance charges has raised concerns about the bank's ability to implement proper controls. Analysts, including Isaac Boltansky, are expressing worry about the extent of internal control failures, which could impact both Washington and Wall Street. This latest revelation adds to the bank's history of scandals, fueling doubts about its ability to effectively manage its operations and maintain regulatory compliance.

site_title: Didi Chuxing announces tie-up with Uber's European rival Taxify
summary: Didi Chuxing, a Chinese ride-sharing firm, announced a strategic partnership with Taxify, an Estonian company with 2.5 million users in 18 European and African countries. The deal aims to support Taxify's growth and make it the top transport option in Europe and Africa. Didi, which has over 400 million users, will invest and collaborate with Taxify, with no disclosed investment amount. This partnership marks a significant move by Didi to expand its presence in Europe and Africa.

site_title: Google accused of gaining sensitive consumer data via secret formula
summary: Google's new advertising program, Store Sales Measurement, ties online behavior to in-store purchases, gaining access to 70% of US consumers' credit- and debit-card records. The Electronic Privacy Information Center (Epic) is asking the FTC to investigate, alleging Google's secrecy and lack of transparency in collecting and protecting this sensitive data. The group claims Google's method, based on CryptDB, has known security flaws and is vulnerable to hacks. Google denies any wrongdoing, stating it has custom encryption technology to protect user data, but Epic demands a review of the algorithm itself.

site_title: Tech advances will lead to MH370 discovery: Malaysia Airlines
summary: Malaysia Airlines' CEO Peter Bellew says advances in technology, including artificial intelligence and high-capacity computing, will eventually lead to the discovery of MH370's resting place. The Boeing 777 disappeared in 2014 with 239 people on board, and despite a lengthy search, no wreckage has been found. Bellew notes that private efforts and new research could unlock closure for some people, and Australia's CSIRO believes MH370 is likely lying north of the former search zone. A second set of data on the sea floor's topography will be released in mid-2018.

site_title: China bond buyers quiz taxi drivers to access credit rating
summary: China's corporate bond market is experiencing a boom in field trips by market participants as investors do due diligence on issuers due to the potential for bond defaults. Since the start of last year, 45 onshore corporate bonds have defaulted, up from eight in 2014 and 2015. Investors are taking a more hands-on approach, visiting local places such as restaurants and talking to taxi drivers to gather information on issuers. This approach is in contrast to the ease of access to information in foreign markets, where issuers often proactively communicate with investors.

site_title: China visitors fuel rise in tourists, jump in spending
summary: Singapore's tourism sector experienced a 15% year-on-year growth in the first quarter, driven by a 4% increase in arrivals to 4.3 million, outpacing the rise in tourism receipts. Chinese travelers accounted for the largest spend, increasing by 30% to S$1.08 billion, followed by Indonesia and India. The Singapore Tourism Board attributes the growth to its marketing strategy targeting top source markets and expanding focus to Tier 2 cities.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Novena Global headed for Taiwan listing to raise US$150m
summary: Novena Global Lifecare Group, a Singapore-based healthcare firm, plans to list on the Taipei Exchange to raise US$150 million, its fourth IPO outside Singapore in four months. The funds will be used to grow organically and through acquisitions. The move aims to cater to "affluent Asians" seeking healthy living and anti-aging treatments.

images.alt_text: Founded six years ago by cousins and former investment bankers Nelson (right) and Terence Loh, Novena Global Lifecare Group (Novena) is the largest medical aesthetic chain in Singapore, with 15 clinics and a database of over 150,000 patients.

site_title: Perennial-led consortium may put AXA Tower on the market
summary: A consortium led by Perennial Real Estate Holdings Limited is considering an en bloc sale of AXA Tower in Singapore for at least S$1.65 billion, translating to S$2,150 per square foot. The sale price is based on the total strata area of 767,358 sq ft after an asset enhancement initiative.

site_title: French film legend Jeanne Moreau dies at 89
summary: French film legend Jeanne Moreau has died at 89, leaving behind a legacy of critically-acclaimed films and a trailblazing spirit. She starred in iconic movies such as Jules et Jim and Lift to the Scaffold, and was known for her daring and tomboy charm. A feminist icon and recipient of numerous lifetime achievement awards, Moreau continued acting late in life, appearing in over 130 films over six decades. French President Emmanuel Macron hailed her as a "free spirit" who "embodied cinema".

images.alt_text: Moreau at a photocall at the 61st Cannes International Film Festival in 2008. Neither pretty nor plain, like a trick of the light her features could range in an instant from radiance to lassitude, from gaiety to sullenness.

site_title: ITCAN is making a name in competitive IT field
summary: ITCAN Pte Ltd, a tech consulting company, is making a name in the competitive IT field by upholding innovation and applying new best practices. Founded by CEO Amit Sujan in 2004, the company has achieved an average annual growth rate of 30% and serves 480 clients globally, including financial institutions, telecoms, and healthcare providers. ITCAN's unique business model and emphasis on employee empowerment, with personalized targets and unlimited salary increments, have contributed to its success. The company's mantra, EVER (Encourage innovation, Value teamwork, Empower team leads, and Reward performance), has fostered a collaborative and motivated workforce.

images.alt_text: "I don't think ITCAN is successful only because of me, but primarily because of the foundations and policies we have been building over the years and the philosophy of taking care of people," says Mr Sujan.

site_title: Togs that empower women
summary: Singapore-based womenswear label Love, Bonito has experienced rapid growth since its inception in 2010, with profits reaching 25-30% annual growth. Founded by childhood friends Rachel Lim, Viola Tan, and Velda Tan, the brand has become a recognized player in the fast fashion market, both locally and internationally. Love, Bonito has expanded into Malaysia, Indonesia, and Cambodia, leveraging government schemes such as the Customer-Centre Initiative and Capability Development Grant to enhance service standards and boost digital capabilities. The brand is set to open its first flagship store in Singapore later this year, with plans to increase revenue by 50% in the next year.

images.alt_text: Viola Tan (left) and Rachel Lim, co- founders of Love Bonito, will move from being an online retailer since 2010 to opening their first brick-and-mortar flagship store at 313@Somerset.

site_title: Chinese developers to flock to bond markets as current debts mature
summary: Chinese developers are expected to flood the bond markets with over $12 billion in dollar bonds this year, driven by maturing debts and refinancing needs. With interest rates rising, companies are calling bonds to avoid costly refinancing, and analysts predict a steady supply of fresh debt. Despite signs of a cooling real estate market, developers are likely to continue issuing debt, driven by a desire to grow and remain competitive.

site_title: Stanchart's take
summary: Companies can gain a competitive advantage by focusing on the Triple P bottomline, prioritizing people, planet, and profit. The Singapore Exchange's sustainability reporting requirement has led to a growing demand for socially conscious businesses. Research shows that sustainable companies perform better and are better equipped to respond to changes in the operating environment. Additionally, impact investing is gaining interest from investors, with Standard Chartered Private Bank estimating a potential growth to $300-400 billion by 2020, driven by millennial wealth and inter-generational transfers. This shift towards sustainability is expected to benefit businesses and investors alike.

site_title: UK house prices rise for second month in July: Nationwide
summary: UK house prices rose 0.3% in July, the second consecutive month of growth, despite economists' expectations of a decline. Annual growth slowed to 2.9%, down from 3.1% in June, but remains within the 3-6% range seen over the past two years. The housing market appears to be stabilizing after weakening since the Brexit vote, with a shortage of homes on the market providing support for price growth. Nationwide's chief economist Robert Gardner attributed the growth to the lack of homes on the market, suggesting a 2% annual growth rate for 2017.

site_title: Qatar launches wide-ranging WTO complaint against trade boycott
summary: Qatar has filed a wide-ranging complaint with the World Trade Organization (WTO) against a trade boycott by Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, and the United Arab Emirates, citing "coercive attempts at economic isolation" and impeding Qatar's rights in trade. The complaint, triggered by Qatar's request for consultations, is the first step in a trade dispute that could lead to litigation and potential retaliatory trade sanctions. The boycott, imposed in June, accuses Qatar of financing militant groups and aligning with Iran, allegations Qatar denies.

images.alt_text: Qatar filed a wide-ranging legal complaint at the World Trade Organization on Monday to challenge a trade boycott by Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and United Arab Emirates, the director of Qatar's WTO office Ali Alwaleed al-Thani told Reuters.

site_title: Singapore's Sunseap and Shell to collaborate on solar projects in Asia-Pacific
summary: Singapore's Sunseap Group has secured investment from Shell Technology Ventures BV to collaborate on solar projects in the country and Asia-Pacific region. Sunseap, a solar leasing company, will leverage Shell's expertise to further grow its business. The partnership aims to capitalize on the growing demand for renewable energy in the region, with the Asia-Pacific projected to see a significant increase in new power generation capacity over the next 25 years, according to Bloomberg New Energy Finance's New Energy Outlook report.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
Sunseap director Frank Phuan said that the group is looking forward to working with Shell to further grow its business.

site_title: China formally opens first overseas military base in Djibouti
summary: China has formally opened its first overseas military base in Djibouti, a strategic location on the northwestern edge of the Indian Ocean. The logistics base, which began construction last year, will support China's navy ships participating in peacekeeping and humanitarian missions. The move has raised concerns in India about China's "string of pearls" military alliances and assets, including in Bangladesh, Myanmar, and Sri Lanka. The opening of the base coincides with the 90th birthday of the People's Liberation Army.

images.alt_text: China formally opened its first overseas military base on Tuesday with a flag raising ceremony in Djibouti in the Horn of Africa, the same day as the People's Liberation Army marks its 90th birthday, state media said.

site_title: Datapulse to sell Tai Seng premises for S$53.5m
summary: Datapulse Technology is selling its Tai Seng premises, a 6-storey industrial building, for S$53.5 million. The leasehold property, with a 30-year tenure, is currently valued at S$8.4 million. The disposal is expected to result in a net gain of S$44.5 million, which will be used to acquire a new facility, fund working capital, and explore new investment opportunities. The sale is conditional on shareholder and JTC approval, and the company aims to reallocate resources to improve asset utilization.

site_title: HDB launches 5,291 flats for sale
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched 5,291 flats for sale on August 1, 2017, comprising 3,897 BTO units and 1,394 Re-Offer of Balance Flats (ROF) units. This is the third BTO launch in 2017, bringing the total to 12,755 units. The total number of flats launched in 2017 so far is 18,095, with more to come in the November BTO exercise offering around 4,800 units.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Inflation data pushes euro from 2-1/2 year highs
summary: The euro dropped from 2-1/2 year highs due to inflation data that met forecasts, easing concerns about a rapid withdrawal of policy stimulus. The eurozone's consumer price rise in July was stable at 1.30%, in line with economists' expectations. This data, which aligns with the European Central Bank's target of just below 2%, led to investors consolidating positions. The euro's decline is a result of the cooling expectations of a swift policy change.

site_title: EPA museum tells history to the beat of the Trump
summary: The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) museum, opened just days before former President Barack Obama left office, is being reworked to reflect the priorities of the Trump administration. The museum, which features exhibits on the agency's work on climate change and the Clean Power Plan, is being altered to include more focus on the Superfund program and the Trump administration's "back to basics" agenda. Employees who worked on the exhibits under the Obama administration informed Trump appointees about the museum, leading to the removal of climate-related displays and potential addition of coal exhibits.

site_title: Tyson reboots brands with fresh ingredients as Amazon looms
summary: US meat giant Tyson Foods Inc is revamping its brands to focus on fresh ingredients, shifting away from packaged foods due to growing consumer demand. The company is introducing new recipes and products, such as soy ginger pork chops and herbed chicken, to compete with healthier sales from the perimeter of grocery stores. Tyson is also expanding its Tastemakers meal kits, which are sold on Amazon and in select stores, and is exploring private-label supplier partnerships with Amazon. This move aims to capitalize on the changing retail environment, which is being disrupted by Amazon's plan to buy Whole Foods Market Inc.

site_title: Google to train 2,500 more Singapore SMEs to go global by 2019
summary: Google will train 2,500 more Singaporean small and medium enterprises (SMEs) to go global by 2019 as part of its expanded Go Global initiative. The program aims to boost digital capabilities and export-readiness through training in online presence, market exploration, and digital leadership. New partnerships with the National Trades Union Congress and the Singapore infocomm Technology Federation have been formed to reach more SMEs. The initiative includes access to dedicated marketing consultants, masterclasses, and export-specific workshops, and aims to train 1,000 business leaders by 2019.

site_title: America's friends need to pay heed: the hegemon is no more
summary: The US has lost its status as a global hegemon, and America's friends should acknowledge this change. The country's inability to dictate global developments is due to its failure to adapt to shifting global power dynamics, rather than the incompetence or appeasement of its leaders. The US military power was overstretched, contributing to its decline in global status, and the public's wariness of new military interventions led to the election of President Trump, who campaigned on re-examining America's global commitments. The US is not a has-been global power, but its decline will be haphazard and requires other nations to adjust to its new position.

site_title: Model 3's buzz belies US market barely getting a lift from EVs
summary: Tesla's Model 3 has started delivering its cheaper sedan in the US, but the market is still not seeing significant growth in electric vehicles (EVs). Despite the Model 3's affordability and range, total car and truck deliveries likely shrank in July, with EVs accounting for only 0.5% of the market. Analysts predict that the industry-wide sedan slump and low-margin shipments will continue to impact sales, with every major automaker projected to post declines. However, some industry leaders, such as Fiat Chrysler Automobiles' Sergio Marchionne, believe that electrification is inevitable and that adoption will pick up in the coming years.

site_title: Market capitalisation
summary: Indonesia has detained a Trafigura employee in connection with a US$17 billion graft case. Meanwhile, Helen Wong is retiring as OCBC CEO, with Tan Teck Long being named her successor. Singapore stocks are experiencing a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. MAS and PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Grab's earnings growth is expected to slow in the second half of the year, leading to a downgrade from CGSI.

site_title: Judgment reserved on Tan Cheng Bock's election appeal
summary: Singapore's highest court has reserved judgment on Tan Cheng Bock's appeal against the basis and timing of the upcoming reserved presidential election. A five-member panel led by Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon heard the case, but no date has been set for the judgment to be delivered. The panel will get back to the court "as soon as possible" to deliver the verdict.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Indonesia detains 153 over US$450m scam targeting Chinese
summary: Indonesian police have detained 153 individuals, mostly Chinese nationals, accused of a US$450 million online scam targeting Chinese citizens. The suspects tricked victims into paying to settle legal cases, with profits reaching 6 trillion rupiah (US$450 million). The syndicate, identified as an international operation, entered Indonesia on tourist visas and will likely be deported after investigation completion. The case is a joint investigation between Indonesia and China, with Chinese police initially reporting the scam.

site_title: A-Smart Technologies snags S$1.2m contract with Singapore-based restaurant chain
summary: A-Smart Technologies has secured a S$1.2 million contract with a Singapore-based restaurant chain to supply smart enterprise solutions, including hardware and software, for five years. The company will also provide consultancy and maintenance services. The contract award was announced on Monday, resulting in a 4.2% increase in AST's shares to S$0.625.

site_title: Butter prices soar to all-time highs in Western Europe as demand surges
summary: Butter prices have soared to all-time highs in Western Europe, driven by shifting consumer views on its health attributes and a slowdown in milk output growth. Global prices have doubled in the past 12 months, reaching a record US$7,212.50 per ton. The European Union's stockpiles have nearly emptied, with reserves falling to 1,240 tonnes, a 99% decline from last year. The US Department of Agriculture forecasts a 3.1% rise in global consumption to a record 8.8 million tonnes this year, outpacing production growth.

site_title: Triyards provides breakdown of US$45.1m impairment
summary: Triyards, a Singapore-based yard operating subsidiary of the Ezra group, reported a US$45.1 million impairment charge in its third-quarter financial results. The impairment pertains to stalled newbuilding projects and marine equipment purchased for supply to an affiliated entity, which could not be redeployed due to a downturn in the oil and gas sector. The company has made provisions for inventory obsolescence, doubtful receivables, and other losses, totaling US$45.1 million.

site_title: When cash (flow) is still king
summary: A company's strong revenue and profit track record can be deceiving if it has poor and negative cash flows, which can lead to financial disaster. A company's financial health is better measured by its cash flow statement, particularly free cash flow (FCF), which represents the cash available to maintain or grow its asset base. A company with weak cash flow is at risk of defaulting on debts and failing, as seen in the examples of Swiber Holdings and Swissco Holdings in the oil and marine industry. Retail investors should consider cash flow when evaluating a company's financial health.

site_title: China manufacturing sector sees slower growth
