summary: China's manufacturing sector saw slower growth in July, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) coming in at 51.4, below analysts' expectations of 51.7. The slowdown was attributed to adverse weather conditions and regulatory clampdowns on financial risks. Despite this, the sector remains robust, with levels near record highs. The construction sector continued to support the economy, with a PMI reading of 62.5, while the non-manufacturing PMI fell to 54.5, hinting at a broader slowdown in the economy.

images.alt_text: The National Bureau of Statistics attributed the slowdown in manufacturing activity to adverse weather conditions, flooding in parts of the country and routine maintenance in some enterprises.

site_title: Loss-making Datapulse looks to sell Tai Seng premises for S$53.5m
summary: Datapulse Technology, a loss-making digital storage products company, is selling its Tai Seng premises, the Datapulse Industrial Building, for S$53.5 million. The leasehold property, with a 30-year lease tenure, is being disposed of to reallocate resources and improve asset utilization. The disposal is conditional on shareholder and JTC approval, with a net gain expected to be around S$44.5 million, to be used for new business acquisition and working capital.

site_title: UK PM May's spokesman: Free of movement with EU will end in March 2019
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman confirmed that free movement of people from the European Union will end in March 2019, when Britain leaves the bloc. This comes as the government struggles to reach a consensus on post-Brexit immigration rules. Finance Minister Philip Hammond and Interior Minister Amber Rudd have expressed support for maintaining immigration rules, while Trade Minister Liam Fox said allowing free movement would not align with the referendum result. The government aims to make Brexit as smooth as possible, but divisions remain.

site_title: Hamburg attacker had 'radical Islamist' motive
summary: A 26-year-old failed asylum seeker, identified as Ahmad A, carried out a deadly knife attack in a Hamburg supermarket, killing one person and wounding six. German prosecutors believe Ahmad A had a "radical Islamist" motive, citing his self-radicalization and intention to die as a martyr. The attack, which occurred two months before Germany's general elections, has raised concerns over the country's handling of refugees and the threat of jihadist attacks. Authorities had deemed Ahmad A to be an "Islamist" but not a threat, sparking accusations of complacency.

site_title: HSBC is first big bank to spell out Brexit bill: US$300 Million
summary: HSBC has revealed that it will face up to $300 million in legal and relocation fees as it prepares to move 1,000 staff to Paris due to Brexit. The bank has taken a $4 million charge in the second quarter for "costs associated with the UK's exit from the EU." This move is part of a larger trend of financial firms relocating staff to maintain access to the European Union's single market, with London's financial executives warning of dire consequences for jobs and investment if no mutual free trade deal is struck.

site_title: SoilBuild Q2 profit down 70%
summary: SoilBuild Construction Group reported a 70% fall in net profit for the second quarter to S$0.6 million, down from S$2.183 million last year. Revenue fell 54.1% to S$48 million, attributed to the completion of projects that started contributing revenue in the current quarter. Earnings per share decreased to 0.10 Singapore cent from 0.33 Singapore cent last year. No dividends were declared for the period.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) have agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Meanwhile, Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, has been named OCBC's incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong. In other news, Singapore stocks have rallied for five consecutive days ahead of the release of GDP data, and Grab's credit rating has been downgraded to 'hold' by the Capital Goods Services Index (CGSI) due to expected earnings growth to slow down in the second half.

site_title: Abe's goal of revising pacifist constitution increasingly elusive
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's goal of revising the pacifist constitution, which has been a cornerstone of his conservative security agenda, appears increasingly elusive. Despite achieving several security-related goals, Abe's declining popularity and flagging ratings threaten to derail his plans. A failure to revise the constitution by the 2020 target would likely erode Abe's clout and damage his chances of becoming Japan's longest-serving prime minister. The ruling party's divided views on the issue and concerns from China and Japan's allies have also raised doubts about the prospects of constitutional revision.

images.alt_text: Mr Abe's second term as LDP leader ends in September 2018 and his support has plunged to below 30% in some polls.

site_title: MUFG to spend up to US$9b on acquisitions to double assets under management
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) plans to spend up to $9 billion on acquisitions to double its assets under management to over $900 billion. The Japanese banking group aims to target US and European asset managers, focusing on those with a global active management edge. The move is part of its strategy to shift focus from traditional lending due to low interest rates and strict capital regulation. After doubling assets, MUFG will still trail behind global leaders BlackRock and Vanguard, but aims to establish a global presence in asset management.

site_title: Trump seeks order, discipline with new chief of staff
summary: US President Donald Trump swore in his new chief of staff, John Kelly, on Monday, aiming to restore order in the White House. Kelly, a retired Marine Corps general, replaces Reince Priebus, who struggled to manage Trump's untraditional style. Trump praised Kelly for reducing border security controversy and credited the new chief with averting controversy. The president highlighted the stock market's gains and low unemployment rate as signs of a working White House, tweeting "No WH chaos!" amid ongoing investigations into Russian meddling and North Korea's latest missile test.

site_title: Ng Yat Chung appointed to SPH Reit board
summary: SPH Reit announced the appointment of Ng Yat Chung as a non-independent, non-executive director to the board, effective August 1, 2017. He will replace Alan Chan as CEO of Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) and also take over Chan's role on the SPH Reit board.

site_title: Flamingo fashion makes a comeback
summary: Flamingo fashion has made a significant comeback in the fashion world, transforming from a tacky lawn ornament to a design element of the moment. After being briefly associated with gay culture and later falling out of favor, the trend gained momentum in 2014 thanks to American fashion designer Marc Jacobs. Celebrities and retailers such as Target and John Lewis have since jumped on the trend, with flamingos now adorning everything from high-end dresses to home decor items. The trend's rapid rise and fall demonstrate the power of social networks in launching and reinforcing consumer trends.

images.alt_text: The flamingo's journey from kitsch to cool illustrates how consumer trends emerge.

site_title: Snap's shares slide as IPO lockup ends
summary: Snap's shares dropped 3.5% to $13.32 on Monday as a share lockup ended, allowing early investors to sell shares for the first time since its $3.4 billion IPO in March. The stock fell below its IPO price of $17, with trading volume at 0.3 times the 10-day moving average. Analysts say this is a buying opportunity, with one predicting a $30 price target in 12 months, citing the company's mobile advertising platform and potential for growth.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher, Dow rises to record high
summary: US stock indexes opened higher on Monday, with the Dow hitting a record high, as investors remained optimistic on corporate earnings in the second quarter. 73% of S&P 500 companies that reported results beat analyst expectations, supporting relatively high valuations for equities. The Dow's record high comes despite tariff uncertainty and ongoing trade talks between the US and EU.

site_title: French government ordered to supply water, sanitation for Calais migrants
summary: France's highest administrative court ruled the government must provide water and sanitation facilities for hundreds of migrants in Calais. The court found the state's failure to do so exposed migrants to inhuman treatment, causing health issues and psychological troubles. The ruling upholds a previous order from a Lille court, which also demanded migrants seeking asylum be offered a place in a reception center. The decision comes after President Emmanuel Macron's government had appealed against the order, citing concerns about the proliferation of makeshift camps.

site_title: IHH buys 55% stake in Angsana Holdings for S$9.3m
summary: IHH Healthcare Berhad acquired a 55% stake in Angsana Holdings Pte Ltd for S$9.3 million through its subsidiary Parkway Pantai Limited. Angsana's principal activity is providing molecular diagnostic test services. The transaction won't affect IHH's issued share capital or financials.

site_title: India set to block US$1.3b Gland Pharma-Fosun deal
summary: India's Cabinet Committee on Economic Affairs has decided to block China's Shanghai Fosun Pharmaceutical Group's proposed US$1.3 billion takeover of Indian drugmaker Gland Pharma. The move comes despite the companies not being formally notified yet. The decision is reportedly due to national security concerns and the potential impact on India's pharmaceutical industry.

site_title: India's Tech Mahindra Q1 profit rises about 7%, beats estimates
summary: Tech Mahindra Ltd, India's fifth largest software services exporter, reported a 7% increase in Q1 net profit to 7.99 billion rupees, beating estimates. Revenue rose 8% to 77.47 billion rupees, driven by a 7% increase in its IT segment to 68.63 billion rupees. This surpasses analysts' average estimate of 6 billion rupees.

Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. CGS International downgraded Grab's rating to 'hold', citing slowing earnings growth in the second half. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Trump and Japan's Abe talk about "grave and growing" North Korea threat
summary: US President Donald Trump and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe agreed on the need for more action against North Korea, describing the threat as "grave and growing." The two leaders discussed the issue just hours after the US Ambassador to the UN said Washington is "done talking" about North Korea, and Japan's Abe stated that international society needs to increase pressure on Pyongyang. The US and Japan are planning concrete actions, but no details were given.

site_title: French actress Jeanne Moreau dies aged 89
summary: French actress Jeanne Moreau, known for her iconic roles in "Jules et Jim" and critically-acclaimed films, has died at 89. Found dead at her Paris home, Moreau's husky voice and beauty captivated cinema audiences throughout her career. With a prolific career spanning decades, she continued to act well into her eighties, leaving behind a legacy in French cinema.

images.alt_text: French actress Jeanne Moreau, who shot to fame in "Jules et Jim" and starred in some of the most critically-acclaimed films of the 20th century, has died aged 89, her agent said Monday.

site_title: Roil Shipping enters into time charter agreement with Gasemas
summary: ROIL Shipping has entered into a time charter agreement with Gasemas, chartering a double hull oil tanker named Roil Orchid for S$15,000 per day for six months. The charter agreement, starting August 1, 2017, is renewable with 60 days' notice. The value of the charter represents approximately 2.3% of Roil Shipping's latest audited net tangible assets.

site_title: Heatec Jietong issues H1 loss warning
summary: Heatec Jietong, a piping and heat exchanger services provider, has issued a profit warning for the half year ended June 30, 2017. The group expects a net loss due to a loss on liquidation of a subsidiary and lower work orders in the marine and offshore engineering sector. A court order has been obtained to wind up a 72.5%-owned subsidiary, Heatec Chariot Envirobotics Pte Ltd, which had disposed its equipment and spares prior to the winding-up. The group's first half unaudited consolidated financial results will be released on or before August 14, 2017.

site_title: Chinese firms from Jiangsu to invest US$300m in industries in Abu Dhabi
summary: Abu Dhabi has attracted five Chinese companies to invest US$300 million in various industries at the Khalifa Industrial Zone Abu Dhabi, marking the emirate's push for economic diversification. The agreements were signed as part of a 50-year lease agreement with the Jiangsu Provincial Overseas Cooperation & Investment Company. The investments are expected to contribute positively to Abu Dhabi's non-oil GDP, helping to diversify the economy from oil. The move is seen as a strategic step by Abu Dhabi to tap into China's growing overseas expansion ambitions.

site_title: European diesel surges after fire at Pernis refinery cuts supply
summary: A fire at Royal Dutch Shell's Pernis refinery in the Netherlands has cut supply, leading to a surge in European diesel prices. The fire halted most units and is expected to disrupt supply until Monday. Traders are scrambling for alternative supplies, with some speculating increased flows from Asia. The shutdown accelerates the tightening of the diesel market, which has been impacted by previous disruptions. Inventories have fallen counter-seasonally, and the market is expected to remain tight, with prices potentially rising due to regional bottlenecks.

site_title: Modi steps up assault on opponents, eyes Indian supremacy
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's ruling alliance is intensifying its attack on the opposition Congress party to secure a majority in the upper house of parliament, a key hurdle to its legislative agenda. Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has recently secured the backing of opposition lawmakers to elect its candidate Ram Nath Kovind as president, addressing a long-standing obstacle. This move is part of the BJP's efforts to expand its national dominance and maintain control over the country.

site_title: Moody's gets licence to rate Saudi Arabia's corporates
summary: Moody's Investors Service has obtained a licence to rate Saudi Arabia's corporates, joining Fitch and Standard & Poor's in the country. This move aims to develop the corporate debt capital markets, as the country seeks to reduce reliance on bank loans. Saudi Arabia's sovereign has issued record-breaking international bonds and sukuk to address budget deficits caused by low oil prices. The Capital Markets Authority (CMA) authorised Moody's to conduct credit rating activities in 2017, following similar permissions for Standard & Poor's and Fitch in 2015 and 2016, respectively.

site_title: Eurozone unemployment falls to 9.1% in June
summary: Eurozone unemployment fell to 9.1% in June, the lowest level since February 2009, according to Eurostat statistics. This marks a slight decrease from May's revised 9.2% unemployment rate. The economic recovery in Europe continues to strengthen, with the jobless rate below the predicted 9.2% estimate.

site_title: US VP Pence, in the Baltics, voices support for mutual defence in Nato
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence assured the Baltic states of US support if they faced aggression from Russia, reaffirming Washington's backing of Nato's collective defense doctrine. Pence's comments followed Russia's 2014 annexation of Crimea and US President Donald Trump's initial lukewarm support for Nato. Pence stated that an attack on one Baltic state would be considered an attack on the US, as the US stands firmly behind Article 5 of the Nato charter. This comes ahead of Russia's scheduled large-scale military manoeuvres with Belarus.

images.alt_text: US Vice President Mike Pence on Monday assured the Baltic states of US support if they faced aggression from Russia, telling them that Washington firmly backs Nato's doctrine of collective defence.

site_title: Germany open to class action lawsuits in emissions scandal
summary: Germany is open to class action lawsuits against carmakers involved in the diesel emissions scandal, the Transport Ministry announced ahead of a diesel summit. The move comes after a court ruled that retrofitting diesel cars with new software would not be sufficient to meet emissions standards. Environmental group DUH is pushing for carmakers to replace emission control systems, and the government is considering using all available legal possibilities. The summit aims to discuss ways to avoid diesel bans and reduce polluting nitrogen oxide emissions.

site_title: Panasonic's Q1 profit increases 16.9%, in line with estimates
summary: Panasonic reported a 16.9% increase in Q1 operating profit to 83.93 billion yen, beating analyst estimates. The company attributed the growth to a shift to advanced automotive parts. Panasonic maintained its full-year operating profit forecast of 335 billion yen, despite 17 analyst estimates averaging 344.23 billion yen. The company's profit rise follows a trend of electronics giants benefiting from a shift to automotive parts.

site_title: India's Punjab, Maharashtra states warn cotton farmers on potential pest attacks
summary: India's Punjab and Maharashtra states have warned cotton farmers of potential pest attacks due to dry weather conditions, which could trigger infestations of pests like whitefly. The states have asked farmers to increase pesticide sprays to prevent infestations. This warning comes after a similar incident in 2015, when whitefly pests hit cotton crops in Punjab and neighboring Haryana, causing significant damage. The states aim to prevent a repeat of the damage, which could impact India's cotton output and production.

site_title: Blackstone in exclusive talks with Banco Popular on property portfolio
summary: US asset manager Blackstone is in exclusive talks with Banco Popular to sell a majority stake in the Spanish lender's property portfolio, valued at around 30 billion euros. The portfolio includes repossessed assets and non-performing loans. This deal comes after Popular was rescued by Banco Santander in June for a symbolic price of one euro. Blackstone is reportedly set to acquire 51% of the portfolio, with Lone Star and Apollo having failed to make competing bids. The sale must be approved by European competition authorities.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore bank lending rose 0.4% in June, according to preliminary data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Meanwhile, tourism spend in Singapore increased 15% and arrivals rose 4% in Q1 2017. In other news, a Malaysia agency is set to seize RM3 billion of assets belonging to Daim Zainuddin, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: China Construction Bank nominates Bank of China boss as next chairman - sources
summary: China Construction Bank (CCB) has nominated Bank of China Ltd's boss Tian Guoli, 57, as its next chairman, following a closed-door meeting. Tian was named Communist Party Secretary of state-owned CCB on Monday. An announcement could be made as early as later Monday.

site_title: Shell contains leak at Singapore refining-petrochemical site
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has contained a leak at its Pulau Bukom refining and petrochemical complex in Singapore, with operations not affected. The leak occurred on Friday at one of the site's units, but no further details were released. The Bukom site, Shell's largest wholly-owned plant, handles 500,000 barrels per day and produces 900,000 tonnes of ethylene annually.

images.alt_text: Royal Dutch Shell Plc is seeking creative solutions to bring gas from Israel and Cyprus to market, a step that could help turn the Mediterranean region into a major gas-producing hub.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mixed at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets were narrowly mixed at the start of trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.3% to 7,389.04 points. HSBC led gains, rising 3.4% after announcing a share buyback plan. In contrast, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index fell 0.2% and Paris's CAC 40 dipped 0.1%. The mixed performance was attributed to solid share-price gains for the mining sector on Chinese economic data, but US-EU trade talks remain a focus.

site_title: Japan banks book gains from stock holdings, but bleak lending persists
summary: Japanese banks Mizuho and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group reported significant gains from selling stock holdings in corporate clients for the first quarter, with gains of 62.3 billion yen and 29 billion yen respectively. The sales aimed to reduce exposure to market swings, but ultra-low interest rates continued to drag on the lenders' results. The banks' stock holdings are valued at billions of dollars and have been subject to pressure from investors and regulators to be trimmed.

site_title: UK consumer borrowing cools after Bank of England warning
summary: UK consumer borrowing slowed in June after the Bank of England took action to limit risk from borrowing. Unsecured lending rose 10% from a year earlier, the lowest in over a year, and £1.5 billion on the month. The BOE strengthened rules on mortgage lending and ordered lenders to hold extra capital. Consumer credit growth includes a 9% rise in credit card borrowing and a 10.6% rise in lending for vehicle finance, personal loans, and overdrafts. The BOE's interest-rate decision is scheduled for Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up for 7th straight month, buoyed by resource firms
summary: Hong Kong stocks reached a 25-month high, closing at 1.3% above the previous day, as they completed a seventh-straight month of gains. The Hang Seng index rose 6.1% for the month, driven by resource firms and strong mainland investor inflows via the stock connect program. Major material firms and Tencent rose 4.5% and 2.8%, respectively, as sectors rallied across the board. The gains were attributed to China's supply-side reforms and a weaker US dollar, with dual-listed firms benefiting from increased familiarity among mainland investors.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia ministers agree to start MRT service to Johor Baru by 2024
summary: Singaporean and Malaysian ministers have agreed to launch the RTS Link, a high-speed rail service connecting Woodlands to Johor Baru, by December 31, 2024. The service will allow up to 10,000 passengers to travel each hour, joining the Thomson-East Coast Line in Woodlands North. The project aims to enhance connectivity between the two countries and boost economic ties.

site_title: Perennial-led consortium to put AXA Tower up for sale at no less than S$1.65b
summary: A Perennial-led consortium is considering an en bloc sale of AXA Tower in Singapore at a minimum price of S$1.65 billion, translating to S$2,150 per square foot. The sale follows strong interest in the commercial office segment and improved market conditions. The asset enhancement initiative costs S$140 million, which will be borne by the new owner. AXA Tower still has 185,850 sq ft of unutilized space, offering potential for further value creation.

site_title: Singapore ranks second after Switzerland in world's top innovation leaders
summary: Singapore ranks second globally in innovation, behind Switzerland, according to the Innovation Indicator 2017. Germany, ranked fourth, shows weaknesses in digitalisation, lagging behind industrial nations like the US and Great Britain. To remain competitive, Germany must improve its digitalisation capabilities, according to the report.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.80 points to 1,766.28. Despite this, gainers outnumbered losers 112 to 83. The lower market opening was not directly linked to any major economic data or news.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific's Q2 earnings fall 26% to S$14.7m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported a 26% decline in net profit to S$14.7m for Q2, driven by lower revenue from property development and hotel ownership segments. Revenue dropped 21% to S$77.8m, primarily due to lower revenue recognition from Jade Residences and LIV on Sophia. Earnings per share fell to 1.24 cents, while the net asset value per share increased to 42.21 cents. The company's shares ended S$0.01 lower at S$0.525.

site_title: Ong Ye Kung takes over as new chairman of the Chinese Community Liaison Group
summary: Singapore's Minister for Education and Second Minister for Defence Ong Ye Kung will take over as chairman of the Chinese Community Liaison Group (CCLG) on August 1, replacing Chan Chun Sing. The CCLG, established in 2000, aims to strengthen government relations with the Chinese community and promote cooperation among Chinese groups. The appointment was made by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore stocks finish mixed
summary: Singapore stocks finished the day at 3,329.5, down 1.23 points, amid a cautious start to the week following recent market volatility. The Dow futures' slight weakness and geopolitical tensions contributed to the mixed performance. Second liners, such as Rowsley and DISA, were among the few gainers, while LionGold and other stocks were less active. The market is now in a "wait-and-see" mode, awaiting GDP data and other economic indicators.

site_title: Philippines' environment minister says ban on open-pit mining to stay in place
summary: Philippines' Environment Minister Roy Cimatu announced he will not lift the ban on open-pit mining imposed in April, citing the need for a review of mining taxation. The ban was issued by his predecessor, firebrand Regina Lopez, as part of an anti-pollution crackdown. Cimatu, a former general, took a more measured approach, saying he needs to review documents and evidence before making a decision. The ban affects 26 mines in the country, which remain uncertain in their fate.

site_title: OKP Holdings' Q2 profit doubles on higher revenue
summary: OKP Holdings reported a Q2 net profit of S$4.95 million, doubling from the same period last year, driven by 43.2% year-over-year revenue growth to S$34.4 million. The increase was mainly attributed to growth in its construction and maintenance segments, with projects progressing to a more active phase during the second quarter.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index edging down 0.17% and the Topix index down 0.16%. Investors were cautious due to below-expectation US economic growth data and renewed tensions over North Korea's ICBM programme. The yen's rise also contributed to the decline.

site_title: Boeing expects India to order up to 2,100 aircraft over 20 years
summary: Boeing forecasts India to order up to 2,100 new aircraft worth US$290 billion over 20 years, citing the country's fast-growing aviation market and favorable conditions for low-cost carriers. The company expects passenger growth of about 8% in South Asia, dominated by India, over the next 20 years. Single-aisle planes, such as the 737 and 737 Max, are expected to account for most deliveries, with India likely to take 1,780 such aircraft.

site_title: 13 Holdings misses Macau Hotel opening
summary: 13 Holdings Ltd, a luxury hotel developer in Macau, missed a deadline to open its $1.6 billion hotel project, which was secured with a US$384 million loan from Bank of Communications Co. The project, now aiming to open before year's end, features 200 villas and 24-hour butler service. The company has obtained an occupation permit and is in the final stages of completion, but still needs to secure necessary licenses and complete construction. Analysts express skepticism about the project's viability due to the downturn in the high-end market and changes in government policy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares down by more than 7 points
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 7.05 points lower at 1,760.03 on Monday, with a trading volume of 1.93 billion lots worth RM2.58 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 586 to 309.

site_title: Abu Dhabi Ports in talks for Africa deal to feed trade with Asia
summary: Abu Dhabi Ports is in talks to expand its presence in Africa by feeding trade with Asia, CEO Mohamed Juma Al Shamisi said. The company is discussing a possible deal with an unspecified partner to capitalize on the growing trade between Africa and Asia. Abu Dhabi Ports operates a terminal in Guinea and is considering an initial public offering. The company has recently signed a US$738 million deal with China's Cosco Shipping Co to build and operate a second terminal at the Khalifa port in Abu Dhabi.

site_title: Australia shares edge higher on boost from miners, NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Monday, driven by a boost from miners and metal prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 18.98 points to 5,721.8, with BHP Billiton and metal stocks rising 2.1%. Oil prices also jumped, lifting oil majors Woodside Petroleum and Oil Search. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.4% on the back of an industrial sector boost. The gains contrasted with falls in financials, led by Westpac and ANZ.

site_title: Chief Justice reserves judgement on Tan Cheng Bock's appeal on presidential election
summary: Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon has reserved judgement on Tan Cheng Bock's appeal against the timing and basis of Singapore's reserved presidential election, heard by a five-judge panel. The appeal was heard on July 31. The hearing has been adjourned, with no date set for the judgement.

site_title: Australia: Shares end the day higher
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.3% to 5,720.6, driven by gains in the materials sector, led by BHP Billiton's 2.1% increase. Oil prices rose after a US inventory decline, while iron ore prices soared 8% to a three-month high. The SS&P/ASX 200 index ended its third consecutive monthly fall. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.7% to its seventh consecutive monthly gain, driven by industrial stocks.

site_title: Singapore launches new tripartite standard for term contract employees
summary: Singapore has launched a new tripartite standard for term contract employees, specifying better employment conditions such as leave benefits, notice period, and training. The standard, developed by the Ministry of Manpower and employers' associations, applies to about 170,000 term contract employees, or 10% of Singapore's workforce. 296 employers have signed on as early adopters, accounting for around 15% of term contract employees. The standard aims to signal progressive employment practices to jobseekers and will be rolled out in subsequent months, with plans for four more standards by the end of 2017.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Majority of manufacturers expect business environment in H2 to remain similar to Q2
summary: A majority of Singapore's manufacturers (80%) expect a similar business environment in the second half of 2017 compared to the second quarter. Biomedical manufacturing is the most optimistic cluster, with 14% anticipating an improvement in business conditions. Precision engineering and electronics also show optimism, while transport engineering and general manufacturing expect a less favorable environment. Most manufacturing clusters forecast a rise in output in the third quarter, with 5% planning to hire fewer workers.

site_title: Update: SoftBank is said to plan making direct offer for Charter
summary: SoftBank Group Corp chairman Masayoshi Son plans to make a direct offer for Charter Communications Inc this week, following a merger proposal by SoftBank's US wireless unit being rejected. Charter had previously spurned an offer to merge with Sprint Corp, which is controlled by SoftBank. The plan could reignite deal talks, although it's not yet complete and may change. Son had previously proposed a deal to create a new public company combining Sprint and Charter.

site_title: Great corn clash is coming as US, Brazil farmers face off
summary: US and Brazilian farmers are preparing for a "Great Corn Clash" as the world's two largest corn exporters face off for global market share. Brazil's massive corn harvest, forecast to surge 45% from last year, is expected to reach a record 97 million metric tons, while the US harvest is also expected to be the second-largest ever. The surplus of supplies is driving down domestic prices, making it attractive to importers, and hedge funds are betting on a price rally, but competition between the two exporters will be tough, according to market experts.

site_title: Asahi Kasei increases S-SBR production in Singapore to meet growing tyre demand
summary: Asahi Kasei Chemicals is expanding its Singapore plant to produce 130,000 tonnes of solution polymerised sytrene-butadiene rubber (S-SBR) annually, from 100,000 tonnes, to meet growing demand for tyres. The expansion, expected to be completed by January 2019, makes the plant the group's largest S-SBR manufacturing site worldwide. The move reflects Singapore's growing importance as a strategic gateway to Asia, driven by rapid urbanization and a growing middle class.

site_title: Turmoil engulfs Kenya's supermarket success
summary: Kenya's largest retailer, Nakumatt supermarkets, is facing severe product shortages and financial struggles, with some suppliers demanding upfront payment and the landlord seizing merchandise due to unpaid rent. The company's downfall is attributed to a combination of bad management, misguided expansion plans, and increased competition. Despite annual sales of $600 million, Nakumatt's financial situation is dire, and industry insiders warn that the company may not survive. The retailer's struggles are also linked to its acquisition of a minority stake by a businessman with a scandalous reputation, further exacerbating the crisis.

site_title: Heineken profit beats expectations on strong Europe
summary: Heineken reported higher than expected operating profit in the first six months of 2017, driven by strong sales in Europe due to warm weather and a late Easter. The company's volumes, revenue, and profits grew on a like-for-like basis in all four regions. Heineken stuck to its target of a 0.4 percentage point improvement in operating margin per year, excluding acquisitions and planned purchases. The company expects revenue and profit growth this year.

images.alt_text: Heineken, the world's second-largest beer maker, reported a higher than expected operating profit in the first six months of 2017 as a late Easter and warm weather in key parts of Europe boosted its sales.

site_title: China says no link between North Korea and China-US trade
summary: China's vice-commerce minister Qian Keming stated there is no link between North Korea's nuclear program and China-US trade, contradicting US President Donald Trump's claims. Trump tweeted that China had done nothing for the US on North Korea, while Qian emphasized that the two issues are in different domains and should not be discussed together. China reiterated its commitment to promoting denuclearization of the Korean peninsula and working with the international community to address the issue.

site_title: Tourism spend up 15%, arrivals rise 4% in Q1 2017
summary: Singapore's tourism sector experienced a 15% year-on-year increase in spending to S$6.4 billion in Q1 2017, driven by 4% growth in visitor arrivals to 4.3 million. China was the top source market, with a 14% increase in arrivals. Spending on shopping jumped 38%, while hotel room revenue declined 1.3% to S$0.8 billion, and average occupancy rate rose 1.3% to 86%.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Fosun's Guo says backs China crackdown on overseas deals
summary: Chinese conglomerate Fosun International's chairman Guo Guangchang backs China's crackdown on overseas deals, calling them "essential and timely" to eliminate risky investments and financial "chaos." The crackdown has stifled deals for top firms, including Dalian Wanda, HNA Group, and Fosun, which had made showy overseas acquisitions. Guo believes tougher rules will prevent foreigners from viewing Chinese firms as "silly money."

images.alt_text: Guo Guangchang, chairman of Chinese conglomerate Fosun International, said in a note on Saturday that tougher rules on overseas deals were "essential and timely" to root out risky investments and sort out financial "chaos".

site_title: Qatar crisis is back to square one as economy shows the strain
summary: The Saudi-led alliance has reinstated 13 demands for Qatar, including ending support for terrorism, before talks to resolve the eight-week crisis can start. The foreign ministers of Saudi Arabia, UAE, Egypt, and Bahrain made the announcement, dealing a blow to mediation efforts by Kuwait and US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson. The demands are a reversal of previous concessions, and talks appear to be stalled, casting doubt on the crisis's resolution. The boycott has taken a significant economic toll on Qatar, with fresh data highlighting its strain.

images.alt_text: Qatar's economy has been hit by the sanctions imposed by a Saudi-led Arab bloc but the emirate's economy is strong enough to survive, analysts say.

site_title: More services sector firms upbeat about business environment in H2
summary: More services sector firms in Singapore are optimistic about the business environment in the second half of 2017, with a net weighted balance of 5% anticipating more favourable conditions compared to the previous quarter and the same period last year. 19% of firms expect business conditions to improve, while 14% foresee slower business. A majority (67%) expect business activity levels to remain the same, marking a turnaround from the previous quarter's survey.

site_title: Charter has 'no interest' in SoftBank's proposal to buy Sprint
summary: Charter Communications Inc has rejected SoftBank's proposal to buy Sprint Corp, citing no interest in the deal. SoftBank Chairman Masayoshi Son had proposed a cash and stock merger between Sprint and Charter, but Charter's management team deemed it a bad idea. Charter plans to launch wireless services to its customers through a resale agreement with Verizon Communications Inc. instead, and is expected to launch these services next year. Charter has ended talks with Sprint over reselling its wireless service and will instead join Comcast in offering wireless services to its customers.

site_title: Australia ramps up airport security after alleged plane bomb plot
summary: Australia has introduced stricter airport security measures after police foiled an alleged "Islamic-inspired" plot for a bomb attack on a plane. Four men were arrested in Sydney, and their detention is under special terror-related powers. Immigration Minister Peter Dutton said the security measures will remain in place indefinitely. Passengers experienced longer-than-usual queues at major airports, including Sydney, but queues dissipated by lunchtime. The government has also instructed airlines and airports to ramp up baggage checks, with some luggage searches being conducted as passengers checked in their bags.

site_title: Singapore bank lending up 0.4% in June: MAS
summary: Singapore bank lending rose 0.4% in June, surpassing May's 0.3% growth, according to preliminary data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore. This marks a 7.6% year-on-year increase, compared to 6.8% in May. Loans totaled S$636 billion in June.

images.alt_text: Bank lending in Singapore rose 0.4 per cent in June from the month before, preliminary data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore on Monday showed.

site_title: China's yuan firms on stronger fixing, set for the 3rd winning month
summary: China's yuan strengthened to 6.7283 per US dollar on Monday, its highest level in over nine months, after the People's Bank of China fixed the currency at a stronger level. This marks the third consecutive month of gains, with the yuan up around 0.8% against the US dollar. The currency's strength is attributed to broad weakness in the US dollar, driven by US political uncertainty and disappointing economic data. Analysts expect China's economy to slow in coming months due to rising borrowing costs and regulatory measures.

images.alt_text: China's yuan firmed against the US dollar on Monday after the official guidance was fixed at the strongest level in over nine months, putting the currency on course for the third straight month of gains.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices climb to new peaks, but growth pace slows
summary: Hong Kong's home prices reached new peaks in June, with a 0.69% increase from May, the smallest rise since December last year. Despite this, prices surged 21.6% from a year earlier. The city's new leader, Carrie Lam, has pledged to make home prices more affordable, while Chinese President Xi Jinping expressed concern over the property market. Income inequality remains high, stoking discontent in the city. The slowdown in growth pace highlights the challenges Lam faces in reining in prices in one of the world's most expensive property markets.

site_title: How casino mogul Steve Wynn lost US$10m on baccarat
summary: Casino mogul Steve Wynn revealed a $10 million loss at his Macau casino, Wynn Palace, in April due to a junket operator's clients winning big at baccarat tables. The unusual loss occurred despite the casino's ability to generate $50 million in profit. Wynn attributed the loss to "enormous volume" and a "unique statistical anomaly." The incident highlights the volatility of the casino business, with extreme swings in winnings and losses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open higher
summary: Hong Kong's main index rose 0.53% on Monday to 27,121.86, following Friday's losses. China's July manufacturing data came in below expectations, with Shanghai stocks opening flat. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index edged 0.02% lower.

site_title: Australian plane plot may have involved gas or bomb disguised as meat mincer: reports
summary: Four men, including two Lebanese-Australian fathers and their sons, were arrested in Sydney for allegedly plotting to bring down a plane using poisonous gas or a crude bomb disguised as a meat mincer. The men planned to carry the device on board a commercial flight as hand luggage. Australian officials described the plans as "advanced" and "sophisticated". The investigation is ongoing, with security measures strengthened at major airports across Australia.

site_title: US dollar struggles on policy uncertainty, political woes
summary: The US dollar struggled against the euro and yen due to US political uncertainty and weak economic data. The US labor cost growth in the second quarter was lower than expected, adding to concerns about low inflation. President Trump's recent cabinet shake-up and the failure to pass tax reforms also contributed to the dollar's decline. The euro reached a 2-1/2-year high against the dollar, while the yen touched its weakest level since mid-June, at 110.525.

site_title: Audi targets 10b euros in cost cuts to fund electric-car push -sources
summary: Audi plans to cut costs by 10 billion euros by 2022 to fund its shift to electric cars. The luxury automaker aims to bring five new electric models to market, including the e-tron SUV, and maintain an operating profit margin of at least 8% per year. Despite expected run-up costs, Audi seeks to keep its profit margin stable, following the emissions scandal that hit the industry. The company plans to start assembling the e-tron SUV in Brussels from 2018.

site_title: Oil surges as dollar continues slide against the yen
summary: Oil prices surged on Monday, reaching US$50 a barrel for WTI and US$53 for Brent, amid a strengthening yen and concerns over gridlock in Washington and tensions on the Korean Peninsula. Analysts attribute the rally to low oil inventories, Saudi Arabia's intentions to increase production, and US sanctions on Venezuela. The yen's rise also contributed to a rise in mining giants' share prices, while Tokyo slipped and Shanghai edged up despite disappointing PMI data.

images.alt_text: Oil prices surged on Monday to build on last week's rally as the yen continued its rise against the greenback, backed by concerns over gridlock in Washington and renewed tensions on the Korean Peninsula.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index slipping 0.22% to 19,915.39, and the Topix index down 0.25% to 1,617.15. The yen strengthened after below-expectation US economic growth data.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks at nearly 3-week low as foreigners sell, won steady
summary: South Korea's Kospi index fell 0.3% to a nearly three-week low at 2,394.84 points, weighed down by foreign investors selling tech and auto stocks. Despite heightened tensions over North Korea's missile launch, the won remained steady against the dollar. Major tech shares like Samsung and SK Hynix gained, while Hyundai Motor dropped 3%. Cosmetic-related companies also declined due to China's concerns over Seoul's THAAD deployment. Despite this, investors' sentiment remained resilient, with the won holding steady.

site_title: Novena Global Lifecare to raise US$150m in Taiwan listing
summary: Novena Global Lifecare Group, a Singapore-based medical aesthetic chain, plans to raise US$150 million in a Taiwan IPO to expand regionally. The funds will be used to grow organically and through acquisitions. Novena aims to develop predictive care through DNA testing and expand its services in Taiwan and other Asian markets. The company, founded by former investment bankers Nelson and Terence Loh, has acquired a majority stake in a Taiwanese health screening service provider and is in talks to develop a maternity care centre.

site_title: China's Hesteel sets up special fund to aid restructuring
summary: Hebei Iron and Steel Group (Hesteel), China's second-largest steelmaker, has established a 10 billion yuan special fund to aid its restructuring efforts. The fund, valued at 2.01 billion Singapore dollars, will be co-financed by Hesteel and the Great Wall Asset Management Corp. The restructuring aims to boost profitability by investing in technological research and high-end steel production. Hesteel also plans to acquire more overseas production capacity and participate in Hebei's state-owned enterprise reform plans to upgrade polluting industries.

site_title: Japan industrial output increase hints at more stable growth
summary: Japan's factory output rebounded in June with a 1.6% increase, beating expectations, suggesting a more stable economic expansion. This follows a 3.6% decline in May. The transport sector and industrial chemicals saw significant rebounds, while inventories fell 2.2% in June. Manufacturers forecast steady growth in output for the coming months, supporting overall economic growth. The positive reading follows data on increased household spending and a tight labor market, building optimism about the economy's upward momentum.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Raffles Medical, TT International Limited
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 0.5% increase in net profit to S$16.76 million for the year-ago period, with revenue up 1% to S$120.09 million for the three months ended June 30. TT International Limited requested a trading halt after receiving a letter from Big Box Pte Ltd claiming repayment of S$50.75 million in alleged rental arrears.

site_title: HNA is said to seek more arrangers for delayed property IPO
summary: HNA Commercial REIT is seeking additional arrangers for its planned Singapore initial public offering (IPO) after Bank of America Corp walked away from the deal. The property trust, backed by HNA Group Co, is aiming to raise over S$400 million and is expected to delay the listing until autumn. The company is reaching out to investment banks to gauge interest in taking a senior role on the deal, with DBS Group Holdings also involved. The IPO's timing is uncertain, with the current timeline likely to be at least delayed until autumn.

site_title: China July official factory PMI dips to 51.4; slightly below expectations
summary: China's manufacturing sector growth slowed to 51.4 in July, slightly below expectations. The official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) was down from June's 51.7, but still above the 50-point mark. This reinforces the expectation of a slight cooling of the world's second-largest economy in the coming months due to rising borrowing costs and regulatory clampdowns. China's first-half economic growth was stronger than expected at 6.9%, but economists expect a slowdown in the second half.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.2 per cent up on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 5.21 points to 3,335.96, opening 0.2% higher on Monday, driven by flat US stocks last week. About 84 million shares changed hands, with Lion Gold being the most actively traded counter. Gainers outnumbered losers 83 to 44, as Japan's Topix index swung between gains and losses, while Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index gained 0.3%.

site_title: What's left of Noble Group as trader retreats to its Asian roots
summary: Noble Group Ltd, a Hong Kong-based commodity trader, is significantly downsizing its global ambitions and shifting focus to its Asian roots in a last-ditch effort to survive. The company is selling its North American gas & power unit to Mercuria Energy Group for US$248 million and seeking buyers for its global oil liquids business. Noble's remaining businesses include marketing rights to Indonesian coal, LNG trading capabilities, and stakes in Australian and Mongolian coal mines, with a market value of less than US$400 million.

site_title: Oil hits highest since May on tighter US market, Venezuela sanctions risk
summary: Oil prices rose to their highest levels since May, with Brent crude futures trading up 18 cents or 0.3% at $52.70 per barrel, and US WTI crude futures up 11 cents or 0.2% at $49.82 per barrel. The gains follow a 10% rise since the last OPEC meeting and a dip in US oil output, with US crude oil inventories falling by almost 10% from their March peaks. The threat of US sanctions on Venezuela's oil sector also contributed to the price increase.

site_title: 'Monkey Bike' nears extinction as Japan cuts tailpipe emissions
summary: Japan is set to phase out the 50cc motorcycle, known as "Monkey Bikes," due to stricter emissions regulations by 2020. The iconic Honda Z-Series, which has been in production for 50 years, will be discontinued in August. Sales of 50cc motorcycles have declined 94% in Japan since 1982, with only Honda, Yamaha, and Suzuki still producing models. The regulations, adopted from the European Union, require on-board systems to ensure engines run cleanly for at least 20,000 kilometers, adding significant costs to the vehicles.

site_title: HSBC says H1 profit rose 5%, announces up to US$2b share buyback
summary: HSBC reported a 5% increase in pretax profit to $10.2 billion in the first half of 2017, beating analyst estimates. The bank announced a potential $2 billion share buyback, bringing the total to $5.5 billion since 2016. HSBC's capital base has grown, allowing it to maintain dividend payouts and strengthen its financial position. The bank's common equity tier 1 ratio increased to 14.7%, and it expects to repatriate $8 billion from its US subsidiary.

site_title: Second typhoon batters Taiwan; financial markets open on Monday
summary: Typhoon Haitang made landfall in southern Taiwan, battering central and southern parts of the island with torrential rain and possible flooding and landslides. The storm, the second to hit Taiwan in 24 hours, forced the cancellation of over 40 flights and injured more than 100 people. Financial markets and businesses in Taipei will operate normally, but Kaohsiung will remain shut. This is the first time Taiwan has issued alerts for two storms simultaneously in 50 years. Typhoon Nesat, which hit the island on Saturday, has moved on to China's Fujian province.

images.alt_text: The second storm to hit Taiwan in 24 hours battered southern and central parts of the island on Monday after Typhoon Nesat injured more than 100 people and shut businesses at the weekend.

site_title: US to cut 755 US diplomatic staff in Russia, says Putin
summary: US President Vladimir Putin announced that the US will cut 755 diplomatic staff in Russia, in response to the US Congress' backing of new sanctions against the Kremlin. This decision comes after Russia demanded the US reduce its diplomatic presence in Russia to 455 people by September 1. Putin warned that this move would lead to a prolonged gridlock in US-Russia ties, raising the stakes between the two nations.

site_title: Motorcar, fitness club sectors among most notorious in losses incurred by consumers due to closures: Case
summary: The Consumers Association of Singapore (Case) reported that the motorcar industry incurred the highest amount of prepayment losses, totaling S$2.74 million, from January 2014 to June 2017. The fitness club industry followed with S$1.39 million in losses. The association warned that the risk of business insolvency may increase with the current uncertain economic outlook, urging consumers to be more aware of the risks involved when making advance payments to businesses. Over 2,000 complaints from consumers with reported losses of S$8.35 million have been received by Case.

images.alt_text: For example, when fitness chain California Fitness ceased operations in 2015, Case received about 600 consumer complaints with about S$1.09 million of reported losses.
Angela Tan

site_title: White economic privilege is alive and well despite its perceived loss
summary: A study of 50 years of household income data reveals that the income gap between black and white Americans remains unchanged, with black households earning an average of 55% as much as white households at the 20th and 40th percentiles. Despite initiatives to combat racism, the gap persists, with median white households holding 13 times the wealth of median black households. This perpetuates the consequences of centuries of social and economic injustice, contradicting claims that white economic privilege has been lost.

site_title: NZ business confidence drops in July: ANZ bank
summary: New Zealand business confidence dropped in July, falling to a net 19.4% from 24.8% in the previous poll, according to an ANZ Bank survey. This decline was attributed to winter-related expectations and concerns over rising construction costs and labor shortages. Dairy prices provided some support, with 40.3% of respondents expecting their businesses to grow in the next 12 months, down from 42.8% last month. The drop in confidence is consistent with a regular winter blip, as ANZ economists noted.

site_title: Venezuela vote triggers deadly violence in the streets
summary: Venezuela's controversial vote for a new "Constituent Assembly" sparked deadly violence, with at least nine people killed and troops and protesters attacking each other. The vote, championed by President Nicolas Maduro, aims to rewrite the nation's constitution and dissolve the opposition-controlled congress. The opposition had called for a boycott and mass demonstrations, and international criticism has led to sanctions and flight cancellations. The US, EU, and Latin American countries have rejected the election, fearing it would destroy Venezuelan democracy.

site_title: Old enemies unite in Malaysia as Najib woos Islamic heartland
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak has been wooing the country's Islamic heartland, uniting old enemies in the process. Kuala Terengganu, a predominantly Muslim city, has seen a new cinema open, featuring Hollywood blockbusters with infra-red cameras to monitor couples. This is the first such cinema to open in more than 20 years, signaling Najib's efforts to win over the region. The move is seen as a significant shift in Najib's strategy to regain support in the Islamic heartland.

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak speaks during the India-Malaysia Business Forum event in New Delhi on April 3, 2017

site_title: TungLok leverages on healthy balance sheet to stay relevant in challenging market
summary: TungLok Restaurants, a Singapore-based Chinese cuisine group, aims to stay relevant in a challenging F&B market by leveraging its healthy balance sheet. The company has accelerated efforts to refresh dining concepts, streamline operations, and expand services to drive growth. TungLok achieved a successful turnaround in 2015 and has strengthened its balance sheet, with a net working capital of S$8.6 million and cash and bank balances of S$15 million. The group plans to focus on new geographical markets, expand services, and promote productivity to deliver differentiated values to customers.

site_title: Saudi unemployment rate climbs to 12.7%
summary: Saudi Arabia's unemployment rate rose to 12.7% in the first quarter of 2017, surpassing its 2030 target of 7% under Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's Vision 2030 reform plan. The economy has struggled with low oil prices, and authorities are introducing new fees and sector restrictions to encourage the employment of Saudis. Despite a 433,000 job creation average over the last 10 years, most new jobs have been taken by non-Saudis, making up for their departure from the market. The data highlights the main challenge for the reform program: job creation.

site_title: Capital markets increasingly sought after in aircraft financing
summary: Capital markets are increasingly sought after in aircraft financing, surpassing commercial banks as the primary source of funding. According to Boeing's 2017 report, capital markets will account for 31% of funding, while commercial banks will make up 33%. Funding requirements are expected to jump to US$126 billion in 2017 and US$185 billion by 2021, with capital markets playing a significant role in meeting these demands.

site_title: French minister promises troops the means to tackle jihadists
summary: French Defence Minister Florence Parly has assured troops in the Sahel region that they will have the necessary means to carry out their mission against jihadist insurgents. She made the promise during a two-day tour of three Sahel countries, including Chad, Niger, and Mali, as part of a joint G5 Sahel force initiative. The force aims to combat terrorism and trafficking in the region, and France is seeking international support for the estimated €423 million cost. German Defence Minister Ursula von der Leyen is also joining the tour to show support for the initiative.

site_title: Promises alone won't kill the combustion engine
summary: European governments have promised to ban the sale of cars with combustion engines by 2030, 2040, and 2040 respectively, but it's unclear if these promises will lead to a significant shift towards electric vehicles. Currently, only 10% of electric vehicle buyers actually purchase one, and range limitations and charging infrastructure concerns remain major obstacles. Financial incentives have shown limited impact, and governments are hesitant to force consumers to adopt electric cars without a proven market demand. The transition to electric vehicles will likely take time, and it's possible that gas-burning and hybrid car sales may even increase in the short term.

site_title: Shell shutters Europe's largest refinery after fire
summary: Shell has temporarily shut down Europe's largest refinery in Rotterdam after a pre-dawn fire broke out at a power station. The fire was brought under control by 6:00am, and the company is shutting down all units due to a power outage. The shutdown is expected to take hours or several days to restart, with no toxic materials released during the fire. The refinery, which processes over 400,000 barrels of petroleum products daily, is unlikely to cause significant fuel shortages. Shell has not confirmed the cause of the fire, which is being investigated.

site_title: China must decide on further action against North Korea: US ambassador to UN
summary: US Ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley says China must decide if it will back stronger UN sanctions on North Korea after two long-range missile tests this month. Haley states that any new resolution "of no value" if it doesn't increase international pressure. The US has flown supersonic B-1B bombers as a show of force and is making progress with China on a draft resolution. China has not responded to a request for comment, and diplomats expect a showdown between the US and Russia over the test.

site_title: Europe's eastern rebels expose next fault line for EU leaders
summary: EU leaders are warning Poland over its plans to weaken the judiciary's independence, sparking a battle between European Union regulators and the Polish government. The government's "authoritarian drift" is threatening the rule of law, democracy, and fundamental rights in the country. EU leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Emmanuel Macron, are defending Europe's values and institutions against populist leaders in Poland and Hungary. The European Commission has threatened to suspend Poland's EU voting rights if the country fails to address its democratic concerns, with some calling for the use of Article 7, a procedure that could lead to economic sanctions.

site_title: Raffles Medical Q2 earnings up 0.5% to S$16.8m, revenue up 1% to S$120.1m
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 0.5% increase in net profit to S$16.76 million for its second quarter, driven by a 1% rise in revenue to S$120.1 million. Despite softer demand from foreign patients, the patient load continued to grow. Earnings per share remained flat at 0.96 Singapore cents, while the net asset value per share increased to 39.53 Singapore cents. The group's shares finished at S$1.275 on Friday.

images.alt_text: Despite the softer than expected demand from foreign patients, patient load continued to grow, giving a lift to results for Raffles Medical Group in its second quarter.

site_title: For some New Yorkers, North Korea threat revives Cold War memories
summary: North Korea's recent test of an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) has sparked concerns among New Yorkers, with some experts suggesting the city could be within range of such an attack. The idea of a nuclear holocaust is surreal for younger generations, but a reminder for older New Yorkers of the city's Cold War-era nuclear bomb shelters. The city's 17,000 bunkers remain a relic of the past, but the threat is a stark reminder of the nuclear threat still looming.

site_title: UK trade boss denies free- movement deal as Cabinet rift widens
summary: UK Trade Secretary Liam Fox denies claims of a free movement deal for three years after Brexit, saying it would "not keep faith" with voters. The move exposes a rift in the government's Brexit strategy, with Chancellor Philip Hammond suggesting a two- to three-year transition period. Economist Gerard Lyons criticizes Hammond's plan, saying it would alleviate concerns and calls for a two-year transition. Luxembourg's Prime Minister Xavier Bettel warns the UK could face a £50 billion bill to leave the EU, amid divisions in Britain's negotiating position.

site_title: Leadership race heats up at Bank of Italy
summary: The Bank of Italy is seeking a new leader to oversee its struggling recovery and review the European Central Bank's stimulus. Competition is heating up, with finance minister Pier Carlo Padoan and ECB Supervisory Board member Ignazio Angeloni among the potential candidates. The position, which comes with a seat on the ECB's Governing Council, is seen as crucial given Italy's slow growth and acute banking problems. A female candidate, economist Lucrezia Reichlin, may also be in the running, making her the central bank's first female governor in its over 120-year history.

site_title: Developed markets into sustained expansion: BlackRock
summary: Developed economies are experiencing sustained growth at above 2% rates since the 2009 financial crisis, driven by low financial market volatility and fewer near-term risks. BlackRock, a prominent investment firm, attributes this growth to a phase of expansion rather than reflation, citing a "synchronised growth story" globally. The firm favours the momentum style factor in today's low-volatility environment and believes investors are under-invested in equities, which are cheaper than they appear.

site_title: Swimming: A star is born - Dressel emerges from Phelps' shadow
summary: Caeleb Dressel became the first swimmer to win three world gold medals in one session, then matched Michael Phelps' record tally of seven golds at the world championships in Budapest. Dressel won three individual titles in the 50m, 100m freestyle, and 100m butterfly, plus four relay golds, including the men's 4x100m medley relay on Sunday. This achievement cements Dressel as a rising star in the swimming world, emerging from Phelps' shadow as a dominant force in the sport.

site_title: Construction boom reaches China's small cities
summary: China's construction boom is reaching smaller cities, including Bengbu, where luxury homes and high-rise condominiums are being built at a rapid pace. Despite a surge in demand, inventories of unsold homes remain high, with 102 million sq m of housing left over, down only 7.1% from the previous year. This poses a worry for policymakers ahead of a Communist Party congress, as the market may be heading towards a bubble. Analysts attribute the growth to cheap credit and lax regulations in smaller cities.

site_title: Xi calls for building of elite force at military parade
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has called for the transformation of the country's military into an elite force, as he oversaw a military parade in Inner Mongolia to mark 90 years since the founding of the People's Liberation Army. Xi emphasized the need for the military to "unswervingly" back the ruling Communist Party and follow its orders. The parade featured advanced jets, stealth fighters, and aircraft carriers, and was attended by thousands of troops. Xi's comments come as China continues its ambitious modernization program, which includes investments in technology and new equipment, as well as cuts to troop numbers.

site_title: Here's to continued US partisan conflict
summary: The US stock market continues to rise despite historically high levels of partisan conflict, with the Partisan Conflict Index at an all-time high. The market's indifference to political upheaval may be attributed to the Federal Reserve's low-interest rate policy, the "bad economic news is good news for stocks" theme, and the "buy in anticipation, sell on news" theme. Additionally, the presence of liquidity in the system and the readiness of central banks to rescue the financial system if needed may also contribute to the market's resilience.

site_title: Samsung faces tougher challenges ahead despite record profits: analysts
summary: Samsung Electronics has reported record-breaking profits of 14.1 trillion won (S$17.1 billion) in the second quarter, a 73% jump from the previous year, driven by strong sales of its Galaxy S8 smartphone and demand for its memory chips. The company's semiconductor business, which provides chips to other companies including Apple, was a key driver of the growth. However, analysts warn that Samsung faces tougher challenges ahead, including questions over its leadership and the growing threat from Chinese rivals in the global semiconductor market.

site_title: Repairing Obamacare tricky but not impossible
summary: The Affordable Care Act (ACA) faces significant challenges as the 2018 open enrollment period approaches, with many insurers proposing rate increases due to uncertainty over the law's future. Despite its survival of Supreme Court decisions and Republican attempts to repeal it, the law still has major problems, including high prices and lack of choice in many areas. To address these concerns, experts agree that stabilizing the insurance market is crucial, and solutions such as guaranteeing continued funding for cost-sharing reductions and reinsurance are being explored. However, the Trump administration's reluctance to help and the lack of bipartisan agreement on key issues, including rising prescription drug prices, remain major obstacles.

site_title: Building on the potential of digitalisation
summary: Bentley Systems' CEO Greg Bentley emphasizes the potential of digitalization in infrastructure design and development. The Singapore Land Authority is using Bentley software to create a high-resolution 3D model of the entire country as part of Singapore's Smart Nation initiative. Digitalization enables data and systems to be linked, allowing for uses beyond the data's original purpose, according to Bentley. This project showcases the power of digitalization in infrastructure development, with Bentley seeing it as a significant step forward in the sector.

site_title: Pakistan's ruling party vows smooth transition for new leader
summary: Pakistan's President Mamnoon Hussain has called a special parliamentary session to install Shahid Khaqan Abbasi as interim prime minister after Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif was ousted by the Supreme Court. The ruling Muslim League-Nawaz party vows a smooth transition, with Abbasi expected to serve for less than two months before his brother Shahbaz takes over. The move aims to ease political upheaval and address Pakistan's economic and security challenges, including worsening ties with the US and India, and persistent militant attacks.

site_title: The promise of artificial intelligence is not assured
summary: Singapore's AI.SG initiative aims to foster AI innovation and adoption to boost labor productivity by 41% and double the economy in 13 years. The program focuses on developing holistic AI solutions, partnering with local SMEs, and addressing societal implications. Mindsets must change for AI adoption to be uniform and rapid across industries. The program employs interdisciplinary teams, including psychologists, social scientists, and lawyers, to tackle concerns and craft comprehensive solutions. However, the high cost of adoption and regulatory challenges remain significant hurdles to widespread AI adoption.

site_title: 'Spot the theme, not the sector' when investing
summary: Investors often rely too heavily on sector-specific indices, underperforming their benchmarks, says Christopher Versace, chief investment officer of Tematica Research. Instead, thematic investing, which looks at broader trends and shifts in economics, demographics, and technology, can be more effective in maximizing returns. Tematica Research identifies sustainable market shifts, or "investment themes," such as the "Ageing of the Population" and "Fattening of the Population," which investors can capitalize on by focusing on companies well-positioned to address these themes.

images.alt_text: "We see sector investing as dead. When we look at the vast majority of institutional investors who follow a sector-based strategy, they tend to underperform their benchmark, like the S&P 500." - Christopher Versace, chief investment officer of Tematica Research.

site_title: Those weird, wacky hobbies in Finland
summary: In Finland, a country known for its eccentric sports, thousands gathered in Hyrynsalmi for the 20th annual Swamp Soccer World Championships. The event, which began in 1998, has grown to include over 200 teams competing in the unusual game. Finland's unique culture, with its emphasis on outdoor activities and a relaxed national character, has contributed to the country's wacky sports scene. The nation's history of athletic success, including a "golden age" of elite sports in the early 20th century, has given way to a new era of quirky competitions, including the Wife Carrying World Championships and Air Guitar World Championships.

site_title: Hutchison to sell HK fixed-line business to I Squared for US$1.9b

site_title: Pyongyang's missile threat, opposition disunity could aid Abe
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's approval ratings have slumped below 30%, sparking speculation about his potential resignation. However, recent events may help him stay in power, including North Korea's missile launch and the sudden resignation of Japan's opposition leader. Abe is expected to announce a Cabinet reshuffle, with a new defence minister being a top priority. Analysts believe that Abe's "Abenomics" policies could be at risk if he steps down, but a snap general election may be called to maintain the LDP-led government's majority.

site_title: Bombardier limits cash burn, sees earnings near top of forecast
summary: Bombardier Inc. reported a surprise adjusted profit of two cents a share in the second quarter, beating analyst estimates, and limited cash burn to $570 million, below expectations. The company reaffirmed its full-year targets, including a "low single digit" revenue increase and cash flow use of $750-1 billion. Pre-tax earnings for the year are expected to be in the top half of a previously disclosed range of $580-630 million. CEO Alain Bellemare's turnaround plan is showing progress, with two major aircraft programs, the C Series and Global 7000, on track to deliver results.

site_title: Property sector leads list of buyouts from Singapore Exchange
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has seen a surge in buyouts, with the property sector leading the way. Analysts attribute this trend to low valuations, suggesting that firms are exiting the market to capitalize on better opportunities elsewhere. Tech, industrials, oil and gas sectors are also expected to see further mergers and acquisitions (M&A) activity, driven by low valuations.

summary: Air France suspended flights to Venezuela from July 30 to August 1 due to safety concerns ahead of a controversial election in the crisis-hit country. The carrier prioritized customer and staff safety, following international criticism and deadly violence.

site_title: Dollar down, euro up as US GDP data fails to sway market
summary: The US dollar fell against the euro and other major currencies as US second-quarter GDP data largely met expectations, with US GDP growth picking up to 2.6% in the second quarter. The euro rose nearly 3% against the dollar this month and over 11.5% this year, with some analysts attributing the dollar's weakness to political uncertainty and expectations for US fiscal stimulus and interest rate increases.

site_title: Australia thwarts plan for 'Islamic-inspired' bomb attack on plane
summary: Australian authorities foiled a plot for an "Islamic-inspired" bomb attack on a plane, arresting four men and tightening security measures at airports. The plot was thwarted in counter-terrorism raids across Sydney, with increased security presence and potential for more significant disruptions expected as traffic picks up during the week. The AFP believes the attack is inspired by Islamic terrorism, but further investigation is needed to determine the specifics.

site_title: Nam Cheong calls for bondholders to form committee
summary: Nam Cheong, a Singapore-based shipbuilder, has formed an informal steering committee with bondholders to pursue a restructuring of its liabilities. The committee, consisting of 5-9 bondholders, aims to ensure a fair and equitable process for all stakeholders. Interested parties can register with the Securities Investors Association of Singapore by August 4, 2017. The company has set aside funds to reimburse legal fees and expenses.

site_title: Inspiring young people to inspire others
summary: Wendy Chua-Sullivan, founder of the Wand Inspiration Network (WIN), was inspired to create the organization after experiencing personal struggles, including being retrenched and divorced, in 1999-2000. WIN was established in 2003 and aims to inspire young people to inspire others.
