The project will be produced in collaboration with Chris Licht, Colbert's executive producer on "The Late Show".

site_title: Apple may skirt IPhone tariffs as Foxconn comes to the US
summary: Apple may avoid iPhone tariffs as Foxconn invests $10 billion in a US factory in Wisconsin, set to create 10,000 jobs. The factory will produce LCD display panels for Apple, potentially discouraging lawmakers from introducing import taxes on products like the iPhone. Foxconn's investment in Wisconsin, in House Speaker Paul Ryan's home district, may gain goodwill and discourage a border tax on imports. This move could discourage a trade war with China, where Apple's contract manufacturers assemble gadgets.

images.alt_text: Apple Inc likes to say it supports 2 million US jobs. Plans by the company's main manufacturing partner for a US$10 billion factory in Wisconsin will add at least 10,000 more, helping Apple fend off the threat of import tariffs on its most important product, the iPhone.

site_title: UOB's Q2 net profit up 5.5%; net interest margin improves to 1.75%
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a 5.5% increase in its Q2 net profit to S$845 million ($2 per share), driven by an improvement in its net interest margin to 1.75%. The bank also declared an interim dividend of 35 Singapore cents per share. This marks a 5.5% increase in its six-month net profit to S$1.7 billion.

images.alt_text: United Overseas Bank grew its second-quarter net profit by 5.5 per cent to S$845 million, or $2 per share on an annualised basis.

site_title: Hillary to explain 'What Happened' in new book
summary: Hillary Clinton is set to release a new book, "What Happened," in September, where she will explain her shock electoral defeat to Donald Trump in 2016. The book will reveal her personal thoughts and feelings during the campaign, including mistakes made and how she coped with the loss. Clinton will also double down on her belief that Russian interference cost her the White House, and describe the intense personal experience of the election. The book is her most personal memoir yet and will be published by Simon and Schuster.

images.alt_text: Defeated Democratic White House hopeful Hillary Clinton promises to let her guard down and explain what happened in her shock electoral defeat to Donald Trump, including the mistakes she made, in a book to published in September.

site_title: IndoAgri Q2 profit more than triples to 99.3b rupiah
summary: IndoAgri Q2 profit more than triples to 99.3 billion rupiah, driven by improved production and a Brazil sugar operation. Revenue rose 15.4% to 4.1 trillion rupiah, with a 70 billion rupiah profit from joint ventures. This marks a significant improvement from the same period last year, where the company posted a net loss. The company is not declaring dividends for the current quarter.

site_title: US dollar bounces back after hitting long-term lows, bolstered by US data
summary: The US dollar rallied after solid economic data, bouncing back from months-long lows. Durable goods orders rose more than expected, and business spending on equipment suggested economic growth in the second quarter. The euro and British pound fell against the US dollar, while the Canadian dollar reached a two-year high. The US dollar's recovery was driven by welcome news and a decrease in uncertainty surrounding President Trump's proposed fiscal stimulus, which had hit the dollar in recent months.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip as AstraZeneca tumble drags indexes lower
summary: European shares slipped on Thursday as AstraZeneca's 15.7% drop following a failed lung cancer trial dominated trading, outweighing well-received earnings from firms like Roche, Diageo, and AB InBev. The Stoxx 600 index fell 0.1% and euro zone bluechips edged down 0.2%. Solid results from Diageo and AB InBev were not enough to lift broad indexes. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended the day with a 0.1% gain, while Germany's DAX dropped 0.8%.

site_title: Resale price index of public housing in Singapore slips
summary: The HDB Resale Price Index (RPI) in Singapore decreased by 0.1% to 133.7 in the second quarter, compared to 133.9 in the first quarter. Resale transactions rose 32.5% to 6,001 cases. The HDB will offer 3,850 BTO flats and 1,394 unsold balance flats in August.

images.alt_text: Blocks of HDB flats in Singapore.
Angela Tan

site_title: 10 hurt in freak Istanbul storm
summary: A violent thunderstorm struck Istanbul, injuring at least 10 people, including two seriously, with hailstones the size of golfballs. The storm paralyzed traffic, caused flash floods, and uprooted 230 trees. Several fires broke out but were quickly extinguished. City officials mobilized over 7,000 people to deal with the aftermath, and further storms were possible in the night. This incident follows recent heavy rains and flooding in the city, which occurred just nine days prior.

site_title: Qatar Airways sticks to jet orders despite crisis
summary: Qatar Airways will proceed with its existing plane orders from Boeing and Airbus, despite the ongoing crisis that has led to a loss of passengers. The airline's financial targets may be impacted, but it remains "in good shape" as it opens new routes. Qatar Transport Minister Jassim Saif Ahmed Al Sulaiti plans to make a case to the International Civil Aviation Organization to restore the country's access to six or seven international flight corridors, which would mitigate the economic fallout from the crisis.

site_title: SGX to allow dual-class structures from developed markets for secondary listings
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has clarified its secondary listing framework to allow companies with dual-class share (DCS) structures from developed markets to hold a secondary listing in Singapore. This decision applies to companies with primary listings in markets recognized by index providers FTSE and MSCI, which includes 22 developed markets. The companies must maintain their primary listing and make continuous disclosures through SGX, with no additional post-listing conditions.

site_title: France unleashes a decade of Italian anger since Zidane headbutt
summary: France has offered to nationalize the STX shipyard in Saint-Nazaire if Italian company Fincantieri doesn't accept its government's conditions, sparking Italian anger and concerns about the country's inferior status compared to France. The move has strained Franco-Italian relations, with Italy threatening to walk away from the deal. The controversy highlights the competition for jobs, security, and glory between the two nations, potentially dampening hopes for tighter EU cooperation.

site_title: US: Tech, transports drag on Wall Street; Dow hits record
summary: US stocks closed slightly lower on Thursday despite a record high for the Dow industrials, due to a decline in technology and transportation shares. The Dow Jones Transport Average fell 3.1% after a negative outlook from United Parcel Service, while the S&P 500 technology sector dropped 0.8% despite Facebook's strong earnings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 85.54 points to 21,796.55, with Verizon's strong quarterly earnings and a surge in Facebook shares contributing to the record high.

site_title: S Africa raises forecast for record corn harvest
summary: South Africa has raised its forecast for a record corn harvest, expecting 15.97 million tonnes this season, a 2.2% increase from the previous estimate. This surpasses the previous record of 7.78 million tonnes set in 2016 due to drought. The forecast is higher than a Bloomberg survey of analysts, with 9.51 million tonnes of white corn and 6.46 million tonnes of yellow corn expected.

site_title: Bocker had 'gift of building industry-defining businesses': Blibros
summary: Former Singapore Exchange (SGX) CEO Magnus Böcker, a Swedish-born entrepreneur, died on July 26 at 55 after a battle with cancer. Böcker was known for his deal-making skills and led the creation of the Nordic exchange group OMX and its merger with Nasdaq. He later took over SGX in 2009 and aimed to raise the exchange into a best-in-class platform in Asia, but his tenure was marked by unsuccessful mergers and controversies. Böcker was also a firm believer in corporate governance and responsible investing, and left a lasting impact on the Singaporean financial industry.

site_title: Forget casinos, Singapore's Indian visitors are boarding ships
summary: Singapore has become a popular departure point for Indian cruise-ship passengers, with about 100,000 Indians sailing from the city-state last year, a 29% increase from 2015. This has bolstered sales for cruise operators, including Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd and Genting Hong Kong Ltd. India is now the biggest market for cruises departing from Singapore, according to the Singapore Tourism Board.

site_title: Chinese electric car startups mull alliance to save money, time
summary: China's electric vehicle startups, including Singulato Motors and CHJ Automotive, are considering an alliance to pool resources and develop joint technology. The move aims to save money and time, as the industry faces increasing competition and stricter regulations. Four other companies, Hongxing Automobile Manufacturing Co, Aiways, WM Motor, and Singulato Motors, have discussed the alliance for months. This consolidation is seen as a response to the growing competition and regulatory challenges in the Chinese EV market.

site_title: Oil rises with gasoline futures to highest since May
summary: Oil prices rose to an eight-week high, with US gasoline futures reaching their highest since May 24, due to a rally in US gasoline futures and Opec members' pledge to reduce exports. US crude inventories declined by 7.2 million barrels, while Saudi Arabia and Kuwait plan to limit crude exports. US shale producers also announced plans to cut spending. Benchmark Brent futures rose 1% to $51.49 a barrel, while US WTI crude gained 0.6% to $49.04, reaching a high since May 30.

site_title: Who are the true monsters here?
summary: Taiwanese horror-comedy Mon Mon Mon Monsters, directed by Giddens Ko, tells the story of a high school student Lin Shu-wei who becomes embroiled in a gang of bullies and together they abuse the elderly and commit heinous crimes. The film is a genre-hybrid of satire and splatter-gore, serving as an indictment of a society in apocalyptic breakdown. It explores themes of adolescent impulses, peer pressure, and the breakdown of adult authority, leaving the audience questioning who the true monsters are - the heartless humans or the perpetrators of violence.

site_title: VW defends discussions with rivals amid cartel probe
summary: Volkswagen (VW) has defended its practice of discussing technical developments with rivals, stating that such conversations foster innovation and benefit customers by offering solutions at lower prices. VW claims that these discussions are a common practice and contribute to the faster development of innovative solutions. The company made this statement after an extraordinary supervisory meeting.

site_title: Pence's Eastern Europe trip has Russia hanging over it
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence is set to embark on a tour of Eastern Europe from July 30 to August 2, amid tensions with Russia over US sanctions. The visit comes after the US House of Representatives voted to impose new sanctions on Moscow, which has been condemned by Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov. The sanctions, if passed by the Senate, would put President Donald Trump in a difficult position, given his apparent pro-Moscow leanings. The trip will include stops in Estonia, Georgia, and Montenegro, and will be closely watched by Eastern European allies and Moscow.

site_title: As sentiment swings bullish, it pays to be ready when it's bearish
summary: Investors are feeling optimistic about the economy, with global growth picking up and low inflation, leading to new highs in stock and bond markets. However, conservative investors should exercise caution as bull markets often end due to financial shocks, excessive debt, and imbalances. Famed debt investor Howard Marks warns that it's better to be cautious early on, rather than too late, and that financial market excesses are already apparent.

site_title: Singdollar rallies to 2017 high of 1.3565 against US dollar following FOMC statement
summary: The Singapore dollar (S$) surged to a 2017 high of 1.3565 against the US dollar following the US Federal Reserve's dovish statement, leaving interest rates unchanged. The FOMC addressed concerns over inflation weakness, with the probability of a December rate hike dropping to 40%. The S$ has strengthened to 6.56% against the US$ year-to-date, and is now trading at a new low of 1.3565, following the broad dollar index's 0.7% fall.

site_title: Singapore-dollar bond market still robust despite Nam Cheong default
summary: Singapore-dollar bond market remains robust despite the recent default by Nam Cheong, a Singapore-dollar bond market that has seen 13 issues worth S$2.5 billion default since 2015. Investors are unfazed due to the liquid market and pricing-in debt woes of the oil and gas/offshore marine sector. The SGD market has seen strong demand for investment-grade and high-yield issues, with the Markit SGD corporates' total-return index reaching a new high. Analysts expect the market to continue being vigorous in the near future, driven by low swap offer rates and a weak US dollar.

images.alt_text: Singapore-dollar bond prices remain strong despite last week's S$365 million default by Nam Cheong, another offshore support vessel-focused group that has become insolvent.

site_title: Arts patronage now
summary: Companies are now supporting artists in complex and sophisticated ways, going beyond traditional patronage. Tiger Beer partnered with Indian inventor Anirudh Sharma to create Air-Ink, a pen that uses air pollution to create art. The company also partnered with artists to raise awareness for environmental causes. UOB, on the other hand, focuses on traditional art competitions and outreach programs, including a Painting of the Year award and art education initiatives. Canon engages artists to create cute and charming images, as well as conceptual art, and provides tools to help local artists hone their craft. These collaborations aim to develop the arts ecosystem and inspire social change.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: US startup Slack raising funds in VC investments
summary: US startup Slack is raising $250 million in a new funding round, valuing the company at over $5 billion. The investment, led by SoftBank Group and Accel, reflects a surge in venture-capital investments in Silicon Valley. This is part of a growing trend of large funding rounds for technology startups, with 34 deals over $100 million in the second quarter of this year, nearly triple the number in the first quarter.

site_title: Banks have vital role in fighting financial crime
summary: Banks play a crucial role in fighting financial crime, and in Singapore, the government, law enforcement agencies, and banks are working together to gather and share intelligence. The Anti-Money Laundering and Countering the Financing of Terrorism Industry Partnership (ACIP) aims to identify, assess, and mitigate financial crime. Banks like HSBC are participating in the partnership and implementing measures such as Know Your Customer (KYC) due diligence and using technology to detect potential financial crimes. The Singapore government is also exploring ways to improve KYC, including the use of MyInfo, a national digital platform.

site_title: Data analytics - breathing new life into Singapore's gloomy retail scene
summary: Singapore's retail scene is experiencing a downturn due to an ever-changing economy and volatile sales. However, leveraging data analytics and technology can be a game-changer. Retailers can empower non-analysts with data, invest in "smart" retail, and deliver a seamless shopping experience by integrating omnichannel data and using agile tools to visualize insights. This approach can help retailers understand customer preferences, allocate resources efficiently, and make data-driven decisions to drive sales and improve the customer experience.

site_title: SGX weighs in on governance worries at YuuZoo
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has weighed in on governance concerns at YuuZoo, a Singapore-listed social media and e-commerce company, amid a tit-for-tat dispute between Professor Mak Yuen Teen and the company. SGX wants a say in the selection of an independent third party to review claims and statements made by YuuZoo, including allegations by its former financial controller. The exchange seeks to ensure the independence and terms of reference of the review, and has called for the identity of the reviewer to be disclosed and the full report to be made available to SGX and other regulators.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Expect only the unexpected
summary: The T'ang Quartet, a Singaporean chamber group, has released its first album in 11 years, "Trampled Souls," with a quirky cover and surreal music videos. The album features the group's signature edgy and ambitious sound, and is their third studio effort. The quartet, consisting of Ang Chek Meng, Ng Yu-Ying, Leslie Tan, and Lionel Tan, continues to surprise fans with their unique style and artistic expression.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: US central bank keeps interest rates unchanged
summary: The US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, maintaining its benchmark rate between 1% and 1.25%. The central bank plans to roll back its massive $4.5 trillion balance sheet "relatively soon" to address persistently low inflation. Despite a strong economy, inflation remains below the 2% target, and the Fed's decision may be influenced by the upcoming leadership shake-up and President Trump's potential reappointment of Janet Yellen as Fed chair.

site_title: Swiss franc hits lowest since 2015; US$ gains ground
summary: The Swiss franc has fallen to its weakest since 2015, dropping by 2-3% against the dollar and euro, amid changing expectations of global monetary policy and tighter financial conditions. The US dollar recovered from 2½ year lows, driven by a policy statement from the US Federal Reserve. Analysts attribute the franc's decline to the euro's seven-month surge, which has raised concerns over European Central Bank policymakers' willingness to allow further euro strength. The dollar index has fallen 13% against the euro since January.

site_title: STI extends gains, lifted by local banks, US rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 17.99 points or 0.54% to a 3-year high of 3,354.71, driven by local banks OCBC, DBS, and UOB, which added 21 points to the index. OCBC reported a 22% rise in Q2 profit, while DBS and UOB gained 19.1% and 18.4% respectively. The US market's rally also contributed to the gains, with the FOMC keeping interest rates unchanged.

site_title: Growth-starved utilities find a new way of making money
summary: US utilities are exploring a new model to profit from America's solar and wind power boom. Companies like American Electric Power Co and NextEra Energy Inc are shifting away from power purchase agreements to buy renewable energy assets outright, recovering costs from customers through rates. This approach guarantees profits for utilities, but requires regulatory buy-in. The cost of building solar and wind farms has decreased, making ownership more attractive, with analysts citing a "big upside" for utilities. Regulatory approval is needed for the deals, which will impact the energy market.

site_title: US$1 trillion airport splurge puts S'pore, HK on notice
summary: A US$1 trillion global airport investment is set to disrupt the status quo in Singapore and Hong Kong, which have long been key transit points in Asia. Approximately half of this investment is going towards upgrading or building new airports in Asia, threatening the dominance of these cities. The surge in airport spending is driven by the increasing demand for air travel and the need for modern infrastructure to accommodate growing passenger numbers.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Stock analysts provide updates on three Singaporean companies: Suntec Reit, Mapletree Industrial Trust, and Viva Industrial Trust. Suntec Reit's Q1 results are in line with expectations, and analysts maintain a "hold" rating with higher target prices. Mapletree Industrial Trust's Q1 results exceed forecasts, leading to a higher target price. Viva Industrial Trust's solid Q2 results are within expectations, but its fair value is downgraded to S$0.895 due to current price levels exceeding its value. Meanwhile, Singapore Airlines is expected to report a Q1 profit of S$96 million, leading to a "hold" rating with a higher target price.

site_title: OCBC posts 22% jump in Q2 earnings
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 22% increase in Q2 net profit to S$1.08 billion, driven by strong performance in banking, wealth management, and insurance operations. Net interest income rose 7% and non-interest income grew 34%. Loans grew 11% and assets under management rose to US$89 billion. Despite this, CEO Samuel Tsien noted that the Singapore economy is subdued and loan demand is not strong domestically, with a forecast of single-digit growth for the full year.

site_title: Japan to hike tariffs on frozen beef imports from US, others: local media
summary: Japan plans to increase tariffs on frozen beef imports from the US and other countries to 50% starting August 1, as a 'safeguard' measure to protect domestic farmers. The move comes after US President Donald Trump aims to expand US exports to Japan. Frozen beef imports from the US have risen this year due to drought in Australia, which had previously been a major supplier. Japan's farm ministry did not immediately comment on the decision.

site_title: Bosideng's misfire in London reveals Chinese fashion's image problem
summary: Bosideng International Holdings Ltd, a Chinese clothing maker, has put its international expansion on hold after closing its unprofitable London store. The company, which makes down jackets for brands like Adidas, struggled to gain traction in the UK market, despite opening a £35 million store in Mayfair in 2012. Bosideng's misfire highlights the challenges for Chinese companies trying to tap overseas markets with their own brands, citing a need for a strong brand profile and story. The company is now focusing on its domestic market and exploring new business opportunities, including a partnership with Disney.

site_title: Greece is the latest word in Tiong Bahru
summary: Bakalaki Greek Taverna, a new Greek restaurant, has opened in Tiong Bahru, offering a large menu in a cheerful setting. It joins a growing list of specialty outlets in the area, including coffee shops, bakeries, and gourmet delis. This addition aims to bring Mediterranean hospitality to the gentrified neighborhood, providing another dining option for locals and visitors alike.

site_title: Noble tumbles 31% on loss warning, further asset sales
summary: NOBLE Group's shares plummeted 31.3% to S$0.395 after the company warned of a potential net loss of up to US$1.8 billion in the second quarter. Noble announced further asset sales to pare debt, including the sale of its global oil liquids business and a US$248 million deal to sell Noble Americas Gas & Power Corp. Moody's Investors Service raised concerns about Noble's financial stability, citing a high risk of default and the uncertainty of whether asset sales will generate sufficient proceeds to meet large debt maturities.

site_title: New EU rules threaten London managers' trillions in AUM
summary: New EU guidance threatens London-based investment firms' ability to manage trillions of euros of assets in other EU countries after Brexit. The guidance aims to prevent "empty shell" subsidiaries from being set up to continue serving European clients while relocating management staff to London. EU regulators have set a "substantial" margin for tasks that can be delegated, but the exact definition remains unclear, raising concerns about the impact on the delegation model and potential job losses in London, with estimates suggesting 5,000 to 10,000 jobs may move to the EU.

site_title: Kuwait joins UAE in pledge to cut oil output
summary: Kuwait and the UAE have pledged to cut oil output, following criticism from Saudi Arabia of Opec members who haven't fulfilled promised supply reductions. Kuwait has agreed to reduce oil sales to the US by 131,000 barrels a day, while the UAE will trim shipments by 10% starting in September. The moves come as oil producers face concerns of a global glut, with oil sliding into a bear market last month.

site_title: Nascent recovery in Sao Paulo's real estate market as vacancies drop
summary: Sao Paulo's real estate market is experiencing a nascent recovery, with vacancy rates for prime-quality commercial space dropping for the first time in five years. The decline is attributed to growing companies and investors taking advantage of low rents to upgrade facilities. Brookfield Asset Management and CBRE Group predict a steady restoration of the market to health, driven by a potential easing of interest rates and a "flight to quality." However, the fragile recovery remains vulnerable to new economic shocks and political turbulence, with Rio de Janeiro struggling with a record vacancy rate of 48% for office space.

site_title: BetterWorks chief, facing assault lawsuit, steps down
summary: BetterWorks Systems Inc CEO Kris Duggan has stepped down amid a lawsuit alleging physical assault by the company's founder. The move comes as Silicon Valley faces growing scrutiny of sexual harassment and misconduct by executives. Duggan will remain interim CEO until a replacement is found, then become president. Shona Brown, a former Google executive, will take on an executive chair role. The incident highlights a growing trend of women in tech speaking out against sexist behavior by men in power.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: China Aviation Oil reported a 4% rise in second-quarter net profit to US$24.6 million due to higher earnings from trading and optimization activities. Mapletree Commercial Trust's first-quarter results showed a 48.2% surge in Q1 income available for distribution to S$64.4 million. Sheng Siong's second-quarter net profit grew 6.3% to S$16.1 million, driven by contributions from new stores and improved consumer sentiment.

site_title: London's boroughs build fewer homes for poor
summary: London's boroughs with the highest property prices are failing to build low-cost homes for their poorest residents. A study by GMB found that six of the capital's 10 most expensive boroughs built below-average levels of low-cost rental housing in 2016-2017. Only 76 social homes were built in Kensington and Chelsea, where a recent fire killed 80 people, and no social homes were built in Kingston upon Thames and Harrow. Mayor Sadiq Khan aims to deliver 35% affordable housing, but critics say it's a slow and ineffective response to the city's housing crisis.

site_title: Completely meaningless, but cool to look at
summary: Charlize Theron stars as Lorraine Broughton, a British MI6 agent, in the Cold War thriller Atomic Blonde. Set in 1989, the film follows Lorraine as she navigates East Berlin to retrieve a list of undercover agents before the intelligence network is compromised. With her physical spectacle and hyper-stylized action sequences, Theron solidifies her status as an action star. The film, directed by David Leitch, prioritizes style over espionage, resulting in a C+ rating. Theron also co-produced the film, which features a blend of action and period soundtrack.

site_title: New acquisitions boost Ascendas Reit's Q1 DPU
summary: Ascendas Reit, a Singapore-based industrial landlord, reported a 10.9% increase in Q1 income available for distribution to S$118.5 million. The trust's distribution per unit (DPU) rose to 4.049 Singapore cents, up from 3.882 cents in the previous year. New acquisitions contributed to the growth, with gross revenue expanding 2.7% to S$213.3 million. Portfolio occupancy improved to 91.6%, despite a soft industrial property market.

site_title: Carrie Lam picks Singapore for her first foreign trip as HK Chief Executive
summary: Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam is set to visit Singapore for the first time as her first foreign trip, marking a strategic partnership between the two cities. During her two-day visit, Lam will study Singapore's innovative technology and land development policies, aiming to further develop economic ties between Hong Kong and Singapore within the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean).

images.alt_text: Mrs Lam will be the first Hong Kong Chief Executive to visit Singapore in nine years. During her Aug 2-3 trip, she is expected to look for opportunities to further develop economic ties between Singapore and Hong Kong and within Asean.

site_title: CWT seeks update over HNA's S$1.4b takeover as banks get jittery
summary: Chinese conglomerate HNA Holding Group has been silent on its proposed S$1.4 billion takeover of Singapore-listed logistics firm CWT Limited for over three months, sparking concerns from banks and investors. The deal faces scrutiny from Beijing and Chinese lenders, with HNA's debt totaling S$99.5 billion. Banks, including Malayan Banking Bhd and RHB Bank Bhd, are reviewing the transaction, and HNA has up to September 9 to fulfill all pre-conditions before proceeding. CWT's chairman has sought an update from HNA, and investors are urged to be cautious due to the deal's uncertain future.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Indian businesses blindsided by unclear GST rules as doubts linger
summary: India's nationwide sales tax, the Goods and Services Tax (GST), has left businesses confused about how to price their products due to its complex structure and ambiguous rules. The multi-rate tax, which ranges from 5 to 28%, has hurt sales and risks denting economic growth and government revenues. Companies such as airlines, car repair shops, and computer maker HP Inc are uncertain about how to apply the tax, leading to overcharging or undercharging. The tax's impact on the economy is being closely watched, with some officials worrying about the repercussions for Asia's third-largest economy.

site_title: Data protection panel proposes mandatory notice of breaches
summary: The Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) in Singapore has proposed a mandatory notice of breaches, requiring companies to inform affected individuals in the event of a personal data breach. The proposal, which involves notifying the PDPC within 72 hours of the incident, aims to let those affected act to protect themselves. The rule would apply to breaches involving 500 or more individuals, with an exception for cases where there is no risk of harm. The proposal is part of efforts to enhance data protection in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) has proposed a framework which would ensure that, in the event of a personal data breach where there was a risk of impact or harm, companies would have to inform the affected individuals as soon as possible.

site_title: Wildlife photo show in memory of Silvana
summary: A year after businesswoman Silvana Regina Sutanto's death in a fire in an Alaskan lodge, her children have set up the Silvana S Foundation to support less-privileged children and animal causes through the sale of her photographic works. Fifteen of her best snapshots will be exhibited and sold at the Visual Arts Centre from July 29 to Aug 6, with profits going to Noah's Ark Natural Animal Sanctuary. Silvana, a wildlife photography enthusiast, had won several awards for her photos before her passing, including a Gold Medal at the Royal Photographic Society Gold Medal Exhibitors' Association International Salon.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Deutsche Bank reports 10% fall in Q2 revenue
summary: Deutsche Bank reported a 10% decline in Q2 revenue to 6.62 billion euros, citing muted client activity in capital markets. This marks the latest in the bank's shrinking performance. Analysts had expected 7.1 billion euros. The decline is expected to continue this year, with operating revenue projected to slide.

site_title: 'For what I pay, I should be living in a palace'
summary: A class-action lawsuit has been filed against Bronstein Properties, a Manhattan landlord, alleging that the company has inflated rents in regulated apartments by falsely claiming to have performed renovations. The lawsuit claims that Bronstein has increased rents by as much as 141% without justification, with tenants paying up to $1,800 per month. The lawsuit is part of a broader effort by the Housing Rights Initiative to expose landlords who take advantage of the lack of transparency and oversight in the rent-regulated apartment system.

images.alt_text: At Ms Garcia's apartment, the wood parquet floor was old, the bathroom's tiles looked old, and the bathtub had not been sealed.

site_title: China willing to sacrifice growth to manage risks
summary: China is willing to sacrifice short-term economic growth to manage systemic risks, said Yang Weimin, vice-minister of Office of the Central Leading Group on Financial and Economic Affairs. The country's total debt has exceeded 250% of GDP, prompting regulators to launch a crackdown on riskier financing. Despite this, China's economy grew 6.9% in the second quarter, and policymakers aim to balance steady growth with risk prevention. The goal is to push state-owned firms to deleverage and safeguard economic growth. A long-term process is expected to manage debt levels and mitigate potential harm to the economy.

site_title: Khaw sets new reliability target for rail network
summary: Singapore's MRT system has seen a significant improvement in reliability, with the mean km between failure (MKBF) increasing to nearly 400,000 train-km in the first half of 2017, up from 133,000km in 2015. Minister Khaw Boon Wan has set a new target of 1,000,000 train-km by 2020, aiming for a 7.5 times increase in reliability. The number of major breakdowns has also decreased, from 10 in the first half of 2016 to three in the same period this year.

site_title: Supermarket stocks battered as orders flood Amazon Prime Now
summary: Amazon's Prime Now has launched in Singapore, offering 20,000 products with two-hour delivery. The move is expected to cannibalize demand on existing e-commerce platforms, with market watchers predicting a hit on online grocery stores like RedMart and honestbee, as well as one-stop consumer electronics chains. However, the impact on physical retail malls is unclear, with experts suggesting that landlords must adapt to changing consumer habits by introducing experiential and lifestyle concepts. Existing e-commerce players, such as supermarket chains, are already feeling the pressure, with Sheng Siong's shares sliding 4.5% on the news.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Prices and rentals of industrial space continue to moderate in Q2
summary: Industrial space prices and rentals in Singapore moderated in Q2 2017, with prices and rentals falling by 1.6% and 0.8% respectively from the previous quarter. Occupancy rates remained steady at 88.7%, while transaction volumes declined by 28% from a year ago. About 2.5 million sqm of industrial space is estimated to come on-stream in the second half of 2017 and 2018, putting downward pressure on occupancy rates and business costs for industrialists. The business park segment remained a bright spot, with rentals increasing by 2.1% from a year ago.

images.alt_text: Prices and rentals of industrial space continued to moderate in tandem with occupancy rates, according to JTC's latest quarterly market report of industrial properties released on Thursday.

site_title: SembMarine's Q2 profit halved to S$5.59 m
summary: SembCorp Marine's Q2 net profit plummeted 51.2% to S$5.59 million due to lower gross profit from offshore and marine businesses, mainly impacted by rig-building and offshore platform projects. Despite challenging operating conditions, the company's president and CEO noted early signs of a possible sectoral recovery, with stabilised offshore day rates and improving rig utilisation. SembMarine has received a request from Transocean to resume work on two drillship orders and plans to return leased yards to JTC.

site_title: Thai renewables firm BCPG looks homeward for US$1b spending budget
summary: Thai renewable energy firm BCPG plans to invest $1 billion over the next five years, with 40% focused on domestic projects. The company, which previously spent $1 billion on overseas projects, will shift its focus to Thailand, focusing on microgrids and biomass/solar power investments. To reach 1,000 MW of renewable generation capacity by 2020, BCPG will acquire 400 MW, with 150 MW in Thailand. The company aims to bring microgrid concept to Thailand, selling excess power back to local consumers, and sees opportunities in India and China despite regulatory challenges.

site_title: AstraZeneca shares plunge as the firm's lung cancer study fails
summary: AstraZeneca shares plummeted over 15% after a lung cancer study failed to show the combination of two immunotherapy drugs to be effective. The Mystic study, a closely watched trial, found the treatment no more effective than chemotherapy in patients with high levels of PD-L1 protein. The setback could be beneficial for Merck & Co, which is the only manufacturer of an immunotherapy treatment for previously untreated lung cancer.

site_title: Durable goods, trade data point to pick-up in Q2 growth
summary: US durable goods orders unexpectedly fell in June, but shipments of key equipment increased for a fifth consecutive month, supporting economic growth in the second quarter. The goods trade deficit narrowed in June, and retail and wholesale inventories rose, bolstering expectations of accelerated growth. The US central bank is expected to start winding down its portfolio "relatively soon."

site_title: SGX aims to be stronger multi-asset exchange in Asia-Pacific
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 10.9% increase in quarterly profit to S$85.2 million, driven by stronger securities and derivatives volumes. The exchange aims to become a stronger multi-asset exchange in the Asia-Pacific region by prioritizing its smaller business segments, including fixed income, foreign exchange, and commodity derivatives. SGX expects a robust initial public offering market in 2018 and is exploring post-trade offerings and technology initiatives to improve its services.

site_title: Amazon expects to create hundreds of Singapore jobs: Iswaran
summary: Amazon expects to create hundreds of jobs in Singapore over the next three years, primarily in managerial, technical, and operational roles. The company's Prime Now service, offering two-hour delivery of tens of thousands of items, will strengthen Amazon's cost-competitiveness and agility in Asia and globally. Prime Now is available in Singapore for free deliveries of S$40 or more, marking the company's first city in South-east Asia to introduce the service.

site_title: Programme launched to ease PMETs back into the workforce
summary: Singapore launched a programme to help professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs) re-enter the workforce after a few years out of it. NTUC Champion for Women and Family Desmond Choo emphasized the need for PMETs to actively address re-employment challenges, which may include accepting lower-level jobs and filling existing skills gaps.

images.alt_text: Local professionals, managers, executives and technicians (PMETs) looking to return to the workforce after a few years out of it must be active about breaching the main re-employment challenges, said NTUC Champion for Women and Family Desmond Choo on Thursday.

site_title: Q2 DPU for CRCT up 0.4%
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 0.4% increase in its second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.62 Singapore cents, driven by contributions from its recently acquired CapitaMall Xinnan in Chengdu. However, additional tax provisions due to a revenue basis change partially dampened the results. The trust also announced plans to sell its entire stake in CapitaMall Anzhen in Beijing for S$232 million to unlock value and generate S$180.9 million in net proceeds. The sale is expected to increase the trust's financial flexibility to seize new growth opportunities.

site_title: Libor to end in 2021 as FCA says bank benchmark is unsustainable
summary: The London interbank offered rate (Libor), a benchmark for over $350 trillion in financial products, will be phased out by the end of 2021 due to a lack of transactions providing data. UK regulators, led by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA), say the current system is unsustainable and will be replaced with a more reliable system. The FCA has asked banks to continue submitting rates until 2021, with some suggesting alternatives could include multiple benchmarks with varying levels of credit risk.

site_title: Samsung Electronics posts record profit
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a record net income of 10.8 trillion won (S$13.2 billion) in Q2, exceeding analyst estimates, driven by the success of its new Galaxy S8 smartphones and demand for semiconductors. Sales rose 20% to 61 trillion won, with the company's chips unit reporting operating profit of eight trillion won. The results come as the trial of billionaire heir Jay Y Lee winds down, with Samsung riding out cyclical downturns and expecting to increase spending this year.

site_title: Not your typical rom-com
summary: Kumail Nanjiani stars in "The Big Sick," a romantic comedy based on his real-life courtship with Emily V. Gordon. The film follows the cross-cultural relationship between a Pakistani comedian and a white graduate student, navigating cultural differences and family expectations. After Emily falls into a coma, Kumail forms an unlikely alliance with her parents, leading to a heartfelt love story that explores identity, faith, and the challenges of interracial relationships. With a smart blend of humor and serious moments, the film is a unique and charming portrayal of love and cultural heritage.

site_title: IE Singapore sets up network for SMEs to expand overseas quickly
summary: Singapore's International Enterprise Singapore (IE Singapore) has launched a Plug and Play Network to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in expanding overseas quickly. The network provides business advisory services, business matching, and market setup through co-working spaces. This move aims to ease market entry for Singaporean SMEs and promote their global growth.

site_title: Mastercard's profit jumps nearly 20%
summary: Mastercard reported a 20% increase in quarterly profit, reaching US$1.18 billion, or US$1.10 per share, in the second quarter. Revenue rose 13.3% to US$3.05 billion. This growth is attributed to increased spending using credit and debit cards.

site_title: Shell Q2 profits triple, beat forecasts
summary: Royal Dutch Shell reported a 245% increase in second-quarter profits to $3.6 billion, beating forecasts, driven by strong refining and chemicals operations. The company's cash flow rose sevenfold to $20.8 billion and debt fell to $78 billion. Shell plans to spend $25 billion this year, despite oil prices struggling to rise. The company's production declined 1% to 3.495 million barrels of oil equivalent per day due to reduced output from a facility in Qatar. Shell's disposal program is expected to impact growth in the third quarter.

site_title: US tax overhaul in doubt as House GOP stuck on budget disagreements
summary: US tax overhaul efforts are uncertain due to budget disagreements among House Republicans. Despite a House Budget committee-approved budget resolution, disputes over spending levels and the border-adjusted tax proposal have prevented Speaker Paul Ryan from securing enough support for a floor vote. The lack of a budget raises doubts about completing a tax rewrite before the 2018 elections, with some Republicans demanding deeper spending cuts. A possible agreement among House, Senate, and White House leaders could help put tax legislation back on track, but experts estimate the chances of a 2018 budget resolution this year at around 30%.

site_title: Malaysia legalises e-hailing services as Grab, Uber compete
summary: Malaysia's parliament passed two bills legalizing e-hailing services, paving the way for ride-hailing firms Grab and Uber to operate in the country. The amendments to the Land Public Transport Act and Commercial Vehicles Licensing Board Act allow e-hailing services to operate on an "intermediation business license". Grab plans to raise $2.5 billion from investors to expand its lead in the region, driven by a young and tech-savvy population. The move is seen as a significant development for the ride-hailing industry in Southeast Asia.

site_title: State-of-the-art looks and performance
summary: LG's Signature OLED TV W7 is a game-changer in home entertainment, boasting a 65-inch OLED panel that measures just 2.57mm and can pass off as a picture frame when mounted on the wall. The TV has won over 40 awards, including Best of Innovations at CES, thanks to its revolutionary pixel dimming control technology and infinite contrast ratio, rendering perfect blacks and an infinite number of colors. This top-of-the-line technology provides incredibly lifelike images, making the W7 a serious piece of hardware.

images.alt_text: The LG Signature OLED TV W7's attached soundbar (above) delivers stunning audio in Dolby Atmos.
The LG Signature OLED TV W7 is designed to look like a piece of art hanging on the wall (right) and the panel's ultra-slim 2.57mm profile (left) will make jaws drop before you even turn it on.
Dylan Tan

site_title: Super children who make their own paths, in BT Weekend
summary: Four sets of parents discuss alternative parenting styles, emphasizing individuality over traditional expectations, in a BT Weekend article. The article also highlights various lifestyle topics, including a review of South Korea's Jeju island, a look at planning for a "good death," and a critique of Singaporeans' work ethic. Additionally, the article mentions various other publications and reviews, including a review of Amazon's Prime Now service and Audi's new Q5 SUV.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end the day higher
summary: Malaysia's shares ended the day higher, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.07 points to 1,770.07. The market saw 1.58 billion lots worth RM1.97 billion traded, with 425 gainers outnumbering 410 losers.

site_title: KepLand, Wing Tai tie-up top bidder for Serangoon North site
summary: KepLand and Wing Tai have emerged as the top bidders for a 99-year-leasehold private housing site in Serangoon North Avenue 1, with a bid of S$446.28 million (S$964.81 psf ppr), 6.6% higher than the second-highest offer from FCL Residences. The site will be developed into over 600 homes, and analysts expect the selling price to be around S$1,600 psf or upwards, indicating a market recovery. The strong turnout of 16 bidders suggests developers have accepted that the market trough is here.

images.alt_text: "We are confident that this new development will see positive demand as there have been few new condominiums launched in recent times in the popular Serangoon Garden area," said KepLand chief executive Ang Wee Gee.
Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: US regulators to approve fix for more than 300,000 VW diesels
summary: US regulators are set to approve a fix for over 300,000 older Volkswagen AG diesel cars, which will include hardware and software upgrades but may reduce fuel economy ratings by up to 2 miles per gallon. The fix is a significant milestone for the company, aiming to move beyond its diesel emissions crisis. The US Environmental Protection Agency and California Air Resources Board will approve the fix, but Volkswagen still needs approval for a resale plan for affected models.

images.alt_text: The US Environmental Protection Agency and California Air Resources Board will approve later on Thursday a fix for more than 300,000 older Volkswagen AG diesel cars, two people briefed on the matter said.

site_title: Bigger but still as authentic and original
summary: The xx, a South London trio, performed their biggest show to date at a near-capacity Singapore Indoor Stadium, marking their third visit to the city. Despite the larger venue, the band maintained an intimate atmosphere with their minimalist electro-pop-rock sound. The set featured a three-song medley, including a reworked version of their debut song "Shelter" and a surprise drop of Jamie Smith's solo track "Loud Places." The band's authenticity and originality remained intact, showcasing their ability to adapt and evolve while maintaining their unique sound.

images.alt_text: The xx is made up of (from left) Jamie Smith aka Jamie xx, Romy Madley Croft and Oliver Sim.
The xx played its biggest show here on Tuesday night at a near-capacity Singapore Indoor Stadium.
Dylan Tan

site_title: UK treasury moves Ramsden to top echelon of Bank of England
summary: The UK Treasury appointed Dave Ramsden as the new deputy governor for markets and banking at the Bank of England, effective September 4. He replaces Charlotte Hogg, who resigned earlier this year, and will manage the central bank's balance sheet, market operations, and gather market intelligence. Ramsden will also represent the BOE at global forums alongside Deputy Governor Jon Cunliffe, who will oversee the central bank's international strategy.

images.alt_text: The UK Treasury appointed one of its most senior officials as the new deputy governor for markets and banking at the Bank of England.

site_title: Singapore firms dip toes into blockchain tech for property
summary: Two Singapore firms, FundPlaces and Reidao, are pioneering the use of blockchain technology to create tokens backed by real estate investments, allowing investors to buy into properties. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has cautioned investors, citing potential abuse of these platforms for illicit activities. Despite this, both companies have raised significant funds for real estate projects, with FundPlaces raising £200,000 and Reidao planning to acquire properties in Malaysia. The use of blockchain technology aims to improve transparency, reduce costs, and increase liquidity in the real estate market, but regulatory frameworks are still evolving to address the risks associated with these new instruments.

site_title: P&G gets boost from stronger results in fight against Peltz
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) reported stronger-than-expected quarterly sales and earnings, beating analyst estimates, in a boost to its fight against activist investor Nelson Peltz. CEO David Taylor's turnaround plan appears to be gaining traction, with the company's shares rising 2.7% to $91.68. P&G's earnings and sales growth are seen as a counterpoint to Peltz's claims that the company needs a shake-up, and the company expects organic revenue to grow 2-3% and earnings to climb 5-7% in the coming year.

site_title: Bezos tops Gates as world's richest ahead of Amazon results
summary: Jeff Bezos has surpassed Bill Gates as the world's richest person, according to a surge in Amazon shares. Bezos' net worth reached $90.9 billion, surpassing Gates' $90.7 billion, if the current share price holds through the 4pm close. Investors will be watching Amazon's earnings report, particularly its Prime membership and cloud-computing division, Amazon Web Services, for clues about its future growth.

images.alt_text: A surge in Amazon.com shares Thursday morning in advance of the online retailer's earnings report has propelled founder Jeff Bezos past Bill Gates as the world's richest person.

site_title: Etihad has US$1.87b loss in worst blow to Gulf carriers
summary: Etihad Airways reported a record annual loss of $1.87 billion, equivalent to 40% of its passenger revenue, due to the impact of terrorism on global traffic flows and low oil prices. The airline's 2016 loss was $1.06 billion, with an additional $808 million loss from writing down the value of aircraft and equity partners. The loss comes as Gulf carriers face challenges from restricted travel to the US and a slump in travel due to a blockade on Qatar Airways.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens at record high after strong earnings
summary: US stocks opened at record high levels on Thursday, driven by strong corporate earnings reports. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 49.59 points, or 0.23%, to 21,760.6, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also reached fresh records, gaining 3.9 and 32.93 points, respectively. The positive sentiment was largely unaffected by recent US-EU trade tensions and ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Sheng Siong's Q2 profit rises 6.3% on higher sales, better margins
summary: Sheng Siong's Q2 net profit rose 6.3% to S$16.1 million, driven by 6.8% revenue growth to S$201.5 million. Improved gross margins and contributions from new stores contributed to the increase. Earnings per share and net asset value per share also rose, while a dividend of 1.55 Singapore cents per share was proposed. Sheng Siong shares finished 4.5% lower at S$0.95 on the same day.

site_title: Premature to bet on a merger of Singapore's leading yard groups
summary: A brokerage report has reignited speculation about a potential merger between Keppel Corporation's marine arm and Sembcorp Industries' marine arm. The report argues that a merger could create a global powerhouse, but investors should take a cautious approach due to differing aspirations and varying shares of the market. Keppel O&M has 30% of the jack-up rigbuilding market, while SembMarine leads in LNG carrier repairs. A merger would require both sides to agree on valuation, and it's unclear if the parties are keen on exploring talks.

site_title: Chinese writers navigate censors to publicise articles and earn cash via apps
summary: Chinese writers are using social media platforms like WeChat and Weibo to self-publish and earn money, despite online censorship. Writers like Dr. Qiao Mu, who was banned from teaching for "work violations," have found success by posting articles and receiving tips from sympathetic readers. With Facebook and Twitter blocked, these platforms have become the primary outlet for Chinese writers to express themselves and reach a wide audience.

images.alt_text: China's widely-used apps have given writers such as Dr Qiao an outlet to self-publish and make money, as long as their words respect the boundaries set by online censors.

site_title: Twitter user growth stalls, revenue dips
summary: Twitter reported a net loss of $116 million in the second quarter, with its base of monthly active users remaining unchanged at 328 million. The company's revenues slipped 5% from a year ago to $574 million, with advertising revenue falling 8% to $489 million. Twitter's shares sank 9% in pre-market trade. Despite a 12% increase in daily active users, the company is making progress on improving its product, with CEO Jack Dorsey expressing confidence in its ability to boost growth and move to profitability.

site_title: Shell CEO Van Beurden says his next car will be electric
summary: Shell CEO Ben Van Beurden plans to switch to an electric car, a plug-in Mercedes-Benz S500e, in September, marking a shift towards cleaner mobility. The company has already adopted a "lower-forever mindset" to adapt to a world of $50-a-barrel oil, with plans to spend $1 billion annually on its New Energies division. Van Beurden believes electric vehicles will outsell fossil-fuel powered cars within two decades, with plug-in cars accounting for a third of the global auto fleet by 2040.

site_title: FHT's Q3 DPS falls due to bigger unit base after rights issue
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) reported a 11.6% increase in Q3 income available for distribution to S$24.1 million, despite a 19.3% decline in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.2374 Singapore cents due to a larger unit base following a rights issue in October. The addition of Novotel Melbourne on Collins to its portfolio contributed to the increase in revenue and earnings.

site_title: China is 'landlord' to Hong Kong says justice chief
summary: China is likened to Hong Kong's "landlord" by the justice chief, sparking concerns over the erosion of the city's freedoms. A new cross-border rail link plan, which would see mainland laws enforced in a Hong Kong train station, is met with criticism that it breaches the city's mini-constitution, the Basic Law. Critics argue the plan would compromise Hong Kong's autonomy and freedoms, while the government claims it would save travel time and not breach local laws.

site_title: Reclaimed land is hot in Manila amid space crunch as economy booms
summary: Reclaimed land in Manila is selling at a high price amid the city's economic boom. Real estate values in the Manila Bay area are projected to rise 30% to $6,700 per square meter by year-end, surpassing the decades-old Ortigas business district. Developers are reclaiming land to convert industrial estates into mixed-use developments, with a 407-hectare project featuring a monorail and golf course. The economy is growing at over 6% due to business process outsourcing and online shopping, with office space vacancies at 1-3%. Reclaimed land prices are 15 times the cost of land reclamation, but 40% cheaper than nearby business districts.

site_title: SIA Q1 earnings fall in absence of one-time gain; operating profit up
summary: Singapore Airlines reported a 8.4% drop in net profit to S$235.1 million in Q1 2017, despite a 45.3% increase in operating profit to S$280.8 million. Revenue edged up 5.6% to S$3.86 billion, driven by higher passenger and cargo revenue. Yields remained under pressure, but SIA Cargo bucked the trend with a 4.8% increase. The airline group warned of a challenging business outlook due to overcapacity and competition, but plans to restructure its cost base and identify new revenue opportunities.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Myanmar seeks WHO help with deadly swine flu outbreak
summary: Myanmar seeks help from the World Health Organization (WHO) to combat a deadly swine flu outbreak, which has claimed at least six lives and infected 30 people in the country's commercial capital, Yangon. The outbreak has sparked alarm, with many residents wearing surgical masks and government officials calling for calm. The WHO has not yet responded to a request for assistance, including diagnosis equipment and medicine. This is the same strain of the virus that caused a global pandemic in 2009, resulting in an estimated 575,000 deaths.

site_title: 16 bids for URA tender for 99-year private housing site in Serangoon North Ave 1
summary: Seventeen bidders participated in a URA tender for a 99-year leasehold private housing site in Serangoon North Avenue 1. The top bid of S$446.28 million was from a partnership between Keppel Land and Wing Tai, with an estimated S$964.81 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). The second-highest bid was S$418.7 million from Frasers Centrepoint's FCL Residences, and the lowest bid was S$338 million from EL Development.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust's Q1 DPU rises to 2.23 cents
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 48.2% surge in Q1 income available for distribution to S$64.4 million, driven by positive contributions from VivoCity, Mapletree Anson, and PSA Building, as well as the accretive acquisition of Mapletree Business City I. DPU rose to 2.23 cents, a 9.7% increase from the previous year. Gross revenue and net property income also increased by 46.9% and 49.6%, respectively. MCT units finished 0.6% higher at S$1.63.

images.alt_text: Positive contributions from VivoCity, Mapletree Anson and PSA Building as well as the accretive acquisition of Mapletree Business City I boosted results for Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) in its first quarter.

site_title: SGX mulls over allowing dual-class shares for secondary listings: sources
summary: SGX is considering allowing dual-class shares for secondary listings, following a review of primary listings. The exchange had proposed safeguards, including a "compelling reason" hurdle and a maximum voting differential of 10 times. Proponents argue it will improve market vibrancy, while opponents see it as detrimental to corporate governance. Associate Professor Mak Yuen Teen, who opposes dual-class shares, believes restricting it to secondary listings may be acceptable due to existing laws in other countries, but doubts its impact on liquidity on SGX.

site_title: Out of the doghouse: South Korea's Moon adopts abused pooch
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-In has welcomed a new family member, Tory, a black mutt rescued from an abusive owner. Tory was found tied to a rope at an abandoned farmhouse and had been destined for the dinner table. Moon, an animal lover, had pledged to adopt Tory during his presidential campaign and has now made it official, marking the first time a rescued dog has entered the presidential Blue House. The adoption comes after his predecessor, Park Geun-Hye, abandoned her nine canine companions.

site_title: US e-commerce deliveries lift UPS quarterly profit
summary: UPS reports a higher-than-expected quarterly net profit of $1.4 billion, driven by a 8% increase in e-commerce deliveries in its US domestic package service. Revenue rose 8% to $9.7 billion, with revenue per package up 3% versus the previous year. The company expects full-year earnings per share in a range of $5.80 to $6.10, in line with analyst expectations. UPS is investing heavily in its network to handle the growth in e-commerce deliveries, citing higher fuel surcharges and workers' compensation as contributing factors to its earnings.

images.alt_text: United Parcel Service (UPS) on Thursday reported a higher-than-expected quarterly net profit, citing a jump in e-commerce deliveries in its US domestic package service and confirmed its forecast for 2017.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher, extending rally
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.54% to 3,354.71 on Thursday, driven by strong earnings from domestic banks and a positive start on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index saw 17.99 points gain and 3.1 billion SGD in turnover. Despite mixed trading, shares of commodity trader Noble declined 18 cents, while others like Singtel, Sinarmas Land, and Cordlife were among the active stocks.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Changi Airport saw a 5.7% increase in passenger traffic to 30.4 million in the first half of 2017. The Singapore dollar reached a year-high of 1.3565 against the US dollar following the US Federal Reserve's dovish statement. IE Singapore launched its Plug and Play Network to support SMEs in the region. The Singapore Exchange considered allowing dual-class shares for secondary listings, while industrial space prices and rentals moderated in Q2. The Personal Data Protection Commission developed a trusted data ecosystem in Singapore, and CWT Limited sought an update on its S$1.4 billion takeover offer.

images.alt_text: In the first half of this year, Changi Airport handled 5.7 per cent more passengers year-on-year at 30.4 million, boosted by growth to and from South-east Asia, North-east Asia and South Asia.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine Q2 profit halves to S$5.6m
summary: Sembcorp Marine's second-quarter net profit dropped 51.2% to S$5.6 million due to lower contributions from rig building and offshore platform projects, as well as foreign exchange translation losses. The company attributed the decline to market conditions.

images.alt_text: Lower contribution from rig building and offshore platform projects took a toll on results for Sembcorp Marine in its second quarter.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler Q2 profits rise 15% but debt disappoints
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) reported a 15% increase in adjusted operating profit to 1.87 billion euros in Q2, beating analyst expectations. Revenue remained flat at 27.9 billion euros. The company's strong performance in Europe, Latin America, and North America contributed to the increase. However, debt was a disappointment, with FCA's net debt increasing by 5.4 billion euros to 33.8 billion euros.

site_title: China Huawei's H1 revenue rises 15%, slowest in four years
summary: Huawei Technologies, a leading telecom equipment maker, reported a 15% rise in first-half revenue to 283.1 billion yuan (S$57.127 billion) in 2017, the slowest growth in four years. Revenue growth outpaced the industry average, but operating margin fell to 11% from 12% in the same period last year. This marks the first time Huawei's revenue growth has slowed since 2013.

site_title: Ascendas Reit's Q1 DPU edges up to 4.049 cents on new acquisitions
summary: Ascendas Reit's Q1 DPU increased to 4.049 Singapore cents, a 4.2% rise from the previous year, driven by contributions from new acquisitions in Sydney, Melbourne, and Singapore. Q1 income available for distribution grew 10.9% to S$118.5 million, while gross revenue expanded 2.7% to S$213.3 million. Net property income rose 2.6% to S$153.4 million. The trust's units ended 0.4% higher at S$2.72.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open mixed
summary: European stocks opened mixed on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index and Frankfurt's DAX 30 dropping 0.2% and 0.3% respectively, while Paris's CAC 40 index rose 0.3%. The mixed start was fueled by the US Federal Reserve's tepid inflation outlook, which sparked speculation of potential rate hikes being delayed this year.

site_title: SIA reports lower net profit for Q1, but operating profit rises
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a net profit of S$235.1 million for Q1 2017, down 8.4% from last year. Operating profit rose 45.3% to S$280.8 million, while revenue increased 5.6% to S$3.86 billion. The airline attributed the lower net profit to the absence of last year's gain on the divestment of its stake in HAESL and special dividends received. SIA also mentioned the completion of the Scoot-Tigerair integration, which will provide expansion opportunities for the low-cost segment.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: UK to scrap Libor interest rate benchmark from end-2021
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) plans to scrap the Libor interest rate benchmark by the end of 2021, with a substitute index to be in place by then. This decision was made by Andrew Bailey, FCA chief executive, who emphasized the need for a smooth transition. Libor, used by banks to determine interest rates, has faced criticism for its lack of transparency and potential manipulation. The FCA aims to replace Libor with a more reliable index, ensuring a stable financial market.

site_title: Magnus Bocker, ex-SGX CEO, dead at 55
summary: Magnus Bocker, the former CEO of Singapore Exchange (SGX), has died at 55 due to cancer in the US. Bocker led SGX after the 2008 financial crisis and aimed to raise the exchange to a best-in-class platform in Asia. He attempted to merge SGX with the Australian stock exchange and lost out to Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing for the London Metal Exchange. Bocker was known for his dealmaking skills, upgrading SGX's infrastructure, and promoting corporate governance and sustainability reporting. He left SGX in 2015 amid trading outages and controversy over his changes.

images.alt_text: Magnus Bocker, who led the Singapore Exchange (SGX) after the global financial crisis and sought to modernise it, has died from cancer at 55.

site_title: Luxury brands get EU court boost in fight of internet sales
summary: Luxury brands, including Coty Inc, have received a boost from the EU court in their fight against internet sales. Advocate General Nils Wahl stated that luxury brands can block retailers from reselling their products online if it preserves their prestige image and is chosen fairly. This ruling may hinder antitrust investigations across Europe, which have targeted unjustified contracts between manufacturers and retailers. The decision could be precedent-setting and settle years of sparring over selective distribution agreements, potentially forcing regulators to reassess their approach.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end at fresh 2-year high
summary: Hong Kong shares reached a fresh 2-year high, closing 0.7% higher at 27,131.17 on Thursday. The gains followed Wall Street's record highs, driven by the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision and strong corporate earnings. Technology and financial shares led the way, with Tencent Holdings and AIA Group rising 2.2% and 1.8% respectively. China Mobile was the biggest drag, 0.4% lower, and impacted the telecom sector. The Hang Seng Index has now gained for a fourth straight session.

site_title: AstraZeneca, Merck strike key cancer drugs partnership
summary: Pharmaceutical giants AstraZeneca and Merck have agreed on a multi-billion-dollar deal to jointly develop key cancer drugs. Merck will pay AstraZeneca up to $8.5 billion under the deal. The collaboration aims to increase treatment options for cancer patients and is expected to further enhance the companies' portfolios. The partnership will involve the development and commercialization of the new cancer drugs, with the financial terms of the deal being a significant boost to AstraZeneca's revenue.

site_title: Nokia profits surge after Apple deal and network gains
summary: Nokia's second-quarter operating profit surged 73% to €574 million, exceeding analysts' expectations, driven by a patent deal with Apple and gains in market share. The company attributed the growth to its broader product portfolio following the 2016 acquisition of Alcatel-Lucent. Nokia warned that the network business could decline by 3-5% this year, but reiterated its full-year operating margin forecast of 8-10%. The company expects 5G trials to accelerate in 2018 and meaningful deployment in 2019.

site_title: Volkswagen lifts 2017 forecast
summary: Volkswagen lifted its forecast for the full year, reporting net profits of 3.1 billion euros (S$4.93 billion) between April and June, up from 1.15 billion in the same period last year. The company expects to increase revenue by "more than 4.0 per cent" and operating profits of between 6.0 and 7.0 per cent. Despite a brewing scandal, Volkswagen's strong performance is attributed to the growth in underlying profits, which increased to 4.5 billion euros.

site_title: SGX Q4 earnings rise 10.9% to S$85.2m
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 10.9% increase in net profit to S$85.2 million in its fourth quarter, driven by better performances in securities trading and clearing, as well as derivatives divisions. Revenue rose 4.9% to S$207.7 million, while earnings per share grew to 8 Singapore cents from 7.2 cents in the previous year. The company's net asset value per share edged up to 96.5 Singapore cents. SGX shares finished down 0.3% at S$7.54 on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Better performances from its securities trading and clearing as well as its derivatives divisions lifted results for Singapore Exchange (SGX) in its fourth quarter.

site_title: Diageo says annual profits fizz higher
summary: Diageo, a British maker of alcoholic drinks, reported a 21% increase in annual profits to £2.7 billion, driven by a 15% rise in sales and the weakening of the pound due to Brexit uncertainty. The company's CEO, Ivan Menezes, stated that the results demonstrate the effective delivery of the company's strategy, with progress in its focus areas of US spirits, scotch, and India. Despite benefiting from the weak pound, Diageo highlighted Brexit uncertainty as a key risk to its outlook.

site_title: Prices, rentals of industrial space in Singapore continue to moderate in Q2
summary: Singapore's industrial space prices and rentals continued to moderate in Q2 2017, with a 1.6% decline in prices and 0.8% decrease in rentals from the previous quarter. Occupancy rates fell to 88.7% and transaction volumes dropped 28% compared to the same period last year. Approximately 1.4 million sqm of industrial space is expected to come online in the second half of 2017, further putting downward pressure on prices and rentals.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Trump pick for Fed's Wall Street watchdog plans to ease rules
summary: Randal Quarles, President Trump's nominee for the Federal Reserve's vice chairman of supervision, has stated that it's time to reconsider bank regulations, citing their role in stabilizing the financial system after the 2008 crisis. Quarles' comments came during a confirmation hearing before the Senate Banking Committee, where he also mentioned that some refinements may be necessary to fine-tune regulations.

site_title: Hong Kong dollar to extend weakening trend, driven by excess cash, spreads
summary: The Hong Kong dollar is expected to continue its weakening trend, driven by excess liquidity and widening interest rate spreads with the US. The currency has fallen about 0.7% this year and is on track for a seventh straight month of decline. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has raised interest rates, but the spread between short-term Hong Kong and US rates has widened, making the Hong Kong dollar a handy funding currency for carry trades. The HKMA is unlikely to intervene to maintain the peg until the economy strengthens further.

site_title: Australia: Shares follow Wall St higher
summary: Australian shares rose 0.15% to 5,785.01, following Wall Street's record highs, driven by firm oil and copper prices. Major US indexes scaled record peaks, while the Fed maintained its benchmark lending rate. BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto led gains, with the 'Big Four' banks adding between 0.1 and 0.3%. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose marginally, while consumer staples stocks were offset by losses in healthcare and telecom stocks.

site_title: AB InBev profit rises, sees brighter hopes for Brazil
summary: AB InBev, the world's largest brewer, reported a 1% increase in beer volumes and a 5% increase in revenues in the second quarter, driven by strong growth in China, Mexico, and South Africa. Despite a decline in profits in Brazil, the company remains "cautiously optimistic" about the market, citing improved revenues per hectolitre and cost savings. AB InBev retained its overall earnings target of $2.8 billion and saw a 11.8% increase in core profit, excluding currency shifts.

site_title: China to speed up bullet trains in September: state media
summary: China plans to increase the speed of its bullet trains to 350 km/h in September, six years after a deadly crash prompted a speed cut from 250-300 km/h. The increased speed will cut travel time between Beijing and Shanghai to 4.5 hours from 6 hours. This move aims to improve efficiency and competitiveness in China's high-speed rail network.

site_title: Nissan posts lower Q1 profit, misses estimate
summary: Nissan Motor reported a 12.8% drop in its first-quarter operating profit to 153.3 billion yen, missing the estimated 171.45 billion yen. The company attributed the decline to higher expenses despite a rise in global vehicle sales. Nissan maintained its forecast for operating profit in the year to March at 685.0 billion yen, below analyst forecasts. The company expects higher raw material costs and a negative currency impact to weigh on operating profit this year.

site_title: Economic euphoria propels Merkel towards fourth term
summary: German consumer morale reached a 16-year high, with a GfK index of 10.8, boosting Chancellor Angela Merkel's chances of a fourth term in office. The positive economic news comes ahead of September's elections, where Merkel's conservative party holds a 13-point lead over her Social Democrat rivals. Germany's manufacturing economy is also performing well, with exports expected to surge. Merkel's challenger, Martin Schulz, is focusing on the refugee crisis, warning of a potential repeat of 2015's influx of Syrian refugees.

site_title: Former Japanese defence minister may replace scandal-hit Inada
summary: Former Japanese Defence Minister Tomomi Inada may be replaced due to a cover-up scandal involving hiding logs on worsening security in South Sudan. The scandal also led to the resignation of General Toshiya Okabe, chief of staff of the Ground Self Defence Forces. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is expected to choose a new defence minister, possibly Itsunori Onodera, a former defence minister who served from 2012, to project stability. A defence ministry report on the cover-up is due out on Friday.

images.alt_text: Defence Minister Tomomi Inada has launched an investigation into media reports that defence officials had tried to hide logs showing worsening security in South Sudan, where Japanese troops were taking part in a UN-led peacekeeping operation.

site_title: Avocado obsessed finally get relief as prices drop from record
summary: US avocado prices, which reached a record high earlier this year, are expected to stabilize and decrease as the supply from Mexico and California increases. Wholesale prices dropped over 6% in July, and Chipotle Mexican Grill reported higher-than-expected supplies from Mexico. Avocado demand remains high, with 6.3 million Instagram posts using the hashtag #Avocado, but growers are planting more trees to meet the demand. The natural growing cycle of avocado trees, which produces larger crops every other year, is expected to add to production, easing price pressure in 2018.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei edge up in global rally
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average rose 0.2% to 20,079.64 points, driven by a global rally and Nintendo's strong earnings report, which beat analyst estimates. The US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, sparking a dovish tone. Nintendo surged 7.6% and Hitachi Kokusai Electric rose 4.6% after raising its earnings outlook. Banks and insurers underperformed, with Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Dai-ichi Life Holdings declining. The broader Topix advanced 0.4% to 1,626.84, with investors focusing on earnings releases from Japanese firms.

site_title: McDonald's swift to respond in China after mouldy ice cream maker pictures go viral in US
summary: McDonald's China swiftly responded to viral photos of a mouldy ice cream maker at a US outlet by posting a statement on its Chinese microblog and website, reassuring customers of the safety and cleanliness of its food-making tools. The move highlights the sensitivity to potential food safety concerns in China, a key market for the company. McDonald's China unit assured customers that it takes food safety seriously and is committed to maintaining high standards.

images.alt_text: Viral photos and news reports in the United States allegedly showing a mouldy ice cream maker at a US outlet of McDonald's Corp have prompted swift action from the fast-food giant thousands of miles away: in China.

site_title: Seoul: Won nears 2017 high as US dollar softens, stocks inch up
summary: The South Korean won reached a four-month high against the US dollar as the US dollar softened due to concerns over potential Fed interest rate hikes.
