This is its third attempt to reinvigorate itself, following failed transformational plans in 2007 and 2012. Despite a sharp spike in its stock price, the company's latest deal lacks details and raises concerns about its valuation, with some analysts calling it "rich" and warning of significant shareholder dilution. The deal, controlled by billionaire Peter Lim, is seen as a "deja vu moment" and investors are urged to exercise caution.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Timely watch exhibition at Paragon
summary: The Federation of the Swiss Watch Industry is hosting a major Swiss watch exhibition at Paragon in Singapore from July 23 to Aug 13, coinciding with the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations between Singapore and Switzerland. The exhibition, titled "watch.swiss," showcases the unique features and history of Swiss timepieces, highlighting precision, design, and manufacturing. The event aims to meet end consumers and promote the Swiss watch industry in the market. Swiss watch exports to Singapore have been steadily increasing, with around 1 billion Swiss francs (S$1.4 billion) in 2016, and the event is expected to boost visibility for the Swiss watch industry in the region.

site_title: Hilton's profit beats; raises earnings forecast again
summary: Hilton Worldwide Holdings reported a higher-than-expected quarterly revenue and profit, driven by increased corporate demand and higher room prices. The company raised its 2017 earnings forecast to a range of $1.78-$1.85 per share and its full-year forecast for adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization to $1.88-$1.92 billion. System-wide occupancy rose 0.4% and average daily room rate increased 1.2% in the second quarter, contributing to the strong performance.

site_title: Lian Beng's Q4 revenue soars 60.3% to S$125.4m
summary: Lian Beng Group's Q4 revenue surged 60.3% to S$125.4 million, driven by the completion of the Mandai Foodlink industrial development project and its investment segments. The company's net profit increased 5.3% to S$31.99 million, with earnings per share rising to 6.4 Singapore cents. Lian Beng is proposing a final dividend of 1.25 Singapore cents per share, totaling 2.25 cents per share for FY2017.

site_title: Mainland Europeans outpace Britons as Ireland tourists for first time
summary: Mainland Europeans surpassed Britons as the largest source of tourists to Ireland in the second quarter, marking the first time since 1999. The 6.6% growth in Irish tourism was offset by a 6% decline in British visitors, partly due to the weaker pound since the Brexit vote. Meanwhile, tourism from the US continued to surge, with a 22% year-on-year increase. This shift in market dynamics reflects Ireland's focus on North American and European markets, according to Tourism Ireland's CEO Niall Gibbons.

site_title: Siam Cement cuts FY sales view on weak private-sector investment
summary: Siam Cement PCL, Thailand's largest industrial conglomerate, lowered its sales growth forecast to 3-5% due to weak private-sector investment. The company now expects domestic cement sales to contract 5% this year. Sales grew 3% in the first half, and the firm expects a slow recovery in demand for cement and building materials. Siam Cement also lowered its capital expenditure plans for this year to 50-60 billion baht. The company attributed the decline to Thailand's sluggish economy, still recovering from a 2014 army coup.

site_title: Coca Cola profit drops 60% on refranchising charge
summary: Coca Cola reported a 60.2% drop in quarterly profit due to a US$653 million charge related to refranchising its North America bottling operations. Net income fell to US$1.37 billion, or 32 US cents per share, from US$3.45 billion, or 79 US cents per share, a year earlier. Revenue also declined to US$9.70 billion, its ninth consecutive drop, due to a strong US dollar and refranchising of bottling territories.

site_title: GM's Q2 profit falls sharply as challenges mount
summary: General Motors reported a 42% decline in second-quarter net income to $1.7 billion, primarily due to its strategic shift away from international markets. Despite this, adjusted earnings per share rose 6% to $1.89, beating Wall Street estimates. The company is restructuring its global business units, cutting costs and reducing production of slow-selling passenger car models. GM's sales in the US have dropped 1.8% so far this year, and the company expects more difficult economic conditions in the US market for the remainder of the year.

site_title: Daimler paves way to potential spinoffs with separation plan
summary: Daimler AG, the parent company of Mercedes-Benz, is studying a plan to separate its businesses into more autonomous divisions, potentially paving the way for future spinoffs. The move aims to make the company more nimble for growth in respective markets. The plan comes as Daimler faces criticism for holding onto a broad range of offerings and faces disruptions from electric vehicles and self-driving technologies. A potential separation could create shareholder value, but Daimler has previously resisted such moves, with CEO Dieter Zetsche's contract set to end in 2019.

site_title: Noble selling businesses, assets to pare debt; expects loss for Q2
summary: Noble Group, a troubled commodity trader, plans to sell its Global Oil Liquids and North American Gas & Power businesses to reduce debt. The sales are expected to generate significant cash proceeds, allowing the group to retire $2 billion in secured borrowing facilities and reduce its remaining debt. The company also plans to recapitalize its hard commodities businesses and explore strategic alliances to fund working capital. Noble expects a loss in Q2 due to a challenging operating environment and conservative liquidity management.

site_title: Ford CEO starts turnaround with profit beat, lifted forecast
summary: Ford's new CEO, Jim Hackett, has started a turnaround with the company beating analyst estimates in its second-quarter earnings report. Ford delivered adjusted earnings per share of 56 US cents, despite a slow US auto market and aging model lineup. Hackett has vowed to accelerate the company's strategy to take on Silicon Valley in the driverless car market. Ford forecasted full-year profit in the range of US$1.65 to US$1.85 per share, up from its previous projection, due to a lower-than-expected tax rate. The company has also announced plans to cut costs and reduce spending on unprofitable models.

site_title: BNP Paribas to buy out full stake in Italian insurance unit from Ageas
summary: BNP Paribas is acquiring full control of Italian insurance unit CARGEAS from Ageas, expanding its presence in the country and boosting cross-selling of products. The French bank aims to boost profitability in Europe, where its retail businesses are impacted by low interest rates. CARGEAS, which sells non-life insurance to companies and individuals, had a 50/50 joint venture with Ageas. The acquisition will give BNP Paribas a complete insurance offer for individual clients, with support from partners UBI Banca and BNL in Italy.

site_title: Sports Direct's Ashley wins court battle over drunk bonus deal
summary: Mike Ashley, billionaire owner of Sports Direct, won a court ruling denying a former employee's claim of a £15 million bonus deal made in a London pub. The deal involved doubling the retailer's share price to £8, but Judge George Leggatt ruled the offer was not serious. The case, marked by references to heavy drinking, was a distraction for Ashley as Sports Direct tries to revive growth after a dismal 18 months, with shares losing over half their value since a 2015 investigation exposed management issues.

site_title: E-commerce giant Amazon to launch in Singapore this week: Report
summary: Amazon is set to launch its e-commerce services in Singapore, marking its entry into South-east Asia. The launch is expected to happen as early as this week, based on social media teasers by the influencer community. This move is part of Amazon's global expansion plans, following its successful launch in other countries. The exact launch date and details of the services offered are not specified.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end the day higher
summary: Malaysia's shares ended higher on Wednesday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.66 points to 1,766.00. Volume reached 1.3 billion lots worth RM1.55 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 431 to 375.

site_title: Heart rate study tests emotional impact of Shakespeare
summary: The Royal Shakespeare Company has launched a study to measure the emotional impact of Shakespeare's "Titus Andronicus" on modern audiences, using heart rate monitors to track reactions to the play's violent scenes. The study aims to determine if the playwright's work still evokes strong emotions, particularly in the face of graphic violence. Initial results show that heart rates rise as audience members anticipate violent moments, and participants reported being more engaged in the theatre than in a cinema. The study's findings will shed light on whether our inuredness to violence affects our emotional response to Shakespeare's work.

site_title: Snapdeal's board accepts Flipkart's up to $950 mln buyout -sources
summary: Snapdeal's board has accepted Flipkart's revised takeover offer of up to $950 million, approving a deal pending shareholder approval. This move strengthens Flipkart's position in India's e-commerce market, which is expected to continue growing at a compound annual rate of over 50%. SoftBank, Snapdeal's largest investor, is keen to consummate the deal and take an equity stake in Flipkart. The deal comes amid a fierce battle between Flipkart and Amazon for dominance in India's online retail market.

images.alt_text: Indian online marketplace Snapdeal has accepted Flipkart's revised takeover offer of up to US$950 million, two sources said on Wednesday, providing heft to its bigger rival in a high-stakes battle with Amazon.com Inc.

site_title: EU-Canada air passenger data deal illegal: court
summary: The European Union's top court ruled that a deal to share air passenger data with Canada to combat terrorism cannot be passed in its present form due to its interference with fundamental rights, specifically the right to privacy and protection of personal data. The deal, which began negotiating in 2010, would involve transferring Passenger Name Record data, including itineraries and payment information, to Canada. The EU has similar deals with the US and Australia, but the court's decision is a setback for the EU-Canada agreement.

site_title: Nintendo swings to operating profit, beats estimates on Switch console sales
summary: Nintendo reported a surprise operating profit of 16.21 billion yen in the first quarter, exceeding analyst estimates, due to strong demand for its Switch console. The company sold 1.97 million Switch consoles, bringing the cumulative total to 4.7 million units. Nintendo expects the Switch to help more than double its annual operating profit and has kept its sales forecast at 10 million units for the year. The company has apologized for the shortage of Switch consoles and plans to raise production to meet demand.

site_title: Agilent Tech to invest S$85m over 5 years in manufacturing, research in Singapore
summary: Agilent Technologies plans to invest S$85 million over 5 years to enhance its manufacturing and research capabilities in Singapore. The investment will add 30,000 square feet to its existing facility and create 100 new jobs. The expanded facility will offer end-to-end manufacturing, testing, and supply chain management using state-of-the-art automated systems. This move aims to support the production of high-end analytical instruments, particularly mass-spec products, for industries such as pharmaceuticals, chemicals, and energy.

images.alt_text: Chow Woai Sheng (left) , vice-president and country general manager of Agilent Singapore, said: "The expansion will leverage advanced manufacturing systems and automated production technologies to support the production of a broader range of high-end analytical instruments, especially our mass-spec products."

site_title: France to nationalise STX shipyard if Italy snubs ownership deal
summary: France threatens to nationalize its STX France shipyard if Italy rejects its proposal to split ownership equally with Paris. The shipyard, which builds aircraft carriers, is being sold after its parent South Korean company STX collapsed. Economy Minister Bruno Le Maire said nationalization would give the state more time to find a better shareholder deal, but it would mark the first major state intervention in the corporate world under President Emmanuel Macron's government. Italy rejected the proposal, and the French state has until Thursday to make a decision.

site_title: Qatar crisis is said to be deadlocked as Saudi bloc adds demands
summary: Efforts to resolve the Qatar crisis have reached an impasse as a Saudi-led bloc refuses to respond to US and UK proposals for direct negotiations. The four-nation bloc has accused Qatar of supporting extremist groups, prompting a boycott and added 18 individuals and organizations to its list of alleged terrorist groups. Qatar denies the charges and says it's ready to start dialogue if its sovereignty is respected, but mediation efforts continue without fresh ideas on how to break the impasse.

images.alt_text: Efforts to resolve the standoff between Qatar and a Saudi-led alliance have reached an impasse, according to a Gulf official with direct knowledge of the matter, amid signs the bloc wants to extract more concessions from Doha.

site_title: Britain's Metro Bank raises cash, swings to H1 profit
summary: Metro Bank Plc, a British lender, raised £278 million by selling new shares and generated a pretax profit of £6 million in the first half of the year. The company, which offers retail, business, and private banking, saw underlying profit before tax increase from a loss of £13 million a year earlier. Metro Bank's shares traded 4% higher at £36.25, boosted by the successful share placing. The lender's Chief Executive Craig Donaldson attributed the oversubscription to the company's growth in lending and customer deposits, despite economic concerns.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end higher helped by energy stocks
summary: Hong Kong shares ended higher on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng index rising 0.3% to 26,941.02, driven by gains in energy and financial stocks. The index is on track for a seventh straight month of gains in July, its longest such rally in 10 years.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong shares ended higher on Wednesday as gains by energy and financial shares overcame sluggishness in other sectors hit by profit-taking after the Hang Seng index temporarily breached the 27,000 mark in early trade.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.3% higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 8.9 points, or 0.3%, to close at 3,336.72 on Wednesday. Around 2.7 billion shares worth S$1.2 billion were traded. Losers outpaced gainers with 272 counters down and 175 counters up. This marks the fifth consecutive day of gains, ahead of the release of GDP data.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: UK to ban sale of petrol and diesel cars by 2040: report
summary: The UK government plans to ban the sale of new petrol and diesel cars, as well as vans, by 2040 to reduce air pollution. The £3 billion air pollution plan, set to be announced, will require councils to propose measures to reduce nitrogen dioxide levels by March 2026. Hybrid vehicles with a petrol or diesel engine will also be affected. This move follows a similar proposal by the French government, and marks a significant shift in the UK's transportation policies.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on positive economic data
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Wednesday, driven by positive economic data and strong earnings results. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.48% to 20,050.16, while the Topix index rose 0.24% to 1,620.88. The gains followed a host of strong earnings results and confidence in leading global economies.

site_title: Indonesia attracts more foreign direct investment in Q2
summary: Indonesia saw a significant increase in foreign direct investment (FDI) in the second quarter of 2017, with a 10.6% annual growth in rupiah terms and a 15.5% increase in US dollar terms. The total FDI amounting to 109.9 trillion rupiah (S$11.2 billion) or US$8.2 billion, excluding banking and oil and gas sectors. This marks a substantial improvement from the 1% growth in the first quarter.

site_title: BlackRock says 'absolutely critical' to look at China bonds
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest money manager, emphasizes the importance of considering China's onshore bond market, valued at $10 trillion. Despite foreign investors holding only 3% of the market, China's regulators are opening the market to foreign investors. BlackRock's head of Asian credit, Neeraj Seth, predicts a gradual process for raising foreign participation, with inclusion in major indexes likely within 12-18 months. The firm is long on the Chinese yuan, Indonesian rupiah, and Indian rupee, favoring higher-quality government bonds and quasi-sovereign names.

images.alt_text: BlackRock, the world's largest money manager, said that investors cannot ignore China's onshore bond market, which has reached the US$10 trillion mark.

site_title: Banksy work comes top of poll of UK's favourite artworks
summary: A poll of 2,000 people has named Banksy's "Balloon Girl" stencil painting as Britain's favourite artwork, surpassing John Constable's "The Hay Wain" and Jack Vettriano's "The Singing Butler". The artwork, which appeared in east London in 2012, was removed and sold for around £500,000 in 2014. The poll, conducted by Samsung TV, also ranked JMW Turner's "The Fighting Temeraire" fourth and Antony Gormley's "The Angel Of The North" fifth, with album covers by artists such as Peter Blake and Jamie Reid also featured in the top 20.

site_title: Accorhotels beefs up luxury rental 'onefinestay' brand to fight Airbnb
summary: AccorHotels is rebranding its luxury home-rental divisions under 'onefinestay' to counter the challenge of Airbnb. The French hotelier will group Travel Keys and Squarebreak units under the 'onefinestay' umbrella, offering over 10,000 rental spaces and hospitality services worldwide. The move aims to generate 30% of revenue from new businesses, such as concierge services and home rentals, and follows recent acquisitions to boost presence in the luxury private rentals market. AccorHotels will also name Javier Cedillo-Espin as the chief executive of the brand.

site_title: Hyundai Motor warns of more uncertainty as profit slumps
summary: Hyundai Motor Co. reported a 24% drop in second-quarter operating income due to weaker demand in China amid political tensions and increased US incentive costs. The company expects a tough second half, citing slowing US sales and repercussions from a US missile defense system deployment in China. To address these issues, Hyundai plans to increase utility vehicle production and introduce a new luxury Genesis brand model. The company's struggles in the US and China, where its sedan-heavy lineup faces competition from premium foreign brands and local offerings, are expected to continue.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall St records as energy firms rally
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, led by energy firms after rising commodity prices and strong earnings. Copper prices jumped to five-month peaks, while oil surged due to lower US stockpiles and a report on global crude producers' adherence to output cuts. Energy giants such as BHP and Rio Tinto rose, while Tokyo's Inpex also gained. The gains followed a record day on Wall Street and positive economic data, including a successful return to debt markets for Greece and record levels of US consumer sentiment.

site_title: Scientists dim sunlight, suck up carbon dioxide to cool planet
summary: Scientists are using a combination of carbon capture and solar geo-engineering to cool the planet. Companies like Climeworks and Carbon Engineering are capturing carbon dioxide from the air with giant fans and filters, while Harvard researchers are developing a plan to release chemicals from a balloon to dim the sun's rays. The goal is to limit global temperatures to less than 2 degrees Celsius, but experts warn that relying on these technologies alone may not be enough and that reducing emissions is still the most critical step in addressing climate change.

site_title: Europe: Energy firms boost shares as earnings roll in
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Wednesday, driven by energy firms Subsea 7 and Tullow Oil's strong earnings reports. Oil and gas stocks gained 0.8%, while banks weighed on the index due to investor concerns about a Fed policy decision and UK GDP figures. The euro zone's industrials sector underperformed, with 86% of firms missing earnings estimates. Despite this, the pan-European STOXX 600 index remained steady, influenced by supportive crude prices and recent euro strength.

site_title: Peugeot sets new profitability record on pricing gains
summary: Peugeot sets a new profitability record with a 3.6% increase in net income to 1.26 billion euros, driven by stronger pricing gains that outweighed weaker sales volumes in Europe and China. The company's core automotive operating margin jumped to 7.3%, a "new historic high." Despite concerns about the pace of recovery, PSA Group beat analyst expectations and raised its full-year European auto-market growth forecast to 3% from 1%. The company's recovery is attributed to cost-cutting, a pared-down lineup, and determined efforts to lift prices.

site_title: US sanctions vote 'hostile', says top Iran negotiator
summary: US sanctions voted on by the House of Representatives are deemed "hostile" by Iran's top nuclear negotiator Abbas Araghchi, who considers them a breach of Washington's commitments under the 2015 nuclear deal. The sanctions target Iran's nuclear program, which was agreed upon in exchange for sanctions relief. Araghchi stated that the action is a "hostile measure" against Iran, contradicting the US position that the sanctions are aimed at enforcing the deal. The move is likely to escalate tensions between the two countries.

site_title: Puma to keep spending on marketing to revive brand: CEO
summary: Puma's CEO, Bjorn Gulden, announced plans to maintain spending on marketing, aiming to revive the brand. The company's operating expenses rose 11% in the second quarter, driven by marketing and retail expenses. Despite this, demand for new shoe models helped more than triple operating profit to 43.4 million euros. Puma's currency-adjusted second-quarter sales jumped 16%, leading to an upgrade of its 2017 sales and operating profit guidance. Gulden stated that marketing will always be between 10% and 12% of sales.

site_title: Malaysia's Mahathir admits knowing classified information on 1MDB
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad admitted in a blog post that he is aware of classified government information, including the auditor general's report on 1MDB, a scandal-ridden state fund. The report was classified as an official secret in 2016. Mahathir stated that his chief source of this information was former Deputy Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin. The admission raises questions about Mahathir's involvement in the 1MDB scandal, which has been a major issue in Malaysia.

site_title: Singapore's factory output up 13.1% in June; electronics remains star performer
summary: Singapore's factory output rose 13.1% in June, driven by the electronics cluster, which saw a 25.5% increase year-on-year. The semiconductors segment posted a 37.4% growth. Biomedical manufacturing also saw a 18.3% increase. The only decline was in general manufacturing, which fell 5.3% in June. Excluding biomedical manufacturing, output grew 11.9% year-on-year, with the electronics cluster being the main contributor.

site_title: Hold the bagel! Higher costs make 2018 a great time to cut carbs
summary: US consumers may benefit from cutting carbs in 2018 due to a predicted 4% increase in grocery and restaurant costs for baked goods and cereals. The US Department of Agriculture attributes this to higher wheat costs, paid to farmers, and lower imports. Price gains will vary across foods, with some products experiencing more dramatic increases depending on the type of wheat used. This could lead to higher prices for bakery goods and cereals in 2018.

site_title: France unemployment falls at start of Macron presidency
summary: France's unemployment rate fell 0.3% in June, with 10,900 fewer jobless, to 3.48 million, marking the first full month under President Emmanuel Macron. The jobless rate stands at 9.6%. Macron's centrist government is negotiating labour reforms to boost hiring, including capping severance payments and giving bosses more freedom to negotiate with workers.

site_title: BMW halts project talks after Daimler blew whistle
summary: BMW has suspended talks with Daimler on future cooperation projects after Daimler disclosed alleged collusion among German carmakers to cartel authorities. BMW's top management will question future cooperation on joint purchasing of auto parts and electric car charging stations. Despite this, the project to develop charging sites for zero emission cars, involving Volkswagen and Ford, will continue and is not facing delays.

site_title: Australia shares hit 3-week high on strong commodity prices; NZ inches down
summary: Australian shares rose to a three-week high, driven by strong commodity prices, particularly oil and copper. The S&P/ASX 200 index increased 1% to 5,785.20, boosted by energy and material stocks. Copper prices hit a two-year high due to demand from China and a weaker US dollar, while oil prices rose 3% on Saudi Arabia's pledge to limit exports. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.1% due to weaker telecoms and utilities.

site_title: Death toll in Mumbai building collapse rises to 17 as rescuers search rubble
summary: A four-storey building in Mumbai's eastern suburb of Ghatkopar collapsed, increasing the death toll to 17 as rescuers search for trapped survivors. The 40-year-old building housed a nursing home and several families. The building was not on the list of dilapidated buildings, contradicting the claim of the Mumbai mayor. Rescuers continue to remove debris, searching for those still trapped.

site_title: Daimler Q2 earnings lag as cartel allegations loom
summary: Daimler's second-quarter operating profit rose 15% to 3.74 billion euros, driven by 28% sales growth in China and improved margins. However, the company's earnings fell short of consensus due to cartel allegations. The European Union and German antitrust regulators are investigating whether Daimler and other German carmakers colluded on suppliers, prices, and standards to the disadvantage of foreign carmakers. The investigation could lead to fines of up to 10% of global revenue, and Daimler's supervisory board is set to discuss the matter on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Booming sales of new Mercedes-Benz cars pushed up quarterly operating profit at Germany's Daimler by 15 per cent, slightly below consensus and overshadowed by allegations that German carmakers were involved in anti-competitive behaviour.

site_title: Singapore SMEs least punctual in repaying debt in 2 years: report
summary: Singaporean small and medium enterprises (SMEs) reported the lowest on-time debt repayment rate in two years, at 37% in the second quarter of 2017. This represents a decline from 52% in the first quarter and 44% in the transportation and storage sector. The construction sector saw the best improvement, with a 10% increase in on-time repayment to 38%. Meanwhile, severely delinquent debt remained at 14%, with average days turned cash increasing to 35 days from 31 days.

site_title: Vietnam jails dissident 9 years for propaganda against state
summary: A Vietnamese court jailed dissident Tran Thi Nga for 9 years and gave her 5 years probation for spreading propaganda against the state. Despite the country's growing openness to social change, the Communist Party maintains tight media censorship and does not tolerate criticism. The charges against Nga are deemed "bogus" by Human Rights Watch, and the US has called for her release and an end to retribution against critics. This verdict comes as a month after another prominent blogger was jailed for 10 years for similar offenses.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on July 8, 2012 shows Tran Thi Nga (R) holding her son and an anti-China poster as she takes part in an anti-China rally in Hanoi.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher after Wall St records
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.41% on Wednesday morning, following a record close on Wall Street. Investors welcomed strong corporate earnings, driving the Hang Seng Index to 26,960.81. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices were flat, while the US stock market reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Britain makes pitch for massive Australia warship contract: report
summary: Britain's Defence Secretary Michael Fallon made a pitch to build Australia's next fleet of warships, proposing nine Type 26 Frigates to hunt "Russian and Chinese submarines" in the region. The A$35 billion project is part of Australia's A$89 billion shipbuilding strategy, which includes constructing new submarines and frigates. The contract is currently the world's largest frigate shipbuilding programme, with three designers vying for the contract. The programme aims to replace Australia's current ANZAC class frigates and will be built with a high level of local construction to boost domestic jobs.

site_title: Hong Kong maids lured by Islamic State recruiters: report
summary: Indonesian maids working in Hong Kong are being radicalized by Islamic State extremists, according to a report by the Jakarta-based Institute for Policy Analysis of Conflict. Around 45 Indonesian domestic helpers have been identified as part of a "radical fringe," drawn to militant circles by online connections or a desire for empowerment. The report notes that exploitation by unscrupulous employment agencies may have contributed to the radicalization, but does not appear to be a direct cause. The incident highlights growing concerns about the spread of extremist ideologies among Hong Kong's Indonesian migrant community.

site_title: Japanese firms avoiding price hikes now but sentiment is changing: BOJ's Nakaso
summary: Japanese firms are avoiding price hikes, but sentiment is changing, according to Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Hiroshi Nakaso. Companies are streamlining operations to absorb higher labour costs by revising business processes, such as shortening business hours or investing in labour-saving technology. The BOJ expects inflation to reach its 2% target around fiscal 2019, but some economists argue the forecast is overly optimistic. A recent tankan survey shows firms considering price hikes, and the BOJ may need to adjust its monetary policy accordingly.

site_title: IMF urges ECB to maintain stimulus amid downside risks to growth
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged the European Central Bank (ECB) to maintain stimulus in the euro area amid downside risks to economic growth. The IMF warned of significant risks, including high debt levels, structural weaknesses in the banking system, and uncertainty from Brexit negotiations. The ECB's assessment of the economic outlook is slightly more optimistic, but officials agree that the region needs central-bank support. The IMF predicts economic growth of 1.9% this year and 1.7% in 2018, with inflation expected to slow to 1.5% in 2018.

site_title: Australia's central bank governor defends low policy rates
summary: Australia's central bank governor, Philip Lowe, defended the country's low policy rates, citing a strong labour market and subdued wages as reasons for maintaining lower rates. The labour market strengthened in June, with full-time jobs rising and the unemployment rate steady at 5.6%. However, wage growth remains slow, and high household debt puts downward pressure on inflation, which remains below the RBA's 2-3% target band. Lowe stated that the RBA will continue to be patient and focused on delivering an average inflation rate of 2-3%, supporting sustainable growth.

site_title: Odebrecht paid US$27.7m in bribes in Colombia: prosecutor
summary: Brazil's Odebrecht paid US$27.7 million in bribes in Colombia, including $11.1 million identified by the US, according to a prosecutor. Four Colombian senators are under investigation for allegedly taking bribes related to infrastructure contracts. Odebrecht has acknowledged distributing $11.1 million in bribes in Colombia, and electoral authorities are investigating potential ties to the 2014 presidential campaigns of Juan Manuel Santos and Oscar Ivan Zuluaga. The graft scandal has rocked several Latin American countries.

site_title: Paris tourism alive and kicking again after terror doldrums
summary: Paris is experiencing a tourism revival after plummeting numbers brought on by terror attacks. The city saw a record 2.6 million foreign arrivals in the first four months of 2017, a 19% increase over the same period in 2016. Terror attacks in other European countries and a sense of fatalism among tourists have contributed to the rebound. The tourism ministry expects a 5-6% increase in overall arrivals to France this year, with a new record of 89 million visitors in 2017.

images.alt_text: High-kicking dancers are enthralling full houses again at the Moulin Rouge and art lovers are swarming the Louvre as Paris enjoys a tourism revival after plummeting numbers brought on by terror attacks.

site_title: China to turn all centrally owned giants into joint-stock firms by 2017
summary: China plans to convert all centrally owned giants into joint-stock firms by the end of 2017, aiming to give state-owned companies a more flexible and market-based operating mechanism. This restructuring follows ongoing reforms to promote market-oriented development and improve corporate governance. The move is expected to enhance the efficiency and competitiveness of state-owned enterprises, ultimately benefiting the Chinese economy.

site_title: Airbnb, Mizuho-backed venture team up to offer Japan-only perks
summary: Airbnb has partnered with Blue Lab Co, a Mizuho-backed venture, to offer Japan-only unique experiences such as staying in temples and train stations. This initiative aims to provide hotel-like extras and promote local events. Japan's government has recently passed a law allowing home-sharing, and the market is expected to grow with over 24 million tourists visiting in 2016. Airbnb and Blue Lab plan to introduce personalized services, local events, and financing options for property owners, competing with local companies such as Rakuten and HomeAway.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open slightly higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened slightly higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.78 points to 1766.04. Gainers outnumbered losers 104 to 51, with a total trading volume of 56.99 million lots worth RM26.14 million.

site_title: Twitter no longer at 'death's door' as earnings report approaches
summary: Twitter's stock has surged over 40% since April, with investors optimistic about the company's user growth. The social media platform reported 6% year-over-year growth in monthly active users in April, reaching 328 million users. Analysts expect Twitter's quarterly earnings report to show revenue of $536.6 million, a 10.9% drop from the previous year. The company's recent positive signs include co-founder Jack Dorsey purchasing additional shares and Biz Stone's return to Twitter. Investors are willing to give Twitter the benefit of the doubt, viewing it as a niche platform.

images.alt_text: Twitter Inc heads toward its quarterly earnings report on Thursday with a stock that has risen more than 40 per cent since April when much of Wall Street was ready to write off the tech company.

site_title: Malaysia Air seeks partners for Hajj-focused service using A380s
summary: Malaysia Airlines is seeking partners for a new Hajj-focused charter service using its A380 superjumbos. The airline aims to offer a separate venture, separate from its main service, and expects it to be operational in about a year. The service will accommodate up to 700 passengers and is seen as a profitable business opportunity. Malaysia Airlines is also exploring leasing options and new purchases to meet its growing demand, and is focusing on business class and premium cabins to increase revenue.

site_title: 'Day From Hell' looms as US$3t of companies post earnings
summary: A record-breaking earnings day is expected in Europe, with over $3 trillion worth of companies reporting results, including Anheuser-Busch InBev, Nestle, and British American Tobacco. Analysts, known as "Day From Hell," will be bracing for a busy day with multiple reports and briefings, potentially leading to volatility in share prices. The day's schedule includes 11 major companies, with no breaks in between, and analysts expect abbreviated notes with shorthand terms, such as "OG" for organic growth.

images.alt_text: If you think your Thursday looks bad, spare a thought for James Edwardes Jones. The RBC analyst is bracing for what he calls the busiest earnings day he's experienced in about 20 years covering the consumer-goods industry.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.24% higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.24% to 3,335.70 on Wednesday, driven by overnight gains in US markets. Gainers outnumbered losers 89 to 50, with Thai Beverage Public Co and Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust among the top performers. The rally follows a 5-day streak of gains ahead of GDP data and amid ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: CNMC warns of 'significantly lower' Q2 profit
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings expects a "significantly lower profit" for Q2 due to lower ore grades, impacting revenue. The company will announce its Q2 results by August 14.

site_title: China Merchants plans US$1.12b investment in Sri Lanka
summary: China Merchants Port Holdings Co plans to invest $1.12 billion in Sri Lanka's Hambantota International Port Group, acquiring 85% stake for $973.7 million. The 99-year concession will enable the terminal operator to develop and operate port and related facilities. The investment aligns with China's "One Belt, One Road" initiative, positioning the company for trade and infrastructure growth in Asia and Europe. This move aims to strengthen economic ties and raise China's profile as a global trade power.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas scraps US$29b western Canada LNG project
summary: Malaysia's state-owned energy company Petronas has scrapped a proposed $29 billion liquefied natural gas (LNG) project in western Canada due to weak global prices. The project, known as Pacific NorthWest LNG, was expected to produce 12 megatonnes per year and spur further development of British Columbia's Montney natural gas play. Petronas' decision is the latest setback for Canada's energy industry, which has seen international oil firms sell off $23 billion in Canadian energy assets this year.

site_title: Uber's new CEO shortlist is said to include HPE's Meg Whitman
summary: Uber Technologies Inc is expected to name a new CEO by early September, with a shortlist of five candidates, including Meg Whitman, former CEO of Hewlett Packard Enterprise. The company's board, assisted by executive recruitment firm Heidrick & Struggles, is overseeing the search process. The new leader will aim to steer the ride-hailing business out of a turbulent period following the ousting of former CEO Travis Kalanick. Uber hopes to complete the hiring process within six weeks.

images.alt_text: Uber Technologies Inc hopes to name a new leader by early September to replace its ousted chief executive officer and steer the ride-hailing business out of a turbulent period.

site_title: US energy secretary duped into fake interview with Russian comedians
summary: US Energy Secretary Rick Perry was duped into a fake phone call with Russian comedians, thinking they were Ukraine's prime minister. During the 22-minute call, Perry discussed expanding American coal exports to Ukraine, sanctions against Russia, and the Paris climate accord. The call was recorded and posted online, and Perry's comments seemed to align with the Trump administration's stance on Ukraine and Russia. The incident highlights the risk of prank calls targeting high-level officials.

site_title: Wynn Resorts' profit falls short despite rebound in Macau
summary: Wynn Resorts' second-quarter profit fell short of expectations, despite a rebound in Macau's casino market. The company's new Macau resort, Wynn Palace, generated property earnings of $87.4 million, below estimates. Macau's industry revenue rose 22% in the second quarter, but the Wynn Palace's mass market revenue growth was disappointing. The company's shares fell 4.3% in extended trading. Despite this, Wynn Resorts' overall revenue topped estimates, driven by the strong recovery in Macau.

site_title: Oil rallies 3% as US shale shows signs of slowdown
summary: Oil prices rose 3.3% to $50.20 a barrel, the highest close in over a month, after US oil producer Anadarko cut capital spending plans and Saudi Arabia vowed to reduce crude exports to curb global oversupply. US shale production may be slowing due to low oil prices, and Opec and non-Opec producers agreed to limit exports to 6.6 million barrels per day in August.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.67% to 20,088.68, driven by a lower yen that brightened exporter earnings prospects. The Topix index also rose 0.59%.

site_title: Apple ordered to pay US$506m to university in patent dispute
summary: A US judge ordered Apple to pay $506 million in damages for infringing on a patent owned by the University of Wisconsin-Madison's patent licensing arm, Wisconsin Alumni Research Foundation (WARF). The verdict, more than doubling the initial $234 million jury verdict, stems from a patent related to computer processor technology. Apple is appealing the ruling, which also includes additional damages and interest for continued infringement until the patent expired in December 2016.

site_title: First Sponsor Q2 profit up 8.8%; Chengdu project being assessed
summary: First Sponsor Group's Q2 net profit rose 8.8% to S$9.4 million, driven by sales of 99% of Millennium Waterfront residential units in Chengdu, China. Revenue increased 27.7% to S$53.9 million. The company declared an interim dividend of one Singapore cent per share. First Sponsor is assessing the development feasibility of the remaining phase of the project amid current market conditions.

site_title: Seoul: Won falters after long rally; stocks ease
summary: The South Korean won fell 0.3% against the US dollar, to 1,118.9, after a two-week long rally ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting. The won rose 3.7% from July 7-24, but is expected to remain calm after the Fed keeps rates unchanged. South Korean shares fluctuated, with the Kospi index down 0.3% at 2,433.48 points, amid foreign investors selling Kospi shares worth 168.1 billion won. Hotel Shilla Co Ltd jumped 8.3% after reporting better-than-expected profits, while Samsung SDS Co Ltd plunged 9% after a research report recommended selling the stock.

site_title: Trump vows to 'terminate' Nafta if negotiations fail
summary: US President Donald Trump vowed to "terminate" the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) if renegotiation talks fail, stating it has been a "disaster" for American workers. Trump announced the plan while visiting Ohio, citing the need for a better deal that benefits American workers. The renegotiation process began earlier this month, with Trump seeking to reform the 23-year-old deal.

site_title: New York outlines US$8.8b plan to overhaul subway
summary: New York's Metropolitan Transport Authority (MTA) has unveiled a $8.8 billion plan to overhaul the city's subway system, addressing chronic delays, breakdowns, and overcrowding. The immediate plan includes $456 million in operating costs and $380 million in capital investments. A long-term plan will require an additional $8 billion. The plan aims to modernize the system, including a pilot program to remove seats to increase passenger capacity, and expedited repairs. The MTA has also launched an international competition to find solutions to improve the subway.

site_title: Viva Q2 DPS up 6.3% on higher contributions from business park
summary: Viva Industrial Trust reported a 6.3% increase in second-quarter distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.861 Singapore cents, driven by higher contributions from its business park. Net property income grew 17.5% to S$20.2 million, with gross revenue increasing 18% to S$27.6 million. The trust's portfolio occupancy weighted by rental income rose to 90.6% as of end-June, up from 87.9% a year ago.

site_title: Trump says Yellen and Cohn possible Fed chair picks: WSJ
summary: US President Donald Trump has named Janet Yellen and Gary Cohn as possible candidates to run the Federal Reserve over the next few years, according to an interview with The Wall Street Journal. Yellen, whose term expires in February, is "in the running" to be renominated, while Cohn, Trump's economic adviser, "certainly would be in the mix." Trump plans to make the announcement at the end of the year, with two or three other contenders also in consideration. Any Fed nominee would require Senate confirmation.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yoma, Suntec Reit, Sabana Reit, CNMC, First Sponsor
summary: Myanmar-based conglomerate Yoma Strategic Holdings reported a 54% increase in first-quarter net profit to S$2.8 million. Suntec Reit's second-quarter distribution per unit slipped 0.3% to 2.493 Singapore cents, while Sabana Reit's gross revenue fell 2.9% to S$22 million. CNMC Goldmine Holdings expects a "significantly lower profit" for the second quarter due to lower ore grades. First Sponsor Group reported a 8.8% increase in second-quarter net profit to S$9.37 million.

site_title: SoftBank said to take stake in Roomba maker in buildout
summary: SoftBank has taken a less than 5% stake in IRobot Corp, the maker of Roomba vacuum cleaners, as part of its efforts to build its holdings in robotics firms. The stake was purchased in a private transaction, below the amount requiring regulatory disclosure in the US. This move follows SoftBank's recent acquisitions of Boston Dynamics and Brain Corp, and is part of its US$93 billion Vision Fund's efforts to target US$100 billion in total commitments. IRobot's shares rose 22% following the announcement.

site_title: Wanna recreate Titanic? Leo and Kate will be your date, for the right price
summary: Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet are auctioning off a private dinner date in New York City for charity, with proceeds going to the Leonardo DiCaprio Foundation. The date, set for fall, is among several lots being offered at the foundation's gala in Saint-Tropez. The dinner, valued at an unspecified price, will be hosted by the Titanic stars, who previously starred in the 1998 film. The auction is part of a growing trend of celebrities offering exclusive experiences to raise funds for charity.

site_title: Microsoft keeps Paint in its software palette
summary: Microsoft has announced that it will not abandon its Paint application, despite earlier reports suggesting its demise. The software giant received an outpouring of support and nostalgia from fans after the news sparked concern. While Paint will no longer be part of the Windows operating system by default, it will be available for free in the Windows Store and updated by Microsoft. A new 3D version of Paint, called Paint 3D, will feature improved capabilities, including photo editing and 2D creation tools.

site_title: Australia inflation surprisingly soft, lengthens odds on rate hike
summary: Australia's consumer prices rose 0.2% in the second quarter, falling short of the 2.2% expected, and the annual rate of 1.8% remains below the Reserve Bank of Australia's 2-3% target. This soft inflation data lengthens the odds of a rate hike and keeps interest rates at record lows. The central bank is unlikely to hike rates soon, citing subdued inflation and a debt-driven housing market bubble.

images.alt_text: Australian consumer prices were surprisingly soft last quarter and core inflation rate stayed below target for a sixth straight quarter, a reminder of just why interest rates in the country are at record lows and set to remain there for months to come.

site_title: Suntec Reit Q2 DPU down 0.3%
summary: Suntec Reit's Q2 DPU decreased 0.3% to 2.493 cents, despite a 12.8% increase in net property income to S$59.4 million. Gross revenue rose 10.6% to S$87.3 million, driven by a 33.4% increase in office revenue. Occupancy rates remained high, at 98.7% for office assets and 99% for retail assets.

site_title: From earthship homes to luxury eco-houses, sustainable living gains ground
summary: Sustainable living is gaining ground, with over 20% of luxury consumers in the US, UK, UAE, India, and China seeking eco-friendly homes. Luxury homes often feature geo-thermal heating and cooling, solar panels, and energy-efficient technologies. Earthship homes, which use natural or recycled materials, and off-grid structures are also popular. However, a sustainable lifestyle can be costly and may not always be environmentally friendly, especially in countries with abundant renewable energy. Experts emphasize the importance of considering factors such as maintenance costs, lifestyle changes, and environmental impact when choosing an eco-friendly home.

site_title: Journalists, NGO slam Saudi 'threats' to close Al-Jazeera
summary: Saudi Arabia and its allies have issued "threats" to close Qatari media organization Al-Jazeera, along with other outlets, following a boycott of Qatar. The "threats" were condemned by journalists, human rights activists, and international organizations at a conference in Doha, which also called for Qatar to engage in reforms to maintain its moral high ground. The boycott, which began on June 5, includes 13 demands, including Al-Jazeera's closure, and has been escalated with the release of a "terrorist" blacklist of 18 organizations and individuals.

site_title: US House votes to slap sanctions on Russia, Iran, North Korea
summary: The US House of Representatives voted 419-3 to impose tough new sanctions on Iran, North Korea, and Russia, a move that will antagonize the Kremlin and European nations. The sanctions package, which now heads to the Senate, aims to punish Russia for meddling in the 2016 US presidential election and Russia's annexation of Crimea. The measure also constrains President Donald Trump's ability to waive penalties, effectively placing him under Congress's watch. The sanctions package includes provisions against Iran and North Korea, with the North Korea sanctions being included for the first time.

site_title: 'Euphoric' exporters lift German business morale to new high in July
summary: German business morale reached a record high in July, with the Ifo economic institute's business climate index rising to 116, its third record high in as many months. Despite a strong euro's impact, exporters are optimistic about a surge in exports, boosting morale to an all-time high. The increase beats expectations and suggests robust economic growth in Europe's largest economy.

site_title: Netflix announces new show from creator of 'The Simpsons'
summary: Netflix has ordered a new animated adult comedy series, "Disenchantment", from creator Matt Groening, best known for "The Simpsons". The show follows the misadventures of hard-drinking princess Bean, her elf companion Elfo, and her demon Luci in the medieval kingdom of Dreamland. The series, featuring Abbi Jacobson, Nat Faxon, and Eric Andre, will consist of 20 episodes, with the first half premiering next year. Netflix describes the show as a perfect fit for its animation fans, bearing Groening's trademark style and wit.

site_title: US Fed opens 2-day meeting amid weak inflation
summary: The US Federal Reserve opened its two-day meeting, but is expected to leave the key interest rate untouched after two hikes this year. Markets are watching for signals on another rate hike in 2017 and when the Fed will start winding down its investment holdings. Despite low unemployment, wage gains remain sluggish, and price pressures have retreated, leaving economists puzzled. The Fed is expected to adopt a wait-and-see posture, citing steady job creation and low unemployment as factors that will eventually drive inflation towards the 2% target.

site_title: US dollar little changed after hitting 13-month low as Fed begins meeting
summary: The US dollar remained little changed after hitting a 13-month low against a basket of major currencies as investors gained hope on President Donald Trump's expansionary fiscal agenda. The euro rose to its highest since August 2015, boosted by a stronger-than-expected German business survey, while the US dollar regained ground against the euro and other currencies after US Treasury yields rose and demand for safe-haven bonds decreased. The US Senate passed a motion to proceed on repealing the Affordable Care Act, further supporting the dollar.

site_title: Trump touts 'very big' trade deal with Britain
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a "very big" trade deal with Britain, citing the potential for significant job creation. The deal is part of the US-UK Trade and Investment Working Group, aimed at boosting trade relations between the two countries post-Brexit. Trade between the US and UK is worth around $230 billion annually, and the US is Britain's largest export market. British Foreign Minister Boris Johnson has expressed optimism about securing trade deals with other nations, including New Zealand.

site_title: VW executive to plead guilty in 'dieselgate' case
summary: Volkswagen executive Oliver Schmidt agreed to plead guilty to charges of fraud and conspiracy in the "dieselgate" emissions-cheating scandal. Schmidt, who led the US regulatory compliance office from 2012 to 2015, will plead guilty on August 4 at a US federal court in Michigan. This is the second VW employee to plead guilty, following James Liang, a former engineer who pleaded guilty last year. VW agreed to pay $4.3 billion in fines and has set aside $22 billion to cover fines and compensation related to the scandal.

site_title: Brain damage found in 110 of 111 deceased NFL players: study
summary: Researchers found that 99% of 111 deceased NFL players' brains showed signs of degenerative disease, likely caused by repeated blows to the head. Chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) was found in 110 players, with 86% of professional players having severe forms of the condition. The study suggests a link between football participation and CTE, but cautions against extrapolating the results to the general population. The findings support growing concerns about the long-term effects of head trauma in football, and the NFL has faced scrutiny and implemented regulations to minimize the impact.

site_title: Women in focus at Toronto film festival
summary: The Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF) is focusing on female directors, screenwriters, and actresses for its 10-day event, starting on September 7. The festival aims to address criticism of its male-dominated past. Key films include "Kings" by Deniz Gamze Erguven, "Mary Shelley" by Haifaa Al Mansour, and "Mudbound" by Dee Rees. Oscar winners Halle Berry, Elle Fanning, and Emma Stone will star in these films, alongside other notable actresses like Jessica Chastain and Margot Robbie. The festival promises a women-heavy line-up for its 400,000 visitors.

site_title: US detects signs of new North Korea missile test
summary: The US has detected signs that North Korea is preparing for another missile test, with possible targets including an intermediate-range missile or intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) known as the KN-20 or Hwasong-14. The test, potentially occurring on July 27, could put Alaska in range and pose a challenge to President Donald Trump. The US has made progress in pushing China to impose tougher UN sanctions, with US Ambassador Nikki Haley stating that "pretty serious" new measures are being considered, including cutting off oil supplies and imposing air and maritime restrictions.

images.alt_text: The Pentagon has picked up signs that North Korea is prepping for another missile test, a US defece official said Tuesday, as the United States cited progress in pushing China to impose tough new UN sanctions.

site_title: Trump won't let Syria's leader Assad get away with 'horrible' crimes
summary: US President Donald Trump accused Syria's leader Bashar al-Assad of committing "horrible" crimes against humanity and vowed to prevent further chemical attacks. Trump also criticized Hezbollah, calling it a threat to the Middle East, and pledged continued US military aid to Lebanon. He recalled his predecessor Barack Obama's red line against Assad, saying it prevented Russia and Iran's involvement in Syria. Trump also accused Iran and Hezbollah of fueling the humanitarian disaster in Syria, and promised to make his position on possible sanctions against Hezbollah clear in the next 24 hours.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump accused Syria's leader Bashar al-Assad on Tuesday of committing "horrible" crimes against humanity and vowed to prevent his regime from carrying out any more chemical attacks.

site_title: S Korea expects fastest growth in 3 years in 2017
summary: South Korea's economy is expected to grow at its fastest rate in three years in 2017, with a forecasted 3% expansion, driven by strong exports and a $10 billion stimulus package. This marks the strongest projected growth since 2014, as the global economy rebounds. The government aims to create 110,000 new jobs, targeting sectors such as education and social welfare, to address record-high youth unemployment. The improved outlook is attributed to a recovery in exports and consumption-led growth reforms.

site_title: Thai authorities freeze ousted premier Yingluck's bank accounts
summary: Thai authorities have frozen seven bank accounts belonging to ousted premier Yingluck Shinawatra, worth around US$1 billion, due to her alleged role in the country's controversial rice subsidy scheme. The move financially sanctions an elected leader for a government policy and is the latest in a barrage of legal battles she faces since being ousted in 2014. Yingluck, who could face up to a decade in jail for allegedly failing to stop graft in the subsidy programme, has denied wrongdoing and plans to prove her innocence in a trial set to conclude on August 25.

site_title: US Senate votes to advance health care bill
summary: The US Senate voted 50-50 to proceed with a debate on Republican plans to repeal and replace Barack Obama's health care reforms, Obamacare. Senator John McCain, who is suffering from brain cancer, cast a crucial vote, and Vice-President Mike Pence broke the tie. The vote is a victory for President Donald Trump, who has been pushing for the repeal of Obamacare. Despite the vote, many Republicans remain skeptical about the impact of the new plan on millions of Americans, and the Senate will now launch into long hours of debate.

site_title: Changi's T4 on last lap of operational trials
summary: Singapore's Changi Airport's Terminal 4 (T4) is in the final stage of operational readiness trials, featuring live flights with airlines such as Spring Airlines and Korean Air. The terminal, set to open in the second half of the year, spans 225,000 sq m and will handle 16 million passengers annually. It offers self-service options and innovative experiences, including art installations and a digital theatre stage. The terminal's design aims to improve efficiency and manpower productivity, while also showcasing local culture and architectural history.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
Operational readiness trials at Changi Airport's Terminal 4, which include live flights, are currently in the final stage.

site_title: Rio Tinto faces corruption investigation by UK prosecutors
summary: Rio Tinto faces a corruption investigation by the UK's Serious Fraud Office (SFO) over its business dealings in Guinea, particularly the $20 billion Simandou iron ore project. The investigation follows a self-report in November 2016 of a $10.5 million payment to an external consultant, and the subsequent termination of contracts with two senior executives. The probe may stretch on for years, coinciding with Rio's efforts to appoint a new chairman and exit the Simandou project, which was sold to partner Aluminum Corp of China in October.

site_title: Yoma Q1 profit up 54% on higher property, tractor sales
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings' first-quarter net profit rose 54% to S$2.8 million due to higher property and tractor sales. Revenue increased by 46.8% to S$25.8 million, with property sales doubling to S$6.2 million. The company also expects to deliver another 312 tractors, generating about S$8 million in revenue. An interim dividend of 0.25 Singapore cents per share is being declared.

site_title: Europe: Stocks spring higher led by banks, miners
summary: European stocks rose 0.4% on Tuesday, driven by gains in commodity firms and banking stocks, as well as solid corporate updates. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index held onto gains despite some investors expressing caution about the macro environment. Key performers included Raiffeisen, Antofagasta, and Informa, while tech stocks saw mixed results after Alphabet's warning on expenses. The US Federal Reserve meeting later in the day is expected to keep interest rates on hold for now.

site_title: Activist hedge funds busy punting M&A ball
summary: Activist hedge funds are increasingly pushing for mergers and acquisitions (M&A) as a preferred strategy, driven by high valuations and the desire for quick returns. This trend has led to a surge in activist-driven deals, with 91 M&A-related campaign demands made so far this year, up from 45 in 2016. The success of these campaigns has boosted returns for dissident investors, but may also put activists at odds with larger investors who prefer long-term strategies.

site_title: US Commerce Secretary: Nafta talks need quick outcome
summary: US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross emphasized the need for a quick outcome in the upcoming talks to rework the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) due to US and Mexican political deadlines. The US side is focused on cutting its $56 billion trade deficit with Mexico. Ross stated that setting a specific date may be a "big mistake," but the political calendars suggest a quick resolution is necessary.

site_title: Hong Kong's IPO naming and shaming hits new low
summary: Hong Kong's IPO naming and shaming has hit a new low with the rejection of AMTD Strategic Capital's application, the sixth company to be publicly shamed by the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong. The bourse cited the filing as "substantially incomplete" and the company could have raised $200 million. The rejection is a blow to joint sponsors China Everbright Capital and China Merchant Securities, and comes amid efforts by the Securities and Futures Commission to clean up the local market. Naming and shaming has significant reputational and financial costs for companies, leading to dropped listing plans and rival bankers gaining an advantage.

site_title: DBS, BOS shift to fast gear as private banks power ahead in Asia
summary: Singapore's DBS and OCBC banks are rapidly expanding their private banking business in Asia, driven by high growth in assets under management (AUM) and income. DBS has leapfrogged international rivals, becoming the fifth-largest private bank in Asia-Pacific, while OCBC's Bank of Singapore has rapidly expanded into the Middle East and Africa. Both banks report double-digit gains in AUM and revenue, driven by new investment and insurance products. The region is leading the way in wealth creation, with Asia minting new billionaires every three days, according to a UBS study.

site_title: BHP Billiton advances hunt for copper in Ecuador
summary: BHP Billiton has established an office in Quito, Ecuador, and plans to spend about US$82 million on exploration, seeking to add staff in the country's last mining frontier. The company joins other major players, including Hancock Prospecting and Newcrest Mining, in a bid to tap into Ecuador's potential for copper and gold deposits. The country's mining sector is expected to rise to US$7.9 billion by 2021, driven by increased exploration and investment. Ecuador's efforts to attract miners include revised tax laws and upgraded infrastructure.

site_title: First Facebook TV episodes are said to be ready for mid-August
summary: Facebook's first TV episodes are set to debut in mid-August, after several delays. The social media giant is funding short-form, inexpensive programs and higher-end TV-style shows, with the latter to be launched later. Facebook aims to create a new video section outside the news feed, targeting the $70 billion US television advertising market. The company has hired former TV and media executives to oversee its foray into original video, with no plans to fund shows long-term. This move is expected to provide a testing ground for the content, competing with YouTube and other video producers.

images.alt_text: Facebook Inc's version of television is coming online in mid-August after several false starts, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Banking, fintech tie-ups represent a potent force
summary: Banks and fintech companies are forming partnerships to leverage the benefits of fintech, such as agility and customer focus, while banks gain access to fintech's expertise and networks. DBS, a Singaporean bank, has successfully integrated fintech into its operations, launching a mobile-only banking platform, digibank, in India, which has acquired over 840,000 customers in 10 months. DBS is also running pre-accelerator programs and innovation facilities to foster collaboration with fintech companies and stay ahead in the digital revolution.

site_title: Is the economy too hot, too cold or just right?
summary: The global economy is experiencing a synchronized recovery, with global growth and earnings revisions turning positive. However, inflation in the US has not picked up as expected, despite falling unemployment. The Federal Reserve is facing a conundrum in deciding when to raise interest rates, with some arguing that it should wait to avoid disrupting markets. Despite this, central banks remain accommodative, and global volatility remains low due to synchronized growth and reduced political uncertainty. The market is pricing in only one rate rise over the next two years, and the Fed is expected to raise rates once this year.

site_title: US: Earnings, bank shares propel S&P 500 to record high
summary: US stocks reached an all-time high on Tuesday, driven by strong corporate earnings reports from McDonald's and Caterpillar, as well as gains in bank shares. The S&P 500 climbed 7.17 points to 2,477.08, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 100.26 points to 21,613.43. Data showing a jump in US consumer confidence also contributed to the bullish sentiment.

site_title: Shaken, not replaced: Craig reportedly back as 007 in 2019
summary: Daniel Craig is reportedly set to return as James Bond in 2019, contrary to his previous statements. The 49-year-old actor, who has expressed reluctance to play Bond again, will star in the 25th film in the franchise. The movie's release date is set for November 8, 2019, with the cast and director to be announced later. Craig's return was confirmed by The New York Times, citing unnamed sources, and will be written by Neal Purvis and Robert Wade, the same duo behind previous Bond films.

site_title: Can't miss the irony in liner trade consolidation
summary: Cosco Shipping Holdings Ltd has acquired Hong Kong-based Orient Overseas International Ltd (OOIL) in a $1.2 billion deal, further consolidating the container industry. The move is seen as a step towards "liner paradise," with the combined Cosco-OOCL operation becoming the world's third-largest container carrier. Analyst Drewry predicts that this consolidation will lead to fewer players in the market, resulting in a more closely aligned supply-demand balance and potentially higher freight rates. However, shippers may be negatively impacted as they lose another carrier from the market, reducing competition and potentially driving up prices.

site_title: Iran's tech sector blooms under shield of sanctions
summary: Iran's tech sector is thriving under US sanctions, with domestic startups recreating foreign services such as Uber and Amazon. The sector has attracted hundreds of millions of dollars in foreign investment, with partnerships between Iranian and international companies. Despite sanctions limiting access to global markets, tech experts believe the sector's growth will continue, with potential for expansion into traditional sectors like retail. The unique challenges and opportunities presented by sanctions are being leveraged to drive innovation and entrepreneurship in Iran.

site_title: FAST and efficient
summary: Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event in Mumbai, while expanding its robotaxi services to California and Arizona. FedEx partnered with Singapore's QuikBot to deploy robots for commercial deliveries, and Delta Air Lines reported an upbeat outlook on travel demand. Japan's carmakers reduced export prices to the US to offset the impact of tariffs. Meanwhile, BYD and other EV battery makers face increased pressure to cut emissions.

site_title: Alibaba, Paytm said to be in talks to invest in India's Bigbasket
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd and Paytm E-commerce Pvt are in talks to invest about $200 million for a 20% stake in India's leading online grocer Bigbasket. The investment, part of a 60-day exclusive pact, would give Alibaba and Paytm a strategic advantage to take on Amazon in the Indian market. Several other companies, including Amazon and global retail titan Amazon.com Inc, are also interested in investing in Bigbasket. The investment comes as India's online grocery segment heats up, with e-commerce growing rapidly in the country.

site_title: Greece announces plans to sell debt for the first time in years
summary: Greece announces plans to sell debt for the first time in years, offering hope that the country may be preparing to wean itself off international bailouts. The proposed bond sale, worth 460 billion euros, could be a landmark moment for Greece and the eurozone. The sale is expected to be dominated by institutional investors, and Greece's economy is still reeling from years of austerity measures. The move represents a significant step towards restoring financial stability and could pave the way for Greece to become a financially self-sufficient country.

site_title: Double boost for PLife Reit Q2 DPU
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 10.3% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit to 3.32 Singapore cents for Q2 2023. This was driven by asset-recycling gains and higher distributable income from operations. Net property income rose 1.4% to S$25.9 million, while gross revenue grew 1.1% to S$27.7 million. The Reit's units rose 3.4% to S$2.76 following the announcement.

site_title: How data can drive new mobile banking for gig economy
summary: Singapore banks are exploring ways to use data to offer more attractive lending options to gig workers, despite the challenges of assessing creditworthiness in this demographic. Two internet-only banks in South Korea, K-Bank and Kakao Bank, have successfully used consumption patterns and data from various apps to customize interest rates for borrowers. In Singapore, banks can tap into data from gig workers' mobile apps, CPF contributions, and contract deals to assess their creditworthiness. This could lead to the introduction of unique credit cards and short-term loans for gig workers, enabling them to access credit and improve their financial stability.

site_title: America's warrior-senator McCain returns to Senate - for now
summary: US Senator John McCain, who announced his battle with brain cancer, made a dramatic return to the Senate on July 25, 2017. Despite his illness, McCain showed his characteristic passion and made his colleagues wait for his entrance. The maverick senator's return was met with a mix of emotions, but he seemed determined to continue serving. The news comes after McCain's health had raised concerns among his colleagues and the public.

images.alt_text: Senator John McCain, who announced last week he was suffering from brain cancer, made a triumphant and emotional return Tuesday, showing glimpses of the fiery passion that has defined his long career.

site_title: IMF based in Beijing? Maybe in 2027, its director says
summary: Christine Lagarde, IMF director, joked about relocating the organization's headquarters to Beijing in 2027, citing the shift in global economic power towards emerging countries like China. The IMF's headquarters is currently in Washington DC, reflecting the US's largest economy. Lagarde also expressed concern over the US's changing role in global organizations and warned of risks to the world economy, including inequality and the backlash against globalization.

images.alt_text: Ms Lagarde (above) may joke, but her comments reflect a concern that world leaders have about the changing role of the United States in global organisations. The articles of the organisation say that the headquarters should be in the country of the member with the largest economy.

site_title: Zombie firms across Europe may tie ECB's hands for years
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) may be limited in its ability to withdraw monetary stimulus due to zombie firms across Europe, which could collapse if support dries up. About 9% of Europe's biggest companies are classified as "zombies" with weak profitability, according to Bank of America analysts. This could slow the ECB's decision to remove stimulus, which is expected to be gradual and patient. The ECB's dovish tone and planned tapering of monetary policy may be hindered by the presence of zombie firms, particularly in the energy and southern European sectors.

site_title: Michael Kors snaps up Jimmy Choo for £900m
summary: Michael Kors has agreed to buy British luxury shoe brand Jimmy Choo for approximately £900 million (S$1.6 billion), making it the "ideal partner" for the US fashion brand. Jimmy Choo, known for its celebrity clients, will continue to operate independently under Michael Kors.

site_title: Turbo Harrier now an official Toyota import
summary: Toyota has officially launched the turbocharged Harrier in Singapore, making it the first country outside Japan to receive the car. The Harrier uses the same platform as the Toyota RAV4 and Lexus NX, but with a new turbocharged engine that produces 227 hp. The car is identical to the Japanese domestic version, with only some localisation to English language. Borneo Motors, the authorised distributor, will offer the Harrier alongside the RAV4, and it is expected to eventually make its way to Thailand and other Asian countries.

site_title: Private banks in Asia having a good year
summary: Asian private banks are experiencing a strong year, driven by wealth creation and growth. According to UBS's 2016 global billionaire study, Asia is leading the way in wealth creation, with new billionaires created every three days. Banks such as UBS, Credit Suisse, and DBS are reporting record growth in assets under management, private banking revenues, and net new assets. Key drivers include increased client activity, digital innovation, and a focus on Asia's growing markets. Hiring continues, with a focus on attracting senior bankers and building talent pipelines. Despite rising competition for talent, banks are managing costs and increasing efficiency to maintain profitability.

site_title: Unlocking global wealth through gender parity
summary: Achieving global gender parity could boost the global GDP by $12 trillion within a decade, according to a McKinsey report. Current gender gaps cost the global economy billions of dollars in lost activity annually. The main obstacles to women's advancement include lack of educational opportunities, domestic responsibilities, and the glass ceiling. To unlock this wealth, it requires courage to succeed and sisterly love. The United Nations has dedicated the fifth Sustainable Development Goal to achieving gender equality, but it will take global solutions and significant funding to realize the goal by 2030.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust reported an in-line set of Q3 FY17 results, with gross revenue falling 3.3% year on year to S$43.6 million. Distribution per unit declined 1.3% year on year to three Singapore cents. Analysts have varying views on the stock, with OCBC Investment Research updating their model to incorporate more conservative occupancy and rental assumptions, Lian Beng calling for a potential breakout, and CSE Global reducing their target price to S$0.39.

site_title: SHS in JV with Japanese to provide steel staircases in Singapore
summary: SHS Holdings' wholly owned subsidiary Hetat Holdings is entering a three-party joint-venture (JV) with Japanese precision staircase manufacturer Yokomori Mfg and steel trader Marubeni-Itochu Steel Inc (MISI) to provide and sell steel staircases in Singapore. The JV, Yokomori Singapore, aims to produce 1,000-1,500 tonnes of staircases in the first few years. Yokomori will hold 60% stake, while SHS and MISI will hold 30% and 10% respectively. This is Yokomori's first venture into the Singapore market, with plans to expand into other Asia-Pacific markets in the next two years.

site_title: Northpoint City mall on track to be 90% leased upon opening
summary: Northpoint City mall in Singapore is on track to be 90% leased upon opening, with over 100 F&B outlets and 400 retail spaces. The mall's two wings will be linked by The Courtyard, featuring over 30 retail and quick serve concepts. Anchor tenants Harvey Norman and FairPrice will move into the South Wing, while the North Wing will complete its renovation by September. Northpoint City aims to serve as a lifestyle hub for over half a million residents, with community-focused services and amenities.

images.alt_text: Northpoint City will open its door to shoppers in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Japan's sake makers a-rice to lure over wine lovers
summary: Japan's sake makers are launching the Tohoku Sake Terroir Project, a collaboration between brewers and farmers to develop new products. The initiative aims to promote high-end Japanese rice wine to sophisticated foreign drinkers.
