Brewery executive Kosuke Kuji's past attempts to promote Japanese sake in the US were met with disappointment, as traditional grape-based wine enthusiasts prioritize the local appellation as much as the final product. The project seeks to change this perception and establish Tohoku as a premium sake region.

site_title: ST Engineering sets up US$150m corporate venture capital unit
summary: ST Engineering has set up a US$150 million corporate venture capital unit, ST Engineering Ventures, to invest in promising technology startups and early-stage companies. The unit will also provide access to the group's business network and distribution channels. Additionally, ST Engineering is opening an open innovation lab, Innosparks, to offer individuals and startups the opportunity to see their ideas go to market. The lab is the "first of its kind" engineering-based incubator in Singapore, providing a pool of skilled engineers and advanced equipment to support innovators.

site_title: Chinese shipbuilders tap rising cruise demand, rattling European rivals
summary: Chinese shipbuilders are tapping into the booming US$117 billion passenger ship industry, potentially threatening European rivals. China's government has set cruise shipbuilding as a major objective under its "Made in China 2025" program, driven by a 30% annual increase in domestic demand for cruise holidays. Chinese yards, such as Shanghai Waigaoqiao Shipbuilding, are learning from European advisers and attracting foreign suppliers to compete in the luxury cruise sector, which requires complex supply chains and high-value items. This shift could lead to China dominating the cruise ship market, similar to its dominance in cargo ships.

images.alt_text: China State Shipbuilding Corp (CSSC) has brought European advisers in to the Shanghai Waigaoqiao Shipbuilding yard to help it learn how to compete in building cruise ships.

site_title: Alphabet reports 21 per cent jump in quarterly revenue
summary: Alphabet Inc. reported a 21% jump in quarterly revenue to $3.5 billion, driven by sales gains from its internet businesses, including Google and YouTube. However, the company's profit was reduced by a record $2.7 billion European Union antitrust fine. Despite this, Alphabet maintained a growth rate that is rare for companies of its size, with shares rising 26% for the year. The company warned that costs would remain high as more searches shift to mobile devices, potentially weighing on future profit.

site_title: Alibaba in talks for stake in Indonesia online marketplace Tokopedia: sources
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd is in talks to invest up to $500 million in Indonesia's PT Tokopedia, potentially securing a stake in the country's largest online marketplace. This deal would join existing backers SoftBank Group Corp and Sequoia Capital, and could preclude a deal with JD.com Inc. The investment would accelerate Alibaba's expansion into South-east Asia, which is expected to reach $65 billion by 2020, according to Macquarie Research.

site_title: Japan's FamilyMart mulls China, Thai partners
summary: Japan's FamilyMart is considering partnering with China's Citic Ltd and Thailand's Charoen Pokphand Group on new business opportunities beyond convenience stores. The company's president, Koji Takayanagi, aims to double operating profit to 100 billion yen in four years by converting Circle K and Sunkus stores into more profitable FamilyMart ones. FamilyMart is reviewing loss-making businesses in Thailand, Vietnam, and Indonesia, and will remain focused on the domestic market due to Japan's labor shortage and aging population.

site_title: Economists raise China GDP forecast after growth beats estimates
summary: China's economic growth beat estimates, with economists raising forecasts for GDP growth in the third and fourth quarters to 6.7% and 6.6%, respectively. Policymakers now have more room to curb excessive borrowing, giving them leeway to act on financial risks. Expectations for inflation slowed slightly, with forecasts for consumer and producer prices lower than last month. The People's Bank of China is expected to keep policy on hold for the rest of the year, with M2 money supply projected to rise 9.8% this year.

site_title: Why some CFOs are more successful than others
summary: A recent study by Oxford Economics found six distinct traits of top-performing chief financial officers (CFOs), including their understanding of digital technology and its importance in finance. These leaders view cloud-based applications, Big Data, and real-time analytics as crucial for successful finance performance. They also emphasize the need for people to use digital tools, articulate insights, and collaborate across boundaries to drive business decision-making. By leveraging digital tools and dashboards, CFOs can improve efficiency, gain visibility, and make data-driven decisions, ultimately driving business performance and growth.

site_title: It's time US worked to gain from opportunities offered by technology
summary: A bipartisan plan is proposed to address the US's lagging technological innovation, citing outdated government regulations and weak consumer protections. Key areas include transitioning to a real sharing economy, protecting consumers from technological barriers, providing free educational materials, promoting broadband competition, modernizing the electricity grid, giving users control of their data, making software and data open to all, laying the groundwork for intelligent transportation, and standardizing medical record storage and transmission. The plan aims to harness technology to liberate individuals' creative and entrepreneurial potential, provide new educational opportunities, and offer higher wages for marginalized people, while minimizing harm and oppression.

site_title: Ingram Micro to organise cloud, security summit in S'pore in Aug
summary: Ingram Micro will host a cloud and security summit in Singapore from August 2-4, providing insights to partners on growing their business in the cloud and security markets. The summit will feature keynotes from Dropbox, Microsoft, and VMware, focusing on cloud strategy, digital disruption, and cybersecurity. The event aims to help partners "rise above the noise" and understand emerging trends in enterprise computing.

site_title: Singapore's work on sustainable energy on show at Astana Expo 2017
summary: Singapore showcased its strides in sustainable energy at the Astana Expo 2017, a celebration of the country's 52nd National Day. The Singapore pavilion, "Small City, Big Ideas," featured over 350 guests and highlighted the country's bilateral trade ties with Kazakhstan. Total bilateral trade between the two countries reached $23.5 million in goods and $40 million in services in 2015. Singapore's Senior Minister of State Koh Poh Koon praised the expo, calling it a sign of Kazakhstan's openness to engage with the world and encouraging Singapore companies to venture into the Central Asian market.

site_title: Merck, Samsung Bioepis launch discounted Remicade alternative
summary: Merck and Samsung Bioepis launched a discounted version of Johnson & Johnson's rheumatoid arthritis drug Remicade in the US, called Renflexis, at a 35% discount to J&J's list price of $735. This move is expected to accelerate price declines for the big-selling medicine, which had US sales of $4.8 billion last year. Renflexis is the second US biosimilar version of Remicade, following Pfizer's Inflectra, and is expected to further reduce prices once multiple biosimilars become available.

site_title: Markets' rally lifts Great Eastern's Q2 bottom line
summary: Great Eastern Holdings' net profit for the second quarter of 2017 more than doubled to S$279.5 million, driven by a rise in non-operating profit and a significant increase in life insurance business. Gross premiums rose 8% year-on-year to S$2.46 billion. The insurer attributed the strong showing to favorable financial market conditions and growth in its Singapore business. The board declared an interim tax-exempt dividend of 10 cents per share, unchanged from last year.

site_title: Toyota plans to sell long-range, fast-charging electric cars from 2022: report
summary: Toyota plans to sell long-range, fast-charging electric cars starting in 2022, according to a report. The new model will use all-solid-state batteries, allowing for rapid charging in just a few minutes and increasing driving range. Toyota aims to close the gap with EV leaders like Nissan and Tesla, but mass production requires stringent quality control and reliability. The company plans to begin mass-producing EVs in China in 2019, with the goal of offering a viable emission-free alternative to conventional cars.

site_title: Asia's equity market has further room to run
summary: Asia's equity markets have surged 22% in the first half of 2017, with China and South Korea leading the pack. Key drivers of the gains include US dollar weakness, a solid earnings recovery, and diminishing chances of punitive US import tariffs. A weaker dollar has boosted capital inflows, increasing demand for stocks and bonds. Earnings growth is expected to increase by 18% this year, with China driving the recovery, while South Korean equities have been re-rated due to easing political risks and reduced US import tariff likelihood.

site_title: Investors should get infrastructure levies, not tax holidays
summary: Asian governments are facing a significant infrastructure funding shortfall, with the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and International Monetary Fund warning of a need to increase revenue collection. The Asian Development Bank estimates the annual infrastructure bill will be $1.7 trillion between 2023 and 2030. Governments have responded with tax holidays and incentives, but this approach is unsustainable. Instead, imposing infrastructure levies on foreign investors could be a viable solution, as the private sector is not gearing up to shoulder the burden.

site_title: Trump kills the messenger: but it's still the same message
summary: US President Donald Trump has fired White House press secretary Sean Spicer, citing the press secretary's inability to effectively communicate the administration's message. Spicer's departure is attributed to his transformation into a national joke due to his appearance and mannerisms, which overshadowed the president's image. Spicer's unflattering portrayal on NBC's Saturday Night Live, particularly in a sketch featuring Melissa McCarthy as a drag-wearing version of him, contributed to his downfall. Trump's obsession with image and appearance is highlighted, as he previously passed over candidates for top jobs, including secretary of state, due to their perceived lack of suitability.

site_title: Revenue from completed HP facility boosts MIT's Q1
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) reported a 2.7% increase in Q1 income available for distribution to S$52.9 million, driven by revenue from Hewlett-Packard's completed facility. Gross revenue rose 5.6% to S$88.8 million, and net property income grew 6.9% to S$68.2 million. The trust's average portfolio passing rent increased marginally to S$1.95 psf per month. Despite positive signs, the business environment remains uncertain, with pressure on rental and occupancy rates expected due to competing industrial space and tenant movement.

site_title: ST Engineering raises S$1m for President's Challenge
summary: ST Engineering raised S$1.27 million, including S$1 million for the President's Challenge 2017, to celebrate its 50th anniversary. The company, led by Chairman Kwa Chong Seng and President Vincent Chong, also initiated a year-round fund-raising drive and encouraged employees to participate in "50 Good Deeds". The efforts have raised over S$6 million for the President's Challenge over the years, demonstrating the company's commitment to community service and corporate social responsibility.

images.alt_text: President Tony Tan with children from Touch Community Services at a games stall, as part of the ST Engineering 50th Anniversary Family Day held at Sentosa.

site_title: After US$50b of deals, HNA moves to clear ownership issues
summary: Chinese conglomerate HNA Group has set up a new charitable foundation to act as its single biggest stakeholder, following reports of mounting pressure from bankers and regulators. The foundation, which now holds a 29.5% stake, was previously a Haikou-based charity established by HNA in 2010. HNA's CEO Adam Tan denied any concerns over its ownership, stating that the company is operating legally and has a strong relationship with its Wall Street banks. The move aims to provide transparency and further HNA's philanthropic mission.

site_title: ThaiBev surges, pennies feel gravity
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 17.03 points to a two-year closing high of 3,327.83, driven by a surge in Thai Beverage, which added S$0.035 to S$0.965 on over 72 million shares traded. ThaiBev's beer market share remains at 40% and its shares were influenced by management's positive views on the company's core spirits segment. However, penny stocks such as Sincap Group and Rowsley fell 35% and 10.7% respectively, with Rowsley's shares more than doubling after the announcement of a significant investment by billionaire Peter Lim.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CITIC Envirotech reported a 7.8% decline in net profit to S$21 million for its second quarter due to a decrease in its membrane business. Unusual's Justin Bieber concert was cancelled, and Chew's Group is in discussions with third parties regarding a possible transaction of shares. Sabana Reit's gross revenue fell 2.9% to S$22 million, and its distribution per unit decreased to 0.81 cents.

site_title: Piecing the growth-inflation puzzle
summary: The US economy has seen a rebound in growth despite the Trump administration's inability to enact policy changes, driven by consumer and business confidence. However, inflation has remained low, with wage growth in developed economies slow and the price of oil declining. This divergence between growth and inflation trends poses a risk, potentially leading to a sharp convergence and higher interest rates. If growth persists while inflation accelerates, bond yields may rise rapidly, affecting emerging market assets. Alternatively, a scenario where confidence fades and growth decelerates to match weak inflation could also occur, potentially benefiting fixed income investments.

site_title: Modi's ambitious 'Housing for All' programme fails to take off
summary: India's "Housing for All" plan, launched by Prime Minister Narendra Modi in 2015, aims to build 50 million homes in under a decade. However, the nation has only added 180,877 homes under the scheme, falling short of the target. The ambitious goal, dubbed a "moon shot," has been hindered by harsh realities, with critics citing a lack of progress and funding challenges. The shortfall has raised concerns about the feasibility of achieving the target, with experts describing it as a "challenge" and a "moon shot."

site_title: M&G makes A$119m Brisbane acquisition
summary: M&G Real Estate Asia has acquired HQ South, a Grade A office building in Brisbane, Australia, for A$119.1 million. The property, which includes seven office floors and retail space, has 207 parking lots and a net lettable area of over 14,000 sq m. The acquisition strengthens M&G's core Asia property portfolio, with the company citing the Brisbane office market's potential for a cyclical recovery and relatively higher yield spreads to government bonds. This is M&G's fifth acquisition in 2017, and the company's core Asia property strategy has grown to over US$3 billion in assets.

site_title: Altis is back with Euro 6 engine
summary: The Euro 6-compliant Toyota Corolla Altis has returned to the market after a brief hiatus due to the expiration of pre-Euro 6 models. The new version features subtle cosmetic changes, a 1.6-litre petrol engine, and added airbags, with prices starting from S$106,988. The Altis is expected to regain its sales momentum with deliveries starting from mid-August, potentially reclaiming its top spot in Singapore's model rankings.

site_title: US consumer confidence unexpectedly rises to four-month high
summary: US consumer confidence unexpectedly rose to a four-month high in July, increasing to 121.1, following a 117.3 reading in June. Analysts had predicted a decline to 116.5. The improvement in consumer confidence was attributed to Americans having a more positive view of the current situation and outlook.

site_title: Vard's Q2 loss widens; LOI to build cruise vessel expires
summary: Vard Holdings reported a 30% year-on-year surge in net loss to 69 million Norwegian kroner (S$11.8 million) in Q2 2017, citing restructuring costs and higher depreciation and amortization costs. Revenue fell 4% to 2.128 million Norwegian kroner due to "softer activity at the Norwegian yards." The group's order book remained strong at 12.88 billion Norwegian kroner, and it sees opportunities in the exploration cruise vessel market despite an expired LOI.

site_title: Bond restructuring in S'pore slower than in major markets
summary: Singapore's bond restructuring process is slower than in major markets, despite being ranked the second-most competitive economy globally. Local note defaults since November 2015 have hindered the process, with debt funds being less attracted to the market due to the fragmented bondholder base dominated by retail investors. Authorities have introduced new restructuring laws and grants to offset costs for issuers seeking credit ratings, but the local bond market remains relatively small and notes are widely held by private banking clients, making it difficult for funds to efficiently build a stake.

site_title: Giving for a lasting impact across generations
summary: Philanthropy plays a crucial role in family harmony and continuity, particularly in wealth transfer. However, research suggests that a significant percentage of high net worth families experience a decrease in their fortune as it's passed on to the next generation. A breakdown in communication and trust, lack of preparation, and shared family goals are common themes. To leave a lasting impact and legacy, philanthropy should focus on replication and scaling-up towards sustainability, rather than just short-term charitable donations.

site_title: Complacency, but not where you expect it
summary: Despite low US S&P 500 market-implied volatility, investors remain complacent in bond markets, flocking to invest in bonds despite depressed yields. However, long-term drivers that have pushed yields lower, such as globalization and demographics, may be reversing. The US economy's supply-side constraints and rising interest rates could put upward pressure on inflation and bond yields, posing a challenge for bond investors. In contrast, global fund managers' surveys indicate that retail investors are not yet showing signs of complacency.

images.alt_text: "The US economy is clearly closing on supply side constraints that could put upward pressure on inflation and bond yields as the Fed continues to hike interest rates. This could prove to be a bigger challenge for bond investors, than the low VIX index is for stock investors, looking ahead." - Steve Brice, chief investment strategist at Standard Chartered Private Bank.

site_title: US equities - balance optimism with caution
summary: US equities have gained over 9% year-to-date, driven by optimism in the economy and fiscal spending plans. However, concerns about US policies and moderating economic recovery have led to some consolidation. Analysts at Deutsche Bank remain cautious, citing the need for tax reform, infrastructure, and healthcare before getting more optimistic on equities. Despite this, they expect the S&P 500 to continue its record highs, with a 146-day streak without a 3% correction. US yields have tightened, and credit is expected to outperform sovereigns.

site_title: Is the recent drop in US inflation a sign of fresh economic weakness?
summary: The US has experienced a recent drop in inflation, sparking concerns about fresh economic weakness. Despite Federal Reserve officials' aim to keep prices rising at 2% annually, the Fed is on track to fail for the sixth consecutive year. Chair Janet Yellen expects inflation to rebound, but warns that the Fed may adjust policy if weakness persists. Economists debate the causes of the sluggish inflation, with some attributing it to declining prices of certain goods and the global economic slowdown. The Fed's failure to achieve its goals may be training people to expect lower inflation, making it harder for the Fed to achieve its objectives.

site_title: Pichai joins Alphabet board as founders show confidence
summary: Google CEO Sundar Pichai has been appointed to Alphabet's board of directors, marking his rising importance at the company. The move follows a restructuring of Alphabet in 2015, when Pichai took over as CEO. Founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin expressed confidence in Pichai's leadership, citing his success in driving growth, partnerships, and product innovation. The appointment resolves a potential conflict of interest, as Pichai previously had oversight of Google Cloud under Diane Greene, an Alphabet board member. Pichai's compensation was increased to $199.7 million in 2016.

site_title: Caterpillar posts 46% rise in profit, boosts forecast
summary: Caterpillar reported a 46% rise in quarterly profit to $802 million, driven by strength in its construction and resources businesses. Total sales and revenue rose 9.6% to $11.33 billion. The company also raised its profit outlook for the year, boosting its forecast. Shares rose 5.4% in premarket trading.

site_title: US reviews claims of collusion among German carmakers
summary: US Justice Department officials are investigating allegations of collusion among German carmakers Daimler, BMW, and Volkswagen, with the European Commission and Germany's cartel office also looking into the matter. The alleged collusion, which dates back to the 1990s, involved coordination on vehicle technology, costs, and strategy, including emissions controls in diesel engines. The investigation comes after a report by German news magazine Der Spiegel suggested that the five car brands may have colluded to obstruct competition. The Justice Department's review is separate from ongoing investigations into diesel emissions cheating.

site_title: SIAEC Q1 earnings dive in absence of divestment gain
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) reported a 81.8% drop in net profit to S$36.2 million in Q1 2017, mainly due to the absence of a divestment gain from the sale of its Hong Kong Aero Engine Services Ltd stake. Despite this, group revenue remained steady at S$272.8 million. The company announced expansion opportunities, including a joint venture with GE Aviation and the incorporation of a new subsidiary in Osaka, to drive sustainable long-term growth.

site_title: Digital tech can't quite replace the private banker - yet
summary: Digital technology has the potential to enhance private banking services, but it cannot replace the personal touch and human interaction that is crucial in this high-touch and complex industry. Robo-advisers lack the cognitive biases and emotional understanding of human bankers, making them less effective in catering to ultra-high net worth clients. While digital support can automate simple tasks and provide timely market data, it is the banker's role to ask tough life questions, address emotional issues, and provide tailored assistance. A balanced blend of technology and human interaction is the optimal approach, with digital support complementing the services of bankers, investment counsellors, and specialists.

site_title: Prospect of Trump tariff casts pall over US solar industry
summary: US solar companies are stockpiling cheap imported solar panels ahead of a potential trade decision by the Trump administration that could drive up costs. The industry, which employs over 260,000 people, is bracing for the worst as tariffs could harm its competitiveness. A recent trade complaint by a Georgia manufacturer, Suniva, has asked the administration to double the price of imported solar panels. If tariffs are imposed, it could slow down solar installations, jobs, and funding for large US solar deals, potentially harming the industry and the country's renewable energy goals.

site_title: As hedge funds bet against oil, traders see another story
summary: Hedge funds continue to hold large bearish bets against oil and Opec, but traders and refiners report a more bullish outlook, citing improving physical differentials worldwide. CEO Ian Taylor of Vitol Group notes that the market is looking "a bit better."

site_title: Sharing the spirit of enterprise
summary: A non-profit organization in Singapore, Spirit of Enterprise (SOE), has launched initiatives to impart entrepreneurial experience to SME owners and students. The organization offers structured business lessons, interviews with successful entrepreneurs, and networking opportunities. SOE's goal is to instill values such as tenacity, passion, and a strong work ethic in aspiring entrepreneurs. The organization has engaged over 15 schools with over 1,000 student participants and plans to launch a new category in the SOE Awards programme to recognize startups.

site_title: Chew's Group controlling shareholder in talks over possible share transaction
summary: Chew's Group, a Singaporean egg producer, announced that its controlling shareholder is in talks with third parties about a possible share transaction. The talks have no certainty of a transaction, and the company will inform shareholders of any material developments. Chew's shares remained unchanged at S$0.52 following the announcement.

site_title: Waiting for that big crash to cash in? Don't bother
summary: Wealth managers must focus on fundamentals in a post-crisis market, as the risk of a correction remains high but a bear market is unlikely. US stocks are overvalued, while European equities are fairly valued, and Asian equities offer better value. Fixed income investments should prioritize income over capital appreciation, and commodities are cheap but oversupplied. The US dollar is expected to rise due to monetary policy divergence and rising interest rates. Investors must return to basics, selecting quality companies with sustainable business models and "moats" to protect against competition.

site_title: US partisan conflict is at historically high levels, but the market doesn't care
summary: The US is experiencing historically high levels of partisan conflict, with a monthly Partisan Conflict Index reaching new highs, according to Marina Azzimonti, a researcher economist. Despite this, the stock market has continued to rise, with a bull run in history. The index, which measures disagreement among lawmakers, has peaked in March and remains at high levels, with conflict increasing during the Trump administration and remaining elevated despite potential tax reform. Economists attribute the market's disregard for conflict to factors such as low interest rates and the market's tendency to rise when negative sentiment is contradicted by strong earnings.

images.alt_text: The stock market has gone on one of the greatest bull runs in history despite rising levels of partisan conflict. Analyst say stocks tend to rise more rapidly when the Partisan Conflict Index soars.

site_title: Justin Bieber concert in Singapore cancelled
summary: Justin Bieber's concert in Singapore on October 7 has been cancelled due to unforeseen circumstances. The cancellation comes after the event was announced as part of his Purpose World Tour concert. Unusual Limited, the promoter, has assured fans that they will work with the ticketing agent to ensure a speedy refund for all tickets purchased. The company's shares were trading at S$0.51 on the day of the announcement, up 2% from the previous close.

site_title: China's push to link east and west puts Iran at 'centre of everything'
summary: China's "One Belt, One Road" project is set to significantly boost Iran's economy, positioning the country as a central hub for trade between East and West. With over $1 trillion in infrastructure investment planned, China is modernizing Iran's rail network, connecting major cities to Europe, Asia, and Africa. Iranian entrepreneurs, like Beijing-based Lin Zuao Ru, are capitalizing on the opportunities, establishing businesses and factories that will benefit from the increased trade. Iran's leadership views the partnership as a strategic advantage over Russia, and the country is willing to take on US sanctions to finance critical infrastructure projects.

images.alt_text: Mr Lin (centre) has built a small empire since moving to Iran in 2002. His eight factories make a wide variety of goods that find markets in Iran and in neighbouring countries.

site_title: US: S&P hits record; Alphabet weighs on Nasdaq
summary: The S&P 500 hit a record high, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.7% to 21,663.75. However, the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.09% to 6,405.31 due to Alphabet's negative impact. Strong earnings from Caterpillar and McDonald's contributed to the Dow's gain, but Alphabet's decline weighed on the tech-heavy Nasdaq.

site_title: Wages shape up as key to Abenomics
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is focusing on raising wages to boost household income and convince an increasingly sceptical electorate that his Abenomics policies are working. Despite record-low unemployment and bumper profits, employers remain reluctant to boost pay, and Abe's government is under pressure to deliver on its promise of 2% inflation. Analysts say that labour market reforms to boost productivity and wages are the "first priority" of Abenomics' structural reform agenda, and that Abe needs to take action to win back public support, which has sunk to a record low.

images.alt_text: In the years following the economic crash in the early 1990s, Japanese workers accepted lower salaries to secure their jobs, thus weakening their negotiating positions.

site_title: Air France's new airline may clip Dutch wings: KLM staff
summary: Air France's new low-cost subsidiary Joon may harm its Dutch partner KLM, according to a Dutch work's committee member, citing the plan as "not economically prudent" and potentially damaging to KLM. The airline's pilots initially opposed the idea, but agreed to support Joon after negotiations. KLM has outperformed Air France in recent years, with higher operating profits, but the committee member warns that the decision may stymie KLM's growth. A leaked internal study has also revealed deep distrust between the two airlines, fueled by cultural differences and petty grievances.

site_title: Exercise takes a toll on the heart
summary: Two major studies of endurance athletes and their coronary arteries found that years of training and competing may lead to a high incidence of plaques in their arteries, a potential hallmark of cardiovascular disease. However, the plaques found in athletes tend to be denser and more calcified, which may not be as concerning as those found in less active individuals. The studies suggest a possible association between high volumes of exercise and coronary calcification, but do not indicate a direct link to harm. Experts advise consulting a doctor and erring on the side of caution, recommending moderate exercise like jogging over intense endurance activities.

site_title: Sabana Reit's Q2 DPU falls to 0.81 Singapore cent
summary: Sabana Reit's Q2 earnings fell 7.4% to S$12.9 million, with gross revenue decreasing 2.9% to S$22 million. Distribution per unit (DPU) dropped to 0.81 Singapore cents, a decline from 1.07 Singapore cents in the previous year. Lower contributions from certain properties and the conversion of 39 Ubi Road 1 into multi-tenanted lease arrangements contributed to the decline.

images.alt_text: Lower contributions from certain properties in its portfolio eroded second-quarter results for industrial landlord Sabana Reit.

site_title: Najib asks investors to move past 1MDB as economy strengthens
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak urged investors to move past the 1MDB issues, saying the country is now "stronger than ever" with a 4.8% growth forecast. He denied any wrongdoing and accused the main opposition alliance of sabotaging the economy. Despite allegations of mismanaging the economy and a slowdown in China, Najib cited the country's gradual recovery and strengthened currency as evidence of its prosperity. He hinted at possible early elections, calling the opposition party "in chaos".

site_title: Supertrends - investing for the long term
summary: Credit Suisse has identified five long-term investment themes, or Supertrends, that are expected to dominate the market in the coming years: Angry Societies, Infrastructure, Technology at the Service of Humans, Silver Economy, and Millennials' Values. These themes are driven by changing societal trends, including rising inequalities within Western countries, a growing focus on infrastructure spending, the impact of technology on human life, aging populations, and the values of the Millennial generation. Investors can benefit from these trends by targeting sectors such as national champions, emerging markets, infrastructure, technology, healthcare, and sustainable investing.

images.alt_text: "Rising inequalities within Western countries and frustration over perceived or real failures of the political establishment to deal with current societal challenges are leading disenchanted middle-class voters to demand change." - John Woods, chief investment officer Asia-Pacific, Credit Suisse

site_title: US$ slumps to 13-month low before Fed meeting
summary: The US dollar slumped to a 13-month low against a basket of currencies on Tuesday before the Federal Reserve meeting, despite low expectations of interest rate changes. The dollar index fell to 93.815, a level not seen since June 2016. Investors remain cautious about the short-term outlook, but the euro rose 0.1% to a 10.5% gain for the year, while the Sri Lankan rupee ended slightly firmer. The Fed meeting starts on Wednesday, with no rate increase expected, and US advance second-quarter growth estimates will be closely watched on Friday.

site_title: McDonald's Q2 profits jump 28% to US$1.4b on solid sales
summary: McDonald's reported a 28% increase in second-quarter profits to US$1.4 billion, beating analyst expectations. Strong comparable sales in key markets, including the US, drove the growth, with new products and customer service initiatives contributing to the success. Shares rose sharply in pre-market trading following the announcement.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.5% up
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.5% to 3,327.83, driven by gains from OCBC Bank, Thai Beverage, and Singtel. About 2.78 billion shares changed hands, with an average unit price of S$0.42. Losers outnumbered gainers 265 to 214, but the rally follows a 5-day streak.

site_title: Trump escalates tension with Sessions, weighs firing Mueller
summary: US President Donald Trump escalated tensions with Attorney General Jeff Sessions, criticizing his recusal from the Russia investigation and suggesting he may want him fired. Trump's top aide, Anthony Scaramucci, said the president likely wants Sessions gone and has considered firing FBI special counsel Robert Mueller, who is leading the Russia probe. Sessions has refused to step down, but Trump's frustration remains, with the president expressing disappointment in Sessions' recusal. The situation is likely to persist, with White House spokeswoman Sarah Huckabee Sanders saying Trump retains full confidence in Sessions but may still make a decision to fire him.

site_title: UK factory output rises at fastest pace since 1995
summary: British manufacturing output increased at its fastest rate since 1995, with a quarterly balance of +31 in the three months to July, according to the Confederation of British Industry's survey. Despite slowing new orders in July, manufacturers remain optimistic about exports, with the highest reading in 40 years. However, this growth may be offset by stronger inflation, which is expected to fuel a slowdown in the economy in Q2.

site_title: BMW says received no post-Brexit trade reassurances from UK over Mini investment
summary: BMW has confirmed plans to build its electric Mini at its Oxford plant in England, despite not receiving post-Brexit trade reassurances from the UK government. The decision was made without any subsidies or guarantees, contradicting earlier reports of a £240 million investment from Toyota secured by the British government. The move was welcomed by Britain's business minister, Greg Clark, who described it as a "vote of confidence" in government efforts to attract automotive investment. The plant is expected to produce electric Minis in 2019.

site_title: Scoot completes merger with Tigerair, plans for expansion with newer, bigger fleet
summary: Scoot, the low-cost airline, has completed its merger with Tigerair, expanding its network by 15% and adding four new destinations by June 2018, including Honolulu, Harbin, Kuantan, and Kuching. The airline plans to introduce new, fuel-efficient aircraft and phase out older ones, aiming to nearly double its fleet in five years. Scoot will also start flying to Honolulu via Osaka before the end of the year, competing with AirAsia X.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Sovereign wealth funds 'ring-fence' UK assets ahead of Brexit
summary: Sovereign wealth funds and institutional investors are separating their UK assets from European and global portfolios due to Brexit uncertainty, with about 30-40% of clients seeking to "ring-fence" their UK holdings. This move aims to manage risks associated with the UK's potential exit from the EU. Despite the government's efforts to negotiate a deal, the pound's weakness and tariffs remain significant concerns for the economy. The International Monetary Fund has cut its 2017 growth forecast for the UK, and investors are taking a cautious approach to mitigate potential economic slowdowns.

site_title: GM focus on sales to actual consumers paying off for profits
summary: General Motors (GM) reported adjusted earnings of $1.89 per share in the second quarter, beating analyst estimates of $1.70 per share. The company's strategy of focusing on more profitable deliveries of pickups and SUVs to US consumers has paid off, with a richer mix of sport utility vehicles and trucks sold to retail buyers. GM cut costs in North America and will temporarily shut down 13 plants in the second half of the year to make fresher models, expecting lower earnings and production in the second half.

site_title: UK watchdog to require banks to publish data on service
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has proposed requiring banks to publish data on the quality of service they provide to customers every quarter, starting from April 2018. The data will include metrics such as account opening times, card replacement times, and access to accounts under power of attorney. The goal is to increase competition in the banking sector, which is dominated by the "Big Four" lenders. The FCA aims to make it easier for customers to compare services and for banks to assess their performance.

site_title: Intertrust cuts profit forecast, shares fall to record low
summary: Intertrust, a Dutch fund and corporate services company, cut its full-year profit margin forecast due to one-off legal costs and weak performance in its home market, sending shares down 19% to a record low. The company now expects a 37.5-38.5% core profit margin and 3.5% underlying revenue growth, down from previous targets. Revenue in the Netherlands was affected by higher staff turnover and lower billing hours, while IT costs and non-recurring items related to a legal claim contributed to the lower forecast.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial's Q1 DPU rises to 2.92 Singapore cents
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust's (MIT) Q1 DPU rose to 2.92 Singapore cents, up from 2.85 cents last year, driven by revenue from its build-to-suit development for Hewlett-Packard Singapore. Q1 income available for distribution increased 2.7% to S$52.9 million, and gross revenue grew 5.6% to S$88.8 million. Net property income also rose 6.9% to S$68.2 million. MIT units ended 0.3% lower at S$1.88.

site_title: Sinopec to invest 34.4b yuan in gas pipeline for new economic zone
summary: Sinopec to invest 34.4 billion yuan in a 30 billion cubic metre gas pipeline project connecting major LNG storage with China's Xiongan New Area, saving 60 million tonnes of coal and cutting greenhouse gas emissions by 36 million tonnes annually.

site_title: Last orca born at a SeaWorld park dies from illness in Texas
summary: A three-month-old female orca, Kyara, born at SeaWorld's San Antonio park, died from pneumonia after a week of illness. This was the last orca born in captivity at a SeaWorld park, following the company's 2016 decision to suspend its breeding program. Attendance at SeaWorld parks has been declining amid animal rights criticism. PETA's Colleen O'Brien called for the release of the remaining 22 captive orcas into seaside sanctuaries, citing the high death toll at SeaWorld parks.

site_title: SIA Engineering Q1 profit nosedives 81.8% to S$36.2m on absence of divestments
summary: SIA Engineering Company's Q1 profit fell 81.8% to S$36.2 million, down from S$198.4 million in the previous year due to the absence of divestment gains. Excluding divestment gains, profit was 4.7% lower than last year.

site_title: Trump says US working on 'big and exciting' UK trade deal
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that the US and UK are working on a potentially "big and exciting" trade deal, with UK Trade Secretary Liam Fox in Washington to pave the way for a deal after Brexit. Trump attacked the EU's protectionist attitude and called for it to drop barriers to commerce. The UK government estimates a post-Brexit trade deal could generate an additional £40 billion in trade by 2030. Economists warn that the deal will be difficult to deliver due to US negotiators having more experience.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump said the US and the UK are working on a potentially "big and exciting" trade deal and the relationship between the two countries is going to be "even better" after Brexit.

site_title: Saudi dairy farm said to mull using cow dung to meet power needs
summary: Saudi Arabia's National Agriculture Development Co plans to build a US$200 million biomass plant using cow dung to meet its power needs, as part of a bid to diversify the economy and reduce reliance on oil. The project, which will also include a solar plant, aims to boost renewable energy sources and cut oil consumption. This initiative is part of Saudi Arabia's 10-year plan to develop 30 solar and wind projects, worth US$50 billion, to reduce its oil consumption and boost power generation.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Key developments include Scoot Airlines announcing flights to five Asian destinations, including Honolulu, and Singapore shares closing 0.5% higher on the STI. Self-driving buses and robot aides could boost Singapore's growth, while DBS Vickers downgraded Ascendas India Trust due to disappointing Q1 2018 earnings. ST Engineering set up a US$150m corporate venture capital unit and Justin Bieber's concert in Singapore has been cancelled. In international news, Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.3% in May, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

site_title: Citic Envirotech profit down 7.8%
summary: Citic Envirotech's net profit fell 7.8% to S$21 million for its second quarter, with revenue decreasing 4% to S$134.4 million. The company attributed the decline to a decrease in its membrane business. Despite this, Citic Envirotech remains confident in its growth prospects, driven by increasing demand for industrial wastewater treatment in China and the government's commitment to environmental conservation. The company is expanding into new segments and aiming to increase its market share in the water sector.

images.alt_text: MAINBOARD-LISTED Citic Envirotech's net profit fell 7.8 per cent to S$21 million for its second quarter ended June 30 compared to the same period a year ago.

site_title: German business climate hits record as economy proves robust
summary: Germany's business climate has reached a record high, with the Ifo index rising to 116.0 in July, the highest level since 1991. The economy has shown strong performance at the start of the year, with steadily declining unemployment supporting domestic demand. The International Monetary Fund has expressed confidence in the country's growth prospects, predicting expansions of 1.8% in 2017 and 1.6% in 2018. The robust economic performance is expected to continue into the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: German companies seem to be unfazed about the summer lull heading their way.

site_title: Evergrande's half-year profit to triple as property prices soar
summary: China Evergrande Group, the country's largest developer, expects its half-year profit to triple to approximately 23.4 billion yuan, driven by soaring property prices and rising home sales. The company's core profit declined 23% in the previous year due to higher costs and debt servicing. Evergrande's strategy of focusing on third- and fourth-tier cities has paid off, and the company's shares have surged over 266% this year. The company's redemption of perpetual securities is expected to boost net income, significantly improving its financial performance.

site_title: ST Engineering sets up US$150m corporate venture capital unit, opens innovation lab
summary: ST Engineering sets up a US$150 million corporate venture capital unit, ST Engineering Ventures, to invest in promising technology startups and early-stage companies. The unit will also establish innovation labs in Singapore, Israel, and the US to support innovators in developing new technologies. Additionally, ST Engineering is opening its Innosparks open innovation lab, which offers a pool of skilled engineers to collaborate with startups and support the development of new concepts. This move aims to leverage the group's business network and distribution channels to drive innovation and growth.

site_title: Vard slides further into the red for Q2
summary: Vard Holdings, a Singapore-listed operating group, reported a net loss of 69 million Norwegian kroner (S$11.7 million) in Q2, a 30% increase from the previous year. The group's operating loss narrowed to 4 million kroner, but was offset by negative financial items and losses from associates. Revenue declined 4.1% to 2.13 billion kroner due to reduced activity at Norwegian shipyards. Loss per share expanded to 0.06 krone, and the net asset value per share slipped to 1.87 krone.

images.alt_text: Yard operating group, Vard Holdings, slipped deeper into the red mainly due to negative financial items and losses in associated ship-owning entities.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end marginally higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended marginally higher on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 5.22 points to 26,852.05, driven by a tepid lead from Wall Street ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.21% and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.33%. The gains were seen as a reflection of traders' cautious optimism despite uncertainty surrounding the Fed's decision.

site_title: Armani reorganises brands as revenue, profit margins slip
summary: Italian luxury goods group Armani is reorganizing its brands into three labels: Giorgio Armani, Emporio Armani, and A|X Armani Exchange. The company is streamlining its shop network and folding its haute couture line Giorgio Armani Privé and homeware brand Armani/Casa into Giorgio Armani. Sales fell 5% to 2.5 billion euros last year, and profit margins contracted slightly. The reorganization aims to counter a difficult business environment, with the designer attributing the decline to China's slowing growth, security concerns, and changing consumer behaviors.

images.alt_text: Italian luxury goods group Armani said on Tuesday it was further reorganising its brands into just three labels and streamlining its shop network to counter a difficult business environment.

site_title: China urges Asean to reject outside interference
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi urged Southeast Asian nations to reject outside interference in the South China Sea dispute, a move seen as a swipe at the US ahead of a regional summit. Wang's visit came as China and the Philippines have strengthened ties, with the Philippines moving closer to China under President Rodrigo Duterte. China claims nearly all of the South China Sea, while ASEAN members claim parts of the sea, and the US has criticized China's "militarization" of the area. Wang pledged $4.036 million to help rehabilitate the southern Philippine city of Marawi.

site_title: England to ban the sale of new 'leasehold' houses
summary: Britain's government proposes to ban the sale of new leasehold houses, which require owners to pay ground rent to a freeholder, to curb sharply increasing costs for buyers. The move aims to regulate the property market and address concerns over unfair practices. The plans, part of Prime Minister Theresa May's efforts to make housing more affordable, include restrictions on ground rents and changes to government-backed loans. The ban would apply in England and affect around 30% of residential leasehold properties, mostly houses, in the country.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end the day higher
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.35 points to 1,763.34, driven by higher trading volume of 1.67 billion lots worth RM1.62 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 510 to 329, marking a mixed market.

site_title: Airlines will need 637,000 new pilots over next 20 years: Boeing
summary: Airlines will need 637,000 new pilots over the next 20 years to keep pace with global air traffic growth, according to Boeing's latest report. The Asia-Pacific region will need 253,000 pilots, followed by North America with 117,000 and Europe with 106,000. The report also forecasts a need for 648,000 aircraft maintenance technicians and 839,000 flight attendants by 2036. This estimate is a 3.6% increase from last year's report, with many experts warning of a looming pilot shortage.

site_title: Former Thai PM Yingluck questions junta move to freeze bank accounts
summary: Former Thai Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra questioned the military government's decision to freeze her bank accounts, worth about $1.433 billion, in relation to a US$1 billion fine imposed over her government's rice buying scheme. The move comes as she fights a criminal charge of alleged negligence over the scheme, with the Supreme Court set to deliver its verdict on August 25. Yingluck denies guilt and claims the move is part of a larger effort to silence her and her family's political machine, which her supporters accuse of political persecution.

images.alt_text: Former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra on Tuesday questioned a move by Thailand's military government to freeze her assets in relation to a US$1 billion fine it imposed over her government's rice buying scheme.

site_title: Excelling In GIFT
summary: BT's GIFT (Global Investment and Trade Forum) has seen a strong performance, with the platform excelling in showcasing mod-Indian cuisine. The forum aims to promote Indian culture and cuisine globally.

site_title: Modi's 50 million homes moonshot is miles from ground reality
summary: India's ambitious "Housing for All" plan, set by Prime Minister Narendra Modi in 2015, aims to build 50 million homes in less than a decade. However, the nation has added only 180,877 homes under the scheme, far short of the target. The program faces roadblocks, including high land prices, lack of affordable land parcels, and lengthy clearances, which increase construction costs. The government has offered incentives, but leading developers have yet to have a significant impact, with most efforts focusing on the middle-income group.

site_title: China backs joint energy development with Philippines in disputed sea
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi expressed support for joint energy development with the Philippines in the disputed South China Sea, warning that unilateral action could lead to complications and damage both sides. This comes as the Philippines prepares to resume oil exploration in the Reed Bank, which was suspended due to a court ruling invalidating China's claim to sovereignty over most of the South China Sea. The proposal to jointly develop resources has been discussed since 1986, but its implementation is seen as complex and politically sensitive due to overlapping claims.

images.alt_text: China's foreign minister on Tuesday said he supported the idea of joint energy ventures with the Philippines in the disputed South China Sea, warning that unilateral action could cause problems and damage both sides.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors' Q1 profit surges as domestic sales recover
summary: Mitsubishi Motors reported a four-fold jump in its operating profit for the first quarter, reaching 20.6 billion yen, driven by a recovery in domestic sales. Sales nearly doubled to 19,000 vehicles compared to the previous year. The company attributed the improvement to reorganized engineering division, improved testing processes, and compliance procedures. Mitsubishi Motors maintained its forecast to post a net profit of 68.0 billion yen for the current year, with a projected operating profit of 70 billion yen, boosted by its alliance with Nissan.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end lower ahead of earnings, Fed meeting
summary: Tokyo stocks ended lower on Tuesday ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting and Japan's earnings season. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.10% to 19,955.20, while the Topix index declined 0.28% to 1,617.07. Traders await the Fed meeting and Japan's earnings reports, which could impact market sentiment.

site_title: Rio Tinto faces corruption probe by UK prosecutors
summary: Rio Tinto faces a UK corruption probe by the Serious Fraud Office over its business dealings in Guinea, specifically the US$20 billion Simandou iron ore project. The investigation involves the miner, its employees, and third parties. The probe follows a self-reported US$10.5 million payment to an external consultant in 2011 and the termination of contracts of two senior executives. Rio Tinto will cooperate with the investigation, which may last for years, as the company looks to appoint a new chairman by the end of the year.

site_title: Boeing signs US$1b contract with Dassault Systemes
summary: US aerospace giant Boeing has signed a $1 billion, 30-year contract with French industrial software company Dassault Systemes to modernize its production system using 3D software. The partnership aims to enhance Boeing's competitiveness by reducing delivery times and accelerating the digital switchover of its production system. The software will be used for designing future products, managing subcontractors, and launching new aircraft, satellites, and defence systems.

site_title: Sri Lanka's Cabinet "clears port deal" after security concerns addressed
summary: Sri Lanka's cabinet has cleared a revised agreement for its Chinese-built southern port of Hambantota, addressing security concerns that sparked public anger. The agreement allows for 80% Chinese control of the port, while two companies will split operations to alleviate fears of military use. The deal also includes plans for an industrial zone next to the port, with 15,000 acres of land to be acquired. The revised pact aims to maintain balanced relations with other countries, with China seeking revenue benefits. The agreement now requires parliament approval.

site_title: Channel tunnel operator Eurotunnel keeps profit goals despite Brexit
summary: Channel tunnel operator Eurotunnel has reaffirmed its profit goals for 2017 and 2018 despite the uncertainty of the British economy following Brexit. CEO Jacques Gounon expressed confidence in the company's performance, citing improved EBITDA and revenue. Eurotunnel's outlook remains positive, with no changes to its profit forecasts.

site_title: Chinese officials to enforce mainland laws in Hong Kong train station
summary: Hong Kong announced a plan to allow mainland officials to enforce Chinese laws inside a train station, sparking concerns over the city's autonomy and freedoms. The train station, set to open in autumn, will have areas under mainland Chinese jurisdiction, including immigration halls and train platforms. The move is seen as a potential encroachment on Hong Kong's Basic Law, which states that mainland laws do not apply in the city. Chief Executive Carrie Lam has defended the plan as being in compliance with the "one country, two systems" formula.

site_title: Michael Kors to buy luxury shoemaker Jimmy Choo for US$1.2b
summary: US retailer Michael Kors has agreed to buy luxury shoemaker Jimmy Choo for $1.2 billion. The British brand, known for its stiletto heels and accessories, was launched in the 1990s and has celebrity fans like Princess Diana. Michael Kors aims to expand Jimmy Choo's global presence and bolster its own sales, which have been declining. The deal will see Jimmy Choo operate under its existing management team, and the brand will continue to offer its iconic products. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to revive Michael Kors' fortunes.

site_title: Shell, SoftBank among potential suitors for US$5b renewable energy firm Equis-sources
summary: Royal Dutch Shell and SoftBank are among potential suitors for Equis Energy, a US$5 billion renewable energy firm, as the company considers selling its portfolio of 97 renewable energy projects across Asia and globally. Japanese trading companies, global pension funds, and buyout firms are also bidding. Bidders are forming groups to divide the portfolio, with Shell, SoftBank, Orix Corp, and I Squared Capital among those considering a bid. The company's valuation is expected to be significant, with Equis Funds Group having raised US$2.7 billion in equity for infrastructure investments over the past five years.

site_title: Alibaba, Paytm in talks to invest in India's Bigbasket
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd and Paytm E-commerce Pvt are in talks to invest approximately $200 million in India's leading online grocer Bigbasket, with the potential for a 20% stake. The two companies have a 60-day exclusive pact and are conducting due diligence. Other interested parties include Amazon.com Inc and Morgan Stanley, which is advising Bigbasket's existing investors on fundraising. The talks follow earlier reports by local media, with existing investors including the Abraaj Group and Sands Capital.

site_title: Scoot to add Honolulu, four other Asian destinations
summary: Scoot, a low-cost carrier, plans to add Honolulu and four other destinations in Asia to its network by June 2018. The new destinations will be Kuantan and Kuching in Malaysia, Palembang in Indonesia, and Harbin in China. This expansion marks Scoot's second long-haul destination after Athens. The airline's merger with Tigerair is complete, and its crew members will wear a new uniform, with the current Tigerair fleet to be repainted in Scoot's colors by mid-2018.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Hot stock: China Star Food queried over price surge
summary: China Star Food Group shares rose 15% to S$0.12 on the Singapore Exchange after a 15% price surge, amid unusual trading activity. The company halted operations at a new plant in May and expects lower profits for the year. A query was issued by the exchange regarding the unusual trading activity.

site_title: Bill Gates backs Uber freight rival, joining other billionaires
summary: Bill Gates has invested $62 million in Convoy Inc, a Seattle-based trucking logistics startup, alongside fellow billionaires Jeff Bezos and other backers. Convoy, which competes with Uber's Uber Freight, aims to match nearby truckers with shipping jobs. The company has raised $80 million in total since 2015 and plans to use the funds to expand operations and software development. With Convoy generating millions in sales a week, CEO Dan Lewis hopes to capitalize on Uber's distractions and take advantage of the market's growing demand for on-demand trucking services.

images.alt_text: As Bill Gates and Jeff Bezos jockey for the designation of world's wealthiest man, the Seattle billionaires are united behind at least one local venture. They're both investors in a trucking logistics startup that competes with Uber Technologies Inc.

site_title: Australia: Shares finish higher as oil rallies
summary: Australian shares rose 0.68% on Tuesday, led by gains in oil and gold prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed 38.53 points to 5,726.6, snapping a two-day losing streak. Oil prices surged after Saudi Arabia pledged to curb exports and OPEC called for increased compliance to reduce oversupply. Gold stocks also hit a one-week high, with Newcrest Mining rising between 0.7% and 0.8%. The Fed's monetary policy meeting is expected to keep interest rates unchanged, with investors awaiting hints on future rate hikes.

site_title: World's biggest miner speeds hunt for copper in 'last frontier'
summary: BHP Billiton, the world's largest miner, has opened an office in Ecuador and is seeking to add staff to advance its search for copper in the country, which is becoming a hot spot for exploration. The company's investment of $82 million will focus on five areas in the Imbabura province. Ecuador's mining sector is expected to rise to $7.9 billion by 2021, driven by major players including Hancock Prospecting, Fortescue Metals, and Newcrest Mining. The country's newly installed President Lenin Moreno has assured investors that he will continue to woo investment.

site_title: Sterling stalls above US$1.30
summary: Sterling stabilizes above US$1.30 as investors take profit on euro gains and UK economic growth concerns persist. The pound recovered from its worst week against the euro in nine months, but a cut in IMF's growth forecast for the UK underscores the risk of economic struggles. The pound traded at US$1.3016, around a cent off 10-month highs, as the greenback weakened globally. A speech by Bank of England chief economist Andy Haldane will be closely watched for its potential impact on interest rates and the pound's value.

site_title: Hynix sees 20% DRAM growth next year
summary: SK Hynix, South Korea's second-largest memory chip maker, expects a 20% growth in DRAM shipments next year, driven by a surge in demand for server chips. The company's server chips now account for 35% of its revenue, up from 25% a year earlier. Stronger-than-expected demand has prompted a review of its product portfolio and a review of its capital expenditure plans. The company's operating profit in the second quarter smashed a record, with analysts expecting the super-cycle to last through 2018, driven by growing demand for cloud computing and increasingly capable devices.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks down at break
summary: Tokyo stocks declined 0.13% in morning trading on July 25, 2017, due to investors awaiting corporate earnings and the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting. The Nikkei 225 index fell to 19,950.11, while the Topix index dropped to 1,617.51.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed before Fed; yen erases losses
summary: Asian stocks were mixed on Tuesday ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy decision, with the yen erasing earlier losses. Oil rose to over $46 a barrel, driven by Saudi Arabia's promise to cut crude exports. Earnings season is underway, with key events including the Fed decision and post-Brexit trade talks between the US and UK. The US economy is expected to have gained traction in the second quarter, with spending by American consumers picking up after a lull early this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.48 points to 1766.00. The market saw a higher volume of 23.78 million lots worth RM12.28 million, with 67 gainers outnumbering 44 losers.

site_title: Economists raise China GDP forecast after growth beats estimates
summary: China's economic growth beat estimates, with economists raising forecasts for the third and fourth quarters. The country's GDP is expected to expand by 6.7% in the third quarter and 6.6% in the fourth quarter, according to a Bloomberg survey. This growth gives policymakers room to curb excessive borrowing and allows them to achieve stability, a priority ahead of the 19th Party Congress. Expectations for inflation have slowed, with forecasts for consumer and producer prices lower than last month. The robust growth is seen as a positive sign for the economy.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS Vickers downgrades Ascendas India Trust on disappointing Q1 2018
summary: DBS Vickers downgraded Ascendas India Trust (a-iTrust) to a "hold" from a "buy" and cut its target price to S$1.15 a unit, citing disappointing Q1 2018 results and limited upside. The trust's share price has rallied 30% since its upgrade 18 months ago, but DBS Vickers expects it to pause for breath, suggesting investors wait for a better entry point. The downgrade reflects the trust's healthy outlook, which appears priced in, and DBS Vickers maintains a positive outlook for a-iTrust's long-term growth.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Japan's Fukuoka, Eighteenth Bank postpone planned integration
summary: Japan's Fukuoka Financial Group Inc and Eighteenth Bank have indefinitely postponed plans to integrate their operations due to anti-monopoly issues. The merger, which aimed to create a banking group controlling 70% of loans in Nagasaki prefecture, was initially set for April but was delayed to October. The Fair Trade Commission is reviewing the merger, and it's unclear when it will be completed. The move is part of broader challenges facing Japan's regional banks due to a dwindling population and thin lending margins.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars camp near multi-month highs
summary: The Australian dollar hovered near two-year highs, while the New Zealand dollar held close to a 10-1/2 month top, driven by a weakened US dollar and anticipation of interest rate changes in the US. The Australian dollar strengthened 4% over the past fortnight, with investors seeking currencies supported by higher interest rates. Second quarter inflation data and a Reserve Bank of Australia speech are key events this week, potentially influencing the Aussie's next move. The New Zealand dollar steadied at US$0.7440, near its highest level since September 2016.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar hovered near two-year highs on Tuesday ahead of second quarter inflation data, while its New Zealand cousin held close to a 10-1/2 month top.

site_title: China's yuan eases on weaker fixing as US dollar strengthens overnight
summary: China's yuan weakened slightly against the US dollar on Tuesday, falling 0.1% to 6.7485 per US dollar, its biggest one-day weakening in percentage terms in three weeks. The move was due to a rebound in the US dollar overnight, following upbeat US economic data. The yuan's offshore counterpart traded 0.05% firmer, and one-year non-deliverable forwards contracts traded 2.00% weaker. Traders expect the yuan to trade at around 6.75 per US dollar if the US dollar index hovers at 94, and potentially test a high of 6.7 if it weakens to 92.

site_title: Seoul: Won edges down from 4-month high, stocks weaker
summary: The South Korean won eased off four-month highs, closing at 1,115.8 to the US dollar, down 0.2% from Monday's close. Foreign investors sold local equities, causing the Kospi index to drop 0.1%. Despite South Korea raising its 2017 growth outlook to 3%, the upgrade had little effect on the markets. Chipmaker SK Hynix and Samsung Electronics fell 1.8% and 1% respectively, while offshore investors sold Kospi shares worth 140.7 billion won.

site_title: South Korea sees 2017 growth at fastest in 3 years, pushes consumption and jobs
summary: South Korea raised its 2017 growth outlook to 3%, the fastest since 2014, driven by improved global demand for goods and increased fiscal spending. The government projects 10.2% export growth and 2.3% private consumption growth, with job creation and consumption-led growth as key priorities. Deputy Finance Minister Lee Chan-Woo vowed to maintain an expansionary fiscal policy to support job creation and promote balanced growth. The government also plans to tighten borrowing rules and encourage debt refinancing to address rapid household debt growth.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand shares edge up as oil prices jump; Fed in focus
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% on Tuesday, rebounding from two straight days of falls, as oil prices jumped following Saudi Arabia's vow to limit exports. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,735, with industrials, healthcare, and material stocks leading gains. Investors are expecting the US Federal Reserve to keep interest rates unchanged, shifting focus to the market's long-term direction. New Zealand's benchmark index also edged up 0.2% as gains were spread across materials, consumer staples, and healthcare stocks.

images.alt_text: Australian shares rebounded on Tuesday, helped by a rally in oil prices after leading Opec producer Saudi Arabia vowed to limit exports from next month while investors turned their focus to the US Federal Reserve's meeting starting later in the day.

site_title: Qualcomm accuses tech group of 'misdirecting' trade regulators
summary: Qualcomm accused a tech group, representing Alphabet Inc, Amazon, Microsoft, and Facebook, of misdirecting US trade regulators in its case against Apple. Qualcomm filed a complaint seeking to ban iPhones with Intel chips, citing patented technology surrounding the chips. However, Qualcomm argued its import ban is not about Intel's chips, but rather about its own patented technology. The company also stated that other companies, such as MediaTek and Samsung, make modem chips and could supply the smartphone industry.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks marginally up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose marginally at open on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.17 points to 26,847.58, following a slack lead from Wall Street. Dealers await the Federal Reserve policy meeting later in the week. The Shanghai Composite Index dipped 1.46 points to 3,249.14, while the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.09% to 1,853.02.

site_title: The force is female: India's women cops take a stand
summary: India's all-female police units are shaking up the male-dominated force, combating sex crimes and a culture of silence around rape in conservative northwest India. The Jaipur unit, established in late May, patrols bus stops, colleges, and parks to address vulnerabilities of women to sexual harassment. With a message of zero tolerance, women police officers aim to encourage more women to report abusers, boosting confidence and encouraging open communication. The units' presence is seen as a preventive measure, restoring faith in the police and promoting law and order.

images.alt_text: All-female police units are shaking up the male-dominated force in conservative northwest India, hitting the streets to combat sex crimes and a pervasive culture of silence around rape.

site_title: Self-driving buses and robot aides could double Singapore growth
summary: A report by Accenture predicts that the integration of artificial intelligence in Singapore's economy could double the domestic growth rate to 5.4% in 18 years, lifting labor productivity and reducing the time needed to double the city-state's GDP from 22 to 13 years. This would translate to an additional US$215 billion in gross value added. The report attributes this growth to the adoption of AI, enabling workers to focus on innovation and addressing labor shortages due to an aging workforce. Singapore's smart nation vision and drive to become a global high-tech hub have already seen the implementation of AI in various industries.

site_title: Great Eastern more than doubles Q2 profit
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a net profit of S$279.5 million for Q2, more than doubling to S$102.2 million last year, driven by favourable financial market conditions. Total weighted new sales rose 6% to S$255.7 million, and earnings per share increased to S$0.59. An interim dividend of 10 cents per share was declared for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2017.

site_title: Toyota set to sell long-range, fast-charging electric cars in 2022 -paper
summary: Toyota plans to sell an electric car in 2022 with a range of up to 300-400 km and rapid charging capabilities, thanks to an all-solid-state battery. The new model would be able to recharge in just a few minutes, addressing current EV shortcomings. Toyota will initially sell the car in Japan, with the potential for international expansion. The move aims to improve the driving range and recharging time of electric vehicles, a key area of improvement for the technology.

site_title: Next James Bond film set for Nov 2019, no word on 007 star
summary: The 25th James Bond film, set for release on November 8, 2019, in the US and slightly earlier in Britain, has been confirmed by Eon Productions and MGM studios. The film's title, casting, and other details have not been announced. Daniel Craig, who played Bond in the last four films, has expressed reluctance to reprise the role, but remains the "first choice" according to executive producer Callum McDougall. Potential candidates to take on the role include Idris Elba, Tom Hiddleston, and Tom Hardy.

images.alt_text: James Bond is returning to movie theaters in November 2019, producers said on Monday, but they did not say who will play Britain's most famous fictional spy.

site_title: Chinese developer Sunac to raise US$516.4m in share sale
summary: Chinese developer Sunac China Holdings Ltd has agreed to sell US$516.4 million in shares, with the proceeds earmarked for general working capital. The sale, which represents 5.33% of the enlarged issued share capital, was priced at HK$18.33 per share, an 8.81% discount to the Monday closing price. The sale is part of a restructured deal involving conglomerate Dalian Wanda Group, with Sunac buying a 91% equity stake in 13 tourism projects for S$8.83 billion.

site_title: Gilberto Gil daughter becomes healthy food 'guru'
summary: Bela Gil, daughter of Brazilian singer and politician Gilberto Gil, has turned her interest in healthy eating into a television show and brand, promoting natural ingredients and sustainable food practices. With a focus on reducing industrialized food and encouraging Brazilians to prioritize organic products, Bela has gained a large following on social media and has launched two restaurants, three recipe books, and various products. Her tropical cuisine, which swaps out processed ingredients for natural alternatives, has been met with both praise and criticism, but Bela remains committed to her vision of healthy, sustainable eating.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hit by autos inquiry, airlines price war fears
summary: European stocks fell 0.2% on Monday, with automakers hitting their lowest level this year after EU antitrust regulators launched an investigation into cartel allegations. Airlines also faced price war concerns, with Ryanair warning of sharp cuts in summer fares. In contrast, Swiss bank Julius Baer rose 4.5% after reporting its biggest inflows since the financial crisis.

site_title: Alphabet profit hit by EU fine on Google
summary: Alphabet reported a quarterly profit of $3.5 billion, despite a $2.74 billion antitrust fine from the European Commission on Google. Revenue grew 21% to $26 billion, with profit impacted by the fine. Alphabet shares fell 2.9% to $969.03. The company continues to invest in new revenue streams, including "other bets" such as self-driving cars. The EU's antitrust investigation on Google's dominance of internet search and its advertising services may last years, with a potential impact on the company's ambition to expand beyond search results.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.11% higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.11% higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,314.29 points. Trading volumes were 66.8 million shares worth S$53.6 million. Gainers led losers with 71 stocks up and 56 down. This marks the fifth consecutive day of gains for Singapore stocks, ahead of the release of GDP data.

site_title: Alibaba said in talks for stake in Indonesia's largest online marketplace
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd is in talks to invest up to $500 million in Indonesia's PT Tokopedia, potentially securing a second deal to expand into Southeast Asia's largest economy. The investment would join existing backers SoftBank Group Corp and Sequoia Capital. This deal could preclude a similar investment by JD.com Inc, which was also in talks with Tokopedia. The investment would further solidify Alibaba's presence in the region, following its control of Lazada Group SA.

site_title: Chinese shipbuilders tap rising cruise demand, rattle European rivals
summary: Chinese shipbuilders are expanding into the cruise ship market, aiming to capitalize on booming local demand and challenge European rivals. China's government has set a goal to upgrade domestic manufacturing and support jobs through the "Made in China 2025" program. European shipbuilders fear China's entry could lead to domination of the cruise ship market, similar to its success in cargo ships. Chinese yards have brought in European advisers and foreign suppliers to learn how to compete, with Carnival Corp partnering with Fincantieri to build two cruise ships in China.

images.alt_text: European shipbuilders' dominance in the US$117 billion passenger ship industry may come under threat as Chinese rivals move into the sector to tap booming local demand for cruise holidays.

site_title: 'Despacito' singers slam Venezuela's Maduro for 'illegal' use of song
summary: Puerto Rican duo Daddy Yankee and Luis Fonsi criticized Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro for using their song "Despacito" to promote a controversial vote, despite altering lyrics to urge people to "vote" and potentially face mass protests. Maduro's plan has been met with widespread opposition, including a nationwide strike and warnings of economic sanctions. The duo condemned Maduro's "dictatorial regime" and stated that the song's purpose was not to manipulate public opinion, but to promote freedom and a better future.

images.alt_text: The Puerto Rican duo behind the worldwide sexy smash Latin pop hit "Despacito" on Monday slammed Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro for "illegally" using their song to promote a controversial vote he is organising.

site_title: Erdogan sees progress in Qatar crisis, says more time needed
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan stated that his recent visit to the Gulf region contributed to easing the Qatar crisis, but more time is needed to resolve the standoff.
