Erdogan expressed support for Kuwait's mediation efforts and praised Qatar's "positive attitude" in trying to solve the crisis. He also discussed joint efforts to combat terrorism with Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al-Thani. Turkey has a military base in Qatar, and Erdogan accelerated the process since the crisis began, with 150 troops now stationed there.

site_title: Justin Bieber abruptly ends tour
summary: Justin Bieber abruptly cancelled the remainder of his "Purpose" world tour due to unforeseen circumstances, citing a need to refund tickets. The 23-year-old Canadian singer had been set to resume the tour on Thursday with 15 shows across North America and Asia. Bieber's team gave no further details, following a string of controversies, including a 2014 visit to the Yasukuni shrine in Tokyo. The cancellation comes after China announced Bieber was unwelcome in the mainland due to his past behavior.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Great Eastern, Parkway Life Reit, IHC, Indiabulls, SIA
summary: Great Eastern Holdings posted S$279.5 million in net profit for Q2, more than double last year's S$102.2 million. Parkway Life Reit reported a 10% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit to 3.32 Singapore cents. IHC is expected to report a net loss for Q2. Indiabulls Property Management Trustee Pte Ltd's net property income rose 8% to S$18.8 million. SIA announced the merger of Scoot and Tiger Airways, with no material impact on financial performance.

images.alt_text: Great Eastern Holdings on Tuesday posted S$279.5 million in net profit for the second quarter ended June 30, more than double last year's S$102.2 million.

site_title: Hundreds battle wild fires across southern France
summary: Hundreds of firefighters battled multiple wildfires across southern France on July 24, 2017, with one blaze spreading 900 hectares of forest and threatening homes on the island of Corsica. Residents were evacuated from the town of Biguglia, and at least 150 firefighters were on the scene, aided by 12 fire engines and three firefighting planes. Other fires were reported in the Luberon region, Var region, and Carros, north of Nice, with over 270 firefighters responding to the blazes.

site_title: Ryanair warns rivals it may cut late summer fares by as much as 9%
summary: Ryanair warns rivals it may cut late summer fares by up to 9% compared to last year, citing a competitive market and over-capacity in Europe. The airline's profits soared 55% in the first quarter, but management expects prices to fall sharply in the coming months. Analysts had predicted Ryanair would scale back planned fare cuts, but the airline's low-cost model and cost base are seen as key factors in its ability to undercut rivals.

site_title: Trump pressures Republicans to repeal, warns 'Obamacare is death'
summary: President Donald Trump urged Republicans to pass health care reform, warning that "Obamacare is death" and calling on them to keep their campaign promise to repeal and replace the law. Despite the Senate's efforts to pass a repeal-only bill, several Republicans have expressed concerns, and the vote on Tuesday's motion to proceed is uncertain. With only one defector needed to block the bill, Trump's pressure on his party to pass reform has heightened, and the consequences of failure could be severe, according to the President.

site_title: US to test anti-missile system in Alaska
summary: The US military plans to conduct a routine test of the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (Thaad) missile-intercept system in Alaska, amid tensions with North Korea over its ballistic missile program. The test, scheduled to occur soon, is a routine measure to ensure the system's readiness and is not related to any real-world geopolitical events. Thaad is designed to intercept and destroy short- to intermediate-range ballistic missiles, while the Ground-based Midcourse Defense (GMD) system handles intercontinental ballistic missiles. This is the second successful test of Thaad against an intermediate-range target.

images.alt_text: The US military is preparing to conduct another test of a missile-intercept system in Alaska, the Pentagon said Monday, amid continued tensions with North Korea over its ballistic missile programme.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit's Q2 DPU up 10%
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 10% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit to 3.32 Singapore cents for Q2, driven by divestment gains of S$5.39 million from asset recycling in February 2017. Net property income rose 1.4% to S$25.9 million, while gross revenue grew 1.1% to S$27.7 million. The Reit attributed the growth to rent contributions from acquired properties and upward minimum guaranteed rent revisions.

site_title: India's power sector struggling to service and pay off loans
summary: India's power sector is struggling to service and pay off loans due to idle power plants. The Raikheda thermal coal power plant, completed years ago, sits idle, unable to buy coal or sell electricity. Dozens of nearby stores have shut down due to the project's failure. The debt-saddled plant was expected to provide power to hundreds of thousands of homes. The power sector's financial struggles are a concern for the country's energy security and economic growth.

site_title: To lure more wine lovers, sake makers learn it's all about rice
summary: Japan's sake makers are shifting their focus to locally grown rice to appeal to wine enthusiasts, following a 16-year-old brewery executive's experience with a New York event where sommeliers were disappointed by the lack of terroir. To address this, breweries in the Tohoku region are collaborating with farmers to develop and produce sake using local rice varieties, with about a third of Nanbu-Bijin's sake now made from Iwate-grown grain. This move aims to boost foreign sales and offset declining domestic consumption, with exports rising to a record 15.6 billion yen in 2016 and expected to reach 30% of total revenue in five years.

site_title: US: Nasdaq, tech shine as earnings pick up; Dow, S&P lag
summary: The US stock market saw a mixed performance on Monday, with the Nasdaq reaching a record high ahead of a big week of technology earnings reports. The S&P 500 and Dow industrials lagged behind, weighed down by losses in healthcare heavyweight Johnson & Johnson. Despite this, tech stocks remain a leading sector, with Alphabet's quarterly report due this week expected to set a positive tone for the sector. The market is now expecting earnings to climb 8.8% in the second quarter, up from a previous projection of 8%.

site_title: Federal Reserve streamlines aspect of Volcker Rule compliance
summary: The Federal Reserve streamlined part of the Volcker Rule compliance regulations, providing guidelines for banks seeking extensions to start and spin off hedge funds and private equity funds. The new guidelines allow regional banks to approve extension requests in most cases, streamlining the process. This marks the second regulatory adjustment to the Volcker Rule in a week, as regulators review the ban on proprietary trading. Banks can apply for up to a two-year extension to hold less than 3% ownership in a fund, with the Fed handling complex applications.

site_title: Kushner denies collusion, insists 'all actions were proper'
summary: Jared Kushner, Donald Trump's son-in-law and White House adviser, denied colluding with Russia to sway the 2016 election, calling his contacts with Russian officials "proper." Kushner testified before a congressional inquiry, stating that all his actions were above board and occurred in the normal course of events. He also denied relying on Russian funds for his business and echoed Trump's claim that investigations are an effort by Democrats to explain away the election loss. Kushner's testimony comes as the Justice Department and Congress investigate possible collusion, with special counsel Robert Mueller leading the investigation.

site_title: Bordeaux wine estate Chateau Fauchey sold to Chinese investor
summary: A Chinese property investment company, Profitsun Holdings, has acquired Chateau Fauchey, a 15th-century Bordeaux wine estate, for an undisclosed price. The estate, which includes 25 hectares of vineyards, will be distributed to members of Profitsun's clubs in Beijing, Shenzhen, and Hong Kong. This is the latest in a series of Chinese investments in Bordeaux wine estates, with over 100 properties acquired since 2010. The sale supports demand for mid-tier properties in the region, where top estates command prices above $10 million per hectare.

site_title: AI challenge pushes Microsoft further into chip development
summary: Microsoft has developed a custom chip for its HoloLens augmented reality goggles, designed to analyze vast amounts of data in real-time without relying on cloud processing. The new processor, a version of the Holographic Processing Unit, will be included in the next version of HoloLens and is the company's first chip designed for a mobile device. This move aims to provide lightning-fast and seamless AI experiences for devices, including phones, VR headsets, and cars, and is part of Microsoft's strategy to bring AI capabilities to mobile devices.

site_title: Oil rises 1% after Saudi vows to cap crude exports next month
summary: Oil prices rose 1% after Saudi Arabia pledged to cap crude exports at 6.6 million barrels per day in August, aiming to reduce the global crude glut. Brent crude futures settled at $48.60 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose to $46.34 a barrel. Russian energy minister Alexander Novak also hinted at additional output cuts if compliance is 100% met. Despite this, market watchers remain concerned about non-compliant nations offsetting the impact.

site_title: STI stays around 3,300; pennies in action
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) opened below 3,300 points but ended above it at 3,310.80 points, 0.1% lower from Friday's close. Penny stocks traded strong, with about 3.26 billion shares worth S$958 million changing hands. Conglomerate Keppel Corp traded down a cent, while construction play Swee Hong rose 27.8% after discharging its creditors and completing a land sale. Astra International was downgraded to a "hold" by CIMB Research, citing soft four-wheeler retail sales and market share threats.

site_title: Making waves in the O&M industry
summary: AMOS International, a 13-year-old technical solutions specialist, has navigated the turbulent shipping industry with innovation and customer-centric approach. Founded by Danny Lien in 2004, the company has grown from 12 employees to 130, offering a range of "one-stop" marine and offshore solutions. AMOS has secured key contracts with major shipping companies and has received international certifications, including the Singapore Productivity Award and ISO 9001. The company is expanding its presence regionally and exploring mergers and acquisitions to strengthen its reach. With a focus on continuous learning and innovation, AMOS is well-positioned to capitalize on growth opportunities in the maritime industry.

site_title: Local interest rates stirring - but will it last?
summary: Local interest rates in Singapore have begun to rise, with the 3-month Sibor reaching a 52-week high of 1.14% in early July, although it has since eased to 1.11%. The increase is attributed to the two interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve this year. The move is expected to benefit Singapore banks, particularly DBS, OCBC, and UOB, as higher interest rates increase earnings. However, the economic growth in Singapore remains uncertain, and the long-term impact of rising interest rates on the local economy is still to be seen.

site_title: As more ships criss-cross the Arctic, fears of disaster rise
summary: The Arctic is experiencing increased shipping due to global warming, with more ships, including luxury liners like the Crystal Serenity, taking tourists to the region. However, concerns arise about maritime safety, as there is a lack of emergency infrastructure, including ice-breakers and helicopters, to respond to potential incidents. Experts warn that a rescue operation could take days and rely on commercial ships in the area, while some advocate for preventing incidents through better training and safety requirements. The region's ice coverage is expected to decline, with the possibility of complete ice-free summers by the 2030s or 2040s.

site_title: Pedal power sways Muscovites despite perils
summary: In Moscow, cycling has become increasingly popular despite the city's challenging road conditions, with many residents like Luiza Nesterova riding without helmets or bike lanes. The city has invested in bike-sharing systems and expanded cycle lanes, but advocates say more needs to be done to prioritize cycling infrastructure. A recent reconstruction project has left cyclists without bike lanes, and there have been calls for the city to clear snow from cycle lanes to encourage more people to cycle.

images.alt_text: Participants of the Moscow bicycle parade riding through the city's streets. But Moscow is not an easy city for cyclists as uncrossable highways filled with speeding cars cut through the centre, and drivers are oblivious to cyclists.

site_title: How to make US$100,000 a month in China, live-streaming your life
summary: Yu Li, a Chinese live-streamer, earns $100,000 a month on YY, a social network run by Tencent. He spends hours broadcasting, cracking jokes, and interacting with fans, who send him virtual gifts representing real money. This lucrative business model has gained popularity in China, with many streamers replicating Li's success. As a result, live-streaming has become a viable way for individuals to monetize their online presence and connect with audiences worldwide.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages Sing Investments & Finance, Phillip Securities Research, and Maybank Kim Eng have released reports on Singapore-listed companies. Sing Investments & Finance recommends "accumulate" for Sing Investments & Finance, targeting S$1.67. Maybank Kim Eng maintains "hold" on Cache Logistics Trust, setting a target price of S$0.95. Phillip Securities Research also holds CapitaLand Mall Trust, setting a target price of S$2.04. CBC Investment Research downgrades Triyards Holdings to "hold", adjusting its fair value to S$0.19.

site_title: Driver charged as death toll climbs among Texas truck migrants
summary: A truck driver in Texas was charged with transporting illegal aliens after 10 migrants suffocated to death in the back of his 18-wheel truck, with two children among the survivors. The migrants, estimated to be between 70 to 200, were being smuggled into the US and were left without air in the sweltering trailer. Authorities have charged the driver, James Mathew Bradley Jr, with one count of transporting illegal aliens, which carries a life imprisonment or death penalty sentence. The incident has been described as a "network of abuse and death" by Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly.

site_title: The Ascott snags 80% stake in US corporate housing player
summary: The Ascott Ltd, a serviced residence arm of CapitaLand, has acquired 80% stake in US corporate housing player Synergy Global Housing for US$33.7 million, tripling its US portfolio to 3,000 units. This deal marks Ascott's first foray into corporate housing and entry into the US West Coast. The acquisition is part of Ascott's asset-light strategy, which is accretive in returns on equity, and will underpin future expansion. The deal also raises Ascott's global portfolio to nearly 70,000 units, with plans to expand further in cities such as New York, Boston, and Washington DC.

site_title: Chinese banks funding HNA's global buying spree getting cold feet
summary: Chinese banks that funded HNA Group Co's global acquisition spree are losing interest in providing new loans, with three banks stopping new loan extensions and a fourth trimming its exposure to the company. This pullback comes as Chinese regulators scrutinize the country's most active overseas dealmakers, including HNA, and amid growing concerns about the group's debt levels and ownership structure. HNA maintains its financial position remains strong, with cash reserves and access to equity markets, but a dearth of fresh credit could further restrain its ambitions.

images.alt_text: HNA took on at least US$73 billion of debt as it transformed from an obscure regional airline into a worldwide conglomerate with multi-billion- dollar stakes in Hilton Worldwide and Deutsche Bank.

site_title: Philips profits plunge 32.9% in second quarter
summary: Philips, a Dutch electronics giant, reported a 32.9% decline in second-quarter profits to €289 million, mainly due to costs associated with spinning off its lighting business. Sales grew 4% to €4.3 billion, with a strong order book and unchanged outlook for 2017. The company cited a solid performance despite market volatility and recent acquisitions, including a $1.9 billion deal to expand its health portfolio.

images.alt_text: Philips was once best known for manufacturing home electronics but now focuses on health technology.

site_title: Trump's FDA chief takes wide aim at opioid addiction crisis
summary: The FDA, led by Commissioner Scott Gottlieb, plans to limit opioid prescriptions by partnering with health insurers and pharmacy benefit managers. Gottlieb aims to reduce the number of people exposed to opioids by making prescriptions medically appropriate. This move is part of a broader overhaul of the FDA's regulation of opioid painkillers, which are linked to a growing addiction crisis in the US, with over 23,000 deaths in 2015. Gottlieb's plan includes examining whether insurers and PBMs can reduce pills dispensed, potentially changing drug labels or requiring doctor education on longer prescriptions.

site_title: Rising from the ashes of the Asian financial crisis
summary: Asian financial markets have made significant progress over the past 20 years, recovering from the 1997 crisis and becoming more resilient and well-placed for future growth. The development of a stronger domestic capital market, led by countries such as Singapore, and local regulators strengthening the banking sector, have contributed to this growth. Asian investors have also become more active, with a shift towards non-bank financial institutions and outbound investments. The region's capital markets have become more efficient, stable, and transparent, facilitating a productive two-way flow of investment between Asia and the rest of the world.

site_title: SoftBank and Didi hand US$2 billion to Grab, making it SEA's most valuable startup
summary: SoftBank and Didi Chuxing invested US$2 billion in Grab, making it the most valuable startup in South-east Asia with a valuation over US$6 billion. The deal cements a partnership between Didi and Grab, which competes against Uber in markets such as Malaysia and Thailand. SoftBank's investment follows Uber's retreat from China and Russia, and the company's chairman, Masayoshi Son, stated that Grab is using technology to address transportation and payments in South-east Asia.

site_title: S'pore firm starts debit card to convert crypto to normal currencies
summary: A Singapore-based startup, TenX, has launched a debit card that can convert multiple digital currencies, including Bitcoin, into fiat money, making it easier for users to spend them in the real world. The card, which charges a 2% conversion fee, has received over 10,000 orders and processes around $100,000 in transactions per month. TenX aims to expand its services and reach 1 million users by the end of 2018, with plans to support 11 digital currencies by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Tenx's bid to make digital currencies easier to spend comes amid massive volatility and infighting within the cryptocurrency community. Bitcoin, the most popular, slumped after reaching a record in June amid concerns about a split in two, only to recover as fears faded.

site_title: China's debt spectre could haunt US Fed meetings
summary: China's growing dollar-denominated debt, totaling over $500 trillion, poses a risk to the US Federal Reserve's rate hikes. The Fed cited China as a reason for delaying its first interest rate hike in 2015. As the Fed raises rates, China's debt may become harder to roll over, potentially weakening the yuan and creating a global challenge for Fed policy. Analysts warn that China's rapid accumulation of dollar debt will lead to a harsher economic adjustment in the future.

site_title: Sapphire bags new China metro contracts worth 308m yuan
summary: Sapphire Corp announced new infrastructure contracts in China worth approximately RMB308 million (S$63 million), sustaining its order book at RMB2.6 billion. The contracts include a RMB224 million civil engineering contract for the Ningbo Rail Transit Line.

site_title: US dollar edges up from 13-month low, aided by solid US data
summary: The US dollar rose from a 13-month low against a basket of six major currencies on Monday, boosted by stronger-than-expected US economic data. The dollar index was 0.15% higher at 94.006, driven by solid readings on the US economy, including manufacturing and services flash surveys. However, market participants remain cautious due to ongoing probes into Russia's alleged interference in the 2016 US election and weak US economic data. The euro rose to a 23-month high against the dollar, but analysts expect a potential selloff and profit taking.

images.alt_text: The US dollar inched up from its lowest level in more than a year on Monday, assisted by stronger-than-expected readings on the US economy, as investors kept a wary eye on developments concerning possible ties between Russia and aides to US President Donald Trump.

site_title: Saudi economic pain testing resolve on reforms
summary: Saudi Arabia's efforts to diversify its economy beyond oil have been hindered by the drop in crude prices, with economists forecasting close to zero economic growth this year. The International Monetary Fund has revised its forecast for Saudi growth, citing a weak non-oil sector and a high budget deficit. Analysts expect the economy to shrink for the first time since the 2009 global financial crisis, and the government's ability to balance its budget by 2020 is uncertain. Despite reforms aimed at stimulating growth, lower oil prices are testing the authorities' resolve to pursue tough measures.

site_title: Vintage fashion is all the rage online
summary: The Fifth Collection, a Singapore-based online vintage fashion retailer, has developed proprietary authentication technology powered by artificial intelligence (AI) called Entrupy to combat counterfeiting in the luxury goods market. The technology uses a microscopic camera to scan items and compare images to a database of authentic products, achieving an accuracy rate of 98%. The company, founded in 2014, promises a lifetime unconditional guarantee on every item sold and has seen significant growth, with sales increasing three times year-on-year. Entrupy is the only authentication technology of its kind in Asia, and The Fifth Collection aims to position itself as a leader in the market.

site_title: Jokowi risks political backlash by banning hardline Islamic group
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has banned the hardline Islamic group Hizbut Tahrir, citing threats to the country's unity and sovereignty. The move has sparked criticism from opposition parties, who warn of potential political backlash and the risk of suppressing organizations not aligned with the government. Analysts predict that the ban could galvanize conservative Muslim voters against Jokowi, potentially harming his chances in the 2019 presidential election. The move has also raised concerns about the erosion of civil society organizations and the potential for extremist groups to fill the power vacuum.

site_title: Tiny Bhutan should speak up in China-India dispute
summary: China and India are facing off in a disputed border area claimed by Bhutan, Doklam. China asserts its claim based on a 1890 treaty with Britain, but the treaty's ambiguity and a subsequent map published by Britain in 1907-1913 raise questions about its validity. Bhutan should speak up and negotiate directly with China, as India's involvement may be seen as supporting a domineering neighbor. The situation has the potential to escalate into a David-versus-Goliath conflict, with Bhutan resisting China's claims.

site_title: Japan launches 'telework' campaign
summary: Japan launches a "Telework Day" campaign to promote working from home, aiming to ease congestion and soften its rigid work culture. Almost 930 companies, including major firms like Suntory Holdings and Tokyu Construction Co, will participate in the initiative, to be held annually from 2018 to 2020. The goal is to ease Tokyo's congestion and improve work-life balance.

site_title: Ambani's Jio venture to launch free smartphone
summary: Mukesh Ambani's telecom venture Jio will launch a free smartphone called JioPhone, available from September, with a deposit of 1,500 rupees (S$32) refundable after three years. The move escalates a price war in India's ultra-competitive mobile market, with rival Bharti Airtel's shares plummeting 6% after the announcement. Jio has already signed up 125 million subscribers since its launch in 2016, forcing competitors to slash their tariffs. The launch is seen as a significant threat to market leaders Samsung and Xiaomi.

site_title: Chainsaw attack injures five in Swiss Town of Schaffhausen
summary: At least five people were injured in a chainsaw attack in Schaffhausen, Switzerland on Monday. The attacker is on the run and authorities have ruled out terrorism, but do not know the motive or background of the perpetrator. Five victims are hospitalized, with two seriously injured. Authorities have advised residents to remain indoors until further notice.

site_title: Trade associations, chambers pump up the volume under Lead programme
summary: Trade associations and chambers in Singapore have increased productivity and market access projects under the Local Enterprise and Association Development (Lead) programme, with 28 projects started in the past year and S$36 million in funding. This represents a significant jump from the previous year, when only 11 projects were supported with close to S$10 million. The programme aims to enhance industry and business competitiveness through partnerships with TACs, and the government has announced the formation of the Logistics Alliance to develop and drive industry projects in the logistics sector.

site_title: Foreign buyer forking out S$430.1m for Citimac in en bloc sale
summary: A foreign developer has purchased Citimac, a freehold industrial complex near Tai Seng MRT Station, for S$430.1 million, or S$1,047 per square foot of potential gross floor area. The unit land price includes an estimated S$82 million development charge. The sale price works out to a significant increase from the previous minimum price of S$550 million in 2014. Owners of the 110 strata units will receive sales proceeds of between S$2.1 million and S$10 million per unit, pending unanimous approval from the owners.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Nigeria oil thieves keep a lid on output even as bombs abate
summary: Nigeria's oil output remains disrupted due to theft, despite efforts to quell militant attacks. The Agbada 2 flow station, owned by Royal Dutch Shell, was idle for three weeks due to a pipeline leak and sabotage. An estimated 30% of Nigeria's oil output is stolen, depriving the country of income amid a recession. Companies are using surveillance and drones to combat theft, but the problem persists, threatening plans to exceed 2 million barrels a day. Experts say sabotage is linked to economic and social issues, and that Nigeria needs transformation to stabilize its oil industry.

site_title: More hiring helps Julius Baer record highest inflows since financial crisis
summary: Julius Baer, Switzerland's third-largest private bank, reported its highest six-month inflows since the 2008 financial crisis, with net new money attracting at an annualized rate of 6.1% of assets. The bank hired over 100 private bankers in 2016 to gain new clients, exceeding its 4-6% target range. Assets under management grew 6% to 355 billion Swiss francs, and adjusted net income remained steady year-over-year. The bank's cost/income ratio was below its target range, and it expects to reach the target in 2018.

site_title: Elderly drivers wreaking havoc on Japan's roads
summary: Elderly drivers in Japan are causing a significant increase in fatal accidents, with 459 fatalities attributed to drivers aged 75 and over in 2016, accounting for 13% of total accidents. The government is stepping up efforts to restrict senior drivers, introducing a cognitive test for those over 75 and potentially revoking their licenses. Despite this, many elderly drivers are voluntarily relinquishing their licenses, with 1,271 old people returning their licenses in the first three months of the new law.

site_title: Banks go digital with services for start-ups and SMEs
summary: Two Singaporean banks, DBS Bank and OCBC Bank, have launched digital services to aid start-ups and small and medium enterprises (SMEs). DBS introduced the DBS Get Set portal, allowing businesses to set up accounts in 30 minutes. OCBC digitized its business account opening process using iPads, eliminating paper forms and reducing the time needed for customer information. These services aim to simplify administrative processes, allowing SMEs to focus on building their customer base and adopting web-based solutions. Both services are already in use.

site_title: Trump's steel curbs risk trade war: Japan mills group
summary: US President Donald Trump's plans to restrict steel imports could lead to a global trade war, according to Japan's leading mills group, citing the potential for retaliatory measures in other areas like farm products. The move could provoke a chain reaction of protectionism, as China and the European Union have already warned of potential retaliation. Economists have also criticized the move, citing its potential to damage the US economy. Japan's steel exports to the US are minimal, but choking off supply could hurt US customers.

site_title: Nomura India fund soars to S$4.9b as Japanese bet on Modi
summary: Japanese investors are betting on India's economic growth, with Nomura Holdings Inc's India equity fund quadrupling to S$4.9 billion in the past year. India's economy is expanding at 7% annually, driven by a burgeoning middle class and reforms under Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Global and local funds have pumped $16 billion into India's stock market this year, making it one of the world's top performers in 2017. Japanese investors own $13 billion of Indian stocks and bonds, the most in data going back to 2012.

site_title: World economy in strongest upswing in a decade, says IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that the global economy is experiencing its strongest upswing in a decade, driven by buoyant trade growth. Global recovery is now on firmer footing than in April, with growth revised up for Japan, the euro area, China, and emerging markets. The IMF expects global growth to remain above its longer-run potential growth rate, but has downgraded forecasts for the US and UK due to near-term fiscal policy. Growth projections for 2017 have been revised up for many euro area countries, while China's growth is expected to remain at 6.7% in 2017 and decline modestly in 2018.

site_title: No winners in Gulf feud as market focus turns to oil prices
summary: Qatar remains in a stalemate with Saudi Arabia and its allies after seven weeks of diplomatic tensions. Investors are focusing on oil prices, with crude languishing under $50 a barrel, rather than the feud. The crisis has overshadowed economic concerns in the region, including Saudi Arabia's first quarterly economic contraction and the UAE's slowing growth. Qatar is relatively well-placed to weather the crisis due to its trade with Asia, and investors are prioritizing market fundamentals over the diplomatic dispute.

site_title: Philippines' biggest money manager sticks with pricey property stocks
summary: The Philippine Stock Exchange Property Index has climbed 24% this year, driven by an accelerating economy, rising remittances, and government incentives. BDO Unibank's head of equity investments, Fitzgerald Aclan, expects the sector to continue growing and outperforming, citing attractive potential upside at undervalued companies like Ayala Land Inc. Analysts at COL Financial Group and First Grade Finance Inc. note that perceptions have improved, but hurdles such as rising borrowing costs and tax incentives for low-cost homes may impact demand.

site_title: Elusive wage growth, ample openings: China too catches it
summary: China's labor market remains tight with low unemployment, yet wages growth is stagnant, mirroring trends in the US and Europe. Demand for hiring remained healthy, with the most in-demand jobs being in technology and professional services. However, white-collar pay edged down and pay rises for migrant workers narrowed. The ratio of vacancies to applicants decreased, with labor demand intensifying in western regions. Despite factories resuming hiring, some pay gains are levelling off, with white-collar pay and new economy professionals experiencing stagnant wage growth.

site_title: Centurion to acquire US student housing
summary: Centurion Corporation Ltd announced its intention to acquire a portfolio of five US student accommodation assets across four states for US$136 million. The assets, which include 1,936 beds, will be added to Centurion's existing accommodation portfolio in Australia and the UK. This move marks Centurion's entry into the US market.

site_title: Singapore ramps up search-and-rescue operations with new S$8.4m satellite system
summary: Singapore is investing S$8.4 million in a new satellite-based system to enhance search-and-rescue operations within its maritime waters and air space. The system, developed by Cospas-Sarsat, will relay distress signals from aircraft, ships, or people to the ground, improving accuracy and speed in detecting and locating distressed parties. The system aims to be operational by 2018, complementing existing equipment and resources, and enabling more expeditious deployment of assets to save lives. This upgrade is part of Singapore's participation in the international Cospas-Sarsat programme since 1991.

site_title: Mason plans acquisitions for wealth unit
summary: Mason Group Holdings, a Hong Kong financial firm backed by Chinese property tycoon Hui Wing Mau, plans to acquire or form partnerships to build an offshore wealth management business of at least $3 billion in assets. The company aims to target affluent Chinese investors and is in talks with multiple firms, with potential deals to be announced by the end of the year. Mason's new wealth business will leverage its Hong Kong brokerage and health business to execute trades and win clients.

site_title: Steelmakers worth most in years, thanks to China
summary: Steel stocks are trading at their highest levels since 2011 due to China's reduced steel exports, which have dropped 28% in the first half of the year. This decrease, combined with robust demand in China, has led to a 45% increase in global steel stocks and a 75% jump in steel prices in Europe and the US over the past 18 months. China's infrastructure spending has boosted local demand, while the government's plant closures have reduced exports. The US Commerce Department's Section 232 probe into steel imports may further restrict Chinese exports, potentially leading to more plant closures.

images.alt_text: Steel stocks are trading at the highest since 2011 and it's mostly thanks to the industry's biggest menace in recent years: China.

site_title: Public spheres for the Trump Age
summary: US universities are facing challenges in addressing the needs of economically disadvantaged students and fostering open debate in the face of a polarized society under President Trump. Economist Lawrence Summers argues that universities should prioritize students from underprivileged backgrounds and provide them with the necessary resources to succeed. He also emphasizes the importance of intellectual diversity and rejecting failed ideas, while acknowledging the need for civility and respect in campus discussions. Summers' comments come as the US experiences a rise in campus radicalism and a shift in the country's political landscape.

site_title: Abe denies cronyism amid declining support
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe held a parliamentary hearing to address declining support, with his approval rating at 26%, the lowest since taking office in 2012. Abe denied cronyism and apologized for disparaging remarks about opponents. His cabinet's approval rating slumped in three media polls, with disapproval exceeding 56%. Abe vowed to focus on the economy to stem the slide in his popularity.

site_title: Initial coin offerings turn the venture capital relationship upside down
summary: US venture capital firms are facing a shift in the traditional funding model with the rise of initial coin offerings (ICOs) in the digital currency market. Startups are now able to raise millions quickly without dilution, making venture capitalists scramble for sought-after offers. Since mid-July, tech firms have raised about $1.1 billion in 89 coin sales, eclipsing funds from venture capital firms. Some issuers limit pre-sale deals, forcing VCs to participate in public offers. Experts say the old business model is no longer applicable, and VCs will become a smaller part of capital formation, with tokens used to attract a broad community of enthusiasts.

site_title: Singapore's public sector more ready than most for the digital future
summary: Singapore's public sector is more prepared for the digital future than many other countries, with a strong foundation to harness emerging technologies and a well-established Smart Nation agenda. However, attracting digitally savvy workers remains a challenge, with 20% of government tech leaders in Singapore citing a lack of internal skills as a barrier. Despite this, 86% of public-sector agencies have made significant structural changes to their workforce to implement emerging technologies, and the majority have the necessary skills, including software engineers, digital developers, and machine-learning specialists.

site_title: Carnegie Mellon University revamps Pittsburgh
summary: Carnegie Mellon University's School of Computer Science has been a driving force behind Pittsburgh's resurgence, attracting top talent and fueling the city's tech industry. The university's proximity to companies like Apple, Facebook, and Google has made Pittsburgh an attractive destination for skilled workers, transforming once-derelict neighborhoods like Lawrenceville and East Liberty into hubs for innovation. With its high-quality of life and affordable cost of living, Pittsburgh has become a magnet for millennials, with many choosing to stay in the city rather than relocate to more expensive cities like New York or San Francisco.

site_title: Eurozone slowdown could delay easing by ECB
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) may delay easing stimulus due to a slowdown in eurozone business growth since Q3, alongside declining inflation pressures. IHS Markit's July PMI showed growth above 50, but at a slower pace. This could impact the ECB's expectation of a stimulus clawback later this year, as inflation remains below the 2% target ceiling.

site_title: Trump's policy is a rocky road with twists and U-turns ahead
summary: US President Donald Trump has rolled back many of former President Barack Obama's international legacy initiatives, including the Trans-Pacific Partnership, the liberalisation deal with Cuba, and the Paris climate change deal. Trump's "America First" policy has also led to a suite of measures eroding bilateral sanctions with Russia and introducing measures to review and potentially withdraw from the North America Free Trade Agreement and the Iranian nuclear agreement. Despite criticism of his administration's international stance, Trump's foreign policy has been marked by U-turns and incoherence, failing to define a clear doctrine or grand strategy.

site_title: In unwinding its balance sheet, Fed should start slow, but start soon
summary: The US Federal Reserve should consider unwinding its balance sheet in a slow and measured approach, but not wait too long. The current balance sheet of $4.5 trillion, accumulated through quantitative easing, poses a risk of premature normalization of policy and snuffing out a fragile US recovery. The Fed should start by letting $10 billion of holdings mature each month and increase the roll-off by $10 billion every quarter. The decision is also influenced by signs of an economic recovery, flattening interest rate spreads, and the need to address market distortions caused by its extraordinary policy.

site_title: Euro settles near 2-year highs; outlook bullish
summary: The euro rose to a 23-month high against the US dollar, trading at US$1.16465, after latest business growth data for July pointed to a mild slowdown in the eurozone economy. The IHS Markit's Euro Zone Flash Composite Purchasing Managers' Index fell to 55.8, still above the 50 level, suggesting continued resilience of the euro area recovery. This bullish outlook has led investment banks to recommend staying long euros and buying short-dated FX calls, with the euro up over 10% so far this year.

site_title: CIMB partners Alipay for mobile wallet and more
summary: CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, Malaysia's second-largest bank, has formed an equity joint venture with Ant Financial Services Group, the parent of Alipay, to provide mobile wallet and related financial services. The CIMB unit, Touch 'n Go Sdn Bhd, will be majority shareholder, while Ant Financial will be a minority shareholder. This partnership aims to expand mobile payment services in Malaysia and is part of CIMB's fintech plans. Ant Financial's investment in Malaysia marks its first in the country, and the move is part of a broader trend of fintech companies entering South-east Asia.

site_title: Stronger performance, acquisitions boost MLT's Q1
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) reported a strong Q1, driven by higher asset performance and new acquisitions. Distribution per unit increased to 1.887 Singapore cents, while income available for distribution expanded 2.5% to S$47.2 million. Gross revenue grew 7% and net property income rose 7.5% due to positive rental reversion and acquisitions in Australia, Malaysia, and Vietnam. The trust's portfolio occupancy rate fell to 95.5% due to lower occupancy in South Korea.

site_title: Hong Kong rejects IPO application of Morgan Stanley-backed insurance broker
summary: The Hong Kong stock exchange has rejected the IPO application of AMTD Strategic Capital Group, a corporate insurance broker backed by Morgan Stanley's private equity arm. The rejection makes it only the sixth company to fall foul of Hong Kong stock listing regulations in nearly four years. The IPO, which could total US$200 million, was filed by AMTD Asia in May.

site_title: Blackstone in talks to buy 40% of Israel cyber firm NSO: report
summary: Blackstone is in talks to buy 40% of NSO Group, a maker of spyware for mobile devices, for US$400 million. ClearSky is expected to join as a secondary buyer, acquiring 10%. This deal would value NSO Group at US$1 billion. The acquisition would further solidify Blackstone's presence in the cybersecurity market.

site_title: Headline inflation up first time in 2 years for middle, highest income
summary: Singapore's headline inflation rose 0.7% year-on-year in H1 2017, reversing the 0.2% decline in H2 2016. The increase was driven by higher prices for food, petrol, tuition, and healthcare services. Middle- and highest-income households experienced their first inflation rise in two years, while the lowest 20% of households saw a 0.1% year-on-year decline. The inflation trend is expected to continue, with economists predicting gradual price increases in the next six months.

site_title: Chinese jets intercept US surveillance plane: US officials
summary: US officials reported that two Chinese fighter jets intercepted a US Navy surveillance plane over the East China Sea on Sunday. One Chinese J-10 aircraft came within 91 meters of the US EP-3 plane, causing it to change direction. The incident occurred without incident, and no further details were provided. The US officials spoke on condition of anonymity due to the sensitive nature of the matter.

site_title: Linkin Park says can never replace late singer
summary: Linkin Park stated that they can never replace late singer Chester Bennington after his suicide, acknowledging that his "demons" fueled his music. The band expressed their appreciation for the "outpouring of love and support" and noted that their future is uncertain. In a statement, they described Bennington as a "boisterous, funny, ambitious, creative, kind, generous voice in the room" whose absence leaves a void that can never be filled.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ascendas India Trust reported a 3.4% decline in Q1 income available for distribution due to higher current income tax expenses and income hedging losses. Gross revenue jumped 29.5% to S$46.7 million, driven by new acquisitions, developments, and positive rental reversions. GuocoLand sold out the first phase of Martin Modern, with total sales exceeding S$220 million. Jasper Investments secured a contract to transport quarry dust for Hong Kong International Airport's third runway system. Lian Beng is divesting a property in Melbourne for A$34 million. Global Logistic Properties has appointed ANZ as its independent financial adviser to advise on its recent offer.

site_title: A billion Indian identities at stake in privacy case
summary: India's top court is considering whether privacy is a fundamental right in a case challenging the government's biometric identity program, Aadhaar. The program, which has collected data from over 1.1 billion citizens, has been used for various purposes beyond its original intention to curb welfare siphoning. Activists and lawyers argue that the data should be limited to specific purposes to prevent leaks or misuse, while the government maintains that privacy is not a fundamental right. A ruling is expected in subsequent weeks, which could impact companies like Microsoft and Samsung that have integrated Aadhaar into their products.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust's Q1 DPU dips to 1.31 cents
summary: Ascendas India Trust's Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) decreased to 1.31 Singapore cents from 1.36 cents in the previous year, due to higher current income tax expenses and income hedging losses. Q1 income available for distribution shrunk 3.4% to S$13.5 million. Gross revenue jumped 29.5% to S$46.7 million, while net property income increased 28.7% to S$30.4 million.

site_title: US existing home sales slide in June Washington
summary: US existing home sales declined in June, reversing May's rebound, due to unsustainable price growth. The National Association of Realtors reported a tight market struggling to meet demand. Despite strong demand, closings were driven down. NAR chief economist Lawrence Yun stated that demand for buying a home is as strong as it was before the Great Recession.

site_title: In year of bad news, Brazilian meat giants finally catch a break
summary: Brazilian meat giants JBS SA, Marfrig Global Foods SA, and Minerva SA are experiencing stellar market conditions for beef, with prices paid by meatpackers declining by the biggest margin in two decades. Wholesale prices have remained mostly flat, fetching a premium of about 38% on cattle, the highest since at least 2008. This positive trend comes after a year of challenging headlines for the industry, including safety scares and export bans.

site_title: Fifteen years after bloody riots, Indian Muslims struggling to escape Gujarat ghettos
summary: Fifteen years after the 2002 Gujarat riots in India, many Muslim families remain stranded in segregated ghettos, unable to escape due to lack of resources and government support. Over 200,000 people were displaced, and 17,000 were resettled in 80 colonies, but these areas remain isolated and underdeveloped. Critics argue that the "Disturbed Areas Act" is being used to enforce social segregation, with Muslims confined to the worst neighborhoods and excluded from development. The government's reluctance to relocate displaced Muslims has exacerbated the problem, leaving thousands in precarious living conditions.

site_title: TT International receives letter of demand for alleged rent arrears
summary: TT International, a consumer electronics retailer, received a letter of demand from BBPL, a 51% subsidiary, claiming S$50.75 million in alleged rent arrears. The demand, which must be repaid within 10 days, threatens legal action if not paid. TT International disputes the claim and is seeking legal advice to challenge the demand. The company is also assessing the impact of the letter on the group.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens flat as earnings season gathers pace
summary: US stock indexes opened flat on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 4.91 points, the S&P 500 losing 1.02 points, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 0.47 points. The focus was on Alphabet's earnings and the upcoming Federal Reserve meeting. The markets await the Fed's two-day meeting, which starts on Tuesday, amidst ongoing trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: WeWork 'looking for space' in HK's Lan Kwai Fong
summary: WeWork, a co-working space company, is in talks to rent a building in Hong Kong's Lan Kwai Fong district. The company is seeking to rent Hotel LKF by Rhombus, a boutique hotel that will be converted into an office building by mid-2018. This move comes as soaring office rents have pushed financial firms out of the financial district, with demand for flexible and shared offices surging in Asia. WeWork plans to expand its operations in Hong Kong, following a joint venture with SoftBank Group in Japan and plans to open its first office in Tokyo in 2018.

images.alt_text: WeWork's expansion in the world's priciest property market comes as soaring office rents have pushed some financial firms and hedge funds out of the financial district.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust's Q3 DPU dips
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust's (FCOT) Q3 distribution per unit (DPU) decreased to 2.4 Singapore cents from 2.41 Singapore cents in the previous year, despite a stronger performance in its Australian portfolio. The company's gross revenue and net property income also declined 0.6% and 0.8% respectively. The decline was mainly due to lower occupancy rates at certain properties. FCOT units ended 0.35% down at S$1.425.

site_title: Kushner says met Russians four times, denies collusion: US media
summary: US media reports that Jared Kushner, a senior White House adviser, had four contacts with Russian officials during the 2016 presidential campaign. Kushner denies any collusion with Russia, describing the contacts as normal for his role as campaign liaison to foreign governments. He plans to submit an 11-page statement to the Senate intelligence committee, stating the contacts were "standard" and did not involve any collusion.

site_title: mm2: Golden Village deal held back because seller did not get approval
summary: MM2 Asia's planned acquisition of a 50% stake in Golden Village cinema business in Singapore has been delayed due to the failure of Village Cinemas Australia to obtain approval from Golden Screen, the entity holding the remaining 50% stake, by July 21. The deal was contingent on this approval, and with it not obtained, the acquisition did not take place. MM2 is now exploring its options.

site_title: Ex-Chongqing CCP boss under probe for 'violations of discipline'
summary: Former Chongqing Communist Party boss Sun Zhengcai is under investigation for "suspected serious violations of discipline" by the party's anti-corruption watchdog. The investigation comes ahead of a key party congress in autumn, where President Xi Jinping will cement his grip on power. Sun, once considered a contender for top leadership, was replaced by a rising political star close to Xi in February, after the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection criticized Chongqing authorities for not rooting out Bo Xilai's influence. The investigation's outcome is likely to result in punishment for Sun.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust's Q3 DPU flat on Northpoint enhancement works
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust's Q3 distribution to unitholders remained flat at S$27.7 million due to ongoing asset enhancement works at Northpoint. Despite a 1% year-on-year decline, portfolio occupancy held steady. The trust's manager, Frasers Centrepoint Asset Management, attributed the flat distribution to the ongoing enhancement works.

site_title: Trump warns of 'last chance' to pass health care reform
summary: President Donald Trump warned Republicans that they have one "last chance" to pass the party's health care reforms, as lawmakers prepare for a vote on a replacement plan. The Senate is set to vote Tuesday to begin debate on the plan, which aims to dismantle Obamacare but delay implementation. Previous versions of the plan have collapsed in recent weeks, casting doubt on its success. Trump's warning comes as the effort to repeal and replace Obamacare remains uncertain, with the Senate's vote expected to be a critical test of the party's ability to pass its agenda.

site_title: Future of Airbus A380 superjumbo said to hinge on Emirates
summary: Airbus is working to secure orders for its A380 superjumbo, with a key deal with Emirates worth $8.7 billion crucial to extending the jet's life. The company aims to secure 20 jets, with follow-on orders from British Airways, ANA Holdings, and Thai Airways International. A failure to secure the Emirates deal could lead to production cuts, with Airbus potentially reducing output to less than one A380 per month. The deal is seen as vital to the career of outgoing marketing chief John Leahy, who has been instrumental in securing the A380's sales.

site_title: TT International gets letter of demand for alleged rent arrears
summary: TT International, a Singapore-based consumer electronics retailer, has received a letter of demand from BBPL, its 51% subsidiary, claiming repayment of S$50.75 million in alleged rental arrears. The company disputes the claim and is seeking legal advice. TT International is being restructured under a scheme of arrangement since 2010 and its shares have halved from the start of the year, closing at 2.3 Singapore cents on Monday. The company must make a payment of S$50.75 million within 10 days or face legal action.

site_title: In China, Silicon Valley giants confront new walls
summary: China's Silicon Valley giants, including Facebook, LinkedIn, and Apple, are facing significant challenges in the country. Despite their global success, these companies are struggling to gain traction in China, with many experiencing declining user engagement and sales. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers to address the issue. Meanwhile, other global news includes Malaysia seizing assets worth RM3 billion, the UK economy shrinking for the second month, and South Korea seeking a 'landing zone' in US trade talks. These developments highlight the complexities of China's tech market and its impact on global business.

site_title: Julius Baer could grow managed assets to more than 500b Swiss francs says CEO
summary: Julius Baer, Switzerland's third-largest private bank, is poised to grow its assets under management by over 40% in the next decade, reaching over 500 billion Swiss francs, according to CEO Boris Collardi. The bank reported its most successful six months in attracting new assets, with assets under management reaching 355 billion francs. Collardi believes Julius Baer could gain ground on number two bank Credit Suisse and is open to using spare cash for acquisitions or returning it to shareholders.

site_title: North American strength helps Halliburton smash profit view
summary: Halliburton reported a quarterly profit of US$28 million, beating analysts' expectations, driven by strong demand in North America. Revenue from the region surged 83% to US$2.77 billion, with margins growing into double digits. The company's shares rose 2.5% after the announcement. US oil producers added 94 rigs in the quarter, and rival Schlumberger also reported strong quarterly results. Halliburton's CEO expects margins from North America to improve, as the company continues to benefit from increased demand for pumping and well-construction services.

site_title: GLP board picks ANZ as independent financial adviser for offer
summary: The Global Logistic Properties (GLP) board has appointed ANZ, Singapore branch, as an independent financial adviser to assist in making a final recommendation to shareholders regarding the recent offer. GLP directors had previously chosen a Chinese consortium with an S$3.38 per share offer, with Nesta Investment Holdings as the offeror. A scheme document containing the final recommendation will be sent to shareholders in due course, after shares of GLP closed at S$3.31 on Monday.

images.alt_text: The board of Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has appointed Australia and New Zealand Banking Group (ANZ), Singapore branch, as the independent financial adviser to advise its independent directors in making a final recommendation to shareholders over the recent offer for the company.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.830 points to 1,761.990. The market saw 1.668 billion lots traded worth RM1.678 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 516 to 314.

site_title: VW, Daimler workers step up pressure to come clean on collusion
summary: Germany's carmakers, including Volkswagen, Daimler, and BMW, face pressure from workers to come clean on allegations of collusion on technology, following the diesel emissions crisis. Labour leaders are demanding explanations and consequences if the allegations are confirmed. The European Union is studying possible collusion among auto manufacturers. The companies' supervisory boards will convene to discuss the situation, with Volkswagen holding a special meeting. Industry leaders warn that collusion could lead to billions of euros in fines and damage the credibility of the German auto industry.

site_title: Hijab goes mainstream as advertisers target Muslim money
summary: Advertisers are increasingly promoting the hijab, a traditional Islamic headscarf, in mainstream media and fashion campaigns, tapping into the estimated $44 billion modest fashion market. Brands like Apple, Nike, and H&M are featuring hijab-wearing models and creating their own hijabs, sparking both excitement and concerns about cultural appropriation and exploitation. Experts say that authentic representation and promotion of the hijab can be a powerful tool for tolerance and acceptance, but warns against exploiting the market for profit without genuine effort to promote understanding.

images.alt_text: Major fashion brands from American Eagle to Nike are creating hijabs, while hijab-wearing models have started gracing Western catwalks and the covers of top fashion magazines.

site_title: Hasbro's quarterly sales rise 10.6%
summary: Hasbro, the No 2 US toymaker, reported a 10.6% rise in quarterly revenue to US$972.51 million, driven by demand for Transformers and Nerf toys in the US. Net income increased to US$67.72 million, or 53 US cents per share. This represents a 29.5% increase from the same period last year.

site_title: Chinese turn to Western zodiac for celestial guidance
summary: China has adopted Western astrology as a mainstream trend, especially among the younger generation. Online platforms and social media accounts offer weekly horoscope forecasts, and dating websites list zodiac signs alongside basic information. The practice has become a cultural phenomenon, with many consulting it for major life decisions, including relationships, friendships, and hiring employees. Some companies, like a car sales company, even use zodiac signs to streamline the hiring process, citing the perceived traits of certain signs as beneficial for specific roles. This trend has led to "zodiac discrimination" in job recruitment, with 4.3% of college graduates reporting experience.

site_title: China probes former rising star in party for violations
summary: China's official Xinhua News Agency confirmed that former Communist Party chief of Chongqing city, Sun Zhengcai, is under investigation for serious disciplinary violations. The 53-year-old Sun, a rising star in the party, was considered a potential future leader. His probe comes ahead of a leadership shuffle later this year and underscores President Xi Jinping's commanding position. This marks a significant setback for Sun, who had been expected to join the party's Standing Committee and potentially secure a top leadership post.

images.alt_text: China's official Xinhua News Agency confirmed on Monday that Sun Zhengcai, the former Communist Party chief of Chongqing city, is under investigation for serious disciplinary violations.

site_title: Nomura India fund reaches 400b yen as Japan bets on Modi
summary: Japan's Nomura Holdings sees significant investment in its India equity fund, with assets quadrupling to nearly 400 billion yen in the past year. This surge is driven by investor optimism about Prime Minister Narendra Modi's policies, which have led to India's economy expanding at 7% annually. Japanese investors now own US$13 billion of Indian stocks and bonds, making it a "consensus trade" among money managers. Experts attribute this interest to India's relatively high yields, structural reforms, and political stability, with some predicting continued growth despite potential market fluctuations.

images.alt_text: The land of Abenomics is betting on Modinomics.

site_title: Advance SCT says BayCrest Int'l plans to subscribe for S$2m worth of its bonds
summary: Advance SCT has entered into a non-binding MOU with BayCrest International Inc to subscribe for S$2 million worth of redeemable convertible bonds (RCBs) with a 3% coupon rate, valid for three years. The RCBs placement is part of a corporate exercise to capitalise debts held by major creditors. The deal is conditional on the completion of the debt capitalisation exercise and parties are still in negotiations on the details.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust Q3 DPU dips on larger unit base
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported a 0.9% increase in distributable income to S$19.2 million in Q3, despite a 2.5% decline in weighted average rent reversion for Singapore properties. The trust's DPU dropped to 2.4 Singapore cents, down from 2.41 cents in the preceding year. Gross revenue slipped 0.6% to S$38.3 million, while net property income fell 0.8% to S$27.9 million. FCOT's Australian portfolio contributed to the increase in distributable income, driven by the stronger Australian dollar.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.62% on Monday, tracking US losses, as a strong yen weighed on exporters. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 19,975.67, and the Topix index at 1,621.57. Investors await key corporate earnings, with the yen's value continuing to impact the market.

site_title: HK analyst maintains 'sell' call on Geely
summary: Hong Kong-based analyst Robin Zhu of Sanford C Bernstein & Co maintains a "sell" call on Geely Automobile Holdings Ltd., citing uninspiring retail trends, issues with its new upscale brand Lynk & Co, and ambitious valuation. Zhu's 12-month target price of HK$7.50 implies a 57% drop from the current share price. Other analysts, including Macquarie's Janet Lewis, share similar concerns, citing reliance on government subsidies and lack of research and development expenses. Despite the negative outlook, some analysts, like Angus Chan, remain bullish on the company's product pipeline and Lynk brand.

site_title: OLS to acquire 51 per cent stake in Advance Capital Partners for S$1.5m
summary: OLS Enterprise Ltd has entered into a share purchase agreement to acquire a 51% stake in Advance Capital Partners Asset Management Pte Ltd for S$1.5 million. The acquisition is in line with OLS' new strategic goal of expanding its business into the financial services sector, despite Advance Capital Partners' net loss of S$24,000 in FY2017. OLS shares rose 50% to close at 0.6 Singapore cent following the announcement.

site_title: UK opens power grid to batteries in step to save £40b
summary: The UK government has announced plans to open the electricity grid to battery storage devices, aiming to save £40 billion on energy bills. The Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy will invest £246 million in battery technology research and amend the 1989 Electricity Act to encourage investment in energy storage. This move is seen as a key step towards allowing greater amounts of renewable energy onto the grid, benefiting both consumers and industry.

site_title: Britain launches fund to boost electric battery technology
summary: Britain has launched a £246 million fund to boost electric battery technology, part of its industrial strategy to protect the economy as it leaves the European Union. The scheme aims to support businesses and academia in developing and manufacturing electric batteries, a key growth area for the car and energy sectors. This initiative is designed to take a more hands-on approach to developing industries and follows the Prime Minister's industrial strategy published in January.

site_title: Sapphire secures 308 million yuan of metro contracts in China
summary: Sapphire Corporation Limited secured 308 million yuan in metro contracts in China, sustaining its order book at 2.6 billion yuan. The contracts include a 224 million-yuan civil engineering contract for the Ningbo Rail Transit Line and design consultancy works for Taiyuan City's Metro Line 2. The projects are expected to be completed over the next 36 months, with the exception of the Taiyuan extension, which is scheduled for completion by end-2021.

site_title: Investors lose US$22 billion as Sweden's benchmark stocks founder
summary: Swedish investors lost US$22 billion as the OMXS30 index, a benchmark of Sweden's top 30 stocks, fell 4% in the busiest week of the summer earnings season. Disappointing earnings from Ericsson AB, Nordea Bank AB, and Atlas Copco AB led the losses, with Ericsson sinking 16% and Atlas Copco falling 6.9%. Analysts attributed the decline to overly high earnings estimates, with some expecting a rebound in the Nordic stock market for the rest of the year.

site_title: China's Politburo pledges to prevent 'systemic' financial risks
summary: China's Politburo pledged to prevent "systemic" financial risks by implementing a proactive fiscal policy and prudent monetary policy in the second half of the year. The decision aims to strengthen financial regulation, stabilize the property market, and address debt risks. The meeting, chaired by President Xi Jinping, also emphasized the need to resolve built-up government debt risks and curb hidden debt. The statements' themes reiterate past declarations of government policies, with economists expecting increased government spending as "proactive" fiscal policy.

site_title: Lian Beng's subsidiary to sell property in Australia for A$34m
summary: Lian Beng's subsidiary, Goldprime Realty, is selling a Melbourne property for A$34 million (S$36.8 million). The property, located at Units 1-19 of 596 St Kilda Road, is being divested through a contract of sale with an unrelated third party.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Philips profits fall 32.9% in second quarter
summary: Dutch electronics giant Philips reported a 32.9% fall in second-quarter profits to 289 million euros, mainly due to costs from spinning off its lighting business. The company's net income dropped from 431 million euros in the same period in 2016. The decline was attributed to lower income from discontinued operations and higher structuring and acquisition-related charges.

site_title: China banks that funded HNA's growth are said to halt new loans
summary: Chinese banks that funded HNA Group Co's global acquisition spree are halting new loans. Three banks have stopped extending new loans to HNA, while a fourth bank reduced its exposure to the company. This move comes as Chinese regulators scrutinize offshore deals to stem capital outflows and shore up the yuan. HNA, which took on at least $73 billion of debt, has cash on hand and no indication of rebuffed funding requests. The pullback may further restrain HNA's ambitions as regulators clamp down on corporate borrowing.

site_title: Stronger asset showing, acquisitions boost Mapletree Logistics' Q1
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) reported a 2.5% increase in Q1 income available for distribution to S$47.2 million, driven by stronger asset performance and new acquisitions. Gross revenue grew 7% to S$95.8 million, with net property income rising 7.5%. The growth was attributed to higher revenue from existing properties, new acquisitions, and stronger currencies. MLT units finished 0.8% higher at S$1.22.

site_title: UN accuses Australia of breaching refugee deal
summary: The UN accused Australia of breaching a deal to relocate asylum-seekers to the US in exchange for accepting some with close family ties in Australia. The UN High Commissioner for Refugees stated that Australia refused to accept vulnerable refugees despite agreeing to do so. Australia's immigration department maintained that it has always barred refugees from settling in the country, and the government has consistently said those transferred to regional processing centers will not be allowed to settle in Australia.

site_title: Euro area economy grows at slowest pace in 6 months
summary: The euro area economy experienced its slowest growth pace in six months during the third quarter, according to data released by IHS Markit. The composite Purchasing Managers' Index fell to 55.8 in July from 56.3 in June. This indicates a quarterly expansion pace of 0.6%, down from 0.7% in the second quarter. Manufacturing cooled, contributing to the slowdown.

site_title: Opec signals no big changes to supply deal at meeting in Russia
summary: Opec and its allies are not planning significant changes to their supply deal, despite oil prices remaining below $50 a barrel. The group, led by Saudi Arabia, is betting that rising demand will combine with existing output cuts to rapidly deplete fuel stockpiles and boost prices in the second half of the year. However, rising production from exempt nations like Libya and Nigeria, and US shale producers, may limit the effectiveness of the cuts. The group will focus on stabilizing the market, rather than making deeper cuts.

site_title: Malaysia's top midcap performer in merger talks to boost profit
summary: Malaysia's top midcap stock, Dagang NeXchange Bhd, is in merger talks to boost profit. The company is in advanced talks to acquire its IT unit and preliminary negotiations for its energy business. Over 80% of its revenue comes from IT, and the group managing director aims to double its profit growth target to double digits this year through mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start week in winning way
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.53% on Monday, driven by a strong week in US earnings, despite a weak lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index ended at 26,846.83, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased by 0.39% and 0.48%, respectively. The gains come ahead of the release of major US earnings this week, with traders looking to gauge the impact of the ongoing trade tensions on the markets.

site_title: WeWork in talks to rent in heart of Hong Kong bar zone
summary: WeWork is in advanced talks to rent a building in Hong Kong's Lan Kwai Fong district, a popular nightlife area, to convert into an office space. The building, Hotel LKF by Rhombus, closed down in July and is expected to be converted by the middle of next year. This move comes as soaring office rents have pushed financial firms out of Hong Kong's financial district, with demand for flexible and shared offices surging in Asia. WeWork's expansion in Hong Kong's pricey property market is part of its broader Asia expansion, which includes plans to open its first office in Tokyo in 2018.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop as banks, commodities drag; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares dropped 1% on Monday, led by a sell-off in bank stocks and a slump in commodity prices, particularly oil. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 57.64 points to 5,665.2, its lowest since June 9. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index remained flat. Analysts attribute the decline to concerns over interest rate hikes and a forecast of Opec's output rise.

site_title: Japan launches "telework" campaign to ease congestion, reform work culture
summary: Japan launched a "Telework Day" campaign to promote working from home and ease congestion during the 2020 Olympics, involving almost 930 companies. The initiative aims to soften Japan's rigid work culture, which has been linked to low labor productivity and high worker stress. The government has also introduced policies to shorten working hours and raise contract workers' pay. The long-term goal is to establish more humane working conditions, shifting the focus from long hours to work-life balance.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust's DPU dips for Q3 on lower revenue, enhancement works
summary: FRASERS Centrepoint Trust's distribution to unitholders dropped 1% year-on-year to S$27.7 million in Q3 2017, due to lower revenue and ongoing asset enhancement initiative works at Northpoint. Net property income fell 1.3% to S$30.8 million, while revenue declined 3.3% to S$43.6 million. The trust's gearing stood at 30% and gearing improvements were reported. Despite this, FCT's suburban malls are expected to remain resilient, with over 90% of reconfigured areas pre-committed at Northpoint.

site_title: IMF cuts UK growth forecast, Treasury calls for smooth Brexit
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has downgraded its growth forecast for the UK economy, predicting a 1.7% growth rate this year, down from 2% previously. This is the largest downgrade for a rich nation this year. The downgrade reflects the UK's weaker-than-expected growth in the first half of the year, mainly due to accelerating inflation. The IMF's chief economist, Maurice Obstfeld, noted that the ultimate impact of Brexit on the UK remains unclear. The UK finance ministry has renewed its call for a smooth Brexit, with finance minister Philip Hammond stressing the need for a transition deal.

images.alt_text: Britain has suffered the biggest downgrade of economic growth projections by the International Monetary Fund for the world's rich nations this year, prompting the finance ministry to renew its call for a smooth exit from the European Union.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's headline inflation fell 0.5% in June due to lower housing and maintenance costs. GuocoLand sold nearly 90 units of apartments at Martin Modern, ranging from S$1.75 million to S$4.55 million. mm2 Asia's Golden Village cinema deal is stalled due to a counterparty's failure to obtain approval. Meanwhile, Centurion plans to buy US student housing assets for $136 million. Grab, Uber's rival, is set to raise $2.5 billion in funding from Didi Chuxing and SoftBank. Singapore shares closed 0.1% lower on Monday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.96 points to 1,758.20. Trading volume reached 241.3 million lots worth RM85.5 million, with 163 gainers outnumbering 134 losers.

site_title: China warns India not to harbour illusions in border stand-off
summary: China's defense ministry warned India not to harbor illusions about its military's ability to defend its territory, amid a border dispute in the Sikkim region. The standoff, which began after Indian guards crossed into China's territory, has escalated tensions between the two nations. China's military has strengthened its ability to defend its territory, with spokesman Wu Qian stating that shaking the People's Liberation Army is hard. The situation remains tense, with both sides' troops facing each other 150m apart, but diplomats have engaged to try to find a peaceful resolution.

site_title: IMF upgrades Malaysia's 2017 growth forecast to 4.8%
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has upgraded Malaysia's 2017 growth forecast to 4.8% from 4.5%, citing a stronger-than-expected performance. The IMF maintained its global growth forecasts for this year and next, but revised up expectations for the eurozone and China. The upgrade is seen as a positive sign for Malaysia's economy, which has been performing well despite regional challenges.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on weak commodity prices and banks
summary: Australian shares fell on Monday, dropping 0.6% to 5,688.1, due to weak commodity prices and a sell-off in bank stocks. The energy subindex fell 2.7% and mining giants BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto lost 0.4% and 0.7% respectively. However, gold miners bucked the trend, with Newcrest Mining Ltd rising 0.9% after meeting its full-year output targets. The S&P/NZX 50 index in New Zealand rose 0.1%.

site_title: India's NSE index hits record high, moves closer to 10,000 mark
summary: India's NSE index reached a record high of 9,968.95, surpassing the previous record set a week earlier, as Reliance Industries Ltd surged 2.5% on optimism about its core business and telecom venture. The BSE index also climbed to an all-time high of 32,242.78. Analysts expect a consolidation phase in the near term, with more companies reporting earnings, including HDFC Bank Ltd. Strong quarterly results lifted stocks such as Vijaya Bank and Jammu and Kashmir Bank.

site_title: BMW, VW and Daimler shares skid on EU probe of German carmakers
summary: German auto stocks, including BMW, VW, and Daimler, declined in early Monday trading due to uncertainty over possible antitrust fines from European regulators. The European Commission received a tip-off about a potential cartel in the car industry, and allegations have surfaced that carmakers may have colluded to fix prices of diesel emissions treatment systems. Analysts say the allegations may weigh on stocks, with BMW, VW, and Daimler shares down 2.5%, 3.3%, and 2.9% respectively, amidst a 0.4% decline in the DAX index.

images.alt_text: German auto stocks took a hit in early Monday trading, weighed down by uncertainty over possible antitrust fines after European regulators said they were investigating allegations that carmakers were operating a cartel.

site_title: Car bomb in Afghan capital kills at least 24: Kabul officials
