summary: A suicide attacker detonated a car bomb in western Kabul, killing at least 24 people and wounding 40, in the Afghan capital. The attack, near the home of a government official, is the latest in a wave of violence in Afghanistan, which has seen at least 1,662 civilian deaths in the first half of the year. The Taliban has been launching attacks around the country, sparking fighting in several provinces. The US is weighing its strategic options for Afghanistan, including potentially sending more troops to bolster Afghan forces.

site_title: Singapore invests $8.4m into new search and rescue satellite technology
summary: Singapore has invested $8.4 million in a new satellite technology called MEOSAR, aiming to improve search and rescue capabilities. The medium-altitude earth orbit search and rescue system uses satellites to receive distress signals from emergency beacons activated by aircraft, ships, or people in distress. The system will enhance the country's search and rescue operations, providing a more efficient and effective response to emergencies.

site_title: Malaysia's CIMB to partner Alipay for mobile payment platform
summary: CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, Malaysia's second-largest bank, announced a partnership with Ant Financial Services Group, the parent of Alipay, to form an equity joint venture for a mobile payment platform. The CIMB subsidiary, Touch 'n Go Sdn Bhd, will be majority shareholder, while Ant Financial will be a minority shareholder. The joint venture aims to provide world-class online and offline payments services, with CIMB injecting capital to support the venture's creation. This is Ant Financial's first investment in Malaysia.

images.alt_text: CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, Malaysia's second-biggest bank, on Monday said its subsidiary will form an equity joint venture with Ant Financial Services Group, the parent of Alipay, to provide mobile wallet and related financial services.

site_title: Deutsche Bank, JPMorgan agree to settle yen-Libor lawsuits
summary: Deutsche Bank and JPMorgan Chase have agreed to pay a combined US$148 million to settle claims they manipulated the benchmark yen Libor rate from 2006 to 2011. Deutsche Bank will pay US$77 million and JPMorgan US$71 million without admitting wrongdoing. This settlement follows similar agreements by Citigroup and HSBC, with other banks still facing lawsuits. The deals are part of a broader trend of banks paying billions in fines to settle allegations of rigging the London interbank offered rate, a key financial benchmark used to set interest rates.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip at start of trading
summary: European shares fell 0.2% at the start of trading, with the autos sector hitting its lowest level this year due to an EU antitrust investigation into regional carmakers. Airlines also suffered losses, with Ryanair's shares dropping 4.7% after warning of sharp cuts to summer fares. In contrast, financials and retail sectors saw gains. Gemalto plummeted 17% after warning of profit losses, while B&M European Value Retail rose 4.1% after a report on a potential Asda takeover bid.

site_title: CPI for Singapore households up by 0.7% in H1 2017
summary: The consumer price index (CPI) for Singapore households rose by 0.7% year-on-year in the first half of 2017, reversing the 0.2% decline in the second half of 2016. Excluding imputed rentals, the CPI increased by 1.9%. The bottom 20% of households saw a 0.1% decline, while the middle 60% and top 20% saw 0.6% and 1% increases, respectively. Higher food, petrol, tuition, and healthcare costs were offset by falling accommodation and transport costs.

site_title: Ryanair to cut fares sharply in coming months
summary: Ryanair plans to cut ticket prices by up to 9% in the coming months, further increasing competition in Europe's short-haul market. The airline, Europe's largest by passenger numbers, has driven down prices by increasing capacity by 33% in the past two years. This move puts pressure on low-cost rivals easyJet and Wizz Air, which have also warned of under-pressure average fare levels during the key summer period.

images.alt_text: Crisis-hit Ryanair has apologised to its pilots and offered to pay more than budget airline rivals, as the likes of EasyJet look to profit from sector turbulence that continued to rumble on Friday.

site_title: Two H1N1 flu cases suspected at Myanmar hospital
summary: A hospital in Yangon, Myanmar's largest city, is treating two patients suspected of having contracted H1N1 influenza, a strain of swine flu. The cases have raised concerns for a potential new outbreak, with the government and healthcare officials meeting to discuss the situation. The virus disproportionately affects younger people and was a global health concern in 2009. A news conference is planned for later Monday to provide further details.

site_title: Grab, Uber's rival, to raise US$2.5b from Didi, SoftBank, others
summary: Grab, the ride-hailing competitor of Uber, plans to raise US$2.5 billion in its latest financing round led by Didi Chuxing and SoftBank Group Corp. The funding will help Grab bolster its market share and grow its payments platform. With this round, Grab expects to be valued at over US$6 billion, solidifying its position as the leading ride-hailing service in Southeast Asia. The company aims to expand its services to include loans, electronic money transfer, and money-market funds.

site_title: GuocoLand sold close to 90 units of Martin Modern during weekend launch
summary: GuocoLand announced on Monday that the first phase of Martin Modern in Singapore has sold out, with close to 90 units sold during the weekend launch. Initially planned for 50-60 units, the sold units range from S$1.75 million to S$4.55 million, with prices from S$2,009 to S$2,500 per square foot. The total value of sold apartments exceeded S$220 million. The development is expected to receive its temporary occupation permit by end 2021.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore headline inflation falls more than expected to 0.5% in June
summary: Singapore's headline inflation fell to 0.5% in June, lower than expected, due to sharply reduced housing and maintenance costs. This was attributed to the timing effects of service and conservancy charges rebates. Economists had predicted a 0.7% year-on-year increase in the consumer price index. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Ministry of Trade and Industry jointly released the data, citing a market consensus of 0.7%.

site_title: A $10b euro credit manager girds for high-yield 'dislocations'
summary: European high-yield investors should prepare for potential "dislocations" as interest rates rise from record-low levels, according to Capital Four CEO Sandro Naef. Despite a 50% rise in the Bloomberg Barclays Pan-European High Yield Total Return Index in the past five years, yields on riskiest bonds are approaching investment grade debt, creating opportunities for investors. Naef expects "huge amounts of opportunity" as the market adjusts to the shift, but notes that no one can predict the outcome of the changes.

site_title: UK households face sharpest squeeze in three years: IHS Markit
summary: UK households face the sharpest financial squeeze in three years, with the Household Finance Index dropping to 41.8 in July, its lowest since 2014. Inflation is rising faster than wages, causing households to cut back on big purchases. Official data is forecast to show a slight economic growth of 0.3% in the second quarter, potentially limiting the Bank of England's decision to raise interest rates for the first time in a decade.

site_title: Japan PM Abe denies favours for friend amid falling support
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe denied allegations of favoritism towards a long-time friend and director of Kake Educational Institution, Kotaro Kake, amid a sinking approval rating. Abe stated he never instructed preferential treatment and that Kake had "never once" sought favors. The scandal, coupled with declining support below 30%, threatens Abe's hopes for a third term as ruling Liberal Democratic Party leader. Abe is expected to reshuffle his cabinet to repair his ratings, but the move may backfire if novice ministers become embroiled in scandals.

site_title: Britain's Johnson compares Maori greeting to headbutt
summary: Britain's Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson compared a traditional Maori greeting, the hongi, to a headbutt during a visit to New Zealand, saying it might be misinterpreted in a Scottish pub. He also praised the country's strong female leadership and described New Zealand as "the most mind-blowingly, mind-numbingly beautiful country" he's ever seen. The visit, which began on Monday, aims to focus on trade, foreign policy, and international security issues. Johnson's comments follow a history of gaffes, including comparing Hillary Clinton to a "sadistic nurse" and referring to Barack Obama as "part-Kenyan".

images.alt_text: Britain's gaffe-prone Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson likened a traditional Maori greeting to a headbutt Monday while visiting indigenous leaders in New Zealand.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, falling 0.67% to 19,964.39, following modest declines on Wall Street and yen strength. The Topix index also dropped 0.69% to 1,618.69.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars near multi-month peaks as USD struggles
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are near multi-month peaks due to the struggling US dollar. The Australian dollar reached a two-year high of US$0.7992 and is now at US$0.7919, while the New Zealand dollar is close to its almost 11-month peak. The gains come as investors seek safe-haven assets amid global economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar stood near two-year highs on Monday while its New Zealand counterpart was within kissing distance of an almost 11-month peak against an unloved greenback.

site_title: 'Dunkirk' opens as top film, while Pricey 'Valerian' flops
summary: "Dunkirk" opened as the top film in the US box office with $50.5 million in weekend sales, beating expectations. The World War II epic, directed by Christopher Nolan, features Tom Hardy and Mark Rylance and had a budget of $150 million. In contrast, "Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets" flopped with $17 million in sales, missing low expectations. "Girls Trip" took second place with $30.4 million in sales, with "Dunkirk" receiving 92% positive reviews from critics.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.64% higher on Monday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.64% higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 20.99 points to 3,314.12. Trading volume was 105.3 million shares worth S$59.1m, with losers initially taking the lead over gainers. However, the market eventually favored gainers, with 54 stocks rising and 73 falling.

site_title: Billionaire-backed Mason plans acquisitions to build wealth unit
summary: Mason Group Holdings Ltd, backed by Chinese property tycoon Hui Wing Mau, plans to acquire or form partnerships to build a US$3 billion offshore wealth-management business. The company aims to target affluent Chinese investors and is in talks with multiple firms, with deals expected to be announced by the end of 2017. Mason's CEO Alex Ko sees opportunities in acquiring well-regulated European banks to tap into the global asset-allocation business. The move enters a crowded market dominated by major private banks in Asia, including UBS and Credit Suisse.

site_title: Melted fuel hunt marks advance in Japan's 40-year atomic cleanup
summary: Japan's Tokyo Electric Power Co Holdings Inc has made a significant discovery in the Fukushima nuclear power plant, with images showing melted fuel at the bottom of the containment vessel of the No 3 reactor. This marks a critical step in the 40-year, $72 billion cleanup process. Experts consider the finding a major breakthrough, saying it's "significant early signs of progress" on safely decontaminating and decommissioning the facility. The discovery is seen as a crucial step towards completing the cleanup, which is expected to take decades.

site_title: IMF keeps global growth forecasts; China, eurozone revised higher
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) maintained its global growth forecasts for 2017 and 2018 at 3.5% and 3.6%, respectively. However, it revised up growth expectations for the eurozone and China, citing "solid momentum" and stronger domestic demand. The IMF also downgraded its forecast for the UK and maintained its forecast for Japan. China's growth is expected to slow to 6.4% in 2018, but the IMF expects the country to maintain high public investment.

site_title: Jokowi courts political risk with ban on hard line islamic group
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has been granted new powers to outlaw religious organizations, including the hard-line Islamic group Hizbut Tahrir, citing threats to Indonesia's unity and sovereignty. The move has sparked criticism from opposition parties, who warn it could lead to further polarization and undermine democratic values. The ban is seen as a risk to Widodo's support among conservative Muslim voters, who may turn to rival Prabowo Subianto in the 2019 presidential election. The decision has also raised concerns about the potential for extremist groups to emerge from the banned organization.

site_title: Jasper signs one-year contract to transport quarry dust in HK airport project
summary: Jasper Investments has signed a one-year contract to transport two million cubic meters of quarry dust for Hong Kong International Airport's third runway system project. The contract, set to begin between August and September 2017, has an option for extension. Jasper will provide transport services for the reclamation and engineering works.

site_title: Singapore startup counts on Visa to take bitcoin into real world
summary: A Singapore-based startup, TenX, is launching a Visa card that converts digital currencies like bitcoin into fiat money, allowing users to spend them in the real world. The card takes a 2% cut from each transaction and has received over 10,000 orders. TenX aims to process $100 million in monthly transactions by 2018 and has already processed $100,000 a month. The company's success may depend on customer relations and whether competitors from major financial institutions can match its service.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open week with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the week with losses, mirroring an Asia-wide sell-off following a negative lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.11% to 26,677.47, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.22% and 0.16% respectively. The losses were attributed to traders awaiting major US earnings releases this week.

site_title: Hail, pummeled cars loom over US insurance results
summary: A hailstorm in Texas damaged 311 cars, causing at least $4 million in damage and $500,000 to a dealership building. This is part of a larger trend of severe weather-related losses for US property insurers, with thousands of cars damaged across multiple states. The damage is expected to result in significant claims for insurance companies, with millions of dollars in losses already reported.

images.alt_text: A steady stream of storm systems that trigger hail and fierce winds has traveled out of the Rocky Mountains and into parts of the central and eastern United States, said Steve Bowen, an Aon Benfield meteorologist.

site_title: mm2: Seller responsible for obtaining approval that held back Golden Village deal
summary: mm2, a movie and TV production company, said its planned acquisition of a 50% share in Golden Village cinema business in Singapore has not taken place due to a lack of approval from the remaining stakeholder, Golden Screen. The condition was that Golden Screen had to approve mm2 by July 21, which was not met. mm2 is now exploring its options, stating that getting the approval was the responsibility of Village Cinemas, as mm2 is not party to the agreement between the two shareholders.

site_title: CapitaLand's Ascott to triple US portfolio with US$33.7m acquisition
summary: CapitaLand's serviced residence arm The Ascott has acquired an 80% stake in US-based Synergy Global Housing for US$33.7 million, tripling its US portfolio to approximately 3,000 units. Globally, Ascott's portfolio will increase to nearly 70,000 units. The acquisition is expected to give Ascott direct access to corporate customers in the US and expand its cross-selling network. Ascott CEO Lee Chee Koon stated that the deal will help the company become a dominant player in the hospitality ecosystem by providing better services and product offerings to customers.

site_title: Malaysia's top midcap performer in merger talks to boost profit
summary: Malaysia's top midcap performer, Dagang NeXchange Bhd, is in merger talks to boost profit, with a focus on its technology and energy businesses. The company aims to double its profit growth target to double digits this year through acquisitions. Dagang NeXchange has risen 195% in the past 12 months, driven by earnings from foreign vehicle entry payment projects and a logistics system. Analysts expect the company to pay a regular annual dividend and explore new energy investments.

site_title: Alaska town's purr-fect unofficial cat mayor dies at 20
summary: Stubbs, the 20-year-old cat who became Talkeetna, Alaska's unofficial mayor, has died. Elected in 1997, Stubbs became a tourist attraction, with over 75% of visitors seeking him out. He survived a 2013 dog attack and was often passed from hand to hand for photos. Stubbs' owners, the Spone family, said he "was a trooper until the very last day of his life." He increasingly stayed at home this year, instead of visiting the store where he was frequently photographed.

site_title: mm2 Asia fails to get key approval for Golden Village acquisition
summary: mm2 Asia failed to secure approval from Golden Screen to acquire a 50% stake in Golden Village cinema business in Singapore, a key condition for the deal. The movie and TV production company is now exploring its options. The acquisition was announced on June 13 but did not take place due to the missed deadline.

site_title: Bordeaux wine estate Chateau Fauchey sold to Chinese investor
summary: A Chinese property investment company, Profitsun Holdings, has acquired Chateau Fauchey, a 15th-century wine estate in Bordeaux, for an undisclosed price. The estate includes 6.5 hectares of AOC Cadillac Cotes de Bordeaux vines and will be distributed to members of the company's clubs in Beijing, Shenzhen, and Hong Kong. This deal follows other recent purchases of Bordeaux wine estates by Chinese investors, who seek to tap into the growing Chinese domestic market and historic properties for wine tourism.

site_title: The Sharknado phenomenon: making America bait again
summary: The Sharknado franchise, which began as a low-rated TV movie, has become a cult classic after its release in 2013. With five films in five years, the series has gained immense popularity, thanks to its over-the-top gore, airborne sharks, and social media buzz. The franchise has spawned a cottage industry of merchandise, including books, action figures, and video games. Stars Ian Ziering and Tara Reid have become fan favorites, despite initially expressing concerns about their involvement. The series' success has also led to international productions, with the upcoming film, Sharknado 5: Global Swarming, set to release on August 6.

site_title: Centurion plans to buy US student housing assets for US$136m
summary: Centurion Corp plans to acquire a US$136m portfolio of student housing assets in the US, comprising 1,936 beds in four locations. The company aims to take up to 30% of the portfolio and is in talks with third parties to complete the deal. Centurion currently owns 3,488 beds in the UK, Australia, and Singapore.

site_title: BMW rejects media reports of emissions manipulations
summary: BMW has denied media reports that its emissions treatment systems in vehicles do not work effectively and that it colluded with rivals on their design. The company stated that its cars meet applicable legal requirements and that the issue lies with the small size of AdBlue tanks, not the technology itself. The European Commission is investigating the allegations, and German politicians are calling for transparency and punishment if wrongdoing is found. BMW reaffirmed its commitment to voluntary software updates for older diesel passenger cars.

site_title: Nine suspected migrants found dead in Texas truck, 30 others ill
summary: Nine suspected migrants were found dead in an overheated truck in a Walmart parking lot in Texas, with 30 others hospitalized, in what police described as a "horrific" human trafficking crime. The victims were packed into a trailer with no functioning air conditioning, with temperatures estimated to have reached 65°C. The truck driver was arrested, and authorities believe the incident may be linked to a larger human trafficking network. This is the latest in a series of tragic incidents involving migrants attempting to cross the US-Mexico border.

site_title: Top Asian investor in hedge funds boosts China-listed shares
summary: Noah Holdings Ltd, a top Asian investor in hedge funds, has cut its China-related American depository receipts by about one-third this year after shares surged, while adding to yuan-denominated shares listed on the mainland. The move is driven by concerns over US market momentum being too concentrated and sentiment-driven. The fund has shifted investments to "A-shares," which are comparatively cheap and have higher expected profit growth than US-listed counterparts. This decision comes as MSCI Inc's decision to include China's stocks in its indexes for the first time is expected to boost A-share investments.

site_title: Venmo app: it's nickel-and-diming everything, literally
summary: A Venmo user, an elementary school teacher, expressed frustration with the app's nickel-and-diming nature, where payments are calculated to the penny, making friendships more transactional. Users have reported a decline in generosity and chivalry, particularly for small purchases. The app's public nature and lack of private options have also led to embarrassing or intimate transactions being visible to others. Some users have abandoned the service, opting for joint bank accounts instead, in an effort to maintain a sense of intimacy and generosity in their financial relationships.

site_title: New Trump communications director promises crackdown on media leaks
summary: Anthony Scaramucci, President Donald Trump's new communications director, vows to stop media leaks and has promised "dramatic action" against staff members who leak information. Scaramucci described leakers as "un-American" and will lead a team meeting on Monday to address the issue. The move comes after White House press secretary Sean Spicer resigned following Scaramucci's appointment. Scaramucci also downplayed the need for pardons, stating there's "no need" for them.

images.alt_text: Anthony Scaramucci, President Donald Trump's new communications director, said on Sunday that one of his first tasks will be to halt leaks and that staff on his team would be fired if the leaks do not stop. "If we don't get the leaks stopped, I am a businessperson, and so I will take dramatic action to stop those leaks," Mr Scaramucci said on Fox News Sunday.

site_title: Nomura India Fund soars to 400b yen as Japanese bet on Modi
summary: Japanese investors are betting on India's economic growth, with Nomura Holdings Inc.'s India equity fund quadrupling to 400 billion yen in the past year. The demand is driven by India's expanding middle class, high growth rate, and relatively high yields, making it a "consensus trade" among money managers. India's economy is growing at 7% annually, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi's policies showing tangible progress. Global and local funds have pumped $16 billion into its stock market this year, making the Sensex one of the world's top performers in 2017.

images.alt_text: The demand is so strong that assets of Nomura Holdings Inc.'s India equity fund quadrupled to almost 400 billion yen (S$4.9 billion) in just the past year.

site_title: Australian regulator investigating Takata airbag recall
summary: Australia's consumer watchdog is investigating the recall of Takata Corp vehicle airbags, amid a possible link to a man's death in a Sydney car crash. The recall, affecting over 2.3 million vehicles since 2009, is the 18th suspected death related to faulty airbags. Takata filed for bankruptcy and agreed to be acquired for $1.6 billion by Key Safety Systems. The investigation comes after the company filed for bankruptcy in the US and Japan.

site_title: US health official saw Coke as fitness ally
summary: US health official Brenda Fitzgerald, newly appointed director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, accepted a $1 million donation from Coca-Cola to fund a child obesity program, despite critics arguing the company is a major contributor to the issue. Fitzgerald's role at the CDC, which previously severed ties with Coke, has sparked backlash from public health advocates. Fitzgerald has defended the program, saying it focuses on exercise and evidence-based strategies, but critics argue the CDC's own research suggests sugar-laden drinks play a significant role in obesity.

site_title: Biggest Philippine manager keeps faith on pricey property stocks
summary: Philippine real-estate stocks are expected to continue their market-beating rally, driven by an accelerating economy, rising remittances, and government incentives. The Philippine Stock Exchange Property Index has climbed 24% this year, with investors becoming more optimistic about President Duterte's pivot to China and the US's trade policies. Key players, such as Fitzgerald Aclan of BDO Unibank Inc., are betting on property stocks, citing attractive potential upside and lower valuations compared to the five-year average. However, challenges such as rising borrowing costs and affordability issues may impact the sector's growth.

images.alt_text: Philippine real-estate stocks will extend a market-beating rally, the country's biggest money manager is betting, unfazed by the most expensive valuation in four years.

site_title: US to drop charges against 2 in London Whale scandal
summary: US federal prosecutors have moved to dismiss all criminal charges against two former JPMorgan Chase employees, Javier Martin-Artajo and Julien Grout, in the London Whale trading scandal, citing doubts over the reliability of key witness Bruno Iksil's testimony. The decision marks another blow to the legacy of former US Attorney Preet Bharara, who was fired by President Trump this year. The charges were filed four years ago in connection with the bank's loss of over $6 billion in derivatives trades.

site_title: A billion Indian identities and more at stake in privacy case
summary: India's top court considers whether privacy is a fundamental right, with implications for the country's biometric identity program, Aadhaar. The program, which has collected data from 1.1 billion citizens, has been challenged by activists, lawyers, and politicians, who argue that personal data should not be stored in a central database. The court will decide if the system should be modified or thrown out, potentially affecting companies like Microsoft and Samsung that have integrated Aadhaar into their products.

images.alt_text: India's top court is considering whether privacy is a fundamental right of every citizen in a case that could have implications for the country's biometric identity program and a slew of global technology companies.

site_title: Football: Man United edges Real Madrid on penalty kicks
summary: Manchester United edged out Real Madrid 4-2 in a penalty shootout after a 1-1 draw in the International Champions Cup tie at Santa Clara. Anthony Martial provided a crucial assist for Jesse Lingard's opening goal, but Real Madrid fought back through Casemiro's penalty in the second half. The match marked a promising start to the season for Manchester United, who were sharper in the first half, while Real Madrid's big names struggled to find their rhythm. The teams will meet again in the European Super Cup final in two weeks.

site_title: White House says open to legislation toughening Russia sanctions
summary: The White House is open to legislation that would toughen sanctions on Russia, following increased momentum in the US Congress for stronger action against Moscow. Two US senators believe the bill could pass with enough votes to override a veto, despite Trump's administration officials arguing against some parts of the bill. The legislation would require Trump to obtain Congress' permission before easing sanctions and limit potential efforts to lift sanctions against Russia.

site_title: Mogherini urges talks to resolve Gulf crisis
summary: European Union foreign affairs chief Federica Mogherini has called for swift direct talks to resolve the Gulf crisis between Qatar and its neighbors. Following a meeting with Emir Sheikh Sabah al-Ahmad Al-Sabah, Mogherini urged all parties to agree on clear principles and a roadmap for a swift resolution. The EU expressed support for Kuwait's mediation efforts and offered assistance in the implementation of a counter-terrorism plan. The crisis began when three Gulf states and Egypt severed ties with Qatar, accusing it of supporting extremist groups.

site_title: Malaysia's PM Najib offers aid to palm oil farmers ahead of election
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has offered financial assistance to palm oil farmers ahead of the election, providing RM5,000 to 94,956 eligible families and debt waivers to those linked to state plantation company Federal Land Development Authority (Felda). The move aims to secure votes from Felda settlers, who are ethnic Malays and a key voter base for Najib's ruling coalition. The decision comes as Najib's party faces opposition from urban Malays who have turned against the government due to scandals.

site_title: Developer interest in Hong Kong's second CBD heating up
summary: Hong Kong's second central business district (CBD), the Kai Tak development area in Kowloon East, is nearing completion and expected to meet soaring demand for office and commercial space by 2021. With rents reaching US$264.27 per square foot, the area is set to become the world's most expensive office market, surpassing Central district. Developers are keenly interested in the area, with record-breaking land transactions and expected significantly higher rents of about HK$65 per sq ft per month. The government aims to sustain Hong Kong's economic growth with the continued supply of land for commercial uses in the area.

site_title: Elderly drivers are wreaking havoc on Japan's roads
summary: Elderly drivers in Japan are causing a surge in fatal accidents, with 459 fatalities involving drivers aged 75 and over in 2016, accounting for 13% of the country's total road deaths. The problem is expected to worsen as Japan's population ages, with one quarter of the population already 65 or older. The government is stepping up efforts to get elderly drivers off the road, introducing new laws requiring cognitive tests for drivers over 75. As a result, up to 15,000 licenses may be revoked annually, and some companies are offering incentives for senior citizens to give up their driving privileges.

site_title: Mission: put onion linked to First Lady's grandpa in White House garden
summary: The Burpee seed company is working to locate the "Raka Red" onion seeds for Melania Trump's White House Kitchen Garden, which is a nod to her Slovenian heritage. The company has been searching for the elusive onion since the beginning of the year, and the seeds are expected to be a "literal piece of home" for the First Lady.

site_title: Asia-Pacific's airports gearing up for growth
summary: Asia-Pacific airports are preparing for growth, with Changi Airport set to receive a boost from the T4 terminal expansion. The region's airports are expected to handle increased passenger traffic. Meanwhile, Tesla has launched operations in India, while FedEx is partnering with a Singapore startup to deploy robots for deliveries. In other news, Delta Air Lines has lifted its travel demand outlook, and Japan's carmakers have reduced export prices to the US to offset tariffs. Additionally, EV battery makers face pressure to cut emissions.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Jihadists take control of major Syrian city
summary: Jihadists from Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS) took control of the Syrian city of Idlib after rival rebels withdrew, strengthening their grip over the northwestern city. A car bomb exploded in Idlib, killing 11 people, including 9 HTS members. HTS, a former Al-Qaeda affiliate, agreed a ceasefire with Ahrar al-Sham rebels, which ended a week of fighting that killed at least 92 people. The fall of Idlib is symbolic, with HTS capturing over 31 towns and villages across the province in the past two days.

site_title: Ill Nigerian president appears in rare photo: presidency
summary: Nigerian President Muhammadu Buhari, who has been receiving medical treatment in London since May, appeared in a rare photo posted on the official Twitter account of the Nigerian presidency. The 74-year-old leader was seen smiling with a group of people, including governors and leaders from his All Progressives Congress party. This photo offers a glimpse into Buhari's condition and his interactions with party officials while in treatment.

site_title: Schlumberger revamps deal for Russian driller
summary: Schlumberger, the world's largest oilfield services provider, has revamped a deal to buy 51% of Eurasia Drilling Co, Russia's biggest drilling company, after a similar plan was scuppered two years ago. The deal, worth US$1.7 billion, will be one of the largest investments by a US company in Russia since sanctions were imposed in 2014. The move is seen as a sign of corporate America's continued interest in Russia's energy sector, despite Washington's sanctions debate.

site_title: China cashing out as mobile payment soars
summary: China's mobile payment market has surged, with the gross merchandise value of third-party mobile payment rising over 200% to 38 trillion yuan in 2016. Mobile payment now accounts for 8% of retail payments, expected to reach 12% by 2020. The use of mobile payment platforms is becoming increasingly popular, with many businesses no longer accepting cash. Analysts forecast that China could become the first cashless society in the next decade, with mobile payment providers expanding into consumer and business credit scoring and short-term lending.

site_title: Baidu, JD.com among those investing in China Unicom: sources
summary: Baidu and JD.com are among major tech firms investing approximately $12 billion in China Unicom's Shanghai-listed unit, with the goal of rejuvenating the state-owned telecom firm. The investment is part of China's mixed-ownership reform drive, which aims to infuse private capital into struggling state-owned enterprises. The move is expected to help China Unicom revamp its business, shift focus to digital services, and invest in 5G technology, with the goal of boosting its competitiveness in the market.

site_title: The Mooch charms in White House debut
summary: New White House communications director Anthony Scaramucci, nicknamed "The Mooch," debuted to the press corps with a polished confidence and charm, contrasting with his predecessor Sean Spicer. Scaramucci praised President Trump's political instincts and humility, while also showcasing his ability to sidestep tough questions and connect with Trump. Despite facing a daunting task in winning over a disapproving public, Scaramucci aims to "close the spread" between public perception and reality. His success will be measured by his ability to devise a strategy to improve Trump's job approval ratings, currently at 36%.

site_title: Major US nursing home chain at risk of receivership
summary: US nursing home chain HCR ManorCare is at risk of receivership after missing a $79.6 million payment for current and past rent to its landlord, Quality Care Properties Inc. The default triggers $265 million in additional overdue rent. Quality Care has delivered a notice of default, allowing it to seek receivership to protect its investment. HCR ManorCare is struggling with declining reimbursements and increasing costs, and the company confirmed ongoing discussions with its landlord. The situation highlights the challenges faced by the US nursing home industry.

site_title: Dollar sinks as politics take a toll
summary: US stocks declined, with the S&P 500 Index falling, as the dollar sank to a 14-month low. The euro reached its highest level against the dollar since January 2015, boosted by European Central Bank president Mario Draghi's comments on unwinding quantitative easing. The euro climbed 0.3% to $1.167, while the yen rose 0.7% to 111.11 dollars. The Bloomberg Dollar Index slid 0.3%, and oil slumped 2.4% after Opec supply increased this month.

site_title: Trump's infrastructure plan falls by the wayside
summary: US President Donald Trump's ambitious infrastructure plan, initially pitched as a $1 trillion campaign pledge, has stalled in the White House. Despite repeated promises, a detailed plan has yet to be produced, and key positions for a new board to green-light big projects remain unfilled. The plan, which aims to use $200 billion in federal spending to attract $800 billion in private investment, faces skepticism from Democrats and centrist Republicans, who question its limited scope. With the budget, debt ceiling, and tax reform all still unresolved, the infrastructure plan's future is uncertain, and time may be running out.

site_title: Corporate intelligence services startup eyes expansion in Asia
summary: Singapore-based startup DC Frontiers plans to expand its corporate intelligence services in Asia, driven by growing ease of creating companies and increasing cross-border trade. The company's Handshakes portal uses artificial intelligence to analyze networks of companies, helping identify conflicts of interest and tender collusion. With plans to expand into more parts of ASEAN and Asia, DC Frontiers aims to serve the whole of Asia, leveraging its expertise in analyzing complex company structures. The company has already expanded its coverage to Malaysia and Hong Kong and has secured a 20% stake investment from Singapore Press Holdings.

site_title: HK's Competition Commission staff quit amid fight for change
summary: Hong Kong's Competition Commission is facing significant challenges amid multiple senior staff departures, just 18 months after the city passed its antitrust law. The regulator is battling to change a culture of price controls and quasi-legal cartels, with companies engaging in price agreements and sharing information. Incoming head Brent Snyder, a former US Justice Department prosecutor, will need to tackle entrenched positions and ensure stability at the commission. Despite some successes, such as complaints from firms discounting rivals, the agency's efforts to change business practices will take time, and staff departures may hinder its ability to investigate and enforce the new rules.

site_title: Obscure coal CEO rains money on Trump while outflanking rivals
summary: Coal CEO Joseph Craft, CEO of Alliance Resource Partners, is bullish on the industry's future despite declining US coal production. Craft sees a return to pro-coal policies under President Trump as reason to believe Alliance can continue growing. He attributes the company's success to its focus on high-sulphur coal, which is still in demand by utilities, and its disciplined operations. Craft has donated $1.3 million to Republican candidates and has been nominated as US ambassador to Canada, highlighting his connections to the Trump administration.

site_title: E-payments in Singapore get a Stripe fillip
summary: Stripe has enabled Internet businesses in Singapore to accept payments via Alipay and WeChat Pay, opening China's massive consumer market to businesses in Singapore and the region. This move allows businesses to tap into the US$5.5 trillion mobile payments sector in China, dominated by Alipay and WeChat Pay. Stripe's addition of Alipay and WeChat Pay also enables businesses to accept recurring payments and charge customers seamlessly. The development aims to connect businesses worldwide with the billion-strong Chinese consumer market, bringing Stripe closer to its goal of building a unified infrastructure for the Internet economy.

images.alt_text: "Some markets have adapted to mobile payments faster than others, and some have leapfrogged credit cards entirely." - Piruze Sabuncu, head of South-east Asia and Hong Kong at Stripe

site_title: "Sorry" - the magic word?
summary: Singapore is considering introducing an apology law to encourage genuine remorse and de-escalate conflicts. Experts argue that an apology law could help businesses communicate authentically, demonstrate duty of care, and restore trust. Proponents believe it could facilitate settlements and align with Singapore's policy to promote mediation. However, some caution that the law may be overly prescriptive and could lead to insincere apologies. The law would not imply guilt or liability, allowing businesses to express regret without fear of automatic liability.

site_title: No-show inflation poses conundrum for US Fed
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to pause interest rate hikes for the next few months to monitor inflation, which remains below the 2% target. Despite seven years of low unemployment, inflationary pressures and wage gains show little sign of life. The Fed faces a conundrum as it waits for signs of inflation to appear, with some policymakers expressing discomfort with plans to increase rates again this year. The central bank is running out of explanations for the lack of inflation, with economists pointing to one-off factors such as lower drug prices and mobile phone costs.

images.alt_text: While the Fed is expected to implement one more rate increase late this year, there are divisions among policymakers on the timing.

site_title: German carmakers face potentially damaging new scandal
summary: European antitrust authorities are investigating allegations that Volkswagen, Daimler, and BMW colluded to hold down prices of key technology, including emissions equipment. If proven, the allegations could further damage Germany's reputation for engineering excellence, following VW's admission of installing software to evade emissions standards. The investigation could have significant consequences for the country's high-end carmakers, potentially leading to further regulatory action and damage to their reputation.

site_title: Giving back to society is this company's pet cause
summary: Pet Lovers Centre (PLC), a Singapore-based pet food and accessories company, has made giving back to society a core part of its mission. Founded in 1973 by brothers Robert and David Ng, the company has grown to become a regional brand with 100 stores across Asia. PLC has established a non-profit arm, the Pet Lovers Foundation, which supports animal welfare groups, adopts out stray animals, and organizes charity drives, including a successful pet food drive and a Common Cause Calendar project that raised S$92,514.70 in 2017. The company encourages its employees to participate in charity initiatives, with 172 staff members volunteering so far.

site_title: FOMC meeting, macro data, corporate results on the radar
summary: US stocks are on traders' radar this week due to the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting, key macro data, and the quarterly reporting season. The Fed is expected to hold interest rates, but its views on inflation and balance sheet reduction will be closely watched. The Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq are near all-time highs, and earnings releases from US and Asian companies will be a key highlight. Moody's Analytics expects South Korean and Taiwanese GDP growth to cool, while Singapore's Straits Times Index added 27 points last week, breaking a two-year psychological mark.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Oil and gas firms cut costs further as recovery falters
summary: Top oil and gas firms are set to cut costs further as the global oil recovery falters, with Brent crude prices averaging below $50 a barrel. Despite a brief rise in January, oil prices have slipped back, and investors are focusing on the ability of major companies like Exxon Mobil, Royal Dutch Shell, and Total to live within their means. The firms have already implemented significant cost-cutting measures since 2014, including shedding jobs and selling assets, and are expected to double their net income on average in the second quarter.

site_title: Computational biologist making waves as hedge fund quant
summary: Computational biologist Desmond Lun, 37, has developed an AI system that beats the market with a 21% average return over the last four years. His models decipher how genes interact and influence each other, then apply this knowledge to financial markets. Lun's system examines tens of thousands of prices from thousands of securities and indices, making it a unique approach to quant trading. Despite skepticism from experts, his firm's US$20 million has outperformed the S&P 500 Index since 2014.

images.alt_text: "It's not that you stick stuff in and have no idea what will come out, we do have parameters," said Mr Lun.

site_title: Global pizza brands battle for Russia's far-flung regions
summary: Global pizza brands Domino's and Papa John's are expanding into Russia's provinces, capitalizing on the growing demand for international food options. Despite past challenges, including bureaucratic delays and limited transportation links, both chains believe they can turn a profit in the regions. Domino's aims to open 1,500 outlets, while Papa John's plans to open 60-80 stores annually over the next five years. The move follows the rise of online card payments and increasing consumer familiarity with foreign brands, with Domino's seeing a 30.1% year-on-year sales growth in Russia.

site_title: India's shadow economy struggles under new GST
summary: India's shadow economy is struggling under the new Goods and Services Tax (GST), with millions of small-time shopkeepers and manufacturers facing higher tax rates. The GST, introduced on July 1, has caused a significant impact on industries such as leather and textiles, with many businesses collapsing due to the 28% tax rate. Analysts expect months of economic chaos, and the GST may have a lasting impact on India's trade balance, raising the chance of a widening trade deficit. The government's previous cash ban and demonetization efforts have also led to economic disruption and job losses.

site_title: House struggles to pass major bills before recess
summary: The US House of Representatives is departing for a five-week summer recess with a lack of major legislative victories, leaving Republican lawmakers with an uncomfortable summer. The chamber is uncertain about passing a $790 billion spending bill, a 2018 budget, or a tax overhaul bill, with President Donald Trump favoring a border wall and a package targeting Iran, Russia, and North Korea. The House Budget Committee has advanced a spending plan, but conservatives and moderates disagree on deep spending cuts, and a tax overhaul framework remains uncertain.

site_title: Ireland setting up fund to manage Apple back taxes
summary: The Irish government is setting up a fund to manage approximately $20.6 billion in back taxes owed to the EU from Apple Inc, following a European Commission ruling that Ireland provided a sweetheart deal on tax to the US firm. The funds will be held in escrow pending appeals, with a custodian and investment managers to be jointly appointed by the government and Apple. This comes after the EU's Competition Commission ruled in August that Ireland gave Apple a special deal on corporation tax, breaking state-aid rules.

site_title: French grape harvest heading for historic low
summary: The French grape harvest is expected to hit a historic low this year, with production 17% lower than in 2016 and 16% below the average of the past five years. The cold spring snap has significantly impacted wine production in regions such as Bordeaux and Alsace. This decline could have long-term effects on the French wine industry, with potential consequences for exports and the economy. The French agriculture ministry has reported the statistics, which are based on data from its statistics bureau Agreste.

site_title: Indian poultry farms are breeding superbugs, study finds
summary: Researchers found that Indian poultry farms are breeding superbugs, including bacteria that produce enzymes resistant to most antibiotics. Random tests on 18 farms in Punjab found that 87% of meat-producing birds and 42% of egg-laying hens carried these "super germs." The study highlights the potential for antibiotic resistance to spread in poultry farming, posing a significant threat to public health.

site_title: Blackstone in talks to buy 40% of Israel cyber firm NSO
summary: Blackstone Group is in talks to pay US$400 million for 40% of Israeli cyber firm NSO Group, maker of spyware for mobile devices. ClearSky is expected to join as a secondary buyer for 10%. An NSO spokesman declined to confirm the report. This deal would value NSO at around US$1 billion, considering its existing ownership structure.

images.alt_text: Blackstone Group is in advanced talks to pay US$400 million for 40 per cent of privately held Israeli firm NSO Group, a maker of spyware for mobile devices, Israel's Calcalist business newspaper reported on Sunday.

site_title: Snail slime boosts US cosmetics trade after taking Korea by storm
summary: US retailers are capitalizing on the growing popularity of K-beauty products, including snail slime, which has taken Korea by storm. American retailers like Target, CVS, and Ulta Beauty are stocking snail slime-based products, with some featuring up to 91% snail secretion filtrate. The products are priced to encourage first-time buyers, with some costing up to $33, and are seen as a way for mainstream retailers to tap into the lucrative beauty market. The trend is expected to continue, with South Korean beauty companies like Amorepacific Corp expanding their US presence.

site_title: EU sounds alarm, urges US to coordinate on Russia sanctions
summary: The European Union has warned the US to coordinate on Russia sanctions, citing concerns that measures discussed in Congress could have "wide and indiscriminate" unintended consequences, notably on energy diversification efforts. The EU is particularly concerned about the impact on its efforts to reduce dependence on Russian energy sources. Germany has already warned of possible retaliation if US sanctions target German firms involved in the Nord Stream 2 pipeline. The EU urges US lawmakers to engage with international partners to ensure coordination and avoid unintended consequences.

site_title: Hundred Palms EC sells out in a day; over 80 units sold at Martin Modern
summary: Hundred Palms EC sold out in one day, with 531 units sold at an average S$836 per square foot, amidst over 2,700 e-applications. The project's strong demand indicates a shift in buying interest from mid-end to EC segment, potentially leading to intense bidding for the next EC land tender. This may also widen the price gap between HDB resales and mass-market condominiums, further stoking demand for ECs.

site_title: Diesel a dirty word? Let's try CNG instead, says Seat chief
summary: Seat's CEO, Luca de Meo, suggests compressed-natural-gas (CNG) as an alternative to diesel, amid declining diesel car sales. De Meo's comments come as the carmaker seeks to diversify its fuel options. The move is seen as a strategic response to the growing negative perception of diesel cars. Seat is reportedly investing in CNG technology to compensate for the decline in diesel sales. The company aims to reduce its dependence on diesel and promote cleaner transportation options.

site_title: Stars aligning for Pacific Star Development
summary: Pacific Star Development, a Singapore-based real estate firm, has turned a profit after two years of losses. The company, which was remade from LH Group, reported a quarterly net profit of S$2.3 million, up from a loss of S$462,000. CEO Glen Chan is optimistic about the company's future, with plans to develop projects in Malaysia, Bangkok, Ho Chi Minh City, and Jakarta. The company's flagship project, Puteri Cove Residences, has won several awards and is expected to generate excitement. Despite concerns about oversupply in Malaysia's southern growth corridor, Chan believes the demand for high-end projects remains strong.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Bullish momentum to continue in short term
summary: US stocks rose slightly last week, fueled by the bull market's momentum. Despite facing risks from politics and economics, including a potentially democracy-rattling Trump presidency, a UK political crisis, and a Korean nuclear threat, investors remain optimistic. The Chicago Board Options Exchange's VIX index hit its lowest level since 1993, indicating low portfolio insurance. Earnings from momentum stocks like Facebook and Alphabet's Google are expected to keep the market momentum going, with Citigroup predicting a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index.

site_title: Headway on Aids threatened by cut in US funding
summary: US President Donald Trump's proposed 2018 budget could lead to a funding shortfall for global health projects, including those combating HIV/AIDS, threatening progress made in the fight against the epidemic. The proposed cuts could deprive 830,000 people, mostly in Africa, of life-saving anti-AIDS drugs, and lead to nearly 200,000 new HIV infections. The US is the biggest contributor to global HIV funding, but Trump's budget would reduce this amount by about $1 billion, leaving many countries reliant on foreign aid.

site_title: In Miami, battling sea level rise may mean surrendering land
summary: Miami is struggling with sea level rise, with flooding becoming a regular occurrence, especially in low-lying areas like Shorecrest. Residents are considering a novel approach to accommodate rising seas by surrendering developed land to nature, involving demolishing properties and relocating people and businesses. The city is investing $500 million in temporary measures, but officials say a long-term solution is needed. A proposal to remove development from Shorecrest and convert properties into parks and retention basins is being considered, with a $275 million funding plan. Climate experts say the consequences of sea level rise are worsening, with the city's flat topography and porous limestone plateau increasing the risk of flooding.

site_title: T4 to give Changi Airport a boost in meeting growing demand
summary: Singapore's Changi Airport is set to receive a boost with the opening of Terminal 4 later this year, serving 9 airlines including AirAsia and Cathay Pacific. The new terminal will add 16 million in passenger capacity per year and feature automated solutions, including fast and seamless travel (Fast) initiatives, which will increase efficiency and reduce manpower by up to 20%. The terminal's design allows for point-to-point operations, making it suitable for low-cost carriers. The addition of Terminal 4 is expected to alleviate air traffic congestion and provide a much-needed capacity boost ahead of the opening of Terminal 5 in the late 2020s.

images.alt_text: Passengers at T4 will be able to check in at a kiosk themselves, drop off their bags at the automated bag drop machine, breeze through the immigration gate and clear the boarding gate.
Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Colt - the new fibre player for enterprise customers in S'pore
summary: Colt, a US-based ICT services provider, is launching a fibre broadband network in Singapore's central business district (CBD) starting October, targeting large enterprises with global connectivity needs. The network will initially connect 54 key buildings and expand to 25-30 more buildings over time. Colt's global network consists of 187,000km of fibre, offering seamless connectivity between Singapore and other cities worldwide. The company claims its services are 30% cheaper than rival operators, attracting 50-60 customers who are seeking end-to-end connectivity. Colt's investment in Singapore is part of a 500 million euro global investment to grow its network.

site_title: Britain buckles up for Brexit; first stop - Heathrow
summary: Britain's aviation sector strategy post-Brexit focuses on enhancing international connectivity, tightening noise and pollution curbs, and improving travel experiences. The plan also aims to safeguard the aerospace manufacturing base, advance the space industry, and encourage new developments like drones and personal "flying taxis." The Department for Transport issued a call for evidence to consider how to utilize spare capacity at other airports, such as Heathrow, before the new strip opens in 2030.

site_title: Toyota eyes mass electric vehicles output in China as early as 2019: report
summary: Toyota is reportedly planning to start mass production of electric vehicles in China as early as 2019, with the first model based on the C-HR sport utility vehicle. The production pace will be determined by regulations and subsidies, with annual output potentially exceeding several thousand units. This move aims to combat air pollution in China, where the government plans to have electric and plug-in hybrid cars make up at least 20% of sales by 2025.

site_title: Linkin Park US tour cancelled after suicide of Chester Bennington
summary: Linkin Park cancels its North American tour due to the sudden death of frontman Chester Bennington, 41, who died by hanging himself at his California home. The tour, set to begin on July 27, has been cancelled with refunds available. Bennington had a history of alcohol and drug abuse and spoke publicly about his struggles. An autopsy and toxicology tests are pending, but no foul play is suspected. The band's statement expresses sadness and offers condolences to those affected.

site_title: Chelsea, Bayern Munich, Inter set to light up Kallang
summary: The International Champions Cup is set to take place in Singapore, featuring top European football clubs Chelsea, Bayern Munich, and Inter Milan. The tournament promises to deliver high-quality football, with Chelsea bringing along stars like N'Golo Kante and Alvaro Morata, Bayern Munich relying on Manuel Neuer and Robert Lewandowski, and Inter Milan packing talent with new signings Milan Skriniar and Mauro Icardi. The matches are expected to be a "must-watch" for local fans, offering a unique opportunity to witness top-class European football in Singapore.

site_title: Latest app coding trend can be a hacker's dream
summary: A new coding trend using containers has made it easier for hackers to steal people's information. Containers, used by companies like Google and Uber, allow data to jump between separate software packages, creating vulnerabilities. Hackers only need to gain access to one container, as administrators may not know what's happening inside. Experts like Sameer Bhalotra, former senior cybersecurity director for Barack Obama, have created startups like StackRox to address this threat. With 25% of large companies using containers and spending expected to double to $2 billion, security risks are becoming a major concern.

site_title: Singapore retailers can move faster to embrace 'new retail'
summary: Singapore retailers can accelerate their adoption of "new retail," a concept that integrates online and offline businesses, by leveraging digital technologies and customer data. Analysts say local companies lack scale but can offer unique online-plus-offline shopping experiences. To succeed, retailers must understand customer needs and adapt to the changing retail landscape, with opportunities for small to medium businesses and large retailers alike. Key players like Qoo10 and GuavaPass are already embracing "new retail," and market experts expect more innovative concepts to emerge.

site_title: Arduous journey ahead for Nam Cheong
summary: Nam Cheong, a Singapore-listed company focused on offshore support vessels, faces an arduous journey in restructuring its debt. To proceed with a scheme of arrangement, the company needs a 75% majority vote from noteholders, who hold $255 million in notes. However, a complete overhaul of its business model is required before it can ride out the downturn in the OSV sector. The company has $770 million in contingent liabilities tied to its build-to-stock program, and it may need to take delivery of some vessels to restructure its bank loans. Noteholders' support is crucial to avoid winding-up proceedings, and experts suggest that all stakeholders must agree to share some pain to ensure the success of the debt restructuring exercise.

site_title: US fines 3 airlines for breaking rules on consumer protection
summary: US fines three airlines, Frontier Airlines, American Airlines, and Delta Air Lines, for violating consumer protection rules. Frontier was fined $400,000 for oversales and disability issues, American Airlines $250,000 for delayed refunds, and Delta $200,000 for inaccurate baggage reports. The fines follow increased scrutiny on airline bumping practices and calls for improved customer service after incidents like the United Airlines passenger dragging. Legislation is proposed to ban bumping already boarded passengers and require refunds for baggage fees.

site_title: Wells Fargo drawing renewed scrutiny after data breach: source
summary: Wells Fargo is facing renewed scrutiny after a lawyer's unauthorized release of sensitive client details for tens of thousands of accounts belonging to wealthy customers of its brokerage unit. The breach occurred when a lawyer was mistakenly provided with the data as part of a lawsuit involving two brothers, one a Wells Fargo employee and the other a former employee. Regulators have started asking questions about the breach, and Wells Fargo is taking steps to investigate and rectify the situation. This latest incident further raises questions about the bank's ability to manage its people and information.

site_title: NY subway derailment causes evacuation, disruptions
summary: A minor derailment occurred on New York's subway system, forcing the evacuation of 135 passengers near Brighton Beach. The incident, which happened shortly before 9am, caused delays and disruptions but resulted in no injuries. This incident comes as the city's 113-year-old subway system faces chronic delays, power cuts, and overcrowding due to decades of underinvestment and deferred maintenance. A replacement bus service was provided for affected passengers.

site_title: Chipotle customer illnesses prove to be magnet for lawsuits
summary: Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc is facing a class action lawsuit by a disgruntled shareholder alleging the company made misleading statements about its ability to keep restaurants clean following a series of food-borne illness outbreaks in 2015. The lawsuit follows recent reports of suspected norovirus cases and rodents at some locations, causing the company's shares to plummet 19% in the past 17 months. The plaintiff claims significant losses and damages resulting from the company's "wrongful acts and omissions."

site_title: When an oligarch owns the empty house next door
summary: A growing number of cities worldwide are experiencing a housing price bubble fueled by foreign investment, particularly from Russian oligarchs, Chinese businessmen, and Brazilian bank accounts. This influx of cash is driving up prices, pushing out local residents, and distorting the market. Foreign investment has surged in cities like New York City, Vancouver, and parts of California, with non-resident foreigners responsible for $153 billion in US housing investments last year. Local governments are struggling to track the cash influx, and experts warn of potential economic threats, including money-laundering and tax evasion. Some cities, like Vancouver, have implemented taxes on foreign home purchases, while others propose alternative solutions, such as a property surtax on high-end homes.

site_title: US gas industry seeks attention as Perry aims to aid coal on the grid
summary: The US natural gas industry is pushing back against potential changes to the power market structure that could favor coal and nuclear producers. Lobbyists argue that natural gas plants are as reliable as coal and nuclear, and can quickly respond to price spikes or wind speed drops. A study by the American Petroleum Institute highlights the flexibility and stability of natural gas fleets, countering the coal industry's claims that coal is more resilient due to its stored fuel. The Energy Department is set to release a study assessing the grid's reliability, which could impact the future of coal and nuclear power plants.

images.alt_text: Coal is more reliable because it sits in piles at the plants whereas natural gas must be delivered by pipelines to the facilities, say coal producers, even as Mr Perry considers whether the US should do more to keep coal and nuclear power plants online.
