images.alt_text: The world's press are gathered at a news conference for Luc Besson's "Valerian and the City of a Thousand Suns" and Dane DeHaan is waxing lyrical about co-star Cara Delevingne.

site_title: Blind 'drivers' try to shape US push for driverless cars
summary: The National Federation of the Blind is lobbying for the inclusion of accessibility features in self-driving cars, aiming to improve travel options for the 1.3 million legally blind people in the US. Following a unanimous vote by the House Energy and Commerce Committee, the industry and technology companies are beginning to address concerns about accessibility. Advocates warn that current regulatory and industry paradigms may limit the blind's ability to use autonomous vehicles, and a coalition of organizations is working to promote inclusive design.

site_title: Trump tells Republicans to get health care done
summary: President Donald Trump urged Republican senators to pass health care reform before their summer break, warning that failure to do so would damage his credibility. Trump made the appeal to a group of 49 senators, saying they should "hammer this out" and not leave town. The latest Republican plan would leave 22 million Americans uninsured by 2026, according to the Congressional Budget Office. Trump's credibility was on the line, with many senators facing pressure from voters to oppose his unpopular plan to overhaul Obamacare.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump made a last-ditch bid to salvage a central campaign pledge Wednesday, deploying a mix of threats and flattery as he told Republican senators to pass health care reform before their summer break.

site_title: US, China fail to agree on trade issues, casting doubt on other issues
summary: The US and China failed to reach an agreement on major trade issues during their annual economic dialogue session in Washington, casting doubt on President Donald Trump's economic and security relations with Beijing. The two sides discussed issues including US access to China's financial services markets, reducing excess Chinese steel capacity, and cutting subsidies for state-owned enterprises, but failed to agree on most major bilateral trade and economic issues. Despite a rare point of consensus on reducing the trade deficit, the session ended without new announcements or a joint statement, fueling concerns about potential steel tariffs and further tensions between the two nations.

site_title: Nam Cheong defaults on S$90m 2017 notes, appoints PwC as restructuring adviser
summary: Nam Cheong, a Malaysian shipping company, has defaulted on a S$90 million 2017 note and temporarily ceased repayment on all borrowings. The company has appointed PwC as its financial adviser to restructure its debt. Nam Cheong has discussions with lenders on restructuring bank facilities, warning that failure to restructure may lead to a going concern issue. The company has S$586 million in outstanding debt from bank loans and bonds.

images.alt_text: The Malaysian shipping company said on Thursday that it has appointed PricewaterhouseCoopers Advisory Services (PwC) as its financial adviser to advise and assist the group on suitable restructuring options.
Angela Tan

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ascott Reit, NetLink NBN Trust
summary: Ascott Reit reported a Q2 distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.84 Singapore cents, down 0.29 cents due to one-off items and the effects of a rights issue and equity placement. Revenue increased 4% to S$123.6 million, driven by additional revenue from new hotel properties. NetLink NBN Trust made its debut on the Singapore Exchange, closing at S$0.81, valued at S$3.1 billion with an annualised distribution yield of 5.43%.

site_title: Pace of British construction activity slows as Brexit delays investment -survey
summary: Britain's construction industry saw a slowdown in growth over the second quarter, with investment delayed due to Brexit uncertainty and the general election. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors reported a net balance of 21% of respondents citing an increase in workload, down from 27% in the previous quarter. Financial constraints, including access to bank finance and cash flow challenges, were cited as the most significant impediments to building activity, with 79% of respondents expressing concern.

site_title: India approves creation of state oil giant in US$4.6b deal
summary: India has approved a $4.6 billion deal to sell a 51.1% stake in state-run refiner Hindustan Petroleum Corp to Oil and Natural Gas Corp (ONGC), creating an Indian oil giant comparable to international rivals. The deal aims to strengthen both companies and add value to shareholders. ONGC Chairman Dinesh Kumar Sarraf stated that the acquisition will make both companies stronger and benefit from synergy. The stake sale is part of India's asset disposal plan, exceeding its goal of raising $4.2 billion last fiscal year.

site_title: Rosenberg says London property prices could fall 10%
summary: London property prices could fall 10% due to the UK's decision to leave the European Union, according to Ralph Rosenberg, head of real estate for KKR & Co. This is partly because the Brexit vote's impact on the economy hasn't been fully reflected in real estate values. Rosenberg also notes that commercial property in London is in flux, with some assets declining in value. However, global demand for real estate remains strong, with investors from South Korea and US pension funds actively bidding for assets.

site_title: NZ's Fletcher Building says CEO stepping down, cuts earnings guidance
summary: New Zealand's Fletcher Building Ltd announced CEO Mark Adamson's departure, citing losses at its building division. The company cut earnings guidance for the second time in four months, expecting NZ$525 million in operating earnings, down from previous NZ$610-$650 million. Share prices plummeted 8% to NZ$7.39, the lowest since March 2016. Construction costs have risen by half in under three years due to New Zealand's economic boom and capacity constraints. Interim CEO Francisco Irazusta will lead the company until a new CEO is appointed.

site_title: US Senator McCain diagnosed with brain cancer: office
summary: US Senator John McCain, 80, has been diagnosed with brain cancer, specifically a glioblastoma, after undergoing surgery to remove a blood clot from above his left eye. Further treatment options, including chemotherapy and radiation, are being reviewed by the senator and his family.

site_title: China border tensions cloud Asia trade pact talks in India
summary: India hosts a meeting of 16 nations in Hyderabad to discuss a mega Asia trade pact, known as the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, amid elevated border tensions between India and China. China urges the 10 members to wrap up the deal as soon as possible, but India's reluctance to cede on its demand for greater market access for professionals has hindered progress. The pact, involving China and Japan, does not include the US, and trade officials are struggling to resolve issues like free movement of people. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, adding pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Tata Group mull streamlining of technology operations
summary: Tata Group, a $100 billion Indian conglomerate, is considering restructuring its technology and infrastructure businesses. The plan would see several technology companies, including Tata Elxsi and Tata Interactive Systems, merged under publicly traded Tata Consultancy Services Ltd. Tata Group may sell smaller units that don't fit its strategy and merge several infrastructure businesses into a single company. The restructuring is at an early stage and no final decision has been made, according to people with knowledge of the matter. Tata Group chairman Natarajan Chandrasekaran is seeking to revamp the conglomerate, which controls a range of businesses from table salt to luxury cars.

site_title: Nafta changes could cost US auto industry jobs, raise car prices: study
summary: A new study by the Motor Equipment Manufacturers Association (Mema) warns that imposing new tariffs on imports from Canada and Mexico under a revised North American Free Trade Agreement could raise new car prices by $1,100 and eliminate up to 50,000 US jobs. The study highlights the potential dangers of such changes and cautions that they would not return jobs to the US.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.1 per cent down on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.1% lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index losing 3.57 points to 3,321.5. About 129.8 million shares changed hands, with Rowsley being the most actively traded counter, rising S$0.018 to S$0.159. Gainers outnumbered losers 89 to 46, as investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Ford's "golden noses" seek edge in slowing China car market
summary: Ford and other automakers are testing materials for a "new car" smell in China, a culturally significant aspect of car ownership in the country. The "golden noses" assessors at Ford's research plant in Nanjing rate the odour of materials from "not perceptible" to "extremely disturbing." Unpleasant smells, such as "burnt tire" or "bad meat," are a top concern for Chinese drivers, ahead of engine issues and fuel consumption. To appeal to consumers, local rivals are offering in-car air filters and other features.

site_title: Ascott Reit's Q2 DPU falls to 1.84 Singapore cents
summary: Ascott Reit reported a 0.29 cent decrease in its Q2 distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.84 Singapore cents, mainly due to one-off items and the effects of a rights issue and equity placement. Revenue for Q2 2017 increased by 4% to S$123.6 million, driven by additional revenue from new properties. The company's H1 DPU was 3.36 Singapore cents, down 0.52 cents from a year ago. Distribution to unitholders for Q2 and H1 2017 increased by 34% and 15%, respectively.

site_title: Billions of tons of plastic trash accumulating on Earth
summary: The world has produced over 9.1 billion tons of plastic trash, with 79% accumulating in landfills or the environment, including oceans. At the current pace, 13 billion tons of plastic waste will be discarded by 2050, equivalent to 35,000 times the weight of the Empire State Building. Most plastics do not biodegrade and can persist for hundreds or thousands of years. Recycling efforts are ineffective due to the non-biodegradable nature of plastics, with only 9% being recycled and 12% incinerated.

site_title: French military chief resigns after row with Macron
summary: French military chief General Pierre de Villiers resigned after a public disagreement with President Emmanuel Macron over budget cuts. Macron had dismissed the general's concerns, saying "I am the boss." The dispute sparked a war of words between the two, with the general refusing to back down on the budget cuts. De Villiers' resignation marks a test of Macron's authority, with the general's comments seen as a challenge to the president's leadership.

site_title: Foreign food chains brave risks for a bite of Iran
summary: Foreign food chains, such as Spain's Telepizza and France's Sushi Shop, have entered the Iranian market despite strict international sanctions and bureaucratic hurdles. The Iranian economy remains challenging, with red tape and limited foreign investment, but the estimated $7 billion spent on restaurants annually presents opportunities for growth. However, the US president's aggressive stance against Iran and ongoing sanctions may deter investors, and some entrepreneurs are taking a cautious approach.

site_title: Dutch paintmaker Akzo's chief quits for health reasons
summary: Akzo Nobel's CEO, Ton Buechner, stepped down due to ill health, leaving the Dutch paintmaker amidst a tumultuous year. He was succeeded by Thierry Vanlancker, head of speciality chemicals, who had joined the company in 2016. Buechner's departure is unrelated to the company's strategy, which includes breaking up its speciality chemicals business to generate more value for shareholders. This move comes after PPG Industries Inc pulled its US$29.5 billion takeover bid in June.

site_title: Diving: Malaysia pips China in 10m platform for historic gold
summary: Malaysia's Cheong Jun Hoong won the country's first-ever diving gold medal at the aquatics world championships in Budapest, taking the top spot with 397.50 points in the women's 10m platform event. China's Si Yajie secured silver with 396.00 points, while Ren Qian of China took bronze with 391.95 points. This historic victory marks a surprise for the Chinese team, who have dominated the event at world championships, winning 22 medals.

site_title: Tech stocks enjoy best day in 10 months as earnings drive European shares higher
summary: European stocks rose 0.7-0.6% on Wednesday, with tech stocks enjoying their best day in 10 months, driven by upbeat earnings from firms like ASML and Ubisoft. The tech sector gained 2.2%, with chipmakers ASM and STMicro following ASML higher. Despite concerns over stretched valuations, the Nasdaq hit a fresh record high, and earnings growth is expected to rise 7.9% in the second quarter.

site_title: NetLink closes at IPO price on first day of trading
summary: NetLink NBN Trust, Singapore's largest IPO, closed its first day of trading at the same offer price of S$0.81. Over 184 million shares worth S$149 million were traded.

site_title: After 17 years, S&P tech index breaks record
summary: The S&P 500 technology index has broken a 17-year record, rising 0.6% to close at 992.29, surpassing its previous peak of 988.49 set in 2000. The sector has led the market in 2017 with a 22% gain, fueled by rallies in tech companies like Apple, Facebook, Microsoft, and Nvidia. This marks the ninth consecutive session of gains for the sector, further solidifying its position as a market leader.

site_title: Borden Company maps bold expansion plans
summary: Borden Company, a Singapore-based firm known for its Eagle Brand medicated oil, has transitioned to professional management after 80 years of family-led management. The new management team aims to structure the group's decision-making process, implement standard operating procedures, and expand into new markets, particularly in developing countries. The company plans to set up an innovation centre to create new products and improve its competitiveness. With a history dating back to 1935, Borden has produced over 100 million bottles of Eagle Brand oil and has received numerous awards for its success.

site_title: What makes a dog man's best friend? It's in the genes
summary: Researchers have identified genetic similarities between dogs that are extremely friendly and people with Williams-Beuren Syndrome, a developmental disorder characterized by hyper-social behavior. Studies of 18 domesticated dogs and 10 captive gray wolves found that changes in two genes, GTF2I and GTF2IRD1, are linked to dog hyper-sociability. These genes also implicated in human Williams-Beuren Syndrome, suggesting that dogs' social behavior may be driven by a genetic condition rather than advanced social cognition. The findings provide new insights into how dogs became domesticated and offer a possible explanation for why dogs became man's best friend.

site_title: Judge halts auction after Madonna objections
summary: A New York judge halted an auction of Madonna's intimate items, including a Tupac Shakur breakup letter, after Madonna objected to the sale, citing a violation of her privacy. The auction house, Gotta Have Rock and Roll, was barred from holding the sale until a hearing in September. Madonna had requested the court's intervention, stating the items were taken without her permission.

site_title: Manulife US Reit completes acquisition of 500 Plaza Drive in New Jersey
summary: Manulife US Reit completed its acquisition of 500 Plaza Drive in New Jersey, expanding its US portfolio to $950.2 million. The 11-storey office building has 98.9% occupancy and a 9.2-year weighted average lease expiry. The acquisition was funded by a private placement of new units, with long-only institutional investors taking up 75% of the offering. The deal brings Manulife US Reit's total units to 728 million and market capitalization to $670 million, with the building's contribution expected to be reflected in the Reit's financial results for the quarter ending Sept 30, 2017.

images.alt_text: Manulife US Reit announced on Thursday that it has completed its maiden acquisition of 500 Plaza Drive in the United States, with the real estate investment trust's (Reit) total portfolio valuation now standing at US$950.2 million.

site_title: Google Glass gets it right the second time
summary: Google Glass, initially released in 2013 as a consumer product, has been revamped for industrial use, known as the Enterprise Edition, which has improved performance and connectivity. The device is being used in factories to boost worker productivity by providing step-by-step instructions, tool selection, and quality control. This unexpected application demonstrates how innovations can have unforeseen uses, and highlights the importance of understanding real-life users of wearables. The failure of initial consumer versions led Google to adopt a more specialized approach, potentially paving the way for future applications beyond the factory floor.

site_title: Choreographer finds a lineage and a bucolic home
summary: Choreographer Adam Weinert is working on a project to recreate the 1938 dance work "Dance of the Ages" by Ted Shawn. Weinert, who was inspired by Shawn's pioneering work, is investigating the past and finding parallels with the present to arrange layers of historical resonance. He has been rehearsing in a rustic building in Hudson, New York, without air-conditioning, and will present the excerpt at Jacob's Pillow, the site of Shawn's former home and dance festival. Weinert's project aims to broaden the conversation on modern dance by incorporating diverse bodies and challenging traditional notions of masculinity.

site_title: US Republicans' latest plan to kill Obamacare looks stillborn
summary: US Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's plan to repeal Obamacare appears to be dead after several Republican senators expressed opposition. The proposal, which included a two-year delay, was met with resistance from senators Susan Collins, Shelley Moore Capito, and Lisa Murkowski, who cited concerns about insurance market instability and the potential for chaos. The White House has invited all Republican senators to a lunch meeting to discuss health care, but it remains unclear what the next steps will be. The failure of the repeal plan is a significant blow to President Donald Trump and Republicans, who have struggled to deliver on their seven-year promise to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act.

site_title: London fire survivors heckle authorities at tense meeting
summary: Survivors of the London Grenfell Tower fire heckled the new leader of the local authority at a tense meeting, criticizing the authorities' handling of the disaster. At least 70 people attended the meeting, where the new chief, Elizabeth Campbell, apologized for the grief and trauma caused by the fire. Survivors continued to express anger and frustration, with one man saying they were "treated like cattle." The recovery operation is expected to take months, and 39 victims have been identified so far, including a five-year-old boy and a stillborn baby.

site_title: Musk says first passengers on SpaceX rockets must be 'brave'
summary: Elon Musk said the first passengers on SpaceX's Falcon Heavy rocket must be "brave" due to the enormous stresses and difficulties in testing the rocket. The company is working to certify the rocket for carrying NASA astronauts and private citizens, with some technical issues remaining. SpaceX is also developing a reusable rocket system, with the goal of reusing the fairing that protects the payload. The company aims to make space travel more efficient and accessible, with the first moon trip around the Falcon Heavy rocket already taking deposits from private citizens.

site_title: US housing starts and permits rebound in June
summary: US housing starts rebounded 8.3% in June to a 1.22 million unit rate, the highest level since February, driven by single-family and multi-family construction. Despite the bounceback, homebuilding remains constrained by rising lumber prices, labour, and land shortages. Single-family homebuilding surged 6.3% and multi-family housing starts increased 13.3%. Building permits also rose 7.4% to a 1.25 million-unit rate. Economists attribute the slowdown to supply bottlenecks, with confidence among homebuilders hitting an eight-month low due to high lumber prices and shortages.

site_title: Qualcomm's profit forecast disappoints as Apple battle takes toll
summary: Qualcomm Inc. forecasted fourth-quarter profit below analysts' estimates due to the escalating patent battle with Apple Inc. The company reported a steep fall in third-quarter profit as Apple's contract manufacturers withheld royalties. Qualcomm forecast adjusted profit of 75-85 cents per share and revenue of $5.4-6.2 billion. The chipmaker's licensing business fell 42.5% to $1.17 billion, while revenue from its chip business rose 5% to $4.05 billion. Qualcomm CEO Steve Mollenkopf stated the company believes it holds the high ground in the dispute.

images.alt_text: Qualcomm Inc forecast fourth-quarter profit below analysts' estimates as the company's escalating patent battle with Apple Inc continues to take a toll on its licensing business.

site_title: Qingjian Realty to launch condo in Bukit Batok
summary: Qingjian Realty is launching its first mixed-use development in Singapore, Le Quest, in Bukit Batok. The 99-year-leasehold project features 516 residential units and 6,000 sqm of retail space. Construction is expected to be completed by November 2021, with estimated average rental prices ranging from S$1,280 per sqft for residential units and no confirmed price for retail space. The developer expects over 40% of retail units to be occupied by food and beverage outlets.

site_title: Divestments hit Keppel T&T's Q2 profit; revenue down 5.1%
summary: Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation (Keppel T&T) reported a net profit of S$10.3 million for its second quarter, 45% less than the previous year, due to lower revenue and higher expenses. Revenue declined 5.1% to S$47.6 million, mainly affected by lower warehousing revenue and the disposal of a data centre stake. The company is building e-commerce capabilities and improving cost efficiencies in its logistics segment. For the half year, net profit fell 32% to S$21.9 million, while revenue dropped 10.3% to S$88.3 million.

site_title: Lloyds to seek London office in cost-saving drive
summary: Lloyds Banking Group is in talks to lease a 100,000 sq ft office space at the 125 London Wall building in the City of London, aiming to consolidate its locations and save 100 million pounds. The bank plans to cut its office portfolio by 30%, resulting in one-time and annual savings, and will modernize its offices to encourage agile working. This move is part of a larger restructuring effort that will cost around 300 million pounds.

site_title: US dollar edges off lows against euro, central banks eyed
summary: The US dollar rose against the euro, but fell against the yen, as traders await meetings of the European Central Bank and the Bank of Japan. The euro was near a one-year high against the dollar, while the yen hit a three-week low. Analysts expect the ECB to adjust its policy language but delay significant details on tapering its asset-purchase program until September. The Bank of Japan's policy meeting also influenced the dollar-yen exchange rate.

site_title: Samsung to manufacture iPhone chips for Apple again in 2018: report
summary: Samsung Electronics will resume manufacturing chips for Apple's new iPhone in 2018, ending a five-year hiatus. The South Korean company was a primary producer of iPhone chips until 2013, when Apple awarded Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) exclusive production rights. The move is reportedly a result of Apple's lawsuit against Samsung in 2011, which reduced the number of components produced by Samsung.

site_title: IBM misses revenue estimates, weighed down by legacy businesses
summary: IBM reported a lower-than-expected quarterly revenue, with total revenue dipping 4.7% to $19.29 billion. The tech giant's shares fell 3% to $149.15. Despite growth in higher-margin businesses like cloud and artificial intelligence services, revenue declines in legacy segments outweighed the gains. IBM backed its forecast for 2017 adjusted earnings, but analysts have expressed concern about the company's aggressive investments in AI. The company expects growth in its "strategic imperatives" to return to a 10-11% range by the end of the year.

site_title: Volvo raises outlook for North America after solid Q2
summary: Volvo raised its forecast for the North American market after a solid second quarter, with order intake rising 22% and beating analyst forecasts. Adjusted operating profit rose to 8.54 billion Swedish kronor, and the company increased its 2017 sales outlook for the North American heavy-truck market to 225,000 trucks. Volvo attributes the strong demand to European markets, including a recovery in Russia, and a gradual improvement in North and South America, with shares jumping nearly 40% this year.

site_title: Growing Sunway Group on a sustainable base
summary: Sunway Group, a Malaysian conglomerate, aims to be the model Asian corporation in sustainable development. Founded by Jeffrey Cheah in the 1970s, the group has expanded into various sectors and now comprises 12 business units, with 80% of its profit coming from Malaysia. Sunway has implemented sustainable practices, such as planting 25,000 trees, and is investing in innovations in urban mobility, education, and building technology. The group has partnered with the United Nations and launched a start-up incubator, Sunway Innovation Labs, to create a Silicon Valley ecosystem. With a growing population in Asia projected to reach 3 billion by 2050, Sunway sees opportunities for expansion in the region.

images.alt_text: 'The diversity of Sunway Group's business units and our established presence in Malaysia has positive implications for our ability to capitalise on the immense potential in Asean.' - Sunway founder and chairman Tan Sri Dr Jeffrey Cheah AO.

site_title: CCT to set aside some divestment gains to shore up H2 DPU
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) plans to use gains from recent divestments to offset losses from the sale of Wilkie Edge and One George Street. Despite the losses, CCT posted improved DPU for Q2 and H1 2017, driven by better performance from CapitaGreen. This helped mitigate negative rent reversions in other assets, providing a positive outcome for the trust. The move aims to shore up distributable income in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: China border tensions cloud Asia trade pact talks in India
summary: India is hosting talks on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) with 16 nations, including China and Japan, amid elevated border tensions between India and China. India is insisting on greater market access for its professionals and mobility for skilled workers, raising concerns among ASEAN nations. China wants a quick end to the deal to establish itself as a leader of world trade, while Japan and New Zealand prefer a high-quality agreement. The talks aim to create a trade pact accounting for 30% of global GDP, but progress is slow due to disagreements on the service sector and trade liberalization.

site_title: Luxury home sales jump in New York's Hamptons
summary: Luxury home sales in New York's Hamptons have surged in the second quarter, with four sales exceeding $20 million, compared to none last year. The sales point to a brighter economy and Wall Street performance, as wealthy individuals take money out of the stock market to invest in hard assets like luxury real estate. The median home price rose 10.1% to $1.1 million, and total sales value jumped 21.7%. The outlook for the rest of the year is expected to be bright, with activity in all markets predicted for the third quarter.

site_title: Bitcoin unstable, too vulnerable to speculation: ECB's Nowotny
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) governing council member Ewald Nowotny warned that bitcoin lacks stability and is too vulnerable to speculation, making it unsuitable as an official payment method. Despite its record high value, bitcoin's value has fallen 20% since June, and its volatility makes it a risk for investors. The ECB is conducting experimental work with blockchain technology, but needs further research before considering adoption. Nowotny's comments come as governments worldwide consider regulating and classifying bitcoin.

images.alt_text: A chain of block erupters used for bitcoin mining. Bitcoin transactions are recorded on thousands of computers across the world that maintain logs and validate transactions - technology known as blockchain.

site_title: Tapping the Asean connection
summary: Asean nations agree that Myanmar's upcoming election is not a priority, with Malaysia stating that it will not intervene in the country's affairs. Meanwhile, China urges Southeast Asian countries to support openness as US tariffs loom, amid concerns over the impact on regional trade. Chinese property shares surge on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. In other news, US weekly jobless claims fall unexpectedly, and Reliance Jio delays its India IPO beyond this year. China also unveils new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: HPH Trust's Q2 profit down 21.5% to HK$269m
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPH Trust) reported a 21.5% year-on-year decline in net profit to HK$269.1 million for the second quarter, mainly due to a loss of HK$24.9 million from associated companies. Revenue fell 1.5% to HK$2.89 billion, and earnings per unit dropped to 3.09 HK cents. The trust cited uncertainties in US policy and the European economic recovery as downside risks, and will maintain cost control disciplines.

site_title: OCBC testing fintech solutions in vetting money laundering
summary: OCBC Bank is testing two fintech solutions from BlackSwan Technologies and Silent Eight to enhance its anti-money laundering and terrorism financing efforts. The solutions utilize artificial intelligence to accelerate the process, increasing analyst productivity by 100%. BlackSwan analyzes suspicious transactions, while Silent Eight automates desktop research by digitally scanning platforms and compiling suspicious dossiers. OCBC aims to increase efficiency and timeliness in investigative research, following a government-industry effort to enhance Singapore's capabilities in combating these threats.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Koh Brothers Development and Heeton Holdings have sold their 50% stake in Buildhome to Central Core for S$41.6 million. The sale price was determined on a willing-buyer, willing-seller basis. Meanwhile, ST Electronics secured S$490 million worth of contracts in the second quarter of 2017. No further details on the sale or contracts were provided.

site_title: US: Wall Street at new highs as tech breaches dot-com era record
summary: US stocks reached record highs on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 tech sector breaking its 2000 record closing high, driven by a 22.8% advance this year. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.31% to 21,640.75, while the Nasdaq Composite added 0.64% to 6,385.04. Tech stocks led the gains, with Vertex jumping 26.4% to an all-time high after reporting positive results for its cystic fibrosis treatment. Despite a drop in IBM shares, analysts expect strong earnings and revenue growth for the S&P 500 companies in the second quarter.

site_title: New York City's biggest foreclosure halted as new creditor emerges
summary: A foreclosure auction for a $83 million NYC penthouse at the One57 luxury tower has been halted after a new creditor, Campion Maverick Inc, filed papers in federal court seeking to recover $83.1 million in unpaid petrol and jet fuel. The creditor claims the owner, linked to a Nigerian businessman accused of bribing a government official, owes the debt. The US Justice Department is also seeking to collect any remaining proceeds, claiming the owner bought the condo with illicit gains from Nigerian crude-oil sales.

site_title: Mapletree to hold student-outreach roadshow
summary: Mapletree Investments, a Singapore-based real estate company, will hold a student-outreach roadshow in VivoCity Singapore on July 28-30. The event, called "Home & Away with Mapletree," will give away fleece jackets to Singapore citizens and permanent residents studying in the UK or about to start tertiary education there. This is part of Mapletree's corporate social responsibility (CSR) program, which aims to build long-term relationships with its community. The roadshow will provide insights into student living in the UK and Mapletree's quality student accommodation portfolio.

site_title: Gold prices buoyed by China, India demand
summary: Gold prices rose to $1,242 an ounce due to demand from China and India, with the two countries accounting for 53% of global consumer demand. The World Gold Council predicts India's demand could reach 900 tonnes by 2020, while China's demand is expected to increase due to improved business conditions and higher wages. The recent price rise is attributed to hedge funds covering short positions, and analysts believe a shift in investor sentiment is needed for prices to reach new heights.

site_title: Huawei partners firms, IMDA to spur innovation
summary: Huawei has partnered with Singapore companies and the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) to spur innovation, with a focus on growing the skilled manpower pool and developing digital infrastructure. The partnership includes memoranda of intent signed with Keppel and Ascent Solutions, with Huawei to offer 45 internship positions and Ascent Solutions to expand its portfolio through a narrow-band Internet of Things (IoT) tracking solution. Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean emphasized the importance of technology innovation in Singapore's development into a knowledge-based economy.

site_title: M1 shares hit by double whammy
summary: M1 shares plummeted 8.8% to S$1.935, down 16.5 cents or 7.9%, after a strategic review by key shareholders ended without a deal. The telco reported a 20.8% drop in second-quarter earnings to S$32.5 million. Revenue rose 4.7% to S$251.6 million despite weak earnings, and analysts predict further downward revisions in consensus earnings and valuation. M1's mobile service revenue fell 2.8% year-on-year, mainly due to over-the-top substitution.

site_title: India's clean energy pledge gives power to country's green bonds
summary: India has set an ambitious target for renewable energy, fueling interest in green bonds issued by companies such as Greenko Energy Holdings, which raised $1 billion, making it the largest corporate green bond issuer in Asia. Indian renewable energy developers face high local currency debt costs and will seek ways to reduce costs, including through overseas markets. As renewable capacity expands, Indian green bonds are expected to increase, driven by growing investor interest.

site_title: Xi's risk-off push ripples through economy as transition nears
summary: China's President Xi Jinping is pushing for a risk-off approach in the economy as he prepares for a leadership transition, targeting corporate acquisitions, returns on wealth-management products, and financial stability. Regulators are clamping down on banks' lending to wealthy consumers, and conglomerate Dalian Wanda Group is under scrutiny for its overseas deals. This move aims to curb financial risks and contain the spread of leverage, but some analysts worry it may not address the real areas of risk, such as bad loans weighing down state-owned companies. The campaign is seen as a "shuffling the deck chairs" approach, with potential risks of triggering a larger problem in China's financial sector.

site_title: Soo Kee ties up with HK's Global Crown to target China bridal market
summary: Soo Kee Group, a Singapore-based jeweller, has entered into a joint venture with Global Crown Group Holding from Hong Kong to target China's bridal market. The two companies will form Diamond Avenue Investments, which will sell diamond products under Soo Kee's Love & Co brand in China and Hong Kong. This deal comes months after Soo Kee expanded into Thailand.

site_title: The winning advantage
summary: Deloitte Southeast Asia, led by CEO Philip Yuen, boasts a competitive edge due to its one-member firm structure and multidisciplinary range of offerings. The firm has over 245,000 professionals and $36.8 billion in revenue, with a focus on advisory and consulting services. Deloitte's unique one-member firm structure, introduced in 2006, enhances efficiency and talent mobility across 11 countries. The firm's consulting business spans technology, strategy, and operations, while its audit services utilize industry knowledge to identify potential issues. Deloitte is also investing in its digital capabilities and SME services, aiming to provide tailored solutions to family-owned businesses and private enterprises.

site_title: Leading medical tourism in South-east Asia
summary: Health Management International (HMI), a Singapore-listed healthcare provider, is expanding its two hospitals in Malaysia and developing holistic healthcare services for the region. HMI's CEO, Chin Wei Jia, aims to enhance its hospitals with new technologies, including PET-CT services and a full emergency specialist centre. The company also plans to double the size of its Regency Specialist Hospital, which will be completed in 2.5 years. HMI's expansion is part of its strategy to stay ahead in the medical industry, driven by its network of 200 specialist doctors and investments in medtech.

site_title: Rowsley soars on Peter Lim's healthcare move
summary: Singapore billionaire Peter Lim's proposed healthcare acquisitions sent Rowsley's shares soaring, with the stock more than doubling to S$0.141. Rowsley plans to purchase 100% of Thomson Medical Pte Ltd and a 70.36% stake in TMC Life Sciences for up to S$1.9 billion, with a sale and purchase agreement expected to be completed within two months. The proposed acquisitions will be financed through 25.3 billion new Rowsley shares at S$0.075 a share, with shareholders set to receive bonus warrants upon completion.

site_title: ShareInvestor unveils Catalist-focused portal
summary: ShareInvestor, a subsidiary of Singapore Press Holdings, is launching a new portal called Investor-One to promote Catalist companies and provide investors with relevant information. The portal will offer live news, interviews, and data on finance, governance, and marketing, and is expected to go live by the end of the year. The development is supported by the Singapore Exchange, Catalist Full Sponsors, and ShareInvestor's own expertise in online investor relations. The portal aims to raise corporate profiles and attract aspiring companies seeking a Catalist listing.

site_title: Reality bites for Trump on Iran and China policies
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration is facing challenges in fulfilling campaign promises, particularly on Iran and China policies. Despite advisors' warnings, Trump has been advised against revoking the Iran nuclear deal, which would have led to a potential new war in the Middle East. Trump has instead certified Iran's compliance with the deal, while also announcing new sanctions targeting Iran's ballistic missile program. Meanwhile, the administration has not imposed punishing steel tariffs on China, instead considering tariffs or quotas on steel imports to protect the American steel industry.

site_title: Making things happen
summary: Huttons, a leading real estate agency in Singapore, reported a double-digit percentage increase in sales of private residential units in the primary and secondary markets for the first five months of the year. CEO GoH Kee Nguan attributes the growth to buyers recognizing that prices won't drop and returning to the market. With over 3,100 agents, Huttons boasts a well-oiled system, rigorous training, and a culture of teamwork, resulting in a higher success rate in concluded deals. The agency aims to be the "Agency of Choice" for developers and clients, offering opportunities for agents to grow and develop their careers.

site_title: A robust tax regime will enable Singapore to attract global capital, investments
summary: Singapore has signed a multilateral tax convention to counter base erosion and profit shifting (BEPS) with 68 other countries. The convention will modify over 2,000 tax treaties and includes internationally accepted standards to defeat tax avoidance schemes. Singapore has also introduced country-by-country (CbC) reporting norms, requiring large multinational corporations to disclose global financial data. The country aims to attract global capital and investments with its robust tax regime, reaffirming its position as a compliant and transparent jurisdiction.

site_title: Gains by banks help equities extend rally
summary: Singapore shares extended their rally for the fifth straight session, driven by gains in banking stocks. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 18.99 points or 0.57% to close at 3,325.07, breaching the 3,300 threshold for the first time in two years. Trading volumes reached 3.6 billion units worth S$1.6 billion, with gainers outnumbering losers 311 to 170.

site_title: IMF's 'taxing' prescription for Asia's infrastructure needs
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has advised Asian governments to raise taxes to afford massive infrastructure investments and public goods, citing that many countries are under-taxed and cheating themselves out of revenue by offering tax breaks to attract foreign investment. IMF deputy managing director Mitsuhiro Furusawa stated that a minimum tax-to-GDP ratio of 15% is necessary for accelerated growth and development, and that many Asian countries fall below this threshold. He suggested strengthening revenue mobilization through measures such as making value-added tax more effective and developing property taxation.

site_title: Car COE premiums edge up
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums for cars rose, with Category A (cars below 1,600 cc and 130 hp) increasing to S$44,002 and Category B (cars above 1,600 cc or 130 hp) rising to S$50,001. Motorcycles premiums slipped, with the decrease attributed to a smaller quota in August. The increases are attributed to the smaller quota, affecting car dealers.

images.alt_text: Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums for cars and commercial vehicles rose, while the premium for motorcycles softened.

site_title: Singapore offers Manila use of drones, urban warfare training facilities
summary: Singapore has offered the Philippines use of its drones and urban warfare training facilities to help combat Islamist militants in the southern city of Marawi. The offer, made by Singapore's Ministry of Defence, aims to prevent the militants from becoming entrenched and threatening the rest of South-east Asia. The Philippines, battling to dislodge militants loyal to ISIS, has seen over 550 people killed in the fighting, which has entered its third month. Singapore's assistance includes a C-130 transport plane to deliver humanitarian supplies.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: First Reit reported an in-line Q2-2017 result, with gross revenue and net property income growing 3.3% and 3.2% year-over-year. OCBC Investment Research maintains a "hold" rating with a target price of S$1.38, citing ample debt headroom for accretive acquisitions. Keppel Reit reported slightly below expectations due to fewer one-off distributions and weaker contribution from Bugis Junction Towers, but maintains a "buy" rating with a target price of S$1.30. M1 Limited's share price may see weakness after its three major shareholders announced they won't sell their stakes.

site_title: Companies view Asean with renewed optimism
summary: Companies are viewing Southeast Asia, particularly Vietnam, as a favorable investment destination due to a growing middle-class population, regional integration, and strong economic growth. Deloitte's Global Manufacturing Competitiveness Index notes that countries like Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, India, and Vietnam are expected to rank among the top 15 in manufacturing competitiveness by 2020. Vietnam's manufacturing labor costs are about half of China's, and its working-age population is projected to expand by 85 million over the next 30 years, providing longer-term competitive advantages over China.

site_title: Darco Water: Relaunched
summary: Darco Water Technologies, a Singapore-based water company, is making a comeback after a setback in 2012. The company, founded by CEO Thye Kim Meng, had a successful run from 2002 to 2010 but was derailed by embezzlement and financial issues. After selling assets and completing loss-making projects, Darco has reversed its loss and recorded a net profit of $4.1 million in 2015. The company has since acquired a stake in a Chinese water treatment specialist and now generates 46% of its revenue from China. Darco is bullish on its prospects in South-east Asia, particularly in Vietnam, and is seeking more funding to expand its business.

site_title: Property-bound Singapore capital now prefers home turf
summary: Singapore's capital flight abroad has slowed, with only 34 outbound investment deals in the first half of 2017, down from 144 in 2016. The property market at home has seen a turnaround, with primary-market property sales and en bloc sales on the rise. The government's measures to cool the market appear to have had a positive effect, and foreign investors are now facing increased tax burdens in countries such as Australia and the UK. This has caused other countries to reassess their investment strategies, with many pumping money into Singapore's sector.

site_title: When wealth managers home in on nationalities ...
summary: Singapore's wealth-management industry is set to resemble a mini-United Nations as nationalities become a key factor in attracting clients. PT Bank Mandiri, Indonesia's largest lender, plans to set up a private-banking outfit in Singapore targeting offshore Indonesian wealth. Meanwhile, Ping An Insurance Group Co's Lufax online wealth-management platform was launched in Singapore, with a focus on serving Chinese nationals with offshore assets. The move is seen as a strategic move to tap into China's growing wealth, with Singapore aiming to compete with Hong Kong as a financial hub.

site_title: 'Atypical' mad cow disease found in Alabama animal: USDA
summary: The US Department of Agriculture announced that an "atypical" case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease, was found in an 11-year-old Alabama cow. The cow was not slaughtered and posed no risk to the food supply. This is the fourth US case of BSE, differing from the "classical" form linked to Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. The USDA concluded that the atypical case will not impact the negligible risk status of US beef exports, and trade partners are unlikely to impose restrictions.

site_title: Australia's big banks rally on 'benign' capital requirements
summary: Australia's big four banks, ANZ, Commonwealth Bank, National Australia Bank, and Westpac, rallied as new capital requirements turned out to be less onerous than expected. The banks need to have Tier-1 capital ratios of at least 10.5% by January 1, 2020, with the average across the banks at 9.85% already close to the target. Analysts consider the new requirements "benign" and predict the banks may meet the target organically without equity raisings or changes to dividends.

site_title: Evergrande has ally against shorts as billionaire Lau invests
summary: Chinese Estates Holdings Ltd, a company controlled by Hong Kong billionaire Joseph Lau, has invested HK$8.1 billion (S$1.4 billion) in Evergrande shares since April, surpassing the 5% threshold, making it the second-largest shareholder. This investment, combined with Evergrande's own share buybacks, helped lift investor confidence and pushed short interest down from 21% to 16% in May. The move also supported Evergrande's stock price, which doubled in the same period, amid a string of purchases of Evergrande's assets by Chinese Estates.

site_title: Lessons from Auditor-General's report must be widely shared
summary: The Auditor-General's report for FY2016/17 highlights significant lapses in public-sector entities, including weaknesses in IT controls, laxity in financial controls, and inadequate oversight of development projects. The report found IT security lapses across multiple entities, delayed payments to vendors, and improper financial transactions. While public-sector entities have committed to rectifying the lapses, there is a need to share and follow lessons from correcting irregularities across the public sector as a whole to prevent repetition and improve management.

site_title: Bold moves forward
summary: ZACD, a Singapore-based wealth and asset management company, is expanding its presence in the Asia-Pacific region with fund management and real estate investment opportunities. The company has established partnerships in countries such as Malaysia and Indonesia, and is exploring investments in Australia and other markets. ZACD's CEO, Kain Sim, aims to capitalize on the region's growing demand for real estate and generate higher returns for investors. The company's integrated services, including project consultancy, asset management, and fund management, will enable it to better manage risks and provide investors with stable yields and attractive internal rates of return.

site_title: China blocks Facebook's WhatsApp in censorship drive
summary: China has blocked Facebook's WhatsApp messaging service, following a censorship crackdown ahead of the 19th Communist Party Congress. The move aims to limit private and encrypted communications, forcing users to adopt WeChat, a highly censored app. The blockage is part of the government's efforts to monitor all internet communication, particularly during sensitive events. Users have resorted to virtual private networks to bypass the block, but the government has cracked down on these tools. The move affects a relatively small number of WhatsApp users in China, who prefer it for being less monitored than WeChat.

images.alt_text: In China, WhatsApp is used by a relatively smaller number of people than Tencent's WeChat, but it is preferred by some because it is deemed to be less closely monitored than its Chinese rival.

site_title: Credit Suisse expands in Saudi Arabia
summary: Credit Suisse is expanding its presence in Saudi Arabia by hiring more relationship managers and establishing a private banking platform. The move comes as the bank seeks to capitalize on the kingdom's expected surge in private wealth, driven by the government's plan to diversify the economy away from oil. Credit Suisse still needs a banking license to open branches in Saudi Arabia, but its investment in the country is seen as a natural progression to build its local footprint. The bank's head of Middle East operations, Bruno Daher, called Saudi Arabia a "key growth market".

site_title: Google Glass reborn for the workplace
summary: Google Glass has been revived for the workplace, with a limited program testing the Glass Enterprise Edition among over 50 businesses, including General Electric, Volkswagen, and Boeing. The program aims to provide workers with wearable devices for information and resources while their hands are busy. After a two-year hiatus, the project was restarted to address feedback from participating businesses. The program's financial details were not disclosed, and the device's customisation process has been ongoing for two years.

site_title: Six months in, Trump's presidency at pivot point
summary: US President Donald Trump's presidency is at a critical juncture six months in, with polls showing him as the most unpopular White House incumbent of the modern era. Trump has achieved little of his campaign promises and faces significant partisan animosity and challenges. The Russia scandal has claimed key figures, and his healthcare efforts have failed. To turn his presidency around, Trump must develop a governing agenda with broad support, use less polarizing rhetoric, and work effectively with Congress to forge a multi-year agenda that brings the country together.

site_title: 5 growth industries picked for job-matching help: Swee Say (Amended)
summary: Singapore is investing in five growth industries - infocommunications & media, wholesale trade, healthcare, financial services, and professional services - to help job-seekers land jobs, with senior officials coordinating efforts. The five sectors are at high risk of disruption.

site_title: Burkina Faso, Ivory Coast to fix rail connection
summary: Burkina Faso and Ivory Coast have signed an agreement to rehabilitate a 1,260-kilometre railway connecting the Sahel and Atlantic coast, with a 400 million euro investment. The rehabilitation work, starting on September 15, will modernize the 1954-era track, which has been in poor condition, limiting train speed. The project aims to increase economic growth between the two countries by transporting 1 million tonnes of minerals over the next four years.

site_title: Coca-Cola opens S$79m storage, distribution centre in Tuas
summary: Coca-Cola has opened a new S$79 million storage and distribution centre in Tuas, Singapore, marking the first warehouse facility in the Asia-Pacific region to use 50% less space than conventional warehouses. The 19-storey facility, completed in March, can store up to 14,000 pallets and reduce storage time by 65%. The centre will support Coca-Cola's businesses in the Asia-Pacific, with plans to develop more beverage options for consumers. The facility is expected to complement the company's existing output and support growth in the region, which comprises 23% of Coca-Cola's unit case volume.

site_title: Malaysia's Aspen launches IPO on Catalist
summary: Malaysia's Aspen (Group) Holdings has launched its initial public offering (IPO) on Singapore Exchange's Catalist board, offering 173.3 million shares at 23 Singapore cents each. The net proceeds of S$36.72 million will be used for land acquisition, loan repayment, and working capital. Aspen's anchored business model focuses on affordability and end-to-end services, in line with the Malaysian government's policies promoting affordable home ownership. The company aims to benefit from the trend with its experience, capabilities, and partnerships, including a 245-acre mixed development in Batu Kawan, Penang.

site_title: DBS prices green bonds at quarterly coupon of 3-mth US$ Libor + 0.62%
summary: DBS Group Holdings successfully priced a US$500 million floating rate green bond with a quarterly coupon of 3-month US$ Libor + 0.62% due in 2022. The bonds will be issued on July 25 and will be used for DBS's finance and treasury activities, including financing green projects. The net proceeds will be allocated towards the funding of Marina Bay Financial Centre Tower 3, a commercial property in Singapore certified Green Mark Platinum. The bond issue was well received, allowing DBS to achieve a compelling pricing level for a five-year benchmark deal.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singaporeans' interest in Australian property wanes
summary: Singaporeans' interest in buying Australian property has decreased, with some attributing it to the abundance of residential options available in their domestic market. According to Julian Sedgwick, head of sales and marketing for Crown Group Australia, Singaporeans are holding back from international purchases due to the availability of suitable properties at home.

site_title: Greenback holds at near 10-month low
summary: The US dollar held near a 10-month low against other currencies, as investors remained cautious before major central bank meetings. The European Central Bank and Bank of Japan meet this week, and market watchers are watching for policy outlooks. The euro fell 0.3% to US$1.1524, while the dollar rose 0.2% to 94.784 against a basket of currencies. The probability of a US rate increase is less than 50% and positioning in the dollar is the most bearish since 2009, suggesting it may be ripe for a reversal.

site_title: US: Nasdaq, S&P open at record highs
summary: The Nasdaq and S&P indices opened at record highs on Wednesday, driven by gains in technology and health stocks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.02%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite added 0.17% and 0.35%, respectively. Investors focused on earnings, despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Building friendships through robotics
summary: At the FIRST Global Challenge competition, hundreds of teens from 157 countries gathered to build robots to sort contaminated water from clean water, fostering friendships and alliances that transcend politics and cultures. The event, founded by inventor Dean Kamen, aims to build a global community of problem-solvers to address the world's most pressing challenges. Despite initial visa denials for teams from Gambia and Afghanistan, the competition brought together unlikely allies from countries with strained relations, such as Team Israel and Team Iran, and even drew a visit from First Daughter Ivanka Trump.

images.alt_text: Team Lebanon members, (from left) Shadi El-Aridi, Wissam Malaeb and Kareem Kawtharani, fixing their robot during the FIRST Global Challenge, an international robotics competition, in Washington, DC.

site_title: Want to escape Sao Paulo's traffic? Take a 30 km flying taxi trip for US$150
summary: A new helicopter taxi service, Voom, has launched in Sao Paulo, offering a 30 km flying taxi trip for US$150, providing an alternative to the city's notorious traffic jams. The service charges by distance and passenger weight, but is weather-dependent. This innovation aims to alleviate traffic congestion, but its limited accessibility may restrict its appeal.

images.alt_text: A new app has opened the sky to commuters in Sao Paulo such as Mr Boyde - Voom, a helicopter taxi service that charges according to distance and the passenger's weight. A new venture launched in April by Europe's Airbus, Voom has taken a page out of Uber's marketing manual offering competitive prices.

site_title: Hong Kong holds memorial for Chinese Nobel laureate Liu
summary: Hundreds gathered in Hong Kong to pay respects to Nobel laureate Liu Xiaobo, a pro-democracy dissident who died in custody last week at 61. Liu, a government critic and Tiananmen Square protests veteran, was sentenced to 11 years in jail in 2009 for "subversion". His death has shocked the world, with many attending the memorial to honor his legacy and advocate for democracy in China. The event comes as Liu's legacy continues to inspire pro-democracy movements worldwide.

site_title: Guangzhou offers incentives to boost home rental as housing supply falls
summary: Guangzhou, a southern Chinese city, has introduced incentives to boost its home rental market amid a year-long property boom. The city offers equal education access, tax cuts, and monetary support to renters, including children of tenants, to encourage them to rent rather than buy. This move aims to support rental supply and reduce housing demand, which has driven up property prices. The city's rental yield has fallen below 2%, making it unattractive for property owners to rent out their apartments, further limiting supply.

site_title: S'pore hotel rates, airfares to take off in 2018
summary: Singapore hotel rates and airfares are expected to rise in 2018, with hotel prices projected to increase 3.2% and airfares rising 3.9%, outpacing the region. Factors contributing to the increase include costlier fuel, fare segmentation, and new long-haul routes. The hotel industry is also expected to see a rebound due to easing supply growth. The Global Travel Forecast report, released by Carlson Wagonlit Travel and the GBTA Foundation, cites strong local economies and emerging markets as key drivers of travel demand.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: China's cyber watchdog orders top tech platforms to increase self-censorship
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration ordered top tech firms, including Tencent Holdings and Baidu, to immediately remove content deemed offensive to the Communist Party and national image. The firms were criticized for distorting Chinese history, spreading fake news, and misinterpreting policy directives. The move comes as part of a wider censorship campaign by President Xi Jinping, who recently introduced new regulations requiring media outlets to be managed by Party-approved editorial staff. The firms must also strengthen auditing systems to avoid future punishment.

images.alt_text: China's top cyber authority ordered the country's top tech firms to carry out "immediate cleaning and rectification" of their platforms to remove content deemed offensive to the Communist Party and the country's national image, it said on Wednesday.

site_title: Triyards' Q3 profit warning raises questions
summary: Tiryards, a yard-operating subsidiary of Ezra Holdings, has issued a profit warning for its third-quarter financial results, citing a material impairment on Houston-based properties. The company's announcement contradicts its previous statements about diversifying its clientele and product offerings beyond oil and gas-related assets, raising questions about its financial stability. Experts suggest that Triyards' exposure to the Ezra group and potential cash flow issues from shipbuilding contracts may be contributing to its woes, despite its efforts to diversify its order book.

site_title: Daimler plans Mercedes fixes on emissions inquiry
summary: Daimler plans to update 3 million Mercedes cars in Europe to reduce diesel emissions, starting in the coming weeks, at a cost of approximately 220 million euros. The move aims to address investigations and public backlash over allegations of evading emissions rules. The software update will broaden the range of temperatures under which emissions controls operate, and is not initially available in the US, where Daimler is also under investigation.

site_title: Japan brokerages' Chinese Wall faces scrutiny
summary: Japanese securities firms face scrutiny after Nomura Holdings Inc found it breached insider rules governing the handling of non-public information. The Japan Securities Dealers Association has pledged to audit its member firms to ensure they train and educate branch managers to prevent the sharing of confidential corporate information. The move comes after a report revealed a former Nomura employee mishandled information about a stock split by a firm that Nomura took public.

site_title: SolarCity co-founder Peter Rive to quit Tesla
summary: Tesla announced that co-founder Peter Rive is leaving the company, eight months after its acquisition of SolarCity. Rive, along with his brother Lyndon, co-founded SolarCity in 2006. The sale of SolarCity for $2.6 billion aimed to create a carbon-free energy and transportation company. Rive's responsibilities, including the development of solar roof tiles, will be reassigned to Tesla's existing engineering teams.

site_title: GSK puts old antibiotics and UK Horlicks business on the block
summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) is considering the sale of its cephalosporins antibiotics business, which has annual sales of around £200 million, and its UK-focused Horlicks business, which has limited sales in Britain but strong demand in India. The company will also sell its MaxiNutrition sports nutrition brand and explore options to divest smaller non-core nutrition brands. The moves aim to simplify operations and focus on priority areas under new CEO Emma Walmsley, who will outline her vision alongside half-year results next week.

site_title: Paytm Mall delists 85,000 sellers to avoid Alibaba's problems with fakes
summary: Paytm Mall has delisted 85,000 sellers from its platform to combat counterfeit goods, leaving 30,000 sellers. The move is aimed at building trust with customers and comes after Alibaba's struggles with fake products. Paytm has made it mandatory for sellers to provide brand authorisation letters, and those without will be removed. The company aims to create a trustworthy e-commerce platform, despite the drastic drop in sellers.

site_title: ECB taken to court over hiring of Draghi's top aide
summary: A staff representative has taken the European Central Bank to court over the hiring of President Mario Draghi's closest adviser, Roland Straub, citing alleged favouritism and lack of transparency in the hiring process. The ECB's Executive Board had not advertised the job, denying others a chance to apply. The case will now be investigated by the General Court of the European Union, highlighting concerns over the ECB's hiring practices and potential favoritism within the institution.

site_title: SoftBank Vision Fund leads US$200m bet on indoor farms
summary: SoftBank Vision Fund has invested $200 million in Silicon Valley startup Plenty, which aims to revolutionize crop production through indoor farming. Founded by Matt Barnard and Nate Storey, Plenty uses 20-foot-tall columns to cultivate crops more efficiently, reducing energy consumption and water usage. The company's innovative approach, which includes using gravity-fed plant food and internet-connected systems, could help boost food production near cities and address global food shortages. SoftBank's investment is seen as a significant boost to vertical farming, a concept that has failed to revolutionize crop production in the past.

site_title: Dalian Wanda amends Sunac property deal after China curbs funding
summary: Dalian Wanda Group amended a deal with Sunac China after Chinese banks scrutinized their credit risk. Wanda will sell 77 hotels to Guangzhou R&F Properties for 19.9 billion yuan and 91% equity in 13 tourism projects to Sunac China for 43.8 billion yuan. The total price is 63.7 billion yuan, the second-largest deal in China's real estate industry. The updated deal reduces Wanda's debt and increases its cash, while Sunac's liquidity and debt level are also improved. Analysts say both companies benefit from the adjusted terms.

site_title: Shakespeare play accused of walking on the grave of England's Richard III
summary: A sold-out performance of Shakespeare's "Richard III" is set to take place at Leicester Cathedral, despite attempts to stop it due to concerns over the play's depiction of the king as a cruel tyrant. The play's defenders argue it was a work of propaganda by the Tudor dynasty, while opponents claim it is an "inappropriate and Christian act" to perform it so close to the king's tomb. The Dean of Leicester Cathedral defended the decision, stating the play will serve as a reminder of the corrupting power of power and the maligned reputation of the good.

site_title: RHT postpones listing; inks Chinese partnership
summary: RHT Holdings, a professional services firm, has postponed its planned listing on the Catalist after inking a partnership with Chinese financial institution Guotai Junan International Asset Management. The firm had initially planned to list in 2017, but now says its long-term view remains to seek a flotation. The partnership aims to expand RHT's services in the region, particularly in Greater China and Hong Kong, and tap into Guotai Junan's significant investor base. RHT's CEO, Jayaprakash Jagateesan, confirms that plans to list are still on the cards, but the company is focusing on growth and expansion in the meantime.

site_title: Young couples to get flats sooner: HDB
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has announced plans to offer Build-To-Order (BTO) flats with a shorter waiting time of approximately 2.5 years. This change is part of two new initiatives: the Re-Offer of Balance Flats (ROF) and the enhanced BTO sales. First-timer families will have priority access to the flats, with at least 95% of four-room and larger flats set aside for them. The first ROF exercise will be held in August, offering unsold balance flats from the November 2016 SBF exercise, and will be held twice-yearly alongside BTO exercises.

site_title: McCormick buys Reckitt Benckiser food unit for US$4.2b
summary: McCormick & Co has agreed to acquire Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc's food business for $4.2 billion, adding French's mustard and Frank's RedHot sauce to the spice giant's lineup. The deal is expected to be completed in the third or fourth quarter of McCormick's fiscal 2017, pending regulatory approvals. With the acquisition, combined pro forma 2017 annual net sales are expected to reach approximately $5 billion, with significant margin growth.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse cultivates local ties after LSE deal setback
summary: Deutsche Boerse, Germany's largest stock exchange, plans to revamp its historic building in Frankfurt to attract more retail investors and improve its image after a proposed merger with the London Stock Exchange collapsed. The changes, including an enhanced viewing gallery and modernized IPO area, aim to rival London as a financial center after Brexit. The company hopes to boost interest in share trading and startups among the German public, with share ownership currently at 14% of the population.

site_title: Asean boom, strong tie-ups fuel E&O's growth
summary: Eastern & Oriental Berhad (E&O) is experiencing growth in the Asean region due to the increasing affluence of the population and the emergence of a middle class. Thirty percent of its foreign buyers are Singaporeans, while 12% are Indonesians. The company attributes the growth to geographical proximity and cultural affinity with these markets. E&O will continue to review its property development and marketing strategy to capitalize on the changing market environment, with Singapore and Indonesia being key focus areas. This growth reflects the region's immense opportunities for property development.

site_title: Koh Brothers, Heeton Land sell off joint venture for S$41.6m
summary: Koh Brothers Group and Heeton Land Pte Ltd sold their 50% stake in joint venture Buildhome Pte Ltd to Central Core Pte Ltd for S$41.6 million. The sale includes the property development The Lumos at 9 Leonie Hill, with 36 units remaining unsold. The disposal is expected to positively impact Koh Brothers' net tangible assets and earnings per share. Central Core's managing director, Koh Keng Siang, has a 25% shareholding interest in the company. The transaction includes a three-year promissory note and refinancing of Buildhome's existing loan.

images.alt_text: Construction and engineering firm Koh Brothers Group, together with another stakeholder, has sold off their joint venture, Buildhome Pte Ltd, for S$41.6 million.

site_title: How the Asian financial crisis reshaped emerging markets
summary: The Asian Financial Crisis of 1998 had a lasting impact on emerging markets, particularly in Asia, with countries like Indonesia, South Korea, Thailand, Malaysia, and the Philippines severely affected by massive currency depreciations. However, over the past two decades, many countries have worked to build resilience to external shocks by increasing external reserve cushions, improving fiscal accounts, and reducing US-dollar liabilities. Indonesia is a prime example, having successfully reduced its external dependencies through structural reforms and withstanding real exogenous shocks, including the 2008 global financial crisis and sharp commodity price declines. Today, several emerging markets have stronger growth and healthier balances than many developed economies, offering undervalued investment opportunities.

site_title: ST Electronics secures S$490m worth of contracts in Q2
summary: ST Electronics secured approximately S$490 million worth of contracts in Q2 2017, primarily in rail electronics, satellite and broadband communications, and advanced electronics and ICT solutions. The rail contracts, valued at around S$131 million, will be completed by 2024. Satellite and broadband communications contracts, totaling S$57 million, will be completed over the next three years.

site_title: Mercedes targets quad-bike loving wealthy with luxury pickup
summary: Mercedes-Benz has introduced its first luxury pickup truck, the X-Class, targeting wealthy clients who enjoy quad biking and sailing. Priced starting at 37,300 euros (S$58,879.6), the X-Class will be available in Europe and other regions, offering two diesel options and a gasoline engine. The company aims to capture the growing demand for mid-sized trucks, which is expected to grow by 43% over the next decade. Despite the risk of entering a new segment, Mercedes sees the X-Class as a workhorse and lifestyle vehicle, and plans to produce the vehicle in cooperation with Renault-Nissan.

site_title: Apple's iPhone manufacturers join legal counter against Qualcomm
summary: Apple and its contract manufacturers, including Compal Electronics, Hon Hai Precision, and Pegatron, are filing counterclaims against Qualcomm, alleging the chipmaker is overcharging them for licensing fees. The manufacturers claim Qualcomm is seeking payments far above normal levels, which could cost the company billions of dollars in refunds and damages. The dispute began when Apple accused Qualcomm of overcharging it billions of dollars for its chips, and now the manufacturers are siding with Apple to avoid being forced to pay excessive fees.

site_title: Rwanda's essential oils offer big profits from little land
summary: Rwanda is leveraging its vast land to cultivate essential oils, generating significant profits despite limited arable land. Nicholas Hitimana, a pioneer in essential oils, has developed high-value crops like geranium, which can yield up to $8,000 per hectare. His company, Ikirezi Natural Products, exports oils to Canada, South Africa, and the US, employing 70 farmers and bringing in $473,000 in revenue last year. Rwanda aims to capitalize on the growing global demand for essential oils, which is forecast to grow by 7% between 2017 and 2022.

site_title: Iran vows to respond to US sanctions violating nuclear deal
summary: Iran's President Hassan Rouhani has vowed to respond to US sanctions that violate the nuclear deal, stating that the Iranian nation will take countersteps if the US implements sanctions. Rouhani said Iran's parliament will approve measures in response to any US congressional legislation. This comes amid escalating tensions between the two countries over the US's decision to withdraw from the nuclear deal.

site_title: Dutch firm TomTom's bet on services business starts paying off
summary: Dutch digital mapping company TomTom beat second-quarter expectations with strong performance from its automotive and licensing businesses, partly offsetting weakness in its consumer products division. The company's adjusted net profit fell 10% to 21.0 million euros due to a drop in consumer product sales. TomTom is betting on higher-margin services, such as map sales and software for self-driving cars, and has nominated SAP executive board member Bernd Leukert to its supervisory board. The company expects combined revenue from its automotive, licensing, and telematics businesses to grow 15% year-over-year in 2017.

images.alt_text: Dutch digital mapping company TomTom beat second quarter expectations as strong performance at its automotives and licensing businesses partly offset weakness in its consumer products division, mainly wearable devices.

site_title: US housing starts, permits rebound in June
summary: US housing starts rebounded 8.3% in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.22 million units, the highest level since February. Single-family homebuilding surged 6.3% to 849,000 units, while multi-family starts increased 13.3% to 366,000 units. Building permits also rose 7.4% to 1.25 million units, driven by single-family home permits up 4.1%. Despite the rebound, economists attribute the slowdown to supply bottlenecks, citing high lumber prices and labor shortages.

site_title: Divestments take Keppel T&T's Q2 profit down 45% to S$10.3m
summary: Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation (Keppel T&T) reported a 45% decline in Q2 net profit to S$10.3m, down from S$18.8m last year, due to weaker logistics revenue and divestments of data centre assets. Revenue fell 5.1% to S$47.6m, primarily affected by the divestments and higher operating expenses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains to eighth day
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for an eighth-straight day on Wednesday, driven by interest from mainland traders concerned about a Beijing crackdown on high-risk dealing. The Hang Seng Index climbed 0.56%, while the Shanghai Composite Index rallied 1.36%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 1.53%. The gains were fueled by hopes for a strong earnings season.

site_title: Morgan Stanley's quarterly profit rises 11.4%
summary: Morgan Stanley reported an 11.4% rise in quarterly profit to $1.59 billion, driven by strong investment banking and wealth management businesses. Earnings per share rose to 87 cents from 75 cents, beating analyst expectations of 76 cents. Investment banking revenue increased 25% to $1.53 billion, while arch-rival Goldman Sachs reported a 40% drop in bond trading revenue.

site_title: Banks may face Kodak-style obsolescence in 5 years
summary: Banks may face obsolescence in 5-15 years due to emerging financial-technology companies, similar to Kodak's downfall, according to former Barclays CEO Antony Jenkins. Traditional banks are already experiencing a transformation, with technology such as smartphones and contactless cards changing the industry. Jenkins described this as an "Uber moment" for the banking industry, where customers discover better alternatives, making the incumbent obsolete. This shift could lead to significant changes in the banking landscape, potentially disrupting traditional banking models.

site_title: Soo Kee taps China's bridal market with Chinese JV partner Global Crown
summary: Soo Kee Group, a Singaporean jeweller, has entered a joint venture with Global Crown Group Holding in China to tap the country's booming bridal market. The venture, Diamond Avenue Investments, will sell Soo Kee's bespoke bridal jewellery brand Love & Co, with plans to set up 550 outlets in China and Hong Kong, aiming for $405.1 million in revenue by the end of five years. The joint venture, backed by Soo Kee's expertise and Global Crown's network, aims to capitalize on China's growing wedding industry, which is expected to rise further.

site_title: British PM welcomes BBC move to publish top earners' salaries
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May welcomes the BBC's decision to publish the salaries of its top earners, citing the importance of tackling the pay gap between male and female workers. May's spokesman praised the move, stating it will help address the issue. The BBC's move comes after pressure from the public to disclose how it uses licence fee funds.
