The move aims to grow readership and serve new groups of readers, particularly among young working professionals.

site_title: EasyJet CEO McCall is said to resign to run broadcaster ITV
summary: EasyJet CEO Carolyn McCall is set to resign to take up the role at ITV Plc, a British broadcaster. McCall informed the airline's board of her decision on Sunday, offering to stay on until the end of the year to facilitate a search for her successor. A search firm will begin the process immediately. No comment was made by EasyJet or ITV representatives.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.22 points to 1,758.22. The market saw 152 gainers compared to 46 losers, with a total trading volume of 71.92 million lots worth RM22.9 million.

site_title: Kicking up a stink: Ukraine's Lviv blighted by trash crisis
summary: Ukraine's western city of Lviv is facing a severe trash crisis, with garbage piling up in streets since May due to a political impasse between the Ukrainian government and the city's authorities. The stench is scaring off tourists and threatening public health, with a rat infestation reported. The crisis is attributed to a "garbage blockade" allegedly imposed by the government to discredit the city's mayor, Andriy Sadovyi. The mayor claims the blockade is preventing the authorities from accepting Lviv's waste, while the government denies it.

images.alt_text: Ukraine's western city of Lviv is famous for its picture-postcard graceful domes and cobblestone streets but it's not such a pretty sight in the back alleys, which are blighted by growing mountains of garbage.

site_title: Japanese markets closed for a holiday
summary: Japanese stock markets were closed on July 17, 2017, due to a holiday. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release. In other news, Popiah king Sam Goi made a mandatory offer for PSC shares at S$0.40 per share. Traders in Asia remained optimistic despite new Trump threats, with stocks extending their rally.

site_title: South Korea proposes military talks with North Korea on July 21
summary: South Korea proposed military talks with North Korea on July 21, the first since 2015, to halt hostile activities near the inter-Korean border. The talks will take place at Tongilgak in Panmunjom, a North Korean building used for previous talks. The proposal comes after a series of missile tests by North Korea and follows President Moon Jae In's statement that dialogue is crucial to curb Pyongyang's nuclear and missile programs. The talks aim to reduce military tension at the military demarcation line.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start week with more gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.76% on Monday, extending a five-day rally, with the Hang Seng Index reaching 26,589.52. This follows a record close on Wall Street. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.08% and 0.47%, respectively. The gains come despite US trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: China property investment, sales quicken in June despite govt curbs
summary: China's real estate investment growth accelerated to 7.9% in June, surpassing May's 7.3% expansion, despite government curbs to tame soaring property prices. The increase in investment is attributed to buyer demand remaining resilient, contradicting expectations. The sector's growth is significant, as it affects over 40 other sectors of the economy. The government's efforts to curb property prices appear to have had a limited impact, suggesting the sector's resilience.

site_title: Developers' sales fall to 820 units in June from 1,039 units in May: URA
summary: Developers sold 820 private homes in June 2017, down from 1,039 in May but up from 536 in June 2016. The preliminary Q2 2017 tally is 3,426 units, exceeding Q1's 2,962 units and last year's Q2 6,388 units. Inclusive of ECs, 1,064 units were sold in June 2017, surpassing June 2016's 768 units. This brings the Q2 2017 EC tally to 992 units.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Hong Kong's cartel cop sees staff exits as it fights for change
summary: Hong Kong's Competition Commission is facing challenges as it enforces the city's first antitrust law, with multiple senior staff departures amid efforts to change a culture of price controls and cartels. The regulator has seen its third chief economist, executive director, and general counsel leave, and will welcome a new chief executive. Despite staff turnover, the agency has taken actions to enforce the new rules, including lawsuits and directing industry organizations to amend their codes of conduct. The regulator is assessing 130 complaints and investigating 12 cases, with lawmakers and industry officials expressing concerns about the time it takes for the new rules to take effect.

site_title: Cosco agrees to buy Orient Overseas for US$6.3b in cash
summary: Cosco Shipping Holdings Ltd has agreed to buy Orient Overseas International Ltd for US$6.3 billion in cash, creating the world's third-largest container shipping line. The deal values Orient Overseas at about US$4.8 billion and will be made through a pre-conditional voluntary general offer. The acquisition, if successful, will help reduce overcapacity and depressed freight rates in the industry. Former Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa's family controls Orient Overseas with about 69% holding, and the company's shares have rallied almost 90% this year.

images.alt_text: China's state-owned Cosco Shipping Holdings Ltd and a unit offered to buy Orient Overseas International Ltd, Hong Kong's biggest container shipping line, to create the world's third-largest box carrier in a deal valued at about US$6.3 billion.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher, STI gains 8.5 points to 3,295.93
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 8.5 points to 3,295.93. Gainers outnumbered losers 153 to 69, and 274.4 million shares were traded with a value of S$242.6 million. This marks the fifth consecutive day of gains ahead of upcoming GDP data.

site_title: Australia military powers beefed up for terror attacks
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull announced enhanced military powers to counter terror attacks, following a review of security responses to local and international incidents. Police will no longer need to exhaust their capacity to call on the army during a terror attack, and special forces will be embedded in law enforcement agencies for better coordination. Defence officials will also provide specialized training to police forces. The changes aim to improve the response to incidents like the 2014 Sydney cafe siege and the recent London terror attack, where police and emergency services responded quickly but were criticized for underestimating the threat.

site_title: AG's Chambers looking into Li Shengwu's Facebook post on Singapore court system
summary: The Attorney-General's Chambers (AGC) in Singapore is investigating a Facebook post by Li Shengwu, son of Lee Hsien Yang and nephew of Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The post, which was later taken down, criticized the Singapore court system and was shared in response to a Wall Street Journal article on the Oxley Road dispute. The AGC's inquiry into the post is ongoing.

site_title: Uber backers said to discuss stock sale to softbank, others
summary: Uber Technologies Inc. shareholders and its board have discussed selling some of their shares to SoftBank Group Corp and other potential investors, amid the company's scandals and troubles this year. Early backers, including Benchmark, want to reduce their stakes, and a potential deal could inject new money into the ride-hailing startup. However, Uber's former CEO Travis Kalanick has opposed allowing early shareholders to sell their stakes, and some investors remain unaware of the effort. The talks come as Uber faces a leadership vacuum and growing competition from Lyft Inc.

site_title: Singapore's June NODX up 8.2% from a year ago
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 8.2% to S$14.7 billion in June 2017, following a flat performance in the previous two months and expansion in the first quarter. On a month-on-month basis, NODX declined 2.7%. Electronic NODX grew 5.4%, while non-electronic NODX increased 9.3%. Total trade rose 7.5% from a year ago, marking the eighth consecutive growth month.

images.alt_text: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose by 8.2 per cent to S$14.7 billion compared to a year ago in June 2017.
Angela Tan

site_title: US-China citizen given 10 years for espionage in Iran: media
summary: A Chinese American citizen, Xiyue Wang, a 37-year-old researcher at Princeton University, has been sentenced to 10 years in prison in Iran for espionage. Wang, born in Beijing, was arrested in 2016 while trying to leave the country and was found to have digitally archived 4,500 pages of Iran's documents. The US State Department confirmed Wang's detention and called for his release, amid tensions between the US and Iran. This conviction comes as the US has taken increasingly harsh positions against Iran, with President Trump vowing to tear up the 2015 nuclear deal.

site_title: Travelers flock to one-way flights as price premium dwindles
summary: Travelers are increasingly purchasing one-way flights as the price premium declines, with 42% of air travel now being one-way, up from 29% three years ago. The price drop is especially pronounced on leisure routes, with the average premium shrinking to $10 from $125. The decline in "fare fences" and rising competition from discount airlines may be contributing to the change. However, one-way fares may incur higher change fees if the full itinerary is changed, making round-trip ticketing a better option in some cases.

site_title: Koda reports rise in gross profit margin after streamlining operations
summary: Koda Limited reported a 4.1 percentage point increase in its gross profit margin to 27.7% in FY2016, attributed to operational restructuring and business strategy changes since the 2008 global financial crisis. The company consolidated production facilities, relocated factories, and disposed of non-core assets, resulting in a net profit of US$1.6 million for the fiscal year ended June 30, 2016. The US market remains a key focus for exports, driven by improving job creation and housing recovery outlooks.

site_title: China Q2 GDP growth likely to cool as Beijing targets property, debt risks
summary: China's economy is expected to report a 6.8% growth rate in Q2, cooling from the previous quarter's 6.9% pace, as policymakers aim to rein in property and debt risks. Authorities have been trying to defuse property bubbles and curb a debt build-up amid fears of a derailment of the world's second-largest economy. Economists predict a gradual slowdown, with some estimating GDP growth at 1.7% quarter-on-quarter, and warn of rising debt levels and potential credit risks.

site_title: Thriving outpost of Japan Inc hums away in dusty Indian town
summary: A Japanese industrial complex in Neemrana, Rajasthan, provides a haven for Japanese corporations, offering uninterrupted power and water supplies, streamlined licence and approval processes, and protection from India's chaotic business landscape. The 1,100-acre complex has created 10,000 factory jobs and is being expanded to another 500-acre plot in Rajasthan and other states. Japanese companies praise the project for allowing them to bypass local officials' demands for bribes and obtaining land at fair prices. The project is seen as a key part of Japan's efforts to tap into India's growing economy and expand its trade presence in South-east Asia and Africa.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corporation, Koda Limited
summary: Keppel Corporation secured two contracts worth over S$20 million for incineration technology and services for waste-to-energy plants in Beijing and Hunan. Koda Limited reported a net profit of US$1.6 million for FY2016, reversing losses in previous years, following operational restructuring and business strategy changes. The companies' shares rose, with Keppel opening at S$6.43 and Koda at S$0.99.

site_title: New Zealand services activity steady in June after May rebound: survey
summary: New Zealand's services sector activity remained steady in June after rebounding in May, according to a survey. The Bank of New Zealand-Business NZ's seasonally adjusted performance of services index (PSI) dipped to 58.6 from 58.8 in May. The reading above 50 indicates expansion in activity, with a robust spread across main sub-indices. This follows a companion survey showing manufacturing activity fell in June after a 16-month high in May.

site_title: Teo Ser Luck named Serial System's deputy chairman
summary: Serial System, an electronic components distributor, appointed Teo Ser Luck, 49, as its non-executive, independent deputy chairman on July 15. Teo, a former minister of state for manpower and trade and industry, joins the company after relinquishing his ministerial portfolio on June 30. He previously served as mayor for the North East District and remains a Member of Parliament for Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC. Serial System's shares rose 0.1 Singapore cent to 18 cents following the appointment.

images.alt_text: Mr Teo relinquished his ministerial portfolio on June 30 but remains an MP for Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC.

site_title: Tennis: Don't laugh! I never dreamed I'd be Wimbledon legend, says Federer
summary: Roger Federer won his eighth Wimbledon title, defeating Marin Cilic in the final, and is now a record eight-time champion. Federer, 35, admitted he never thought he'd achieve this feat and even laughed at the idea. He had been written off after being knocked out of Wimbledon last year, but a strong season, including a fifth Australian Open title, led to his historic win. Federer is also the oldest Wimbledon men's champion of the modern era and plans to defend his title in 2018.

site_title: Keppel unit secures 2 technology solutions contracts for China waste-to-energy plants
summary: Keppel Seghers Belgium NV has secured two contracts worth over S$20 million for two waste-to-energy plants in China, with a combined incineration capacity of 2,220 tonnes per day. The contracts, awarded by Beijing Environmental and Sanitary Group and Yueyang City Construction Investment Group Co Ltd, cover the provision of core equipment, design, and technical services for the plants' furnaces and boilers. Both plants are scheduled for operational completion by 2019, marking Keppel's first WTE project in Hunan province.

site_title: BBC television unveils first female 'Doctor Who'
summary: The BBC has unveiled Jodie Whittaker as the first female Doctor Who, a role she will play as the 13th incarnation of the Time Lord. Whittaker, 35, will take over from Peter Capaldi later this year and has expressed her excitement to challenge stereotypes and push boundaries. The announcement has sparked mixed reactions from fans, with some welcoming the change and others expressing concerns. Whittaker's first appearance will be in the Christmas special, which will see her "regenerate" into the new doctor.

site_title: Debt collecting with charm and persistence
summary: Singapore debt collectors are seeking to clear their name by highlighting their professional and legal operations. Unlike the stereotypical "Ah Longs" or loansharks, debt collectors in Singapore adhere to strict guidelines, prohibiting vandalism, violence, and vulgarities. They operate as a legal entity, ensuring a different set of standards. This move aims to showcase the industry's professionalism and improve public perception.

images.alt_text: Wong Shiying

site_title: Police smash Europe-wide horsemeat racket
summary: A Spanish-led European police investigation has broken up an organized crime group selling "unsuitable" horsemeat across Europe. 65 people, including a Dutch national suspected leader, were arrested in Spain, Belgium, and other countries. The group allegedly modified horse microchips and documentation to pass off the meat as edible. The operation is believed to have earned over $31.5 million per year. The investigation began in 2016 after detecting unusual behavior in horsemeat markets, following a 2013 British horsemeat scandal.

site_title: Venture capitalist's fundraising runs into trouble after sex abuse claims
summary: Venture capitalist Fred Destin's fundraising efforts for a $100 million fund are being scrutinized due to allegations of a 2013 incident involving a young female startup founder at a technology conference in Nantucket, Massachusetts. The woman claims Destin made unwanted advances and touched her without consent, while Destin denies the allegations and claims he apologized to her after learning of the incident. The controversy raises questions about the venture capital industry's handling of similar allegations and its commitment to promoting gender equality.

site_title: YuuZoo to appoint third party to investigate claims
summary: YuuZoo Corporation has announced that it will appoint an independent third party to investigate claims made in six articles published by The Business Times. The company, which received a clean audit from its auditors, has taken steps to ensure the review process is impartial. YuuZoo's executive chairman will step down from his executive position during the review to prevent any claims of executive interference. The findings and recommendations will be reported to Anthony Williams, the company's lead independent director.

site_title: NJ Transit to use record US$505m from capital fund to pay bills
summary: New Jersey Transit is using a record $505 million from its capital fund to cover its operating expenses through mid-2018, continuing a practice of raiding the fund for day-to-day costs. Since 1990, the agency has tapped $7.6 billion from the fund, with 45% of that amount, or $3.4 billion, attributed to Governor Chris Christie's administration. This practice has been criticized, despite the commuter rail system's ongoing delays and crowding issues.

site_title: Einhorn's hedge fund upbeat on Toshiba
summary: Greenlight Capital, a hedge fund firm led by David Einhorn, has taken a new stake in Toshiba Corp, betting on a rise in shares once the company exits money-losing contracts. The firm believes Toshiba can resolve a legal dispute and resolve uncertainties, leading to significant margin and valuation upside. Despite a 4% drop in its aggregate value, Greenlight's main long holdings beat or met earnings expectations. The firm also exited several shorts, including a stake in Liberty Global Plc, and closed decade-long shorts on credit-rating companies.

site_title: Problem robotaxis face: cleaning up customers' mess
summary: Rideshare companies face significant costs associated with cleaning and maintaining vehicles, including vomit, grease, and other forms of filth. Estimated annual costs could range from tens of millions to billions of dollars. Companies like General Motors, Uber, and Lyft are exploring partnerships with rental companies, such as Hertz and Avis, to manage driverless fleets and mitigate these costs. While the potential for robotaxis to revolutionize transportation and reduce costs for consumers is significant, the financial and logistical challenges must be addressed before the industry can achieve its full potential.

site_title: First signs of oil market rebalance showing in NY
summary: US petrol traders have successfully rebalanced the oil market, with mid-Atlantic supplies dropping by over 5 million barrels from year-ago levels. This decline is attributed to East Coast importers being more disciplined in their purchases, mindful of avoiding a supply glut. Total US petrol demand slowed in Q1 2017, but reversed in April, with lower volumes arriving from Europe and smaller domestic supplies to the region. The rebalance is a relief for suppliers ready to shift to winter-grade fuels.

site_title: French FM urges 'de-escalation' in Gulf crisis
summary: French Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian urged "de-escalation" in the Gulf crisis between Qatar and four Arab countries during talks in the UAE and Kuwait. He met with leaders in Abu Dhabi, Kuwait City, and Saudi Arabia, supporting Kuwait as a mediator. Le Drian emphasized the need for constructive negotiations and a regional resolution, stating France does not want to substitute the mediator but rather facilitate efforts. The crisis, which began with Saudi Arabia and its allies imposing sanctions on Qatar, has strained regional relations since 1981.

images.alt_text: French Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian called on Sunday for a "de-escalation" in the row between Qatar and four Arab countries, as he held talks in the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait, a mediator in the crisis.

site_title: Chongqing's former party chief under probe: report
summary: Former Communist Party chief of Chongqing, Sun Zhengcai, is under investigation by authorities, according to The Wall Street Journal. He was replaced by provincial party chief Chen Miner, an associate of President Xi Jinping, at a party meeting in Chongqing. This move comes ahead of a key leadership reshuffle and is seen as a way for Xi to solidify his grip on power. If confirmed, it would be the first probe of a sitting Politburo member since the 2012 downfall of Bo Xilai.

images.alt_text: Mr Sun, 53, was the youngest member of the party's Politburo and was considered a rising star. No details of the probe were given.

site_title: US mom-and-pop stores take on the chains
summary: US mom-and-pop dollar stores are struggling to compete with expanding chains like Dollar Tree and Dollar General, which are taking over neighborhoods with deep discounts and huge selections. To adapt, some stores are focusing on personalized service, offering household staples, and catering to local needs. Despite the challenges, dollar stores are thriving, with national sales reaching $33.8 billion in 2016, and chains like Dollar General and Dollar Tree expanding rapidly. The industry's evolution has made it difficult for small, independent stores to survive, with many facing rising rents and operating costs.

site_title: Advance SCT posts Q2 profit of over S$1m
summary: Advance SCT, a Singapore-based copper supplier, posted a net profit of S$1.01 million for the second quarter of 2017, its first profitable quarter in two years. The company has achieved operational profitability for the first half of 2017 and has generated positive cash flow. Advance SCT has submitted a resumption proposal to the Singapore Exchange and is exploring corporate restructuring initiatives to exit the watch-list before March 2018. The company is also discussing potential acquisitions of profitable businesses in the metal industry.

site_title: Sunpower eyes China's growing market for 'green' services
summary: Sunpower Group, a mainboard-listed company, is expanding its operations in China's growing market for 'green' services. The company has ventured into the construction and operation of centralized steam facilities, which are more environmentally friendly alternatives to small boilers used by local industries. With an estimated investible market of 500 billion yuan by next year, Sunpower aims to secure at least three to five projects annually and have recurring income from the green investment segment account for more than half of total revenue by 2019. The company's superior heat transfer technology and competitive advantage are expected to drive its growth in this segment.

site_title: Two killed in China supermarket knife attack
summary: A 30-year-old man in Shenzhen, China, attacked a Wal-Mart supermarket, killing two and injuring nine with a kitchen knife. The suspect was detained. This incident follows previous violent knife attacks in China, highlighting a rise in violent crime as the country's economy booms and social gaps widen. Experts attribute the increase in violence to stress and mental disorders linked to China's fast-paced lifestyle and inadequate support systems.

images.alt_text: A man armed with a kitchen knife killed two people and wounded nine others in a Wal-Mart supermarket in the southern Chinese city of Shenzhen Sunday night, state media reported.

site_title: Keppel O&M may clinch 2 more FLNG conversions from Golar
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) is set to secure two more floating liquefied natural gas (FLNG) vessel conversion contracts from Golar LNG, each worth over US$700 million. The contracts, part of a three-project agreement, are expected to be awarded in the next two years. Golar's CEO Oscar Spieler stated that the company can underwrite only one FLNG project annually, limiting the scope of the agreement. Keppel O&M, along with its partner Black & Veatch, will undertake the conversions.

site_title: Britain needs phased Brexit to shield economy: finance minister
summary: Britain's finance minister Philip Hammond says a phased Brexit is necessary to shield the economy. Hammond, a proponent of a "soft Brexit," believes a transitional period would allow the UK to replicate existing EU arrangements, minimizing business disruption. The government needs to provide clarity on the future relationship with Europe to restore confidence and keep the economy moving. A transition period is likely to be around two years long, with negotiations on the length and terms to begin in Brussels on Monday.

site_title: Eco-systems a must for developing technologies: ST Electronics head
summary: ST Electronics' president, Ravinder Singh, emphasizes the need for developing industry ecosystems to foster innovation and technology development. The company has established partnerships with various stakeholders, including the Singapore University of Technology and Design, Motorola Solutions, and the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore, to co-develop new technologies and solutions. Singh highlights the importance of smart city capabilities, cybersecurity, and data analytics in driving Singapore's "Smart Nation" initiative, which aims to transform urban challenges such as public transportation, utilities, and security.

site_title: Greece may be heading for bond market test
summary: Greece is expected to return to the bond markets in 2018, but may test the waters with a new bond issue as early as Monday. The country has secured its third bailout program and has made significant progress in balancing its budget, running a surplus of 0.7% in 2016. European officials and creditors are supportive of a market test, citing Ireland, Portugal, and Cyprus as examples of successful returns to the markets. However, some experts caution that it may be premature for Greece to re-enter the bond markets, citing the need for further reforms and economic progress.

site_title: Central banks in danger of misreading markets
summary: Central banks are at risk of misreading markets due to accelerating inflation and rising bond yields. Despite these signals, most central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, and Bank of England, are delaying rate hikes. In contrast, Canada is the only major economy to raise rates recently. Ten-year sovereign bond yields are higher than their 2016 lows, and real inflation-adjusted yields are negative, indicating that bond prices are high and yields too low. This suggests that central bankers are behind the curve, and economies are growing faster than previously thought.

site_title: Former US$2b private equity fund now nearly worthless
summary: A US$2 billion private equity fund managed by EnerVest Ltd is now nearly worthless due to significant losses in the energy sector. The fund, which focused on oil investments, raised and invested over US$1.3 billion in 2013 when oil prices were high. However, with oil prices plummeting to US$46.54 a barrel, the fund's value has decreased drastically. Wells Fargo and other lenders are negotiating to take control of the fund, which will leave clients with at most pennies on the dollar. The fund's co-founder and CEO, John Walker, expressed regret over the outcome.

site_title: Honda seeks refuge from sedan slump with bigger, sportier new Accord
summary: Honda has unveiled a redesigned Accord, a mid-size sedan aimed at revitalizing sales in a declining segment. The new model features a sportier stance, more interior room, and a lower starting price. It will be built on shared underpinnings with the Civic and CR-V, allowing for greater flexibility in production. The Accord will come with two turbocharged four-cylinder powerplants and a gas-electric hybrid, and will be standard-equipped with the Honda Sensing safety system. Honda aims to sell around 320,000 Accords this year, despite a broader decline in mid-size car sales.

site_title: Cash is no longer king
summary: Singaporeans can be encouraged to use cashless payments by making everyday tasks, such as public transport and food purchases, easily transactable with a single device or card. Credit cards, contactless payments, and mobile payments are helping to speed up this process. To promote mobile money, comprehensive processes and a robust financial ecosystem must be coordinated among banks, retailers, and consumers. Businesses can incentivize the use of cashless payments by offering discounts and reintroducing stamp duty on cheques. The government can also provide grants for contactless POS terminals and support small businesses in adopting electronic payments.

site_title: China seen gaining ground on US: report
summary: A new report from the Pew Research Center found that 12 nations, including Canada and Russia, believe China has the world's largest economy, a shift from 6 countries in 2014-2016. The report attributes this change to the aftermath of the Great Recession and the US retreat from the global stage under President Trump. However, many experts are concerned about China's deep-seated economic woes, including rising labor costs and inefficient state firms. The poll also shows a decline in the US's global standing, with only 49% of respondents holding a favorable view of the US, down from 64% in 2014-2016.

site_title: Share buybacks slow; acquisitions outnumber disposals
summary: The Straits Times Index gained 0.2% over five trading sessions from July 7 to July 13, bringing its dividend-inclusive return for the 2017 year to date to 14.1%. Share buybacks slowed, with a total consideration of S$3.70 million, down 70% from the preceding five sessions. More than 50 stocks lodged over 150 changes in interests for directors and substantial shareholders, with a nearly three-to-one ratio of acquisitions to disposals. Notable transactions include Y Ventures Group's trading debut, First Sponsor Group's open-market acquisitions, and Alliance Mineral Assets' seizure and sale of shares to creditor Grande Pacific.

site_title: Opec tries to ride out oil market's perfect storm
summary: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) is facing a challenging oil market due to the rapid emergence of US shale oil and the shift to electric cars. As a result, the price of oil has dropped to less than $50 per barrel, down from a high of $147 in 2007. Opec's mood at the World Petroleum Congress was described as "pensive and sombre" as the cartel struggles to adapt to these changes.

site_title: Facebook finds allies in legal battle against secret government access
summary: Facebook is fighting a court order that prohibits it from informing users when law enforcement investigators ask to search their political communications. The company claims this ban tramples First Amendment protections. The case relates to President Donald Trump's inauguration protests, where over 200 people were detained and charged with felony rioting. Facebook is seeking to notify users about search warrants, arguing that the public is already aware of the investigation and that users should have the opportunity to challenge the warrants. The DC Court of Appeals is considering the case, which has implications for First Amendment rights of Facebook users and others who are politically active online.

site_title: US-China trade talks sputter ahead of 100-day deadline
summary: US-China trade talks have yielded some initial deals ahead of a 100-day deadline, including reopening China's market to US beef and granting access to some financial services. However, significant progress has been slow, with US firms demanding cuts in excess steel and aluminum production, access to China's services market, and removal of national security curbs on high-tech exports. The talks, aimed at reducing the US trade deficit with China, are linked to China's ability to rein in North Korea, which has cast a shadow over the relationship.

site_title: Disaster looms for Asia-Pacific from global warming: report
summary: A report by the Asian Development Bank and the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research warns that unchecked climate change poses "devastating consequences" for Asia-Pacific countries, threatening a 6°C rise in temperature, typhoons, floods, and famine. The report urges urgent measures to counter the impact of global warming, warning of severely curbed economic growth prospects, a reversal of development gains, and a degradation of quality of life in the region unless action is taken.

site_title: UOB raises over S$1m for four charities
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) raised over S$1 million for four Singapore charities through its 11th annual Heartbeat Run/Walk event. Over 7,000 participants, including employees, family members, and customers, contributed to the funds, which will support underprivileged and special needs children and youth. The event is part of UOB's long-term commitment to making a difference in the community through its corporate social responsibility programme.

site_title: Inflation safari - bulls, bears and the elephant in the room
summary: US stocks rose last week amid Federal Reserve Chairman Janet Yellen's comments on interest rates, while some strategists warn of a potential end to the bull market due to low inflation and signs of economic peak. The economy has been experiencing unorthodox growth, with job creation and GDP lagging past cycles, and some economists believe deflationary pressures may outlast inflationary pressures. Analysts expect strong earnings and low interest rates to support the bull market, but a 5% correction is possible if inflation doesn't improve.

site_title: Tech firm compiling blacklist of investors who harass women
summary: A tech firm is creating a blacklist of investors who harass women in Silicon Valley. The company, BT, has an online reporting form for entrepreneurs to report incidents, and is now developing an app to provide reviews of financiers, similar to Yelp or Glassdoor. The move aims to address the growing sexual harassment crisis in the region. BT's effort is seen as a Silicon Valley solution to the problem, utilizing technology to create a platform for victims to share their experiences and hold perpetrators accountable.

site_title: DISA warrants look set to be exercised
summary: A DISA warrant is set to expire on August 2 with only eight trading days left, making it a short-term investment opportunity. The warrant has an exercise price of S$0.007 versus the shares at S$0.015, making it an "in-the-money" warrant. With no premium or discount, holders can exercise the warrant at the current share price. Given the company's history of providing regular disclosure on warrant exercises, it's likely that most outstanding warrants will be exercised when trading ends, providing a fresh cash injection for DISA.

site_title: Is your board future-proof?
summary: Singapore companies must adapt their boards to address emerging challenges, including cybersecurity, digital transformation, and human capital. The current skill sets in demand include digital marketing, customer experience, human capital, and cybersecurity expertise. Women are increasingly being appointed to boards, particularly in the marketing and human capital spaces, and are seen as valuable contributors to the boardroom debate. To remain relevant, boards must develop a skills matrix to identify and recruit directors with the necessary expertise, including those with a background in digital and social media, customer experience, and HR.

site_title: Saying sorry without admitting fault
summary: Hong Kong has become the first Asian jurisdiction to pass a law allowing people to apologize without admitting fault or liability in non-criminal proceedings. The new law, which took effect last week, removes the admissibility of apologies as evidence to determine fault or liability in civil and other non-criminal cases, subject to certain exemptions. The law aims to facilitate dispute resolution by promoting apologies, but critics worry that insincere apologies may become more common and the law may be used to protect administrators rather than resolve conflicts.

site_title: Telegram to close some channels after ban by Indonesia
summary: Telegram will shut down "terrorist-related" public channels in Indonesia after the government blocked access to the platform, citing security concerns. The move follows a resurgence in homegrown radicalism in the country. Indonesia has stepped up cooperation with neighboring countries to combat the growing presence of extremist group Islamic State.

images.alt_text: Encrypted messaging service Telegram will shut down "terrorist-related" public channels, its founder said on Sunday, after Indonesia's government blocked access to the platform, citing security concerns.

site_title: Ecuadorian designers reinvent indigenous style for the modern age
summary: In Ecuador, a new generation of indigenous designers is reviving traditional clothing, reimagining it for the modern age. Led by designers Juana Chicaiza, Lucia Guillin, and Franklin Janeta, these entrepreneurs are promoting cultural pride and challenging Western fashion norms. Their designs, blending traditional ornaments with contemporary styles, have gained popularity, with prices ranging from $150 to $800. This movement aims to strengthen the identity of Ecuador's indigenous population, which makes up 30% of the country's 16.5 million inhabitants.

images.alt_text: A customer checking out a Puruha-style hand-embroidered blouse at a store in Riobamba. Indigenous designers in Ecuador have created a thriving fashion industry of their own.

site_title: Incentivise our footballers at SEA Games
summary: Singapore's football team, known as the Young Lions, are set to face Malaysia in the SEA Games. To boost their morale, the team could be incentivized with a monetary reward if they beat Malaysia or a national prize if they win the gold medal. This could be a motivating factor, considering Singapore has never won the gold medal in the competition and has come close three times since its inception in 1959. The team, which features a mix of experienced and young players, will face Malaysia, hosts of the tournament, and other perennial giants in the group stage.

site_title: Hamilton cuts Vettel's lead to one point
summary: Lewis Hamilton won the British Grand Prix for the fourth consecutive year, securing a 57th career win. His lead over Sebastian Vettel in the championship narrowed to one point after Vettel's late puncture. Vettel finished seventh, while Valtteri Bottas secured the one-two. The result puts Hamilton at 176 points, with Vettel on 177. The win marked Hamilton's first home victory at Silverstone, a circuit he has won five times before, tying him with Jim Clark and Alain Prost.

site_title: Gold hits near 2-week high after US data disappoints
summary: Gold prices jumped 1.4% to a nearly two-week high after weak US inflation data, reaffirming doubts about a US interest rate hike this year. US consumer prices were unchanged in June, and retail sales fell for a second straight month. The weaker dollar boosted gold, making it cheaper for investors holding other currencies. Gold was poised for a weekly gain of 1.3%, its largest since mid-May. The US Federal Reserve's slow interest rate hike is expected to continue.

site_title: Asia under-insured against cyber threats: study
summary: A study by Lloyd's and Cyence found that Asia is under-insured against cyber threats, with estimated losses ranging from $4.6 billion to $53 billion in a hypothetical scenario. Despite this, only 14-17% of losses were insured, and only 7% in another scenario. The report highlights the need for greater awareness and demand for cyber insurance in Asia, particularly in Singapore, where cybercrime is a growing economic concern. The market is expected to grow 10-fold to $500 million by 2025, but the lack of mandatory notification and litigious climate in some countries hinder its growth.

site_title: Human error looms large as possible cause of work site collapse near PIE
summary: A construction site collapse in Singapore's Upper Changi Road East killed one worker and injured 10, with human error likely the cause. Local firm Or Kim Peow (OKP) was casting a viaduct section when it gave way. The incident highlights the importance of safety measures in construction projects.

site_title: Serial System appoints Teo Ser Luck as deputy chairman
summary: Serial System appointed Teo Ser Luck as its non-executive, independent deputy chairman on July 15. Teo, a former Minister of State for Manpower and Mayor, stepped down on June 30. He remains a Member of Parliament for Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC. The appointment follows Teo's term ending on May 26. Serial System, led by Derek Goh Bak Heng, operates in semiconductors and consumer appliances.

site_title: Malaysia, Indonesia may take palm oil issue to WTO
summary: Malaysia and Indonesia plan to raise the prospect of European Union curbs on palm oil imports with the World Trade Organization (WTO), following a resolution calling for the phase-out of unsustainable biodiesel production by 2020. The two countries, major palm oil producers, will meet in July to discuss and coordinate palm oil issues, including organizing a joint mission to Europe. If the EU directive is discriminatory, Malaysia and Indonesia may consider taking the issue to the WTO, amid criticism of palm oil's links to deforestation and haze outbreaks.

site_title: Strengthening Singapore-China ties
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong presented the Business China Awards on July 14, honoring individuals and organizations for their contributions to strengthening Singapore-China ties. The awards, now in its eighth year, recognized Chen Deming for his efforts in promoting bilateral relations, while Lien Ying Chow Legacy Fellowship was awarded for its people-to-people exchange program. The Business China Young Achiever Award went to Lee Chee Koon, CEO of The Ascott Limited, which has seen significant growth in China, becoming one of the leading international serviced residence owner-operators in the country.

site_title: Setting sail
summary: Gold prices rose following US President Trump's announcement of fresh tariffs on Canada and threats to other countries. Oil prices fell due to a bearish outlook under Trump's tariffs. China's solar stocks surged as Beijing attempted to calm price wars. OPEC announced a reduction in oil demand for the next four years. Meanwhile, Aster is reportedly in talks to acquire Exxon Singapore stations, and Chinese tycoons are investing in Indonesia's aluminium industry. These developments have significant implications for global energy markets and trade.

site_title: US$ sinks to 10-month low as Fed-hike bets fade
summary: The US dollar has fallen to a 10-month low due to weaker-than-forecast economic data and fading bets on additional Federal Reserve tightening this year. Analysts predict further dollar decline ahead of the European Central Bank meeting, where ECB President Mario Draghi may signal plans for bond-buying. Hedge funds have increased net-short bets on the dollar, and options markets show a high probability of the euro's strength. The dollar's chances of rising against the euro by year-end have dropped to 4%, down from 40% in January.

site_title: The Greater Bay Area: China's gateway to the world
summary: China is developing the Greater Bay Area (GBA), a region comprising Hong Kong, Macau, and Guangdong province, as a gateway for Chinese companies to expand overseas. The initiative aims to boost economic integration, promote innovation, and rival major bay areas like San Francisco and Tokyo. The GBA will focus on advanced IT industries, manufacturing, and financial services, with four cities - Hong Kong, Macau, Shenzhen, and Guangzhou - driving development. The project is part of China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), which aims to promote globalisation and cooperation within the country.

site_title: Where indoors meets outdoors, and too much is not enough
summary: In the luxury real estate market of the Hamptons, homes are being designed to blur the lines between indoors and outdoors. With features like retractable glass walls, outdoor covered terraces, and screened-in porches, homeowners are creating stylish outdoor rooms that rival indoor spaces. The trend is driven by the desire for more outdoor space, with many Hamptons residents from Manhattan seeking a respite from the city. Architects and designers are responding by incorporating amenities like fireplaces, outdoor showers, and chaise longues into outdoor spaces, creating a seamless transition between indoors and outdoors.

site_title: Debt collecting a brisk business in tough times
summary: Debt collection companies in Singapore are experiencing a significant rise in clients due to the country's slow economic growth. The number of cases received by companies such as Singapore Debt Collection Service and KX-Unit has more than doubled over the past three years. Troubled small businesses, particularly in the construction industry, are driving the growth, with 187 companies wound up in 2016, a 47.2% increase from 2013. Debt collectors are adapting by offering flexible payment plans and investigating cases of investment scams, which have seen a 20% rise in recent years.

images.alt_text: Wong Shiying
Ms Tan (in white), managing director of Vantage Debt Recovery, says there's business for them in good times and bad, as long as there's money owing.

site_title: Are valuations justified by the growth outlook?
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index broke out of a trading range on Friday, closing at 3,287.43 after Global Logistic Properties' takeover offer was announced. The index's breakout may prompt a re-evaluation of charts and raise upside resistance to 3,300. Despite Wall Street's optimism, weak oil prices, geopolitical risk, and possible earnings disappointments could cap prices. The Singapore economy's growth outlook is seen as modest, with forecasts ranging from 2.1% to 3% in 2017, and 1.5% in 2018, according to various analysts.

site_title: Greater accountability for regulators needed: Xi
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has called for greater accountability among financial regulators, stating that regulators must identify and report risks in a timely manner. The central bank will take on a bigger role in managing financial risk and a Financial Stability and Development Committee will be set up under the State Council to oversee the financial sector. Xi also emphasized the importance of financial security to national security, vowing to strengthen the Communist Party's leadership in the financial sector and control new local government debt.

site_title: Halimah Yacob indicates she may run for President
summary: Singaporean Speaker of Parliament Halimah Yacob, 62, has hinted at running for president in the upcoming election, which is reserved for Malay candidates. She said she is considering the role, citing her experience in public service and her commitment to serving Singapore. Halimah, a unionist-turned-politician, has been Speaker of Parliament since 2013 and has been asked by Singaporeans about her potential candidacy. She plans to consult her family and colleagues before making a final decision, and will need to step down as Speaker and MP to contest the election.

images.alt_text: Madam Halimah at a community event in her Marsiling ward on Sunday. To contest, she will have to step down as Speaker of Parliament and MP, and also resign from the PAP.

site_title: Speaker of Parliament Halimah Yacob may run for President
summary: Speaker of Parliament Halimah Yacob has confirmed she is considering running for President in Singapore's upcoming election, which is reserved for Malay candidates. This is her strongest indication yet of her intention to run, following months of speculation. Halimah emphasized the importance of taking the responsibility of the presidency seriously and needs time to think about it.

site_title: Chinese wind power giant wants to be app store of energy world
summary: Envision Energy, a Chinese wind turbine manufacturer, aims to create a global "ecosystem" of energy by connecting solar and wind farms, power plants, and utility companies on a single digital platform. CEO Lei Zhang plans to supply the platform, enabling seamless communication and data exchange among industry stakeholders. Envision has partnered with Microsoft and Accenture to promote digitalization in the energy industry, positioning itself as a key player in the transition to a more efficient and interconnected energy system.

site_title: West, Russia tussle for gas corridors through the Balkans
summary: The West and Russia are competing for control of natural gas transport through the Balkans, a region crucial for Europe's energy security. Russia's Gazprom supplies a third of Europe's gas, but its influence is limited by a lack of infrastructure. The West is backing rival projects, such as the Trans-Adriatic Pipeline (TAP) and the Ionian-Adriatic Pipeline (IAP), to reduce the region's dependence on Russian gas. As the West gains the upper hand, Russia is seeking alternative routes, including the TurkStream pipeline, but its technical demands and geopolitical sensitivities hinder its progress.

images.alt_text: The EU-backed TAP project to bring Azeri gas via Turkey to Greece, Albania and across the Adriatic to Italy could make its first deliveries in 2020.

site_title: Bollywood stars dazzle at Indian film awards
summary: Bollywood stars gathered for the 18th International Indian Film Academy (IIFA) awards in East Rutherford, New Jersey, on July 15, 2017. The ceremony honored films like "Neerja," "Udta Punjab," and "Pink," which won major awards, including Best Picture, Best Actor, and Best Director. The event showcased Indian cinema's growing popularity worldwide, with an estimated 800 million viewers. Bollywood stars and celebrities praised the industry's increasing international presence, with many expressing their desire to further seduce global audiences and promote Indian films globally.

images.alt_text: A closing song-and-dance routine from Bollywood bad boy Salman Khan, which had love-struck women screaming in delight.

site_title: Former China Chongqing party chief under probe
summary: Former China Chongqing party chief Sun Zhengcai, 53, is under investigation by authorities, according to the Wall Street Journal. He was the youngest member of the Communist Party's Politburo and a rising star ahead of a key leadership reshuffle. The investigation, if confirmed, would be the first of a sitting Politburo member since 2012. It comes as President Xi Jinping heads into the second half of his term and embarks on a crackdown on graft, allowing him to amass greater power.

site_title: China's economy slows in second quarter: AFP survey
summary: China's economy expanded by 6.8% in the second quarter, down from a 6.9% increase in the first quarter, according to a survey of 12 analysts. The slowdown is attributed to Beijing's efforts to curb risky lending and investment, which has led to a decrease in debt-fuelled infrastructure and real estate growth. Despite this, policymakers are expected to intervene to ensure a positive economic outcome ahead of a key Communist Party congress later this year, with some economists forecasting a potential GDP growth target of 6.5% for 2017.

site_title: Greece heading for bond market test 'within days'
summary: Greece plans to test its bond market within days, taking advantage of a current positive trend in liquidity levels and risk-taking. The move aims to prepare for its emergence from the bailout program in August 2018. Despite having no immediate need for funding, the Greek government seeks to regain access to the markets. The European Stability Mechanism's support will continue to provide low-rate loans until the end of the program. This test will be part of Greece's global strategy to regain market access.

site_title: Four in a row for Hamilton as blowout hits Vettel
summary: Lewis Hamilton won the British Grand Prix for the fourth consecutive year, dominating the race from pole position. Sebastian Vettel, who needed a podium to narrow the championship lead, suffered a late puncture and finished seventh. Valtteri Bottas secured the one-two with Hamilton, while Kimi Raikkonen finished third. Hamilton became the third driver to win the British Grand Prix five times and the first to take four consecutive victories at Silverstone.

site_title: Trump stance a 'setback' in US-Cuba relations: Raul Castro
summary: Cuba's President Raul Castro criticized US President Donald Trump's hardline stance towards the country, calling it a "setback" in relations. Trump's measures, including banning ties with a military-run tourism firm and tightening rules for Americans traveling to Cuba, were seen as a rollback of his predecessor Barack Obama's rapprochement. Castro denounced the measures as a "toughening of the US embargo" and emphasized Cuba's sovereignty, reaffirming his willingness to engage in "respectful dialogue" and negotiations.

site_title: Treasury is said to seek Wall Street input on overhauling FSOC
summary: The Trump administration is seeking input from Wall Street on overhauling the Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC), a super regulator established to prevent a repeat of the 2008 crisis. Industry groups, including banks and securities firms, argue that the council should stop labeling companies as "systemically important" and make it easier for firms to escape additional oversight. Treasury officials were receptive to the industry's ideas during a closed-door meeting, indicating a potential shift in the council's approach.

site_title: Trump's first Scion hotel delayed for revisions, owner says
summary: The Scion hotel in Cleveland, Mississippi, scheduled to be the first not to bear the name of US President Donald Trump, has been delayed by 5-6 months due to design changes requested by company executives. The changes, requiring new construction permits, were prompted by visits from Trump executives, who made three visits to the site since June. The hotel's opening is now expected in spring 2018, with room rates estimated to be around $150 per night. The delay is not due to financial issues but rather structural and aesthetic changes aimed at repositioning the buildings and creating more open space.

site_title: Update: Honolulu high-rise blaze kills at least three, injures two
summary: A fire at a 36-story condominium tower in Honolulu, Hawaii, killed at least three people and injured two, with smoke inhalation reported. The blaze began on the 26th floor and spread to floors above and below. Over 100 firefighters battled the flames, and emergency responders treated several people, with two hospitalized. The cause of the fire was unknown, and authorities have opened an investigation. Evacuees were accommodated at a nearby park, and a major road in front of the complex was closed due to the incident.

site_title: ISR responds to SGX queries on MOU with Straits Hi-Rel
summary: ISR Capital has responded to queries from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) regarding its MOU with Straits Hi-Rel (SHR) for a potential US$2 million investment. SHR's initial operational costs are estimated at US$3.5 million. The shareholders and directors of SHR are John Dean Ritchie and Yeo Soon Lye, with Ritchie having extensive experience in electronics manufacturing. ISR undertook due diligence before entering the MOU, but details on SHR's operating licence and patent are not disclosed. The MOU was announced on July 11.

site_title: North Korea may have more nuclear bomb material than thought: US think tank
summary: North Korea may have more nuclear bomb material than initially thought, according to a US think tank. Thermal images of the Yongbyon nuclear plant suggest reprocessing of plutonium, potentially increasing its nuclear weapons stockpile. The images also indicate possible operation of centrifuges for enriched uranium and short-term activity at an experimental reactor. This raises concerns for US officials, who view North Korea as a top security threat. The country has tested five nuclear bombs and is working to develop a nuclear-tipped missile capable of hitting the US.

site_title: Australia set to join UN Human Rights Council: report
summary: Australia appears set to join the UN Human Rights Council, following France's withdrawal from the process. Foreign Minister Julie Bishop secured 141 written pledges and 20 verbal commitments from UN members to support Australia's bid. This comes amid criticism of Australia's human rights record, particularly against indigenous people and asylum seekers. Australia's appointment would be its first to the powerful body, which has previously criticized its treatment of indigenous Australians. A decision is expected in October.

site_title: 'Walking Dead' halts production after stuntman dies
summary: Stuntman John Bernecker, 33, died after falling 6.70 meters from a balcony onto concrete while filming for AMC's "The Walking Dead" in Georgia. He missed a safety cushion and tried to break his fall, but died in hospital. Production has been halted temporarily. Bernecker's family has donated his organs, and the actors' union SAG-AFTRA described his death as "heartbreaking" and emphasized the importance of safety on set. An investigation is underway.

site_title: Trump takes travel ban dispute to US Supreme Court again
summary: The US Supreme Court is being asked to block a lower court order requiring the government to give people with grandparents in the US an exemption to enter the country under President Trump's temporary travel ban. The limited travel ban, which took effect June 30, allows people with a "bona fide relationship" to enter, excluding those with grandparents. A federal judge in Hawaii ruled the exemption was too narrow, prompting the Trump administration to take the dispute to the Supreme Court again, seeking to clarify the ruling and block the injunction.

site_title: HK regulator's intervention in company listings is long overdue
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) has started using its power to object to questionable company listings, significantly undermining the city's stock exchange's role in approving initial public offerings. The SFC will now publicly disclose its concerns and take direct action against companies, following a flurry of boom-and-bust equity market scandals. This move may lead to a single strong regulator for the city and could complicate oversight in the short term, putting the SFC on a collision course with the exchange.

site_title: Ashley Madison parent in US$11.2m settlement over data breach
summary: Ruby Corp, owner of Ashley Madison, agreed to a US$11.2 million settlement over the 2015 data breach affecting 37 million users. The settlement, which requires judicial approval, allows users to recoup up to US$3,500 depending on documented losses. The company denied wrongdoing and will pay users' lawyers up to one-third of the payout for legal fees. This settlement comes after a previous US Federal Trade Commission probe resulted in a US$1.66 million payment to settle data security and deceptive practices allegations.

site_title: Oil up 1%, posts weekly gain of 5%
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Friday, with US crude and Brent crude futures increasing by 1% and 49 cents, respectively. This marks a weekly gain of 5.2% for US crude and 4.7% for Brent. The US Energy Information Administration reported a 7.6 million barrel drop in crude inventories, while energy firms added only two oil rigs in the latest week. Global supply remains strong, with output cuts from OPEC stymied by rising output from Libya and Nigeria.

images.alt_text: Oil rose 1 per cent on Friday, boosted as US crude producers added only two rigs in the latest week and on signs of increased Chinese demand, but trading was volatile as global supply remained strong.

site_title: US judge postpones decision in bid to block Toshiba memory unit sale
summary: A US judge has postponed a decision in Western Digital Corp's bid to block Toshiba Corp from selling its flash memory business in a $18 billion deal. The judge proposed requiring Toshiba to give Western Digital two weeks' notice before closing the sale, but the two sides could not agree. Western Digital has called the proposal a "victory," while Toshiba has described it as a "finessed" alternative to issuing a preliminary injunction. The case will be heard again on July 28.

images.alt_text: A US judge did not reach a decision Friday in Western Digital Corp's bid to temporarily block Toshiba Corp from selling its flash memory business in an US$18 billion deal but proposed requiring Toshiba to give Western Digital two weeks' notice before closing.

site_title: Cheung Kong Property plans name change to better reflect strategy
summary: Cheung Kong Property Holdings Limited, owned by Li Ka-shing, plans to change its name to CK Asset Holdings Limited to reflect its strategy in infrastructure investment and aircraft leasing. The company will sell 25% of a Canadian unit for C$714.92 million, which has an unaudited net asset value of C$1.14 billion. The name change aims to better align with its long-term business growth and value creation through property businesses and quality investments.

site_title: Xi confidant and rising Chinese political star promoted
summary: China has named Chen Miner, a trusted confidant of President Xi Jinping, as Communist Party boss in southwestern Chongqing, solidifying his reputation as a favorite of the president. Chen's elevation is seen as a sign of Xi's growing influence ahead of a potential leadership reshuffle at the upcoming party congress. Chen has risen rapidly through the party ranks, previously working under Xi in Zhejiang province and now becoming a key ally in Xi's efforts to shape the country's leadership.

site_title: Blair says UK should keep open the option of staying in EU
summary: Former UK Prime Minister Tony Blair suggests Britain should keep the option of staying in the European Union open during the two-year Brexit negotiation period. He believes this could prevent economic damage and allow for a compromise with the EU. Blair criticizes Jeremy Corbyn's "jobs first" approach to Brexit, calling it a contradiction in terms. He argues that remaining in the single market and customs union is the only way to limit the economic damage of leaving the EU. Blair's comments reiterate his push for a more open-minded approach to Brexit negotiations.

images.alt_text: Former UK Prime Minister Tony Blair said Britain should keep open the option of staying in the European Union so Brexit can be called off if the mood of voters changes during the two-year negotiation period.

site_title: Tennis: Ageless Venus eyes historic title
summary: Venus Williams, 37, is set to become the oldest Grand Slam champion in the Open era at Wimbledon, facing Garbine Muguruza in the final. Williams, who has hit a rich vein of form over the last 12 months, has overcome personal struggles, including a car crash that killed an elderly man, to reach the final. She believes her big game experience will prove decisive, and is seeking advice from her sister Serena, who is absent from the tournament due to pregnancy. Williams aims to cap her remarkable renaissance and earn a sixth Wimbledon title.

site_title: Tennis: Federer wins record 8th Wimbledon as Cilic bid ends in tears
summary: Roger Federer won his record eighth Wimbledon title, defeating Marin Cilic 6-3, 6-1, 6-4. Federer, 35, became Wimbledon's oldest men's champion of the modern era. Cilic broke down in tears after losing the second set 3-0, marking a dramatic end to the match. Federer secured his 19th Grand Slam title, solidifying his position as one of the greatest tennis players in history.

site_title: AT&T to run wireless, media as separate units: source
summary: AT&T plans to run its wireless and media businesses separately following its $85.4 billion acquisition of Time Warner, a source says. The deal gives AT&T control of media assets such as HBO and CNN, and aims to provide content for streaming over its network. AT&T executives will lead the combined company, with John Stankey heading the media division and John Donovan running the wireless business. The merger is expected to close by the end of the year, pending approvals from international agencies and the US Justice Department.

site_title: HSBC is said to ban staff buying stock, bonds on own account
summary: HSBC has instructed approximately 6,000 employees in its global markets division to stop buying single-name securities on their personal accounts, including stocks and bonds. This ban applies to employees managing the bank's own balance sheet, and existing holdings can be maintained while sales must be pre-approved by compliance personnel. The move aims to address conflicts of interest, following similar policies implemented by Goldman Sachs and Deutsche Bank. The bank has also increased its compliance staff to over 6,000 worldwide to improve its anti-financial crime capabilities.

images.alt_text: HSBC Holdings Plc has instructed about 6,000 employees of its global markets division to cease buying single-name securities on their personal accounts, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

site_title: China says Nobel laureate cremated and his wife is "free"
summary: China has cremated Nobel laureate Liu Xiaobo, who died of multiple organ failure on Thursday, and his wife Liu Xia is reportedly "free", according to a government official. Liu Xiaobo, 61, was jailed for 11 years for "inciting subversion of state power" after helping to write a petition calling for political reforms. Rights groups and Western governments have mourned his death and urged authorities to grant freedom of movement to his wife and family, but China has attacked foreign concerns, labeling Liu Xiaobo as a "despised" criminal out of step with Chinese society.

site_title: Uber shareholders discuss stock sale to SoftBank, others: Bloomberg
summary: Uber shareholders and its board have discussed selling shares to SoftBank Group Corp and other investors, Bloomberg reported. The deal may include investment of new money into the startup. Details about the valuation of shares or how much SoftBank or other investors would buy are unclear. This comes after a Wall Street Journal report that Grab, Uber's rival in South-east Asia, is raising up to $2 billion in funding from SoftBank and Didi Chuxing.

site_title: StanChart targets 'silver' dollar with a touch of Sinatra
summary: Standard Chartered Singapore introduces a new retail offering, MyWay, targeting the 'silver' dollar demographic with interest rates of up to 1.28% per annum for deposits of S$5 million. The program includes on-site reading glasses and redesigned marketing material. Clients aged 55 and above can participate in the step-up savings account, offering a unique banking experience.

site_title: Food bonanza
summary: The month of July is marked by a food festival extravaganza in Singapore, with the 24th Singapore Food Festival running until July 30. The festival features various events, including the Singapore Restaurant Festival, which showcases Singapore-inspired dishes until the end of September, and the Specialty & Fine Food Fair Asia 2017, which takes place from July 18-20.

site_title: US lawmaker calls for hearing on Amazon's Whole Foods deal
summary: US Representative David Cicilline has requested a congressional hearing to examine Amazon's $13.7 billion acquisition of Whole Foods Market, citing concerns about the potential impact on consumers and the grocery market. Cicilline argues that the deal could upend neighborhood grocery stores and hardworking consumers. The hearing, which would likely require Republican support, aims to scrutinize the merger before it goes ahead. Antitrust experts expect the deal to win regulatory approval, but critics argue it gives Amazon an unfair advantage over traditional grocers and new players.

site_title: Analysts see short-term DPU pain for CCT unitholders post-disposals
summary: Analysts predict short-term pain for CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) unitholders following a series of property disposals, including the sale of Golden Shoe Carpark to a joint venture. The disposal is expected to impact DPU in the short term, but long-term redevelopment plans for the mixed-use project are seen as a positive development. Despite the short-term concerns, analysts remain optimistic about CCT's prospects.

site_title: Russian-American lobbyist met with Trump Jr, Russian lawyer: NBC News
summary: A Russian-American lobbyist, identified as Rinat Akhmetshin, met with Donald Trump Jr, Jared Kushner, and former campaign adviser Paul Manafort at Trump Tower in June 2016. Akhmetshin, a former Soviet counter-intelligence officer, denied ties to Russian intelligence. The meeting appears to be the most tangible evidence of a connection between Trump's election campaign and Russia, prompting investigations by congressional committees and a federal special counsel. Akhmetshin was present at the meeting, which Trump Jr attended to gather damaging information about Hillary Clinton.

site_title: US issues revised security directive to airlines worldwide
summary: The US Department of Homeland Security has issued a revised security directive to airlines worldwide, clarifying aviation security measures set to take effect on July 19. The directive provides more flexibility and additional time for airlines to obtain explosive trace detection equipment, strengthening global aviation security. The new requirements include enhanced passenger screening, increased security protocols, and expanded canine screening, affecting 325,000 airline passengers on 2,000 daily flights arriving in the US, on 180 airlines from 280 airports in 105 countries.

site_title: One of worst droughts in decades devastates South Europe crops
summary: A severe drought in southern Europe, particularly in Italy and Spain, has devastated crops, with estimated losses of 60-70% in Spain's Castile and Leon region and a 60% drop in Italian olive oil production. The drought has also affected wheat, almonds, and pistachios, with crop revenues insufficient to cover labor costs, leading to significant economic losses for farmers. The EU's wheat exports are expected to rise, but the drought highlights the region's vulnerability to climate change, with some scientists attributing heat waves like this year's to man-made climate change.

site_title: US House backs massive increase in defence spending
summary: The US House of Representatives passed its version of a massive annual defense bill, the National Defense Authorization Act, with a vote of 344-81. The bill authorizes up to $696 billion in spending for the Department of Defense, aligning with President Donald Trump's desire for a bigger military. Despite some Republican opposition, the measure passed with bipartisan support, with 117 Democrats joining 227 Republicans in backing the bill.

site_title: OKP calls for trading halt after worksite accident
summary: A construction firm, OKP Holdings, has halted trading after a fatal accident at one of its worksites in Singapore. One worker died and 10 others were injured when a viaduct under construction collapsed early Friday morning. Investigations are ongoing, with the Land Transport Authority, Ministry of Manpower, and Building & Construction Authority involved. The company will cooperate fully with the authorities and ensure the needs of the affected workers are met.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Dynamic denim
summary: Denim is being reimagined as a stylish and practical workwear option for the pre-fall season. Designers such as Karen Walker, Ulla Johnson, Stella McCartney, and Max Mara have created denim suits and separates that are both fashionable and office-friendly. The trend is seen in tailored silhouettes, such as dresses and coats, that can be easily dressed up or down. Denim's evolution from a workman's uniform to a corporate wear staple is a testament to its versatility and enduring appeal.

site_title: "Hard works starts now": Brexit bargaining to begin
summary: EU officials and British negotiators are set to begin full talks on Brexit on Monday, with EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier warning that "the hard work starts now" as the UK's departure looms in March 2019. The talks aim to settle key issues such as expatriate citizens' rights, EU budget contributions, and the new border, with a withdrawal treaty expected by October next year. If no progress is made, EU leaders may block talks on a free trade relationship, and the EU is unhappy with the UK's refusal to accept EU judges as arbiters of disputes.

site_title: Europe: Strongest week since May for European shares as Fed tone spurs relief
summary: European shares experienced their strongest week since May, driven by a positive tone from the Federal Reserve and relief that monetary policy tightening would not be accelerated. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.1% on Friday, while euro zone bluechips fell 0.2%. Gains were seen in mining stocks, led by steel firms, and banking stocks benefited from low yields. However, US banks' disappointing earnings reports and slower US inflation raised concerns about the Fed's plans.

site_title: Weak US inflation, retail sales data dim rate hike prospects
summary: US consumer prices remained unchanged in June, while retail sales fell for a second consecutive month, indicating tame inflation and soft domestic demand. Industrial production picked up in June, driven by a surge in oil and gas drilling. This data suggests the Federal Reserve may go slowly in normalizing interest rates, but businesses will need to find ways to sustain strong earnings growth.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hotel Properties Limited has formed a joint venture with Anchorage View Pte Ltd to acquire a hotel operation in West London for £39.4 million (S$70.2 million). Marco Polo Marine and its subsidiary have been granted moratoriums until end-August to finalise a plan with creditors. China Jinjiang Environment Holding Company has secured its third overseas waste treatment project in India, with an estimated investment of S$83 million, on a build-operate-transfer model for 20 years.

site_title: US 30-year mortgage rates hit 2-month high
summary: US 30-year mortgage rates reached a 2-month high of 4.03% in the week ended July 13, according to Freddie Mac. This marks the highest level since 4.05% in May 11. The rise in mortgage rates led to a decline in mortgage application activity, with the lowest level in nearly five months in the previous week. The jump in mortgage rates is attributed to increased US Treasury yields and concerns about central banks raising interest rates.

site_title: Box of tricks
summary: Cirque du Soleil returns to Singapore with its production of Kooza, a circus show featuring 50 international performers from 19 countries. The plot revolves around The Innocent's self-discovery journey through a kingdom of eccentric characters. The show, seen by over seven million people worldwide, runs until August 27 at the Big Top near Marina Bay Sands.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: JPMorgan CEO being American 'almost an embarrassment'
summary: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon criticized the US political gridlock, calling it an "embarrassment" to be an American citizen. He stated that the country's inability to pass pro-business policies would hinder economic growth, which is currently trending at 1.5-2.0%. Dimon also emphasized the need to reform the tax code and reduce excessive regulations to promote infrastructure development and job creation. He contrasted the US with other countries, such as France, Argentina, and China, which he said understand the importance of practical policies for business growth and job creation.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan Chase chief executive Jamie Dimon ripped into the political gridlock in Washington and said Friday that they dysfunction threatened US economic prospects.

site_title: Cycling: Frenchman Barguil wins Bastille Day Tour stage
summary: French cyclist Warren Barguil won stage 13 of the Tour de France, Bastille Day Tour, on July 14, 2017. Barguil overtook Alberto Contador and Nairo Quintana in a sprint, regaining his Bastille Day stage win after missing out last year. Quintana and Contador reclaimed almost two minutes on leader Fabio Aru, while Chris Froome maintained second place. Mikel Landa's fourth-place finish moved him up to fifth overall, 1:09 behind Aru. The stage sets the stage for a resurgent Nairo Quintana's overall victory hopes in the Alps stages to come.

site_title: Goldman honcho mixes it up at the clubs
summary: Goldman Sachs co-president David Solomon, 55, has been performing as a DJ under the stage name DJ D-Sol, mixing electronic music for live audiences. The hobby has become a monthly gig, with recent stops in New York, Miami, and the Bahamas. Solomon's love of music is seen as a youthful and unguarded side to his personality, rare in the button-down world of high finance. His DJing has inspired a younger generation of Wall Street talent and is part of his effort to lead by example and promote a balanced life.

site_title: Freed and easy
summary: Honda unveiled the Freed Hybrid Sensing, a seven-seat MPV with a high-end driver assistance system. The vehicle features a cool interior and curvier sheet metal, giving it a robust appearance. The name "Freed Hybrid Sensing" represents freedom and unrestricted thinking, while "Sensing" refers to Honda's advanced driver assistance system. The Freed Hybrid Sensing is a mainstream MPV with a focus on comfort and safety, offering a unique blend of practicality and style.

site_title: Five hurt in acid attack robberies in London, two teenagers arrested
summary: British police arrested two teenagers after five acid attacks on moped riders in east London, leaving five people with facial burns. The attacks occurred in less than 90 minutes across Hackney and Islington, with one victim suffering horrific injuries. The two assailants on a moped were seen throwing acid at victims before fleeing the scene. The motive behind the attacks is currently unknown.

site_title: Planning and achieving financial goals
summary: Ivan, a 30-year-old individual, sought financial planning assistance due to his piecemeal purchases of financial products.
