site_title: Gold rises after Yellen hints at only gradual tightening
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen hinted at gradual tightening of monetary policy, reducing speculation of multiple interest rate hikes this year. Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,223.11 per ounce, while the US dollar slipped and Treasury yields declined. Lower yields reduce the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding gold, and a weaker dollar makes bullion cheaper for non-US investors. The Fed's comments are expected to influence gold prices, with some analysts predicting a potential revisit of the July 10 low of $1,204.45 per ounce.

site_title: Trump jets off to Paris as Russia crisis plagues Washington
summary: US President Donald Trump departed for France, amidst a Russia crisis in Washington. Trump's visit comes after the release of emails showing his son's dealings with Russia during the 2016 campaign. The trip includes talks with French President Emmanuel Macron and participation in national holiday festivities. The visit occurs days after the latest development in the probe into potential Trump campaign collusion with Moscow. Trump's departure follows a tumultuous week in Washington, with ongoing investigations and allegations of Russian interference in the 2016 election.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 1.84 points to 1,759.08. The market saw 36.85 million lots traded worth RM19.46 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 147 to 32.

site_title: LaBeouf apologises for Georgia arrest, is seeking addiction treatment
summary: Actor Shia LaBeouf apologized for his expletive-filled rants during his arrest in Georgia, calling his behavior "deeply shameful" and seeking help for addiction. LaBeouf, 31, was arrested on charges of disorderly conduct and public intoxication after a dispute with police in the lobby of his Savannah hotel. He previously sought treatment for alcoholism in 2014 and has now stated he is actively seeking sobriety.

site_title: Financier Jho Low denies wrongdoing claims linked to 1MDB
summary: Malaysian financier Jho Low has denied wrongdoing claims linked to 1MDB, stating that attempts to link him to recent guilty pleas are based on "unfounded assumptions." Low, the central figure in 1MDB probes, received millions of dollars, with US$1 billion allegedly diverted from the state fund to a bank account beneficially owned by him. Despite Singapore's investigations leading to five convictions, Low's representative claims no wrongdoing has been proved, and the allegations against him are "flawed, biased, and create an inaccurate picture."

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.32% to 3,219.18
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index increasing 0.32% to 3,219.18. The index saw 86.6 million shares worth S$57.6 million change hands, with consumer blue chips such as Thai Beverage Public Co and Genting Singapore leading the gains. The rally follows overnight US market gains and comes ahead of GDP data.

site_title: China's push to foster tech startups at risk from net crackdown
summary: China's government plans to block personal virtual private networks (VPNs) by February, effectively cutting off access to the global internet for individuals, students, and expats. This move would severely impact tech startups, entrepreneurs, and businesses, as VPNs are crucial for accessing blocked websites, news sites, and social media platforms. The restrictions would also affect students, academics, and business travelers in China, potentially hindering the country's vision of becoming an innovative nation.

images.alt_text: China wants to create the world's next Silicon Valley, but will the world's top inventors and entrepreneurs want to work in an environment cut off from the global internet?

site_title: Openness, connectivity key to realising full potential of China's Belt and Road Initiative: DPM Teo
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean emphasized the importance of openness and connectivity in realizing China's Belt and Road Initiative's full potential. Key aspects include keeping sea lanes open and safe for shipping, enhancing financial cooperation, and strengthening people-to-people connectivity. Teo stressed that Singapore will uphold the right of passage for ships and aircraft, support the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, and promote joint research and seminars to benefit third countries.

site_title: US announces plan to renegotiate trade deal with South Korea
summary: The US has announced plans to renegotiate its trade deal with South Korea, with the goal of removing barriers to trade. US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer was instructed by President Donald Trump to call a special Joint Committee meeting under the US-Korea Free Trade Agreement (KORUS). The move aims to reduce the trade deficit and give Americans a better chance to succeed in global markets.

site_title: Oil prices dip as Opec expects less demand for its crude
summary: Oil prices dropped 4 US cents, or 0.1%, to $47.70 per barrel, amid Opec's forecast of a market surplus in 2018 due to increased demand from rivals. The producer club attributed the decline to Opec's efforts to tighten supply, but a drawdown in US fuel inventories and strong demand from China prevented further price falls.

site_title: China H1 outbound investment plummets as capital outflow controls bite
summary: China's non-financial outbound direct investment (ODI) nearly halved in the first half of 2017, falling 45.8% to US$48.19 billion due to tightened capital outflow controls. The yuan's rapid depreciation prompted Beijing to curb funds moving out of China. Investment in real estate, hotels, and entertainment plummeted, with overseas real estate investment dropping 82.1% in the first six months of the year. The decline is attributed to a recovery in the domestic economy and rising global trade instability.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks jump to record high, won at 2-week high
summary: South Korean stocks reached a record high, with the won also hitting a two-week high, following Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments that monetary tightening would come gradually due to low inflation and neutral rates. Despite the Bank of Korea keeping interest rates at a record low for a 13th straight month, investor demand for riskier assets surged, driving up shares. Yellen's comments overshadowed the Bank of Korea's decision, which was widely expected.

site_title: Tech firms protest proposed changes to US net neutrality rules
summary: Tech firms like Facebook, Twitter, and Alphabet protested proposed changes to US net neutrality rules, urging the public to oppose the overturn of 2015 rules. Over 80,000 websites displayed banners and content to raise awareness. The proposed changes would allow broadband providers to give or sell access to certain internet services, potentially creating a "fast lane." The Obama administration implemented net neutrality rules in 2015, and the public is urged to oppose the potential reversal of these rules.

site_title: Mary Chia will delay AGM; halts trading
summary: MARY Chia Holdings, operator of beauty and slimming centers, has delayed its annual general meeting (AGM) to July 30-Sept 15, 2017, due to delays in completing its annual audit. The Singapore Exchange granted the extension after Mary Chia disclosed the reasons for the delay, which was caused by high staff turnover. The company halted trading of its stock pending the announcement.

images.alt_text: Madam Mary Chia (right), the founder and executive chairman of local lifestyle and wellness service provider Mary Chia Holdings, with her daughter, Ms Wendy Ho, the chief executive officer of the company.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.14% at the open, driven by a record close for the Dow on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index reached 26,340.29, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.16% and 0.09%, respectively. The gains came despite uncertainty over US trade policies, with investors focusing on the market's momentum.

site_title: US panel urges approval of cutting-edge cancer therapy
summary: A US advisory panel has unanimously recommended the FDA approve a cancer therapy called CTL019, developed by Carl June at the University of Pennsylvania. The treatment genetically alters a patient's immune system to attack leukemia. CTL019 works by altering a patient's T-cells to recognize and kill cancer cells. The treatment is licensed to Novartis and is being developed as a treatment for pediatric acute lymphoblastic leukemia. The FDA is expected to make a final decision on the approval of CTL019.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally with Wall St as Yellen sparks buying spree
summary: Asian markets surged on Thursday, extending a global rally, after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen indicated a gradual approach to raising US interest rates. Yellen said inflation remained below 2% and would be the critical determinant of Fed rate hikes, sparking buying. Asian markets rose, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney, Singapore, and Seoul all up, while the dollar came under pressure. The rally came despite ongoing concerns about US President Donald Trump's ability to push through a market-friendly economic agenda due to Russian collusion allegations.

site_title: Qatar's biggest bank turns to Asia to offset Saudi-led campaign
summary: Qatar National Bank (QNB) is expanding into Asia to offset the impact of a Saudi-led campaign to isolate Qatar. The bank aims to cut its domestic market income to 50% by 2020 and plans to open branches in Hong Kong, China, Oman, Kuwait, and India. Despite a one-month standoff with its neighbors, QNB's CEO says the impact is minimal, as Gulf countries represent less than 5% of the bank's balance sheet. The bank reported a 2% increase in second-quarter profit, maintaining its annual profit guidance at 6-8%.

images.alt_text: Qatar National Bank QPSC's expansion into Asia is helping the lender offset the impact of the ongoing Saudi-led campaign to isolate the gas-rich Arab state, its chief executive officer said.

site_title: Women finally hold more than 10% of board seats, but still far from 20% by 2020 target
summary: Women's share of board seats among Singapore-listed companies exceeded 10% for the first time since data collection began, reaching 10.3%, according to the Diversity Action Committee. Despite improvements, women's representation remains short of the 20% target by 2020. The proportion of boards with at least one woman director remained flat at 48%, with larger companies leading the way in increasing diversity. The committee urged boards to appoint more women with diverse skillsets, citing a surplus of senior women executives in certain fields.

images.alt_text: Women's share of board seats among Singapore-listed companies exceeded 10 per cent for the first time since data has been collected, the Diversity Action Committee (DAC) reported on Wednesday.

site_title: New Zealand consumer confidence eases in July: ANZ survey
summary: New Zealand consumer confidence eased in July, falling to 125.4 from 127.8 in June, according to an ANZ-Roy Morgan survey. Expectations for consumer price inflation over the next two years also decreased to 3.4%. This marks a return to a level above 100, indicating optimism. The drop in confidence may be attributed to the decline in inflation expectations.

site_title: North Korea quake 'not a nuclear test': report
summary: A 5.9 magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of North Korea, approximately 190km southeast of Chongjin, on July 12, 2017. Contrary to speculation, the US Geological Survey stated that the quake was not caused by a nuclear test, but rather a natural earthquake occurring 500km below the seabed.

site_title: Tennis: Konta humbled to be facing stellar Venus
summary: Britain's Johanna Konta will face five-time Wimbledon singles champion Venus Williams in the semi-finals on Thursday. Konta, who became the first British woman to reach the last four in almost 40 years by beating Simona Halep, is hoping to make history with her first grand slam title. Standing in her way is Williams, who has won five singles and six doubles titles at the All England Club. Konta's win over Halep marked a significant milestone for British women's tennis, with Konta now facing a tough test against the experienced Williams.

site_title: GLP is said to pick China consortium for final deal negotiations
summary: Global Logistic Properties Ltd (GLP) has chosen a Chinese consortium, led by private equity firms Hillhouse Capital Management and Hopu Investment Management, for final deal negotiations. The consortium edged out a rival group led by Warburg Pincus. GLP's shares have risen 23% this year, and the company is halting trading pending an announcement. The Chinese consortium will now negotiate definitive terms for the transaction, which is valued at around S$12.7 billion.

site_title: GLP halts trading pending announcement
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has halted trading of its stock pending an announcement. The developer is assessing firm bids for its business as part of a strategic review requested by major shareholder GIC. Leading bidders include a Chinese consortium backed by management and a group led by Warburg Pincus. The review is part of a strategic shift for GLP.

site_title: Kelantan introduces public caning for Islamic crimes
summary: Malaysia's Kelantan state has introduced public caning for Islamic crimes, allowing sharia courts to mete out punishments such as amputations and stoning to death. The move was approved by the state legislature, sparking criticism that it contradicts the federal constitution. The caning can be carried out in prison or publicly, according to the state deputy chief minister. The decision has been met with opposition from the Malaysian Chinese Association, which claims it disregards federal laws. This move is seen as a step towards introducing a harsh Islamic criminal code, known as hudud, in the northeastern state.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sincap, ESR-Reit, GLP
summary: Directors of SINCAP Group face an attempt to remove them through an extraordinary general meeting, as the company's stock slipped 4.5% due to the requisition. ESR-REIT posted a 9.2% decline in second-quarter net property income, citing lost revenue and conversion costs. GLOBAL Logistic Properties halted trading pending an announcement, as the company assesses firm bids for its business as part of a strategic review requested by major shareholder GIC.

site_title: ESR-Reit Q2 net property income falls 9.2% to S$19.2m; DPU down 11.3% to S$0.00956
summary: ESR-Reit reported a 9.2% decline in Q2 net property income to S$19.2 million, with distribution per unit dropping 11.3% to 0.956 Singapore cents. The trust's properties are 95.4% occupied, and its gearing ratio remains within the target range of 30-40%. The decline is attributed to lost revenue and costs from converting single-tenant properties into multi-tenant projects.

site_title: CNN video shows Trump with figures linked to Russia email controversy
summary: CNN released a video showing Donald Trump attending a 2013 dinner with figures linked to the Russia email controversy, including Aras Agalarov, Emin Agalarov, and Rob Goldstone. The video offers fresh insights into Trump's relationship with the Azerbaijani-Russian family, which includes Trump's eldest son Donald Jr in an email exchange that has been described as a possible "smoking gun" in the ongoing investigation into Russian interference in the US presidential election.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars climb as Yellen testimony caps greenback
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose against the US dollar, with the Aussie reaching a 3-1/2 month peak and the Kiwi edging higher for a second day. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's cautious policy outlook, which suggested the Fed may not raise interest rates further, contributed to the currency gains. The decline in US Treasury yields and a rate hike in Canada also supported the carry trades. However, most analysts expect interest rates in Australia and New Zealand to remain at record lows.

site_title: Jakarta moves to tackle tax avoidance by MNCs
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Sri Mulyani Indrawati, vows to tackle corporate tax avoidance by multinational corporations (MNCs) and raise the country's tax-to-GDP ratio to 16% by 2019. Aggressive tax planning by MNCs, including tech firms like Google and Facebook, has put local businesses at a disadvantage. The government is pushing for MNCs to incorporate locally and resist "damaging tax competition". The IMF is working with countries to counter artificial shifting of profits and assets to low-tax locations.

site_title: Facebook's Zuckerberg drills down into North Dakota's oil patch
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg toured a North Dakota drilling rig, meeting with oil industry workers and learning about automation, safety, and fracking. The visit was part of his 50-state tour to understand local economies and communities. Zuckerberg acknowledged climate change concerns but also expressed pride in the industry's contribution to daily needs. He discussed education, housing, and the Dakota Access Pipeline with community members, where some felt their livelihoods were blocked by government delays. Zuckerberg's visit highlighted the intersection of technology and energy production.

site_title: Michael Jackson estate plans TV animated Halloween special
summary: The Michael Jackson estate has announced plans to premiere an animated Halloween special, "Michael Jackson's Halloween," on CBS in the US around October 31. This is part of the estate's ongoing efforts to monetize the late pop star's legacy, following the release of two new albums of unreleased material since his death in 2009. The special will air on CBS and potentially abroad, following previous posthumous projects such as a 2010 album release that sparked controversy over its authenticity.

site_title: Google escapes 1.1b euro tax bill in France
summary: A French court ruled that Google's Irish subsidiary is not taxable in France, dismissing a 1.115 billion euro tax bill. The ruling comes after Google paid just 6.7 million euros in corporate taxes in 2015 by booking revenues in Ireland. The decision is part of a series of EU actions against US technology giants, including a 2.4 billion euro fine on Google for abusing its dominant position in search. The French government plans to appeal the ruling within two months.

site_title: Australia, NZ shares higher after Fed signals gradual policy tightening
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares rose on Thursday, mirroring a rise in Wall Street, after US Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen signaled a gradual tightening of policy. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 1% to 5,700, while the S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.4%. Yellen's less hawkish testimony was seen as a green light for Wall Street to step up riskier trades, amid concerns over a dip in US inflation. Australian financials, including Commonwealth Bank and Westpac, were among the top performers.

images.alt_text: Australian shares recovered the previous day's losses on Thursday, mirroring a rise in Wall Street, after US Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen signalled only a gradual tightening of policy.

site_title: UK election jitters push house price rises to 11-month low: RICS
summary: UK house price inflation slowed to its weakest since July last year, with the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) reporting a +7 index in June, down from +17 in May. Domestic political uncertainty, particularly after the June 8 election, was cited as the main reason for slowing property sales, with 44% of respondents blaming it. Brexit and property taxes were a bigger factor in London, where luxury property prices fell. A shortage of homes for sale remained a problem, with estate agents having a record-low amount of property to sell.

site_title: Startup launches new platform to compare electricity prices
summary: A Singapore-based startup, Electrify, has launched a platform to compare electricity prices, providing consumers with information on prices in just a click. Eight retailers are currently on board, with seven more expected to join by the end of the month. Electrify plans to expand to other South-east Asian markets in the next few years, capitalizing on the increasing competition in the electricity sector.

site_title: Former Brazil president Lula convicted of graft
summary: Brazil's former president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva was convicted of graft and sentenced to 9.5 years in prison for accepting a bribe of a luxury apartment and $1.1 million. Lula's conviction, part of the Operation "Car Wash" anti-corruption probe, may rule him out of the presidential election in October. The verdict also sends a message to Brazil's political class that they risk falling afoul of the anti-graft drive, with several high-profile politicians already charged or resigned.

site_title: CapitaLand, CCT, Mitsubishi to redevelop Golden Shoe for S$1.82b
summary: CapitaLand, CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT), and Mitsubishi Estate Co are redeveloping Golden Shoe Car Park in Singapore's financial district into a mixed-use project for S$1.82 billion. The joint venture will acquire the car park for S$161.1 million and set up two single-purpose trusts to carry out the redevelopment. The project will feature 29 floors of Grade A office space, an 8-storey serviced residence, and 12,000 sq ft of ancillary retail space, with completion estimated by 2021.

site_title: Personal computer market continues to slump
summary: The personal computer market continued to decline in the second quarter of 2017, with 61.1 million PCs shipped worldwide, a 4.3% drop from the same period last year. The decline was also reported by IDC, which estimated 60.5 million PCs shipped, a 3.3% year-over-year decrease.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by US rallies and Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's forecast of "gradual" interest rate hikes. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.39% and the Topix index rose 0.34%. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close for the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq. Despite tariff uncertainty, investors remained positive, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore penthouse on sale for S$100m, a test for luxury market's recovery
summary: A Singapore penthouse in the Tanjong Pagar Centre is on sale for S$100 million, making it likely to become the city-state's most expensive apartment. The penthouse, which features a private pool on the 64th floor, is part of a luxury development that is testing the endurance of demand for high-end property in Singapore, which has taken a hit from cooling measures. Despite a 15-20% drop in luxury home prices since 2013, analysts predict a 3-5% increase in luxury prices this year, driven by demand from locals and foreigners seeking value.

site_title: Infinio's auditor withholds opinion, citing uncertainty about valuations, going concern
summary: Infinio Group's external auditor has withheld its opinion on the company's financial report due to uncertainty about asset valuations and the company's ability to remain as a going concern. The auditor cited significant doubt about Infinio's ability to remain a going concern, citing a loss of S$1.2 million, negative equity, and a lack of sufficient evidence for certain asset valuations. This raises concerns about the company's financial stability and future prospects.

site_title: HK property prices to grow at a slower rate in H2 2017: Colliers
summary: Hong Kong property prices are expected to grow at a slower rate in the second half of 2017, with a 5.7-6.6% year-to-date growth in office market prices, driven by stronger-than-expected economic growth. Kowloon prices have increased by 4.2%. The slower growth is attributed to a more cautious market, with prices likely to be driven by the office market. Colliers International's mid-year review highlights the impact of economic growth on the property market.

site_title: Trump's foreign policy is evolving
summary: US President Donald Trump's foreign policy is evolving, with efforts to build ties with leaders and work with China on North Korea. Despite criticism of his performance at the G-20 summit, Trump has developed friendly relations with China, India, Russia, Japan, Saudi Arabia, and Turkey. He has also made progress on the North Korea nuclear crisis and reached a deal with Russian President Vladimir Putin on establishing order in Syria. While Trump's policies have been criticized, they have also shown signs of improvement, particularly in his efforts to improve ties with the Arab Gulf states and Israel.

site_title: JV by Japan's top shipping lines takes 50,000 sq ft at Marina One
summary: Japan's Ocean Network Express, a joint venture of Japan's top shipping lines, is taking up 50,000 sq ft of office space at Marina One in Singapore, planning to use it as its regional and global headquarters. The move comes as the city-state's premium office rents are showing signs of recovery, with gross effective rents in Grade-A CBD space rising 0.6% in the second quarter to S$8.49 psf pm. Other major tenants, including Macquarie Bank and Edmund Tie & Company, are also moving into the building, highlighting the area's growing attractiveness.

site_title: Intel rolls out new chips in battle for data centre business
summary: Intel has announced a new line of Xeon Scalable Processor chips for data centers, targeting companies such as Google, Microsoft, and Amazon in the lucrative cloud computing market. The new chips provide support for artificial intelligence and driverless cars, and Google was the first to adopt them. Intel faces stiff competition from AMD, and big internet companies are designing their own hardware, which may lead to price pressure. Analysts see the new processor as an improvement with better power efficiency and AI capabilities, but note that demand is subject to the success of companies in the cloud battle for customers.

site_title: US economy needs only 'gradual' rate hikes: Federal Reserve's Yellen
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen testified before Congress, stating the US economy needs only "gradual" interest rate increases over the next few years. She cautioned against making premature decisions about inflation, citing its current rate of 1.4%, and emphasized the importance of adjusting monetary policy as more data becomes available. Yellen also rejected the idea of auditing the Fed, citing the need for central bank independence. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates once more this year, with additional gradual hikes likely in the next few years to sustain economic growth.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen said on Wednesday that even as the US economy grows stronger and employment expands, she foresees only "gradual" interest rate increases in the next few years.

site_title: Europe: Biggest gains for stocks since Macron's first round win
summary: European stocks surged 1.5% on Wednesday, their best gains since April 24, driven by strong updates from Norwegian lender DNB and a more dovish tone from US Federal Reserve Chief Janet Yellen. Energy shares and miners also rose, while the media sector was weighed down by publisher Pearson's pain. The STOXX 600 index enjoyed its best day's gains since Macron's first round victory, with investors optimistic about the outlook despite renewed trade uncertainty.

site_title: US: Dow closes at record as Yellen pledges gradual rate hikes
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached a record high on Wednesday, closing at 21,534.22, as Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen pledged to implement gradual interest rate hikes. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose, with the Nasdaq jumping 1.1% to a fresh record. The positive market sentiment was driven by Yellen's testimony, which reaffirmed the Fed's commitment to gradual rate increases, despite uncertainty surrounding US-China trade tensions.

site_title: US sees 'slight to moderate' growth in June: Fed survey
summary: The US economy experienced "slight to moderate" growth in June, according to the Federal Reserve's survey, with signs of inflation remaining scarce despite tight labor markets. Businesses reported feeling pressure to offer higher pay and benefits to attract qualified workers. Fed Chair Janet Yellen stated the central bank expects gradual interest rate increases to support continued growth, contradicting expectations of more aggressive rate hikes.

site_title: JM seeks buyers for Mercator's listing status as current deal falls through
summary: MERCATOR Lines, under judicial management, has terminated a proposed deal to transfer its listing status to a company set up by two individuals, Nickolaos Mitropoulous and Dimitrios Podaridis, due to the parties' failure to meet condition precedents. The judicial manager will recommence efforts to source other potential investors for the transfer. Mercator underwent judicial management in January 2016 and has since sold its vessels for cash. The transfer was intended to provide recovery to incumbent shareholders and creditors.

site_title: Australia firms, consumers divided over economy
summary: Australia's economy is dividing companies and consumers, with business confidence at a post-2008 crisis high while consumer sentiment remains low. Consumer pessimism has outnumbered optimism for an eighth-straight month, partly due to stagnant wages and underemployment. The Aussie dollar's 25% depreciation since 2012 has benefited exporters but not consumers, and low interest rates have also hindered wage growth. The Reserve Bank of Australia predicts a gradual increase in wages, but officials are surprised that wages aren't rising faster, given the nation's historical response to unemployment.

site_title: Private apartment rents down 3.2% in June
summary: Singapore's private apartment rents fell 3.2% year-over-year in June, with HDB flats down 4% from their peak in 2013. However, analysts see a silver lining in reduced private home completions, which may ease downward rental pressure. Some consultants predict a recovery in prime areas, with Savills Singapore's Alan Cheong forecasting a 1.5% increase in non-landed private home rents in the Core Central Region by year-end. The rental market is expected to stabilize and bottom out by end-2017, driven by improving economic prospects and a decrease in private home completions.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Oil rises as US crude stocks drop by more than expected
summary: US crude oil inventories dropped 7.6 million barrels last week, exceeding expectations, while petrol stocks fell 1.6 million barrels. Oil prices rose, with Brent crude futures increasing 22 cents to $47.74 a barrel and US WTI crude rising 45 cents to $45.49. Despite the gains, petrol demand remains lackluster, and analysts expect prices to be capped by above-average inventory levels. OPEC's forecast of a market surplus in 2018 due to increased production and declining demand also contributed to the price gains.

site_title: US$ edges lower vs yen before Yellen testimony
summary: The US dollar fell against the yen and euro, reaching 14-month lows, ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's testimony on monetary policy. Investors took profits after a recent dollar rally, citing a softening of US Treasury yields. Yellen's testimony is expected to provide clues on when the Fed will start reducing its massive balance sheet. Markets are optimistic about the dollar's outlook, with some strategists predicting a long position against sterling. The Bank of England is also expected to maintain a dovish stance, with the deputy governor citing "a lot of imponderables" regarding interest rate hikes.

site_title: SPH Reit achieves stable Q3 results
summary: SPH Reit reported stable Q3 results with a 2% increase in distributable income to S$35.7 million, up from S$35 million in the previous year. The distribution per unit (DPU) rose 0.7% to 1.37 S'pore cents, driven by the 2% increase.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Summer heat could fire up corn prices despite record stocks
summary: Global corn stocks are at record highs, but rising demand and potential damage to the US crop from a hot summer could boost prices. The global stocks-to-use ratio is heading for a five-year low, leaving the US crop vulnerable to weather-related damage. A forecasted stifling summer could stress harvest yields and impact the balance sheet, potentially leading to a price increase. The USDA is expected to trim its yield expectations, and any revision could significantly impact US ending stocks.

site_title: Konta raises British fans' hopes at Wimbledon
summary: Johanna Konta, a British tennis player, has made history by becoming the first British woman to reach a Wimbledon singles semi-final since 1978. Konta, 26, defeated No. 2 Simona Halep 6-7 (2), 7-6 (5), 6-4, ending a 39-year British women's drought at Wimbledon. Konta will face No. 10 Venus Williams in the next round, while fellow British player Andy Murray is also seeking to advance to the semi-finals.

site_title: BNP Paribas targeting investments from German SMEs into Asean
summary: BNP Paribas is targeting investments from German SMEs into the Asean region, leveraging its European heritage to tap into a niche space. The bank aims to grow its revenue by 10% in the next few years, driven by cross-border flows and companies tapping corridors between South-east Asia, North Asia, and Europe. With 40% of its revenue generated through cross-border flows, BNP expects to gain ground as Asean markets invest in infrastructure, generating up to $5 trillion in investments by 2030 and creating 230 million jobs.

site_title: Democrat files first impeachment article against Trump
summary: Democratic congressman Brad Sherman filed the first article of impeachment against President Donald Trump, citing obstruction of justice. The resolution accuses Trump of trying to quash investigations into his campaign's ties to Russia and an investigation into a senior aide. Sherman's effort is likely to stall in the Republican-controlled Congress. Only one lawmaker, Democrat Al Green, has signed on to the resolution, and the White House has dismissed the move as "utterly and completely ridiculous."

site_title: Mitsubishi UFJ to take on Wall Street banks in US lending push
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) is expanding its US investment-banking unit to compete with Wall Street banks, focusing on areas like receivables finance and asset-based finance. The Japanese firm aims to move beyond traditional strengths and become a bigger player in these areas. MUFG plans to underwrite and sell more debt in the US, play a bigger role in high-yield bonds and leveraged loans, and make more equipment-financing loans, including for aircraft purchases. The expansion strategy is driven by record-low interest rates and the need for revenue and growth opportunities.

site_title: Mercedes widens lead over BMW with trendy new E-Class, SUVs
summary: Mercedes-Benz widened its global luxury-car sales lead in the first half of 2017, selling 1.14 million vehicles, a 14% increase from the previous year, thanks to the success of its revamped E-Class sedan and trendy SUVs. BMW lagged behind with a 5.2% gain to 1.04 million vehicles. Audi, struggling with the diesel scandal, fell 4.7% to 908,950 vehicles. Mercedes' sales surged 68% for the E-Class and 13% for its SUVs, while BMW's X1 SUV was its biggest growth driver. Mercedes' lead is expected to remain in the coming years, with Audi hoping to pull back with its revamped A8 flagship sedan.

site_title: APP taps ex-ST Engg executive to tackle haze
summary: Asia Pulp and Paper (APP) has appointed Bernard Tan, formerly chief marketing officer of ST Engineering and president of ST Kinetics, to drive sustainability work at the paper giant. Tan's immediate priority is addressing the haze issue, particularly during the dry season from July to October. He aims to strengthen APP's fire prevention efforts, investing over US$80 million, and set up a fire audit team to review the firm's programmes. Tan's appointment comes after the group's sustainability chief Aida Greenbury left in May, and he will lead APP's efforts to lead the industry standard in sustainability.

images.alt_text: Mr Tan is also setting up a new fire audit team which will review APP's programmes to combat the haze and assess how ready and effective they are.

site_title: COE supply to fall by 13.7% from August to October
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority announced a 13.7% decrease in COE supply from August to October, with a total of 27,370 COEs available. This translates to 9,122 COEs per month. The drop is attributed to fewer vehicle deregistrations in previous months.

site_title: Razer Inc eyeing Hong Kong IPO at up to US$5b valuation: sources
summary: Razer Inc is planning a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) valued at up to US$5 billion, aiming to fund the development of its own mobile phone and expand into China's US$25 billion gaming market. The company, co-founded in 2005, is developing a mobile device for hardcore gamers and has sold US$1 billion worth of products globally in the past three years. The IPO, expected to list in October, would be one of the largest tech debuts in Hong Kong in years.

site_title: Trump defends eldest son's actions over Russia 'Hillary dirt' emails
summary: US President Donald Trump defended his eldest son Donald Trump Jr after emails revealed his involvement in a meeting with a Russian lawyer who claimed to have information about Hillary Clinton's campaign. The emails showed Trump Jr responding to an offer of "high level and sensitive information" from Russia, saying "if it's what you say, I love it." Trump Jr attended a meeting with Natalia Veselnitskaya, a Russian lawyer, along with campaign officials Paul Manafort and Jared Kushner. The President's lawyer said Trump was not aware of the emails until recently, and Trump Jr described the meeting as "such a nothing." The revelation fuels speculation about Moscow's role in the 2016 election and raises questions about Trump's associates colluding with Russia.

site_title: Why inequality may be worse than it seems
summary: Global income inequality has decreased over the past 25 years, with a lower poverty rate than ever before. However, within economies, income inequality has risen, creating social and economic problems. The issue lies in measuring living standards, as income inequality is accompanied by inflation inequality. Different countries and individuals prioritize different goods and services when calculating inflation, making it a complex task to determine the average cost of living. This highlights the need to consider real or inflation-adjusted income levels when assessing economic inequality.

site_title: Deutsche Bank targets Saudis in big push for wealth
summary: Deutsche Bank is targeting Saudi Arabia as a priority region for wealth management, aiming to recoup assets lost after concerns about its capital levels prompted a client exodus. The bank plans to hire about 20 private bankers in Europe, Middle East, and Africa, with a focus on the Middle East. This move is part of the bank's efforts to expand its products and attract new wealth management clients in the region.

site_title: Stronger IPO flows in Asean seen for 2nd half of the year
summary: Asean is expected to see stronger initial public offering (IPO) activity in the second half of the year, driven by rising business confidence in the region. Malaysia is poised to lead the charge, with several large IPOs in progress, while Singapore and Thailand are also expected to see increased activity in the infrastructure, power, and utilities sectors. The healthy IPO pipeline reflects the rally in markets and ample liquidity from yield-hungry investors. This is expected to offer relief to investors seeking long-term assets, particularly pension funds and insurance companies.

site_title: Yanlord partnering Perennial to bid for United Engineers: sources
summary: Yanlord Land Group, a China-focused developer, is partnering Perennial Real Estate Holdings in a bid to acquire United Engineers Ltd, a century-old Singapore property group. The consortium plans to announce an agreement to buy Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp's stakes in United Engineers and its WBL Corp subsidiary, followed by an offer for the rest of the company, valued at S$1.73 billion. This deal would cap OCBC's efforts to offload its stake in United Engineers, which has been discussed since 2014.

site_title: Los Angeles and Paris gain Olympic favour
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has unanimously decided to award the 2024 and 2028 Summer Olympics to Paris and Los Angeles, respectively. The unusual plan, announced on July 11, 2017, aims to alleviate concerns about diminishing interest in hosting the Olympics due to high costs and corruption. Paris is the favourite to host the 2024 Games, while Los Angeles is expected to host in 2028. The decision is seen as a welcome response to the withdrawals of several candidate cities and as a potential step towards reforming the Olympics.

site_title: Zimbabwe businesses looking to solar power as means to cut costs
summary: Zimbabwe businesses are turning to solar power to reduce costs amid a power crisis. Old Mutual Zimbabwe Ltd plans to install 20 megawatts of rooftop solar panels on its commercial buildings over two years. This move aims to ease the country's power shortages, which have been dragging down profits. The company's decision follows the widespread adoption of solar power in homes, with over 100,000 systems installed.

site_title: Dow jumps as market welcomes good jobs data in upbeat report from Yellen
summary: The Dow Jones Index surged to a record intraday high as Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen reported strong jobs growth, with the US economy adding 180,000 jobs per month during the first half of 2017. Yellen signaled the Fed will continue to raise interest rates and reduce investment holdings, but not rush to tighten monetary policy due to persistently low inflation. The US dollar retreated, and treasuries rallied, as investors took confidence in the American economy from Yellen's upbeat report.

site_title: YuuZoo CFO quits; he's sixth person to leave the post in 3 years
summary: YuuZoo Corporation's CFO, Raul Ikonen, has resigned four months after taking the post due to "personal reasons." This is the sixth CFO to leave the company in three years. The departure follows a string of high-profile exits, including two audit committee chairs, a non-executive director, and five CFOs since the firm's listing in 2014. YuuZoo cited personal reasons for Ikonen's departure, but some have questioned the company's retention and departure policies. The company's stock closed unchanged at 7.4 Singapore cents.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Men dominate in the crowdfunding arena
summary: A report by PricewaterhouseCoopers and The Crowdfunding Centre found that men dominate crowdfunding efforts in terms of the amount of capital raised, but women are more successful at meeting their funding goals. Women led 22% of successful campaigns, while men led only 17%. Despite setting smaller funding goals, women tend to garner more funds per pledge than men, with an average of US$87 per pledge for women compared to US$83 for men. The report also noted that women are more successful in global crowdfunding efforts, particularly in the education and technology sectors.

site_title: The lonely giant of Taipei skyline is about to get some company
summary: Taipei's skyline is set to change as a new skyscraper, Nan Shan Plaza, is scheduled for completion at the end of 2017. The 48-storey, 892-foot building will be the first of several new structures in the Xinyi District, which is rapidly becoming the center of finance, business, and shopping in Taipei. Nan Shan Plaza's design aims to express gratitude to Taiwan, with its elongated triangle shape resembling two hands pressed together. The building's completion is seen as a positive sign for the local office space market, with rents expected to remain competitive despite the new supply of office space.

site_title: S'pore inks deals for aviation training and research collaboration
summary: Singapore has signed two agreements to develop aviation leadership and embark on research collaboration. The country will partner the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) to develop a two-day executive program on aviation security for directors-general of civil aviation, with seven runs planned between 2018 and 2020. Additionally, Singapore will collaborate with the ICAO on research projects to benefit the Asia-Pacific region, enhancing aviation safety and security in the region. The agreements aim to promote aviation excellence and cooperation in the Asia-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Japan bank mergers now a matter of averting 'extinction'
summary: Japan's regional banks face an existential threat due to negative interest rates and demographic decline in rural areas. By 2025, about half of Japan's lenders are expected to disappear or merge, with only a handful able to reach profitability. Despite some mergers, many banks remain resistant to teaming up due to rivalries and corporate identities. The new entity formed by Daisan Bank and Mie Bank will have a stronger presence in urban areas, but the industry as a whole still faces significant challenges.

site_title: S'pore IPO star Unusual Ltd seeks China expansion
summary: Unusual Ltd, Singapore's top-performing IPO this year, plans to double its concert shows by next year, with a focus on China's second-tier cities and South-east Asia. The company, which has brought Mariah Carey and the Foo Fighters to Asia, is in talks with a venue operator in China and considers acquiring ticketing platforms and children's show rights. China's domestic media and entertainment industry has grown 70% in the last five years, fueling Unusual's ambitions. The company's share price has surged 158% since its April listing, but some analysts question the valuation at 50-60 times earnings.

site_title: Yellen sees inflation key uncertainty amid moderate growth
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen expressed uncertainty about the inflation outlook, citing "considerable uncertainty" about when and how much inflation will respond to tightening resource utilization. Yellen emphasized the Fed's focus on keeping inflation at the 2% target, but also acknowledged that temporary influences, such as changes in mobile-phone plans and prescription drugs, are holding down price measures. She suggested the Fed will continue to raise interest rates to support job gains and income growth, and anticipates starting to reduce its balance sheet this year.

site_title: Why banks need new operating models
summary: Banks are facing pressure from new technology and entrants with disruptive business models, leading to the need for a truly differentiated strategy and new operating models. To succeed, banks must rethink critical functions such as IT, risk and compliance, and develop models that suit their strategies. Key strategies include putting customer priorities at the centre, reaching outside the bank for expert partners, getting Agile fast, modernising legacy IT, finding and redeploying new talent, and adapting to an evolving market environment.

site_title: Australia makes cautious entry into medicinal marijuana market
summary: Australia has begun its medicinal marijuana market with a cautious approach, granting commercial licenses to companies like Cann Group and BuddingTech. The country's regulatory framework aims to ensure the quality and safety of the product before exporting it to other countries. Despite growing recognition of the plant's potential, patient access remains limited due to conservative government regulations and a lack of confidence among doctors in prescribing the drug. The global market is expected to reach $55.8 billion by 2025, but Australia's domestic market is estimated to be worth around $100 million initially.

site_title: Mobility to shape women leaders
summary: Singapore is seeking to attract and retain a diverse workforce, particularly women, to drive high-quality growth and development. A Boston Consulting Group report found that 55% of women are willing to take international job assignments, but only a small subset currently do so. To address this, companies should focus on mobility programs for young women, ensure merit-based consideration for international job assignments, provide tailored logistical support, develop a compelling communication strategy, and create opportunities for women who cannot relocate abroad. By doing so, companies can create more balanced leadership teams and improve performance.

site_title: Tiny HK homes offer big potential to storage firms
summary: Hong Kong's tiny apartments are creating a demand for self-storage facilities, with investors like Blackstone Group LP seeing opportunity in the small spaces. The majority of city residents struggle to find room for personal belongings, making self-storage a potential solution. As the city's population continues to grow, the demand for storage facilities is expected to increase, providing a lucrative market for investors and developers.

site_title: IMF signals strong growth prospects for Asia but warns of challenges
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has signaled strong growth prospects for Asia, citing the region's "strongest" economic outlook. However, deputy managing director Mitsuhiro Furusawa also warned of significant challenges, including uncertainty in advanced economies, market volatility, and infrastructure investment needs. Furusawa emphasized the importance of domestic revenue mobilization, particularly in Asia, where tax revenues are relatively low, and suggested a minimum tax-to-GDP ratio of 15% is necessary for accelerated growth and development. Indonesia is seen as one of the strongest performers in the region, with solid growth and manageable inflation.

site_title: Land of the Rising Sun needs a new long-term vision
summary: Japan faces a sense of stagnation, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's popularity plummeting amid political scandals. A power vacuum is feared, potentially drawing in extremist groups. Parliamentary opposition parties struggle to form viable alternatives, leaving the country uncertain about its future. The public's cynicism grows, and the nation's long-term vision appears to be lacking.

site_title: China sends troops to open first overseas military base
summary: China has deployed troops to establish its first overseas military base in Djibouti, a strategic location at the edge of the Indian Ocean, fueling concerns in India about China's growing global military presence. The base, initially described as a logistics facility, will enable China to conduct escort, peacekeeping, and humanitarian missions in Africa and the Middle East. China's military modernization and global reach are expected to increase, but Beijing denies seeking military expansionism, promising to avoid arms races.

site_title: Market mixed ahead of Yellen report
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 9.89 points, or 0.31%, to 3,208.91 on Wednesday, despite the Dow futures being in green territory. Trading in the broad market was mixed, with gainers beating losers 210-208. Investors awaited signs on when the US Federal Reserve would start reducing its balance sheet ahead of Fed chief Janet Yellen's testimony.

site_title: Rebound in Chinese demand helps boost Burberry sales
summary: Burberry reported better-than-expected same-store sales in its first quarterly report under new CEO Marco Gobbetti, driven by a rebound in Chinese demand and strong performance in the UK market. Like-for-like sales rose 4%, double analysts' expectations, with Chief Financial Officer Julie Brown citing a return to consumer confidence in China and a positive response to new products. Burberry's retail revenue reached £478 million, exceeding analysts' forecast of £456 million. The company also plans to continue engaging with shareholders and assess options for its manufacturing.

site_title: Apple setting up China data centre to meet new cybersecurity rules
summary: Apple is setting up its first data centre in China, partnering with Guizhou-Cloud Big Data Industry Co Ltd, to comply with the country's new cybersecurity laws. The $1 billion investment is part of a planned expansion in the southern province of Guizhou. The data centre will store iCloud data and allow Apple to improve product and service reliability while meeting regulatory requirements. Apple is the first foreign firm to announce compliance measures following the June 1 law, which requires foreign firms to store data within the country.

site_title: Traders combat glut by offering bespoke oil
summary: Singapore oil traders are offering bespoke oil cargoes to meet buyers' niche specifications in a world with a crude glut. Companies like Vitol Group, Trafigura Group, and Glencore Plc are mixing and matching crude from various sources to create made-to-measure cargoes. This strategy aims to lure buyers who are becoming more demanding, providing an edge in a highly competitive market.

site_title: London's iconic black cabs rebrand for electric future
summary: Hundreds of London's black cabs will be sold in Amsterdam starting in 2018, powered by batteries instead of diesel fuel. The vehicles, designed by London Taxi Co (LTC) and manufactured by Geely Automobile Holdings Ltd, meet new pollution rules in the Dutch capital. The £325 million investment has led to the renaming of LTC to London EV Co (LEVC) and the introduction of a new, all-electric taxi model called the TX. The vehicles will feature a roomy interior, a large sunroof, and a touch screen for driver navigation, with a price to be announced in August.

site_title: Fed's Yellen still sees only 'gradual' rate hikes
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen expects only "gradual" interest rate hikes in the next few years as the US economy grows stronger and employment expands. Despite low inflation, Yellen believes the economy will rebound and inflation will eventually return to the Fed's 2% target rate. She also cautioned that uncertainties, such as potential shifts in President Trump's administration and global economic prospects, may impact the economic outlook.

site_title: US$ may rebound, signalling a 'choppy' quarter for equities
summary: The US dollar may experience a temporary recovery against Asian currencies, including the Singapore dollar, signaling a choppy third quarter for equities. DBS Group Research expects a rebound in the USD/SGD currency pair to 1.41 from 1.37. The Straits Times Index (STI) may trade within the 3,130 to 3,275 band, but is expected to reach 3,350 by year-end. Defensive yield names and alpha picks with catalysts are recommended during this period, with yield picks including Sheng Siong and Keppel Reit.

site_title: It's an open field at this year's Emmys
summary: The 2017 Emmy Awards nominations are expected to be a wide-open race, with several newcomers vying for top prizes. Game of Thrones, a perennial favorite, is ineligible due to its new season not starting until Sunday. Favorites like The Crown, Stranger Things, The Handmaid's Tale, and Westworld are expected to receive nods, while returning shows like The Americans, Better Call Saul, and Homeland are also contenders. The ceremony will take place on September 17, with Stephen Colbert hosting and live-streaming on CBS.

A number of nods for the Emmys should go to newcomers like lavish period drama The Crown and Stranger Things (above).
