site_title: EU flexing muscle on trade and climate change
summary: The European Union (EU) took a leading role at the Group of 20 meeting in Hamburg, focusing on trade and climate change issues. With the US looking inward, the EU is flexing its muscle, coordinating positions and representing its member countries' interests. The EU's efforts come amid a resurgence of unity among its members, as it forges new trade deals and addresses pressing global concerns.

site_title: The man who went head-on against the West in 1997 - and won
summary: Japan's Eisuke Sakakibara, known as "Mr Yen," played a key role in the 1997 Asian financial crisis by proposing the Asian Monetary Fund (AMF) as a counter to the IMF. Sakakibara clashed with the IMF and US Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers over crisis handling, criticizing the IMF's radical reforms. Despite opposition, Sakakibara's idea eventually led to the establishment of the Chiang Mai Initiative Multilateralisation (CMIM), a regional currency swap arrangement. Sakakibara believes the AMF could have prevented much of the damage done in 1997, and he remains critical of IMF behavior during the crisis. He argues that Asia's economic independence and a more pragmatic approach could have mitigated the crisis.

site_title: US mortgage activity posts biggest weekly drop since December: MBA
summary: US mortgage application activity plummeted 7.4% to 391.9 in the week ended July 7, its largest decline since December. The drop was driven by interest rates on 30-year fixed-rate home loans, which rose to nearly two months' highest level. This marks the steepest weekly drop in mortgage activity since December.

site_title: Bid for Croesus: Is Blackstone buying into a retail boom in Japan?
summary: Private equity giant Blackstone has made a buyout offer for Japanese mall owner Croesus Retail Trust (CRT) at a price of S$1.17 per unit, exceeding brokerages' 12-month targets. Blackstone took a risk by having no prior stake in the trust, building its stake up from scratch. The offer is valued at more than S$900 million. The exact value Blackstone saw in CRT is unclear, but analysts speculate it may be a bigger potential or value.

images.alt_text: What value did private equity giant Blackstone see in Japanese mall owner Croesus Retail Trust (CRT) to warrant its buyout offer at a price that far exceeded brokerages' 12-month targets ranging from S$1.08 to as low as S$0.98?

site_title: Ex-banker admits to money laundering in 1MDB-linked case
summary: Ex-banker Yeo Jiawei, serving the longest jail term for obstruction of justice in Singapore's 1MDB probe, has admitted to money laundering and pleaded guilty to cheating his former employer. Yeo, a former BSI SA wealth planner, was identified as a central figure linked to Malaysian financier Low Taek Jho, who controlled a plan to drain billions from 1MDB. Yeo's admission comes after a two-year probe into fund flows related to the Malaysian investment fund, which has consistently denied any wrongdoing.

site_title: Amazon's Prime Day proves to be biggest shopping day ever
summary: Amazon's third annual Prime Day event surpassed traditional retailing blowouts like Black Friday and Cyber Monday, with sales exceeding $1 billion and a 60% growth compared to last year. The most popular purchase was the Echo Dot mini-speaker, discounted by 30%. The event saw an influx of new Prime members, with "tens of millions" making a purchase, and Amazon Prime membership increased by 50% compared to last year. The event promoted Prime membership and converted occasional shoppers into devotees, with Amazon's Alexa platform gaining a foothold.

site_title: United Food plans to raise S$10m through share placement
summary: United Food Holdings plans to raise S$10 million through a share placement of 25.8 million new shares at 39 Singapore cents apiece. The placement, which is a 3.75% premium to the volume-weighted average price, aims to pursue potential acquisitions or joint-venture opportunities and for general working capital. Private investors Gu Yulin, Liu Jun, and Ting Cheng-Fa will receive the shares, which were introduced to the company by its non-executive chairman Song Yanan.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Nam Cheong to meet noteholders on July 19 to update them on restructuring
summary: Nam Cheong will hold an informal meeting with noteholders on July 19 to update them on restructuring options for three issues totaling S$365 million, due between 2017 and 2019. The meeting will be facilitated by the Securities Investors Association of Singapore and will allow noteholders to ask questions to the company's management and advisers. The restructuring relates to notes issued under Nam Cheong's S$600 million multi-currency medium-term note programme, including S$90 million, S$200 million, and S$75 million notes due 2017, 2019, and 2018, respectively.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo's condition critical, breathing failing, hospital says
summary: Chinese Nobel Peace Prize winner Liu Xiaobo is in critical condition, with failing breathing and kidney/liver functions. His condition has deteriorated significantly since early Wednesday, and his family has declined hospital treatment, including intubation. Despite Western governments' calls for him to be allowed to travel abroad for treatment, China has warned against interference in its internal affairs. The government has allowed two foreign doctors to visit Liu Xiaobo, but his condition remains uncertain, with friends and protesters expressing concerns and calling for his release.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on Yellen's rate comments
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Wednesday after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated that rate hikes would be gradual and not excessively high to reach a neutral level. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 106.47 points, the S&P 500 gained 12.81 points, and the Nasdaq Composite added 46.80 points. Yellen's comments were seen as positive for markets, which had been impacted by uncertainty over interest rate hikes and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Abe seeks to avoid repeat of his swift exit a decade ago
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is facing a similar situation to his 2007 resignation, with unpopular policies and scandals contributing to a decline in public support. Abe, who cited health issues for his abrupt exit, is now seeking to avoid a repeat. His government is under pressure, with the upper house election defeat in 2007 leading to his resignation. Ten years later, Abe's situation is similarly precarious, with his leadership facing scrutiny.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Oxley Holdings is purchasing a freehold property in Singapore's southern region for S$121 million, with plans to redevelop it. Duty Free International reported a 24.1% drop in net profit to RM15.1 million for the first quarter, while Sincap Group faces a requisition to remove directors. Katrina Group has entered into a joint-venture agreement with Big Benefit Group to manage Vietnamese-style restaurants in China and Hong Kong.

site_title: Chinese Internet clampdown hurts businesses: US group
summary: China's clampdown on virtual private networks (VPNs) to circumvent internet controls may disrupt businesses relying on them for cloud services and data security. The US-China Business Council warns that the crackdown, targeting mainly individual users, could expand and hurt operations. Over 20% of foreign businesses in China reported that internet restrictions affected more than 10% of their revenue. Businesses use VPNs to access blocked websites, ensure speed and security, and connect to cloud-based services. The Ministry of Industry and Information Technology has pledged to step up enforcement against unauthorized VPNs, and companies must register their usage of leased lines to access the international web.

site_title: Falcon Energy seeks extension for S$50m notes due September
summary: Falcon Energy Group, a listed offshore oil and gas contractor, is seeking an extension for its S$50 million notes due in September 2017. The company plans to extend the maturity date by three years and waive all covenants. This move aims to conserve cash amid an industry-wide downturn. Falcon Energy will conduct a consent solicitation exercise and hold a third informal meeting with bondholders once details are finalized.

site_title: Oxley to acquire residential property in Pasir Panjang for S$121m
summary: OXLEY Holdings is acquiring a freehold property in Pasir Panjang, Singapore, for S$121 million. The 231 Pasir Panjang Road property will be redeveloped, subject to necessary approvals. The purchase is funded by internal resources and bank borrowings.

site_title: London house price drag prompts UK's weakest gains since 2013
summary: The UK's annual house price growth slowed to its weakest since 2013, with London experiencing a 0.8% increase, compared to 13.7% in 2016. Nationally, prices rose 2.4%, down from 3.6% in the first quarter. Affordability constraints, tax changes, and caution among buyers are cited as contributing factors. The slowdown is attributed to a "sustained slowdown" in UK property price inflation, with the average London house price reaching £452,758, double the national level of £222,911.

site_title: Oil rises a third day to trade near US$46 on US stockpile drop
summary: Oil prices rose a third day to near US$46 per barrel as US crude and gasoline stockpiles declined. Crude inventories fell by 8.13 million barrels, while gasoline supplies shrank by 801,000 barrels. The Energy Information Administration is expected to confirm this decline in its report Wednesday, marking the biggest decrease since September. Despite concerns about expanding global supply offsetting OPEC curbs, oil remains in a bear market amid concerns about US production.

site_title: Australia to pay China's Shenhua Energy A$262m to buy back mining licence
summary: Australia's New South Wales state agreed to pay A$262m to China's Shenhua Energy Co Ltd to buy back 51.4% of a coal exploration licence on the Liverpool Plains 400km north-west of Sydney. The move comes after pressure from farmers and environmentalists opposed to mining on prime agricultural land. The purchase price is part of a deal to retain Shenhua's remaining 48.6% stake in the licence, which had been under scrutiny due to its potential environmental impact. The agreement is seen as a compromise to balance economic interests with environmental concerns.

images.alt_text: Shenhua says that it is disappointed by the government's move but says the buyback is an acceptable financial outcome.

site_title: Insurance could cut US$29b natural disaster bill for poor nations
summary: A new report suggests that specialized insurance, particularly "parametric" structures, could significantly reduce the financial burden of natural disasters on poor nations. Catastrophe modeling firm RMS estimates that such insurance could cover up to $6.8 billion in disaster costs, compared to current coverage of just $900 million. This could alleviate pressure on humanitarian aid budgets, with each dollar paid through parametric insurance having the same impact as $3.50 of slower-moving aid payments. Britain plans to establish a London Centre for Global Disaster Protection to help developing countries use insurance to cut disaster costs.

site_title: E.ON's nuclear unit to cut at least half its workforce by 2026
summary: E.ON's nuclear unit, PreussenElektra, plans to cut at least 1,000 of its 2,000-strong workforce by 2026 due to Germany's exit from nuclear power. This move follows the country's 2011 Fukushima disaster and its aim to reduce reactor capacity to zero by 2022. The job cuts are not related to E.ON's previous plan to reduce group headcount by 1,300 by 2018. Negotiations for the PreussenElektra cuts are ongoing, while E.ON's offshoot Uniper plans to reduce personnel costs by 100 million euros this year and next.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz widens lead over BMW as E-Class, SUVs boost sales
summary: Mercedes-Benz widened its global luxury-car sales lead in the first half of 2017, selling 106,244 fewer vehicles than BMW, with a 14% delivery jump. The sales disparity contrasts with BMW's 5.2% increase. Mercedes' E-Class and SUV sales surged 68% and 13% respectively, driven by younger buyers. BMW's efforts to restore its lead have been hindered by its slower pace in adopting electric autos, while Mercedes is set to launch its EQ battery-powered SUV in 2019. Audi's sales declined 4.7% due to a dealers dispute in China.

site_title: Indonesia finance minister says to tackle tax avoidance by MNCs
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Sri Mulyani Indrawati, announced plans to sharply increase tax collection and collaborate with other nations to combat tax avoidance by multinational corporations. The move comes as digital companies exploit loopholes in the domestic tax system, putting local businesses at a competitive disadvantage. Indrawati stated that aggressive tax planning by MNCs has become a significant issue, threatening Indonesia's economic growth.

site_title: Audi labour boss criticises management for lack of production roadmap
summary: Audi's labour boss criticises top management for lacking a production roadmap, citing workers' fears of being left behind in the race for orders and projects. The works council chairman, Peter Mosch, called for new models to be assigned to the carmaker's German factories. This comes after Audi assigned a new electric model to a factory in Brussels, where the company plans to start building its first mass-produced sport-utility vehicle in 2018. Audi had no immediate comment on the matter.

images.alt_text: Audi's labour boss has criticised top management for lacking a roadmap for production as workers at the luxury carmaker's core German plants fear they could be left behind in the race for orders and projects.

site_title: EU court should be guarantor of expats' rights after Brexit
summary: The European Union's chief Brexit negotiator, Michel Barnier, stated that the EU court should be the ultimate guarantor of expats' rights after Brexit. He emphasized the need for progress on citizens' rights, the exit bill, and borders before talks on a wider future relationship can start. Barnier warned that Britain's opposition to the EU court's role would create uncertainty, while dismissing accusations that the Brexit bill was a ransom bill. He also expressed skepticism about the UK's claims, saying "I'm not hearing any whistling, just the clock ticking."

site_title: Merkel and Macron sweeten EU path for volatile western Balkans
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Emmanuel Macron will host a summit in Trieste, Italy, to offer incentives to western Balkan countries to join the EU. The region, which includes 20 million people, is struggling to integrate with the bloc due to challenges such as economic and democratic values. The EU is offering 220 million euros in aid for infrastructure projects and endorsing a regional economic area. The goal is to stabilize the volatile region and counter Russia's influence, with Serbia aiming to join the EU by the end of the decade.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.210 points to 1,757.240 on Wednesday, with a trading volume of 1.786 billion lots worth RM1.770 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 460 to 362, indicating a positive market trend.

site_title: Microsoft creates new AI lab to take on Google's DeepMind
summary: Microsoft is establishing a new AI research lab, Microsoft Research AI, at its headquarters in Redmond, Washington, to develop more general-purpose learning systems. The lab aims to combine disciplines like perception, learning, and natural language processing to create a single system that can tackle various tasks and problems. This effort competes with other AI research companies, including Google's DeepMind and OpenAI. Microsoft plans to hire experts in cognitive psychology and partner with the Center for Brains, Minds and Machines at MIT, while also creating an advisory panel to oversee AI ethics.

site_title: Singapore shares close nearly 10 points lower
summary: Singapore shares closed 9.89 points lower on Wednesday, down 0.31% to 3,208.91, as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy testimony. The Straits Times Index dropped despite a mixed broader market, with DBS Group Holdings and Genting Singapore among the main movers. The session marked the second straight day of losses.

site_title: Giant iceberg breaks off Antarctica
summary: A 5,800 square km iceberg, one of the largest on record, broke away from Antarctica's Larsen C Ice Shelf between July 10-12, scientists said. The 1 trillion tonne iceberg poses a hazard for ships and may break into fragments, with some parts drifting north into warmer waters. The calving reduces the ice shelf's area by 12% and may contribute to sea-level rise if the shelf collapses. Scientists say the rift is not linked to manmade climate change, but the ice shelf has warmed in recent decades, increasing the risk of further calving events.

site_title: UK minister blames media gossip as May faces new questions
summary: UK Justice Secretary David Lidington blamed media gossip for the scrutiny on Prime Minister Theresa May's position, saying the government should focus on real problems. Former cabinet minister Andrew Mitchell reportedly told a dinner that May must resign due to losing authority, but downplayed the claim. May insists she'll remain prime minister, despite losing her parliamentary majority. US President Donald Trump said a trade deal with the UK will be done quickly, but the Confederation of British Industry urged caution. German industry groups warn Britain cannot rely on German industry to secure a good Brexit deal.

site_title: Takata recalls 2.7m more airbags, citing new hazard
summary: Takata recalls an additional 2.7 million airbags due to a new hazard detected in inflaters that use calcium sulfate, which can rupture and deploy metal shards into vehicles. This recall adds to the ongoing effort to replace 70 million airbag inflaters in 42 million vehicles. The hazard is linked to exposure to moisture and temperature fluctuations, and 17 deaths worldwide, including 12 in the US, have been linked to Takata inflaters. The recall affects vehicles manufactured from 2005 to 2012, with Ford, Mazda, and Nissan installing the affected inflaters.

site_title: China releases first Crown Resorts staff jailed for gambling crimes
summary: China released 10 employees of Crown Resorts Ltd, the first of 16 detained for illegally promoting gambling, on July 12. The employees, including four Australians, were sentenced to 9-10 months in jail in June. The release comes after Crown shifted its focus to its home market following the incident. Another six employees were released from a second facility, with one relative expressing hope for the company's future actions. Crown's head of international VIP gambling, Jason O'Connor, is set to be released on August 12.

site_title: British pay growth lags further behind inflation, but jobless rate drops
summary: British workers' pay growth fell further behind inflation in the three months to end-May, with the jobless rate hitting a 42-year low at 4.5%. The data complicates the debate on interest rates. Sterling rose against the dollar after the unemployment rate fell below forecast. The UK economy shrank for the second month, dealing a fresh blow to Prime Minister Starmer.

site_title: Australia blows the whistle on moving house by rail
summary: Australian rail chiefs are warning passengers not to move house by rail, citing safety concerns and potential fines. Footage shows passengers struggling to transport oversized items, such as a refrigerator and a three-seater sofa, on trains. Queensland Rail is urging customers to book removalists instead, citing the risk of injury and obstruction. The rail authority has posted videos on social media to remind passengers of the rules, with fines of up to A$252 for violating the rules. The campaign aims to prevent accidents and ensure a smooth commute.

site_title: YuuZoo CFO quits, sixth person to leave the post since the firm's 2014 listing
summary: YuuZoo's CFO, Raul Ikonen, has resigned four months after being appointed, citing "personal reasons" for moving back to Finland. This is the sixth CFO to leave the firm since its 2014 listing. The resignation has no impact on the company's stock price, which closed unchanged at 7.4 Singapore cents. The move raises concerns about YuuZoo's leadership stability, following a series of high-level departures.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Seoul: Won climbs to near 2-week high, stocks slip
summary: The South Korean won reached a near two-week high, closing at 1,145.1 against the US dollar, amid US President Donald Trump's son releasing emails showing he welcomed Russia's support for his father's 2016 election campaign. This led to a decline in the US dollar, boosting the won. Meanwhile, South Korean shares slipped 0.2% at 2,391.77 points, despite offshore investors buying 89.1 billion won worth of local equities.

site_title: Katrina partners Ajisen China to push 'So Pho' brand in China, HK
summary: Katrina Group partners with Ajisen China to launch the "So Pho" brand in China and Hong Kong through a joint-venture company, So Pho International. Katrina will hold a 30% stake in the venture, with funding for working capital provided by both companies. The partnership aims to expand Katrina's geographical reach in China and enter the Hong Kong market. Ajisen China, a leading fast-casual restaurant chain operator, will manage restaurants, snack bars, and cafes serving Vietnamese-style dishes under the "So Pho" brand.

site_title: BOE's Broadbent says he's not ready to raise rates just yet
summary: Bank of England Deputy Governor Ben Broadbent stated he's not ready to vote for higher interest rates, despite seeing pressures to do so. The Monetary Policy Committee voted 5-3 to keep rates on hold last month, amid a diverging economy with inflation above target due to the pound's slump since the Brexit vote. The next decision is on August 3, when the committee will also publish new economic forecasts, and some officials are making cases for tightening policy.

site_title: Sincap asked to hold EGM to remove directors
summary: SINCAP Group has received a requisition letter to convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to remove its directors, according to a filing on the Singapore Exchange. The company is advising shareholders to exercise caution before making any decisions regarding their shares. The notice was received from "certain shareholders" and is being reviewed to ensure compliance with the Companies Act.

site_title: SPH Reit reports 0.7% increase in Q3 DPU
summary: SPH Reit reported a 5.4% increase in net property income to S$42.2 million in Q3, driven by proactive management of expenses. The Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) rose 0.7% to 1.37 Singapore cents, exceeding expectations. This 2% increase in income available for distribution to S$35.7 million was also reported. The Reit's performance was attributed to effective management of expenses, contributing to the 0.7% increase in DPU.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Opec's first 2018 outlook shows it's still pumping too much oil
summary: Opec's first 2018 outlook shows the group is still pumping too much oil, despite cutting output. The organization's production exceeded demand in the first half of 2017, with 32.6 million barrels a day in June. Opec's output is expected to exceed demand in 2018, with the group aiming to reduce the global surplus by 70 million barrels in the second half. The cuts implemented by Opec and Russia since the start of the year may not be deep enough to clear the global glut, and US shale-oil producers are gearing up to fill in any shortfall.

images.alt_text: Opec's first assessment of world markets in 2018 showed that, despite cutting output, the group is still pumping too much crude.

site_title: Singapore banker admits to money laundering in 1MDB-linked case
summary: A former Singapore banker, Yeo Jiawei, pleaded guilty to money laundering in a 1MDB-linked case. He admitted to laundering funds and also cheated his former employer. Yeo's 30-month jail term is the longest in Singapore's probes linked to 1MDB. The case involves Malaysian financier Low Taek Jho, who has denied any wrongdoing. Singapore has imposed penalties on eight banks, with five people, including Yeo, convicted in the country's 1MDB probes.

site_title: Indonesia president inks decree to ban radical groups
summary: Indonesia President Joko Widodo has signed a decree allowing the government to ban groups that oppose the official state ideology, Pancasila, which promotes pluralism and tolerance. The law empowers the government to disband groups that challenge Pancasila without trial, targeting radical Islamists in the country. The decree is seen as aimed at disbanding Hizb ut-Tahrir Indonesia, a radical Islamist group, and also bans mass organisations spreading ideologies such as atheism and communism. Rights activists warn that the decree could stifle democratic institutions and freedom of association and expression.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end higher, bucking Asia trend
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.64% for a third-straight day, bucking a broader Asia-wide sell-off, driven by a rebound in oil prices. The Hang Seng Index reached 26,043.64, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices fell 0.17% and 0.11%, respectively. The rally in Hong Kong was attributed to energy firms benefiting from the oil price increase.

site_title: BMW Group June sales up 2.1% as sales of 5 series fall
summary: BMW Group reported a 2.1% increase in June car sales worldwide, despite a decline in Germany and a drop in 5 series sales. The 5 series sales fell 7.9% due to unavailability of a long-wheelbase variant in China. Production shortages were caused by delays in components from Bosch and a Takata airbag issue. Total passenger car sales reached 232,620, with 192,873 being BMW branded cars.

site_title: Deutsche Bank targets Saudis in 'massive' wealth management push
summary: Deutsche Bank is targeting Saudi Arabia in its wealth management push, aiming to recoup assets lost after concerns about its capital levels prompted clients to leave. The bank plans to hire 20 private bankers and expand its product offerings to attract new money. Economic reforms in Saudi Arabia present "incredible potential" for the bank, with the kingdom expected to become more attractive to foreign lenders as it overhauls its economy. Deutsche Bank is one of several global banks investing in the kingdom, seeking to reap the rewards from wealth management and investment-banking services.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank AG is targeting the Middle East as a priority region in wealth management as the bank seeks to recoup assets that were lost late last year when concerns about its capital levels prompted some clients to leave.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 0.9% year-over-year in May but fell 1% month-over-month. The Land Transport Authority plans to install 3,000 bicycle parking lots at 28 MRT stations. OCBC and Great Eastern are in talks to sell their combined stake in United Engineers Limited. Singapore signed agreements to advance international civil aviation development. Yeo Jiawei, a former banker, admitted to money laundering in a 1MDB-linked case. Singapore shares ended nearly 10 points lower, awaiting US Federal Reserve's monetary policy testimony.

site_title: Indonesia says unlikely to need to import gas until at least 2020
summary: Indonesia is unlikely to need to import natural gas until at least 2020 due to robust domestic production, according to a senior government official. The country has increased gas consumption targets for environmental reasons and plans to subsidize natural gas for industrial buyers. Indonesia's Director General of Oil and Gas, Wiratmaja Puja, stated that production has exceeded expectations, without providing further details.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is unlikely to need to import natural gas until at least 2020 due to robust production at home, a senior government official said on Wednesday.

site_title: Razer is said to target an IPO at up to US$5b valuation
summary: Razer, a gaming gear maker, is targeting a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) with a potential valuation of up to $5 billion, according to people familiar with the matter. The company aims to list around October and use the funds to develop its own mobile phone and expand into China's $25 billion gaming market. Razer has sold $1 billion worth of products globally in the past three years and counts gaming hardware as its main source of revenue.

site_title: Singapore signs agreements to advance development of international civil aviation
summary: Singapore signed two agreements to advance international civil aviation, focusing on leadership and research. A two-day executive programme on aviation security will be conducted with the International Civil Aviation Organization from 2018 to 2020, targeting directors-general of civil aviation. A memorandum of understanding was also signed between CAAS and SUTD for research collaboration, covering areas such as innovation and talent. The agreements aim to enhance Singapore's role in international civil aviation development.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Oil extends advance toward US$46 on signs US stockpiles declined
summary: Oil prices rose, extending gains toward US$46 a barrel, as US industry data showed crude and gasoline stockpiles declined. Crude inventories fell by 8.13 million barrels last week, and gasoline supplies shrank by 801,000 barrels. If the decline is replicated in government data, it will be the biggest decrease since September. Oil remains in a bear market due to concerns over global supply, but a decline in US production and inventory data may lead to higher prices.

site_title: Ophir to cut 15% jobs amid oil price glut
summary: Ophir Energy Plc announced plans to cut 15% of its global workforce, mainly in corporate roles and expatriate positions, to save an estimated $10-12 million annually. The company also lowered its full-year production forecast to 12,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day due to slower-than-expected production at its Kerendan gas field.

site_title: LTA to call tender to install 3,000 bicycle parking lots at 28 MRT stations
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore plans to install 3,000 bicycle parking lots at 28 MRT stations, with 1,700 more to be added at Downtown Line 3 stations. The new parking lots will be located in housing estates and stations with high cyclist traffic. Additionally, 34 new bicycle parking zones will be added at existing MRT stations and bus stops, accommodating 1,400 bicycles.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Wednesday, with the FTSE 100 index up 0.5% to 7,367.07 points. The DAX 30 in Frankfurt climbed 0.3% to 12,469.85 points, and the CAC 40 in Paris grew 0.3% to 5,158.23 points. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower as strong yen weighs
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Wednesday due to a strong yen, which negatively impacted Japan's exporters, and banks. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.48% to 20,098.38, while the Topix index declined 0.48% to 1,619.34. Investors await Fed chief Janet Yellen's remarks later in the day.

site_title: Australia shares end at 3-week lows as financial stocks weigh; NZ softer
summary: Australian shares fell to a three-week low on Wednesday, ending at 5,673.8, down about 1% due to financial stocks trailing US peers amid Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's upcoming testimony. Healthcare stocks also declined, with CSL Ltd losing 2.5%. New Zealand's benchmark index finished 0.6% lower. The decline was attributed to cautious investors awaiting US earnings reports and Yellen's comments on monetary policy tightening.

site_title: Australians are divided over their economy like never before
summary: Australian companies are optimistic about the economy, with business confidence at a post-2008 crisis high, but consumer sentiment remains low. Pessimists outnumbered optimists for the eighth-straight month, as households struggle with stagnant wages and debt. This divide is unusual, highlighting the differing views on the nation's economic performance.

site_title: Qatar's first air shipment of cows lands amid Saudi-led boycott
summary: Qatar has successfully received its first air shipment of 165 dairy cows from Germany, marking a significant step in addressing food shortages caused by the Saudi-led boycott. The shipment is expected to produce milk immediately and supply about 30% of Qatar's dairy needs when all cows are flown in over the next month. The boycott, which began in June, has disrupted trade and forced Qatar to open new routes to import food, building materials, and equipment for its natural gas industry.

images.alt_text: The first batch of an anticipated 4,000 dairy cows was flown into Qatar Tuesday, five weeks after the start of a Saudi Arabia-led boycott of the Gulf country.

site_title: Malaysia May factory output up 4.6% y-o-y, beats forecast
summary: Malaysia's industrial production in May rose 4.6% from the previous year, exceeding expectations. The growth was driven by the manufacturing and electricity sectors. Economists had forecast a 4.2% growth rate, which would have been unchanged from the previous month. The Statistics Department reported the data, indicating a stronger-than-expected performance.

site_title: China detains 35 Japanese nationals for alleged fraud: Japanese govt
summary: China has detained 35 Japanese nationals in the southeastern province of Fujian for alleged involvement in telephone scams targeting residents in Chiba prefecture, east of Tokyo. The detainees are suspected of using scams to defraud elderly individuals. The Japanese government has been notified of the detention, and Chinese authorities are conducting an investigation.

site_title: Goldman, JPMorgan, HSBC vie for lead roles on UAE Adnoc retail unit IPO
summary: Abu Dhabi's state-owned oil company Adnoc is planning to list its retail business, which manages 300 petrol stations and convenience stores, before the end of the year. Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan, HSBC, and First Abu Dhabi Bank are vying for lead roles in the initial public offering (IPO). The listing aims to boost Adnoc's valuation amid low oil prices. This move could also revitalize the UAE's lacklustre IPO scene, which has seen only two IPOs in 2017 so far.

site_title: Apple sets up China data centre to meet new cybersecurity rules
summary: Apple has set up its first data centre in China, in partnership with Guizhou-Cloud Big Data Industry Co Ltd, to comply with the country's new cybersecurity laws. The facility, valued at $1 billion, will allow Apple to improve product and service speed while meeting regulations requiring cloud services to be operated by Chinese companies. The company has stated it has strong data privacy and security protections in place, with no backdoors to be created in its systems. This move follows China's June 1 cyber security law, which mandates data storage within China and security reviews.

images.alt_text: Apple Inc has set up its first data centre in China, in partnership with a local internet services company, to comply with tougher cybersecurity laws introduced by Beijing last month, it said on Wednesday.

site_title: Sterling dips after BOE's Broadbent says not ready to hike interest rates
summary: Sterling drops to a two-week low against the US dollar and its lowest in eight months against the euro after Bank of England deputy governor Ben Broadbent expressed hesitation to raise interest rates, citing "a lot of imponderables." The pound fell around a quarter of a percent to US$1.2815 and weakened to 89.49 pence per euro, its lowest since Donald Trump's election. Broadbent's comments indicate the Bank of England may not be ready to hike interest rates, providing a boost to the pound.

site_title: Justin Bieber's Singapore show organiser seeks China expansion
summary: Unusual Ltd, the organiser of Justin Bieber's upcoming Singapore concert, plans to double its number of shows by next year, targeting China's second-tier cities and Southeast Asian capitals. CEO Leslie Ong believes these cities have great potential due to population and limited concert events, with a "hungry crowd" eager for such events.

site_title: Yanlord is said to join Perennial in United Engineers offer
summary: Yanlord Land Group Ltd is partnering with Perennial Real Estate Holdings Ltd to bid for Singapore's century-old property group United Engineers Ltd. The consortium plans to announce an agreement to buy Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp's stakes in United Engineers and its WBL Corp subsidiary, then make an offer for the rest of the company, valued at S$1.73 billion.

site_title: Japanese PM Abe promises to help victims of floods; death toll up to 25
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe visited a flooded region on the island of Kyushu, promising the government's assistance in rebuilding. Torrential rain caused landslides and flooding, displacing over 400,000 people and resulting in a death toll of 25, with 23 still missing.

site_title: China's yuan firms as US dollar weakens on worries over Trump's Russian connection
summary: China's yuan strengthened against the US dollar on renewed concerns over President Donald Trump's alleged Russian connection, with the midpoint rate reaching 6.7868 per dollar. The US dollar weakened amid traders' anticipation of Fed Chair Yellen's testimony to Congress and a commentary piece on yuan reforms.

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 0.9% y-o-y in May, down 1% m-o-m
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 0.9% year-over-year in May, but declined 1% month-over-month. Excluding car sales, the increase was 0.6%. However, excluding cars, sales fell 3% month-over-month. These results contrast with April's 0.6% year-over-year increase.

site_title: Facebook expands ad testing on Messenger globally
summary: Facebook is expanding its ad testing on Messenger globally, following initial tests in Australia and Thailand. The ads will be displayed on the home tab of the Messenger app and users can click through to the advertiser's website or a chat window. This move aims to further monetize the popular chat service, which already allows businesses to have conversations with its 1.2 billion monthly users. The expansion is part of Facebook's efforts to diversify its revenue streams, with mobile ads accounting for 85% of its ad revenue.

site_title: Singapore ready to embark on automatic exchange of financial account information relationship with Indonesia
summary: Singapore is set to establish a bilateral relationship with Indonesia for the automatic exchange of financial account information, following Singapore's signing of the Multilateral Competent Authority Agreement (MCAA) under the Common Reporting Standard (CRS). This move aims to create a level playing field with other key financial centers. Indonesia has been listed as one of Singapore's intended partners under the MCAA. The Automatic Exchange of Financial Account Information (AEOI) relationship is expected to facilitate cooperation between the two countries in combating tax evasion and promoting transparency in the financial sector.

site_title: Frustrated Mercator Lines judicial manager jettisons old lifeline, searches for new investors
summary: Mercator Lines' judicial manager has terminated an agreement with Nickolaos Mitropoulos and Dimitrios Podaridis due to their failure to meet conditions, despite several extensions of time. The agreement, signed in April, aimed to transfer the company's listing status and provide recovery to shareholders and creditors. The judicial manager will now search for new investors to achieve this goal. This marks the second attempt to secure a new lifeline for the struggling shipping company.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as yen rebounds
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, July 12, 2017, as the yen rebounded against the dollar, weighing on Japanese exporters. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index slipped 0.27% to 20,140.14, while the Topix index fell 0.25%. The decline was attributed to the yen's strengthening, which negatively impacted Japanese exporters.

site_title: Toyota invests US$100m in fund for AI, robotic startups
summary: Toyota Motor Corp has launched Toyota AI Ventures, a US$100 million venture capital business focused on investing in AI and robotic startups. The first three companies to receive funding are those developing driver monitoring cameras, autonomous car mapping algorithms, and robotic companions for the elderly. Toyota aims to support innovative research and potentially acquire promising startups, smoothing the startup journey and expanding its artificial intelligence and robotics capabilities.

site_title: Private apartment, condo rents rise 0.5% m-o-m in June; HDB flat rents ease 0.6%
summary: Singapore's non-landed private home rents rose 0.5% in June, while HDB flat rents fell 0.6% compared to the previous month, according to SRX Property's flash estimates. This marks a 3.2% year-on-year decline in private apartment rents, with 4,250 units rented in June. In contrast, HDB flat rentals decreased 8.8% from May, and 7.3% from June 2016.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: COE supply for Aug to Oct dips to 9,122 per month
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) announced that the monthly COE supply for August to October will be 9,122, a decrease from the 10,568 monthly average in the preceding period. This results in a total of 27,370 COEs for the three months. Category C, commercial vehicles, will see the largest drop in supply per month, averaging 888, down from 2,168 previously. Category A, smaller cars, will also experience a decrease, averaging 3,630 COEs per month, down from 3,797.

site_title: Seoul: Won up as US dollar sags on Trump, stocks little changed
summary: The South Korean won rose to a one-week high of 1,145.2 to the US dollar, driven by the weakening of the greenback following the release of emails that sparked controversy over US President Donald Trump's administration. The won's gain was largely influenced by the overnight drop in the US dollar. South Korean shares also traded relatively flat, with the Kospi index at 2,394.40 points, little changed from the previous close. Tech giant Samsung Electronics and Hyundai Motor edged up, while decliners outnumbered advancers.

site_title: US firms in China decry local favouritism as market improves
summary: US companies in China report revenue growth, but remain concerned about local favouritism and unfair policies, according to a survey by the American Chamber of Commerce. 73.5% of 426 companies surveyed reported revenue growth in 2016, but many expressed concerns about Beijing's "Made in China 2025" policies and state-driven company mergers, which they say favour local firms over foreign ones. The survey also highlighted concerns over regulatory transparency, intellectual property protections, and China's new cybersecurity law, which restricts foreign firms' participation in the cloud market.

images.alt_text: More US companies in China are reporting revenue growth so far in 2017 but remain concerned that Beijing's policies and regulations unfairly favour local competitors, according to a survey released on Wednesday.

site_title: Taiwan says Chinese carrier sails into its defence zone
summary: China's aircraft carrier Liaoning entered Taiwan's air defence identification zone on July 12, 2017, while en route from Hong Kong. Taiwan's defence ministry stated there was no cause for alarm, citing routine drills and monitoring the situation. The Liaoning's visit was the fourth time it had sailed near Taiwan in recent months, amid China's continued claims of sovereignty over the self-ruled island.

site_title: Australia shares pulled down by banks, healthcare shares; NZ softens
summary: Australian shares fell 0.7% on Wednesday, weighed down by financial stocks and healthcare shares, as investors awaited US Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's testimony and earnings reports from major US banks. The Aussie benchmark index closed at 5,691, with big banks and healthcare stocks losing 1-1.4% and 1.4% respectively. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.4%, dragged down by telecom and industrial stocks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.44% at open, pushing a rally into its third day, driven by a rebound in oil prices. The Hang Seng Index reached 25,991.35, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index remained flat and eased slightly, respectively. The rally follows a broader market trend, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: US dollar pressured by Trump Jr emails, focus on Yellen testimony
summary: The US dollar declined in early Asian trading on July 12, 2017, as investors digested emails released by Donald Trump Jr. suggesting Russia's involvement in the 2016 US presidential election. Despite this, the dollar remains supported by divergent monetary policy expectations between the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen is set to testify on Wednesday, with investors parsing her remarks for clues on when the Fed will start reducing its balance sheet.

site_title: Takata recalls 2.7m air bags that have drying agent
summary: Takata Corp is recalling an additional 2.7 million airbag inflators in the US, bringing the total to 68 million, due to a potential explosion risk in a crash. The inflators were made from 2005 to 2012 and used in vehicles from Nissan, Mazda, and Ford. The recall comes after 18 deaths worldwide and 11 in the US, with costs estimated at $17.9 billion. The company has filed for bankruptcy and is seeking court protection to sell its assets.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, Great Eastern, United Engineers, Perennial, Yanlord Land
summary: OCBC, Great Eastern, United Engineers, Perennial Real Estate, and Yanlord Land Group have seen new developments that may affect trading. A bidder has been shortlisted for United Engineers, while Perennial Real Estate requested a trading halt. Yanlord Land Group also halted trading before market open. The developments follow a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Yanlord Land requests for trading halt
summary: Yanlord Land Group, a Singapore-listed real estate developer, requested a trading halt of its shares on July 12, 2017, amid its acquisition of Greens Investments in Zhuhai, China, for 600 million yuan. The shares closed lower by 1.5 cents on Tuesday at S$1.725.

site_title: Australia consumer mood stays dark despite brighter signs: survey
summary: Australian consumer sentiment edged 0.4% higher in July, but remained dark due to pessimists outnumbering optimists. The Melbourne Institute and Westpac Bank survey found the index reading of 96.6 was 2.5% lower than last year, contradicting upbeat business polls that show firms feel conditions are strong. Despite some promising signs, such as improved retail sales and employment, analysts note that business surveys have a closer correlation to the broader economy, suggesting the disparity may resolve itself in a favorable manner.

site_title: Uber said to see financial growth, possible Waymo settlement
summary: Uber reported a 10% increase in gross bookings and narrowing losses, with executives citing a possible settlement with Alphabet's Waymo in the works. The company also increased booking fees in the US and Canada, generating an additional $1.50 to $3 per fare. Despite a shallow leadership bench, Uber's executives expressed confidence in the company's growth and ability to address its challenges. The Waymo lawsuit is expected to be resolved before a scheduled court date in October, with both companies preparing for a potential trial.

site_title: Google Earth to let users post stories, photos in coming years
summary: Google Earth is set to allow users to post stories, photos, and videos on the platform within the next 2-3 years. The "Voyager" tool, which currently features guided tours led by experts, will give users the ability to create their own unedited content. The feature aims to allow users to share personal stories, such as family history or hiking trips, without the need for editing. Google has ruled out advertising on the platform, with the goal of making Google Earth a "gift to the world."

site_title: Tiny Hong Kong homes offer big opportunity for storage firms
summary: Hong Kong's tiny apartments are creating a demand for self-storage facilities, with the majority of residents seeking space for non-essential belongings. The city's self-storage supply is significantly underdeveloped, with only 0.44 square feet per person, compared to the US average of 7.8 sq ft. Investors like Blackstone Group LP are capitalizing on this opportunity, with one unit costing HK$400 for a 20 sq ft space. The sector is expected to post 3-5% annual growth, driven by the growing middle class and rising death rate, with around three-quarters of customers being individuals, including those who have combined households or inherited belongings.

site_title: North Korean defectors down as border tightened: Seoul
summary: North Korea's number of defectors to South Korea decreased by 20.8% in the first half of 2017, with 593 entering the country, compared to 741 in the same period in 2016. Most defectors, 85%, are women, who face risks of being repatriated if caught. The North's tightened border controls and strengthened grip on the population have made it more difficult for defectors to escape. This decline in defectors is attributed to leader Kim Jong-Un's crackdowns on defectors and tightened border controls since 2011.

site_title: Oil rises 2.5% after surprisingly large US crude stock draw
summary: Oil prices rose 2.5% after a larger-than-expected decline in US crude stockpiles. US crude inventories fell 8.1 million barrels to 495.6 million, exceeding analyst forecasts of a 2.9 million-barrel decrease. Gasoline inventories also declined, while distillate stocks built. The American Petroleum Institute attributed the cuts to reduced US oil production.

site_title: Aussie gains altitude as kiwi bulls bail out
summary: The Australian dollar rose to US$0.7657, surpassing its US$0.7587 low, driven by a rally in iron ore and upbeat domestic data, despite US currency volatility due to President Trump's election campaign emails. The Aussie surged 1.2% against the New Zealand dollar, reaching a six-week peak of NZ$1.0591, as traders shorted the kiwi against the Aussie. Analysts at Westpac recommended shorting the kiwi, citing moderating NZ data and benign inflation pressures.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar pushed ahead against a generally softer US currency on Wednesday, a marked contrast to its New Zealand counterpart which suffered a sudden setback as speculators bailed out of crowded long positions.

site_title: Donald Trump Jr's Russia meeting creates more legal jeopardy
summary: Donald Trump Jr's meeting with a Russian attorney in June 2016, which included then-campaign chairman Paul Manafort and Jared Kushner, has raised more legal jeopardy. The email chain, which Trump Jr released, contradicts previous denials of meetings with Russians about the election. The meeting involved a woman claiming to have damaging information about Hillary Clinton, and Trump Jr's comments about receiving "helpful information" from someone connected to the Russian government may be considered soliciting a foreign contribution. The incident is now likely to be examined by special counsel Robert Mueller and could lead to potential charges.

site_title: Aberdeen Asset Management launches 5 new funds in Singapore
summary: Aberdeen Asset Management has launched five new funds in Singapore, including the group's first multi-asset funds and Luxembourg-domiciled funds available to retail investors. The funds invest in areas such as catastrophe bonds, aircraft leasing, and corporate loans, typically accessed via closed-end structures. This expansion marks Aberdeen's first direct sales of Luxembourg-domiciled funds in Singapore under the Monetary Authority of Singapore's recognised scheme.

site_title: Abe seeks to avoid repeat of his swift demise a decade ago
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe returned to Tokyo after a curtailed European trip, facing a slide in public support and record low voter support. His unpopular policies and scandals, including a cronyism scandal, led to a heavy election defeat in a recent Tokyo election. Despite this, Abe is likely to hold onto his job until a party leadership election in autumn next year. The main opposition party, the Democratic Party, is weak, and no senior member of Abe's ruling Liberal Democratic Party has emerged as a challenger, making it unlikely for him to lose power in the near future.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.44 points to 1755.94. The market saw 32.39 million lots traded worth RM13.39 million, with 81 gainers and 72 losers.

site_title: Amazon.com on pace to break sales record for 'Prime Day'
summary: Amazon's Prime Day sale is on track to break sales records, with customers ordering more than three times as many Echo-family speakers as during the same event last year. Third-party sales on Amazon's site increased by 50% by noon, with US Prime members driving the majority of purchases. The 30-hour sale, exclusive to Prime members, offered discounts and a timer to encourage shopping. This marks another milestone in Amazon's growth, highlighting the success of its Prime shopping club and voice-controlled Echo devices.

site_title: Intel rolls out new chips in battle for data centre business
summary: Intel Corp announced a new line of microprocessors for data centers, targeting companies like Google, Microsoft, and Amazon for their cloud computing needs. The Xeon Scalable Processor chips provide support for next-generation computing applications such as artificial intelligence and driverless cars. The new chips are designed to power data centers with thousands of computers, offering computing horsepower for customers who don't want to own and maintain their own systems. This move sets up a battle with Advanced Micro Devices for the lucrative data center business.

site_title: Nobel Design suspends trading
summary: Nobel Design shares suspended from trading due to a 10% drop in public shareholder ownership. The Singapore Exchange halted trading at 9 am on July 12, 2017. The company's takeover offer by OCBC closed with 97.28% of shares owned or agreed upon.

site_title: Ant Financial refiles for US approval of MoneyGram deal: sources
summary: Ant Financial, the affiliate of Alibaba Group, has refiled its $1.2 billion deal to buy MoneyGram International Inc for US review by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS). The deal was unable to secure clearance within the 75-day maximum time frame, prompting a resubmission. This is the latest high-profile transaction to be refiled with CFIUS this year, raising concerns about potential national security risks.

site_title: Football revenue records tumble in Britain : Deloitte
summary: The 92 Premier League and Football League clubs in Britain recorded combined revenues of £4.4 billion in the 2015/16 season, a 9% increase from the previous year. English topflight clubs generated £3.6 billion, with wage costs rising to 12% to £2.3 billion. The Premier League showed no signs of austerity, with its 20 clubs recording operating profits of over £500 million for the third consecutive season. Deloitte forecasts Premier League revenues to rise to over £4.5 billion in the 2017/18 season, with newly-promoted clubs set to benefit from a revenue uplift of at least £170 million.

site_title: China sends troops to Djibouti for opening of military base
summary: China has sent troops to Djibouti to establish its first overseas military base, which will serve as a logistics hub for naval vessels in the Indian Ocean. The base, located on the northwestern edge of the ocean, has raised concerns in India about becoming another "string of pearls" of Chinese military alliances. Construction of the base began last year, and it will resupply naval vessels participating in peacekeeping and humanitarian missions in Yemen and Somalia.

images.alt_text: Ships carrying Chinese military personnel for Beijing's first overseas military base, in Djibouti in the Horn of Africa, have left China to begin setting up the facility, state news agency Xinhua has reported.

site_title: US to review remaining Middle East airlines under laptop ban
summary: The US Department of Homeland Security plans to review three Middle Eastern airlines - Saudi Arabian Airlines, Royal Air Maroc, and EgyptAir - to lift the laptop ban restrictions. The review will assess the airlines' introduction of security measures to allow the ban to be removed at four airports. The restrictions, imposed in March, were initially lifted on six airlines, and the US government will work with airlines to implement enhanced security procedures, which could lead to additional screening time for passengers. The review is expected to be completed in coming weeks.

site_title: Air Canada jet nearly lands on taxiway in San Francisco
summary: A US Air Canada Airbus A320 nearly landed on a taxiway instead of a runway at San Francisco International Airport on Friday, prompting an FAA investigation. The plane was cleared to land on Runway 28-Right, but the pilot mistakenly lined up for Taxiway C. Fortunately, the incident did not result in any injuries or damage. The FAA is reviewing the incident to determine the cause and take necessary actions to prevent similar incidents in the future.

images.alt_text: US aviation authorities are looking into an incident involving an Air Canada plane which nearly landed on a crowded taxiway instead of a runway at San Francisco airport, officials said Tuesday.

site_title: Riding the BRI with partners for mutual win-win outcomes
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping emphasized the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) should be built into a road of prosperity and innovation. Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong also highlighted the potential of the BRI to promote regional cooperation and development. Companies like CNQC International Holdings Limited are expanding their regional footprint through BRI partnerships, creating a diversified financing system and investing in smart cities. This cooperation aims to achieve a win-win situation for both countries, leveraging Singapore's financial expertise and CNQC's innovative development strategies.

images.alt_text: CNQC's smart strategies comprise three domains: Smart Communities, Smart Homes and Smart Space.

CNQC (Qingjian) is applying advanced construction technology, Prefabricated Prefinished Volumetric Construction (PPVC), in its own mixed-use property development, Le Quest, which is poised to be launched.

site_title: OCBC, Great Eastern talks to sell UEL stake enter final stages; Perennial calls for trading halt
summary: OCBC Bank and Great Eastern Holdings Limited are in final stages of discussions with a shortlisted bidder to sell their combined stakes in United Engineers Limited (UEL) and its subsidiary WBL Corp Ltd. The transaction, worth S$1.8 billion, would not significantly impact OCBC's earnings. Perennial Real Estate, which had submitted a proposal, has requested a trading halt. The shortlisted bidder's identity remains undisclosed.

site_title: US eyes continued presence in Iraq after IS: general
summary: US General Stephen Townsend stated that the US and coalition countries aim to maintain a military presence in Iraq after the defeat of the Islamic State group. The Iraqi government has expressed interest in having US and coalition troops stay in the country. Discussions are in the final stages, with Townsend anticipating a coalition presence after ISIS' defeat. Currently, over 5,000 US troops are in Iraq, with a smaller future footprint expected to be housed in existing facilities.

site_title: Nod for Rickmers to sell nine remaining vessels for US$54m
summary: The trustee manager of Rickmers Maritime has received approval from the HSH Nordbank-led syndicate to sell nine remaining vessels for US$54 million to Navios Partners Containers Inc and Navios Partners Containers Finance Inc. This sale is part of the trust's plan to wind down its operations and follows an earlier sale of five vessels for US$59 million. The trust expects to pay US$27 million to unsecured creditors, representing an 11.4% recovery.

site_title: PE firm bets on Asia's healthcare industry
summary: Quadria Capital, a private equity firm focusing on healthcare, has invested in Singapore's MWH Holdings and Vietnam's FV Hospital, both multi-million dollar deals. The investments represent the sixth and seventh from Quadria Capital Fund LP, which has assets under management exceeding $1.5 billion. The investments aim to bring Singapore's specialist doctors and infrastructure to new markets, providing low-cost specialist healthcare in emerging markets, and increasing the capacity and capability of FV Hospital in Vietnam.

site_title: PM Lee: Singapore has to speak up on key issues to secure its space in the world
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the country's need to speak up on key issues to secure its position in the world, particularly on international law and disputes. He stressed the importance of small states being included in global processes like the G-20, but also highlighted the need for self-protection and advancement of interests. Lee's visit to Germany was productive, with him securing meetings with world leaders, including US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping, and calling for a stronger commitment to multilateral trade and climate action.

site_title: US looks to defuse Qatar-Gulf row with counter-terror deal
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson signed a counter-terrorism deal with Qatar, aiming to defuse the Gulf diplomatic crisis. The deal targets extremist financing, with Qatar being the "first to respond" to President Trump's call to stop funding terrorism. However, the Arab countries that imposed sanctions on Qatar dismissed the initiative as insufficient, citing concerns about Qatar's credibility in combating terrorism. Tillerson expressed hope for progress in resolving the crisis, but the diplomatic stalemate persists.

site_title: Europe: Defensives drag shares lower, Pearson drops after stake sale
summary: European shares ended Tuesday down 0.7% due to losses in defensive consumer staples and real estate stocks, outweighing gains in autos and miners. Consumer staples, including food and drink companies and household goods, fell 1.2%, while real estate stocks dropped 0.4%. Auto stocks rose 1% after Chinese passenger car sales increased. Pearson fell 5% after selling a 22% stake in Penguin Random House, and Marks & Spencer's shares dropped 4.7% despite a rise in full-price sales.

site_title: France to cut 11b euros in taxes next year: PM
summary: France's Prime Minister Edouard Philippe announced a 11 billion euro tax cut, exceeding the initial 7 billion euro plan, to boost investment and economic growth. The measure includes eliminating a local residence tax for 80% of households and reducing corporate taxes to 25% by 2022. The government aims to achieve 1.6% economic growth this year and 1.7% in the next 12 months, while keeping the budget deficit below 3% of GDP. This move follows President Emmanuel Macron's promise to reduce taxes by 20 billion euros over his five-year term.

site_title: JLo back with an ex - Marc Anthony for video
summary: Jennifer Lopez has released a music video for her single "Ni Tu Ni Yo (Neither You Nor Me)", which features her ex-husband Marc Anthony. The video shows the two embracing and posing together, sparking speculation about a possible reunion. Lopez and Anthony's marriage ended in divorce in 2014, but the video suggests they may be back on good terms. The song and video are now available on various music streaming platforms.

site_title: China envoy says North Korea trade growth picture 'distorted'
summary: China's ambassador to the US has disputed reports of a 40% increase in China's trade with North Korea, saying the data gives a "distorted picture". The trade growth, which was 37.4% year-on-year in the first quarter, contradicts US President Donald Trump's claims. The ban on coal imports from North Korea was announced in February, but trade continued to grow. The ambassador's comments suggest China's efforts to counter North Korea's nuclear and missile programs may be being misinterpreted.

site_title: VP Pence distances himself as Russia probe threatens Trump
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence sought to distance himself from the Russia probe, following President Donald Trump's son Donald Jr.'s admission to a meeting with a Russian lawyer offering dirt on Hillary Clinton. Pence claimed he knew nothing about the June meeting, which took place before he became Trump's running mate. Trump Jr. released emails showing the meeting, which critics say suggests the Trump campaign was prepared to collude with Russian efforts to undermine Clinton's presidential run. Pence stated he's focused on advancing the president's agenda, but the scandal threatens Trump's presidency.

site_title: New Jetstar-SATS partnership to boost customer ground and air experience
summary: Jetstar Asia has partnered with SATS Ltd to enhance airport and inflight customer experience. The airline has appointed SATS to supply catering and logistics on board all 18 aircraft, offering double the current meal options and seasonal menus. Passengers will also benefit from added-value promotions. The partnership includes a three-year ground-handling agreement, allowing Jetstar to build on operational efficiencies. The airline has also introduced self-service check-in and automated bag drops at Changi Airport, aiming to elevate customer experience.

site_title: Second presidential hopeful announced
summary: Farid Khan Kaim Khan, chairman of marine firm Bourbon Offshore Asia Pacific, has announced his candidacy for Singapore's upcoming Presidential Election, becoming the second person to do so. Born in Singapore to Pakistani parents, Khan is eligible to run despite the election being reserved for Malay candidates. He has 48 years of work experience and has expressed concerns about radicalism and strengthening trust among Singaporeans. Khan's candidacy comes as another potential candidate, Speaker of Parliament Halimah Yacob, has yet to make her decision known.

site_title: China-focused hedge funds rebound
summary: China-focused hedge funds rebounded from their worst performance in five years, adding over 13% in the first half of 2017, surpassing global counterparts. Despite global hedge funds averaging a 3% gain, China funds outperformed due to investor inflows, with many seeing redemptions in May for the first time since 2015. This marks a significant turnaround for China-focused hedge funds, which had suffered an annual loss in 2016.

site_title: Asian firms seek to shake up Chilean infrastructure: official
summary: Asian firms are seeking to enter Chile's infrastructure sector, which has traditionally been dominated by domestic and European companies. The country's concessions unit has over $2 billion in tenders scheduled for the end of the year, including a $600 million tender for Route 66. Chile aims to attract private investment to improve its ports, roads, and airports, with two presidential candidates pledging to expand the transport network.

site_title: Going digital enhances customer satisfaction
summary: A leading expert in digital transformation, Laurence Smith, emphasizes the importance of going digital to increase customer satisfaction. He notes that digital offers the opportunity to remove friction, engage customers deeper, and enhance the overall customer experience. However, it relies on the organization's understanding of digital and its leaders' ability to rethink the customer journey. To achieve this, organizations must develop a digital mindset, understand design thinking, and run small experiments. Smith advises businesses to harness technology to build a competitive advantage, rather than ignoring it. By doing so, they can create a culture of purposeful innovation, enrich the business world, and increase customer satisfaction.

site_title: Snapchat parent Snap slides below IPO price
summary: Snapchat parent Snap Inc. shares plummeted 8.7% to $15.50, falling below its IPO price of $17, after a Wall Street analyst expressed pessimism about the company's advertising products. Morgan Stanley analyst Brian Nowak stated that Snapchat's advertising products are not catching on as quickly as expected. This market action follows a disappointing outlook for the popular messaging service.

site_title: US: Stocks steady after midday Trump swoon
summary: US stocks finished essentially flat on Tuesday, rebounding from a mid-session slump sparked by Donald Trump Jr.'s interactions with Russian interests. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 21,409.07, while the S&P 500 dipped 0.1% to 2,425.53. Despite concerns over White House's Russia travails, investors concluded the Russia story is "still pretty contained." The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.3% to 6,193.30, with Boeing and General Electric among strong performers.

site_title: Building a hyper-connected, smarter world
summary: China Telecom is working to democratize global connectivity through its partnerships and infrastructure development. The company has partnered with Kazakhtelecom to deliver a low-latency network along the "Transit Silk Road" and is constructing a 20,000 km fibre-optic submarine cable, the SEA-ME-WE 5 cable, providing high-speed connections to 16 countries. This aims to foster regional connectivity along the Belt and Road route, promoting economic growth.

site_title: China on track to achieve 2017 growth target
summary: China is on track to achieve its 2017 growth target of 6.5% despite concerns over high corporate debt and a downgrade by credit rating agency Moody's. The country's unique debt structure, with more than 55% of corporate debt owed by state-owned enterprises, has given it more room to maneuver. China's policymakers have implemented tightening policies to curb debt, but the steady private sentiment and improving manufacturing outlook have largely balanced the negative effects. Private investment remains stable, and the country is expected to achieve its growth target.

site_title: From Silk Road trade to Belt and Road e-commerce
summary: Hangzhou, a city in China, was once the largest city in the world with a population of nearly two million people between 1200 and 1350. Its prosperity was driven by the Silk Road trade and well-developed transportation infrastructure. In recent years, Hangzhou has regained its significance, hosting the G-20 summit in 2016 and experiencing rapid e-commerce growth led by Alibaba. Today, Hangzhou remains a key hub for trade and commerce, with the city's economy continuing to thrive under the influence of the Belt and Road initiative.

site_title: Food prices to remain low globally over next decade: OECD, FAO
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) have jointly reported that global food commodity prices are expected to remain low over the next decade due to slowing demand growth. Real prices of agricultural and fish commodities are projected to decline slightly, except in least developed countries. However, the growth of agriculture and fisheries in South-east Asia has put pressure on natural resources, and the region needs to focus on sustainable development to avoid depletion of land and water resources.

site_title: Resale condo prices up 0.9% in June to hit 3-year high: SRX
summary: Resale condo prices in Singapore rose 0.9% in June to a 3-year high, according to SRX Property. The Core Central Region and Outside Central Region saw increases of 1.3% and 1.1% respectively, while the Rest of Central Region remained flat. Resale volumes decreased 12.5% from May, but surged 51.1% from last year. Experts predict the market will continue to recover, with prices expected to rise in 2018, driven by the pending launch of Martin Residences and government tweaks to cooling measures.

site_title: Trend-following quant funds are this year's biggest losers
summary: Quant funds that follow trends are experiencing their worst year since 1987, with commodity trading advisers (CTAs) posting a 5.4% loss in the first seven months of 2017. The decline is attributed to sector overcrowding, suppressed price moves due to central bank stimulus, and low cross-asset volatility. This year's poor performance is particularly concerning for investors who have poured money into managed futures, including CTAs, which now manage a record $350 billion in assets. Despite the challenges, some experts believe that higher volatility could benefit trend-following strategies in the long term.

site_title: The importance of keeping customers satisfied
summary: Neeta Lachmandas, executive director of the Institute of Service Excellence at SMU, emphasizes the importance of keeping customers satisfied for businesses and the Singapore economy. Higher customer satisfaction levels predict lower complaints, customer loyalty, and competitiveness. A more satisfied customer base implies greater stability in consumer spending, benefiting the economy. The CSISG model provides an objective benchmark for companies to track their performance year-on-year, allowing them to identify gaps and opportunities to optimize resources and invest in areas for higher customer satisfaction.

site_title: Tesla's sales seem stalling in Hong Kong as tax breaks end
summary: Tesla's sales appear to be stalling in Hong Kong after the government capped tax benefits for e-car buyers at HK$97,500 (S$17,280) starting April 1. This policy change, which is expected to last until March 2018, resulted in no new Tesla model registrations in April. Prior to the change, the city saw 2,939 first-time Tesla registrations in March and around five times that number in February. The policy shift may impact Tesla's sales in Hong Kong.

site_title: UK shoppers spend more on essentials as inflation rises
summary: UK households increased spending on food and essentials, with Barclays reporting 2.5% year-on-year growth in June, while the British Retail Consortium reported 2% growth. However, consumer spending growth slowed to a 15-month low due to rising prices and a cautious approach to discretionary purchases. The figures suggest that consumer demand has slowed further, with inflation running at a near four-year high of 2.9%.

site_title: Self-dependence vital for Asean states in relations with China
summary: Southeast Asian countries, known as Asean states, are adopting a unique approach to their relations with China, neither purely balancing nor bandwagoning. They are instead employing self-dependence, hedging diplomacy, and risk contingency strategies to maximize returns while avoiding dependency on China. This approach includes economic diversification, "dominance denial," and indirect balancing through military development. Asean states are seeking a peaceful and predictable world order with security guarantees from powerful countries and multilateral organizations, and their economic size, international ambitions, and military capability are becoming more dynamic yardsticks for measuring their influence.

site_title: UK fintech start-up Revolut raises US$66m, adds bitcoin
summary: UK fintech start-up Revolut raises $66 million in a fund-raising round, led by Index Ventures, to provide payment cards with interbank exchange rates and zero-fee international money transfers. Revolut, which has 700,000 customers, plans to expand into the US and Asia with the funding. The company, founded by Russian-born Nikolay Storonsky, says it will not be affected by Brexit, as it holds a UK e-money license. Revolut also announces the addition of digital currency bitcoin to its app.

site_title: Siemens opens its first global fully integrated digitalisation hub in Singapore
summary: Siemens has opened its first global fully integrated digitalisation hub in Singapore, aiming to help companies in the South-east Asia region digitalise. The hub has partnered with three local companies to develop smart solutions, including SP Group, ST Electronics, and Nanyang Technological University.

images.alt_text: Global technology giant Siemens opens its first fully integrated digitalisation hub in Singapore on Tuesday, with plans to help companies in the South-east Asia region digitalise.

site_title: Y Ventures up as much as 27.3% in first-day trading
summary: Y Ventures Group, a Singapore-based e-commerce retailer and distributor, made its debut on the Catalist exchange with its stock price rising 27.3% above its IPO price, closing at S$0.255. The company generated US$12.1 million in revenue and US$1.8 million in profit before tax in 2016. Its market capitalization is S$51 million, and management plans to declare dividends of at least 20% of net profits. The company's listing brings the number of Catalist-listed companies to 196, with a combined market capitalization of over S$12 billion.

site_title: SAL pilots programme to prepare lawyers for advances in AI
summary: The Singapore Academy of Law (SAL) has launched a two-year pilot programme, the Future Law Innovation Programme (FLIP), to prepare law firms for the disruption caused by advances in artificial intelligence (AI) technology. The programme, which begins in January, aims to help law firms adopt technology and "give form and substance" to the Legal Technology Vision. Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon emphasized the need for lawyers to adapt to new realities, citing the rise of AI-powered legal research tools like Ross. FLIP comprises three components: a co-working space, an online platform, and an accelerator programme linking law firms with startups and investors.

images.alt_text: Wong Shiying

site_title: Woodleigh site also draws robust bidding
summary: A residential site in Singapore's Bidadari estate, Woodleigh Lane, drew aggressive bidding with 15 participants, including CEL Unique Development's S$700.7 million (S$1,110 psf ppr) top bid. Analysts expect a breakeven price of S$1,500-1,600 psf and eventual sale price of S$1,800 psf. The site, near the Woodleigh MRT station, has been identified as a high-profile location, contributing to the intense bidding, with some experts anticipating a market recovery in 2018.
