summary: Zimbabwe's Steward Bank has suspended payments to South Africa's Naspers-owned Multichoice pay-TV company due to unavailability of foreign currency, exacerbating dollar shortages in the country. Local banks have limited withdrawals, and importers face long delays in paying for goods, forcing businesses to buy dollars on the parallel market. The suspension follows a series of measures by the central bank to ease the acute shortage of money, including setting priorities for imports and introducing a bond note currency.

site_title: Investors may find it hard to resist being 'complacent': Schroders
summary: A Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC warned investors about stretched market valuations and potential complacency, citing low economic growth rates and high valuations. Research firm Schroders noted rising equity markets and low volatility, which may indicate investor complacency. The economists warned that the next market shock could be geopolitical in origin, with the US Federal Reserve underestimating potential interest rate hikes. They cautioned that investors may be hard to resist complacency due to the risk of market bubbles, despite the Fed's cautious stance.

images.alt_text: Early Monday, Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC warned about stretched market valuations and investor complacency despite looming risks.
Angela Tan

site_title: Tokyo:Nikkei rises to more than 1-week high on yen; shipping sector surges
summary: Japanese stocks rose to a one-week high on Monday, with the Nikkei gaining 0.8% to 20,080.98. The gain was driven by US jobs data showing stronger-than-expected growth, lifting the dollar against the yen. The marine transport sector surged, with Nippon Yusen KK, Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha, and Mitsui OSK Lines Ltd jumping 1.4%, 2.9%, and 5.0% respectively. Tech shares also rose, while Japanese banking shares declined.

site_title: Life behind bars gets new twist in empty Dutch prisons
summary: A former Dutch prison in Breda, built in 1886, is now empty due to falling crime rates and changing ideas on punishment. The 130-year-old building, once a classic example of Panopticism, is being repurposed by 90 businesses, including a 3D VR start-up, which views the location as a perfect office space. The prison's 33,302 square meters of space is being reused for "social" projects, with interest from over 300 people. The building's history still casts a presence, but it's being transformed into a hub for start-ups and innovation, with some areas being used for events and activities.

site_title: Gold buyers flee a month after their most bullish bet of '17
summary: Gold's bullish bets have dwindled significantly as money managers rush to sell, with hedge funds' net-long positions falling 51% to 37,776 contracts in the week ending July 3. The metal's price has dropped for five consecutive weeks, despite geopolitical tensions. Central banks' interest rate hikes are seen as a major factor, with the Federal Reserve indicating more rate increases. Despite some analysts predicting a range of $1,200 to $1,300, others expect prices to drop further, with some forecasting a price of $1,165 in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: Total assets in SPDR Gold Shares, the world's top bullion ETF, fell to the lowest since March last week.

site_title: Barclays on hiring spree in Japan after cash equity exit
summary: Barclays is expanding its investment banking and market operations in Japan, hiring over 10 bankers and sales staff this fiscal year. The move comes after the firm cut 120 jobs and exited the cash equity business last year. Barclays Securities Japan Ltd president Kentaro Kiso aims to boost revenue by advising on mergers and selling investment products, citing low interest rates and increasing demand from Japanese companies seeking acquisitions abroad. The firm plans to hire around five to seven people to sell products to hedge funds and large banks.

site_title: M&A among top 50 consumer goods giants fall to US$50b in 2016: report
summary: Mergers and acquisitions among the top 50 consumer goods giants have declined significantly, from US$226 billion in 2015 to US$50 billion in 2016, according to a report by OC&C Strategy Consultants. The decline is attributed to low organic revenue growth and pressure from activist shareholders to boost margins. Political uncertainty, including the EU referendum and US presidential election, also likely contributed to the decrease in deal-making. The report notes that M&A had become a critical source of growth for these companies in recent years.

site_title: Weakened May appeals to opponents to help deliver Brexit success
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May is seeking cross-party cooperation to deliver Brexit success despite her weakened position after the general election. May will call on opposition lawmakers to help steer Britain out of the EU, acknowledging her loss of authority in Parliament. The government faces challenges from within its own party and opposition parties, with some calling for her resignation. May has received a boost from US President Donald Trump, but her weakened position has reopened the debate over how Brexit should unfold.

site_title: In Good Company: Marathon man Zafrul Aziz sets CIMB up for long haul
summary: Malaysia's No. 2 banking services company, CIMB Group, has posted a record net profit of RM1.18 billion and a 10.3% annualized return on equity (ROE) in the first quarter of 2017. The company's CEO, Tengku Datuk Seri Zafrul Aziz, has implemented cost-cutting measures, cross-selling, and data mining to yield fresh business streams. Zafrul, who took over as CEO in 2014, has also revamped the company's operating model, reduced staff, and improved efficiency. CIMB's market capitalization has increased by over 60% in the past year, and the company is focusing on growing its wholesale business in Singapore and expanding its presence in Asean markets.

site_title: Party may be over for this housing market that boomed for decade
summary: Israel's housing market, which has experienced a decade-long boom, may be slowing down. Rising mortgage rates have led to fewer investors buying homes, slowing down appreciation in home values. The average price of a three-bedroom apartment in Tel Aviv is around $920,000, pricing many out of the market. Lower home prices could mitigate risks to the financial system, where credit for construction and residential purposes is a significant portion of non-finance private-sector loans. A reversal of this trend could have significant social and economic implications for the country.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars restrained on US$, gain ground on yen
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars gained ground against the US dollar on Monday, but remained below recent highs. The Australian dollar was stuck at US$0.7610, while the New Zealand dollar rose to US$0.6710. The gains came as the Japanese yen weakened, driven by diverging global interest rate outlooks. Speculation about a potential interest rate hike by the Bank of Canada also contributed to the currencies' gains.

site_title: S.Korea: Stocks inch up at end of trading
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.1% to close at 2,382.10 points on Monday, despite foreign investors selling a net $50.32 million of KOSPI shares. This follows a global rally driven by the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records. Meanwhile, in Singapore, the Straits Times Index (STI) surged 0.4% on Thursday, with investors staying positive despite US tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Japan PM Abe to reshuffle cabinet as support plunges to lowest since 2012
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe plans to reshuffle his cabinet and ruling party leaders in August to address plummeting support, with his popularity at its lowest since returning to power in 2012. Abe will retain core officials, including Deputy Prime Minister Taro Aso and Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga, in the reshuffle. The move comes after a historic loss in a Tokyo assembly election, where a novice political group won a landslide victory, and amid concerns over Abe's economic policies and plans to revise the nation's postwar constitution.

site_title: Govt calls for public consultation on proposed Cybersecurity Bill
summary: The Ministry of Communications and Information and the Cyber Security Agency of Singapore have launched a public consultation on the proposed Cybersecurity Bill, aiming to establish a framework for national cyber security oversight and maintenance. The bill, set to be tabled in Parliament later this year, will empower the Cyber Security Agency to regulate critical information infrastructure owners and provide powers to manage cyber security threats. The consultation runs from July 10 to August 3, with the public invited to provide feedback on the proposed bill.

images.alt_text: The Ministry of Communications and Information (MCI) and the Cyber Security Agency of Singapore (CSA) have called for public feedback on the proposed Cybersecurity Bill which is likely to be tabled in Parliament later this year.

site_title: Seoul: Won rises focusing on US wage lag, stocks steady
summary: The South Korean won strengthened 0.3% against the US dollar to 1,150.6, despite higher-than-expected US jobs growth, as traders focused on sluggish wage gains. The won is expected to remain in a narrow range until the Bank of Korea's policy meeting on Thursday. South Korean shares rose 0.2%, with Samsung Electronics up 1.3% and LG Electronics down 2.3%. Offshore investors are expected to be net sellers, but analysts predict the won may strengthen further after the Bank of Korea's economic growth forecast.

site_title: Australia shares ride Wall Street higher; NZ post minor gains
summary: Australia's share market rose 0.7% on Monday, driven by a rally in financial and consumer stocks, following positive sentiment from Wall Street's gains on better-than-expected jobs data. The benchmark index gained 39.23 points to 5,742.80. Financial stocks, led by the 'Big Four' banks, and consumer cyclicals and durables sectors contributed to the gains. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.1% as gains in financial and technology stocks offset losses in consumer shares.

site_title: Chinese developer Sunac to buy US$9.3b of Wanda assets
summary: Chinese developer Sunac China Holdings plans to acquire US$9.3 billion worth of assets from Wanda, including 76 hotels and 13 projects, in a deal announced on July 10, 2017. Wanda, led by billionaire Wang Jianlin, had been a target of official scrutiny due to potentially risky loans stemming from overseas acquisitions. The acquisition is part of Wanda's efforts to reduce debt, which had been a concern following a wave of overseas investments. Details of the deal were not provided, but the acquisition is expected to be a significant move for both companies.

site_title: Myanmar workers in Thailand victims of a broken system
summary: Tens of thousands of Myanmar migrant workers fled Thailand in two weeks, fearing a new labor decree that increases fines on unregistered workers. The decree, part of Thailand's efforts to clean up its migrant labor sector, has sent migrant communities into panic. Despite dire poverty in Myanmar, many migrants chose to return home, citing the prospect of better wages and job security. The mass exodus highlights the precarious lives of migrant workers, who face exploitation and lack proper documentation. Economists blame the slump in Myanmar's economy on a lack of clarity on economic policies and slow progress in passing a new investment law.

images.alt_text: With only meagre belongings stuffed into backpacks and duffel bags, tens of thousands of Myanmar migrants have streamed home across the Thai border over the past two weeks.

site_title: Cambodia changes election law ahead of 2018 vote
summary: Cambodia's parliament amended the election law to ban people from associating with those convicted of a criminal offense, a move the opposition claims aims to hinder Prime Minister Hun Sen's rivals ahead of the 2018 general election. The law prohibits political parties from engaging with individuals with bans, and those violating it may face a five-year suspension or dissolution. The ruling Cambodian People's Party (CPP) voted in favor of the change, which is seen as a strategic move to limit opposition parties' influence.

site_title: All small claims to be filed online as new system kicks off
summary: Singapore's Small Claims Tribunals system has launched, allowing public to file claims online. The new system enables e-negotiation, online document submission, and online payments, streamlining the process. Parties can apply for a Tribunal Order online if a settlement is reached. The implementation of Community Disputes Resolution Tribunals and Employment Claims Tribunals will be rolled out from 2018.

site_title: Europe must claim tax due from US giants: France
summary: France's finance minister Bruno Le Maire urged European counterparts to increase efforts to collect taxes from US tech giants like Google, Amazon, and Facebook. Le Maire criticized the complex tax arrangements of multinational corporations that shift revenue across borders. He stated that the current era is not for the weak, emphasizing the need for stronger action. This issue has been a contentious topic, with the European operations of US tech giants slashing European tax bills. Le Maire's comments come after the G20 meeting in Hamburg, where he highlighted the importance of addressing this tax avoidance issue.

site_title: HR Industry Manpower Plan for future growth unveiled on Monday
summary: The Human Resource (HR) Industry Manpower Plan was unveiled on Monday, aiming to strengthen the HR profession, enhance HR support for employers, and nurture a vibrant HR services sector. The plan, developed by tripartite partners, is a key development to support employees and employers in Singapore's next phase of growth. It aligns with the 23 Industry Transformation Maps (ITMs) to promote growth and competitiveness in key sectors and create good jobs for Singaporeans. The plan is expected to unlock the potential of people and businesses for future growth.

images.alt_text: The Human Resource (HR) Industry Manpower Plan to transform the HR sector was unveiled on Monday, with tripartite partners welcoming it as a "timely and essential development to support employees and employers in Singapore's next phase of growth".

site_title: Asia: Stocks follow Wall Street higher after US jobs data beats forecasts
summary: Asian stocks rose on Monday, following a strong performance on Wall Street, with the MSCI's Asia-Pacific index advancing 0.15%. The US dollar extended gains after stronger-than-expected June employment data, pushing the 10-year US Treasury yield to a two-month high. The US dollar index also rose, while the euro declined. The rally was fueled by a "perfect storm" of strong headline growth and poor wage growth, according to Chris Weston, chief market strategist at IG.

site_title: Comac wins China's approval for mass production of regional jet
summary: Comac, a Chinese aircraft builder, has received approval from the Civil Aviation Administration of China to start mass production of its 90-seater ARJ21 regional jet. The plane, which took over a decade to design and build, aims to compete with models by Bombardier and Embraer, with 413 orders from 19 clients. Deliveries are expected to begin by the end of this year, with a target of five planes. The approval is part of China's "Made in China 2025" program, which aims to increase the country's technological and manufacturing prowess.

site_title: J&F ends Brazil's Alpargatas sale talks over price, source says
summary: J&F Investimentos SA has ended talks to sell a controlling stake in Alpargatas SA, a Brazilian footwear manufacturer, due to disagreements over price. The investment firms of Brazil's prominent banking clans, Cambuhy Investimentos Ltda and Itaúsa Investimentos SA, had offered 3.3-3.5 billion reais for an 86% stake in Alpargatas. J&F, led by billionaire Batista family members, had sought a higher price for the company, which manages a wide range of Brazilian fashion brands. The Batistas plan to sell Alpargatas through a competitive auction "as soon as possible" to raise cash and refinance debt.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks up on weak yen, rallies on Wall Street
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Monday, driven by US market gains and a weak yen. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index increased 0.60% to 20,048.78, while the Topix index gained 0.56%. The rally follows better-than-expected US pay roll figures and is expected to continue despite US President Trump's recent trade threats.

site_title: Fire ravages building in London's Camden Lock Market
summary: A large fire broke out in a building at London's Camden Lock Market, prompting a 70-firefighter response. The fire, which engulfed the first, second, and third floors, as well as the roof, was reported to be moving quickly. Witnesses described the flames as "tall" and "flying through the air." No casualties were reported, and the area was evacuated. The cause of the fire is not specified.

site_title: Vietnam's surprise rate cut may spur growth amid credit worries
summary: Vietnam's central bank unexpectedly cut interest rates for the first time in three years, lowering the refinance rate to 6.25% and the discount rate to 4.25%, to support economic growth and keep inflation under control. The move aims to boost loan demand and consumption, but raises concerns about increasing bad debt. The rate cuts come as the International Monetary Fund stressed the need to contain rapid credit growth, citing Vietnam's slow banking sector reforms and vulnerability to rapid economic expansion.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.2% higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index rising 7.73 points to 3,236.74, driven by 50 million shares worth S$40 million. The most actively traded stock was Jadason Enterprises, which rose S$0.004 to S$0.109. Gainers outnumbered losers 76 to 62, as investors continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Cosco Shipping offers US$6.3b to buy Orient Overseas
summary: Cosco Shipping Holdings Co offered US$6.3 billion to acquire Orient Overseas International Ltd, a Hong Kong-based container carrier, in a deal that would catapult the mainland Chinese group into the world's third-largest shipping line. The acquisition, which requires regulatory approvals and consent from Cosco's investors, would combine the two companies' capacities to surpass France's CMA CGM SA and move closer to AP Moller-Maersk A/S and Mediterranean Shipping Co. The deal, valued at HK$78.67 per share, represents a 31% premium over the stock's last closing price.

site_title: China producer price inflation steadies as demand remains robust
summary: China's producer price inflation remained steady at 5.5% in June, signaling robust demand despite regulatory curbs. The consumer price index rose 1.5% in June, slightly below forecast. Economists warn that strictures on real estate construction and credit growth may erode momentum later in the year, potentially slowing industrial production. Despite this, overall steady growth is expected with maintained industrial production momentum, according to UBS Group AG economist Zhang Ning.

site_title: China's big land grab: Records topple as developers splash out
summary: Chinese property developers are aggressively acquiring rivals and their land, with a record 96.7 billion yuan spent on acquisitions in the second quarter. This "mega-consolidation" is driven by tight credit, competition for land, and local government measures to cool home markets. Citigroup predicts the biggest 10 developers will boost their joint share of sales to 28% this year, with aggressive firms like China Evergrande and Country Garden Holdings set to drive this growth. Smaller developers are exiting the industry, and larger players are seizing opportunities to acquire land and assets.

images.alt_text: Chinese property developers are swallowing up rivals and their land at a record pace as some of the nation's largest builders are accelerating the pace of what Citigroup Inc predicts will be a "mega-consolidation" in the industry.

site_title: Miyoshi swings into profit with Q3 net profit of S$408,000
summary: Miyoshi Limited, an engineering group, reported a Q3 net profit of S$408,000, reversing a net loss of S$366,000 in the previous year. Revenue rose 11.1% to S$12.9 million, driven by increased orders from automotive and data storage customers. Earnings per share and net asset value per share also improved, with shares edging up to 11.91 Singapore cents.

site_title: Stock to watch: Miyoshi Limited
summary: Miyoshi Limited, an engineering group, reported a third-quarter net profit of S$408,000, reversing a net loss of S$366,000 in the previous year. Revenue rose 11.1% to S$12.9 million, driven by increased orders from automotive and data storage customers. This positive earnings report may influence trading on Monday.

site_title: Hong Kong's mortgage lenders doing booming business in the shadows
summary: Hong Kong's mortgage lenders are booming in the shadows, offering attractive financing options to buyers. Lenders are competing fiercely, providing 85% financing with interest deferment options, making it a good investment opportunity for some, despite the risk. This trend is driven by the desire for affordable housing and the limited supply of affordable properties in the market.

site_title: Frenchman arrested with Belgians charged over terror
summary: A 42-year-old Frenchman, Salah Ghemit, was charged with terror offences on Sunday after being suspected of plotting attacks with two Belgian brothers, Akim and Khalid Saouti. Ghemit is believed to have links to extremist groups and was known to authorities before his arrest. The brothers, who were charged in Brussels, were planning an attack with a large stash of weapons. Authorities feared an imminent attack in France or Belgium and had been monitoring Ghemit's activities since his release from prison in 2015, when he was believed to have been radicalised.

site_title: Flying cars to AI feature in contest to solve Bangalore gridlock
summary: Tech giants and startups in Bangalore are competing in a contest to solve the city's gridlock problem, with solutions ranging from artificial intelligence and big data to flying cars. The Gridlock Hackathon, initiated by Flipkart, has attracted teams from global giants Microsoft, Google, and Amazon, as well as local startups like Ola. The contest aims to find solutions to the city's inadequate roads, unprecedented growth, and overpopulation, which cost the economy billions of dollars. The winner will receive a $5,500 prize, but the real impact may come from the innovative ideas presented, with Binny Bansal, Flipkart's CEO, stating that any solution must originate from and have the support of citizens.

images.alt_text: In Bangalore, tech giants and startups typically spend their days fiercely battling each other for customers. Now they are turning their attention to a common enemy: the Indian city's infernal traffic congestion.

site_title: US dollar stands tall after US jobs report backs Fed tightening plans
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the yen after a stronger-than-expected jobs report in the US, suggesting the Federal Reserve may stick to its interest rate hike plans for this year. The US dollar index was steady at 96.018, while the benchmark 10-year US yield reached 2.389%. This move was seen as a boost to the dollar, which had been under pressure ahead of the jobs report. The report's impact was also felt in the currency markets, with the euro edging down 0.1% to US$1.1400.

site_title: Golf: Thai 14-year-old becomes youngest Ladies European Tour winner
summary: A 14-year-old Thai amateur golfer, Atthaya Thitikul, won the Ladies European Tour championship, breaking Lydia Ko's record as the youngest champion on the circuit. Thitikul clinched a two-stroke victory at the Ladies European Thailand Championship, finishing at five-under 283. The victory marked her first professional win and came after Ko's 2013 New Zealand Open win at 15 years, nine months, and 17 days. Thitikul credited her caddie for keeping her calm during the final round, saying she was happy and proud of her achievement.

images.alt_text: Atthaya Thitikul, aged 14 years, four months and 19 days, clinched a two-stroke victory at the Ladies European Thailand Championship at Phoenix Country Club in Pattaya.

site_title: Europe must claim tax due from US tech giants: France
summary: France's finance minister, Bruno Le Maire, urged European counterparts to pursue tax owed by US tech giants like Google, Amazon, and Facebook. Le Maire criticized the companies for shifting revenue to avoid paying European taxes, calling for Europe to "defend its interests." France has been seeking to collect 1.115 billion euros from Google, following a settlement with Apple. The European Commission has also fined Google 2.4 billion euros for favoring its shopping service in search results, further escalating tensions with the US.

site_title: Oil pact monitors won't discuss further cuts at July meet: report
summary: Opec's Joint Ministerial Monitoring Committee will not discuss further oil production cuts at its July 24 meeting, according to Opec's secretary-general. The committee, set up to monitor the global deal on oil output curbs, will instead focus on deal implementation and market situation. Oil prices have fallen since May due to rising production from the US and other non-Opec countries, as well as exemptions for Nigeria and Libya. Energy ministers have stated there's no need for immediate extra measures to support oil prices.

site_title: Tesla rolls out its first Model 3, and it's CEO Elon Musk's
summary: Tesla has rolled out its first Model 3, priced at $35,000, with CEO Elon Musk owning the vehicle. The car's production ramp-up is expected to reach 20,000 cars per month by December, significantly outpacing BMW and Mercedes. Initial production will be slow, with 30 cars delivered at a launch celebration on July 28. The Model 3 features a 15-inch touchscreen, dual-motor all-wheel drive, and high-performance versions will be delayed for six to nine months. Autopilot features and Supercharging will be available, but at an additional cost.

site_title: Kuwait Airways says US laptop ban lifted
summary: Kuwait Airways announced that the US laptop ban on its flights has been lifted, allowing passengers to use personal electronic devices in the cabin. The ban was implemented by the US in March due to concerns over bomb-making efforts by the Islamic State group. Other airlines, including Etihad, Emirates, Turkish Airways, Qatar Airways, and Saudi Arabian Airlines, have also lifted the ban on their US-bound flights. The lifting of the ban is seen as a positive development for the airline industry.

site_title: Foreigners are shoring up Japan's shrinking population
summary: Foreigners are helping to boost Japan's shrinking population, with the number of foreign residents increasing by almost 150,000 last year, halving the decline in Japan's population. As of 2017, there are 2.3 million foreigners in Japan, with Tokyo's 486,346 foreign residents accounting for 4% of the city's population. This growth is attributed to an influx of foreigners, primarily in Tokyo, which is helping to counterbalance the country's declining native-born population.

site_title: Does Brexit's EU-budget pinch really hurt? Yes! Cry the mayors
summary: The European Union's local governments are concerned about a potential 10 billion-euro budget gap due to the UK's Brexit exit, which could lead to sharp cuts in EU regional funding. The European Committee of the Regions estimates that other rich countries may need to increase their contributions by 16% to fill the gap. This could impact research outlays and farm subsidies, which are considered key to economic growth and security challenges. The EU's regional funding accounts for a third of its annual expenditure.

site_title: Trump's son met Russian lawyer after promise of info on Clinton: NY Times
summary: President Donald Trump's son Donald Trump Jr. agreed to meet with a Kremlin-linked lawyer, Natalia Veselnitskaya, on June 9, 2016, after being promised damaging information about Hillary Clinton. The meeting, attended by Trump Jr.'s father-in-law Jared Kushner and former campaign chairman Paul Manafort, was two weeks after Trump won the Republican nomination. Trump Jr. acknowledged meeting with Veselnitskaya, but no information was provided.

site_title: No MVNO talks with MyRepublic, says M1
summary: M1, a Singaporean telco, has clarified that it did not make an offer to MyRepublic to be its MVNO partner, contrary to media reports. M1 stated it supports MVNOs to offer consumers more choice in niche market segments, currently supporting Circles.Life and PLDT Singapore. The telco is prepared to defend its market share and attract new customers in a highly competitive industry.

site_title: Western Canada wildfires may spread with more hot, dry weather
summary: Western Canada is bracing for potentially devastating wildfires as hot, dry weather forecasts continue for the coming week. British Columbia is battling 220 wildfires, with officials warning of greater devastation. "We are going to be at the mercy of the weather," said Kevin Skrepnek, British Columbia's chief fire spokesman. The region's wildfires are expected to spread, posing a significant threat to the province.

site_title: StarHub bets on more data sales as mobile space gets squeezed
summary: StarHub, Singapore's No 2 telecommunications company, is shifting focus to data analytics for corporate clients amid increased competition from a new mobile operator, TPG Telecom Ltd. The company aims to grow beyond its consumer market, which has been squeezed by the new entrant. StarHub warns that TPG could offer unlimited data with broadband, posing a significant threat to its business. The company's strategy involves providing more data analytics to corporate clients, seeking to differentiate itself from competitors and maintain market share.

site_title: Big UK firms curtail investment plans, consumer slowdown deepens: surveys
summary: Major UK firms have curtailed investment plans and consumers spent less on credit cards, according to surveys. Business optimism at large British companies fell sharply in the second quarter, dampened by the inconclusive outcome of the national election. The reports add to a string of lacklustre economic data, raising questions about the chances of the Bank of England raising interest rates this year. The UK economy shrank for the second month, dealing a fresh blow to Prime Minister Starmer.

site_title: As elites switch to texting, watchdogs fear loss of transparency
summary: Elites are increasingly using secure messaging apps like WhatsApp, Signal, and Confide, sparking concerns over transparency and record-keeping. Lawmakers, corporate executives, and other prominent communicators are switching from phone calls and emails to encrypted and self-destructing texts due to fears of surveillance and hackers. This trend poses problems in heavily regulated industries, where careful record-keeping is standard procedure. Critics argue that secure chats are tough to regulate and that the practice is being used to evade the law and circumvent public records laws.

site_title: Iraq PM hails forces for securing Mosul 'victory'
summary: Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi visited Mosul, hailing his forces for securing a "victory" against the Islamic State group, although he noted that final pockets of resistance remain. The city, once the group's stronghold, is now largely in ruins, with thousands dead and wounded, and nearly a million displaced. Abadi vowed to declare victory once all remnants are cleared, emphasizing the need for sustained efforts to rebuild and eliminate the threat posed by IS. The victory comes after a long and bloody campaign, with the group's territory now largely limited to Syria.

site_title: Cash for Bulgarian passport empties village
summary: In Albania's Trebisht village, a rush to obtain Bulgarian passports has led to a mass exodus of residents, with over 2,500 leaving in the past four years. The passports, which grant access to the European Union, have been obtained by around 100,000 Albanians of Bulgarian descent, who consider themselves part of the diaspora. The European Parliament has recommended that Albania enshrine the rights of these individuals in law, but the process remains disputed, with neighboring Macedonia claiming they are ethnic Macedonians.

site_title: French bosses laud impact of Macron
summary: French company bosses praised newly elected President Emmanuel Macron's first steps towards reforms, citing a renewed sense of confidence and optimism about the country's image abroad. Despite no concrete measures passed, Macron's government outlined an action plan and began talks with unions to reform French labor regulations. CEOs, including Total's Patrick Pouyanne, expressed hope that the government will maintain this momentum, encouraging investment and spending. This shift in attitude is seen as a significant change from previous years, when companies had lamented France's slow pace of reforms.

site_title: Oil prices drop almost 3% on rising supplies
summary: Oil prices dropped nearly 3% on Friday due to rising US production and exports by Opec, casting doubt on efforts to curb global oversupply. Brent crude settled at $46.71 a barrel, its lowest in over a week.

site_title: STI stuck within a trading range
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) remains stuck within a trading range of 3,200 to 3,280, with investors buying dips and selling into strength. This range, after the index started at 2,880 in 2017, suggests a higher likelihood of a downward move. Valuations are high, with sector valuations below their long-term historical average, and economists caution against taking heavy positions. The market's recent behavior is also attributed to stalled upward momentum and the desire to justify volatility, rather than interest rate concerns.

site_title: LA cools down by making pavements lighter
summary: Los Angeles is implementing a plan to cool down the city by turning streets lighter, using a light grey coating known as CoolSeal, which has shown a 10 deg F reduction in heat gain. This measure aims to mitigate the urban heat island effect, which could see three times as many extreme heat days by mid-century. Mayor Eric Garcetti predicts a three deg F reduction in temperatures over the next 20 years, which could reduce energy use and mitigate health risks associated with extreme heat.

site_title: US Republicans voice growing doubts on healthcare bill's fate
summary: US Republicans express growing pessimism about the fate of a healthcare bill aimed at repealing and replacing the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). Senator John McCain says the bill is "probably going to be dead," and many more Republicans have criticized or opposed the legislation. The bill would repeal most Obamacare taxes, overhaul tax credits, and cut Medicaid funding, but critics warn it would cause millions to lose healthcare coverage. The bill's future is uncertain, with Senate leadership continuing to work on a revised version.

images.alt_text: One prominent Republican lawmaker, Senator John McCain, said he thought the Republican bill would probably fail.

site_title: GIC still evaluating banks as investments
summary: Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) is continuing to evaluate its investments in the banking sector, including a 4 billion Swiss franc loss from its stake in UBS Group, as it seeks to adapt to disruption and new technology trends. GIC reduced its stake in UBS by selling 93 million shares, citing the need to find better use of capital elsewhere. The sovereign wealth fund is also studying the impact of fintechs on the banking sector and has invested in fintech start-ups, including a mobile payments company in 2014.

site_title: Qualcomm suing Apple over use of mobile tech in iPhone
summary: Qualcomm is suing Apple for patent infringement over the use of mobile technology in iPhones, claiming six patents covering various aspects of mobile phone technology are being infringed. Qualcomm is seeking to stop versions of the iPhone from entering the US market and is asking for increased payments for its technology. Apple disputes the claims, arguing the system is unfair and that Qualcomm has used licensing leverage to illegally help its semiconductor unit. The dispute is part of a broader legal battle over patent licensing terms.

site_title: How a home bargain became a 'pain in the butt', and worse
summary: A contract for deed, a high-interest, seller-financed deal for housing, has become a money trap for many homeowners, including James Williams, who signed a 30-year contract for a Cincinnati home. The deal, which allows buyers to make monthly payments towards the purchase price, can lead to confusion and difficulties in tracking ownership and paying property taxes. In some cases, the original contract is sold to multiple investors, making it hard to determine who is responsible for upkeep and repairs. The issue has prompted calls for better recording of contracts and a uniform law governing the rights and responsibilities of buyers and sellers.

site_title: Sprynt's fleet of electric cars comes without charge for passengers
summary: Sprynt, a Washington-based startup, has launched a free electric ride-hailing service in Arlington, Virginia, targeting short trips within the downtown area. The company, which raised $250,000 in private investment, offers a unique win-win situation for customers and advertisers, providing free rides while promoting local businesses. With a fleet of four electric vehicles, Sprynt aims to foster a steady stream of pickups and drop-offs and expand to areas with high demand, complementing existing ride services like Uber and Lyft.

site_title: Reflation attempts gaining traction in Japan
summary: Japan's reflation attempts appear to be gaining traction as real wages rose 0.1% in May, the fastest rate in 17 years, despite inflation turning slightly positive. This marks a shift in wage dynamics, with tight labor markets translating into higher pay. Analysts attribute the improvement to a growing middle-class and increased job security for younger generations. The data suggests upward pressure on wages and inflation, potentially leading to further central bank monetary tightening.

site_title: HK's mortgage lenders doing booming business in the shadows
summary: In Hong Kong, non-bank lenders, known as "shadow banks," are filling the gap in traditional financing due to curbs on mortgages. These lenders, often affiliated with developers, offer high-interest loans with minimal down payments, allowing buyers to secure properties at record-high prices. However, regulators warn of potential risks if property prices correct or borrowers default, as these lenders are not deposit-taking companies and are monitored by the police, not financial regulators. The share of shadow banks in the mortgage market is growing rapidly, posing concerns about the stability of the financial system.

site_title: S'pore and HK - how they compare
summary:

Twenty years after the handover, Hong Kong remains a key financial and business hub, but its prospects are changing. The city is evolving into a digital hub, with China's tech giants growing their footprint. Despite this, Hong Kong's economic competitiveness is expected to be compromised, potentially benefiting Singapore. The two cities have complementary roles, with Hong Kong focusing on mainland China and Singapore on South-east Asia. While Hong Kong's financial services and business environment remain stable, its future is tied to China's growth, and Singapore may gain as Hong Kong's importance wanes.

site_title: Surfer who stopped WannaCry attack braces for next wave
summary: A 23-year-old surfer, Marcus Hutchins, saved the world from a devastating cyberattack in May by stopping the WannaCry malware that had infected hundreds of thousands of computers in over 150 countries. Hutchins, a self-taught computer-security researcher, detected the attack and registered a domain that triggered the malware's kill switch, mitigating over 100 million attempts to infect computers. With his skills in high demand, Hutchins can command six-figure salaries and has been courted by top cybersecurity firms. Experts warn that more attacks are likely, as hackers continue to exploit vulnerabilities in Microsoft's Windows operating system.

site_title: How KPMG lends a hand to those in need
summary: KPMG Cares in Singapore has implemented the Inclusive Employment Initiative, providing a corporate responsibility program for individuals with disabilities, such as Deaf and Hard of Hearing Federation (Singapore) member Daley. The initiative allows Daley to earn an income through his work, enabling him to pursue his ambition of becoming a film-maker. This program demonstrates KPMG's commitment to supporting individuals with disabilities in the workforce.

site_title: Merkel defends decision to host G-20 in Hamburg after rioting
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel defended her decision to host the G-20 summit in Hamburg, despite violent clashes and looting that left over 200 police injured and 260 protesters detained. Merkel condemned the "unleashed violence and unrestrained brutality" and promised government compensation for property damage. The summit concluded with a peaceful mass rally and march, with protesters denouncing police tactics and Merkel's handling of the protests. Merkel's government has criticized the riots, with her chief of staff calling them "terror".

site_title: Speculators chop net long US dollar bets
summary: Speculators have significantly reduced their net long bets on the US dollar, with the value of the US dollar's net long position dropping to $135 million in the week ended July 4, the lowest since mid-May 2016. This follows a mixed set of economic data, including low inflation and lower-than-expected average wage growth. The reduction in net long dollar positioning is driven by uncertainty over the Federal Reserve's future interest rate rises and the challenge of low inflation.

site_title: Trump says time to work 'constructively' with Russia
summary: US President Donald Trump said it's time to work "constructively" with Russia, despite differences over election meddling and Syria. Trump confronted Vladimir Putin over alleged meddling in the 2016 US elections, but Putin denied it. Trump expressed willingness to work together on cyber security and Syria, where a ceasefire has been brokered. However, Republican senators criticized the idea of setting up a cyber security unit with Russia, calling it "not the dumbest idea I've ever heard, but it's pretty close." The US and Russia have sharply conflicting accounts of their meeting, with Putin saying Trump was satisfied by his denials.

site_title: Treaty reached to ban nuclear arms, now comes the hard part
summary: A global treaty to ban nuclear arms has been negotiated and adopted by the United Nations, with 122 countries in favor and one against, the Netherlands. The Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons will be open for signature on September 20 and will enter into force 90 days after 50 countries ratify it. Proponents say the treaty aims to increase public pressure and stigma on nuclear-armed countries, while critics, including the US, reject the effort, calling it misguided and reckless. The treaty excludes nuclear-armed countries, which boycotted the negotiations.

site_title: Indonesian state firms planning to securitise infrastructure projects
summary: Indonesian state firms are planning to securitize infrastructure projects, including toll roads and power stations, to raise US$10 billion in additional funding. The move is part of President Joko Widodo's plan to expand infrastructure in the country, which faces high costs of moving goods around. Foreign pension funds, such as the Canada Pension Plan and Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund, are being courted to invest in these projects. The government plans to securitize existing and revenue-generating projects to attract investors and mitigate the risk of new projects.

site_title: Gulf crisis: states settle in for the long haul
summary: A diplomatic crisis between Qatar and Saudi-led allies has entered its second month, with no signs of a swift resolution. Qatar denies supporting Islamist extremists, while Saudi Arabia and its allies demand Qatar's closure of Al-Jazeera and a Turkish military base. The US State Department warns that the conflict could drag on for weeks or months, and the region is bracing for economic sanctions and potential isolation. International companies are forming contracts with Qatar, making sanctions unlikely to be effective. Diplomatic efforts, including a visit by British Foreign Minister Boris Johnson, are underway to mediate the crisis.

site_title: Town of US$1m homes declares fiscal emergency
summary: The town of Moraga, California, with a median family income of $169,000, has declared a fiscal emergency due to a lack of revenue growth. Despite a surge in property prices to over $1.2 million, local tax collections are restrained by Proposition 13, a 1978 ballot measure limiting annual tax increases. The town, with a $8.5 million budget and 36 full-time workers, is exploring new revenue measures, including a flat fee on property or utility tax, to address its $1.6 million in reserves and $7.7 million in outstanding debt.

site_title: ECB monetary easing hurts German savers but heals state finances
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) monetary easing has reduced Germany's regions' debt servicing costs by 40% over eight years, according to S&P Global. The ECB's bond-buying scheme and interest rate cuts have helped countries such as Spain, Italy, and Portugal manage increased debt loads, while punishing German savers with record-low interest rates. This has transformed the finances of Germany's regions, with most now running surpluses, and allowed them to issue long-dated bonds at extremely low levels, benefiting their bond markets.

images.alt_text: "Given the scarcity of German Bunds, we think that the ECB does not have any chance other than becoming even more active in the German sub-sovereign market." - Citi strategist Michael Spies

site_title: Argentina losing lustre as debt glut adds to election risks
summary: Argentina is losing its economic appeal as its debt glut and currency volatility increase election risks. The country's overseas bonds are performing poorly, the peso has hit record lows, and foreign exchange volatility has led to a scrapped debt sale. Argentina lost its bid to regain emerging market status, now stuck at the "frontier" level with countries like Mauritius and Sri Lanka.

site_title: Premium jeans are dead, killed by US$100 leggings
summary: Premium jeans have seen significant decline in sales, with True Religion filing for bankruptcy and closing 27 stores. Sales of super premium jeans fell 8% last year, while Americans are increasingly opting for lower-priced brands like Levi's and H&M. The rise of yoga pants and leggings has contributed to the decline, with Americans wearing them for both athletic and casual purposes. The premium denim market has been in decline for several years due to increased competition from fast fashion and low-priced retailers.

site_title: Buffett bets on energy with bid for Texas utility
summary: Warren Buffett is set to pay US$9 billion in cash for Texas utility operator Energy Future Holdings, a company that has spent nearly a decade in financial distress. However, Paul Singer, the hedge fund mogul with the largest stake in Energy Future, is exploring a takeover bid of his own, potentially sparking a battle between the two billionaires. Energy Future has been in bankruptcy proceedings for over three years.

images.alt_text: Mr Buffett has agreed to pay US$9 billion in cash for utility operator Energy Future Holdings.

site_title: Lupin sets off Indian pharma's long road to redemption
summary: India's pharmaceutical industry is working to regain its reputation after facing sanctions and bans from the US FDA. Lupin, India's No 2 drugmaker, has been implementing quality control measures to meet the FDA's standards, including increased training and equipment. Despite progress, the industry faces a long road to redemption, with many companies struggling to meet the requirements. Consolidation is expected among manufacturers, and the FDA has expanded its presence in India to ensure quality and safety standards are met. Indian companies claim their standards are stringent enough, but the FDA has taken a hands-on approach to inspections.

site_title: Football giants gravitating towards South-east Asia
summary: Top European football clubs are gravitating towards South-east Asia, with Singapore emerging as a preferred hub. The International Champions Cup (ICC) tournament, featuring teams like Chelsea, Bayern Munich, and Inter Milan, will be held in Singapore for the next four years. The decision was made by Catalyst, the exclusive developer of the ICC in the Asia-Pacific region, citing Singapore's government support, ready venue, and experience in accommodating large numbers of tourists. The tournament aims to grow the brand and fan base in the region, with the expectation of packed houses and high attendance.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

"I've worked in sports promotion for more than 20 years across the region, including in Singapore, and It was always very obvious to us that if we were to stage a world-class football tournament in South-east Asia, Singapore is the only country that we would consider at this time," says Catalyst Media Group's Mr Murphy.

site_title: Viking's new warrant has time on its side
summary: Viking Offshore and Marine issued a two-for-five renounceable and non-underwritten rights issue in May, resulting in one free detachable warrant for every two rights shares taken up. The warrants have a five-year life span, an exercise price of S$0.025, and a present price of around S$0.003. Due to being out-of-the-money, the warrants command a 87% conversion premium but offer 5 times gearing. The money raised from the exercise was for partial loan repayment and working capital.

site_title: Europe turns to Europe for deals as US and Asia M&A slips
summary: European companies are turning to domestic mergers and acquisitions (M&A) as the continent's economic growth and market stability improve, driven by the UK's Brexit decision and French presidential elections. The volume of deals in Europe reached about US$250 billion in the first half of the year, a 70% increase from 2016, with buyers paying US$10 billion or more for the largest deals. This trend is expected to continue, with financial investors playing a key role in the coming months.

site_title: Trump's trip ends with few prizes, little consensus on goals
summary: US President Donald Trump returned from the G-20 summit with little concrete progress on key issues, including trade and North Korea. Despite a ceasefire agreement with Russian President Vladimir Putin, the meeting yielded controversy, with both sides offering competing narratives. Trump's inability to rally world leaders to his causes is further complicated by ongoing FBI probes into his campaign. Analysts say the trip highlighted stark differences between the US and other nations, with the G-20's final statement calling the 2015 Paris climate accord "irreversible" and rejecting the US's stance on trade.

site_title: US stocks riding into sunset of low-interest era
summary: US stocks remained relatively flat last week as a strong jobs report led to expectations of a rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The economy added 222,000 jobs in June, with the unemployment rate ticking up to 4.4%, forcing traders to accept the end of the low-interest-rate era. Despite concerns over stagnant wages, the jobs report suggests a push towards higher wages and tighter labor markets. The Fed is likely to raise interest rates and wind down its balance sheet, potentially benefiting financial stocks and driving a rotation in the market.

site_title: Decades of trying, but health reform remains elusive in US
summary: The US has struggled to achieve comprehensive health reform for decades, despite efforts by multiple presidents, including Bill Clinton and Barack Obama. Despite the Affordable Care Act (ACA) lowering the uninsured rate to 10%, 26 million Americans remain without coverage. The country's split-personality system, combining private and public elements, complicates reform efforts. Experts, including Bill Hoagland, believe a middle path is necessary to control costs and expand coverage, but finding common ground between Democrats and Republicans remains elusive.

site_title: London's Grosvenor House hotel sold

site_title: One in five Singaporeans consider switch in main bank in one year: study
summary: A study by JD Power found that one in five Singaporean bank customers (21%) is considering leaving their primary bank within the next 12 months. This signals a need for banks to strengthen their relationship and engagement with customers. Self-service channels, such as mobile banking, generated higher satisfaction scores than traditional high-touch channels. Customers are also more inclined to recommend their bank to others when using mobile applications, with 43% of mobile users expressing this intention.

site_title: Tesla April registrations drop 24% in key California market
summary: Tesla's April vehicle registrations in California, the company's largest market, dropped 24% from a year ago, according to IHS Markit data. The company reported a 53% increase in deliveries in the second quarter compared to last year, but sales of its luxury Model S sedan, which has been on the market since 2012, are reportedly softening ahead of the mass market Model 3 launch.

site_title: Yellen's bet on pulling workers back to labour force pays off
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's bet on pulling workers back into the labor force appears to have paid off, with June's payroll report showing a 4.7 million surge in job holders entering the labor force, its highest level since 1990. This data supports Yellen's strategy of fostering a sustained recovery and drawing Americans back into employment, which has helped to reduce labor market slack and potentially limit wage pressures.

site_title: GIC prepares for protracted uncertainty, low returns
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC expects steady long-term returns despite heightened uncertainty and "investor complacency." site_title: 122 countries adopt global treaty banning nuclear weapons
summary: The United Nations adopted a global treaty banning nuclear weapons, with 122 countries voting in favour, while the US, Britain, and France rejected it, citing concerns over security threats like North Korea's nuclear program. site_title: Why business models matter
summary: Two structural steel firms, Yongnam Holdings and TTJ Holdings, in Singapore, exhibit stark differences in financial performance and valuations despite operating in the same industry. In contrast, TTJ Holdings, a smaller company, has positive cash flows, a lower capital intensity, and a market valuation 50% higher than Yongnam's. site_title: Ladders came up short, and cost lives, in London high-rise: firefighters
summary: Firefighters in London believe that more lives could have been saved in the Grenfell Tower blaze if the city had access to higher-ladder fire engines. summary: A major fire broke out at El Salvador's Finance Ministry, killing at least one person and injuring 22. A 57-year-old woman died, while another woman was resuscitated in hospital. The government sent in helicopters to rescue people and reported that there were no remaining trapped individuals in the building.

site_title: EU-Norway crab row can fuel Arctic oil tensions
summary: Norway and the European Union are in a dispute over fishing rights in the Arctic region of Svalbard, with Norway accusing the EU of violating its national sovereignty. The EU has authorized vessels from Baltic nations to fish for snow crabs in the area, but Norway claims this violates the 1920 Svalbard Treaty, which it believes only applies to the territorial waters surrounding Svalbard. The dispute could have implications for oil and gas exploration in the region, with experts warning of a potential "domino effect" as other countries may seek to claim a share of the resources.

site_title: Former martial arts star Battulga wins Mongolian presidential election
summary: Former Mongolian martial arts star and businessman Khaltmaa Battulga won the country's presidential election with 50.6% of the vote, defeating parliament speaker Miyeegombo Enkhbold of the ruling Mongolian People's Party. summary: India is considering selling state-owned Air India in parts to make it more attractive to potential buyers, as it reviews options to divest the loss-making airline. site_title: US bombers drill near Korea DMZ in show of force
summary: US bombers conducted a rare live fire drill near the Korea DMZ in South Korea, simulating a show of force after North Korea's latest missile test. The drill aimed to respond to North Korea's ballistic missile launches, demonstrating the South Korean and US air forces' capability to "thoroughly punish the enemy." site_title: 8Telecom changes independent directors and appoints new non-exec director
summary: 8Telecom has made changes to its board, with independent directors Ross Yu Limjoco and Richard Tan Kheng Swee resigning on July 7. site_title: Even Melania Trump couldn't keep Trump, Putin on time: Tillerson
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said the 2-hour and 15-minute meeting between President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin ran long due to their engaging conversation. Tillerson described the two leaders as having a "very clear positive chemistry" and attributed the extended meeting to their mutual interest in discussing various topics.

site_title: US banks face variety of risks, financial performance strong: regulator
summary: US banks face various risks, including those beyond their control, despite strong financial performance. The US Office of the Comptroller of the Currency found that banks rely heavily on third-party servicers and vendors, creating concentrated points of failure. Additionally, banks may struggle to comply with new regulations, particularly in lending and real estate, as their vendors may not be aware of changes. Other areas of risk include Brexit, commodity price declines, auto loans, and interest-rate changes. Despite these risks, US banks' revenue increased 3.6% in 2016, with net interest income rising the largest since 2010.

site_title: US trade partners watch warily as Trump considers steel tariffs
summary: The US is expected to impose tariffs on steel imports, potentially sparking a global trade war. Critics argue that tariffs would harm the US economy and lead to job losses in other industries. The move has also been met with skepticism, with some experts viewing it as a bluff by the Trump administration.

site_title: UK wants to insure poorer nations against natural disasters
summary: The UK plans to launch a £30 million market for insuring countries against natural disasters, with the goal of providing more stable funding for relief efforts in developing nations. This move aims to support the UK's international aid work while addressing the moral responsibility to meet humanitarian needs.

site_title: Many HK penny investors caught in cross-holdings web
summary: A network of 50 Hong Kong small-cap firms, linked by overlapping directorships and cross-holdings, raised corporate governance concerns after a recent market plunge wiped out $6.1 billion in market value. Regulators are increasing focus on corporate issues, but a Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) statement declined to confirm investigations into specific individuals or companies.

summary: US Senator Amy Klobuchar urged the Justice Department to reject any White House push to inject politics into merger investigations, citing concerns about altering or censoring the press. site_title: Advance SCT restructures debts with two major creditors
summary: Advance SCT, a copper-based products supplier, restructured its debts with two major creditors. site_title: Austrian F1 Grand Prix: Bottas holds off Vettel by 0.6 of a second in cliffhanger
summary: Valtteri Bottas won the Austrian F1 Grand Prix for Mercedes, edging out Sebastian Vettel by 0.6 of a second. Vettel's win narrowed Lewis Hamilton's lead to 20 points after nine races. site_title: Pakistan orders Shell subsidiary to pay 257m rupees for tanker blast
summary: Pakistan's oil and gas regulator ordered Shell Pakistan Ltd to pay 257 million rupees in damages and compensation for a tanker explosion that killed over 200 people. The regulator found Shell Pakistan responsible for the accident, citing non-professional driving and safety standards violations. The company must pay a penalty of 10 million rupees, compensation to victims' families, and upgrade its infrastructure. Shell Pakistan has the right to appeal against the fine and compensation demand.

site_title: Casting a light on shadow directors
summary: A shadow director, also known as the "puppet master" or "cat's paw," is a person who directs or advises the directors of a company, despite not being formally appointed as a director. In Singapore corporate law, a person is considered a shadow director if the directors are accustomed to act in accordance with their directions or instructions, regardless of whether it's on a regular or occasional basis. Shadow directors owe fiduciary duties to the company and can be held liable for any wrongdoing, including breach of fiduciary duties or statutory duties. Recent changes to the Companies Act have clarified the concept of shadow directorship, requiring nominee directors to disclose their nominator and information about their control.

images.alt_text: A person may be a shadow director if the board consults him on all significant issues in the running of the company, and he expects his views to be respected by the board.

site_title: Prince videos appear on old foe YouTube

site_title: Facebook to build housing in Silicon Valley for first time

site_title: Affordable housing in black neighbourhoods can lead to greater racial and income integration: study
summary: A study by Stanford economists found that affordable housing developments built in poor, heavily black communities can lead to greater racial and income integration. site_title: Yoshikawa Masahiro

site_title: 'Death in the Ice': Story of an ill-fated Arctic expedition

site_title: Venus Williams driving 'lawfully' at time of fatal crash: police

site_title: Europe: Shares seek floor after sell-off, posting modest weekly gain

Gilbert believes Tomic needs to question his attitude and find motivation, rather than making excuses. Other players, including Andre Agassi, agree that players should be held accountable for feigning injury.

images.alt_text: Tomic, who said he could not find motivation during his first round defeat, was fined £11,600 (S$20,673) for "unsportsmanlike conduct" after also admitting he took a medical pause just to break up the momentum of the game.

site_title: Oil prices drop 3% on rising global supplies
summary: Oil prices dropped 3% on Friday after data showed rising US production and Opec exports reached a 2017 high, casting doubt on efforts to curb global oversupply. Brent crude fell 2.9% to $46.71 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures declined 2.8% to $44.23 a barrel. Despite Opec's production cut deal, oil producers seem undeterred, with drillers adding 7 oil rigs this week, and US production rose 1% to 9.34 million barrels per day.

site_title: Double Take
summary: Black and white monochromatic dressing has been a fashion staple, with designers finding fresh ways to incorporate the color combination into their collections. The classic print of black and white polka dots has proven its staying power, with notable looks on the fall/winter 2017 runways. Layering, texture, and structure are key elements in creating a monochromatic ensemble, with designers incorporating details like sequins, tassels, and quilting to add interest. Simple tailoring with exaggerated features can also add a powerful impact to a monochrome outfit.

site_title: Yellen bet on pulling workers back to labour force is paying off
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's cautious approach to interest rate hikes appears to be paying off, as the labor market continues to show signs of improvement. The latest payroll report suggests that millions of Americans who had dropped out of the labor force are now returning to employment, helping to stabilize labor force participation and keep wage gains modest. The Fed's decision to hold interest rates lower than expected has helped to foster a sustained recovery, and Yellen's strategy to draw in potential workers from the sidelines seems to be working, with the labor market "reasonably close" to full employment.

site_title: Room to dare
summary: Adrian Zecha, 84, is redefining luxury hospitality with his Azerai resorts, which offer affordable luxury experiences. Zecha, who never left his hotel empire after a messy ownership dispute, is working on multiple projects, including one in Cuba. He believes true luxury is a sense, not a formula, and his approach is to create unique experiences. Meanwhile, Frasers Hospitality is expanding its Capri brand, taking calculated risks to succeed in the market. Yoshiharu Hoshino, fourth-generation ryokan owner, is modernizing traditional Japanese ryokan hospitality to cater to international visitors.

site_title: US: Wall Street climbs after jobs data as tech, financials rise
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, with the S&P 500 index posting its best gain in six sessions, driven by a jobs report showing 222,000 jobs added, exceeding expectations. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 94.3 points, and the technology sector led the charge higher, buoyed by gains in Apple, Microsoft, and Facebook. Financials also advanced as investors expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates later this year.

site_title: Thai Beverage to use F&N to grow non-Thai business: CIMB report
summary: Thai Beverage Public Company plans to use Singapore-based Fraser & Neave (F&N) to expand its non-Thai business, according to a CIMB report. The company will likely first divest its stake in Frasers Centrepoint and use the proceeds to increase its stake in F&N. F&N is expected to bid for Sabeco and increase its stake in Vinamilk, a Vietnamese dairy company. CIMB analysts expect Thai Beverage to acquire assets outside of Thailand using F&N, reaffirming their "add" call on Thai Beverage stock with a target price of S$1.07.

site_title: Hotel room demand surges as NDP returns to Marina Bay float
summary: Hotel room demand in Singapore's city area has surged as the National Day Parade (NDP) returns to The Float@Marina Bay, a temporary venue, on August 9. This marks a departure from the parade's previous location at the National Stadium, where booking rates were slower in 2016. As a result, hotels are charging higher premiums for rooms compared to the previous year, with the surge attributed to the NDP's perennial popularity among the public.

site_title: Trump emerges from Putin meeting with cease-fire and little else
summary: US President Donald Trump met with Russian President Vladimir Putin, resulting in a cease-fire in southwest Syria, but no significant progress on other issues, including election hacking and Ukraine. Trump did not extract any concessions from Putin, and instead, seemed to downplay the issue of election interference. The meeting was seen as a victory for Putin, who was praised by Russians for the outcome. US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson described the meeting as a breakthrough, but foreign policy experts criticized Trump's approach, saying he should have taken a stronger stance on election interference and sanctions.

site_title: How to save thousands on your next (nearly) new car
summary: Volkswagen and BMW have partnered with event organizers to sell nearly-new cars at discounted prices. The "event cars" are sold before the event, registered in customers' names, and then used for the duration of the event. These cars can be aggressively discounted without impacting the value of a brand's cars. Customers can score a bargain by registering their interest with a sales executive, and the first drive may have gone to someone else, but the last laugh would be yours.

site_title: Grantham's firm dissolves international stock team as assets fall
summary: Grantham Mayo Van Otterloo & Co (GMO) dissolved its 10-member international stock team, which managed $1.5 billion in assets, following a 46% decline in assets over the past three years. The team, led by Drew Spangler, was restructured to focus on quantitative investing, and its staff is being reassigned. This move comes as GMO shifts assets to other strategies, including an emerging-market equity strategy and one on climate change. The firm is trying to revitalize its stock-picking business, which faces pressure from investors shifting to lower-cost exchange-traded funds.

site_title: How leaders can be fit for the job
summary: Leadership is no longer just about thinking or feeling, but also about physical fitness, according to husband-and-wife team Marcus and Sari Marsden. Their new book, "Fit to Lead," emphasizes the importance of integrating physical, mental, and emotional well-being for maximum impact. They argue that paying attention to physical state can help leaders build resilience, manage stress, and make better decisions. The Marsdens also highlight the importance of self-awareness, rest, and recovery, and caution against burnout. By prioritizing physical fitness and emotional intelligence, leaders can become more effective and influential.

site_title: World leaders lean on Trump over climate, trade
summary: World leaders, including Brazil, Russia, India, and China, are urging US President Donald Trump to reconsider his decision to pull the US out of the Paris climate deal, as the G-20 summit in Hamburg, Germany, began amid clashes between police and protesters. The Brics countries called for the G-20 to push for implementation of the Paris deal, while British Prime Minister Theresa May urged Trump to reconsider his decision. The summit also brings together Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin, amid allegations of Russian interference in the US election.

site_title: Hillhouse Capital planning new yuan fund to tap demand for China exposure: sources
summary: Hillhouse Capital Group, a top Chinese technology firm investor, plans to raise a new yuan-denominated fund of about 8 billion yuan (S$1.6 billion) to tap into demand for China exposure. This move follows a trend of venture capital and private equity funds raising yuan funds, as investors seek opportunities in domestic Chinese businesses and institutions look to boost returns in alternative assets. This year's yuan fund-raising is on pace to be the biggest since 2012, driven by growing sources of capital at insurance firms and wealthy individuals.

site_title: Flying High
summary: Singapore's first public housing estate, Tiong Bahru, was built by the Singapore Improvement Trust (SIT) in the 1930s, offering 784 flats, 54 tenements, and 33 shops. The SIT was established in 1927 to address housing and living conditions, but it couldn't keep up with demand, leading to the construction of more estates. In 1960, the SIT was dissolved, and the Housing Development Board took over, transforming Singapore's public housing landscape. The remaining SIT flats, now gentrified in the heritage neighbourhood of Tiong Bahru, remain a nostalgic reminder of Singapore's early public housing era.

site_title: Gonna ride a classic
summary: A 50-year-old Silver Shadow Rolls-Royce, owned by a Singaporean and registered under the classic vehicle scheme since 2013, is up for sale at this weekend's Luxglove classic car event at Marina Bay Sands. The vehicle is described as being in "very good condition."

site_title: Picnic en masse
summary: Tiong Bahru Bakery is hosting the "Weird Wonderful World" mass picnic event at the Singapore Botanic Gardens from July 8-9. The event will feature buskers, workshops, games, and pop-up stalls from eateries like Open Farm Community and Common Man Coffee Roasters. Picnic buckets, which include picnic mats, food, and drinks, can be ordered from TBB. The event aims to bring people together and provide a fun outdoor experience.

site_title: US jobs growth accelerates in June but wages continue to lag as Fed ponders hike
summary: The US added 222,000 jobs in June, exceeding analyst forecasts, with the unemployment rate rising to 4.4% due to increased labor force participation. Average hourly earnings rose 0.2%, but wages continued to lag. Job gains were seen in healthcare, financial services, and mining, while the manufacturing sector added only 1,000 new positions. The positive jobs report may ease concerns about a rate hike by the Federal Reserve later this year, but inflation pressures remain a concern.

images.alt_text: The jobs rebound was welcome news for the White House after several months in which other economic data suggested the world's largest economy could be starting to lose steam.

site_title: Honda Civic Type R review: A wing and a player
summary: The Honda Civic Type R review highlights the car's functional design, despite its unusual appearance. The vehicle features multiple aerodynamic wings, which provide improved handling and stability. The reviewer notes that the Civic Type R's appearance is not just for show, but rather a result of its advanced aerodynamics. The car's performance and capabilities are not discussed in the provided text.

site_title: Remembering Zaha Hadid
summary: Architect Zaha Hadid, considered one of the most influential architects of the 21st century, is remembered with an exhibition at MAXXI - National Museum of XXI Century Arts in Italy. The exhibition, running until January 14, 2018, showcases Hadid's work through various media, including sketches, models, and virtual renderings. Hadid designed MAXXI, featuring intersecting walls that separate interior and exterior spaces. The exhibition explores her rich and complex career, highlighting her innovative and visionary approach to architecture.
