site_title: Watch this CEO
summary: Chabi Nouri, the first female CEO of Piaget, aims to diversify the luxury brand beyond its timepieces, focusing on jewellery and boosting its presence in the market. She replaces Philippe Leopold-Metzger and is the first woman to lead Richemont's watch and jewellery business. Nouri, a 36-year veteran of the industry, played down the gender aspect, saying it was never a disadvantage during her years at Cartier and British American Tobacco. Her goal is to correct the imbalance and reposition Piaget as a major player in the jewellery market.

site_title: Funds to benefit from positive returns in markets
summary: Financial markets experienced a slowdown in June, with the MSCI AC World Index falling 0.3% and global bonds losing 0.5%. The portfolio underperformed its benchmark, losing 1.9% due to significant losses in equity holdings. However, the Neuberger Berman US Multicap Opportunity Fund was the best performer, delivering a 1.4% return. As the year progresses, Asia is expected to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification, with retail investors forecasted to drive massive growth in ETFs in Asia and Europe.

site_title: US dollar firms after strong US jobs report, backs Fed hike view
summary: The US dollar surged after a strong jobs report, with the greenback rising to two-month highs against the yen and a more-than-one-week peak against sterling. The US economy created 222,000 jobs in June, beating expectations, and inflation pressure remained tame. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates at least one more time this year, driven by solid employment data. The US dollar index rose 0.2% to 96.0132, while the euro fell 0.2% to $1.1403.

images.alt_text: The US dollar gained on Friday after a report showed the US economy created far more jobs than expected in June and previous months, keeping the Federal Reserve on track to raise interest rates at least one more time this year.

site_title: YuuZoo says it'll be more mindful about 'over-promising' to shareholders
summary: YuuZoo Corporation has announced a more conservative approach to reporting finances and has vowed to be more mindful of "over-promising" to shareholders. The company's directors have also sought to improve the quality of executives and board members. Shareholders passed resolutions, including the issuance of up to 1.5 million stock options to chairman Thomas Ziliacus. The company has faced criticism for its accounting practices, significant impairments, and negative cash flow, leading to a 60% cut in net profit. YuuZoo has also faced numerous changes among its top finance executives.

site_title: Mazda's G Vectoring control explained
summary: Mazda's G Vectoring Control is a system that enhances passenger comfort by automatically adjusting engine power to reduce body movement during cornering. It works by detecting speed, accelerator position, and steering wheel angle, then trimming engine power to transfer weight to the rear wheels. This system, fitted to the Mazda 6 and Mazda 3, aims to provide a smoother ride and reduce fatigue for drivers, while also enhancing the feeling of precision. The technology will be introduced in the upcoming Mazda CX-5 SUV.

site_title: Edible art
summary: Two eateries in Singapore are offering Yayoi Kusama-inspired desserts and sweets, respectively, as part of their exhibitions at the National Gallery Singapore. Gallery & Co's Yayoi Special Food Menu features a pumpkin-inspired dessert, while The Courtyard's Yayoi Kusama-inspired Afternoon Tea offers five sweets inspired by her artwork. Meanwhile, baker Nura Alkhatib's Batikrolls, edible Swiss rolls with colourful batik-inspired designs, are also gaining popularity. These edible art pieces aim to enhance the visitor experience and immerse fans in Kusama's quirky art installations.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: StarHub acquires remaining 49% stake in cybersecurity services provider Accel Systems & Technologies Pte Ltd for S$26.2 million in two phases. WongPartnership forms strategic alliance with Philippine law firm ZGLaw to expand regional network. Cityneon Holdings' controlling shareholder transfers shares to Lucrum 1 Investment Limited, fulfilling general offer precondition. Meanwhile, Tan Teck Long is named OCBC's incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong, who retires.

site_title: Hong Kong braces for higher rates as currency losses accelerate
summary: Hong Kong's currency peg to the US dollar is facing pressure as the gap between local and US interbank rates widens to its most since 2009. The city's currency has weakened 0.7% in 2017, with forward points and interest rate swaps starting to bottom out, indicating a possible increase in rates. This could lead to a depreciation of the Hong Kong dollar and a rise in rates, affecting the city's real estate and equities markets.

site_title: Korea Exchange thriving despite being just next door to a nuclear nightmare
summary: South Korea's stock market, the Korea Exchange, has reached record highs despite the ongoing threat of nuclear conflict on the Korean Peninsula. The Kospi Index has gained 22% this year, second only to India among the world's biggest equity markets. Investors are prioritizing traditional stock market metrics, such as earnings growth and profit ratios, over concerns about war. Foreign investors have poured into South Korean stocks, and experts believe the market is undervalued compared to historical standards. Analysts predict continued growth, with some forecasting a 25% surge in the next two years.

site_title: OCBC Cycle unveils corporate race category
summary: OCBC Cycle, Singapore's largest mass cycling event, has unveiled a corporate race category, Speedway Corporate Championship, in partnership with companies. The event aims to attract 32 companies to compete for top honors. The corporate races will feature a four-rider team relay format, with the fastest time determining the winning team. The OCBC Cycle event, launched in 2009, has grown in popularity and will take place on November 18 and 19 on the roads. Safety is a priority, with a session on preventing cycling injuries to be conducted by a sports doctor.

images.alt_text: OCBC Bank CEO Samuel Tsien (third from left) and Sport Singapore CEO Lim Teck Yin (third from right) at the launch of OCBC Cycle 2017 on Friday. On the right is BT editor Wong Wei Kong. PHOTO: OCBC

site_title: dnata S'pore gets capacity boost with S$16.2m maintenance base
summary: dnata Singapore has opened a S$16.2 million maintenance base at Changi Airport, tripling its handling capacity and featuring environmentally friendly design and equipment. The 6,900 sq m facility can handle over 9,000 repairs and maintenance activities annually, and will service dnata's fleet of over 1,200 GSE. The new facility is part of the airport's expansion plans, including the upcoming Terminal 4 and Terminal 5 openings. Minister for Transport Khaw Boon Wan attended the launch event, praising the investment as a key contributor to the "Changi Experience".

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Ceasefire after bombshell
summary: North Korea launched its first ICBM on July 4, sparking a G-20 Summit in Hamburg, where US President Donald Trump was set to meet Russian President Vladimir Putin. Meanwhile, in Singapore, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong faced allegations of abuse of power from his siblings, which led to a family feud that had played out on social media and in Parliament. The siblings, Lee Hsien Yang and Lee Wei Ling, extended an olive branch, suggesting a possible reconciliation. The family dispute centered on the Oxley Road home of Singapore's founding prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew.

site_title: Manhattan home sales surge as price discounts draw in buyers
summary: Manhattan home sales surged in the second quarter, with 16% more resale purchases than the previous year, reaching 2,597. Average price cuts of 6.1% fueled buyer interest, the largest since 2012. Luxury apartments saw the biggest discounts, with 10% cuts, and properties spent an average of 108 days on the market. Despite this, contracts to buy homes declined 8% from last year.

site_title: NetLink IPO set to be priced near low end: IFR
summary: NetLink NBN Trust, the broadband unit of Singtel, is set to price its IPO near the low end, raising about US$1.7 billion in Singapore's largest listing in four years. The offering will be priced at S$0.81 per unit, targeting a diverse base of investors. NetLink is offering 2.9 billion units, with Singtel owning 24.99% after the IPO, which is slated for debut on the Singapore stock exchange on July 19.

site_title: Why your next car will be more than a car
summary: SUVs and crossover cars are dominating car sales, with one in three cars sold being an SUV or crossover. In the US, SUVs made up 63% of new car sales last year. Modern SUVs are becoming more car-like, with features like sleek designs, advanced tech, and agile handling. Car manufacturers are responding by launching new SUVs, such as the Kia Sorento GT Line, Audi Q5, DS 7 Crossback, Mazda CX-5, Toyota Harrier, and Honda CR-V, which are designed to appeal to a wider audience and challenge traditional car sales.

site_title: Just like old times
summary: Australian chef Clayton Wells' upcoming restaurant Blackwattle will open in September in Singapore, marking his second collaboration with local restaurateur Loh Lik Peng. The restaurant, named after a native Australian plant, will feature a menu with familiar dishes and locally-inspired options, with prices in the mid-range. Wells plans to divide his time between Blackwattle and his Sydney restaurant Automata, which has been well-received. The chef aims to build his style organically, engaging with the local community and incorporating local ingredients into his menu.

site_title: Straphangers, unite
summary: MRT grab handles are designed to have some slack, allowing for a "give" when passengers grab onto them, reducing the risk of injury from head trauma. However, this design also causes passengers to swing forward and lose balance during acceleration. A 2001 peer-reviewed paper by Royal Adelaide Hospital general surgeon Michael Patkin provides guidelines for handle design, including the importance of stiffness and minimal slack. In contrast, some subway systems, like the New York subway, have eliminated swinging handles in favor of fixed bars, reducing the need for maintenance and improving safety.

site_title: Triyards issues Q3 loss warning
summary: Triyards Holdings issued a profit warning for Q3 2017 due to the depressed oil and gas industry and marine market. The listed yard group expects a net loss in Q3 compared to the previous year, and is considering impairing certain assets, including properties in Houston. The group also faces a US$38 million financial exposure to Ezra Holdings, its parent company, which filed for bankruptcy. Triyards has applied for extra time to announce its Q3 unaudited financial results, which are expected to take 21 days to receive.

site_title: Tip to fund managers: Stop hugging the benchmark; take on more active risk
summary: The US$16 trillion mutual-fund industry is facing a major crisis as investors shift to passive funds offering better returns for less. The industry's growth is slowing, with flows out of active funds and into passive funds reaching US$500 billion in the first half of 2017. Experts say active fund managers must differentiate themselves by taking on more risk and demonstrating a clear investment strategy, as the "exodus" mainly hits "high-priced benchmark huggers." East Capital's founder Peter Elam Hakansson advises investors to focus on being active owners and meeting the company's owners to gain an edge.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint unit to buy 76.5% of German logistics player
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited's unit, Geneba Properties NV, has agreed to acquire a 76.5% stake in German logistics company Harder, Gutperle, Harder & Gutperle GmbH GbR for 20.5 million euros (S$32.1 million). The acquisition is for a 38,870 sqm automotive logistics facility leased to a leading German car manufacturer. The purchase price is payable in cash and funded from borrowings and internal resources.

site_title: Recession not imminent despite economic uncertainty
summary: DBS speakers at a forum have expressed confidence that a recession is not imminent, citing robust macro fundamentals worldwide. The treasury yield curve spread remains "respectably positive," and corporate earnings growth continues, despite slow global economic growth. Analysts also highlight potential value in commodities and equities, particularly in Europe and Asia. The market's reliance on liquidity and concerns about monetary tightening by the Fed are seen as overdone, with expected Fed balance sheet reduction taking about five years.

site_title: Revisiting her memorable experiences
summary: Sumiko Tan, executive editor of The Straits Times, has published a new book titled "Sundays with Sumiko" featuring 74 of her personal columns from over 22 years. She began writing for the newspaper in 1985 as a university graduate, and her columns have made her a household name among readers. Tan's career spans 32 years, from her first column to her current position, showcasing her growth and contributions to the publication.

site_title: Will golf get another shot on the greens?
summary: Golf faces a crisis due to declining participation, course closures, and negative publicity. The sport has been criticized for being slow, expensive, and exclusive. A report by the Asian Golf Industry Federation states that the number of golf courses closing exceeds those opening, with notable examples including Golfsmith's bankruptcy and Nike's club production halt. The future of golf is uncertain, but efforts to revitalize the sport are underway.

site_title: Shopping bag
summary: The Club 21 Bazaar will be held at the Marina Bay Sands Convention Centre from July 8-9, offering over 300 brands at up to 80% off past-season collections from labels such as Armani and Comme des Garcons. Shoppers are advised to carry small cross-body bags, locate favorite brands, and ensure items have tags for easy checkout. The event will run from 10am to 8pm on July 8 and 10am to 6pm on July 9.

site_title: Chevron House owner said to be seeking buyer
summary: DEKA Immobilien GmbH, a German unit of DekaBank Group, is selling Chevron House in Singapore's central business district for approximately S$700 million. The building was acquired by Deka in 2010 for around US$420 million from a Goldman Sachs fund. The sale process is private, and the buyer has not been identified.

site_title: BOJ offers to buy unlimited amount of bonds to calm markets
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) announced an unlimited bond-buying operation to calm domestic interest rates and weaken the yen. This move sent Japanese government bond yields lower and marked a reversal in the recent slow tapering of its bond buying policy. The BOJ's goal is to keep the 10-year yield around zero percent, and its announcement followed a spike in yields due to concerns about global central banks reducing stimulus.

site_title: Tech stocks boom, but some stock pickers are wary
summary: Tech stocks have experienced a scorching weeklong run, with Amazon's $13.4 billion Whole Foods acquisition further fueling the trend. However, portfolio managers at Parnassus Investments are concerned that the rise of machine-driven tracking funds and low-cost ETFs is distorting the market, making it harder for traditional fund managers to beat the broader market indexes. With $263 billion exiting actively managed mutual funds and $308 billion pouring into ETFs and index funds, the pressure is mounting on Parnassus to adapt its investment strategy, which has lagged in returns compared to its peers.

images.alt_text: STRESSFUL The explosion in low-cost, index-tracking ETFs and soaring technology stocks are generating existential angst among portfolio managers working in traditional mutual fund companies.

site_title: Grow your greens
summary: The Plantui Smart Garden, a fully automated indoor hydroponics kit, allows anyone to grow herbs and vegetables indoors. The kit consists of a lighting unit and a watering unit, utilizing a professional irrigation method. Plantui capsules, containing seeds, are made of lava stone wool and are said to produce five times more nutritious greens than supermarket ones. The system is priced at S$398 for the kit and S$8 for plant capsules, available from plantui.sg.

site_title: Fashion Plate
summary: Lisbon's QUOI, a three-floor lifestyle hub, has opened in the former Teatro Tivoli, offering a range of luxury brands, gourmet meals, and a top-floor restaurant serving dishes like duck confit and lobster bisque. The hub features Ladurée and Assouline outlets, a menswear haven, and a central grocery store. QUOI aims to provide a unique experience for visitors, showcasing Lisbon's grandeur and elegance.

site_title: Bank fees leap from record US syndicated lending
summary: US syndicated loan issuance reached a new half-year record of $1.22 trillion in the first six months of 2017, driven by lower-rated companies repricing higher-cost debt and boosting bank fees to an all-time high of $6.3 billion. Refinancing deals accounted for nearly three-quarters of all syndicated loans, offsetting falling fees on investment-grade loans. M&A activity declined 3.5% from last year, with only one large acquisition loan topping $5 billion in the second quarter.

site_title: France to sell 10 billion euros worth of state assets: source
summary: France plans to sell 10 billion euros worth of state assets, primarily minority stakes, to finance projects promoting innovation. The sale, expected to start in September, aims to support industrial and research projects. This initiative was announced by Emmanuel Macron during his presidential campaign, and Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire confirmed the plan in recent days.

site_title: Cheong's enduring art
summary: A centenary exhibition of Singaporean artist Cheong Soo Pieng's works is on display at Artspace@Helutrans until July 22. The exhibition showcases around 140 pieces, including 100 drawings and 40 paintings, spanning his career and illustrating his evolution in style and abstraction. The artworks depict iconic subjects such as women and landscapes, providing insight into Cheong's unique approach to art in a local context. This celebration highlights Cheong's enduring contribution to Singapore's artistic landscape.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Furry Retreats
summary: A dog and owner retreat staycation, "Bark-A-Tree's Dog & Owner Retreat Staycation," is being organized in Punggol Ranch from July 14 to 16. The 3-day, 2-night package starts at S$628 for two people and a dog, covering meals, accommodation, and activities like grooming workshops and training classes. The event aims to provide a fun and relaxing getaway for dog owners and their pets.

site_title: Embattled May insists she'll still be PM in 2018
summary: Theresa May insisted she'll remain Britain's prime minister in 2018, despite losing her majority in the general election. She faced questions about her job security, Brexit strategy, and influence abroad, but denied losing influence. May said she's determined to fight on and will play her full part, despite polls showing her trailing the Labour opposition. She also stood by the decision to hold the snap election, calling it the "right decision".

images.alt_text: Theresa May insisted she'll still be Britain's prime minister next year, despite losing her majority at last month's general election.

site_title: IMF raises growth forecast for Germany, calls for more investment
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has raised its growth forecast for Germany, citing soaring domestic demand and rebounding exports. The IMF now expects Germany's economy to grow 1.8% in 2017 and 1.6% in 2018, up from previous forecasts. The IMF calls for increased investment and reduced current account surplus, warning that Germany's ageing population and slow structural reforms may dampen growth in the medium term. The IMF recommends boosting public investment in infrastructure and reducing tax burden on labor to support growth.

site_title: Whole Foods sought US$45 per share offer from Amazon
summary: Whole Foods Market Inc accepted Amazon's "best and final" offer of US$42 per share, surpassing its initial offer of US$41 in May. Amazon had also warned it would call off discussions if other potential bidders were approached. Whole Foods had received interest from two other companies and four private equity firms before agreeing to engage with Amazon, which had proposed a US$13.7 billion deal to buy the grocery chain.

site_title: GK Goh dismisses report that it is rethinking investment in Opal Aged Care
summary: GK Goh Holdings has denied a report that it is reconsidering its investment in Australian residential aged care operator Opal Aged Care. The company, which holds a 47.6% stake in Opal, stated there is no truth to the report and remains committed to its partnership with AMP Life, citing Opal's expected growth over the medium to long term.

site_title: Law allows Wee Kim Wee's term to trigger reserved presidential election: High Court
summary: The High Court in Singapore ruled that Parliament can start counting down to the next reserved presidential election from Wee Kim Wee's term, triggering the election for Malay candidates. The court dismissed a legal challenge, citing constitutional amendments that emphasize the president's unifying role and the need for a multi-racial character in the office. This decision allows for the election to proceed, maintaining the reserved position for Malay candidates.

site_title: New York suburban commuters gear up for 'summer of hell'
summary: New York City's suburban commuters face disruptions starting Monday as Amtrak undertakes $40 million in track repairs at Pennsylvania Station, affecting 600,000 daily commuters from New Jersey and Long Island. The repairs, which will last through September 1, may lead to a "summer of hell" with ferry, bus, and parking lot operators capitalizing on the disruption. Officials advise commuters to travel outside of peak hours, purchase tickets ahead of time, and consider alternative routes, while some regular riders see the change as an opportunity to explore new modes of transportation.

site_title: Canada adds 45,300 jobs in June, jobless rate hits 6.5%
summary: Canada's economy added 45,300 jobs in June, with the jobless rate falling to 6.5% from 6.6% in May. The majority of jobs were in part-time employment, with gains in the professional and scientific services sector. The goods producing sector added 16,000 jobs, mostly in agriculture, exceeding analyst expectations of 10,000 jobs.

site_title: Signs of cheer for property, but don't break out the bubbly yet
summary: Singapore's property market shows signs of improvement, with record-high prices in Government Land Sales (GLS) tenders, but analysts caution that the market is not yet fully recovered. Despite a supply glut and weak global economic growth, some analysts believe the market is bottoming out and expect a rise in economic activity in the next six to eight months. However, others warn that the market remains price-sensitive and that rising interest rates and weak employment prospects could dampen demand.

images.alt_text: "The inventory of private residential units will remain high with a supply overhang of about 37,000 uncompleted units as at Q1 2017, of which nearly 16,000 units or 43 per cent are still unsold," said Redas president Augustine Tan

site_title: US job growth accelerates in June
summary: US job growth surged in June with 222,000 nonfarm payrolls added, exceeding expectations. The unemployment rate rose to 4.4% due to more people seeking work, but remains near the Fed's forecast for 2017. This strength in the labor market suggests the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates for a third time this year, despite benign inflation.

site_title: Allianz and Columbia form US$1.26b US real estate venture
summary: Allianz, Europe's largest insurer, has formed a US$1.26 billion real estate venture with Columbia Property Trust Inc, partnering with the company to acquire office complexes in Manhattan, Palo Alto, and San Francisco. Allianz contributed a Manhattan office tower valued at US$220 million, while Columbia added the US$540 million University Circle and US$500 million 333 Market St. The partnership will allow Allianz to increase its ownership in the properties, with a 22.5% stake in University Circle and 333 Market St. The joint venture aims to pursue more office acquisitions.

site_title: Freight rates for very large crude carriers could rise next week
summary: Freight rates for very large crude carriers (VLCCs) may rise next week due to firm sentiment in the Middle East and West Africa markets. However, higher oil prices and limited floating storage opportunities could cap increases. As of Friday, VLCC rates are at W52.50, with a slightly firm undertone, according to brokers.

site_title: Triyards issues profit warning for Q3
summary: Triyards Holdings, a listed yard group, issued a profit warning for Q3 2017, citing a depressed O&G industry and marine market. The company expects a net loss in Q3 and plans to reassess asset values, including Houston properties acquired for offshore crane development. Triyards is waiting for information to evaluate options to unlock cash for current projects and has requested extra time to announce Q3 unaudited financial results. The board views Q3 as a net loss compared to the previous year, citing industry downturns.

site_title: Malaysia's exports surge in May on robust external demand
summary: Malaysia's exports surged 32.5% in May to RM79.4 billion, driven by robust external demand for manufactured and agricultural products. Total trade grew 31.5% to RM153.3 billion, with a trade surplus of RM5.5 billion for its 235th consecutive month. Exports of manufactured goods, mainly electrical & electronic goods, and agricultural products, such as palm oil, also increased. The strong export performance boosted hopes of sustained global demand for Malaysia's products, despite economists' initial forecast of softer trade numbers.

site_title: EU watchdog quizzes ECB's Draghi over ties with G30 bankers
summary: The European Union's ethics watchdog, Emily O'Reilly, has questioned European Central Bank (ECB) President Mario Draghi over his involvement in the exclusive Group of Thirty (G30), a forum attended by bankers and financiers. O'Reilly expressed concerns about the lack of transparency in G30 meetings, which could be incompatible with the ECB's role as a banking watchdog. Draghi has until September to respond to the inquiry, which was triggered by a complaint from activist group Corporate Europe Observatory.

site_title: Syngenta settles farmer's contamination suit ahead of trial
summary: Syngenta, a Swiss agrochemical company, has settled a lawsuit with Nebraska farmer Daniel Mensik over the alleged mishandling of genetically modified seed, causing US corn prices to plummet. The settlement avoids a trial scheduled to start on July 10. Syngenta had previously lost a $218 million jury verdict in Kansas. The company faces additional class action lawsuits in Minnesota and other states, seeking over $600 million in damages. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed.

site_title: Piglet-killing virus threatens supplies from Canada's prairies
summary: A surge in cases of porcine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDv) in Manitoba, Canada, has threatened the supply of piglets to the US market. Fifty cases have been reported in the province, affecting 63,000 sows and potentially cutting output by 200,000 piglets. The outbreak may lead to shortages in the US market, causing US feeder pig prices to rise 24% to $26.76 per piglet. The surge in cases is "unprecedented," with Manitoba reporting only 10 cases in three years prior to 2017.

site_title: Mexico annual inflation rises to 8-1/2 year high in June
summary: Mexico's annual inflation rate rose to 6.31% in June, the highest in 8-1/2 years, surpassing May's 6.16% but below expectations. The increase was attributed to a 0.25% rise in consumer prices and a 0.30% rise in the core index. The central bank's recent interest rate hikes may be paused as inflation could soon peak, supporting the view that policymakers could begin cutting rates next year. The core rate, which strips out volatile prices, rose to 4.83%.

site_title: Opec delegates encouraged by Russian comments on adjusting oil cut deal
summary: Opec delegates are encouraged by Russia's openness to revising the oil supply cut deal, which aims to clear a global supply glut. The existing agreement runs until March 2018, but delegates are considering a larger cut or capping production from Libya and Nigeria, which would face resistance. Oil ministers from Opec member countries, including Saudi Arabia, are scheduled to meet in Russia on July 24 to discuss potential adjustments to the pact. A larger production cut is unlikely to gain sufficient support, with one delegate saying member countries are not ready to do anything more.

site_title: Design's Oscar Winners
summary: The Red Dot Award for Product Design has recognized several outstanding designs, including Alphabet of Light, a modular lighting system by Artemide that enables straight and curved lines to be produced, and LG Smart InstaView Refrigerator, which features a built-in display that shows the contents of the fridge. These designs showcase innovative uses of technology and materials, highlighting the creativity and expertise of designers in the field of product design.

site_title: Audi sales up 1% in June, eyes stronger H2 volume growth
summary: Audi reported a 1% increase in June sales to 170,650 cars, driven by a rebound in Chinese deliveries, which rose 1.7% after a dispute between management and dealers was resolved in May. This marks a contrast to the 4.7% decline in six-month sales. Audi expects stronger volume growth in the second half of the year, citing a positive order position.

site_title: Indonesian state firms securitise assets in bid for big inflows
summary: Indonesian state firms are securitizing assets to attract international pension funds and secure $10 billion in additional investments. The move aims to capitalize on the country's upgraded credit rating and expand infrastructure. Projects such as toll roads, power plants, and airports will be securitized, allowing pension funds to invest in revenue-generating assets with lower risk. The government plans to issue securities with annual returns of 8-9% over five years, but faces competition and concerns about liquidity in the domestic market.

site_title: Saudi Aramco reaffirms commitment to Pertamina JV as CEOs meet
summary: Saudi Aramco CEO Amin Nasser reaffirmed the company's commitment to the Pertamina joint venture project at a meeting in Jakarta. The joint development of the Cilacap Refinery in Indonesia will increase capacity to 400,000 barrels per day. The upgrade, originally set for 2021, has been delayed to 2023 due to Pertamina's need for Saudi Aramco's approval.

site_title: Zambia to build US$548 million cement plant
summary: Zambia will build a US$548 million cement plant in a joint venture with China's Sinoconst to diversify the economy and reduce reliance on copper mining. The plant, to be built in Ndola, will create 1,000 jobs at construction stage and produce 5,000 tonnes of cement daily. The project will also include two 20 megawatt coal-fired power plants. President Edgar Lungu aims to reduce Zambia's dependence on copper mining, which has been affected by commodity price shocks. The project is expected to be completed in three years.

site_title: Singapore Business Federation to lead inaugural business mission to Bangladesh
summary: The Singapore Business Federation will lead a business delegation to Bangladesh from July 8-14, exploring opportunities in infrastructure and consumer sectors. The delegation, comprising 38 government representatives and 32 companies, will sign memoranda of understanding during the visit. Organised by SBF, the Singapore Indian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and the Bangladesh Business Chamber of Singapore, the trip aims to strengthen economic ties between the two countries.

site_title: France steps up efforts to lure London banks to Paris
summary: France is stepping up efforts to attract London banks to Paris after Brexit by offering lower labor costs and equal regulatory treatment to European rivals. The move aims to maintain access to the EU's single market. Several international banks are considering relocating staff to Paris, Frankfurt, or other European cities. French authorities are competing with other European hubs to win over the banks, which are trying to minimize disruption to their operations.

site_title: Mumbai ups purge of British names from railway stations
summary: Indian authorities are renaming Mumbai's railway stations to remove British names, following the recent change from Elphinstone Road to Prabhadevi station. The Maharashtra transport minister plans to rename stations as per locally known names, a move seen as an attempt to purge the city of colonial remnants. Critics argue the name changes are a cynical ploy to appeal to the local Maratha community, while historians lament the erasure of the city's history.

site_title: Panama Canal does some good while upending historic trade routes
summary: The Panama Canal's $5.25 billion expansion has reduced carbon emissions by 17 million metric tons in its first year of operation, exceeding internal forecasts of 9.6 million tons. The widened canal has enabled more efficient ships to travel through, shaving thousands of miles off journeys and reducing fuel consumption. The Panama Canal Authority expects customers to save 320 million tons of CO2 in the first decade of the expanded operation, with the goal of combating climate change for the country's future.

site_title: US:Wall St higher after strong jobs report
summary: US stocks rose on Friday after a strong jobs report, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 49.53 points, or 0.23%, at 21,369.57. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the S&P 500 up 6.67 points, or 0.27%, and the Nasdaq up 27.33 points, or 0.45%. The strong jobs report may lead to a third interest rate hike this year, despite benign inflation.

site_title: Trump hails Nafta progress, says Mexico will pay for wall
summary: US President Donald Trump said progress is being made on trade issues with Mexico, despite strained relations over migration, a proposed border wall, and free-trade costs. Trump reiterated his pledge that Mexico will pay for the wall, but Mexico has refused. The meeting between Trump and Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto at the G20 summit in Hamburg aimed to continue a strong dialogue on Nafta.

images.alt_text: The United States is making very good progress on trade issues with Mexico, President Donald Trump said on Friday after a meeting with Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto, but he also repeated a pledge to make the southern neighbour pay for a border wall.

site_title: Weaker capesize rates pull Baltic index down
summary: The Baltic Exchange's main sea freight index fell 7 points, or 0.84%, to 822 points, as capesize vessel rates dropped 65 points, or 7.95%, to 753 points, its lowest level since February 17. The decline is attributed to weaker capesize rates, which accounts for the majority of the index's value.

site_title: UK industry and trade disappoint in May, adding to questions over economic outlook
summary: The UK manufacturing sector experienced a 0.2% decline in May, disappointing forecasts and adding to concerns over the economic outlook. Industrial output also fell 0.1% in May, with a 4.4% drop in motor vehicle production contributing to the decline. The data follows a slowdown in the economy after the Brexit vote, with consumers reining in spending due to rising inflation. Separate trade data showed a £11.863 billion goods trade deficit in May, wider than forecasts.

site_title: Azeus secures conditional acceptance of tender from HK govt for HK$79.1m contract
summary: Azeus Systems Holdings Ltd secured conditional acceptance of a HK$79.1 million contract from the Hong Kong government for IT services and maintenance. The contract involves designing and implementing a procurement and contract management system for the Hong Kong government. Azeus expects to generate HK$44.0 million in revenue, payable in stages, upon project milestones completion. The tender is expected to be finalized in July 2017.

site_title: Apple fires back at supplier Imagination in contract dispute
summary: Apple has fired back at supplier Imagination Technologies Group, disputing the UK company's claim that it was blindsided by the decision to end their 10-year partnership. Apple says it informed Imagination in 2015 that it would no longer be buying its latest technology, and the relationship was further diminished by 2016. Imagination's CEO says Apple told him in March that products in 2018 or early 2019 would no longer use Imagination's intellectual property, contradicting Apple's timeline. The dispute escalates a contract dispute that has devastated Imagination's business, with its shares down 41% since March.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish weaker despite late rise in STI
summary: Singapore stocks finished weaker despite a late rise, closing with a net gain of 2.67 points at 3,229.01. The Straits Times Index (STI) was capped by uncertainty over North Korea's missile test, US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank's hawkish tone, and a slide in oil prices. Liquidity was low, with 1.4 billion units transacted on Friday. The market had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI adding three points for the week.

site_title: Taiwan June exports surge, fuelling hope for robust H2 gadget demand
summary: Taiwan's exports surged 13% in June, beating forecasts, driven by strong shipments to China, its largest export market. Electronic components and parts related to information gadgets saw double-digit gains. The second half of the year is expected to be robust, fueled by anticipation of new iPhone launches and year-end holiday demand. This growth is seen as a positive indicator of global demand for technology gadgets.

site_title: Indonesia palm oil group worries EU nations will follow French restriction
summary: Indonesia's palm oil association is worried that France's plan to restrict the use of palm oil in biofuels could prompt other European countries to follow, damaging exports. France aims to reduce deforestation by limiting palm oil use, a move seen as part of international pressure on the palm oil industry. Indonesia exported 4.37 million tonnes of palm oil to the EU last year, and the government is working with Malaysia to prevent the implementation of a European parliament resolution calling for sustainable palm oil production. The Indonesian government will defend national interests and take the issue to the World Trade Organization.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 10.600 points to 1,759.930. Losers outnumbered gainers 644 to 209, with a total volume of 1.307 billion lots worth RM1.547 billion.

site_title: May to urge G-20 to coordinate on tracking terrorist finances
summary: Theresa May will urge the G-20 to coordinate on tracking terrorist finances, citing the need for new technology to monitor small sums of money transferred between groups. She argues that parts of the international finance system act as "safe spaces" for groups like Islamic State, and proposes partnerships between police and banks to spot suspicious activity. This comes as Britain faces vulnerability from Islamist-inspired attacks, and May seeks to demonstrate her confidence in counter-terrorism policy, an area where she has a strong track record as home secretary.

images.alt_text: Theresa May will use the Group of 20 summit in Hamburg to call for international coordination to track even small sums of money being transferred between terrorist groups.

site_title: PM Lee Hsien Loong meets Dutch PM Mark Rutte at G-20 Summit
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong met with Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte at the G-20 Leaders' Summit in Hamburg, Germany, on July 7, 2017. The leaders reaffirmed their excellent bilateral relations and discussed regional and international developments, including stepping up cybersecurity cooperation.

site_title: Unesco declares West Bank city of Hebron a heritage site
summary: Unesco declared the Old City of Hebron in the West Bank a protected heritage site in a 12-3 secret ballot, with six abstentions. The decision has sparked a new Israeli-Palestinian spat at the international body. The city, home to over 200,000 Palestinians and a few hundred Israeli settlers, has been a contentious issue in the occupied territory. The UNESCO designation aims to preserve the city's cultural and historical significance.

site_title: StarHub to acquire remaining 49% stake in Accel for up to S$26.2m
summary: StarHub has agreed to acquire the remaining 49% stake in cybersecurity services provider Accel Systems & Technologies for up to S$26.2 million. The acquisition will be in two phases, with the first phase closing by July 2017 and the second phase by 2020. The deal complements StarHub's network-based capabilities and demonstrates confidence in growing its enterprise business, according to CEO Tan Tong Hai.

site_title: Allianz, Columbia form US$1.3b US real estate venture
summary: Allianz SE, Europe's largest insurer, has formed a US$1.26 billion joint venture with Columbia Property Trust Inc. for US real estate. Allianz contributed a Manhattan office tower valued at US$220 million, while Columbia added office complexes in Palo Alto and San Francisco. The partnership aims to acquire more office assets, with Allianz expecting to double its stakes in the properties. This venture is part of insurers' shift to real estate investments to boost investments in longer-term assets, following MetLife's similar deal in 2013.

site_title: Sweden opens US$155b in pension cash to greater risks
summary: Sweden's AP pension system has been given permission to invest more in private equity and reduce bond holdings to boost returns and safeguard retirement funds. The new rules will require 20% of assets to be in safest bonds, down from 30%, and cap "illiquid" investments at 40% of portfolios. This move aims to increase the possibility of good returns and good pensions, especially considering current low interest rates.

site_title: US seeks funds tied to North Korea from eight big banks
summary: US authorities have sought to seize millions of dollars associated with North Korea from eight large international banks, including Bank of America, Bank of New York Mellon, and Citigroup, over transactions worth over $700 million since 2009. The effort comes amid heightened tensions with North Korea following its recent long-range missile test. The seizures are aimed at entities tied to the North Korean military and nuclear programs, including Dandong Zhicheng Metallic Material and its affiliated companies, which prosecutors claim tried to evade sanctions.

site_title: World's top oil traders bet American shale is here to stay
summary: World's top oil traders, including Trafigura, Mercuria, and Vitol, are betting on the long-term viability of US shale oil production. They have invested in US infrastructure and struck supply deals to secure flows of shale oil and gas. This shift reflects the industry's resilience and ability to adapt to market fluctuations. Shale oil has transformed global energy markets, driving crude prices down and prompting OPEC to cut production. The traders see shale as a new reality, offering optionality for oil trading and fueling their growth in the US market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's PM Lee Hsien Loong met Chinese President Xi Jinping in Hamburg ahead of the G-20 summit, marking his first meeting since their last encounter in Hangzhou last September. Meanwhile, Malaysia's exports surged 32.5% in May, exceeding expectations. DNATA Singapore launched a new maintenance base at Changi Airport and WongPartnership formed an alliance with a Philippine law firm. In other news, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and the UK economy contracted for the second month, citing a fresh blow to Labour leader Starmer.

site_title: EU's Tusk hails Trump words, wants to see deeds
summary: European Council President Donald Tusk welcomed US President Donald Trump's comments on strengthening Transatlantic ties, but expressed caution on whether they reflect a change in US policy. Trump stated his support for NATO's mutual defense commitments and criticized Russia. Tusk noted Trump's past willingness to favor better ties with Moscow, and emphasized that words alone are insufficient, actions will be key. The first test of Trump's commitment will be their meeting in Hamburg, where the real question is whether his words translate into a new policy.

site_title: Bank Negara Malaysia reserves slightly up at US$98.9b as of June 30
summary: Malaysia's gross international reserves rose to US$98.9 billion as of June 30, an increase from US$98.7 billion on June 15. The reserves are sufficient to finance 7.9 months of retained imports and are 1.1 times the short-term external debt.

site_title: Strong rise in German industrial output signals solid Q2 growth
summary: German industrial production rose 1.2% in May, exceeding expectations, driven by energy production and capital/consumer goods. This marks the fifth consecutive monthly increase, boosting growth expectations for the second quarter. The sector is expected to continue gaining momentum.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower ahead of US jobs report
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday, July 7, 2017, ahead of a key US jobs report, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.32% and the Topix index down 0.52%. Investors remained cautious, and the benchmark indices closed at 19,929.09 and 1,607.06, respectively.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dip at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets dipped at the start of trading on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.1% to 7,330.52 points. The Paris CAC 40 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 also declined, with the eurozone and German markets experiencing a 0.1% drop. The decline comes as investors await US jobs data, with the US market having edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Japan to raise crude storage capacity for Saudi Aramco by 30%
summary: Japan is set to increase the crude oil storage capacity it lends for free to Saudi Aramco by 30% starting this summer, from 8.2 million barrels to 10.6 million barrels. This move aims to support Saudi Arabia in maintaining customer relationships in northern Asia amidst a global oil glut. In return, Japan secures a priority claim on the stored crude in case of an emergency. The deal, which was extended to 2019, benefits Japan's strategic oil reserves and strengthens its relationship with Saudi Arabia.

site_title: China foreign exchange reserves edge up by US$3b in June to US$3.057t
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves rose $3 billion in June to $3.057 trillion, marking a fifth consecutive month of growth. The increase was less than expected, with economists anticipating a $6 billion rise. China has been tightening capital controls to support the yuan and stem reserve losses, which fell 6.5% against the US dollar last year. The value of gold reserves also decreased to $73.585 billion.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end down on strong foreign selling; won edges up
summary: South Korean shares declined on Friday due to strong foreign selling, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closing down 0.3% at 2,379.87 points. Foreign investors sold 138.6 billion won worth of Kospi shares, while the South Korean won edged up 0.3% against the US dollar. This marks the sixth consecutive week of losses for the won, with a weekly decline of 0.9%. The decline is attributed to offshore investors locking in profits after recent gains.

site_title: Samsung Electronics expects record-high Q2 profits
summary: Samsung Electronics expects a 72% increase in Q2 profits to a record high of 14 trillion won (S$16.75 billion), driven by rising memory chip prices and increased demand for smartphones. This would surpass US tech giant Apple's estimated profit of $10.6 billion. The company's improved outlook comes after moving past a recall debacle.

site_title: US charges former Audi manager in 'dieselgate' scandal
summary: US officials have charged Giovanni Pamio, a former Audi manager, with conspiracy, wire fraud, and Clean Air Act violations for directing employees to design software to cheat US emission tests. This is part of the ongoing 'Dieselgate' scandal, in which Volkswagen admitted to using "defeat device" software in 11 million cars worldwide. The US Department of Justice issued the charges on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end the week on a low
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed the week with a 0.49% decline, following a broad retreat in Asian markets and sharp falls on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index fell to 25,340.85. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.17% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.18%. The decline in Hong Kong's stock market comes ahead of the release of key US jobs data later in the day.

site_title: Share transfer of controlling stake in Cityneon clears hurdle
summary: Cityneon Holdings has cleared the hurdle for the transfer of its controlling stake after shareholders of Malaysia's Star Media Group approved the deal. The 52.51% stake, valued at S$115.6 million, was transferred from Laviani Pte Ltd to Lucrum 1 Investment Limited. This marks a significant development for Cityneon, with Lucrum, an investment holding company in the British Virgin Islands, now holding the majority stake.

site_title: LG Electronics Q2 profit likely to miss estimates on mobile unit woes
summary: LG Electronics reported a preliminary Q2 operating profit of 664 billion won (S$794.8 million), 14% higher than the previous year but missing analyst estimates. Revenue likely rose 3.9% to 14.6 trillion won, also below expectations. The company's mobile division struggles are likely to continue, impacting overall performance. The results were below Thomson Reuters' SmartEstimate of 755 billion won and 15.1 trillion won in revenue.

site_title: ECB taper fears leave euro zone bonds battered and bruised
summary: Euro zone government bonds experienced heavy losses as investors reassessed the outlook for fixed income following comments from European Central Bank board member Benoit Coeure, who suggested the ECB should adjust its policy carefully to avoid abrupt market moves. Yields jumped 12 basis points, with German 10-year Bund yields reaching 18-month highs. The market is expected to remain bearish without fresh information, with concerns about tighter monetary policies from major central banks affecting global markets and supporting the euro.

site_title: Too soon to call property market recovery despite optimistic sentiment: Redas
summary: Singapore's property market is not yet recovered, according to Augustine Tan, president of Redas. Despite government tweaks to cooling measures and developers' optimism, Tan cites weak macroeconomic fundamentals, anaemic global growth, and rising interest rates as reasons for his pessimism. The rental market, office prices, and retail sector continue to face lacklustre demand, with vacancy rates rising. Tan warns that business and consumer confidence could be weakened, further dampening investment and consumption, making it too soon to call a property market recovery.

site_title: dnata Singapore launches new maintenance base at Changi Airport
summary: DNATA Singapore has launched a new 6,900 sq m maintenance base at Changi Airport, boosting its handling capacity by tripling its existing equipment. The base, located next to the dnata Cargo Centre, can handle over 9,000 repairs annually, equipped with new equipment and technology. The move aims to future-proof the company's business, ensuring its fleet of ground service equipment runs smoothly and efficiently. The base was inaugurated by Coordinating Minister for Infrastructure and Transport Khaw Boon Wan, who praised the investment as enhancing the delivery of dnata's services and contributing to the Changi Experience.

site_title: US bombers challenge China in South China Sea flyover
summary: US bombers flew over the disputed South China Sea, asserting the right to treat the region as international territory despite China's claims. The B-1Bs, accompanied by Japanese jet fighters, conducted night-time drills in the area. The move came amid heightened tension in the region, with North Korea claiming it has developed a long-range missile that could threaten the US. The US seeks China to pressure Pyongyang to halt missile research.

site_title: Altrad Investment to buy UK oil services firm Cape for £332.2m
summary: French construction equipment maker Altrad Investment Authority agreed to buy UK oil services company Cape Plc for £332.2m in cash, representing a 46.2% premium to its closing price. Cape's stock rose 47.8% to its highest since May 2015. The acquisition will provide Altrad with a foothold in the UK oil services market.

site_title: UK house prices rise at slowest pace in more than 4 years: Halifax
summary: UK house prices rose 2.6% in the three months to June, the slowest pace in over 4 years, according to Halifax. This marks a slowdown from a 3.3% increase in May. Economists had expected a 3.1% rise. The acceleration in inflation has put pressure on households' finances, contributing to the slower growth.

site_title: China jails labour activist for 4-1/2 years
summary: A Chinese court jailed labour activist Liu Shaoming for 4-1/2 years on a subversion charge over a published account of the Tiananmen crackdown in 1989. Liu had campaigned on labour rights and was detained in 2015. His lawyer, Wu Kuiming, stated that Liu is innocent and will appeal the decision. Western countries have expressed concerns about China's widening campaign to quash dissent, with Amnesty International calling Liu a "prisoner of conscience."

site_title: Malaysia's May exports soar 32.5% y-o-y, well above expectations
summary: Malaysia's exports in May surged 32.5% year-over-year, beating expectations, driven by a 51.5% increase in shipments to China and rising demand for manufactured goods. Imports rose 30.4% in the same period, outpacing exports for the first time since May 2016. The trade surplus narrowed to RM5.5 billion, with exports to the US and EU also showing significant growth.

site_title: South Korea police raid Korean Air headquarters in embezzlement probe
summary: South Korean police raided Korean Air's headquarters as part of an investigation into embezzlement and breach of trust. The probe allegedly involved using company funds to pay for construction work at the home of Chairman Cho Yang-ho. The investigation has not yet identified suspects, and the company's shares declined 3% after the news. The raid was part of a broader probe into the airline's financial practices.

site_title: Canon drops to more than 2-month low after EU threatens huge fine
summary: Canon Inc's stock fell to its lowest level in over two months after the EU threatened to fine it up to 10% of its annual revenue for allegedly breaching rules in its acquisition of Toshiba Corp's medical unit. The EU Commission reached a preliminary view that Canon used an interim buyer to buy the unit before obtaining necessary approvals, potentially resulting in a $2.9 billion fine. Canon declined further comment, but said it would respond appropriately to the regulators' decision.

site_title: South Australia picks Tesla to provide grid-scale battery
summary: South Australia has chosen Tesla to install a grid-scale battery to stabilize the energy grid, following a shutdown of coal-fired plants due to increased wind power. This move aims to prevent outages and drive down energy prices. Dozens of companies from 10 countries initially expressed interest in the project. The battery will be paired with a wind farm provided by Neoen, marking South Australia's efforts to lead the nation in renewable energy.

site_title: Outlook for Asian currencies brightens as Trump trade fades: poll
summary: A Reuters poll found that emerging Asian currencies have brightened compared to the beginning of the year, driven by a weaker US dollar on fading expectations for major US tax cuts. Most Asian currencies, including the Chinese yuan, Taiwanese dollar, and Korean won, have gained over 4% this year. The poll also showed that many Asian currencies are likely to hold onto their gains over the coming 12 months, with the yuan predicted to trade at 6.95 per US dollar by the end of the year.

site_title: US job growth seen accelerating; unemployment rate steady
summary: US employers likely increased hiring in June, boosting wages, indicating a strong labor market. The unemployment rate is forecast to remain steady at 4.3%, a 16-year low. This could lead to a third interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve this year, as labor market strength suggests continued economic growth.

site_title: Hundreds show support for former Thai PM Yingluck as rice scheme trial nears an end
summary: Former Thai Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra appeared at a Bangkok court, where a trial on her involvement in a state rice subsidy scheme is nearing its end. If found guilty, she faces up to 10 years in prison. Critics say the trial is politically motivated, while supporters see it as a test of the military's commitment to tackling corruption. Around 500 supporters showed up outside the court, with Yingluck denying the charges against her and expressing confidence in the witnesses presented.

images.alt_text: Thailand's former prime minister Yingluck Shinawatra arrived at a Bangkok court to shouts of encouragement from her supporters on Friday, two weeks before the final stages of a case about her involvement in a ruinously expensive state rice subsidy scheme.

site_title: Commuter train derails in New York City, no one hurt
summary: A commuter train derailed at New York's Penn Station on Thursday night, but no one was injured. Services from the station were suspended, and the cause of the derailment was not immediately given. The incident was described by the rail company as minor.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars gain against yen; US jobs report eyed
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars gained against the yen after the Bank of Japan offered to buy unlimited government bonds to stem a rise in yields. The Australian dollar rose 0.4% and the New Zealand dollar reached a six-month peak. However, the currencies fell to one-month lows on the euro due to the European Central Bank's plans to dial back stimulus. The US jobs report is expected to be released later, with economists predicting 179,000 jobs added in June.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars gained against the yen on Friday after the Bank of Japan offered to buy an unlimited amount of the country's government bonds (JGBs) to stem a rise in yields, reaffirming its super easy policy.

site_title: China-bound flight returns to Seattle after passenger assaults crew member
summary: A Delta Air Lines flight from Seattle to Beijing returned to Seattle after a passenger in the first-class cabin assaulted a crew member, causing non-life-threatening injuries to two people. The unruly male passenger was subdued by other travelers and taken into custody by local law enforcement assisted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The plane landed safely shortly after 7pm.

site_title: Japan's Rakuten bans ivory sales amid mounting international pressure
summary: Japanese online retailer Rakuten has banned the sale of ivory on its site amid mounting international pressure. The decision follows criticism from wildlife groups, with China planning to shut down its domestic ivory trade by the end of the year. Japan's legal ivory trade has been criticized for its impact on African elephant numbers, with conservation groups stating the trade has no impact on elephant populations. Rakuten's move is seen as a step towards reducing the country's role in the ivory trade.

images.alt_text: Japanese online retailer Rakuten said on Friday it was banning the sale of ivory on its site, shutting a major sales route in one of the world's largest legal ivory markets.

site_title: WongPartnership forms alliance with Philippine law firm ZGLaw
summary: WongPartnership, a Singapore-based law firm, has formed a strategic alliance with Philippine law firm ZGLaw. The partnership aims to leverage each other's expertise to serve clients in the ASEAN region. WongPartnership, with over 300 lawyers, will gain access to ZGLaw's Philippine law capability, while ZGLaw will benefit from WongPartnership's regional expertise in China, the Middle East, and other ASEAN countries. The alliance was formed after the two firms worked together on a high-profile arbitration case worth over $600 million.

site_title: Chinese tabloid says assess North Korea trade 'fairly', after Trump tweet
summary: A Chinese state-run tabloid, the Global Times, has defended China's trade with North Korea, saying it's "fair" despite US President Donald Trump's claims that it's helping the isolated nation. Despite a 37.4% increase in first-quarter trade, the paper notes that longer-term trends show a decline, citing sanctions and a coal import ban as factors. The paper urges China and the US to communicate on sanctions and urges Beijing to continue normal trade activities with Pyongyang.

site_title: ECB needs to adjust policy carefully, flexibly: Coeure
summary: European Central Bank board member Benoit Coeure advises the bank to adjust its policy carefully, flexibly, and transparently to avoid abrupt market adjustments. Coeure emphasizes the need to consider the inflation outlook and communicate decisions clearly to the markets. This approach aims to maintain stability and avoid significant market fluctuations.

site_title: Tencent said to take Honour of Kings to the US and Europe
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd plans to roll out its hit mobile game Honour of Kings to the US and Western Europe as early as September, introducing it to millions of new players beyond China. The game, which generates the majority of Tencent's smartphone gaming revenue, will be launched in the US, France, Italy, Spain, and Germany. This move aims to diversify Tencent's revenue base and create a truly global title to stand alongside foreign acquisitions like League of Legends and Clash of Clans.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tick up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at the open on Friday, despite a global sell-off, due to a below-par US jobs report. The Hang Seng Index shed 0.29% to 25,391.39, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell. Energy firms were hit by plunging oil prices. The US jobs report was seen as a positive factor, but overall, the market was influenced by global uncertainty and the ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Bank of Japan offers to buy unlimited amount of bonds to calm markets
summary: The Bank of Japan announced an unlimited bond buying operation to calm domestic interest rates, which had surged due to a sell-off in developed market bonds. The move sent Japanese government bond yields lower and weakened the yen, as the central bank aimed to keep the 10-year yield around zero percent. The BOJ's actions followed hawkish messages from other central banks and minutes from the European Central Bank suggesting a possible end to stimulus. The move was seen as a strong signal of the BOJ's commitment to its yield curve control policy.

site_title: Morricone's melodies beyond the gunshots
summary: Ennio Morricone, a renowned composer, emphasizes the importance of listening to his music beyond the gunshots in his films. In an interview, he notes that the audience is distracted by dialogue, noises, and special effects, making it difficult to focus on the music. Morricone is celebrating 60 years in the business with a world tour, encouraging listeners to tune in to his melodies.

site_title: Bitcoin can be an asset but not currency: PBOC advisor
summary: A PBOC adviser, Sheng Songcheng, stated that Bitcoin lacks fundamental attributes to be a currency, considering it's generated by complex algorithms and lacks a medium of exchange. Despite this, virtual currencies like Bitcoin have technical value and are assets. The adviser also suggested that China should study issuing a central bank virtual currency to regulate and manage properly, rather than relying on Bitcoin.

site_title: OCBC Yangon branch celebrates second anniversary
summary: OCBC Bank's Yangon branch celebrated its 2nd anniversary with a dinner attended by over 200 people. Since 2014, the branch has provided training and coordinated study trips to over 1,000 bankers. OCBC aims to contribute to Myanmar's long-term economic growth by collaborating with local banks in training and capability-building. The branch offers various banking services, including internet banking facilities, and has been a pioneer in introducing foreign banking services to the country.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.37 points to 1768.07. Volume was 47.84 million lots worth RM22.49 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 95 to 72.

site_title: The next WannaCry cyber attack could cost insurers US$2.5b
summary: A potential next WannaCry cyber attack could result in costly claims for insurers, estimated at up to $2.5 billion. Insurers have largely avoided claims from recent attacks, but a combination of WannaCry's wide reach and Petya's destructive force could lead to significant losses. The global cyber insurance market is expected to grow to $8.5-10 billion by 2020, with demand outpacing supply, but regulators are concerned about insurers' preparedness for potential payouts.

site_title: Asia hit by Wall Street stumble, debt yields spike after ECB minutes
summary: Asian shares fell 0.3% on Friday, following a weak US stock market session, amid expectations of the European Central Bank unwinding its monetary stimulus. Global sovereign debt yields rose, and the US dollar strengthened against major currencies. The ECB's June meeting minutes showed a possible end to its bond-buying pledge, causing investors to diversify funds away from Treasuries. This led to higher funding costs for high-tech sectors, weighing on equities.

site_title: BOJ should steadily proceed with 'implicit' tapering: former policymaker
summary: A former Bank of Japan policymaker, Sayuri Shirai, suggests the central bank should continue its "implicit tapering" of bond purchases, despite potential temporary rises in yields. Shirai believes private investors will buy on dips, and the BOJ won't need to buy large amounts to maintain its zero-interest target. The BOJ has already slowed its purchases to around 50-60 trillion yen, and Shirai's comments come as the central bank considers its strategy for containing bond yields.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks subdued despite record earnings from Samsung
summary: South Korean shares remained subdued on Friday, despite Samsung Electronics' record-breaking quarterly operating profit of 14 trillion won (S$16.75 billion), a 72% increase from last year. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) fell 0.3% to 2,381.80 points. Analysts attributed the market's lack of reaction to the news, citing that investors had already factored in the expected profit growth. The Seoul bourse took a breather amid uncertainty over monetary policy, with offshore investors selling Kospi shares worth 60.4 billion Korean won.

site_title: Coldplay release song to support migrants
summary: Coldplay released a new song, "Aliens," with proceeds supporting migrants crossing the Mediterranean. The song, written with Brian Eno, alludes to the migrant crisis metaphorically. Proceeds will benefit the Migrant Offshore Aid Station in Malta. Frontman Chris Martin sings, "Just an alien / We just want to get home again," referencing the migrants' desire to return home. The song is part of Coldplay's upcoming EP, Kaleidoscope.

images.alt_text: English rockers Coldplay have released a new song written with ambient legend Brian Eno, with proceeds to support migrants who make the dangerous journey to Europe across the Mediterranean.

site_title: Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway nears US$18b deal for Oncor
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway is nearing a $18 billion deal to acquire Oncor Electric Delivery Company LLC, a US power-transmission network. This would be Berkshire's third-largest acquisition and a return to a previously soured investment, following a $2 billion bond investment in Oncor's bankrupt parent in 2013. The deal must be approved by the judge overseeing the bankruptcy and the Public Utility Commission of Texas, which rejected two earlier attempts to sell Oncor.

site_title: China Vanke signs deal to buy 55.1b yuan land assets, shares to resume trade
summary: China Vanke Co Ltd signed an asset transfer agreement to buy land assets worth 55.1 billion yuan from bankrupt Guangdong International Trust Investment Corporation. The Hong Kong shares of the property developer, which were suspended, will resume trading on Friday. China Vanke had won an auction for the land assets last Friday but no formal agreement was initially entered.

site_title: UK retail has biggest June sales rise for six years: survey
summary: British retailers experienced their biggest June sales rise in six years, with a 1.3% increase in like-for-like sales, according to a survey by accountancy firm BDO. The growth was driven by warm weather and weak sales in June last year. Despite a slowdown in consumer spending, fashion sales rose 1.4% and homeware sales increased 0.5%. However, retailers are cautious, as shoppers are dipping into their savings, which may not be sustainable.

site_title: Made in Myanmar: designers put ethical twist on local fashion
summary: Myanmar designers are reviving the country's sartorial heritage by incorporating traditional patterns and fabrics into modern clothing. Pyone Thet Thet Kyaw's boutique in Yangon showcases unique designs, such as the inngyi-inspired dress, which blends traditional and modern elements. This move aims to shift away from mass-produced clothes and promote a more sustainable and ethical approach to fashion. By preserving local designs, Myanmar is also preserving its cultural identity.

site_title: Australia shares tumble on Wall Street; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares tumbled 1.4% on Friday, led by strong declines in the financial sector, following US labour market data that clashed with expectations of a more hawkish Federal Reserve. The decline was broad-based, affecting all sectors, with the "Big Four" banks falling over 1%. New Zealand's benchmark index also slid 0.4%, with Telecom company Spark New Zealand being the biggest loser. The market is expected to remain volatile for at least a month before the reporting season.

site_title: Maersk says too early to predict financial impact of cyber attack
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container shipping line, said it's too early to predict the financial impact of a recent cyber attack on its second- and third-quarter results. The company is focusing on bringing its systems back online and addressing issues with individual customers, with all ports now operational and releasing cargo. Maersk's Asia Pacific chief executive, Robbert van Trooijen, stated that liability and settlement discussions will be addressed later.

images.alt_text: Maersk on Friday said it was too early to predict the financial impact on its second- and third-quarter results from a cyber attack that caused computer outages across the world.

site_title: Samsung rides surging chip demand to record quarterly profit
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a record quarterly operating profit of 14 trillion won ($16.6 billion) in the second quarter, surpassing analyst estimates. Strong demand for semiconductors and the success of its Galaxy S8 smartphone contributed to the earnings. Revenue rose to 60 trillion won, and the company is expected to earn around 15.2 trillion won in the third quarter, with annual profit of 54 trillion won. The results show Samsung is benefiting from higher prices for memory chips and display sales, potentially generating more profit than Apple in the second quarter.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Fischer says fiscal-policy uncertainty denting US investment
summary: Federal Reserve vice-chairman Stanley Fischer stated that uncertainty surrounding US government policy is holding back economic growth due to its negative impact on business investment. Companies have curtailed capital spending partly due to uncertainty about future government policies. Fischer emphasized the need for clarity on government policy to mitigate the damping effect of uncertainty. He suggested that government spending on research and development, infrastructure, education, and public health could promote faster increases in living standards and support productivity growth.

site_title: China urges GM, Mercedes-Benz and Volkswagen to recall cars with faulty air bags
summary: China's General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine has urged General Motors, Mercedes-Benz, and Volkswagen to recall vehicles in China with faulty Takata air bags, citing at least 16 deaths and 180 injuries worldwide. The watchdog estimated over 20 million cars in China are affected, with 24 manufacturers having already recalled 10.59 million vehicles or made plans to recall 1.26 million more. The three foreign carmakers have only proposed testing and analysis, despite legal obligations to recall affected vehicles.

site_title: PM Lee Hsien Loong meets Chinese President Xi Jinping in Hamburg ahead of G-20 summit
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong met Chinese President Xi Jinping in Hamburg ahead of the G-20 summit. The meeting reaffirmed bilateral ties, discussed the Belt and Road Initiative, and the China-Singapore Free Trade Agreement upgrade. Both leaders agreed to promote closer economic integration and cooperation between ASEAN and China. They also discussed regional and global developments, including the KL-Singapore High Speed Rail project and the 20th anniversary of Hong Kong's return to China. The meeting comes after Chinese Premier Li Keqiang accepted PM Lee's invitation to visit Singapore.

site_title: Cities dubbed immigrant 'sanctuaries' hit back on Trump funding threat
summary: The Department of Justice is reviewing letters from 10 cities, including New York, to determine whether to cut federal funding for non-compliance with a US immigration law. The Trump administration claims cities that don't cooperate are shielding "criminal illegal aliens," but officials say the cities are in compliance. The dispute escalates a long-standing feud between sanctuary cities and the administration.

site_title: Panic, damage after deadly Philippine quake
summary: A 6.5-magnitude earthquake struck the central Philippines, killing two people and injuring at least 72 others. Aftershocks caused panic and damage, with 13 trapped people rescued from a collapsed building and three provinces without power. Schools are closed in Leyte, and geothermal plants were damaged. The quake hit at a depth of six kilometers, and local airlines canceled flights to Ormoc City. This is the latest in a series of earthquakes to hit the Philippines, which lies on the Ring of Fire.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.24% lower on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.24% at market open on Friday, following a US sell-off, with losers beating gainers 3:1. The benchmark Straits Times Index dropped to 3,218.51. In the US, the S&P 500 Index closed below its 50-day moving average for the first time in seven weeks.

site_title: Chinese aircraft carrier Liaoning arrives in Hong Kong
summary: China's aircraft carrier Liaoning arrived in Hong Kong on July 7, 2017, as part of a display of military might, amid heightened tensions over Hong Kong's political dissent. The visit by President Xi Jinping, marking 20 years since Hong Kong's return to China, was seen as a warning to activists calling for self-determination or independence. Xi's 30-minute speech warned that any challenge to Beijing's control over the city crossed a "red line", marking a significant escalation of Beijing's stance on Hong Kong's autonomy.

site_title: Europe turns to Europe for deals as US and Asia M&A slips
summary: European companies are turning to domestic mergers and acquisitions for growth, with the first half of 2017 seeing a 70% increase in deal value to $250 billion, driven by high equity valuations and improving economies in Southern Europe. This has outpaced dealmaking in the US and Asia, where spending fell 8.6% and 11% respectively in the first half. Big deals, such as Italy's Atlantia SpA and French lensmaker Essilor International SA, have driven European M&A growth, with buyers paying $10 billion or more. The trend is expected to continue, with financial investors playing a key role.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine unit further extends standstill agreement for drilling rig
summary: Sembcorp Marine's unit, Jurong Shipyard, has extended the standstill agreement for the delivery of the semi-submersible drilling rig West Rigel to January 6, 2018, for the fifth time. The agreement allows North Atlantic Drilling to market the unit for a drilling contract while Jurong Shipyard has the right to sell the unit at an acceptable price.

site_title: Deadly floods sweep southern Japan
summary: Deadly floods have swept through southern Japan, killing at least six people and leaving hundreds stranded. Torrential rain caused rivers to burst their banks, destroying homes and schools, with hundreds of thousands ordered to flee. The floods, exacerbated by a typhoon, have caused widespread damage and disruption, with 20 people still missing. Authorities have deployed 7,800 personnel to affected areas, and the region is expected to continue experiencing heavy rain through Friday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp Marine, Frasers Centrepoint, Noble, KLW
summary: Sembcorp Marine's standstill agreement with North Atlantic Drilling Ltd for the delivery of the West Rigel drilling rig has been extended to Jan 6, 2018. Frasers Centrepoint acquired a 76.5% stake in a German company for S$32.1 million. Noble Group's shares surged 40% on Thursday, but the company attributed it to unknown reasons. KLW Holdings' independent auditor issued a qualified opinion and emphasis on matters for its 2017 financial year.

site_title: Swiss coffee capsule maker leaving 'losing' Nespresso format
