summary: Swiss coffee capsule maker Ethical Coffee Company is winding down production of Nespresso-compatible pods, citing the "losing" format as "totally outdated" and a "loss-making" market. The company, which once made 300 million pods a year, will now produce only 10-15 million biodegradable capsules. Founder Jean-Paul Gaillard aims to shift focus to a new, environmentally friendly and flexible capsule format, promising it will disrupt the coffee market like the iPhone disrupted the mobile phone market.

site_title: Japan May regular pay posts biggest gain in 17 years, real wages inch up
summary: Japan's regular pay grew 0.9% in May, the largest increase in 17 years, while real wages rose 0.1% year-over-year, marking the first positive growth in five months. This suggests Japan's economic recovery is spreading, with the labor ministry data showing the country's recent economic growth is gaining momentum.

site_title: Protests turn violent for Trump's maiden G20
summary: Demonstrations in Hamburg turned violent ahead of US President Donald Trump's first G20 summit, with 1,000 far-left militants clashing with police using water cannon and tear gas. 76 police officers were injured as around 12,000 protesters marched against globalization. The protest was halted, and the event was marred by violence.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint unit acquires 76.5% stake in German logistics facility owner for 20.5m euros
summary: Frasers Centrepoint has agreed to acquire a 76.5% stake in German logistics facility owner Geneba Properties NV for 20.5 million euros (S$32.1 million). The facility, located in Offenbach an der Queich, Germany, has a gross lettable area of 38,870 square meters and is leased to a leading German car manufacturer. The acquisition is valued at 22 million euros as of December 20, 2016, and will be funded by borrowings and internal resources. The deal marks a significant expansion for Frasers Centrepoint's presence in the German market.

site_title: Pence vows 'new era' in US space exploration, but offers few details
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence vowed to usher in a "new era" of American leadership in space, with plans to return to the Moon and send explorers to Mars, but provided few details. Pence toured NASA's Kennedy Space Center, highlighting progress on a spaceship for deep space and privately built capsules for low-Earth orbit. He emphasized the need for cooperation with private industry to make space travel cheaper and safer. However, critics expressed concerns over the lack of policy details, personnel, and budgetary priorities, with some questioning the feasibility of Pence's ambitious plans.

site_title: 'Some' job cuts confirmed by Microsoft
summary: Microsoft has confirmed it is cutting an unspecified number of jobs amid reports of reorganizing its global sales operations, with 3,000 positions potentially affected. The layoffs come as the company refocuses on cloud computing and business services under CEO Satya Nadella, who has shifted the company away from software. Revenue from Microsoft's cloud platform, Azure, rose 11% to $6.8 billion, and the company expects to release its earnings for the recently-ended quarter on July 20.

site_title: SoundCloud slashes staff despite streaming growth
summary: SoundCloud is laying off nearly half its staff, eliminating 173 positions out of 420, as the streaming platform struggles to find ways to make money despite growing revenue. Founded in 2008, SoundCloud has signed deals with major labels but faces challenges in monetizing its model. CEO Alex Ljung stated that the company needs to take "tough decisions" to ensure its long-term health, focusing on cost-cutting, revenue growth, and maintaining its unique competitive advantage. Despite the layoffs, SoundCloud's revenue has more than doubled in the past year.

site_title: Trump weighs 'severe' response to North Korea ICBM test
summary: US President Donald Trump is considering a "pretty severe" response to North Korea's intercontinental ballistic missile test, amid international divisions on how to contain the North Korean threat. Russia blocked a UN Security Council statement calling for fresh sanctions, while China appealed for a scaling down of rhetoric. The US has led the push for tougher sanctions, and Trump warned he is ready to use force if necessary, but Pentagon chief Jim Mattis said diplomatic efforts remain the priority.

site_title: Trump critic quits as US ethics chief
summary: US government ethics chief Walter Shaub has announced his resignation, effective July 19, citing mounting problems with reining in the Trump administration's conflicts of interest. Shaub clashed with the administration over ethics complaints and Trump's business dealings, including his failure to fully divest from his global property empire. His successor will be nominated by Trump, with Senate Democrat Chuck Schumer calling for the new chief to demonstrate a commitment to preventing administration officials from using their positions for personal gain.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower ahead of US jobs report
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on July 7, 2017, due to concerns about tightening monetary policy and North Korea's nuclear ambitions, with the Nikkei 225 index slipping 0.65% to 19,863.37. Investors remained cautious ahead of the US jobs report, also affecting global markets.

site_title: UK business lobby urges 'transitional' Brexit deal
summary: The UK business lobby group Confederation of Business Industry has urged a "transitional" Brexit deal, calling for the UK to stay in the EU single market and customs union until a final deal is in place. The proposal aims to protect jobs and investment, and avoid a hard break with the EU that would impact trade flows. The CBI has argued that uncertainty over Brexit terms is deterring investment and warns against a situation where Britain leaves the single market without a new trade deal.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit 11-week low after ECB minutes; Reckitt, Sodexo weigh
summary: European shares hit an 11-week low on Thursday after minutes from the ECB's latest meeting showed the central bank may scrap its bond-buying pledge. The Stoxx 600 fell 0.7% and Euro zone blue chips also declined. Sodexo and Reckitt Benckiser led the fallers after cutting their growth forecasts due to global cyber attacks and weaker-than-expected results. However, some sectors, such as banks and Italian lenders, rose due to improved confidence and government support.

site_title: Katy Perry promo slammed for 'cruel' koala joke
summary: Katy Perry has faced backlash for telling her pet dog to "chase some koalas" in a promotional video for her Australian tour. Koalas are listed as vulnerable to extinction due to dog attacks, habitat loss, and vehicle strikes. Wildlife vet Claire Madden condemned the joke, calling it "absolute ignorance" and "cruelty to animals." Myer, the retailer promoting the tour, removed the reference to koalas from the video, replacing it with a line about getting a puppy passport. Perry has not commented on the incident.

images.alt_text: Pop superstar Katy Perry has been slammed by animal activists for telling her pet dog to "chase some koalas" in a promotional video for the Australian leg of her global tour.

site_title: US dollar retreats after soft US labour market data
summary: The US dollar fell on Thursday after weaker-than-expected US employment data, affirming a gradual pace of interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The ADP National Employment Report showed private-sector payrolls increased by 158,000 jobs, below economists' expectations, and the Labor Department reported a rise in initial claims for state unemployment benefits. The US services sector index rose, but the employment index fell, suggesting a cooling labour market. This data may lead to further dampening of Fed expectations and a potential pullback for the dollar.

site_title: UK starting salaries jump as Brexit vote hits staff supply: REC
summary: UK starting salaries for permanent jobs rose at the fastest pace since 2015, driven by a shortage of staff due to Brexit. The Recruitment and Employment Confederation (REC) survey found a 19-month high in June, contradicting recent weak earnings growth. This suggests wage growth in Britain may accelerate, offering a rare positive note for Bank of England policymakers.

images.alt_text: Salaries for British workers starting in permanent jobs rose at the fastest pace since 2015 as businesses found it harder to hire staff, a problem exacerbated by Brexit, a survey of recruitment firms showed on Friday.

site_title: Trump blasts Russia, warns future of the West at stake
summary: US President Donald Trump warned that the future of the West is at risk during a speech in Warsaw, Poland, on the first leg of his European trip. He accused Russia of "destabilising" action in Ukraine and warned North Korea of consequences after its intercontinental ballistic missile test. Trump also endorsed NATO's Article Five mutual defence pact and urged Russia to cease its destabilising activities. The speech aimed to ease concerns about the US commitment to NATO and burnish Trump's credentials as a global statesman, but critics say his nationalism and sovereignty stance may divide Europe.

site_title: YuuZoo responds to governance criticism
summary: YuuZoo Corporation responded to criticism over governance issues, clarifying that the appointment of RHT Corporate Advisory (RHTCA) as share transfer agent and Elizabeth Krishnan as company secretary were concurrent and bundled for efficiency. The company secretary role is distinct and independent, with no conflict of interest. YuuZoo is also in talks with Cinram Europe's subsidiaries on a country-to-country basis, despite having an exclusive option to buy the logistics provider's holding company.

site_title: US isolated over climate stance, says G20 host Merkel
summary: US President Donald Trump faces isolation at the G20 summit due to his climate sceptic stance, with many countries determined to honor the Paris accord. Chancellor Angela Merkel stated that the talks on the issue would be challenging, but the G20 nations would not paper over differences. The final document is expected to reflect the 19-versus-US situation, reaffirming the Paris accord's irreversibility while "taking note" of Washington's decision.

site_title: Migrant worker dragnet unsettles Malaysia's firms
summary: Malaysia's crackdown on illegal migrant workers, which began on June 30, is disrupting operations in construction and agriculture, with many fleeing underground or leaving the country. The crackdown, led by Immigration Director-General Mustafar Ali, aims to curb the estimated 5-6.7 million migrant workers in the country, with about 2.1 million having permits. The move is expected to impact businesses, with the Malaysian Employers Federation warning of disruptions and SME Association of Malaysia describing documentation checks as troublesome and time-consuming.

site_title: France and Russia vow to fight extremism
summary: French Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian and Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov vowed to put aside differences to combat extremism. The two nations agreed they share a common enemy in Syria and a common objective of peace, despite disagreements over the use of chemical weapons in an April attack. France and Russia are both battling the Islamic State group and have been hit by attacks in recent years. The meeting comes as Russia faces diplomatic pressure from Western nations over its support for Syrian President Bashar al-Assad.

images.alt_text: The French and Russian foreign ministers vowed Thursday to put aside their countries' differences to fight and defeat extremism.

site_title: US: Wall Street drops on labour market data, North Korea concern
summary: US stocks dropped sharply on Thursday due to disappointing labour market data and rising tensions in the Korean peninsula. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.74%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. Private employers added 158,000 jobs in June, below expectations, and weekly jobless claims rose for the third straight week. The Federal Reserve's hawkish stance and geopolitical tensions further dampened investor sentiment, with shares of Tesla, General Electric, and L Brands plummeting.

site_title: Cambodia needs to restore balance in ties with US, China
summary: Cambodia is shifting its focus towards China, ending joint military exercises with the US and scrapping US military aid. The country is seeking to capitalize on China's investments, but is facing difficulties due to strict capital controls imposed by the Chinese central bank. Cambodia's decision to tilt towards China may lead to over-dependence and create a mockery of its neutrality. The country needs to restore balance in its ties with both the US and China to access international trade and investments.

site_title: Starbucks service hurt by understaffing: survey
summary: A survey of 184 Starbucks US workers, supervisors, and managers found that the company's initiative to improve speed and customer service, dubbed "North Star", has not fixed staffing shortages. Despite adding labor to 15% of stores, 75% of respondents said their stores were understaffed. Eighty-nine percent of respondents reported staffing levels as a problem in the past three months, and 62% said their ability to deliver customer service decreased during that time.

site_title: 28 inmates killed in Mexico prison riot: officials
summary: A riot at the Cereso federal prison in Acapulco, Mexico, has resulted in the deaths of 28 inmates and three wounded. The riot was triggered by a permanent feud between rival groups within the prison, with victims reportedly being stabbed, beaten, and mutilated. State police, backed by federal police and the army, have regained control of the prison, and an investigation has been ordered, including into prison staff. This incident highlights the ongoing issues of violence and overcrowding in Mexico's prisons.

images.alt_text: State police have regained control of the prison, backed by federal police and the army, which set up a security cordon outside.

site_title: Qualcomm accuses Apple of infringing six patents in iPhone, iPad
summary: Qualcomm is accusing Apple of infringing six patents on iPhones and iPads that use Intel chips, seeking a ban on the devices from the US market. The dispute centers on Qualcomm's modem chips, which help devices perform well without draining the battery. Apple has accused Qualcomm of unfairly imposing a "tax" on devices using Qualcomm chips. A related lawsuit was filed in federal court, and the US International Trade Commission is expected to consider the complaint, which could affect Apple's 10th anniversary iPhone launch this fall.

site_title: YuuZoo responds to Business Times commentary
summary: YuuZoo Corporation responded to a commentary in The Business Times questioning its disclosure and accounting practices. The company addressed issues with a deal to acquire Relativity Media and a duplicate agreement with Etisalat Nigeria. YuuZoo stated that it cancelled the Relativity deal due to misrepresentation and clarified this in February 2017. The company also corrected the duplicate agreement, stating it was signed directly between YuuZoo and Etisalat Nigeria in 2016 after YuuZoo UK's operations ended in 2015.

site_title: Oil settles slightly up; rally on US inventory draw fades
summary: Oil futures settled up 39 cents to $45.52 a barrel after a sharp decline in US inventories of crude oil and gasoline, with US crude stocks falling 6.3 million barrels. However, the rally was short-lived as investors remained bearish about the global crude glut, citing the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries' need to make further output cuts to balance supplies. Oil prices have tumbled from one-month highs due to increased production from Opec, with some investment banks reducing their price outlooks to $50 per barrel.

site_title: China bond defaults a way to price risks: analysts
summary: China's corporate debt market is shifting towards proper market pricing, with investors distinguishing among issuers based on perceived credit quality. Defaults have led to a rise in delinquencies, causing investors to demand higher returns from riskier borrowers. This trend is reflected in higher bond yields for sectors such as coal and real estate, which have seen significant declines in business due to government policies. The government is encouraging foreign expertise to develop pricing in the market, which may lead to further differentiation in bond ratings.

site_title: MSIG, DBS launch instant e-payment service for travel claims
summary: MSIG and DBS have launched Singapore's first instant electronic payment service for travel insurance claims, reducing settlement time by about four days. The service, using DBS' real-time payment technology, is the first to utilize an application programming interface (API) and marks MSIG's first deployment of this service. This reflects MSIG's partnership with DBS, which aims to improve customer experience.

site_title: Airbus gets US$22b China orders for 140 jets
summary: Airbus secured US$22 billion in orders from China for 140 jets, including 100 A320s and 40 A350s, over the next five to six years. The deal was signed with state-owned China Aviation Supplies Holding Co, which will allocate aircraft to individual airline operators. The agreement marks a significant milestone for Airbus as China is expected to become the world's largest aviation market by 2024, surpassing the US. Airbus is also exploring opportunities to sell more A380 superjumbos, with demand estimated at up to 100 units in the region.

site_title: Time to push efforts to deliver on Paris climate pledges
summary: US President Donald Trump's withdrawal from the Paris climate accord should not divert attention from global efforts to combat climate change. The world's energy demand is set to double this century, driven by population growth and air pollution concerns. Asia, where coal is the largest source of power, must transition to cleaner energy sources to reduce emissions and improve air quality. The region's 11 billion population by 2050 will require significant changes to its energy system, with cleaner energy and reduced carbon emissions essential for sustainable development.

site_title: Paying tribute to ordinary heroes
summary: Hong Kong director Ann Hui's film "Our Time Will Come" is based on true events during the Japanese occupation in 1941. The story follows Fang Lan, a schoolteacher who becomes involved in the resistance movement, and her relationships with a recruiter and her ex-beau, a double agent. The film explores themes of maternal bonds, strong females, and everyman valour, with a focus on ordinary heroes. With a fine cast, Hui's historical espionage thriller is a quiet and moving tribute to the civilian heroes of the time, winning awards in 1999.

site_title: LeEco's billionaire founder pleads for time as creditors close in
summary: LeEco's billionaire founder Jia Yueting has pleaded for time to repay debt and pursue his electric car ambitions, as creditors close in. A Chinese court has frozen billions of dollars in assets held by him and associated companies. Jia stepped down as CEO of LeEco's main listed company to focus on Faraday Future, a US-based startup. LeEco has struggled with cash shortages and debt, with shares frozen by the court and the company considering asset sales. Jia vowed to repay debts and focus on developing a futuristic electric car, despite facing significant financial challenges.

site_title: Tencent unit's request to withhold execs' shareholding info draws flak
summary: China Literature Ltd, a subsidiary of Tencent Holdings, has requested a waiver from Hong Kong listing rules to withhold shareholding information of three executives, citing concerns over workplace culture and distraction from business duties. The request has drawn criticism from corporate governance advocates, who argue it sets a bad precedent and undermines transparency. The three executives, who are also board members, hold "insignificant" stakes in Tencent, but the request has sparked concerns over the potential for undue influence and lack of accountability.

site_title: Need a bike, ball or brolly? In China, there are sharing apps for these and more
summary: China's sharing economy has reached $3.45 trillion, more than doubling in a year, with bike-sharing, electric scooters, and umbrellas being the most popular services. However, the industry is facing challenges, with some startups going bust, and the government is warning of over-sharing. Regulations are being introduced to control the industry, including a three-year service life for bicycles and requiring companies to hire maintenance employees. Experts warn of industry consolidation and a bubble in sharing companies, with investors pouring in large sums.

site_title: GuocoLand sets July launch date for Robertson Quay condo
summary: GuocoLand has set a July 22 launch date for its Martin Modern condo in the Robertson Quay area, with an estimated average price of S$2,300 per sq ft.

site_title: Good old days once again for NY's Grand Central Terminal
summary: Grand Central Terminal in New York will briefly regain its role as a major transportation hub when six Amtrak Empire Service trains are rerouted to the terminal from Pennsylvania Station starting July 10. The move is part of a service adjustment that will relieve pressure on Penn Station during ongoing infrastructure repairs. This temporary restoration of intercity rail service is a surprise silver lining for riders, with some speculating that it could lead to permanent changes. The move is seen as a positive development for the iconic terminal, which has been largely unused for intercity travel since 1991.

site_title: Any kind of Brexit break-up will carry costs, EU warns
summary: EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier warned that any Brexit break-up will carry costs for the UK, including friction in trade relationships and a loss of freedom of labor movement. He rejected the idea of a "frictionless" trade relationship and stated that the UK's decision to leave the EU will have significant consequences, including leaving the UK in an inferior position. The EU will not allow the UK to weaken the single market's rules or cherry-pick sectors, and any withdrawal will have significant economic implications.

site_title: Teen Spidey comes of age in reboot
summary: Spider-Man: Homecoming, the second reboot of the Spider-Man franchise in 15 years, offers a high-energy episode with a multi-faceted villain, frenetic action scenes, and humor. The film follows 15-year-old Peter Parker as he navigates his training-wheel phase, learning to balance superhero life with adolescence. With a new suit of high-tech armor and the help of Tony Stark, Peter pursues the villainous Vulture, played by Michael Keaton. The film explores Peter's vulnerability and human qualities, setting him apart from other Avengers.

site_title: Noble shares jump nearly 40 per cent
summary: Noble Group's shares surged nearly 40% to a 6-month high of 64 cents, with 123.7 million shares changing hands, amid unexplained trading activity. The group denied knowledge of any reason for the price surge, sparking speculation of big player acquisitions. Noble has recently acquired a 50% stake in Tailai Coal and reduced its deemed interest due to stock borrow return. The company is still in talks with potential investors on the sale of an interest in the group or parts of its business.

site_title: Inchcape opens S$55m facility, marks 50 years with Toyota
summary: Inchcape, a London-based vehicle distributor and retailer, has opened a new S$55 million facility in Singapore, marking its 50-year partnership with Toyota. The 10-storey integrated vehicle facility houses Borneo Motors' corporate office, regional training centre, and is a one-stop shop for Toyota customers. The investment demonstrates Inchcape's commitment to the Singapore market, where the company also represents Lexus and Hino commercial vehicles. Despite challenges from a competitive car market, Inchcape CEO George Ashford remains confident in its strategy and market leading sales figures.

site_title: Improving the return on your AI and 'big data' investment
summary: The Singapore government has identified AI and data science as key "frontier technologies" to boost the digital economy, investing up to S$150 million over the next five years. This move aims to improve the return on investment in AI and big data. The government's focus on AI development comes as companies worldwide are investing heavily in the technology.

site_title: Trade deficit narrows in May as exports hit two-year high
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed to US$46.5 billion in May, a 2.3% decrease from April, driven by a surge in exports to a two-year high. Real goods exports rose 0.4% to US$192 billion, lifted by record high petroleum exports and increases in exports to China, Mexico, and Canada. Despite the decline in the trade deficit, economists expect it to still weigh on economic growth in the second quarter, with the Atlanta Federal Reserve forecasting a 3% GDP growth rate.

site_title: From peak to peak, in BT Weekend
summary: Aman founder Adrian Zecha's new hotel brand Azerai has made a comeback, marking his return to the spotlight after a split with the luxury group he co-founded. Meanwhile, independent hoteliers are breaking the mold of international chains, and a spotlight is on this year's Red Dot award winners for innovative design. The article also explores the link between peak physical fitness and corporate performance, and features interviews with women who balance work and family life.

site_title: Mahathir still hates currency traders - decades after crisis
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad still expresses disdain for currency traders, calling them "unscrupulous profiteers" in an "immoral" line of work. Two decades after the Asian financial crisis, Malaysia's economy contracted but rebounded, with capital controls defended by Nobel Laureate Paul Krugman and later the IMF and World Bank. Mahathir's approach was seen as correct, as it restored stability and gave businesses certainty to plan and invest. However, his legacy is now being questioned, with business leaders arguing that affirmative action policies hinder competitiveness and the government blaming the current administration for the economy's woes.

images.alt_text: "There's no point in treating a currency like a commodity, devaluing it artificially and causing a lot of poverty among poor countries," says Dr Mahathir.

site_title: Comfort food from the southern USA
summary: The Bird Southern Table & Bar, a Miami-based restaurant, has opened its first overseas outpost in Singapore at Marina Bay Sands. The restaurant serves classic Southern comfort food, including fried chicken, grits, and biscuits. Reviewers praise the restaurant's hearty portions, sumptuous decor, and showmanship. However, some dishes, such as the shrimp and grits, fell short of expectations. The restaurant is a great option for those seeking a break from healthy or fine dining, offering a convivial vibe and indulgent menu options. Rating: 6.5.

site_title: US dollar's bounce falls flat; euro edges up
summary: The US dollar's bounce after a brief rally failed to hold, closing flat against the euro, which edged up. The US Federal Reserve's policy minutes failed to provide clarity on future interest rate increases, despite a split among policymakers on inflation. Analysts remain cautious, awaiting US data and comments from Fed officials, which could impact the dollar's strength against emerging markets and the euro.

site_title: World's first listed social bond draws private banking clients
summary: Singapore's Impact Investment Exchange (IIX) has issued the world's first social sustainability bond, listing US$8 million of 5.65% four-year Women's Livelihood Bonds on the Singapore Exchange. The bonds fund impact enterprises benefiting women, with IIX providing first-loss capital and the US Agency for International Development guaranteeing 50% of the principal amount. The transaction marks a step forward for social capital markets, with robust take-up among private banking clients, and aims to establish a template for self-sustaining fundraising for social causes.

site_title: Hsien Yang, Wei Ling to stop posting evidence on social media
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's siblings, Lee Wei Ling and Lee Hsien Yang, have agreed to cease posting further evidence on social media regarding their public feud over the fate of their family home, 38 Oxley Road. The siblings, who are the children of late Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, had been sharing evidence and accusing their brother of abusing his power. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has expressed his wish to settle the dispute privately, and the siblings have accepted this, stating they will discuss the matter without government agencies.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Energy players quit Nasdaq for better deals with brokers, banks
summary: Nasdaq Commodities, a power exchange in the Nordic region and Germany, has seen a significant decline in trading activity, with at least 16 companies, including nine utilities, quitting the exchange since 2014. The new rules imposed to reduce risk have made trading too expensive and cumbersome, with the loss of bank guarantees as collateral and changes to contracts requiring daily settlement. Energy players are now buying directly from power plants or brokers and banks, with trading on the exchange plummeting 25% in the first half of 2017.

site_title: ElderShield panel floats idea of government managing the scheme
summary: The ElderShield Review Committee in Singapore proposes that the government manage the enhanced severe disability insurance scheme, citing feedback from focus group discussions. The idea aims to simplify administration, similar to MediShield Life. The committee has submitted the proposal to the Ministry of Health and set up a claims assessment sub-committee to improve the claims process. The sub-committee aims to provide better guidance for users, particularly caregivers, and identify key points for important information. Recommendations are expected in the first half of next year.

site_title: South Korea's bond market shows cracks with sudden outflow
summary: Foreign investors pulled 2.7 trillion won (S$3.2 billion) from South Korea's bond market on Monday, the largest one-day outflow since 2011, amid rising hawkish comments from global central banks and escalating tensions over North Korea. The outflow was followed by a slight recovery, but analysts warn that more withdrawals are possible if policymakers worldwide follow their rhetoric with action. The won has weakened to its lowest level in almost four months, and the cost of insuring against a default in South Korea's sovereign or corporate debt rose to a near seven-week high.

site_title: Can Scoot's long-haul routes be viable?
summary: Budget carrier Scoot, a subsidiary of Singapore Airlines, has launched its first long-haul flight between Asia-Pacific and Europe, with plans for five new destinations in the next year. Despite the airline's success, its parent company, Singapore Airlines, reported a net loss of S$138.3 million in Q4 FY17 due to low yields and increasing fuel costs. Scoot's business model, which focuses on basic budget fares, may not be sustainable for long-haul routes, and the airline needs to adapt to the challenges in the aviation industry to maintain its lead.

site_title: Trump confronts German port city already turning to China
summary: US President Donald Trump's "America First" protectionist stance will clash with Germany's free-trade mantra at the upcoming G20 summit in Hamburg, where the country's vast trade surplus and significant exporting industry are on the line. Chancellor Angela Merkel has warned that any protectionist measures would be a "grave error," while Trump has pledged to address Germany's massive trade deficit with the US, threatening retaliation. Hamburg, a major European port, is particularly vulnerable to any downturn, with 150,000 jobs dependent on trade, including companies such as Airbus and Deutsche Lufthansa.

site_title: Looking at the world, in more than one way
summary: David Hockney: A Matter of Perspective, an exhibition at STPI, explores the artist's experimentations in printmaking framed by the concept of perspective. The show features 36 works by Britain's most celebrated living artist, including paintings, drawings, photomontage, and digital painting. The exhibition, which opened on the gallery's 15th anniversary, unites different strands of Hockney's practice, exploring the act of looking and how it captures three-dimensional forms in two-dimensional forms. The show includes works such as "The Perspective Lesson" and "An Image of Celia," which invite visitors to explore connections between works and reflect on how we perceive the world around us.

site_title: Cesar Millan shows he's still pack leader
summary: Cesar Millan, known as the "Dog Whisperer," visited Singapore to film a TV show and share his training methods. He emphasizes the importance of finding balance and harmony with nature, and educating humans to become "pack leaders" to train their pets. Millan advocates for discipline, affection, and exercise, and believes that dogs reflect how humans live their lives. He also credits his own upbringing on a farm in rural Mexico with shaping his approach to canine behavior, which has led to his success as a celebrity trainer and author.

site_title: Vietnamese architect comes up with easy-to-erect dwelling for poor
summary: Vietnamese architect Vo Trong Nghia has designed "S Houses," prefabricated homes that can be assembled in under an hour and cost $1,500 each. The structures, which are iterations of a prototype developed since 2013, will serve as living quarters for a Buddhist meditation center in Vietnam and aim to provide affordable housing for people in slums and remote areas worldwide. The S House is designed to last 30 years, withstand severe tropical storms, and can be modified to suit local conditions, with plans to mass-produce and sell them at cost to institutions and refugees.

site_title: A reimagined French lifestyle empire that pulls out all stops to impress
summary: L'Officine Universelle Buly, a French luxury cosmetics company, has opened its second Parisian outpost in the Marais district. The 2,000-sq ft space features a boutique selling potions, powders, soaps, and perfumes, as well as a Japanese florist and Café Tortoni, a revived Belle Époque cafe. Founder Ramdane Touhami aims to expand the brand into a European luxury group, offering a range of amenities in five-star hotels and opening 30 more boutiques worldwide in the next year.

site_title: 2015 - a vintage that comes just once in a decade
summary: A 2015 vintage wine holiday in Europe's Tuscany and Burgundy regions offered pleasant weather, with warm temperatures and low humidity, making it a comfortable and enjoyable experience. Visitors to wineries, including Fontodi, Conti Costanti, and Domaines Comtes de Vogue, praised the 2015 and 2016 vintages, with many considering them potentially very good. The warm weather allowed for tastings of both vintages, showcasing the quality of the wines.

site_title: Barclays chairman confident London's euro-clearing hub is safe
summary: Barclays chairman John McFarlane expressed confidence that London will remain a hub for euro-clearing activities despite Brexit, countering dire predictions of a mass exodus of bankers from Britain. He argued that euro-clearing is less likely to be forced to move than other bank businesses, citing its efficiency and economic rationale. McFarlane's comments contrast with warnings from London Stock Exchange Group CEO Xavier Rolet that up to 232,000 jobs are at risk, and are seen as a sign of differing opinions among Britain's business elite on Brexit.

site_title: Serious deals not done while drunk: Sports Direct's Ashley
summary: Sports Direct owner Mike Ashley denies making serious business decisions while drunk, calling a former employee's claim of a £15 million bonus deal while intoxicated "nonsense". Ashley testified that he doesn't make major deals while drinking, contradicting a lawsuit alleging he reneged on a pledge to pay a £15 million bonus if the retailer's share price doubled.

site_title: The science behind interior design's ability to charm and captivate
summary: Hotel interior design is evolving to cater to the changing needs of savvy travelers, particularly millennials. With the rise of the gig economy and digital disruption, travelers are seeking immersive experiences and unique environments. Hotels must design spaces that provide an all-encompassing offer, rather than just a commodity, to stay relevant. Effective interior design can affect guests' emotions and behavior, from calming to inducing hunger. To succeed, hotels need to understand their guests' needs and create a seamless connection through design, from booking to departure.

site_title: Safety, reliability top priorities for AssetCo in KL-S'pore high-speed rail tender
summary: Malaysia's MyHSR Corp and Singapore's LTA announced key details for the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High-Speed Rail, including the development of AssetCo, a private company to design, build, finance, and maintain the rail system. Safety and reliability will be top priorities, along with meeting availability and reliability requirements, and developing a network code for all entities involved. The double-track line will accommodate a design speed of 350 km/h, with operations expected to begin by Dec 31, 2026, and travel time between cities reduced to 90 minutes.

site_title: Vallianz expects to raise as much as S$179m from enlarged rights issue
summary: Vallianz Holdings is expected to raise up to S$179 million from an enlarged rights issue, with the rights shares having warrants attached. The move is part of debt restructuring agreements with Swiber Holdings and Rawabi Holding Company. The maximum number of new shares and warrants has been increased, with Rawabi, a strategic shareholder, planning to subscribe for all excess rights shares. The gross proceeds will be used to partially repay advances made by Rawabi and Swiber, as well as for bank loans and working capital purposes.

site_title: Baidu snags 50-plus partners for its Apollo driverless car
summary: Baidu has enlisted over 50 partners for its Apollo driverless car project, including major players in mapping, ride-sharing, and carmaking. The program aims to fine-tune Baidu's autonomous car software and overtake rival research efforts, with a goal of releasing a driverless car by 2018 and mass production by 2021. The partnerships include Chinese carmakers, suppliers, and technology companies, and aim to get fully autonomous vehicles on city streets as early as 2018. Baidu's shares rose 2.7% following the announcement.

site_title: STI drops 0.7% but pennies stay firm
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.7% to 3,226.34 on Thursday, led by banking stocks, with DBS dropping 0.36% and Noble Group rising 36% after its governance and accounting practices were questioned. Penny stocks performed better, with 200 rises versus 222 falls, excluding warrants. The US Federal Reserve's minutes showed a third interest rate hike this year is likely, and market expectations are for rate hikes in September and December.

site_title: Terrorism, bureaucracy threats to West: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump delivered a speech in Warsaw, Poland, warning that Western nations are threatened by terrorism and bureaucratic overreach, and must cling to values of faith, family, and freedom to survive. Trump equated bureaucracy with terrorism, saying it drains the vitality and wealth of the people, and that the West can prevail only if nations stand up to these threats. He also praised Poland as a model for Western values and urged unity against shared enemies.

site_title: MyRepublic not buying M1: CEO
summary: MyRepublic, a Singapore-based fibre broadband services provider, will not buy telco M1, instead opting to become an MVNO (mobile virtual network operator) in Singapore. The company will lease mobile bandwidth from an existing telco to offer services starting in October. MyRepublic plans to raise S$100 million through private equity investors, with IPO proceeds to fund expansion in eight South-east Asian markets. CEO Malcolm Rodrigues aims to grow the company's valuation from S$500 million and become a leading telco in the region within three years.

images.alt_text: "Once TPG Telecom won its bid to become Singapore's fourth telco, I got calls from all three players with offers to collaborate with us, against a common enemy (TPG)," says Mr Rodrigues.

site_title: Branson shoots for 2018 space trip as Virgin resumes test flights
summary: Richard Branson is set to revive powered test flights for Virgin Galactic's space tourism venture by the middle of next year, with the aim of extending them into space by November or December. The billionaire entrepreneur aims to start full commercial passenger operations by the end of 2018. Following a series of glide-only sorties, powered tests will take place every three weeks, with Virgin Galactic competing with other companies such as SpaceX and Blue Origin in the space tourism market.

images.alt_text: The co-pilot died when Virgin Galactic's original SpaceShipTwo was torn apart in 2014 after he prematurely unlocked a braking mechanism.

site_title: Bike-sharing war in S'pore goes up a gear
summary: Bike-sharing companies in Singapore are intensifying competition, with Ofo raising $700m in funding and Mobike unveiling new bikes. oBike claims to have a local advantage, citing familiarity with Singapore's roads and regulations. The surge in bike-sharing services raises concerns about the sustainability of the sharing economy, similar to the rise of ride-sharing apps.

images.alt_text: To mark its 100th day milestone in Singapore, Mobike will offer free rides till July 31, and introduce a fleet of bikes that feature three gears, adjustable seats and solar-powered headlights.
To mark its 100th day milestone in Singapore, Mobike will offer free rides till July 31, and introduce a fleet of bikes that feature three gears, adjustable seats and solar-powered headlights.

site_title: Energy firms hit by oil dive; North Korea crisis fuels uncertainty
summary: Asian energy firms declined due to a 4% drop in oil prices, amid concerns of a global supply glut. North Korea's missile test and US warnings of force against the country fueled uncertainty, while investors remain cautious about the impact of an Opec-Russia output cut. Oil prices had surged 10% since mid-June on bargain-buying, but fell back on supply worries. Global equity markets also swung back into negative territory due to lingering worries about the North Korea crisis, with the US pushing for tougher sanctions.

site_title: Another side of 'the Greatest Briton'
summary: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill, played by Brian Cox, is portrayed in a new biopic as a man struggling with guilt, insecurity, and depression, despite his iconic status as the "Greatest Briton." On the eve of the D-Day invasion, Churchill's mental state is fragile, leading him to attempt to sabotage the mission. The film humanizes the legendary leader, but its character study is thin, with Cox delivering a compelling performance as the isolated and troubled Churchill.

site_title: Creative diplomacy is the least worst option for dealing with Pyongyang
summary: North Korea successfully tested its first intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) on the US's America's independence day, prompting the US to consider its response. The US initially called for tougher sanctions, but this has failed to contain the regime's ambitions. With military options no longer viable, diplomacy is seen as the least worst option, despite past failures. The US and South Korea may be able to offer adequate assurances and incentives to persuade North Korea to freeze its nuclear development and consider independent verification.

site_title: The economy still Trump's main political asset
summary: Renowned economists initially predicted a global recession if Donald Trump won the 2016 US presidential election, but the markets have since rallied, defying those warnings. Investors now expect a "Trump Bump" in the economy, driven by tax reform, regulatory reform, and stimulus spending. However, some economists, known as "Trump bears," believe the rally will soon end, while others, "Trump bulls," predict a "Trump Boom" with potential economic growth and stock market highs. The outcome depends on the administration's ability to deliver on its economic pledges, including infrastructure spending and tax cuts.

site_title: Australian housing 'bubble' fears overblown: HSBC economist
summary: HSBC economist Paul Bloxham says Australia's housing 'bubble' fears are overblown, citing strong demand and undersupply as the main drivers of soaring home prices. Despite concerns about a potential bubble, Bloxham notes that fundamental factors explain the price boom, and regulatory measures to cool the market will likely help. Price increases have been smaller in areas like Perth, where demand has weakened due to a mining boom decline. A significant fall in housing prices is unlikely, unlike in the US and Spain during the global financial crisis.

site_title: Temasek takes stake in European malt producer
summary: Temasek, a Singapore state investor, has taken a stake in Boortmalt, the world's fifth largest malt producer, through a 150 million euro capital increase. The investment, alongside French farmer-controlled Unigrains and French sugar group Tereos, aims to tap into rising demand for beer in emerging markets. Temasek's involvement is expected to bring expertise on international markets, particularly in Asia. The move follows Axereal's announcement of expanding its malt production in Ethiopia and Antwerp.

site_title: Norway's housing market downturn gathers pace amid bubble fears
summary: Norway's housing market is experiencing a downturn, with average nationwide house prices falling seasonally-adjusted 0.7% in June, marking the second consecutive month of decline. Annual nationwide gains slowed to 6.3% from 8.3% in May and 11.5% from 16.5% in Oslo. The cooling market is attributed to government-tightened lending standards, particularly in Oslo, and rising debt levels among households. Experts warn that the market may be experiencing a bubble burst, with prices expected to decline further, but some economists argue that the downturn is exaggerated.

site_title: Pricey tickets worth it for pop princess
summary: Britney Spears' debut concert in Singapore drew 7,800 fans despite exorbitant ticket prices ranging from S$188 to S$568. The 90-minute show featured numerous costume changes and a memorable a cappella rendition of "Happy Birthday" to a bodyguard's birthday. Although Spears' lip-syncing was criticized, her vocals were praised during the performance, which included hits like "Womanizer" and "...Baby One More Time." The concert was deemed worth the price of admission, with fans singing along to the pop icon's infectious tunes.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: YuuZoo clarifies points raised over governance criticism
summary: YuuZoo Corporation has clarified points raised in a commentary criticizing its governance issues. Associate professor Mak Yuen Teen pointed out the surprise bundling of announcements for the appointment of RHT Corporate Advisory as share transfer agent and Elizabeth Krishnan as company secretary, without separate announcements. YuuZoo responded that the bundling was for efficiency and that there were separate titles for each appointment.

site_title: Music veteran revisits past for inspiration
summary: Singer-songwriter Kevin Mathews is releasing an EP, Reel2Real, featuring re-recorded songs from his past works, including those from Eric Khoo's 1997 film 12 Storeys. The EP marks the 20th anniversary of the film's release and will be accompanied by a restored version of the film. Mathews shares that revisiting his past works was "satisfying" and "nostalgic," and he drew inspiration from various sources, including Malay legends and his favorite songs. The EP is the latest in a prolific period for Mathews, who has released synth-pop EPs under the moniker KayMac.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Vancouver to impose fresh Airbnb rules
summary: Vancouver is introducing new restrictions on Airbnb and other short-term rental operators, effective next April. The rules will prohibit rentals of secondary suites, laneway homes, and investment properties, and require residents to obtain a business licence and pay a 3% tax on stays. The city aims to ease the near-zero supply of homes to let, with a benchmark home price of C$998,700, up 7.9% from a year ago. Violators may face a C$1,000 fine and potential legal action.

site_title: HDB resale volume slips 11.6% in June: SRX
summary: HDB resale volume in Singapore dropped 11.6% in June, reaching 1,753 units sold, compared to May's 1,984 units and an 8.1% increase from April. Resale prices also declined 0.1% year-over-year, with a 52% drop from the peak of 3,649 units in May 2010. Prices of executive units rose 1.7%, while those of three-room, four-room, and five-room units decreased 0.2%, 0.3%, and 1.5% respectively.

site_title: US housing finance system 'unsustainable': Fed's Powell
summary: US Federal Reserve Governor Jerome Powell says the country's housing finance system is "unsustainable" due to its reliance on government-backed agencies Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The system puts taxpayers at risk, and policymakers must act to reform it before it's too late. Powell argues that the current situation is a "now-or-never moment" for reform, citing the need to promote private capital and prevent future taxpayer bailouts. The Fed is urging lawmakers to craft legislation to overhaul housing finance, a process that has been stalled for years.

site_title: Early payout for FLT units issued before Thursday
summary: Frasers Logistics and Industrial Trust (FLT) has announced an early payout for its units issued before Thursday, covering the period from April 1 to July 5, 2017. The semi-annual distribution aims to ensure fairness to existing unit holders. The new units, issued at S$1.01 apiece, were 4.6 times subscribed, bringing the total units in issue to almost 1.51 billion. FLT plans to distribute its distributable income semi-annually, with the next distribution covering the period from July 6 to September 30, 2017.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Olam International secured a US$1 billion revolving credit facility in Europe, with three tranches. China Taisan Technology Group lost its lead independent director Ngan See Juan due to a bankruptcy order. Sabana Reit terminated its put and call option agreement for a proposed property acquisition. Meanwhile, Tan Teck Long was named OCBC's incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong. Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Fed consensus coming apart amid unease over low inflation
summary: The Federal Reserve's consensus on shrinking its balance sheet and interest-rate increases is fragmenting amid concerns over low inflation. Fed officials continue to support gradual interest-rate hikes, but there's a split on timing the balance sheet roll-off and inflation strategy. Chair Janet Yellen aims to manage a smooth exit from unprecedented policy stimulus without roiling bond markets or slowing growth. Despite low unemployment, inflation remains below the 2% target, and officials are divided on policy strategy, with some advocating for a "run-it-hot" scenario for the labor market.

site_title: Custom-made clothes for all within reach, says Japanese designer
summary: Japanese designer Yuima Nakazato claims to have cracked a digital technique for mass-made-to-measure clothes, revolutionizing fashion with precisely tailored garments using traditional materials. His "unit constructed textile" technique allows for infinite adaptability and incorporation of wearable devices. Nakazato aims to make high-end fashion accessible to everyone, using digital scanning and digitally-cut fabrics to create bespoke pieces without needles and thread.

site_title: EU and Japan emerge as champions of global free trade with new accord
summary: The European Union and Japan have reached a new free trade agreement (FTA) after four years of talks, marking a significant step towards global trade liberalization. The deal aims to cut EU tariffs on Japanese cars and boost EU farm produce exports to Japan, with key provisions including eliminating tariffs on wine, cheese, and meat. The agreement is seen as a counterbalance to protectionist moves, with EU leaders hoping to demonstrate their commitment to free trade to US President Donald Trump and other global economies.

images.alt_text: Japan and the European Union (EU) will go into the Group of Twenty (G-20) summit in Hamburg on Friday as global champions of trade liberalisation following an agreement reached on Thursday in Brussels on an EU-Japan free trade agreement (FTA) that has been four years in the making.

site_title: SGX rejects A-Sonic Aerospace's warrant issue
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has rejected A-Sonic Aerospace's proposed warrant issue, citing a 99.9% discount to the last transacted price of S$0.196 per share. The regulator deemed the proposed bonus warrants issue akin to a bonus issue.

images.alt_text: A-SONIC Aerospace said on Thursday that Singapore Exchange (SGX) has rejected its proposed warrant issue.

site_title: Saudi Arabia accuses Qatar of using Twitter to stoke dissent
summary: Saudi Arabia accused Qatar of using Twitter to stoke dissent, claiming over 23,000 accounts were linked to Qatar, including @mujtahidd with 1.8 million followers. The accounts allegedly called for 'revolution' in Saudi Arabia and claimed Saudi Arabia was trying to overthrow Qatar's emir. Saudi Information Minister Awwad Saleh al-Awwad blamed a London-based dissident, Saad al-Faqih, for the accounts, "together with Qatar." The claims come as Saudi Arabia continues its month-old boycott of Qatar, which refused to meet demands to end the diplomatic crisis.

site_title: QVC to merge with Home Shopping Network in US$2.1 billion deal
summary: QVC and the Home Shopping Network (HSN) are merging in an all-stock deal worth $2.1 billion, with Liberty Interactive Corp acquiring 62% of HSN. The combined company will have greater scale and reduce costs, and will be the leading global video e-commerce retailer. HSN's sales declined 3% last year, but the merger aims to enhance QVC's position and reduce costs. The deal is expected to close in the fourth quarter and is subject to shareholder and regulatory approval.

site_title: China's LeEco founder resigns as chair of listed unit after public plea for patience
summary: LeEco founder Jia Yueting resigned as chairman of its main listed unit, Leshi Internet Information & Technology Corp Beijing, amid a deepening financial crisis. He had previously made a public plea for patience, promising to repay debts and reaffirming the company's electric car commitment. This move comes after a Shanghai court froze $182 million in assets due to late interest payments, prompting investors to pause new investments and consider exiting invested projects.

site_title: Japan, EU seal landmark trade deal
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and top EU officials agreed on a landmark trade deal, dubbed the Economic Partnership Agreement, after four years of negotiations. The pact aims to boost trade between the EU and Japan, with the EU seeking access to Japan's massive market and Japan hoping to stimulate its stagnant economy. Key aspects of the deal include Japan's auto industry opening to EU markets and EU farming products gaining access to Japan. The agreement is seen as a challenge to US President Donald Trump's "America First" stance on trade.

site_title: SoftBank aims to raise US$3b-US$5b through bond issue: source
summary: SoftBank Group Corp is planning to raise US$3 billion to US$5 billion through a US dollar bond issue, according to a source. The bond offering will be led by Morgan Stanley, Bank of America Merrill Lynch, and Deutsche Bank. This comes after the telecoms-to-investment conglomerate raised the world's largest private equity fund, the US$100 billion Vision Fund, in May. The bond offering is seen as a way to bolster SoftBank's capital base and secure funds for future growth.

site_title: Symantec to buy Israeli cybersecurity firm Fireglass
summary: Symantec is acquiring Israeli cybersecurity firm Fireglass for an undisclosed sum, boosting its products that protect corporate email and web browsing from threats. Fireglass specializes in browser isolation technology, which creates virtual websites to prevent viruses from reaching networks. The deal is expected to close in the third quarter and will increase Symantec's presence in Israel, a hotbed for cybersecurity. The acquisition is part of Symantec's efforts to expand its offerings and talent base in the region.

site_title: Swiss court rejects Platini's appeal against FIFA soccer ban
summary: Switzerland's highest court rejected Michel Platini's appeal against a four-year ban from soccer due to ethics violations. The ban stems from a 2 million Swiss franc payment Platini received from FIFA in 2011. The decision upholds a Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) ruling, which found Platini guilty of violating FIFA's ethics code. Platini has denied wrongdoing and was banned along with former FIFA head Sepp Blatter, who approved the payment.

site_title: PM Lee shares siblings' wish to take dispute private; DPM Teo sees statement by Lee Hsien Yang and Lee Wei Ling as positive development
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated he shares his siblings' desire to keep a private dispute over their father's 38, Oxley Road house. This follows comments by Lee Hsien Yang and Lee Wei Ling, who expressed a similar wish. DPM Teo said Lee Hsien Yang and Lee Wei Ling's statements were a positive development.

site_title: JD, Lazada face off in Indonesia, Asia's next e-commerce prize
summary: JD.com, a Chinese e-commerce giant, is expanding into Indonesia, Asia's next e-commerce prize, with plans to build more warehouses and delivery centers. The company faces competition from Lazada, owned by Alibaba, and Amazon, which is also exploring growth in the region. Indonesia's underdeveloped infrastructure, including a cash-based payment system, is a significant challenge for e-commerce growth. Despite these hurdles, JD's head of operations in Indonesia, Zhang Li, believes that "e-commerce is a no-brainer" and that the company will succeed by building out its delivery network.

images.alt_text: JD and Alibaba are betting they can apply know-how and delivery skills learned during rapid growth in China. At stake is the future of e-commerce in Indonesia and its rapidly- expanding middle class.

site_title: Myanmar tycoon says economy neglected by Suu Kyi's government
summary: Myanmar tycoon Serge Pun criticized Aung San Suu Kyi's government for neglecting the nation's economic reform, stating the economy "has not performed well enough" since her power in 2016. Despite relatively strong growth, foreign investment has fallen sharply, and the country's GDP growth slowed to 6.3% in 2016. Pun urged authorities to focus on economic growth, citing its importance in achieving peace and stability, warning that a weak economy could undermine the administration's goals.

site_title: US 30-year mortgage rates rise from November low: Freddie Mac
summary: US 30-year mortgage rates rose to 3.96% in the week ending July 6, marking the highest level since November 2016. This increase follows a rise in US Treasury yields. The previous week's rate was 3.88%, which was the lowest since November 2016.

site_title: Qatar Air said to cancel 4 Airbus A350s on supplier issue
summary: Qatar Airways is set to scrap its orders for four Airbus A350-900 jets due to issues with quality control and cabin specifications. The decision, made by the airline's CEO, Akbar Al Baker, comes amid a history of Qatar Airways declining aircraft deliveries that fail to meet its standards. The cancellation may be reflected in Airbus's monthly order data, but is unlikely to impact the airline's growth plans, which include leasing additional A350s from Latam Airlines.

site_title: US trade deficit narrows as exports hit two-year high
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed in May to $46.5 billion, down 2.3% from the previous month. Exports reached a two-year high, driven by record-high petroleum exports. The trade deficit, adjusted for inflation, decreased to $62.8 billion from $63.8 billion in April. This narrowing gap is seen as a positive sign for economic growth, despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Swiss Re shifts US$130b investments to track ethical indices
summary: Swiss Re, the world's second-largest reinsurer, is shifting its US$130 billion in liquid assets to track ethical indices, a move towards principled investments by the insurance industry. This process, expected to be completed by the end of the third quarter in 2017, aims to reduce the risk of losses for long-term investors by incorporating social and governance (ESG) criteria. The decision is seen as a step towards more responsible investments, with Swiss Re citing reduced risk as the primary motivation.

site_title: France extends emergency rule until Nov 1
summary: France's parliament voted to extend the state of emergency until November 1, amid concerns over civil liberties. The measure, initially imposed after the 2015 Paris attacks, was supported by lawmakers across the political divide except for those from Jean-Luc Melenchon's party and the Communist party. Interior Minister Gerard Collomb stated that strengthening security does not compromise civil liberties, but rather preserves and enhances them.

site_title: Hong Kong braces for higher rates as currency losses accelerate
summary: Hong Kong's currency peg to the US dollar is facing increased pressure as the gap between local and US interbank rates widens to its most significant level since 2009. The city's currency has fallen to the middle of its permitted band, prompting concerns that the local monetary authority will need to intervene to maintain stability. As forward points and interest-rate swaps in Hong Kong's dollar start to bottom out, it's likely that the city's exchange rate will reach its weak limit, forcing the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to act.

site_title: KLW auditors make qualified opinion over fiscal statement
summary: KLW Holdings' independent auditor has issued a qualified opinion and emphasis of matters over the audited financial statements for the financial year ended March 31, 2017. The auditor was unable to verify the quantities of work-in-progress and finished goods totaling S$2.91 million held by a subsidiary due to lack of access to predecessor auditors' work papers. This has led to a qualified opinion on the financial statements.

images.alt_text: KLW Holdings said on Thursday its independent auditor has included a qualified opinion and an emphasis of matters over the audited financial statements of the group for the financial year ended March 31, 2017.

site_title: Tesla seen pulling away from GM for clear US electric car lead
summary: Tesla is projected to lead the US electric car market by 2021, with nearly 709,000 cumulative deliveries, surpassing General Motors' total sales. Bloomberg New Energy Finance predicts Tesla's dominance will continue, with Volkswagen AG expected to rank second. The report suggests Tesla's Model 3, set to be released this year, will drive its growth, and analysts expect battery electric vehicles to win the market due to decreasing battery costs.

site_title: G-20 seeks to contain Trump by avoiding 'climate change' mention
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel is seeking to unite the G-20 nations on environmental goals by avoiding references to climate change, according to a draft being circulated ahead of a summit. The US's decision to withdraw from the Paris Agreement is noted, but other countries are not expected to follow. Merkel aims to contain Trump's influence and avoid provoking him, instead promoting collaboration on less contentious issues like innovation and sustainable growth. The draft communique does not mention climate change, but other countries will endorse a separate climate plan.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on tepid ADP jobs data
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday after the release of tepid ADP jobs data, which showed lower-than-expected hiring in the private sector. The Dow Jones fell 56.02 points, the S&P 500 lost 10.21 points, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 44.83 points. Despite this, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records earlier in the week. The ADP data has raised concerns about the health of the US economy.

site_title: Indian panel seeks comments on new bankruptcy code
summary: India's Insolvency and Bankruptcy Board has called for public comments on the country's revised bankruptcy code, which aims to resolve the US$150 billion stressed-loans problem. The code went into effect last year and is set to be tweaked, with modifications expected to be made by March 31 and take effect from April 1, 2018. The board seeks to address issues such as borrowers' right to fair hearing before tribunals rule on cases, following criticism from lawyers and insolvency professionals. The new code is set to be tested in major cases and is part of the government's efforts to resolve the country's stressed-loan problem.

site_title: Sabana Reit drops plans to buy Eunos property
summary: Sabana Reit has terminated the put and call option agreement for the proposed acquisition of a property at 107 Eunos Avenue 3 due to feedback from unitholders and vendors. The Reit had initially planned to buy the property for S$77.5 million, but dropped plans for similar acquisitions earlier this year. The decision follows criticism from investors over the potential dilutive rights issue.

site_title: PM Lee, Merkel discuss boosting defence, cybersecurity and trade ties between S'pore and Germany
summary: Singapore and Germany signed a Joint Statement on Cybersecurity Cooperation and an enhanced Defence Cooperation Agreement, aiming to boost ties in defense, cybersecurity, and trade. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and German Chancellor Angela Merkel discussed cooperation in research and development, fintech, and sports. The agreement marks a significant expansion of bilateral relations, with both countries seeking to strengthen economic and security ties.

site_title: Trump calls Poland exemplary ally against Russian "destablising" behaviour
summary: US President Donald Trump praised Poland as an exemplary ally in countering Russian "destabilising behaviour", while encouraging Polish defiance towards the European Union. Trump urged western NATO allies to spend more on defense, drawing a comparison with Poland, which meets the two percent target. The visit came amid tensions with Russia over its annexation of Crimea and military activity in eastern Europe. Trump's comments were seen as a nod to Poland's eurosceptic government, which has faced criticism from Western peers over its views on migration and EU power.

site_title: AIG gives incoming operating chief Peter Zaffino US$23.5 million
summary: American International Group (AIG) has awarded incoming chief operating officer Peter Zaffino a $23.5 million pay package, including a $15 million sign-on award and $4.25 million in restricted stock units. The package also includes a $1.25 million salary, a $3 million cash bonus, and 1 million stock options. Zaffino, 50, joins AIG next month and must remain with the company until December 2019 to receive the rest of the restricted shares. The move is seen as part of AIG's succession planning efforts under CEO Brian Duperreault.

site_title: US services sector growth rebounds in June
summary: The US services sector experienced a rebound in growth in June, with the Non-Manufacturing Index rising 0.5 points to 57.4%, exceeding analyst expectations. This growth was driven by a 3-point increase in new orders to 60.5%, despite a 2-point decline in employment to 55.8%. The sector has been growing for 90 months, with the overall index capturing activity among all services sector segments. Experts attribute the growth to sustained momentum, with no signs of the economy weakening.

site_title: France aims to end sale of fossil fuel powered cars by 2040
summary: France plans to end the sale of gasoline- and diesel-powered vehicles by 2040, aiming to become a carbon-neutral nation by 2050. Energy Minister Nicolas Hulot announced the "Climate Plan" in Paris, offering tax incentives to replace old diesel and gasoline cars. The government will also end oil and gas exploration, eliminate coal-fired power plants by 2022, and encourage home energy production. This move follows other manufacturers like Volvo, which plans to phase out fossil fuel-powered vehicles by 2025. The plan is part of a broader effort to combat climate change and reduce emissions.

site_title: Volkswagen recalls 766,000 VW cars worldwide for brake system update
summary: Volkswagen is recalling 766,000 vehicles worldwide for a software update to their braking control systems, which may not function properly in certain driving conditions. The German recall affects 385,000 vehicles, including 288,000 VW-brand cars, and is related to over-steering, under-steering, or slamming on the brakes. The issue was first reported by news agency DPA on Saturday.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen is recalling 766,000 vehicles of its core passenger car brand worldwide for a software update to their braking control systems, a spokesman said.

site_title: ECB discussed removing easing bias on bond-buying program
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) discussed removing a pledge to increase its bond-buying program, citing improved economic conditions and a vanishing tail risk. However, the decision was not made, and only the wording on interest rates was changed. The ECB's cautious approach reflects concerns about the post-crisis recovery and the need to maintain a steady hand to achieve its inflation target. The decision was seen as a signal of the ECB's ongoing efforts to balance the need for stimulus with the risk of overstimulation.

site_title: Qatar Airways CEO says no plans to cancel Airbus A350 order
summary: Qatar Airways CEO Akbar al Baker stated that the airline will not cancel its Airbus A350 order, despite delivery delays. The CEO expressed frustration with Airbus for the delays, saying "The delay is from Airbus." This decision comes after the airline previously delayed expansion plans due to the delays. Additionally, Qatar Airways recently ordered two Boeing 747-8 freighters.

site_title: IndiGo says keen only on Air India's international and low-cost units
summary: IndiGo expressed interest in buying only Air India's international and low-cost units, not the entire carrier. Co-founder Rahul Bhatia stated that IndiGo would assess the feasibility of acquiring all parts of Air India if the government only sells the business as a whole. The government has given "in-principle" approval to privatize Air India, which has been struggling to turn a profit due to growing competition from low-cost rivals. This move aims to offload the airline amidst the process of selling its international and low-cost units.

site_title: Indonesian teenage boy weds 73-year-old bride
summary: A 15-year-old boy in Indonesia married a 73-year-old woman, Rohaya Binti Kiagus Muhammad Jakfar, after she promised to commit suicide if the match was rejected. The couple met when Rohaya cared for the boy, Selamet Riyadi, who had malaria. The marriage was performed privately due to the boy's age, and Rohaya has been married twice before. The union has sparked national interest, with a viral video of their wedding vows. Indonesian law allows marriage at 19 for men and 16 for women, but the couple chose to proceed despite the age difference.

site_title: Avic International Maritime wins contracts worth over 11m euros
summary: AVIC International Maritime Holdings announced that its unit Deltamarin has secured contracts worth over 11 million euros with Xiamen Shipbuilding Industry Co in China for engineering and construction support services on a ro-pax vessel for Viking Line.

site_title: Billionaire LeEco founder turns to cars as debtors close in
summary: Billionaire LeEco founder Jia Yueting has resigned as chairman of his main listed company in favor of leading LeEco's automobile division, citing a need to focus on debt repayment and his ambitions to disrupt the automotive industry. A Chinese court has frozen billions of dollars in assets held by LeEco and its affiliates, and the company has slashed costs and staff to address a cash crunch. Jia will now devote his time to LeEco's cars, including his US-based startup Faraday Future, which is trying to raise funds for its electric car, the FF91.

site_title: Corbyn to meet with Barnier as he anticipates snap UK election
summary: UK Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn will meet with European Union's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier next week, ahead of a potential snap election that could make him prime minister. Corbyn, who has been gaining ground in opinion polls, is ready to outline Labour's Brexit issues and has expressed confidence in coming to power on a call to end austerity. The meeting comes as Labour has edged ahead of Conservative Prime Minister Theresa May in polls, and Corbyn is poised to capitalize on her weakness.

site_title: Trump cites Russian election meddling but blames others too
summary: President Donald Trump stated he believes Russia meddled in the 2016 election, but also suggested others may have been involved. Trump expressed uncertainty about the matter, likening it to intelligence on Iraq's WMDs that was later proven incorrect. He will meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin on Friday, despite his previous comments about Russia's involvement. Trump's comments on Russian election meddling are his first since taking office.

site_title: No such thing as "frictionless" trade, Barnier warns Britain
summary: European Union's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier warned British ministers and businesses that "frictionless trade" with the EU after Britain leaves is "not possible" unless the UK remains in the single market and customs union. However, the UK aims to secure a comprehensive free trade deal and customs agreement to minimize trade disruptions.

site_title: China Taisan Technology loses lead ID after bankruptcy order against him
summary: China Taisan Technology Group Holdings lost its lead independent director Ngan See Juan after a bankruptcy order was made against him. The company will reconstitute various committees and update shareholders on the vacancy. Ngan See Juan's bankruptcy order led to his removal from the position, resulting in a vacancy that will be addressed by the board.

site_title: Vallianz to raise as much as S$179m from enlarged rights issue
summary: Vallianz Holdings plans to raise up to S$179 million from an enlarged rights issue, with 4.48 billion new shares and 8.97 billion warrants attached, priced at S$0.02 each. Existing shareholders will receive one rights share and two free detachable warrants per share. The rights issue is expected to be oversubscribed, with shares trading at S$0.015 prior to the announcement.

site_title: Oil rises after signs of US demand, but supply threat remains
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, recovering from a steep slide, after US crude inventories fell more sharply than expected. Brent crude futures rose 67 US cents to $48.46 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 66 US cents to $45.79 a barrel. Despite the increase, analysts cut their price forecasts due to the prospect of oversupply in 2018, with some predicting prices could rise to $55 in coming months.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's siblings Lee Wei Ling and Lee Hsien Yang have agreed to settle their dispute over an Oxley Road property in private, ending weeks of online evidence presentation. HDB resale transactions fell 11.6% in June, with prices dipping 0.1%. MyRepublic will become a mobile virtual network operator, not buying M1, and plans to IPO in 2018-19. The URA has launched a Beach Road commercial site for tender with a minimum bid price of S$1.138 billion.

site_title: US private sector adds 158,000 jobs in June: ADP
summary: US private sector employers added 158,000 jobs in June, below economists' expectations of 185,000. The ADP National Employment Report, jointly developed with Moody's Analytics, showed private payroll gains in the month earlier were revised down to 230,000 from an originally reported 253,000 increase. The US Labor Department's non-farm payrolls report, due Friday, is expected to show US private payroll employment grew by 172,000 jobs and total non-farm employment increased by 179,000, with the unemployment rate forecast to remain steady at 4.3%.

site_title: Electric guitar maker Fender jumps into online learning
summary: Fender, the electric guitar maker, is launching "Fender Play", an online learning system for guitar lessons. The app aims to reduce the abandonment rate of first-time guitarists, who often give up after a year. According to Fender, 90% of first-time buyers abandon the instrument, but the company hopes to double the guitar industry's size by reducing this rate by 10%. Fender Play, which costs $19.99 a month, offers video lessons for no prior knowledge and will also be made available to dealers to manage their students.

site_title: South Korea's Moon, China's Xi say North Korea's ICBM test "unforgivable"
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae In and Chinese President Xi Jinping have condemned North Korea's recent intercontinental ballistic missile test as "unforgivable" during a G20 summit meeting. The leaders also discussed strengthening sanctions and pressure on North Korea. This comes amid growing concerns over North Korea's nuclear ambitions and the need for international cooperation to address the issue.

images.alt_text: South Korea's President Moon Jae In and his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping agreed at a summit meeting on Thursday that North Korea's test-launch of an intercontinental ballistic missile on Tuesday was "unforgivable", Yonhap news agency reported.

site_title: Global air passenger traffic demand rises 7.7% in May: Iata
summary: Global air passenger traffic demand rose 7.7% in May, with almost all regions excluding the Middle East and North America posting record-high May load factors, according to the International Air Transport Association (Iata).
