The Middle East carriers saw a 3.7% rise in demand, largely due to the ban on portable electronics devices in the cabin and travel bans. However, the ban has been lifted for Qatar Airways, joining Emirates, Turkish Airlines, and Etihad.

site_title: Indonesia proposes to raise 2017 budget deficit to close to legal limit
summary: Indonesia's government has proposed a revised 2017 budget that would hike spending and cut revenue targets, resulting in a wider budget deficit of 2.92%, nearly reaching the three per cent limit set by law. The proposed changes aim to close the deficit gap, but critics argue that the move may lead to increased borrowing and debt.

site_title: Olam secures US$1b European revolving credit facility
summary: Olam International has secured a US$1 billion European revolving credit facility, the first of its kind in Europe, through its wholly owned European subsidiary. The facility consists of three tranches: a 364-day revolving credit facility of US$400 million, a two-year revolving credit facility of US$300 million, and a three-year revolving credit facility of US$300 million.

site_title: UK regulator seeks Brexit bridge this year to avoid cliff-edge
summary: The UK Financial Conduct Authority's head, Andrew Bailey, is urging regulators to establish transitional arrangements by the end of the year to avoid a "cliff-edge" effect in the post-Brexit world. Banks and asset managers need certainty on how much time they have to transition, as the UK's withdrawal from the EU will end EU rules in the UK. The EU has taken a hard line, but Bailey called for coordination and equivalence-based decisions to preserve open access and free trade.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares retreat with energy firms
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.22% on Thursday due to a decline in oil prices and concerns over the North Korea missile crisis. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 25,465.22, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.17% and the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.08%.

site_title: Britain opens separate 'jihadi jails'
summary: Britain has opened its first "separation centre" at Frankland jail in north-east England, housing 28 Islamist extremists in separate units to prevent radicalization among inmates. The move follows a review that highlighted the influence of "charismatic" prisoners and extremist literature in prisons. The new centre is part of a three-unit plan to tackle the growing terror threat, with 4,500 frontline staff receiving specialist training on identifying and challenging extremist views. The UK has seen a surge in terrorism-related incidents, with 304 people arrested and 70 trials completed in the past year.

site_title: YuuZoo in talks with Cinram Europe units after delays in buying holding company
summary: YuuZoo Corporation is in talks with Cinram Europe's subsidiaries on a country-to-country basis, despite having an exclusive option to buy the holding company for 7.5 million YuuZoo shares. The option was initially set to expire on June 30 but was later extended to July 5. The discussions' purpose and outcome have not been disclosed.

site_title: US cars a tough sell in South Korea even as Trump targets trade deal
summary: US auto imports from General Motors, Ford, and Chrysler face a tough market in South Korea, despite President Trump's efforts to renegotiate a trade deal. Sales account for just 1% of the market, dominated by affordable Hyundai and Kia models. To succeed, US carmakers must make their products more chic, affordable, or fuel-efficient. Trump's meeting with South Korean President Moon Jae In last week aimed to address trade imbalances and create a level playing field for US businesses, particularly in the auto sector.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares finish higher
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.37 points to 1,770.53, with 1.55 billion lots traded at RM1.74 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 511 to 359. The market closed higher despite uncertainty from US trade threats.

site_title: MSIG, DBS launch Singapore's first instant travel claims payment service
summary: MSIG Insurance and DBS Bank have launched Singapore's first instant electronic payment service for travel insurance claims, reducing claim settlement time by about four days. The service, using DBS's real-time payment technology, is the first of its kind in Singapore and aims to improve customer experience. MSIG plans to expand this service to other areas of its business, while DBS aims to co-create digital experiences for its clients and partners.

site_title: Chess legend Kasparov back from retirement for US tournament
summary: Former world chess champion Garry Kasparov is returning from retirement to compete in the Sinquefield Cup in St Louis, Missouri, from August 14-19. At 54, Kasparov will face top players including Magnus Carlsen and Hikaru Nakamura. Kasparov, who dominated chess for over 15 years, retired in 2005 to focus on politics and has since been involved in opposition movements against Russian President Vladimir Putin. He will participate in the Rapid and Blitz competition, sparking speculation about his potential re-retirement.

site_title: Axis Capital to buy Lloyd's of London insurer Novae for £467.6m
summary: Axis Capital Holdings Ltd has agreed to acquire Lloyd's of London insurer Novae Group Plc for £467.6 million (S$835.348 million) in cash, sending Novae's shares soaring over 20%. The deal, expected to close in the final quarter of the year, will create a US$2 billion player in the London speciality market and add to Axis' earnings in the first year. The acquisition has no termination fee, indicating confidence from both parties.

site_title: Deutsche Bank is said to retreat from London for Frankfurt
summary: Deutsche Bank is planning to move large parts of its trading and investment-banking assets from London to Frankfurt in response to Brexit. The move will shift jobs and client accounts, with the plan likely to be implemented over the next 18 months. Frankfurt has emerged as a preferred alternative location for European banks, with Standard Chartered and others having already made the move. The transition will require investments in infrastructure, technology, and office space, and is part of a two-year Brexit project.

site_title: China's Baidu probed after CEO tests driverless car on public roads
summary: China's Baidu, the country's largest search engine provider, is under investigation for allegedly testing a driverless car on public roads without permission. The move has raised concerns about safety and compliance with traffic laws. Baidu's CEO, Robin Li, had conducted a live video chat from the passenger seat of the self-driving car, sparking debate online. The investigation is ongoing, and any violations of the law may result in punishment. This incident highlights the regulatory challenges and risks associated with the development of autonomous vehicles in China.

site_title: EU charges Merck, GE, Canon of misleading merger info
summary: EU antitrust regulators have accused Merck, General Electric, and Canon of providing misleading information during their merger deals. The European Commission sent statements of objections to the companies, which could lead to fines of up to 1% of global revenue for Merck and GE, and up to 10% for Canon. Merck was accused of failing to disclose information about a chemicals innovation project, GE provided misleading research and development information, and Canon acquired Toshiba Medical Systems Corp before securing regulatory approval. The charges do not affect the EU approvals of the deals.

site_title: EU countries lack investment strategy in shift to low-carbon economy: EEA
summary: The European Environment Agency (EEA) states that most EU countries lack a clear investment strategy for redirecting public and private funds towards low-carbon investments. Only a few countries, including Belgium, the Czech Republic, Estonia, France, and Germany, have a national strategy in place. The EU estimates it needs around 177 billion euros per year from 2021-2030 to meet climate and energy targets, requiring a doubling of current investments in renewable energy and energy efficiency. A lack of preparedness and information on estimated investment needs is hindering EU countries' ability to meet these targets.

site_title: Reckitt Benckiser cuts forecast after cyberattack hits sales
summary: Reckitt Benckiser Group Plc cut its full-year sales forecast after a global cyberattack disrupted manufacturing and distribution, with estimated losses of about £90 million. The attack, which began in Ukraine, affected shipping terminals and corporate networks worldwide, with the company's health-care division suffering the most damage. Reckitt Benckiser now expects a two percent like-for-like sales growth, down from the previously forecasted three percent.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 losing 0.44% and the Topix index dropping 0.19%. The decline was driven by minutes from the US Federal Reserve's June meeting, fueling uncertainty about its plans for US monetary policy.

site_title: New tax could dampen India gold demand in short-term: WGC
summary: India's new nationwide sales tax on gold, increasing the Goods and Services Tax (GST) to 3% from 1.2%, may dampen short-term gold demand. The World Gold Council (WGC) warns that small-scale artisans and retailers may struggle to adapt, potentially leading to under-the-counter buying and a black market. The tax increase, combined with a government move to ban cash transactions over 200,000 rupees, could hurt gold demand in rural areas. The WGC maintains its demand estimate for India at 650-750 tonnes for 2017, below average annual demand.

site_title: Thai June consumer confidence drops for 2nd month: survey
summary: Thailand's consumer confidence index declined to 74.9 in June, its lowest in five months, due to economic recovery worries, global uncertainty, and low commodity prices. This marks the second consecutive month of decline. The University of the Thai Chamber of Commerce suggests consumer spending may pick up in the second half of the year if the government speeds up spending.

site_title: UK working to 'mitigate' White House attitudes: Boris Johnson
summary: UK Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson stated Britain is working to moderate some of President Donald Trump's positions, aiming to "mitigate" US attitudes and policies. Despite disagreements, Johnson praised Trump for engaging people in politics through social media. The UK has made progress in changing administration positions, with Johnson noting that Trump raises awareness on issues and engages the public in politics. Trump is scheduled to meet with Prime Minister Theresa May on Friday.

site_title: US small business borrowing rose in May
summary: US small business borrowing rose to its highest level in nearly a year in May, driven by an 11% year-on-year increase in arts and entertainment borrowing, while transportation and healthcare companies reduced borrowing by 14% and 13%, respectively. The Thomson Reuters/PayNet Small Business Lending Index reached 137, its highest since June 2016. The rise suggests businesses are ramping up investments to meet customer demand, but the index's growth is not sufficient to indicate a strong economic expansion, according to PayNet's CEO.

site_title: Qatar Airways secures US laptop-ban exemption
summary: Qatar Airways has secured an exemption from the US laptop-ban for its flights departing from Doha's Hamad International Airport, allowing passengers to carry personal electronic devices onboard. This comes after meeting the US Department of Homeland Security's new security guidelines, with other affected airports and carriers still under the ban. The exemption brings relief to the Gulf carrier, which has seen customers switch to other airlines during the ban. Other airports and carriers, including Emirates and Turkish Airlines, have also secured exemptions for flights from their respective bases.

site_title: At Ikea, Chinese shoppers make themselves at home
summary: Chinese shoppers at an Ikea store in Shanghai have adopted the practice of taking naps and eating at tables while browsing, especially during the sweltering summer months. With temperatures reaching 37C, people of all ages can be seen lounging on beds and couches in the air-conditioned showrooms. This phenomenon is a common occurrence at Ikea stores in China, where locals make themselves at home, often sleeping or eating in the showroom. The trend is seen as a reflection of the country's growing middle class and their desire for comfort and relaxation.

site_title: Hong Kong seizes largest ivory haul in 30 years
summary: Hong Kong authorities seized 7,200 kg of ivory tusks, valued at HK$72 million, in a 40-foot container from Malaysia. The tusks, estimated to have come from around 720 elephants, were discovered beneath frozen fish in a cargo warehouse. The seizure is Hong Kong's largest in 30 years, amid concerns over lax regulations and high demand from mainland China. Conservation groups say regulatory loopholes allow traders to use legal ivory as cover for smuggling, with China, Singapore, and the US banning the ivory trade.

site_title: Singapore shares finish mixed; STI slumps 0.7% but broad market is firm
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) slumped 0.7% to 3,226.34 on Thursday, despite a broad market showing resilience. The decline was led by banks, with DBS dropping 3.2 million shares, cutting 88 points off the index. The STI's weakness was influenced by US Federal Reserve meeting minutes indicating a likely third interest rate hike this year. The market showed a mixed performance, with 200 rises in the broad market, excluding warrants, but 222 falls.

site_title: Rare footage shows Korean "comfort women" from World War Two
summary: The Seoul government released rare video footage of Korean women forced to work in Japanese military brothels during World War II, the first time moving images have been shown of the "comfort women". The footage, filmed in 1944 by an American soldier, was found in the US National Archives after a two-year search. This discovery provides South Korea with its own data on the issue, which the government had been relying on Japanese and American sources. The footage is crucial for understanding the historical context of the comfort women issue.

site_title: JGB yields edge up to multi-month highs, near BOJ's defence lines
summary: Japanese government bond yields reached multi-month highs, edging near the Bank of Japan's intervention levels, as global expectations of tighter monetary policies grew. The benchmark 10-year yield rose to 0.100%, its highest level since February, due to rising bond yields in the West making Japanese bonds relatively less attractive. Despite this, the BOJ is still expected to maintain its "around zero per cent" yield target.

site_title: Mobike marks 100th day in S'pore with Mastercard partnership, free rides in July
summary: Mobike, a bike-rental company, has partnered with Mastercard to integrate Masterpass into its mobile application, allowing for easier and secure payments. To celebrate its 100th day in Singapore, Mobike will introduce newly designed bikes tailored to the country's road conditions. The partnership aims to enhance the user experience and increase convenience for riders.

site_title: URA launches Beach Road commercial site for minimum bid price of S$1.138b
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a Beach Road commercial site for sale at a minimum bid price of S$1.138 billion. The 99-year lease site, spanning 21,026.9 sq m, includes a conserved building and is intended for office development with complementary uses. The site is part of the H1 2017 government land sales programme and comes next to Shaw Tower.

site_title: Trump kicks off fraught Europe tour with Poland speech
summary: US President Donald Trump kicked off his four-day Europe tour with a speech in Warsaw, Poland, where he received a warm welcome from his sympathetic hosts. The visit comes amid tense US-Europe relations and a G20 summit in Hamburg, where Trump will meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin. Trump's speech aims to burnish his global statesman credentials, but his policies on Europe's security and NATO are expected to be scrutinized, with some questioning whether his administration can maintain a strong transatlantic partnership.

site_title: Seoul: Won weaker after Fed minutes; North Korea worries linger
summary: The South Korean won dropped to a near four-month low against the US dollar after the US Federal Reserve's June meeting minutes, which showed policymakers were split on inflation and interest rate rises. The won fell 0.2% to 1,152.4, amid concerns over North Korea's nuclear missile programme, with the US warning it would use force if necessary. South Korean shares also eased, with the Kospi index down 0.2% and Samsung Electronics shares gaining nearly 1%, while LG Electronics lost 3.7%.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mixed at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened mixed on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 unchanged and Frankfurt's DAX 30 up 0.2%, while Paris's CAC 40 declined 0.1%. Sliding oil prices and US-EU trade talks were major factors. Meanwhile, US stocks reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, and the Singapore Stock Index (STI) rose 0.4%.

site_title: Aussie falls again, NZ dollars near one-week lows
summary: The Australian dollar fell to US$0.7594, its fourth consecutive decline, despite a higher-than-expected trade surplus of A$2.47 billion in May. The New Zealand dollar remained near one-week lows at US$0.7275. The Australian currency's decline was driven by the Reserve Bank of Australia's neutral interest rate stance, while the New Zealand dollar was supported by strong domestic factors and a 2.1% gain in the ANZ commodity price index.

site_title: Thin crust: Pizza Hut weighs on Yum China growth
summary: Yum China Holdings Inc, operator of KFC, Pizza Hut, and Taco Bell in China, reported quarterly sales slightly below estimates due to sluggish growth at Pizza Hut. Same-store sales rose 3% driven by KFC's 4% growth, but Pizza Hut's flat sales fell short of analyst estimates. The company is working to turn around Pizza Hut, simplifying its menu and investing in mobile payments and delivery. Despite this, shares eased due to concerns over Pizza Hut's performance.

site_title: GuocoLand to launch luxury condominium Martin Modern on July 22
summary: GUOCOLAND Limited will launch its luxury condominium Martin Modern on July 22 at 8 Martin Place in Robertson Quay, Singapore. The sales gallery and show suites will open on July 8. This marks the first large-scale launch in the area in eight years, and Martin Modern is expected to test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 per square foot.

site_title: India considers private cars for ridesharing to cut traffic
summary: India is exploring the use of private vehicles as shared taxis to reduce car ownership and traffic congestion in major cities. The federal think-tank, chaired by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, has partnered with Uber and Ola to assess the economic and environmental impact. The three-month study aims to establish a clear regulatory framework for ride-sharing, potentially allowing companies to operate without ambiguity. The move could improve supply of vehicles at a low cost but may antagonize current drivers and raise safety concerns.

images.alt_text: India is examining the use of private vehicles as shared taxis in an effort to reduce car ownership and curb growing traffic congestion in major cities, sources familiar with the matter told Reuters.

site_title: SoftBank aims to raise US$3b to US$5b via bond issue: source
summary: SoftBank Group Corp plans to raise between $3 billion and $5 billion through a US dollar bond offering, named Morgan Stanley, Bank of America Merrill Lynch, and Deutsche Bank as joint global coordinators. The bond offering comes after the telecoms-to-investment conglomerate raised the world's largest private equity fund, the $100 billion Vision Fund. This is the second bond issuance by SoftBank, following a $9.8 billion hybrid bond sale in March to bolster its capital base and secure funds for future growth.

site_title: Vancouver extends Airbnb rules as home prices keep rising
summary: Vancouver has introduced new restrictions on short-term rentals, including a ban on rentals of secondary suites and laneway homes, to address the city's affordable housing crisis. The new rules require a business license and a 3% tax on stays, and violators face a $1,000 fine. The city aims to ease the near-zero supply of homes to let, with vacant dwellings estimated at over 66,000. Mayor Gregor Robertson said "housing is first and foremost for homes, not to be operated as a business."

site_title: Need a ball or umbrella? In China there's a sharing app for that
summary: China's booming "sharing economy" has more than doubled to 3.45 trillion yuan last year, with bike-sharing being a standout success, featuring 10 million bicycles. However, experts warn of oversharing, citing the collapse of Wukong Bike and 3Vbike, and the need for industry consolidation. Authorities have stepped in, with Shanghai and Tianjin imposing regulations, including a three-year bicycle service life and maintenance requirements. Despite the challenges, the sharing economy is expected to continue growing, driven by price-sensitive consumers and a desire for convenience, with venture capital backing the boom.

site_title: Manhattan home sales surge as cuts bring prices to buyers' level
summary: Manhattan home sales surged in the second quarter, with a 16% increase in previously owned properties, the largest jump in over two years. Average price cuts of 6.1% fueled buyer interest, with luxury apartments seeing a 10% discount, the largest in 16 years. Median prices rose 3.2% for resales and 3.5% for luxury homes. However, contracts to buy homes fell 8% from a year earlier, and buyers are becoming more price-conscious, leading to fewer bidding wars and lower prices.

site_title: Bike-sharing firm ofo raises over US$700m in latest funding round
summary: China-based bike-sharing firm ofo has raised over $700 million in its latest funding round led by Alibaba Group, Hony Capital, and Citic Private Equity. The company has connected over 6.5 million bikes to riders in 150 cities across five countries and plans to deploy 20 million bikes, expanding to 200 cities in 20 countries by the end of 2017. Executive vice-chairman Joe Tsai stated that ofo has redefined short-distance commuting with a low-carbon footprint experience, delivering value to users and society.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble Group rises almost 30 per cent on heavy trading
summary: Noble Group shares surged almost 30% on heavy trading after the company acquired a 50% stake in Tailai Coal (Shanghai) Company Limited for $5.4 million. The move was made from internal resources, with the book value of the stake valued at $4.5 million. Noble also announced it had extended a loan facility and was in talks with potential investors on the sale of an interest in the group or parts of its business. The stock traded at 61 Singapore cents, making it the most active stock on the exchange.

images.alt_text: Shares in embattled commodity trader Noble Group surged almost 30 per cent on Thursday on heavy trading.

site_title: London VC firm that backed Gwyneth Paltrow raises US$150m
summary: London-based venture-capital firm Felix Capital Partners raised $150 million, exceeding its target of $200 million, to expand its portfolio focused on European and US startups. The fund, which has backed Gwyneth Paltrow's Goop and Frichti, will invest in digital brands, well-being, and technology startups. Founder Frederic Court attributed the oversubscription to the resilience of investors despite Brexit. The funds will be used to grab stakes in early-stage startups, tapping into the growth of digital brands and well-being trends.

site_title: IIX, DBS price new US$8m social sustainability bond to be listed on SGX
summary: DBS Bank and Impact Investment Exchange (IIX) have priced a US$8 million social sustainability bond, the Women's Livelihood Bond (WLB), to support the livelihoods of over 385,000 women in South-east Asia. The four-year bond offers a 5.65% coupon rate and will be listed on the Singapore Exchange within a month. Proceeds will be lent to social enterprises and microfinance institutions, providing financial and social returns to investors. The bond includes credit protection features, including a US$500,000 first-loss capital and a 50% USAID guarantee.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday due to investor jitters over US monetary policy. The Nikkei 225 index slipped 0.08% and the Topix index declined 0.03%. The US Federal Reserve's minutes showed central bankers at odds over interest rate hikes, sparking uncertainty.

site_title: China graft watchdog says former Sinochem general manager to be prosecuted
summary: China's anti-graft panel announced the prosecution of former Sinochem Group general manager Cai Xiyou, suspected of taking bribes. Cai previously served as senior vice-president of Sinopec Corp. before joining Sinochem. This move highlights ongoing efforts to combat corruption in China's state-owned enterprises.

site_title: North Korea seeks 'driver's seat' with ICBM test: analysts
summary: North Korea has successfully tested an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) that can reach Alaska, prompting analysts to say the country is seeking to put itself in a "driver's seat" for future negotiations with the US. The test brings within reach Pyongyang's long-held dream of delivering an atomic warhead to the continental US, increasing pressure on President Trump. The timing of the test, ahead of the G-20 summit, appears deliberate, slamming the door on South Korean President Moon Jae In's efforts to engage with North Korea.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tick up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.21% at the open, extending a recovery from earlier losses, but traders remain cautious due to developments on the Korean peninsula. The Hang Seng Index reached 25,574.57. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.10% and 0.06% respectively.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.17 point to 1768.00. Volume reached 42.28 million lots worth RM15.1 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 102 to 56.

site_title: Thailand leads the pack for Asia's abused tourist elephants
summary: Thailand leads Asia's tourism industry in keeping elephants in "severely inadequate conditions," with 2,198 out of 2,923 documented working in the industry. Researchers from World Animal Protection found that three-quarters of Asia's captive elephants are kept in poor or unacceptable conditions, with Thailand's elephant entertainment industry taking hold in the 1990s after logging bans. The industry's focus on profit over animal welfare has led to cruel treatment, including chaining elephants to short chains, poor diets, and limited veterinary care. Tourists can push for change by choosing venues that promote observing animals over interacting with them.

site_title: MyRepublic to become an MVNO telco, not interested in buying M1; to IPO in 2018-19
summary: MyRepublic, a fibre broadband services player, will become a mobile virtual network operator (MVNO) in Singapore to pursue mobile telco aspirations. The company will buy mobile bandwidth wholesale from a telco and launch mobile services in October. MyRepublic plans an initial public offering (IPO) in 2018-19, with IPO proceeds funding expansion into eight Southeast Asian markets. The company is also raising S$220 million from private equity investors, with two-thirds going towards Indonesia's broadband expansion.

site_title: Temasek, Unigrains take stake in malt producer Boortmalt
summary: Temasek and Unigrains, a Singapore state investor and French farmer-controlled fund, respectively, have taken a stake in Boortmalt, the world's fifth-largest malt producer, through a capital increase worth 150 million euros. The investment aims to tap into rising demand for beer in emerging markets. Boortmalt's CEO, Yvan Schaepman, welcomed the expertise of Temasek and Unigrains in valuing the company's business and international markets.

site_title: Baidu snags 50-plus partners for its Apollo driverless car
summary: Baidu Inc has enlisted over 50 partners for its Apollo driverless car project, including major players in mapping, ride-sharing, automaking, and technology. The program aims to fine-tune Baidu's autonomous car software and overtake rival research efforts. Partners include Chinese carmakers, suppliers, and technology companies such as Microsoft, Grab, and TomTom. Baidu aims to release a driverless car by 2018 and mass produce by 2021, with the goal of creating new products to revive revenue growth.

site_title: HDB resale transactions in June down 11.6% m-o-m, prices dip 0.1%: SRX
summary: HDB resale transactions in June decreased 11.6% from May, with 1,753 units sold, marking a 5% year-on-year decline. Prices also dropped 0.1% from May and 0.2% from June 2016. The decline in prices has seen a 11.7% drop since the peak in April 2013. Resale prices of executive units increased 1.7%, while those of three-room, four-room, and five-room units decreased 0.2%, 0.3%, and 1.5% respectively.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower by 1.95 points on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.06% lower on Thursday, with 100.8 million shares traded for S$82.6 million. Despite a 5-day rally, the benchmark Straits Times Index declined 1.95 points to 3,246.76.

site_title: Tesla sales falling flat cloud outlook for bold Musk targets
summary: Tesla's second-quarter deliveries fell short of expectations, with 22,000 vehicles shipped, down from 25,051 in the first quarter. The company's production issues, including problems with 100 kWh batteries, have raised concerns about the success of its Model 3 sedan, which is expected to be a key driver of growth. Analysts question Elon Musk's ability to meet his production targets, and the company's stock price plummeted 7.5% following the report. Despite this, Tesla remains optimistic about the second half of the year, with deliveries for the Model S and X expected to exceed first-half sales.

site_title: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust's 78m new units commence trading; existing units to get early payouts
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) has begun trading 78 million new units at S$1.01 apiece to fund a proposed property acquisition. Existing units are expected to receive an early payout of distributable income from April 1, 2017 to July 5, 2017. The trust manager aims to ensure fairness to existing unit holders by distributing accrued income before new units are issued. FLT's shares closed 0.95% higher on Wednesday, ahead of the next distribution following the early payout.

site_title: Earnings support European shares but oil slump weighs
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Wednesday, driven by gains in consumer stocks, particularly Adidas, which beat profit forecasts and raised revenue guidance. Oil prices fell 3% after a prolonged bull run, weighing on energy stocks. Housebuilder Persimmon jumped 2.4% after reporting a 7% rise in sales. The top faller was Worldpay, down 8.8% after being acquired by Vantiv. Interest rate-sensitive utilities were also weak, down 0.7%.

site_title: Google's fine said to be only the start as EU probes progresses
summary: Google faces potential additional fines from European Union antitrust regulators as probes into its AdSense and Android services near completion. The EU has already imposed a record $3.76 billion penalty on Google for favoring its shopping service in search results. Regulators are seeking expert advice in the Android investigation, a sign that they may be testing possible flaws in the case before making a final decision. Google has until late August to make changes that satisfy the EU order, with Commissioner Margrethe Vestager warning of further fines if Google fails to comply.

site_title: Lee Wei Ling, Lee Hsien Yang to stop presenting online evidence, welcome private settlement of Oxley Road dispute
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's younger siblings, Lee Wei Ling and Lee Hsien Yang, announced they will stop presenting evidence on social media and welcome a private settlement of their dispute with the PM. They claimed their father, Lee Kuan Yew, wanted a private resolution and did not wish to see Singapore embroiled in a public argument. The siblings had raised allegations of an abuse of power over the demolition of their family home on Oxley Road. They look forward to discussing the matter without government agencies.

site_title: New notes mark 50 years of currency accord with Brunei
summary: Singapore and Brunei celebrate 50 years of currency accord with the launch of special $50 commemorative polymer notes. The Currency Interchangeability Agreement, signed in 1967, allows for freely convertible currencies, eliminating foreign-exchange risks and minimising transaction costs, facilitating trade and investment between the two nations. The agreement has resulted in over $1 billion in bilateral trade and significant investments, including a $20 million joint venture in Brunei. One million Brunei $50 notes and two million Singapore $50 notes are available for public exchange at face value.

site_title: Tennis: Red-hot Nadal rolls over American Young
summary: Rafael Nadal continued his dominant form at Wimbledon, defeating American Donald Young 6-4, 6-2, 7-5 in the second round. The two-time champion has yet to drop a set in the tournament and will face 21-year-old Russian Karen Khachanov in the third round. Nadal praised Khachanov's potential to win a grand slam, but also noted that there are other strong players in the competition. Nadal's impressive win came after a 10th French Open title just last month, and he seemed nearly unstoppable on Centre Court.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust, Singtel
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust and Singtel are set to be affected by market developments. Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust will start trading new units at S$1.01 apiece and declare a distribution for existing units. Singtel has received provisional permission to redevelop its Hill Street property into a hotel, potentially worth S$172 million. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by positive investor sentiment despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Are US banks regaining their appetite for acquisitions?
summary: US banks may be regaining their appetite for acquisitions, with JPMorgan Chase considering a bid for British payment company Worldpay, but ultimately deciding not to pursue it. This move is seen as a sign of a shift away from the tough regulatory environment following the 2008 financial crisis. The decision to back off the Worldpay bid has opened the way for Vantiv to acquire the company, marking a potential return to acquisition mode for big US banks after nearly a decade of playing defense.

site_title: Branson aims mid-2018 space trip as Virgin resumes powered tests
summary: Richard Branson aims to revive powered test flights for Virgin Galactic's spaceplane, with the goal of reaching space by mid-2018. After a series of glide-only flights, powered tests will take place every three weeks, with the aim of extending them into space by November or December. Branson targets full commercial passenger operations by the end of 2018, despite the fatal 2014 crash that killed co-pilot Michael Alsbury. The incident has not deterred Branson, who believes the appetite for space travel remains strong.

site_title: Italy finally makes torture illegal
summary: Italy's lawmakers have passed a bill making torture a crime under national law, punishable by 4-10 years in prison. The bill was passed with 198 votes in favor, 35 against, and 104 abstaining. This move comes after the European Court of Human Rights criticized Italy for police violence against protesters in 2001, stating there was a "structural problem" with Italian legislation. Italy had previously signed the UN Convention Against Torture in 1984 but never converted it into national legislation.

site_title: Worldpay deal: JPMorgan both broker and suitor
summary: JPMorgan Chase, the top corporate broker in the UK, has won a coveted broking mandate for Worldpay Group plc, advising clients on potential takeover approaches. However, JPMorgan has also suspended analyst research on Worldpay and will not provide broking services during the transaction, due to potential conflicts of interest. The company's interest in acquiring Worldpay has sparked concerns about the blurred lines between brokerage and buying activities, with experts warning that this unusual situation has the highest probability of causing conflicts.

site_title: US Fed members divided on inflation risk: minutes
summary: US Federal Reserve members are divided on the risk of inflation, disagreeing on the timing of interest rate hikes into 2018. Monetary policymakers also split on winding down the Fed's $4.5 trillion investment holdings, with some wanting to announce the start "within a couple of months" and others pushing for a delay. Concerns over Wall Street stocks being overvalued and risks to financial stability have also been expressed. Despite this, the Fed is expected to maintain its current interest rate hike pace, with Fed funds futures markets predicting no rate increase before December.

site_title: Oil slides as Opec exports rise, prices end 8 days of gains
summary: Oil prices dropped 4% on Wednesday, ending an 8-day gain, as Opec exports rose and the US dollar strengthened. Brent crude futures fell to $47.79 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell to $45.13 a barrel. Opec exports rose for a second month in June, despite a vow to cut production. Analysts attribute the price drop to a reversal of the trend and a lack of fundamental drivers, with some technical signs suggesting a potential recovery.

site_title: At least 10 missing and 400,000 evacuated as heavy rain pounds Japan
summary: Heavy rain in southwestern Japan has left at least 10 people missing and 400,000 evacuated due to record rainfall, with 774 mm of rain falling in nine hours. The rain, caused by a low pressure area on the Pacific Ocean, has also led to landslides and flooded roads, with 7,500 rescuers deployed. Residents spent a worried night at evacuation centers, with reports of thunder and lightning. The area was previously hit by Tropical Storm Nanmadol, and the situation is being closely monitored by authorities.

images.alt_text: Local residents are rescued by firefighters after heavy rain hit the area in Asakura, Fukuoka Prefecture, on July 6, 2017.

site_title: India's GST system unlikely to see smooth rollout
summary: India's Goods and Services Tax (GST) system, launched on June 30/July 1, 2017, is unlikely to have a smooth rollout due to concerns over its complexity, documentation requirements, and potential for exploitation by unscrupulous businesses. Smaller businesses, particularly traders, are worried about the tax reform's impact on their livelihoods, citing issues with varying tax rates, excessive documentation, and fears of lawsuits. The system's technical infrastructure is also being questioned, with concerns over software glitches and the potential for a massive backlog of cases clogging the judicial system.

site_title: US prepared to use force on North Korea 'if we must': UN envoy
summary: The US is prepared to use force against North Korea if necessary to stop its nuclear missile program, according to US Ambassador Nikki Haley at the UN Security Council. North Korea test-launched an intercontinental ballistic missile, potentially capable of reaching the US states of Alaska and Hawaii, prompting the US to propose new UN sanctions. China, North Korea's ally, has been criticized for not fully enforcing existing sanctions, and the US may take unilateral action against Chinese companies doing business with North Korea. The US military assures Americans it can defend against a North Korean ICBM, but experts say the US national missile defense system is only minimally operational.

site_title: Britain's May to hold talks with Trump at G-20
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May will meet US President Donald Trump on the sidelines of the G-20 summit in Hamburg, Germany, on Friday. The bilateral meeting comes as both leaders face global challenges, including the Brexit process and North Korea's missile tests. May had previously offered Trump a state visit to London, but criticism at home led to speculation that the visit may be cancelled. Trump's visit to Europe follows a G-7 summit in Italy, where he clashed with other leaders on climate change.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Theresa May will hold talks with Donald Trump on the sidelines of the G-20 summit in Hamburg, a UK government official told AFP on Wednesday.

site_title: US dollar index flat as Fed minutes hint tensions on inflation
summary: The US dollar index remained flat against a basket of currencies as the Federal Reserve's June policy meeting minutes hinted at potential tensions over inflation, despite a downshift in inflation data. The minutes showed several Fed officials expressed concerns about the softening inflation data, while most agreed to raise rates by a quarter point last month. The yen rose on safe-haven demand after North Korea's ICBM test, while commodity-sensitive currencies, such as the Canadian dollar, pared losses. The US dollar index has fallen 4.71% in the second quarter, its biggest quarterly drop since 2010.

site_title: Trump arrives in Warsaw, kicking off landmark Europe trip
summary: US President Donald Trump arrived in Warsaw, Poland, on Wednesday, kicking off a four-day trip to Europe, including a G20 summit in Hamburg and a meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin. The visit comes amid heightened tensions over North Korea's nuclear threat and the ongoing scandal surrounding Trump's administration's ties to Russia. Trump's meeting with Putin will be closely watched, as it will be his first face-to-face encounter with the Russian leader. The trip aims to repair Trump's image at home, following his "disastrous" trip to Brussels last May.

site_title: Citi eyes expansion in Asian trade corridors to tap region's growth
summary: Citi aims to double its growth in major intra-Asia trade corridors, targeting $2 billion in lending, as the region's trade flows reach $2.5 trillion. The bank is expanding its presence in 8 trade corridors, adding 25 staff, and is engaging with Chinese and regional clients to tap into China's "One Belt, One Road" initiative. This move is seen as a response to regional clients seeking growth closer to home, amid a shift in US trade policy and trade tensions between the US and China.

site_title: MAS joins other regulators in delaying Basel's trading risk rules
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has reportedly delayed the implementation of global Basel rules to tackle trading risks, initially set for end-2019, due to concerns over consistency across jurisdictions. The delay is part of a broader trend among regulators, with the European Commission and US Treasury also recommending delays. The rules, known as FRTB, aim to address trading risks and increase capital requirements by up to 40%. MAS will consider factors such as industry readiness and global implementation guidance when determining the new timeline.

site_title: Konica Minolta opens facility for customers here
summary: Konica Minolta has launched its fourth customer engagement centre (CEC) in Singapore, showcasing its latest digital print technologies and serving as the anchor industrial printing facility for South-east Asia. The S$4.3 million facility, located at Techlink in Kaki Bukit, will offer customers the ability to print in smaller volumes with greater versatility. The company aims to provide transformative digital solutions to its extensive production printing portfolio, capitalizing on the growing demand in the global industrial printing market estimated at US$450 billion.

images.alt_text: Wong Shiying

site_title: Fashion's kaiser Karl Lagerfeld crowned king of Paris
summary: Karl Lagerfeld, the 83-year-old German-born fashion designer, was awarded the Grand Vermeil medal by Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo, recognizing him as "an immense talent and a wonderful person." The honor was bestowed upon him on Tuesday, solidifying his status as a legendary figure in the fashion world.

site_title: World's costliest gas clouding China's campaign for blue skies
summary: China's efforts to reduce pollution and achieve a 10% gas share by 2020 and 15% by 2030 are hindered by high natural gas prices. The country's biggest energy companies have struggled to maintain profitability due to government-controlled prices, leading to a decrease in investment and production. To balance demand growth and industry returns, the government has set a goal of increasing gas imports and expanding domestic production, but the high cost of imports poses a significant challenge. The government has issued guidelines to encourage private companies to invest in overseas gas projects and has capped investment returns for natural gas distributors.

site_title: Rebels and outcasts remaking female pop
summary: Rebel female pop singers like Lorde, Halsey, and Alessia Cara are redefining the genre with their gloomy moods and pop songcraft skills. Hey Violet's lead singer, Rena Lovelis, 19, is a notable example, making a bad attitude shine with her frank lyrics and versatility. Her album "From the Outside" combines pop, punk, and electronic elements, tackling themes of teenage boys, men's approval, and self-discovery. In contrast, Bop City 2: TerroRising, another female-fronted act, is more dance-floor-oriented and derivative, with a lead singer, Lisa Terror, showcasing a saccharine sweet voice.

site_title: The building of an empire: from computers to coffee
summary: Tan Wang Cheow, founder of Food Empire Holdings Ltd, shares his journey from a computer salesman to a coffee kingpin. In the 1980s, he built a network of distributors in Eastern Europe, exporting electronics products. This network later helped him transition to the food and beverage industry. Tan's odyssey spanned two continents and turned him into a successful entrepreneur, with Food Empire becoming a Singapore-listed company.

site_title: HK hedge fund thanks shortsellers, bets against them
summary: Hong Kong hedge fund Quam Asset Management has taken the opposite side of recent short-seller bets, buying shares of companies targeted by shortsellers, such as AAC Technologies Holdings and Man Wah Holdings. The fund's portfolio manager, Jim Fong, praises short-sellers for providing valuable information, which helps him make informed investment decisions. Quam has returned an estimated 23% through June, outperforming the success rate of Hong Kong shortsellers, which has been as high as 81% since 2011.

site_title: US: Tech lifts Nasdaq; energy curbs Dow, S&P gains
summary: US stocks experienced mixed results on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq buoyed by tech gains and the Dow and S&P 500 hindered by a 4% drop in oil prices. The S&P energy index fell 2% and Exxon and Chevron shares plummeted over 1.5%. Recent economic data showed new orders for US-made goods fell more than expected, while capital equipment orders showed moderate growth. The Fed's interest rate hike plans remain uncertain due to split views on inflation.

site_title: Ascott quadrupling Quest stake to 80%
summary: CapitaLand's subsidiary, The Ascott, is acquiring a 60% stake in Quest Apartment Hotels for A$180 million, increasing its stake to 80% and making it the largest serviced residence provider in Australasia. This acquisition will boost Ascott's portfolio by over 11,000 units and expand its global presence. The deal is expected to be completed in the third quarter of 2017 and will enhance Ascott's offerings to customers, sales, and distribution.

site_title: EU, Japan near record trade deal as 'political' accord reached
summary: The European Union and Japan have reached a "political" agreement on a free-trade deal, overcoming differences on farm and car exports. The EU will phase out its 10% import duty on Japanese cars, while Japan will expand access for European farm goods. The deal, expected to eliminate 99% of tariffs, would be the EU's largest free-trade agreement. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe seeks to establish Japan as a global trade leader, while EU leaders prepare to endorse the pact at a summit. Talks will continue into the fall, with a legal text expected in the next few months.

images.alt_text: The European Union and Japan overcame their differences on farm and car exports, paving the way for a free-trade agreement between two partners that make up more than a quarter of the world's economic output.

site_title: Tencent makes smart TV push in joint venture
summary: Tencent Holdings has agreed to feature its video content on TCL Corp's smart TVs, expanding its dominance from mobile phones to living rooms. Tencent invested 450 million yuan in TCL subsidiary Shenzhen Thunderbird Network Technology, gaining a 16.67% stake. This is Tencent's second smart TV investment in a month, following a 300 million yuan investment in Coocaa, a smart TV subsidiary of TCL competitor Skyworth Digital Holdings. The partnership aims to deliver online content and over-the-top services, such as movies and video, to users.

site_title: Goldman's commodity push under scrutiny after worst start to the year in a decade
summary: Goldman Sachs' commodity division faces its worst start to the year in over a decade, with declining profitability. The unit, which has dominated global commodity markets for decades, is under review after CEO Lloyd Blankfein's insistence that it would eventually return to previous levels of profitability is beginning to waver. The decline is attributed to low volatility, increased competition, and regulatory restrictions on speculative and physical trading, making it less profitable for Goldman. The bank's commodity business has been shrinking, with other major investment banks also cutting back on their physical commodities operations.

site_title: KKR bids US$500m for Australian mortgage lender Pepper
summary: US private equity giant KKR & Co LP has made a US$500 million bid for Australian mortgage lender Pepper Group Ltd at an indicative price of A$3.60 per share, a 4% discount to Tuesday's close. The deal comes amid early signs of a property market slowdown in Australia. Pepper shares dropped 7.2% to A$3.48 on the news.

site_title: Volvo to go all electric with new models from 2019
summary: Volvo announced its plan to phase out vehicles powered solely by internal combustion engines, with all new models launched after 2019 to be electric or hybrids. The company will continue producing combustion-engine Volvos until then, but the move marks the end of nearly a century of such vehicles. Five new models, including three Volvos and two Polestar-branded cars, will be fully electric, with the option of plug-in and mild hybrid options. This strategy aims to capitalize on growing demand for premium electric vehicles.

site_title: Modi's Israel trip signals India's shifting foreign policy calculus
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is making a landmark trip to Israel, the first by a sitting Indian prime minister, to strengthen security and economic ties. Modi is seeking advanced agriculture technology and high-tech weapons to fuel India's military modernization program, and has already inked three missile deals worth $2.6 billion with Israel. The visit is seen as a significant shift in India's foreign policy calculus, with Israel emerging as a key defence partner. Modi will focus on cooperation in areas such as homeland security, pharmaceuticals, and tourism, with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accompanying him throughout the 49-hour visit.

site_title: Dollar up as short bets unwind before US data
summary: The US dollar rose to nearly two-month highs against the Japanese yen on July 5, as investors reduced bearish bets ahead of US data that may indicate an ongoing economic recovery. This move contrasts with a rise in short-dated US government bond yields since June. The dollar's upward trend is expected to continue, despite a sideways trade-weighted basket of the dollar against its peers.

site_title: Japan Inc scrambles for mid-career job-hoppers to cope with staff shortages
summary: Japan Inc is experiencing its highest level of mid-career job-hopping since the global financial crisis due to the country's labour shortage. The rapidly ageing economy has led to companies curbing labour costs and shifting away from Japan's traditional "jobs-for-life" system. This change is forcing companies to seek experienced workers, despite job-hopping being against the country's work culture. The shift is a result of Japan's labour shortage and the need to adapt to a changing society.

images.alt_text: Masae Miyachi, 41, an employee at Kaonavi Inc, switched jobs a year and a half ago and her annual salary has now risen by one million yen (S$12,208), helping her to finance a home loan.

site_title: UK developer St Modwen backs away from retail property after Brexit vote
summary: UK property developer St Modwen will not pursue major retail projects due to declining consumer spending and online rival threats. Instead, the company will focus on building houses and "sheds and beds" in areas with strong demand, capitalizing on e-commerce growth and student accommodation. St Modwen will speed up plans to deliver new homes on 17,000 approved plots and sell smaller projects to fund these efforts. The company's decision comes as the UK retail property market struggles amid Brexit-induced economic uncertainty.

site_title: More Asian HNWI seeing value in professional managers
summary: Asian high net worth individuals are increasingly seeking professional managers for their investments due to volatile markets. Bank of Singapore reports a 10-fold increase in demand for discretionary portfolio management services since 2010, with over 7% of its $85 billion assets under management now held in this category. Asian investors, often first-generation entrepreneurs, are willing to leave investment control to professionals to mitigate emotions and ensure a disciplined investment process. Diversification is key in today's low-growth environment, with Bank of Singapore offering innovative discretionary mandates that spread risk across factors rather than asset classes.

site_title: US carmakers cutting jobs as growth slows
summary: US carmakers are cutting jobs as the American car industry slows down, with sales dropping 3% in June for a sixth consecutive month. Industry analysts attribute the decline to tighter credit conditions and more expensive vehicle loans, causing consumers to pull back on spending. This trend is expected to continue, leading to reduced work in car-assembly plants and affecting traditional passenger car production.

images.alt_text: Workers in the body shop of the Ford plant in Hangzhou, China. The company says it plans to move production of its Focus sedan to China from Michigan in a bid to cut costs.

site_title: Hugo Boss makes debut in BT Corporate Golf League
summary: Hugo Boss makes its debut in the BT Corporate Golf League, a six-leg competition in Singapore. The fashion company sees the tournament as a platform to develop its golf brand in the local corporate community. Hugo Boss joins existing sponsors such as Audi, DHL, and Edrington, and will co-sponsor The Open this month. The league features 12 teams competing in the main event and 11 teams in the social event, with cash prizes and sponsorships including cars and luxury goods.

site_title: Trump slams China trade with N Korea, doubts cooperation effort
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized China's trade with North Korea, stating it grew almost 40% in the first quarter, contradicting efforts to counter Pyongyang's nuclear threat. Trump expressed frustration with China's steps to pressure North Korea, which he believes is not using enough leverage. The US leader's comments come ahead of a G-20 summit in Germany, where he will meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping to discuss the issue. China is North Korea's largest trading partner and ally, with imports and exports increasing significantly in the first quarter.

site_title: Juncker lashes out at European Parliament
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker criticized the European Parliament for a low attendance rate, with only 30 of 751 members present at a meeting. Juncker, who was speaking about the importance of EU attendance, was met with anger and told to change his language. The incident has raised questions about the Parliament's relevance, with some lawmakers arguing that ceremonial events overshadow more important debates. Juncker later apologized to Parliament President Antonio Tajani, but the incident has highlighted the EU's internal challenges.

site_title: Singtel gets URA nod for hotel project on Hill Street site
summary: Singtel has received provisional permission from the Urban Redevelopment Authority to redevelop its Hill Street site into a hotel, with a proposed 172-room hotel and 12,730 sq ft of retail space. The telco is exploring options, including selling the land, with market watchers suggesting a sale price could be influenced by the site's redevelopment potential and zoning. The property's lease tenure and taxes will impact the price, with estimates suggesting a potential sale price of S$172 million.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Apple's new 'spaceship' home wows one and all
summary: Apple's $5 billion Apple Park in Cupertino, California, has transformed the surrounding area, drawing tourists and businesses. The 70-hectare campus features a futuristic ring, the Steve Jobs Theater, and 9,000 trees. While the development has helped boost local businesses, it has also raised concerns among residents, including increased traffic and property prices. The campus is expected to be fully staffed by 12,000 employees in several months, with Apple hosting community gatherings and offering to cover construction costs for nearby residents. The project is seen as a major milestone for the tech industry in Silicon Valley.

site_title: China's Primavera Capital looks closer to home for investment opportunities
summary: China's Primavera Capital, one of the country's largest private equity firms, is shifting focus towards domestic investments due to stricter capital controls and rising protectionism. The firm has joined a $1.1 billion fundraising round for Alibaba's Koubei and taken stakes in Zhejiang Dasouche Finance Leasing Company. Primavera's co-founder and chairman, Fred Hu, believes China still "punches below its weight" and will become a big capital exporter, but faces hurdles in the near term. The firm manages $8 billion in funds and has a diverse portfolio of investments, including Yum China Holdings and Ant Financial Services Group.

site_title: Bid to relocate Louisiana town runs into difficulties
summary: The town of Isle de Jean Charles, Louisiana, is relocating due to global warming, with the US government providing $48 million to move fewer than 40 families, mostly from the Biloxi-Chitimacha-Choctaw tribe. However, the relocation process is facing difficulties, including definitional issues over who is part of the community, concerns over the new sites' suitability, and fears of the state taking over the island after relocation. The relocation aims to demonstrate the viability of such efforts, but the stakes are high, and the Trump administration's reversal of climate change policies may increase pressure on coastal communities to reconsider their fate.

site_title: Foreigners account for 4.7% of home sales in Toronto region
summary: The Ontario government reported that foreign buyers accounted for 4.7% of home sales in the Toronto region from April 24 to May 26, aligning with previous surveys. This data is part of a new housing plan to make homes more affordable for Canadian residents. A 15% levy on foreign investors buying residential property in Toronto and nearby cities was implemented in April to curb speculation. The move aims to test whether the levy will impact the market and curb the influence of non-resident buyers on home prices in the city.

site_title: PM Lee waives Parliamentary privilege on his statements
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong waived his Parliamentary privilege to dispute allegations by his siblings over the fate of the Lees' family home. His siblings, Lee Hsien Yang and Lee Wei Ling, claimed an abuse of power, while Lee Hsien Loong argued that suing them would further besmirch their parents' names. The siblings denied making a criticism of the government, stating their goal is to expose Lee Hsien Loong's misconduct, not to bring down the government. The public clash highlights the internal struggles within the Lee family following the death of founding Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has waived his Parliamentary privilege over the statements he made in Parliament to dispute the claims made against him by his siblings over the fate of 38 Oxley Road.

site_title: G-20 may be most remarkable since 2009
summary: World leaders are gathering in Hamburg for the G-20 summit, marking what could be the most remarkable meeting since 2009 due to expected splits between the US and other Western countries over issues like trade, migration, and climate change. The summit will also see a high-profile meeting between US President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin. German Chancellor Angela Merkel is seeking to unite Western powers on climate and trade issues, potentially with the support of Chinese President Xi Jinping. However, the G-20's effectiveness remains limited due to a lack of formal mechanisms to enforce agreements, and critics argue that the group's composition and agenda may not adequately represent the needs of all countries.

site_title: British PM May finds it lonely at the top, but battles on - for now
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May faces challenges as she begins 2 years of Brexit talks, but party sources say moves to oust her are on hold. May lost her party's parliamentary majority in the ill-fated election and struggled to unite her government, but will lead Brexit talks to give the economy some breathing space. Despite differences with her team, May's control is draining away, and some lawmakers say she will stay for as long as the party wants her to, but her sense of duty may be bigger than her pride.

site_title: Xiaomi goes back to basics to woo customers
summary: Xiaomi, the Chinese smartphone maker, is undergoing a major transformation to revamp its brand and sales strategy. After missing targets, the company is shifting focus to building its own retail outlets, called "Mi Homes," which will offer an upscale shopping experience. Xiaomi aims to build 1,000 Mi Homes by 2019, with an estimated 70 billion yuan (S$13.8 billion) in sales by 2021. However, the company faces stiff competition from rivals Huawei, Oppo, and Vivo, who have secured prime locations and reseller deals. Xiaomi's retail efforts are seen as a long-term strategy to appeal to higher-end buyers and complement its online presence.

site_title: Foreign brands losing favour with China consumers
summary: Foreign brands are losing market share in China, with domestic companies gaining ground. According to Nielsen, foreign companies now hold 30.2% of the market, down from 33.5% in 2006. Chinese consumers prioritize brand origin, quality, and natural ingredients, driving the preference for domestic brands. The stable economy and e-commerce convenience have fueled a consumption boom, with domestic companies benefiting from their better understanding of customers and faster decision-making. Foreign companies still dominate in personal care products, but domestic companies are gaining ground in other sectors.

site_title: Catalonia to declare independence instantly if 'yes' vote wins referendum
summary: Catalonia's ruling coalition has unveiled a bill aimed at holding a referendum on independence from Spain on October 1, despite Madrid's refusal. If the "yes" side wins, the region will declare independence "immediately." A recent poll shows 48.5% of Catalans are against independence, but a majority want the referendum to take place. The bill, which will be submitted to the Catalan parliament, aims to circumvent legal and practical challenges to organizing the vote, deepening tensions with Madrid.

site_title: EU, Japan reach 'political agreement' on trade deal
summary: The European Union and Japan reached a "political agreement" on a historic free trade deal, ending four years of negotiations. The deal, which covers some of the accord's toughest aspects, includes Japan's commitment to open its market to the EU's car industry and scrap barriers to EU farming products, particularly dairy. The agreement is seen as a provocation to US President Donald Trump, who has taken a protectionist stance, and marks a significant win for free trade. The deal will be confirmed at a G-20 summit on Thursday.

site_title: Why innovators can give new products more mileage
summary: Marketers can benefit from targeting innovators, a small but influential group of consumers who are willing to try new products and share their experiences with others. Unlike early adopters, innovators are often highly affluent and less risk-averse, making them ideal for disruptive products. A study found that a stable lifestyle contributes to innovators' willingness to try new products and share them with others. Companies can use big data to identify and target innovators, and tailor their marketing strategies to appeal to this group. By doing so, they can increase the chances of a product being accepted by more skeptical audiences.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CIMB Research has upgraded its ratings for four tech manufacturing services stocks: AEM, Jadason, Memtech, and Sunningdale, citing potential earnings outperformance and mergers and acquisitions. The stocks have room for upside, with Memtech and Sunningdale trading below book value. The tech sector remains a healthy place for investors, with valuations aligned with growth prospects. CIMB Research also notes that companies like UMS and Venture have potential for earnings surprises and mergers, driving dividend coverage.

site_title: COE premiums mostly up; Cat A stays flat
summary: Singapore's COE (Car Certificate of Entitlement) premiums rebounded, with Cat B and Cat C experiencing hikes, despite a weak market. Cat A premiums remained flat at S$42,801, while Cat B rose to S$49,802 and Cat E to S$49,899. Industry experts attributed the surge in Cat B to dealers clearing non-Euro 6 stock ahead of the stricter emission standard, and favorable exchange rates giving dealers bigger margins.

images.alt_text: The big car certificate of entitlement (COE) premium rebounded even as the small car premium remained exactly the same.

site_title: Homegrown, but foreign
summary: Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event in Mumbai, expanding its robotaxi services to California and Arizona. FedEx partnered with Singapore's QuikBot to deploy robots for commercial deliveries. Delta Air Lines reported an upbeat outlook on travel demand, lifting its shares. Japan's carmakers reduced export prices to the US to offset the impact of tariffs. Meanwhile, BYD and other EV battery makers faced increased pressure to cut emissions.

site_title: Indonesian economy more resilient, 20 years after IMF's 'wrong advice'
summary: Indonesia's economy has become more resilient 20 years after the country was hit by a severe economic crisis in 1998, largely due to the implementation of reforms led by President Joko Widodo and Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati. The crisis led to a new crop of leaders and reformers, who have worked to tackle corruption and clean up the tax system. Today, Indonesia boasts near-record foreign-currency reserves, a large economy, and investors are lining up to tap its growing and youthful population.

images.alt_text: Indonesia has South-east Asia's largest economy that's posted annual average growth of more than 5 per cent in the past five years.

site_title: America's mall owners cough up to stay relevant in Amazon era
summary: US mall owners are renovating and repositioning their properties to remain relevant in the Amazon era. Time Equities Inc, the owner of Newgate Mall, plans to spend $500,000 on a food court renovation to attract new businesses and shoppers. This is part of a larger effort to increase foot traffic and stay competitive. Similar landlords are investing in makeovers to keep their properties relevant as online shopping continues to grow.

site_title: A holdout delays US developer's high-rise dream
summary: Sheldon Solow, a billionaire developer, is set to build a 54-storey hotel and condominium tower on Billionaires' Row in Manhattan. However, a holdout tenant, Metropolitan Fine Arts and Antiques, is delaying the project by contesting a five-day eviction notice issued by Solow's company. The tenant claims it has a valid lease and refuses to leave the location, citing concerns that the scaffolding erected by Solow's company is discouraging customers from entering the store. The case is scheduled to be heard in state Supreme Court on Thursday.

site_title: Hamburg bets on hydrogen to power its cars; customers aren't so sure
summary: Hamburg is investing in hydrogen fueling stations, aiming to reduce emissions and switch from traditional petrol and diesel. However, the initiative has sparked skepticism among customers, who are uncertain about the availability and cost-effectiveness of hydrogen. The city's gas station in the warehouse district now features hydrogen pumps, but the city's residents remain hesitant to adopt the new technology.

site_title: China's big short looks more likely to be a squeeze on investors
summary: China's largest non-state controlled financial firm, Ping An Insurance Group Co, saw its short interest surge to a record HK$54 billion (S$9.5 billion) in June, making it the biggest bearish wager on Hong Kong's stock exchange. This has raised concerns among top-ranked fund managers and analysts that a squeeze on investors may be imminent. The significant short interest could lead to a sharp decline in Ping An's stock price, potentially affecting other Chinese companies listed on the Hong Kong exchange.

site_title: Tencent makes smart TV push in joint venture with China's biggest TV maker
summary: Tencent Holdings, China's largest social media and gaming company, has agreed to feature its video content on TCL Corp's smart TVs, expanding its content dominance from mobile phones to living rooms. Tencent invested 450 million yuan (S$91.497 million) in TCL subsidiary Shenzhen Thunderbird Network Technology, making it the second-largest shareholder. The partnership aims to deliver online content and over-the-top services, increasing membership bases and revenue from user spending on content.

site_title: Luxury cars offer more models, but find fewer buyers
summary: Luxury car sales declined 3% in June, the sixth consecutive monthly decline, as consumers prefer SUVs and trucks. Despite the addition of new models, luxury brands such as BMW and Mercedes-Benz saw sales fall, with BMW's sales down 2.8% and Mercedes-Benz's sales slightly lower. The luxury sector is facing challenges due to a shift in consumer preferences, with American consumers now strongly preferring SUVs and crossovers. Luxury brands are struggling to attract new buyers and expand market share, with some models experiencing significant declines in sales.

site_title: US indie brewers act to differentiate 'true' craft beers from those made by Big Beer
summary: The US craft beer industry is launching a new initiative to differentiate "true" craft beers from those made by large breweries. Over 800 breweries, including Sam Adams and Sierra Nevada, will print a "Certified Independent Craft" seal on their beers, indicating they meet certain ownership and production requirements. The move aims to clear up confusion and provide transparency for consumers, as large breweries have acquired many independent craft breweries, giving them significant advantages in distribution and marketing.

site_title: Lower density regions to lead consumer growth in Asean
summary: A report by Nielsen and AlphaBeta predicts that Asean's consumer markets will be driven by "middleweight" regions, which are less densely populated than major cities, rather than densely populated mega-cities, until 2030. These regions are expected to outpace cities like Jakarta, Manila, and Bangkok, which do not dominate Asean's consumer demand.

site_title: Drugmakers, distributors face deluge of opioid lawsuits in the US
summary: US drugmakers and distributors are facing a surge of lawsuits over the opioid epidemic, with at least 25 states, cities, and counties filing civil cases against manufacturers, distributors, and pharmaceutical chains since last year. The lawsuits claim the companies' products contributed to nearly 180,000 overdose deaths from 2000 to 2015. The attorneys-general of Ohio, Missouri, and Oklahoma have recently filed suits against the industry, with more cases expected. The US opioid industry generates $13 billion annually, and the lawsuits could have significant economic implications.

site_title: US town raises airport traffic, noise complaints
summary: The town of East Hampton, New York, has lost its ability to restrict late-night and early-morning flights at its airport due to a US Supreme Court decision not to review an appellate court ruling. The decision, made on June 26, invalidated the town's year-round curfew and noise restrictions, allowing helicopters and business jets to operate freely at any time. Residents, including Patricia Currie and Barry Raebeck, expressed frustration, saying the noise is a daily nuisance. Local officials plan to file an application with the FAA for noise restrictions, but the decision has left them with limited options.

site_title: YuuZoo: More troubling issues
summary: YuuZoo Corporation, a Singapore-based company, is facing concerns over its corporate governance, disclosure, and accounting practices. The company's reverse takeover (RTO) of Infocomm Asia Holdings (IAH) in 2015 raised questions about its valuation, with the effective consideration being S$18 million despite a proposed purchase price of US$36.6 million. YuuZoo also faced issues with its investment in Relativity Holdings LLC, which was cancelled due to conditions precedent not being met. The company's dealings with Etisalat Nigeria, including a "rationalisation transaction agreement" and a potential bond default, have raised concerns about its financial distress. Additionally, YuuZoo's franchise sales and revenue recognition practices have been questioned, with the company changing its accounting policy in 2016. The company's auditor has highlighted significant judgement required in assessing revenue recognition, and questions have been raised about the valuation of its shares in companies operating franchise agreements.

site_title: Russia hits Islamic State in Syria with advanced cruise missiles
summary: Russia launched a strike on Islamic State targets in Syria using advanced cruise missiles, with Tupolev-95MS strategic bombers firing Kh-101 missiles from 1,000 kilometers away. The attack destroyed three ammunition depots and a command post. The move comes ahead of a meeting between Russian President Vladimir Putin and US President Donald Trump at the G20 summit. The strike was carried out with escorting Sukhoi-30SM fighters and all bombers returned safely to Russia.

site_title: Buy gold near US$1,200 an ounce: UBS Wealth
summary: UBS Wealth predicts gold will trade between $1,200 and $1,300 an ounce in the short term, as it tracks US real interest rates. The metal's price may be negatively affected by a falling US unemployment rate and rising interest rates, but solid demand and a lower dollar could support prices. Geopolitical risks and lower equity valuations could also boost gold prices, with a possible range of $1,150 to $1,350 in the second half of the year.

site_title: China's LeEco confirms that assets have been frozen
summary: LeEco, a Chinese tech giant, has had assets frozen in a dispute with China Merchants Bank over unpaid loans to a LeEco smartphone unit. A Shanghai court ordered the freezing of 1.237 billion yuan (S$252 million) in assets, including 519 million shares owned by billionaire founder Jia Yueting. LeEco, founded in 2004, has struggled with financial woes, including a cash crunch and setbacks in its expansion plans, including a US market push. The court action may impact LeEco's operations, but negotiations with LeEco are ongoing.

site_title: How Silicon Valley pushed coding into American classrooms
summary: Silicon Valley tech companies, led by Code.org, are pushing for coding courses in every US public school, citing the need for skilled engineers to drive the nation's tech industry. Founded by Hadi Partovi, a former Facebook and Airbnb investor, Code.org has raised $60 million from tech giants and helped persuade two dozen states to adopt computer science education policies. The movement raises concerns about industry influence in public schools, with some experts warning that it could prioritize industry demands over students' interests.

site_title: Sacked Vogue editor slams fashion industry, magazines
summary: Former British Vogue fashion director Lucinda Chambers publicly criticized the fashion industry and magazines, citing the brutal nature of the business and the influence of advertisers over publishers. Chambers claimed she was fired from Vogue in just three minutes, with no prior warning, and expressed frustration with the industry's focus on exclusivity and profit over quality content. The interview was initially removed from a journal but later republished, sparking praise from readers and speculation about potential legal action. Chambers' candid remarks have reignited debate about the fashion industry's priorities and the role of magazines in shaping consumer behavior.

site_title: Firefly to hold back on capacity growth this year: CEO
summary: Firefly Airlines, a Malaysia-based carrier, will not add capacity this year after reducing its fleet and network last year due to a slower economic climate and weaker currency. The airline has 12 aircraft, down from 18, and will review its network again next year.
