The service aims to cater to the growing demand for affordable funerals in a country where the population is rapidly aging.

site_title: Short-term positive, longer-term uncertain
summary: US stocks have reached all-time highs despite valuation concerns, driven by financials, technology, and cyclicals. Analysts expect a correction, citing high valuations, but the global economy's growth and low interest rates suggest a bear market is unlikely. The Singapore market has also seen a 5-day rally, but the longer-term outlook remains uncertain, with the Straits Times Index diverging from the broader market. DBS's chief investment officer notes that a correction is possible but a bear market is unlikely due to manageable political risks.

site_title: In tweeted video, Trump knocks down, beats up 'CNN'
summary: US President Donald Trump tweeted a video showing him knocking down and beating a professional wrestling "villain" with a CNN logo, sparking widespread condemnation from journalists and politicians. The tweet was seen as promoting physical violence against the media, with some labeling it as an attempt to "weaponise distrust." This comes after a week of unrestrained Twitter attacks on MSNBC talk show hosts, drawing criticism from both parties. Trump's actions have raised concerns about his handling of the media and potential implications for the country's democratic institutions.

site_title: Tokyo election defeat could mean Abe's days are numbered
summary: Tokyo governor Yuriko Koike's "Tokyo Citizens First" party is set for a decisive victory in the Tokyo Metropolitan Government election, potentially threatening Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's hold on power. Koike's party is expected to win 48-50 seats, mirroring the national political mood. This outcome could lead to a shift in Japan's national political scene, with Koike's party's victory seen as a challenge to Abe's Liberal Democratic Party.

site_title: Japan banks continue post-Brexit departure from London
summary: Japan's Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group plans to set up its new European head office in Frankfurt, following other Japanese financial institutions that have announced similar moves. The decision is driven by the need for "passporting" rights to market products across the EU, which could be lost if the UK exits the EU single market. This trend is expected to continue as other financial centers, such as Paris and Luxembourg, compete to attract institutions from the City of London. The move is seen as a significant shift in the post-Brexit landscape for the City of London.

site_title: Big pharma turns to artificial intelligence to speed up drug discovery process
summary: Big pharma companies, including Glaxo-SmithKline, Merck & Co, Johnson & Johnson, and Sanofi, are using artificial intelligence (AI) to speed up the drug discovery process. A new $43 million deal was announced, marking a significant investment in AI technology to improve the hit-or-miss business of finding new medicines. Other pharmaceutical giants are also exploring AI's potential to streamline the drug discovery process, with the goal of developing more effective treatments.

site_title: East Europeans unhappy over 'food apartheid'
summary: Eastern European leaders are upset over findings that Western brands use cheaper ingredients in food products sold in former communist countries. Tests in Hungary, Slovakia, and the Czech Republic showed that identical packaging often contained superior quality ingredients in richer neighboring EU countries. Bulgarian government-backed studies confirmed discrepancies in at least seven products, including lower milk and cocoa content in chocolate desserts and sweeter soft drinks. The issue has fueled concerns about "food apartheid" and "two-tiered Europe," with experts citing EU regulations allowing companies to tweak recipes for local palates.

site_title: Fashion tries to prove women can look good in bin bags
summary: Belgian fashion designers Filip Arickx and An Vandevorst showcased their unconventional haute couture creations at a Paris fashion show, challenging the notion that a stylish woman can only look good in expensive, luxurious clothing. The duo transformed black plastic bin liners and dry cleaning sheaths into elaborate ball gowns, demonstrating that fashion can be both sustainable and stylish. Their show aimed to prove that a woman can look beautiful in even the most unlikely of materials, highlighting the potential for creativity and innovation in the fashion industry.

site_title: Pacquiao camp, social media slam judges after shock loss to Australian
summary: Manny Pacquiao lost his World Boxing Organisation welterweight title to Jeff Horn in a unanimous decision in Brisbane, Australia. Pacquiao's camp criticized the judges, calling them "crazy" and the referee "sketchy". Pacquiao's strength and conditioning coach, Justin Fortune, expressed his frustration, stating that the outcome was unfair. The loss marked a shock to Pacquiao's fans, who had expected a victory. The result has sparked debate and controversy in the boxing community.

site_title: Singapore firms band together for HSR projects
summary: Six Singapore companies, including Clifford Capital, DBS Bank, and Sembcorp Design & Construction, are partnering to participate in the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail project. The companies will collaborate with international players to bid on the AssetsCo tender, responsible for designing, building, and maintaining the rail assets. The project aims to be operational by 2026, facilitating travel between Kuala Lumpur and Singapore. The partnership leverages the unique strengths of each company, covering the entire value chain of financing, design, construction, and operations.

site_title: Equity crowdfunding still a relevant, dynamic financing tool
summary: Equity crowdfunding remains a relevant financing tool for startups, allowing them to raise funds from accredited investors globally without requiring collateral or track records. OurCrowd, an Israel-based platform, has amassed nearly 20,000 global investors, investing over US$440 million in portfolio companies and funds since 2013. Despite the emergence of cryptocurrency crowdfunding, equity crowdfunding is preferred by startups as it offers a chance to tap into venture capital firms and allows investors to add value. OurCrowd is leveraging artificial intelligence to improve its due diligence process and identify high-quality startups.

site_title: Printing money leads to recession: S Africa central bank governor
summary: South African Reserve Bank Governor Lesetja Kganyago warns that printing money to spur growth could lead to a recession. He cites past examples of painful recessions caused by reducing runaway inflation. The warning comes amid economic contraction, credit downgrades, and a court challenge to an anti-graft agency's recommendation to focus on growth over inflation. The central bank aims to keep inflation below 6% and has lifted interest rates to encourage long-term investment. If the central bank abandons its inflation-targeting policy, South Africa risks slipping into a recession.

site_title: Samsung to start selling refurbished Galaxy Note 7 this week
summary: Samsung plans to sell a refurbished Galaxy Note 7 smartphone, called the Galaxy Note Fan Edition (FE), starting this week in South Korea. The device is made from recalled, unsealed Note 7 handsets and comes with new batteries. Priced at 699,000 won (S$840), it's significantly cheaper than the original version. The move aims to minimize waste and reduce environmental harm from discarded phones. The company has also launched a new flagship device, the Galaxy S8, and posted its biggest quarterly net profit in over three years.

site_title: Keppel O&M to deliver world's first converted FLNGV
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (O&M) is set to deliver the world's first converted floating liquefaction vessel (FLNGV) to Golar Hilli Corporation in August. The US$735 million contract marks a significant milestone in the development of stranded gas fields, as liquefaction of natural gas has traditionally taken place at purpose-built onshore plants. The conversion of the LNG carrier to an FLNGV is considered cost-effective and faster to market, making it a viable option for LNG projects in a low commodity price environment.

site_title: CapitaLand revving up expansion plans
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-based property developer, is expanding its presence in China with plans to acquire more assets and land. The company has already opened four integrated projects in China, including three Raffles City projects, and has a US$1.5 billion private equity fund to deploy. CapitaLand aims to continue its growth in core markets of China and Singapore, and has secured management contracts for third-party malls in both countries. The company's CEO, Lim Ming Yan, stated that the group will explore more Raffles City projects in Beijing, Shanghai, and other cities.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Indonesia detains a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO is Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran. Helen Wong is retiring as OCBC CEO, with Tan Teck Long taking over. Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. CGSI downgraded Grab to 'hold' due to slowing earnings growth in H2.

site_title: New US security rules will strain airlines, airports: aviation officials
summary: The US Department of Homeland Security has issued new security directives requiring airlines to screen passengers for trace amounts of explosives and impose more stringent security checks. The rules, which must be implemented within 21 days, require 280 airports to have explosive-detection technology in place. Airlines and airports will need to buy equipment, hire staff, and train employees, leading to potential delays and increased ticket prices. Smaller airports and airlines may struggle to comply, and non-compliance could result in penalties, including the loss of US flight rights.

site_title: All eyes on July for US oil demand to drain glut
summary: US oil traders expect July to be a key month for demand, with summer driving demand and export opportunities to Asia driving a potential drawdown in inventories. July has historically seen a 2.9 million barrel weekly drop in inventories, but analysts warn that a lack of drawdown could dash hopes for higher prices by year-end. A record number of motorists are expected for the Fourth of July holiday, and robust appetite from Japanese and South Korean buyers could help absorb excess supplies, which have remained above seasonal averages due to Libyan and Nigerian supply recoveries and US shale production rebound.

site_title: Europe is the new hunting ground for US investors
summary: US investors, seeking big dividends, are targeting European companies, following their successful campaigns in the US. Activist shareholders, such as Daniel Loeb, are buying stakes in companies like Nestle and pushing for cost-cutting, asset sales, and share buybacks to boost dividends. Europe's friendly laws and lack of deterrent measures against activist investors make it an attractive target, but strong trade unions and government interventions may pose challenges.

site_title: China, HK bond link scheme to start on Monday to lure inflows
summary: China and Hong Kong's central banks announced a trial of the Bond Connect program, allowing non-mainland investors to trade Chinese corporate bonds starting Monday. The initial "northbound" phase will not allow mainland investors to buy and sell Hong Kong-listed debt. The program aims to open up China's $9 trillion bond market to foreign investors, with the goal of increasing global debt indices' inclusion of Chinese bonds. China Development Bank plans to issue up to $4.06 billion worth of bonds, and foreign investors are expected to increase their investment in China's bond market, potentially reaching $250 billion.

site_title: Portrait of an artiste as a tormented man
summary: Michael K. Williams, the actor who played Omar Little in HBO's The Wire, struggled to grasp his character's signature shotgun on the show's first day of filming. Despite this, he persisted and enlisted a local drug dealer to help him learn about firearms. Williams's dedication to his craft led to a memorable performance, cementing his role as one of television's most iconic characters.

site_title: S'pore startup launching SEA's first cryptocurrency crowdfunding platform
summary: A Singapore startup, FundYourselfNow, is launching the region's first cryptocurrency crowdfunding platform, set to launch in early 2018. The platform will allow entrepreneurs to raise funds for projects using virtual currencies like Bitcoin or Ethereum. Funded by co-founders Jack Ser and Kenneth Tan, it will cater to the growing demand for alternative funding options in South-east Asia. The platform is expected to revolutionize the fintech industry in the region, providing a new way for startups to access capital and for investors to participate in projects.

site_title: Buyback flows consistent and acquisition to disposal ratios higher
summary: STI added 1.3% in four trading sessions from June 23 to June 29, bringing its 2017 year-to-date dividend-inclusive return to 14.9%. Ten stocks conducted share buybacks totaling S$11.8 million, with OCBC contributing the most, purchasing 800,000 shares at an average price of S$10.76. Buyback activity is expected to decline in July ahead of second-quarter earnings reports.

site_title: Banks offering bras, buffets, facelifts while you check your balance online
summary: Singapore's Big Three banks are poised to launch online shopping malls, allowing customers to browse and purchase goods and services while checking their account balances online. The move comes as the Monetary Authority of Singapore streamlines anti-commingling policies to enable banks to invest up to 10% of their capital in non-financial businesses. Chinese banks have already operated online shopping malls for years, offering a wide range of products and services. Singaporean banks, including DBS, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC, are ready to follow suit, citing the potential to improve customer experience and create new opportunities.

site_title: Wealthy new DC residents blame rich newcomers for housing cost hike: poll
summary: A Washington Post poll found 78% of DC residents with incomes over $150,000 blame wealthy newcomers for the city's affordable housing shortage. The majority of residents, 64%, also criticize the city government for not spending enough on affordable housing, and 54% say the city prioritizes developers over residents. The median home value in DC has tripled since 2000, and rents have risen in parallel, with many residents, including some with above-average incomes, being priced out of the city.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Tuesday, following gains across Asia and record highs for Wall Street. London's FTSE 100 index increased 0.4% to 7,400.96 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.2% to 12,147.89 points. The Paris CAC 40 advanced 0.5% to 5,116.90 points. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: In South-east Asia, you can't win alone: Lazada
summary: Alibaba's $2 billion investment in Lazada has led to a shift in the online retailer's strategy in South-east Asia, from a centralized model to focusing on data analysis for merchants. Lazada Singapore's CEO, Alexis Lanternier, stated that the company initially controlled all aspects of the online shopping process but now prioritizes data analysis to support merchants. This change has helped Lazada understand the importance of building partnerships and infrastructure in the region for long-term success.

site_title: Trump budget plans cut funds for affordable housing in US
summary: US President Donald Trump's proposed corporate tax cut has weakened a federal tax-credit program that finances affordable housing, resulting in a 10% drop in private funding. The program, which supplies $14 billion annually for low-income housing, has seen a $1 billion reduction in funding since November. States and cities are now covering the gap, but this depletes funds for other housing projects and related programs. The White House also plans to cut spending on rental vouchers and other federal programs, exacerbating the issue, and HUD Secretary Ben Carson says the cuts are needed to promote "freedom from regulations and bureaucracy".

site_title: High-tech dashboards signal big changes for car parts suppliers
summary: US car supplier Visteon Corp has found a cluttered electronics system behind modern car dashboards, as digital features become increasingly popular. The electronics are comprised of components from multiple suppliers, creating a "rat's nest" of components. This trend is expected to continue as car manufacturers prioritize digital features over traditional components. The findings highlight the need for better supply chain management and standardization in the automotive industry.

site_title: Voluntary unconditional cash offer for Changtian Plastic & Chemical closes
summary: A voluntary unconditional cash offer for Changtian Plastic & Chemical Limited closed on July 31, with RHT Capital, on behalf of United Tech Industries Limited, acquiring 11,906,023 shares. The offeror plans to delist the company, citing low trading liquidity, greater management flexibility, and elimination of listing-related expenses. The offeror, a privately held vehicle, is owned by Changtian Plastic's chairman and deputy chairman, Yang Qingjin and Chen Yongfu, respectively.

site_title: Germany braces for anti-globalisation protests ahead of G20
summary: Germany is bracing for anti-globalization protests ahead of the G20 summit in Hamburg, with Chancellor Angela Merkel emphasizing the need for sustainable and inclusive economic growth. The protests, which drew tens of thousands of demonstrators, are centered on issues like wealth distribution, resource consumption, and climate change. Merkel outlined the G20's agenda as focusing on achieving "win-win" situations for all parties involved, with a focus on climate protection, open markets, and social and environmental standards. German authorities are worried about possible acts of sabotage and violence during the protests.

site_title: Uncertainty as India's landmark new sales tax is rolled out
summary: India's new nationwide sales tax, the Goods and Services Tax (GST), was rolled out on July 1, 2017, replacing over a dozen state and territory taxes and levies. The unified tax structure aims to expand the country's narrow tax base, increase government revenues, and boost foreign investment. However, businesses and consumers are uncertain about the new system, with many shops closed and consumers staying away due to price changes and confusion over tax rates. The government expects some short-term pain but expects long-term benefits, including improved ease of doing business and increased compliance.

images.alt_text: A textile trader waiting outside shops which were closed in protest of the new sales tax, in the Mangaldas cloth market in Mumbai on June 30.

site_title: Investors waiting to see if bull market wobbles get more pronounced
summary: The US stock market ended the first half of the year with a whimper, with investors concerned about the sustainability of the bull market. The dollar hit its lowest mark since October against a basket of currencies, and investors are worried about the Federal Reserve's interest rate plans. The June jobs report is expected to be released this week, which could influence market sentiment. The Fed's actions could lead to a rally in rate-sensitive sectors, while concerns about inflation, policy rates, and bond yields could weigh on the S&P 500's valuation.

site_title: Philippines vows to defend outsourcing empire as China rises
summary: The Philippines' $23 billion outsourcing empire faces mounting risks due to China's rising competitiveness. The country's English proficiency, young population, and cheap labor have made it a global leader in IT business process outsourcing, but China has surpassed the Philippines in competitiveness, according to a report by advisory firm Tholons. The government aims to cut incentives and address concerns from investors amid a siege in the south. The Philippines' outsourcing industry head, Rey Untal, emphasized the need for the country to "put its act together" to maintain its position.

site_title: Greece's road to bailout exit: 140 reforms down, more to go
summary: Greece is nearing its exit from the bailout program, but the country still faces significant challenges in implementing structural reforms. With 140 reforms agreed upon, Greece needs to implement an additional 100 measures to access the remaining €26.9 billion in funds. Critics argue that the Greek state lacks political will and technical expertise to put these reforms into action, threatening to prolong uncertainty and delay opportunities for the country. Despite progress in austerity measures, Greece's record on implementing reforms has been poor, and further long-lasting reforms are needed to address entrenched habits.

site_title: Junk-bond investor unease resurfaces as another debt deal is pulled
summary: Hecla Mining Co pulled a US$500 million junk-bond deal, citing unattractive terms. This is the latest sign of investor unease in the junk-bond market, which has seen significant outflows from high-yield bond funds and leveraged-loan markets. Investors are seeking better compensation for riskier debt due to close-to-all-time high valuations and market uncertainty, particularly amid a renewed oil price rout. This trend is part of a broader credit market pullback, with several companies, including Virgin Media and Charter Communications, also withdrawing deals in recent days.

site_title: Thrill is gone as metals investors start to ditch ETFs
summary: Investors are pulling out of industrial metals ETFs, with a net outflow of about $90.4 million in the first six months of 2017, the largest since 2015. Copper remains a top performer, but prices are seen as being in a "price trap" due to increasing doubts about demand growth in China and the US. Low volatility and fading enthusiasm from hedge funds are contributing to the outflow, with some assets offering similar gains. Analysts expect China's economic data to beat expectations, but demand growth is expected to slow to less than 3% in the second half, hurting industrial metals prospects.

images.alt_text: A long list of mine disruptions this year has helped to push copper prices higher. Those include a contractual dispute inhibiting shipments from Freeport-McMoRan's Grasberg mine in Indonesia (above).

site_title: A city built on the resilience and heart of its people
summary: The article highlights the resilience and character of the Hong Kong people, arguing that the city's values and spirit will carry it through tough times. Despite sociopolitical troubles and growing distrust of Beijing, Hong Kongers remain unafraid to speak up and take action, as seen in the 2014 Occupy Central protests and the recent case of an elderly woman arrested for selling a piece of cardboard. The author believes that the resilience and heart of the people will define the city, regardless of its future path.

site_title: Q&M Dental Group to acquire 20% stake in China's Superline
summary: Q&M Dental Group, a Singapore-listed dental group, is set to acquire a 20% stake in China's Superline Technology Co for 62 million yuan (S$12.6 million). The acquisition is part of Q&M's expansion into dental-related industries in China. Superline, founded by three PhD scientists, manufactures endodontic root canal files and orthodontic arch wires. The deal involves a 12-year service agreement and a guarantee of Q&M's entitled dividends.

site_title: Qatar mimics the 'investment diplomacy' of rival Saudi Arabia
summary: Qatar has adopted a strategy of "investment diplomacy" to counter Saudi Arabia's influence, buying stakes in US companies such as the Empire State Building, American Airlines, and Boeing. The move is seen as a way to promote Qatar's interests and counter US President Donald Trump's support for Saudi Arabia in the ongoing dispute. Despite Trump's accusations of Qatar sponsoring terrorism, the US has continued to support Qatar's position, with the State Department rebuking the Saudi coalition for its treatment of the country. Qatar's investments in the US economy have given it a degree of leverage, but its smaller size and financial resources mean it remains vulnerable to shifting political sands.

site_title: Graft-tainted ex-Israeli PM released from jail on parole
summary: Israeli ex-Prime Minister Ehud Olmert was released from prison on parole after serving a 27-month sentence for corruption scandals. This marks the first time a former Israeli premier has served jail time. Olmert did not comment on his release, leaving the prison in central Israel. The decision comes after his promising political career was marred by corruption scandals that led to his downfall.

site_title: Six companies band together for high speed rail projects
summary: Six Singapore companies, including Clifford Capital and SMRT International, are teaming up to participate in the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail project. The companies will partner international players to design, build, finance, and maintain the rail assets. The project aims to facilitate travel between Kuala Lumpur and Singapore by 2026, enhancing business linkages and people-to-people ties. An industry briefing will be held on July 5 to outline the parameters of the AssetsCo tender, expected to be called by the end of 2017.

site_title: Keppel O&M to deliver world's first converted FLNGV
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (O&M) is set to deliver the world's first converted floating liquefaction vessel (FLNGV), Hilli Episeyo, to Golar Hilli Corporation in August. The vessel, converted from an LNG carrier, is the first of its kind and represents a significant milestone in the use of floating liquefaction technology. The delivery is expected to demonstrate the cost-effectiveness and speed of converted FLNGVs, making LNG projects viable even in a low commodity price environment.

site_title: Bone-dry US Northern plains means crops from barley to oats are parched
summary: A severe drought has gripped the US Great Plains, affecting crop production in North Dakota and neighboring states. Almost half of North Dakota is in severe to extreme drought, impacting barley, oats, and other crops. Spring wheat futures are expected to rise 32% this month, while soyabeans and oats are also on the rise. The drought puts pressure on the Midwest to have favorable conditions, and North Dakota's drought is expected to persist, with less than 4.9 inches of rain falling in the past week.

site_title: Silicon Valley women frankly describe sexual harassment
summary: More than two dozen women in the technology startup industry have come forward to describe being sexually harassed by investors, revealing a pervasive and ingrained problem in Silicon Valley. The women, who spoke to The New York Times, shared stories of propositioned venture capitalists, suggestive messages, and sexist comments. The disclosures have led to high-profile venture capitalists such as Chris Sacca and Dave McClure being accused of misconduct, and have sparked a cultural shift in the industry. The women's experiences highlight the imbalance of power and limited ability to push back against inappropriate behavior, often due to the need for funding.

site_title: Q&M to buy 20% stake in Superline for S$12.65m
summary: Q&M Dental Group has agreed to acquire a 20% stake in Superline Technology Co for S$12.65 million. The acquisition is part of Q&M's expansion into dental-related industries in China. Superline, a China-incorporated company, manufactures nikel-titanium endodontic root canal files and orthodontic arch wires. The deal is subject to shareholder approval and is expected to enhance Q&M's presence in the Chinese market.

site_title: France launches two new high-speed rail lines
summary: France has inaugurated two new high-speed rail lines, connecting Paris to Bordeaux and Rennes, with 35,000 and 30,000 daily passengers expected, respectively. The lines, valued at nearly 8 billion euros, were built under public-private partnerships and will be operated by Vinci for 50 years. However, the SNCF's president warned of a loss of 90 million euros this year due to high usage costs. The lines are seen as a last major project before the government's financial constraints limit new investments.

site_title: Abe's ruling LDP humbled by upstart party in Tokyo election
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) suffered a heavy loss in Tokyo's assembly election, with upstart party Tomin First (Tokyo Residents First) projected to win 48-50 seats. The LDP's Tokyo chapter, led by Hakubun Shimomura, acknowledged the result as a national politics issue, while analysts predict Abe will face a deepening crisis, potentially leading to a cabinet reshuffle and criticism of his leadership. The outcome may also hurt the LDP's chances in a national election next year, with some analysts speculating that Abe's popularity and grip on power are eroding.

site_title: Boeing takes aim at its avionics suppliers, sending stocks down
summary: Boeing established an avionics group to produce aircraft controls and electronics, aiming to compete with suppliers Rockwell Collins, Honeywell, and United Technologies. The new unit, set to begin work in 2019, will focus on military, civil, and space vehicles, capturing a market worth hundreds of millions of dollars annually. Boeing's goal is to reduce costs and increase value for customers, while also generating additional services revenue. The move may impact suppliers, with Rockwell Collins' stock falling 6.3%.

site_title: Can America and China avoid Thucydides's Trap?
summary: US and China are not destined for war, but predictability is crucial in avoiding Thucydides's Trap, a concept coined by ancient Greek historian Thucydides to describe the inevitability of conflict between a rising power and an established power. Graham Allison's book, Destined for War, examines 16 major power rivalries, including the US-China relationship, and warns that the two nations are "on a collision course" unless they take steps to avoid war. The US lacks a coherent strategy for dealing with a rising China, while China seeks to regain its rightful place as a global power, posing significant challenges to the US and the global economy.

site_title: Pakistan's PM's fall new consequence of Panama Papers
summary: Pakistan's Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif was disqualified from public office over corruption allegations linked to the Panama Papers scandal. The leak of 11.5 million digital records revealed how wealthy individuals, including politicians and public officials, used offshore companies to stash assets. The scandal led to resignations, investigations, and blacklisting of tax havens, with France and the OECD taking action against Panama and other countries. The incident is the latest twist in the global fallout from the Panama Papers scandal, which has sparked calls for greater transparency and cooperation in tax evasion and corruption.

site_title: An engaging and insightful experience through dialogue
summary: The National Volunteer & Philanthropy Centre (NVPC) launched the Company of Good Fellowship Programme, a five-month learning series on corporate giving. The programme, which kicked off in May, includes a dialogue on CSR statements and community investment, led by Samsui Supplies and Services director Ang Kian Peng. Panelists shared their experiences on engaging stakeholders and articulating the importance of sustainability and corporate giving. The programme aims to provide a framework for companies to guide their decision-making and strategically address societal needs.

images.alt_text: Fellows and panel speakers at the dialogue session on sustainability and corporate giving.

site_title: Is a China-centric world inevitable?
summary: India is in a prolonged standoff with China on the Doklam plateau, with China attempting to establish a permanent presence in the area. The standoff is part of China's broader strategy to assert its dominance in the region and promote its "One Belt One Road" initiative. China's narrative of power is rooted in its history, using templates from the past to construct a modern narrative of power and dominance. However, this narrative is not supported by historical facts, and China's contemporary rise does not entitle it to claim a fictitious centrality. India must form its own narrative and resist attempts by any power to establish dominance over Asia and the world, leveraging its cosmopolitan culture and values to shape a new international order.

site_title: Life in graphics
summary: Japanese graphic artist Takora Futori's work is featured at K+ TAKO LABO in Singapore until Sept 10, showcasing seven patterns on textiles and handmade dresses. The exhibition also includes fabric items, accessories, and a craft workshop.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: China's new heavy-lift rocket launch fails in flight
summary: China's launch of the Long March-5 Y2 rocket, carrying its heaviest satellite, failed on Sunday, according to official news agency Xinhua. The failed launch occurred just before the rocket was expected to take China's lunar probe to the Moon and return with samples. President Xi Jinping has prioritized advancing China's space program for national security and defense, and it is unclear how the lunar mission's timetable may be affected. The cause of the failure is not specified.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.990 points to 1,767.080. Losers outnumbered gainers 495 to 335, with a total trading volume of 1.644 billion lots worth RM2.203 billion.

site_title: CapitaLand seeks more active land-banking in China
summary: CapitaLand plans to increase its active land-banking in China, with its third Raffles City private equity fund still holding $1 billion in dry powder. The fund can acquire up to $2 billion worth of assets with 50% leverage. The company has completed four integrated projects in China, including three Raffles City projects, and plans to develop more projects in the country, including a $5 billion investment in Raffles City Chongqing. CapitaLand's focus on China and Singapore will continue, with opportunities to acquire completed assets in developed markets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 1.53 points to 1,768.54. The index saw 55.7 million lots traded worth RM32.3 million, with 102 gainers and 95 losers.

site_title: Deutsche Bank ex-executives said to forfeit half bonuses in deal
summary: Deutsche Bank AG is set to announce a deal where ten former and one incumbent executive board member will forfeit about half of their bonuses. The lender is seeking to persuade the former executives to help pay for billions of dollars in fines due to past misconduct. An official announcement could happen as early as today. The deal is part of Deutsche Bank's efforts to address regulatory issues and recover from a financial crisis.

site_title: Marking 10 years of prepping PMETs for careers in real estate
summary: The Real Estate & Construction Centre (RECC) and Real Estate & Construction Academy (RECA) celebrated 10 years of preparing mid-career professionals for jobs in real estate and facilities management. Since 2006, over 500 professionals have undergone training, and 45 individuals were recognized for completing the Property Executive Career Conversion Programme. Minister of Manpower Lim Swee Say attended the graduation ceremony, emphasizing the need for industry transformation to become more productive and innovative.

site_title: Hindsight key to assessing market opportunities, dangers
summary: The article discusses the 30th anniversary of the 1987 financial crash and the current bull market, which has seen the S&P 500 index rise 240% since 2008. Economist Brendan Brown argues that monetary disorder has led to asset price inflation, characterized by irrational exuberance and speculative narratives. Brown identifies two types of inflation: boom-type, driven by flourishing investment opportunities, and depression-type, driven by a famine of income on safe assets. He warns that the current depression-type inflation, fueled by central bank ease, will inevitably end in a bust, causing malinvestment and job losses.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Tuesday, driven by cautious optimism ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.1%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.2%. Investors are watching for clues on future interest rate hikes and the Fed's plan to reduce bond holdings. The Fed's meeting begins Tuesday and concludes Wednesday, with no expected policy changes or press conference.

site_title: Indonesia issues new rules to revive use of corporate commercial paper
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, has issued new rules to revive the use of corporate commercial paper, allowing limited liability companies to issue promissory notes with a maturity of one year or less. The rules, set to take effect on September 4, require companies to meet minimum capital and profitability requirements, present good financial statements, and be assessed by a rating agency. The goal is to diversify financial instruments and provide an alternative short-term funding option for firms, addressing a lack of such notes in the market since the Asian financial crisis in 1997-98.

site_title: Passenger traffic at Changi Airport up 5.7% in 1H 2017
summary: Changi Airport reported a 5.7% increase in passenger traffic to 30.4 million in the first half of 2017, driven by growth to and from South-east Asia, North-east Asia, and South Asia. India was the fastest-growing country market, with over 2 million passengers. Aircraft movements rose 3% to 183,230, while airfreight throughput increased 6.8% to 1.02 million tonnes.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Michelin reaffirms goals despite operating profit dip
summary: Michelin reported first-half sales and operating profit that narrowly missed market expectations, with recurring operating profit falling 0.9% to 1.39 billion euros. Revenue increased 7.4% to 11.06 billion euros, but profitability slipped to a 12.6% operating margin from 13.7% last year. Despite the dip, Michelin reaffirmed its 2017 goals, citing price increases expected to bolster earnings for the remainder of the year.

site_title: China's LKK to buy London's "Walkie Talkie" skyscraper
summary: Chinese herbal health products maker LKK Health Products Group Ltd has agreed to buy London's "Walkie Talkie" skyscraper for £1.28 billion, marking its first international acquisition. The deal comes as London's property market attracts foreign investors seeking opportunities post-Brexit. The 20 Fenchurch Street building, valued at £567.5 million, was previously owned by Land Securities Group plc and Canary Wharf Group plc. The sale will generate £641 million for Land Securities, with the rest used to repay debt. The acquisition is LKK's first outside of Hong Kong and China.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.1 per cent down
summary: Singapore stocks ended 0.1% lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index falling 3.32 points to 3,310.8. The blue-chip index was weighed down by falls in OCBC, DBS, and Genting Singapore, while rises in UOB, Singtel, and CapitaLand Mall Trust helped to offset losses. Losers outnumbered gainers 264 to 185, with about 3.26 billion shares changing hands for S$958 million.

site_title: Lyft team steers toward open self-driving tech
summary: Lyft has dedicated a new team to developing an open self-driving vehicle platform, allowing other companies to use and learn from the technology. The platform, set to be launched in the US, will be used by Lyft's own self-driving cars and partners, aiming to enhance safety and accessibility. The move follows similar efforts by Uber and Waymo, and comes as major automakers and tech firms invest in autonomous driving. Lyft's vice-president, Luc Vincent, says the self-driving division is core to the company's business, and will accelerate partners' efforts.

site_title: New York suburbs get makeovers to attract millennials
summary: New York suburbs are revamping their image to attract millennials with modern amenities, such as restaurants and public transportation links. Developments like New Rochelle's $1.2 billion project, featuring 650-700 rental units, are part of a broader effort to revitalize the area. Westchester County is seeing a surge in new residential projects, with over 1,000 rentals in the pipeline, and rents expected to rise to $2,159 per month on average. The strategy aims to offer a more affordable urban alternative to Manhattan, with some units potentially being more competitive than the county average.

site_title: China officials to enforce mainland laws in Hong Kong train station
summary: Hong Kong announced a plan to allow mainland officials to enforce Chinese laws inside a train station, encroaching on the city's autonomy and freedoms. This move contradicts the city's Basic Law, which states that mainland laws are not applicable in Hong Kong unless explicitly stated. Critics fear this will endanger existing freedoms, sparking concerns about the erosion of Hong Kong's autonomy.

site_title: Eurozone lending growth falls back in June: ECB
summary: The European Central Bank reported that eurozone lending growth fell back in June, with loans to the private sector rising 2.5% and borrowing by households growing at 2.6%. This marks a slight decrease from May's 2.7% and 2.5% respectively. The ECB watches these indicators to gauge the effectiveness of its policies aimed at boosting growth and inflation. Despite this, the bank's growth forecasts for the coming years remain unchanged, and ECB president Mario Draghi has indicated no immediate change to the easy-money policy.

site_title: Record number of firms leaving London's AIM market after advisers quit: study
summary: London's Alternative Investment Market (AIM) has seen a record 14 companies leave the junior stock market in the year to June 30, after their "nominated adviser" quit, with many brokers and investment banks reducing their exposure to riskier parts of the market. The highest number of companies have left since 2011/12. Companies often leave due to a loss of trust in management, and must replace a resigned adviser within a month or face delisting. The London Stock Exchange has launched a consultation to improve nomads' due diligence on companies.

site_title: Oil dives about 2.5%; Opec crude output rise forecast
summary: Oil prices dropped 2.5% on Friday, with Brent crude futures falling to $48.06 a barrel and US WTI crude futures falling to $45.77 a barrel. A consultancy forecasted a rise in Opec production for July, despite the group's pledge to cut output, reigniting concerns about a global surplus. The forecast, which cited higher supply from Saudi Arabia, the UAE, and Nigeria, suggests that the Opec meeting in St. Petersburg on Monday may not lead to significant production cuts.

site_title: Abe's low-key foreign minister watched as potential rival
summary: Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida is reportedly positioning himself as a potential successor to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, who has seen a decline in popularity due to allegations of cronyism. Kishida's clean image and backing from the dovish Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) faction could propel him into the leadership role. A cabinet reshuffle is expected in the coming weeks, with Kishida potentially excluded from the new lineup, which could pave the way for him to run against Abe.

site_title: Watch this space
summary: Danish design duo Space Copenhagen, founded by Signe Bindslev Henriksen and Peter Bundgaard Rützou, is working on a project in London with property magnate Harry Handelsman. The studio is creating the interiors for a double-cantilevered residential tower and hotel in the city's east end, a gentrification project. Both designers grew up in creative families, with Bindslev Henriksen from a family close to the Louisiana Museum of Modern Art and Bundgaard Rützou from an expat background, which sparked his curiosity about different cityscapes and cultures.

site_title: Genting Singapore, Singtel and banking stocks lift STI
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 20.99 points or 0.64% to 3,314.12 on Friday, lifted by banking stocks, Genting Singapore, and Singtel. The gains were attributed to Singtel's launch of near-gigabit speeds on its LTE advanced network and Keppel Corporation's revenue and net profit. The benchmark index surpassed the 3,300-point threshold, with 3.7 billion units worth S$1.4 billion traded on Friday.

site_title: William, Kate take Brexit 'charm offensive' to Germany
summary: Prince William and his wife Kate began a three-day visit to Germany on July 19, 2017, as part of a "charm offensive" amid the Brexit talks. The royal couple, accompanied by their children, met with Chancellor Angela Merkel at a lunch at her office complex. The visit aimed to strengthen ties and showcase British culture.

site_title: Eco high
summary: Bertrand Piccard, a Swiss explorer and founder of the Solar Impulse Foundation, aims to promote clean energy by encouraging businesses to adopt sustainable technologies. After completing the first round-the-world solar-powered flight in 2015, Piccard launched the World Alliance for Efficient Solutions, a global initiative to promote profitable and efficient solutions to environmental problems. With the support of major companies and individuals, including billionaires Richard Branson and Elon Musk, Piccard hopes to translate his vision of a cleaner future into reality. He emphasizes that clean technology can create jobs, fuel growth, and protect the environment, citing examples of countries like Morocco and Sweden that are making significant strides in renewable energy. However, Piccard believes that more leadership and vision are needed to achieve a cleaner and greener world.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Honeywell beats profit estimates, raises full-year forecasts
summary: Honeywell International Inc reported a quarterly profit better than expected, with sales in its aerospace unit falling 3% to $3.67 billion, but margins rising to 22.3%. The company raised its full-year earnings forecast and expects 2017 sales in the range of $39.3 billion to $40 billion. The aerospace business benefited from strength in commercial aviation after-sales business and growth in US defense volumes. Honeywell also raised its earnings per share forecast range by 10 cents to $7.00.

site_title: Hot stock: Union Gas debuts above IPO price
summary: Union Gas, a bottled gas supplier and compressed natural gas provider, made its initial public offering (IPO) debut on the Catalist board in Singapore, opening at S$0.295, slightly above its IPO price of S$0.25. The IPO was 7.1 times subscribed, with 58.72 million shares placed out to the public, and 1.28 million shares available for public subscription. This marked a successful debut for the company, with its shares trading above the IPO price.

site_title: Thakral starting tender process to sell HK warehouse property
summary: Thakral Corporation has initiated the tender process to sell a warehouse property in Hong Kong's Kowloon area. The property, located at No 4 Tung Yuen Street, will be put up for sale after a five-week bidding period. The company's decision comes as it seeks to divest its real estate assets.

site_title: NUS-Redas property sentiment index at its highest since Q1 2010
summary: The NUS-Redas property sentiment index in Singapore reached its highest level since Q1 2010, increasing to 6.1 in Q2 from 5.2 in Q1. Despite weak macroeconomic fundamentals, the index showed improvement, with the future sentiment index also rising to 6.2. This suggests a positive outlook for the Singapore property market, with a benchmark price of S$3,000 psf for prime projects expected to be tested in the upcoming Q3 condo launches.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: China cashing out as mobile payment soars
summary: China's mobile payment platforms have seen a surge in usage, with consumers increasingly opting to use their smartphones to pay for everyday expenses. The trend is driven by convenience, with many users preferring to carry fewer bags and avoid the hassle of handling cash. As a result, mobile payments have grown significantly, with Yang Qianqian, a 25-year-old dance student, using her smartphone to pay for fresh produce at a market in Beijing. This shift is expected to continue, potentially reducing the country's reliance on cash.

images.alt_text: Yang Qianqian holds out her smartphone to scan a barcode on the mobile of a vendor selling fresh fruit and vegetables at a bustling outdoor market in Beijing.

site_title: Philippine MPs to vote on Duterte bid for longer martial rule
summary: The Philippine Congress is set to vote on President Rodrigo Duterte's bid for a longer martial rule over the southern third of the country, which could last until the end of the year. The military has failed to recapture the city of Marawi after two months of fighting, with only about 60 Islamist gunmen remaining. Duterte needs martial law powers to rebuild the city and prevent the war from spreading. The proposed extension has sparked opposition, with critics alleging it is a step towards a military-backed dictatorship.

images.alt_text: Mr Duterte is widely expected to win approval for martial law in the region until the end of the year, with troops having failed to wrest back the southern city of Marawi following two months of fighting.

site_title: SoftBank fund leads US$114m push in robotech
summary: SoftBank Group Corp's Vision Fund led a US$114 million investment in Brain Corp, a startup specializing in developing self-driving technology for robots. Brain Corp's AI and technology enables robots to perceive their environment, learn to control motion, and navigate using visual cues and landmarks. The investment aims to further develop the startup's capabilities in robotics and artificial intelligence.

site_title: Fintech firms charmed by Macron but not ready yet to leave London for Paris
summary: France's fintech sector is optimistic about President Macron's efforts to boost its global rankings, but London remains a hub for fintech startups despite having French roots. A Deloitte study ranks Paris 29th globally and 7th in Europe, indicating a need for further development. The industry is crucial for financial services and economic growth, but startups are hesitant to leave London for Paris.

site_title: Saudi King overhauls interior ministry after palace shake-up
summary: Saudi King Salman overhauled the Interior Ministry, stripping it of key powers, a month after appointing his son as crown prince. The king established a homeland security agency linked to the prime minister's office, consolidating units such as counterterrorism and special forces. The move aims to centralize security powers and reduce the influence of the Interior Ministry, which was led by the king's nephew before the palace shake-up.

site_title: Trump, Putin had previously undisclosed visit at G20 dinner
summary: US President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin had a previously undisclosed conversation during a G20 dinner in Germany on July 7, in which Putin denied allegations of meddling in the 2016 US presidential election. The conversation, which took place after a formal bilateral meeting, was attended by a translator and lasted about an hour. Trump's interactions with Putin have raised renewed concern as Congress and a special counsel investigate allegations of collusion. Trump Jr, a key figure in the investigation, is set to be interviewed by a congressional panel.

site_title: Thai June export growth seen slowing, output to rise: poll
summary: Thailand's customs-cleared annual exports are expected to rise 7.85% in June, slower than the 12.7% increase in May, driven by a global economic recovery and stronger demand for commodities. This would mark the fourth consecutive month of growth. Exports are forecast to rise 5% in 2017, despite the baht appreciating 6.5% against the US dollar. Imports are expected to rise 11.2% in June, contributing to a trade surplus of $1.32 billion.

site_title: Bolshoi, under the exacting eye of Makhar Vaziev
summary: Makhar Vaziev, the new ballet director at the Bolshoi Theatre, has implemented a Big Brother-like method of supervision, using a large flat-screen TV to monitor rehearsals and make adjustments remotely. Vaziev, a former director at the Mariinsky Theatre and La Scala, aims to modernize the traditional company's classical repertory, suggesting 70% older and 30% contemporary works. The decision to postpone the premiere of Nureyev, a groundbreaking biographical piece, was met with criticism, with some claiming it is censorship reminiscent of the Stalinist era. Vaziev defends the decision, stating that the company is not ready for the production.

site_title: Thriving in the disruptive age
summary: Industry players in the real estate sector are reframing their approach due to disruptions from technologies and the emergence of millennials. Disruption is impacting offices, retail shops, and the role of real estate agents, but it also creates opportunities. Companies like CapitaLand and Frasers Centrepoint Limited are leveraging digital tools and technology to engage customers and stay ahead. Overseas investments have become a key strategy, with Singaporean investors increasing their share of global real estate investments to 79% in the first half of 2017.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend rally at open
summary: Hong Kong's stock market rallied for a ninth consecutive day on July 20, 2017, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.37% to 26,770.48. This follows a record close for US stocks, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Oil jumps to 6-week high on surprisingly big US inventory draws
summary: Oil prices surged to a six-week high on Wednesday after the US Energy Information Administration reported a larger-than-expected weekly drawdown in crude and gasoline stocks. Crude stocks fell 4.7 million barrels, while distillate stocks decreased 2.1 million barrels and gasoline stocks declined 4.4 million barrels. US production reached a two-year high, increasing pressure on Opec to support prices. Brent futures rose 1.8% to $49.70, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 1.6% to $47.12, marking the highest close since June 6.

site_title: Global buyers of quality wheat face disappointment in Canada
summary: Canada's wheat supply faces disappointment for global buyers seeking high-quality wheat due to drought-affected crops. US wheat output has shrunk, prompting the country to potentially import record amounts. Japan and the Philippines, top importers of high protein spring wheat, are searching for alternative sources. Canadian farmers are struggling to produce average crops, with some giving up on failed spring wheat crops, driving prices to four-year highs.

site_title: The future of work
summary: The co-working concept has become mainstream, providing a hub for entrepreneurs and businesses to interact and collaborate. Designers and small business owners, like Mashizan, value the community and networking opportunities offered by co-working spaces. This shift is driven by the desire for a "buzzy" feel, allowing creative minds to thrive. As the concept gains popularity, it is likely to continue to play a significant role in shaping the future of work.

site_title: Yahoo Japan launches gaming platform that bypasses app stores
summary: Yahoo Japan launches Game Plus, a web-based gaming platform offering cloud streaming and HTML5 titles. The service starts in Japan with 39 titles, partnering with 52 game publishers, including Square Enix Holdings and Koei Tecmo Holdings. Game Plus allows users to play games without downloading apps or software, bypassing app stores run by Apple and Alphabet. The move aims to tap into the growing web-based gaming market, expected to generate US$50 billion in sales last year. The platform offers a mix of free-to-play games and others requiring a one-time payment.

site_title: US to push for lower trade gap in Nafta talks
summary: The US is seeking to renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) to reduce trade deficits with Canada and Mexico. US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer stated that the US aims to lower trade barriers and eliminate unfair trade practices. However, economists warn that reducing bilateral deficits may be impractical and unlikely to achieve. The talks, which begin next month, will focus on updating the trade pact, strengthening labour and environmental commitments, and addressing digital economy issues.

site_title: Saudi Aramco's strange response to a future oil shortage
summary: Saudi Aramco's CEO Amin Nasser plans to invest $300 billion over the next decade, primarily to maintain current production capacity and double gas output, despite concerns over a potential oil shortage. The company's oil reserves are vast, with 266.5 billion barrels, but experts question the strategy, suggesting that Saudi Arabia could benefit from foreign investment to boost production capacity. The lack of transparency in oil reserves and high production costs make it difficult to determine the true extent of the potential shortage.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported Q2-2017 results with a 4.2% year-over-year increase in distribution per unit, meeting expectations. Despite a decrease in occupancy to 63.1%, the company's financials are expected to remain stable. Viva Industrial Trust announced the completion of an asset enhancement initiative and is expected to see a positive impact on its business, with a target price of S$0.97. Analysts also expect improving cash flows and profits from other companies, including Keppel and Sembcorp Industries, driven by sales and lease agreements.

site_title: China just made the most steel ever as Trump gets set to act
summary: China's steel output reached a record 73.23 million metric tons in June, a 5.7% increase from the same period last year, and 4.6% higher than the first half. Aluminum production also surged, with a 7.4% increase in June and 8.8% over the six months. The strong performance is attributed to China's efforts to cut outdated capacity and boost production after a crackdown on the informal sector. This comes as the US considers imposing tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from China, which could impact global markets.

site_title: A breed of its own
summary: Loro Piana, an Italian luxury fashion brand, showcases its Fall/Winter 2017 collection featuring high-quality fabrics sourced from natural materials like cashmere and vicuña. The brand, known for its superlative wool from Australia and New Zealand, utilizes cutting-edge technology and innovation to produce superior quality products. Loro Piana's latest collection includes classic duster coats and reversible winter jackets, available at its stores in ION Orchard and The Shoppes at MBS.

site_title: Merkel's rival takes a leaf from Macron's election playbook
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's main domestic challenger, Martin Schulz, criticized Germany's budget surplus, pledging to allocate surplus revenue to infrastructure spending if he wins the federal election on September 24. Merkel responded by saying that bureaucratic barriers are the main challenge to increasing spending, not the need for more funds. Schulz aims to capitalize on Merkel's record on spending, while Merkel plans to serve a full four-year term if re-elected, potentially extending her chancellorship to 16 years.

site_title: What do you do when the boss wants you to do something unethical
summary: When a boss asks an employee to engage in unethical behavior, such as misleading a customer or taking a shortcut that compromises product quality, it can be a difficult decision. Employees may consider discussing the issue with their boss, escalating the complaint to a higher authority, or reporting it to the government or media. However, this can come with risks, including retaliation, social costs, and potential job loss. Experts suggest that employees should start by explaining the request in plain language, citing company policies, and offering an alternative solution. If internal options are exhausted, employees may need to weigh the risks and consider leaving the job to maintain their moral values.

site_title: GLP to develop Adidas' largest distribution centre in Asia
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has signed an agreement with Adidas to develop its largest distribution centre in Asia, a 83,000 sq m build-to-suit project in Suzhou, Eastern China. The facility will be GLP's first LEED Gold standard facility in China, reflecting growing demand for logistics facilities to serve domestic consumption. The project is part of Adidas' plans to double its space in the park, driven by strong demand from domestic consumption.

site_title: 'Russiagate' to hang over Washington for the foreseeable future
summary: A growing "Russian Collusion" scandal is expected to hang over Washington for the foreseeable future, hindering the White House's agenda and making President Trump more politically dependent on Republicans. The controversy centers on allegations of a Trump-Putin conspiracy to influence the 2016 presidential election, fueled by the release of emails between Donald Trump Jr. and a Russian lawyer. The emails suggest that Trump campaign aides and family members were prepared to work with Russia to ensure Clinton's loss. This development is likely to shift the political balance of power in Washington, making it more difficult for the White House to pursue its agenda and potentially damaging the president's relationship with Vladimir Putin.

site_title: Structure on highway under construction collapses near PIE; 1 dead, 10 injured
summary: A structure on an incomplete highway collapsed near the Pan-Island Expressway (PIE) exit to Tampines Expressway (TPE) in Singapore, resulting in one death and 10 injuries. The deceased, 31-year-old Mr. Chen Yinchuan, was pronounced dead at the scene. The Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) has sent the injured to Changi General Hospital. The cause of the collapse is currently unknown, and an investigation is underway.

site_title: Corrupt former Fifa official Chuck Blazer dies of cancer, aged 72
summary: Former Fifa official Chuck Blazer, nicknamed "Mr Ten Percent," has died at 72 due to cancer. Blazer was a pivotal figure in the corruption scandal that convulsed Fifa in 2015, pleading guilty to charges of racketeering and money laundering in 2013. He was a key player in schemes involving bribes and kickbacks, and was banned for life from all football activities. Blazer's lavish lifestyle was funded by millions in commissions and fees, and he was also a close confidante of former Concacaf president Jack Warner, who is also facing charges in the US.

site_title: Business lessons - the hard way
summary: Terence Neo, 33, overcame financial struggles to turn his interior design boutique eightytwo into a successful business. Initially, Neo made rookie mistakes, including overspending on office renovations and struggling to find clients. The company faced bankruptcy, but Neo's wife encouraged him to take a leap of faith and invest more money. With a renewed perspective, Neo opened the company to a broader range of clients and adopted a more mindful approach to finances. Today, eightytwo has 18 employees and has completed prominent projects, including the design of Starker Bistro at Katong Square. Neo now mentors his employees and prioritizes work-life balance, ensuring a healthy and sustainable business.

images.alt_text: Wong Shiying

site_title: With S$100m to fund tech startups, Spring looks for co-investors
summary: Singapore's investment arm Spring Singapore has committed up to S$100 million to support deep-tech startups in three sectors: Advanced Manufacturing and Engineering, Health and Biomedical Sciences, and Urban Solutions and Sustainability. The funding will be co-invested with partners, who must demonstrate financial commitment, resources, and expertise to nurture Singapore-based startups. Interested parties can apply by August 25 and may concurrently apply for two tax incentives. This initiative is part of the Startup SG Equity scheme, which aims to boost support for startups in deep-tech areas.

site_title: British online trading firm IG's profit rises as client base grows
summary: British online trading firm IG Group Holdings reported a 3% pretax profit rise for the year ended May, beating analysts' estimates, as its client base grew 18% to 186,000. Revenue rose 8% to £491.1 million, with full-year net trading revenue and average revenue per client down due to quiet markets. IG has made progress in getting regulatory approval for a European Union subsidiary and is exploring further opportunities outside the EU. The company's shares rose 7.6% to 597 pence.

site_title: Japan pledges US$1b to back UN development goals
summary: Japan has pledged $1 billion over the next two years to support the UN's development agenda, focusing on education, health, disaster response, and gender equality. This move aims to help the UN achieve its sustainable development goals by 2030, particularly in ending extreme poverty. The funding is seen as a boost to the UN, which is facing a funding crisis amid growing demands and potential US cuts to its financial support.

images.alt_text: Japan on Monday pledged US$1 billion over the next two years to back the UN's development agenda, raising its profile as one of the world's largest foreign aid donors.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slides on Ericsson slump, souring bank mood
summary: European shares fell by over 1% on Tuesday, snapping a four-day winning streak, due to disappointing earnings from Ericsson and Lufthansa, as well as scaled-back expectations of monetary tightening by major central banks. European banks fell 1.6% and Goldman Sachs' lower bond trading revenue added to the selling pressure. The euro zone's broader earnings picture is expected to weaken slightly in the third quarter, with analysts citing a stronger currency weighing on large exporters.

site_title: Smells like teen spirit
summary: Lorde's sophomore album Melodrama has been praised as one of the best new pop albums of the year. The 20-year-old singer-songwriter reflects on heartbreak and personal struggle through sleek electronic beats and grandiose instrumentation. Released in 2017, Melodrama showcases her growth as a musician and individual, offering a glimpse into her musings as a young woman navigating life's challenges.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Standing out
summary: Judy Hsu, the new CEO of Standard Chartered Bank in Singapore, is known for her competitive streak and determination to challenge norms. She took the job in 2015, despite leaving behind her global wealth management team, to bring back independent thinking to the bank. Under her leadership, the Singapore operations have been restructured to give more autonomy to make decisions, and a five-year plan has been designed to grow the retail franchise and invest in commercial banking. Hsu aims to bring back a competitive spirit to the bank, which has been dominated by fines and regulations. She also focuses on diversity, flexibility, and cultural sensitivity, encouraging staff to take breaks, learn new skills, and invest in Singaporean talent.

site_title: The scenic route
summary: The new Renault Grand Scenic boasts a stylish design with a long roof, aerodynamic profile, and massive wheels. The fourth-generation compact MPV features a new design language, a 1.5-litre turbodiesel engine, and a 7-speed dual clutch transmission. The interior is notable for its spacious cabin, One-Touch Folding control function, and advanced features like a 8.7-inch touchscreen and Arkamys 3D sound system. The Grand Scenic is designed for a seven-seat family van, offering a balance of performance, fuel efficiency, and practicality.

site_title: Union Gas launches IPO for Catalist listing
summary: Union Gas Holdings launched its initial public offering (IPO) on the Catalist board, offering 60 million shares at 25 Singapore cents each. The IPO aims to raise funds to acquire other LPG dealers and enter the piped natural gas business. With an initial market capitalization of about S$50 million, the company plans to use the funds to expand its business through acquisitions, joint ventures, or strategic alliances. The IPO is also seen as a way to raise brand awareness and give the public a chance to participate in the company's equity growth.

images.alt_text: Chief executive Alexis Teo says the IPO is to raise brand awareness and to reward its customers with a chance to take part in the company's growth.

site_title: Beat goes on for evergreen boyband
summary: Grasshopper, a 30-year-old Cantopop boyband, credits strict exercise regimes and diets for maintaining their physical appearance. The trio, consisting of brothers Remus and Calvin Choy and friend Edmond So, relies on these habits to perform high-energy, two-hour concerts. Talent-spotted by late "Queen of Cantopop" Anita Mui in 1985, Grasshopper returns to Singapore for a concert next Saturday, showcasing their flamboyant costumes and choreography.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Local music festivals kick off
summary: Local music festivals kick off this July with three events: Baybeats, Ignite!, and 100 Festival. Baybeats features 28 bands, including Obedient Wives Club and Amateur Takes Control, at the Esplanade from July 13-15. Ignite! takes place at the Republic Polytechnic Lawn on July 28-29, while 100 Festival, held at the former Bedok Town Secondary School, will feature a diverse lineup of local acts, including Shigga Shay, TheLionCityBoy, and The Analog Girl, from July 14-16 and 21-23. The festivals aim to promote homegrown music and community engagement.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Commodity trader Clearsource adds LPG, naphtha
summary: Clearsource, a Singapore-based petroleum and metals trader, is expanding its Asian operations to include naphtha and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) from its Singapore office. The company has hired I S Ryu, a former Castleton Commodities International trader, for its light fuels desk. This expansion aims to capitalize on growing demand for these fuels in Asia.

site_title: US is said to plan talks soon to revamp South Korea trade deal
summary: The US is planning to renegotiate its free-trade agreement with South Korea, according to US Trade Representative officials who notified lawmakers of the plan. The talks are expected to start soon, with US officials seeking to address issues such as trade imbalances and South Korea's export subsidies. The move comes amid growing tensions over trade and US President Donald Trump's "America First" agenda. The outcome of the renegotiations is uncertain, but the talks are seen as a key step in re-evaluating the US-South Korea trade deal, which was signed in 2012.

site_title: ADB warns climate change 'disastrous' for Asia
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) warns that a business-as-usual approach to climate change will be "disastrous" for Asia, undoing decades of economic growth and development advancements. A continued reliance on fossil fuels will lead to prolonged heat waves, rising sea levels, and disrupted ecosystems, causing high economic losses and potentially even wars. The report emphasizes the need for urgent action to mitigate climate change and protect Asia's development gains.

images.alt_text: A business-as-usual approach to climate change will be "disastrous" for Asia, undoing much of the phenomenal economic growth that has helped it make vast inroads against poverty, the Asian Development Bank said in a report released Friday.

site_title: US to review remaining Middle East airlines under laptop ban
summary: The US Department of Homeland Security plans to review three Middle Eastern airlines - Saudi Arabian Airlines, Royal Air Maroc, and EgyptAir - to lift the laptop ban at four airports. The review comes after the airlines have introduced security measures to address the threat of hidden explosives. The ban was initially imposed in March on nine airlines, including these three, and has been lifted for six airlines since then. The review is expected to determine if the airlines have met the necessary security standards, with the ban potentially being lifted as early as July 19.

site_title: Duty Free International's Q1 earnings down 24.1%
summary: Duty Free International (DFI) reported a 24.1% decline in its Q1 earnings to RM15.1 million, primarily due to lower demand for certain products and the Malaysian government's goods and services tax at border outlets. Revenue decreased by 13.1% to RM167.5 million. The company's effective tax rate was 24.9%, higher than the statutory income tax rate, mainly due to non-deductible expenses related to an unrealised foreign-exchange loss.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: OCBC Investment Research downgraded CapitaLand Retail China Trust to "Hold" with a target price of S$1.58, citing reasonable current price levels following the recovery of CapitaMall Minzhongleyuan and contributions from recently acquired CapitaMall Xinnan.

site_title: UK Tata Steel completes UK restructuring with sale of pipe mills
summary: Tata Steel has completed its UK restructuring with the sale of two steel pipe mills in Hartlepool to Liberty House Group. The 42-inch and 84-inch mills, which employ about 140 people, were sold for an undisclosed financial value. The sale will allow Tata Steel to focus on its strip products supply chain at Port Talbot, while retaining a 20-inch mill at Hartlepool, which will be invested in to increase its high-strength steel tube production capacity. This move is part of Tata Steel's efforts to cut debt by selling unprofitable assets.

site_title: In America's richest state, the capital flirts with bankruptcy
summary: Hartford, the capital of Connecticut, is on the brink of bankruptcy, with a projected two-year deficit of $5 billion. Despite being the wealthiest state in the US, with a per-capita income of $71,033, the city faces a fiscal crisis due to underfunded state-worker pensions, rising pension, debt, and healthcare costs. The city's tax base is strained, and its credit rating may be downgraded. Hartford is considering bankruptcy as a last resort, with Mayor Luke Bronin saying the city's hands are "behind its back" due to lack of state support.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 2.10 points lower at 1,755.03 on Tuesday, with 1.73 billion lots valued at RM2.07 billion traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 715 to 198.

site_title: China to make nearly half of new electric car models by 2020: study
summary: China is expected to produce nearly half of the 103 new electric car models launched globally by 2020, according to a study by US consulting firm AlixPartners. Chinese carmakers already account for 96% of electric vehicles sold in China, and the country aims to have nearly two-thirds of the world's lithium-ion battery manufacturing capacity by 2021. By 2025, electric vehicle batteries are forecast to be close to production costs of internal combustion engines, potentially boosting consumer acceptance.

site_title: StarHub to step up sale of data analytics to corporate clients
summary: StarHub, Singapore's second-largest telecommunications company, plans to expand its data analytics services to corporate clients as a growth strategy. The company aims to capitalize on the valuable data generated by its customers' mobile, broadband, and TV usage. StarHub has already seen significant growth in its corporate segment, accounting for 42% of its revenue last year. The company plans to purchase a 51% stake in cybersecurity solutions provider Accel Systems & Technologies Pte and shares in media content company mm2 Asia Ltd to support its enterprise business.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly higher by 0.06% on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.06% to 3,220.64 on Wednesday, despite regional markets experiencing slight dips. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 1.84 points, driven by gains in City Developments and United Overseas Bank. The market's resilience comes as US President Donald Trump's son revealed emails showing the Russian government backing his father's presidential campaign. This follows a 0.85% decline in the STI on Tuesday, and comes ahead of US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen's testimony to Congress on the pace of inflation and labour-market tightness.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Williams still sees rate hike, asset unwinding this year
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams expressed his expectation of one more interest rate hike this year and asset unwinding in the next few months. Williams believes US inflation will pick up to around 2% over the coming year, citing a transitory softening in recent inflation data. If inflation doesn't accelerate as expected, it would suggest a slower pace of rate rises than currently projected.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end with fresh gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.48% on Tuesday, driven by gains ahead of the US corporate season and Federal Reserve testimony by Janet Yellen. The Hang Seng Index reached 25,877.64, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices declined 0.30% and 0.72% respectively.

site_title: Asia: Energy firms rally with oil but markets struggle
summary: Asian energy firms rallied on Wednesday, driven by oil price gains of over 1% after US stockpiles fell, while energy companies in Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Sydney rose. However, markets struggled overall due to concerns over US President Donald Trump's Russia links, with Tokyo and Seoul ending the session lower. The dollar retreated from recent gains amid expectations of interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve and other central banks.

site_title: Oil could hit US$60 before year-end, says Barron's citing Citi analyst
summary: Oil prices are expected to rise to $60 a barrel by the end of the year, according to a report by Barron's citing Citigroup analyst Eric Lee. Lee projects a record high demand of 97.3 million barrels a day in 2017, driven by emerging markets, and reduced OPEC supply of 0.7 million barrels a day.
