Despite rising US production and increased OPEC exports, Lee expects prices to remain flat in 2018, barring major disruptions.

site_title: South Korea says exports robust but weak domestic demand hampering economy
summary: South Korea's economy is being held back by weak domestic demand despite robust exports. May retail sales declined 0.9% and service sector output fell 0.3%, while consumer price index gained 1.9% year-on-year. The finance ministry attributes the slowdown to private consumption, tepid employment growth, and uncertainties from North Korean risks and soaring household debt. The economy faces challenges, and the ministry is seeking a "landing zone" in US trade talks to boost exports.

site_title: In China's murky waters, global sewage firms seek rewards
summary: Global sewage and water treatment firms are targeting China, the world's most populous nation, to capitalize on its growing waste management needs. China aims to lay 126,000 km of new sewage pipes by 2020 and raise wastewater treatment by 50 million cubic meters daily. The country's annual environmental spend is estimated at three trillion yuan, creating a massive market opportunity for foreign players. China has introduced new legislation making local officials directly responsible for water quality, and foreign firms are investing in small-scale sewage treatment units to meet the demand.

site_title: Same same but different
summary: Up-and-coming electronic music artist Jasmine Sokko has released a surprise EP of covers on her Soundcloud page, featuring tracks by LANY, Maggie Rogers, Britney Spears, and Shura. The songs, titled "Songs I Would Love To Call Mine," were initially recorded as demos for fun and were not meant to be publicly released. Sokko has edited the tracks to make them more listenable, sharing them with her fans. The EP showcases Sokko's love for the original songs and her talent for electronic music.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: At least 23 Egyptian soldiers killed in deadliest Sinai attack in years
summary: At least 23 Egyptian soldiers were killed in a deadly attack on two military checkpoints in North Sinai, marking one of the bloodiest assaults on security forces in years. The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack, which also injured 26 soldiers, and targeted a military compound on the border with the Gaza Strip. The attack is the most severe in Sinai since 2015 and comes as Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi faces a challenge in combating Islamist militancy.

site_title: US VP Pence's hands-on Nasa gaffe goes viral
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence's visit to NASA headquarters ended in a viral moment when he touched a critical space flight hardware piece despite a warning sign, prompting a response from NASA and criticism from social media users. Pence initially blamed Florida Senator Marco Rubio, but later apologized and joked about the incident. NASA later downplayed the incident, stating the hardware needed to be cleaned anyway. The incident highlighted Pence's reputation for being straight-laced and conservative.

site_title: Being better off by doing less, whatever one's condition
summary: Recent medical studies suggest that doing less can be beneficial for patients with diabetes, heart conditions, and chest pain. A study found that non-insulin-dependent diabetics who self-monitored their blood sugar levels daily did not have better outcomes compared to those who did not monitor. In contrast, patients who received blood thinning medication after heart stent implantation may benefit from a shorter DAPT period if they are at low risk of heart attack or bleeding complications. New-generation stents with thin metallic struts can potentially allow patients to stop blood thinners after a certain period. Additionally, computed tomography (CT) of the coronary arteries (CCTA) can identify patients at risk of future heart events, potentially reducing the need for multiple tests and lifestyle modifications.

site_title: North Korea celebrates ICBM launch with fireworks
summary: North Korea celebrated its successful launch of an intercontinental ballistic missile, a milestone in its decades-long nuclear drive, with fireworks in Pyongyang's Juche Tower. The Hwasong-14 rocket, with a range of up to 8,000 km, was described by leader Kim Jong-Un as a "gift to American bastards" and triggered international condemnation. The launch has raised concerns about North Korea's nuclear capabilities and its potential threat to the US, with the UN imposing new sanctions. Thousands of officials and citizens gathered to rejoice, with Kim Yong-Nam and top general Hwang Pyong-So in attendance.

site_title: Tennis: 'Please help me' - Mattek-Sands suffers horror Wimbledon injury
summary: Bethanie Mattek-Sands, a 32-year-old American tennis player, suffered a severe knee injury during her first-round match at Wimbledon against Sorana Cirstea. The injury occurred when Mattek-Sands collapsed to the ground after damaging her right knee while approaching the net. She was left screaming in pain and crying, and it took around 20 minutes for medical services to arrive. Mattek-Sands was eventually stretchered away and taken to a hospital for further treatment, with her doubles partner Lucie Safarova expressing distress and concern for her well-being.

images.alt_text: America's Bethanie Mattek-Sands suffered a horror knee injury at Wimbledon on Thursday which left her screaming and crying in pain in the middle of the court.

site_title: Cedric Bourdy in a class of his own
summary: Bank of Singapore golfer Cedric Bourdy secured individual honours in the first leg of the Business Times Corporate Golf League with a one-over 73 score and 41 stableford points. Bourdy's impressive performance included an eagle and three birdies. Despite his individual success, Bank of Singapore finished eighth in the 12-team league. Tea Party (Centurion) took the team honours with 111 points, followed by the Crane Boomers and Team Boustead by five points.

site_title: Made in Myanmar: designers put ethical twist on local fashion
summary: In Myanmar, a new generation of designers is embracing the country's traditional fashion to preserve its heritage while promoting ethical practices. Designers like Pyone Thet Thet Kyaw and Mo Hom are creating unique, high-quality clothing using local fabrics and traditional patterns. This shift comes as the country's garment industry faces criticism for its poor labor practices and reliance on cheap, imported materials. Myanmar's emerging fashion scene aims to redefine the industry, prioritizing worker welfare and cultural preservation.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 0.49% in June 2017, reaching 3,226.48 points, driven by telecoms and finance sectors. M&A activity and sector rotation from technology to banks also contributed to the gains. Analysts from UOB Kay Hian Research predict a 2017 year-end target of 3,250 points, citing a range trade market due to priced-in earnings recovery expectations. Key buys include blue-chip stocks with earnings visibility and yield on dips, while mid-cap stocks Citic Envirotech and Hotung are favored.

site_title: Tea & symmetry
summary: Nirmal Sethia, a 75-year-old British-Indian businessman, is the founder of Newby Teas, a company he revived in 2000 after a 30-year hiatus. Sethia, who dropped out of school at 14, began his career as a tea apprentice and eventually became a successful tea exporter before leaving the industry to run his family's jute business. He returned to tea in 2000 and turned Newby Teas around, with a focus on preserving the culture and quality of tea. Today, the company has a turnover of around $15 million a year and Sethia is known for his passion for tea, his extensive collection of teapots and accessories, and his charitable work through the N Sethia Foundation.

site_title: Australia shares hurt by Wall Street tumble; NZ dips
summary: Australian shares declined for a third consecutive session, falling 0.3% to 5,703.60, as US stocks slipped after disappointing labor market data. The financial sector, particularly the "Big Four" banks, was a major drag. Oil prices also dropped, with US crude futures falling below $45 per barrel. New Zealand's benchmark index edged down 0.1% to 7,622.13. The declines were broad-based, with nine out of 10 sectors in the red, reflecting global market uncertainty.

site_title: Japan's Aeon posts higher Q1 profit on restructuring boost
summary: Japan's largest retailer, Aeon, posted a 11.4% increase in quarterly operating profit to 36.6 billion yen, exceeding expectations, due to restructuring efforts and price cuts to attract buyers amid weak domestic consumption. The company cited the success of its price cuts and plans to make further reductions. Aeon aims to reach a 290 billion yen operating profit target by 2020. Despite a 0.5% decline in shares, the company reiterated its operating profit forecast of 195 billion yen for the current financial year.

site_title: Wonder women
summary: Working mothers in Singapore face numerous challenges in balancing their careers and family life. Many struggle with "mommy guilt" and lack of support from family and employers, leading to trade-offs such as delegating childcare to others or working longer hours. Despite these challenges, some women have found success in juggling work and motherhood, citing the importance of a supportive partner, flexible work arrangements, and good role models. However, the majority of working mothers in Singapore spend less than 10 hours with their children on a workweek and feel the need to make sacrifices. Governments and corporations are beginning to address these issues, but more needs to be done to support working mothers in achieving a better work-life balance.

site_title: Central bank minutes, weak oil main factors this week
summary: Singapore stocks closed with a net gain of 2.67 points at 3,229.01 on Friday, despite a weak session, driven by a late push. The Straits Times Index was capped by US Treasuries selling off on Thursday, pushing up yields and dragging stocks lower. Liquidity was mediocre, with low daily volume, and trading was described as largely featureless. Key factors contributing to the market's performance included the hawkish tone from the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank, and a slide in oil prices, with Noble Group's shares rocketing up 36.2% on Thursday before falling back on Friday.

site_title: Hamburg summit shaping up to be the stormiest G-20 meeting in years
summary: The G-20 summit in Hamburg, Germany, is set to be one of the stormiest in years, with leaders gathering to discuss pressing global issues such as wars, trade, and climate change. US President Donald Trump's "America First" policy is expected to clash with world leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel, over trade and climate change. Trump's withdrawal from the Paris Agreement has sparked tensions, with Merkel urging the remaining G-20 members to meet their carbon-reduction goals. The summit's theme is "shaping an interconnected world," but the event's outcome remains uncertain, with the world's largest economies facing a test of unity in the face of disagreement.

site_title: Hamburg braces for 'Welcome to Hell' protest
summary: Hamburg, Germany is bracing for a potentially violent "Welcome to Hell" protest by anti-capitalist activists during the upcoming G20 summit. Tensions rise as police have clashed with protesters, and demonstrators are expected to block access to the summit venue. The city has deployed 20,000 police and set up a holding center for detainees. The protest's organizer, Andreas Blechschmidt, has vowed to blockade access and "reserve the option of militant resistance" against police, while Chancellor Angela Merkel has warned against using violence.

site_title: Oil rises on US crude stock draw, but prices remain weak
summary: Oil prices rose 0.7% on Thursday, driven by strong US fuel demand, with Brent crude futures up 34 cents to $48.13 per barrel and US WTI crude futures up 32 cents to $45.45 per barrel. However, analysts predict oversupply will continue to weigh on markets, with Bank of America Merrill Lynch cutting its forecasts to $47 and $50 per barrel this year and next. Despite OPEC's pledge to hold back production, OECD total oil inventories remain above 3 billion barrels, and US shale output is expected to rise further.

site_title: BOE's Saunders warns of 1st UK rate rise in decade
summary: The Bank of England's Michael Saunders warns that interest rates in the UK may rise for the first time in a decade, citing a "benign economic environment" and low unemployment. Saunders, a member of the Monetary Policy Committee, suggests that households should prepare for higher interest rates, but emphasizes that the decision will be made in the context of a strong economy. The BOE's benchmark interest rate has remained at 0.25% since 2016, and policymakers are weighing the risks of inflation and supporting growth ahead of their next announcement on August 3.

site_title: Building a thoughtful business
summary: The Thought Collective, a social enterprise group, operates as a for-profit organization with a mission to make Singapore stronger emotionally and socially. Founded 15 years ago by Kuik Shiao-yin and two co-founders, the group has grown into an ecosystem of complementary businesses, including a café chain, content curation studio, and training consultancy. Despite facing challenges, including increased competition and rising costs, the company remains committed to its social mission and balances profitability with its goals. To adapt to the changing market, The Thought Collective is exploring digitalization and scaling down its business to ensure sustainability.

site_title: China's Fosun says online rumours about Chairman false after shares fall
summary: Chinese conglomerate Fosun's shares fell 4% and 7.5% after online rumors surfaced that its billionaire chairman, Guo Guangchang, had gone missing. The company denied the rumors, stating that Guo was giving a speech in Shaanxi province and that his operations were normal. This comes amid concerns about high-profile Chinese executives going missing and potential exposure to offshore deals by firms including Fosun.

images.alt_text: Chinese conglomerate Fosun saw shares in its listed units fall on Thursday, prompting it to refute online rumours that it had lost contact with its billionaire chairman, Guo Guangchang.

site_title: Threat to HIV business spooks GlaxoSmithKline shares
summary: GlaxoSmithKline's shares fell 1.8% as investors reacted to a downgrade and reduced earnings forecasts due to slowing demand and new competition in its HIV drug business. Citigroup cited concerns over the repeal of the Affordable Care Act and the potential of rival companies' new treatments, including Merck's EFdA, which could reach the market as early as 2021. The downgrade and reduced forecasts led to a 0.8% decline in GSK's shares, making it one of the top losers in the FTSE-100 index.

site_title: WP's Low questions conflicts of roles, says Lee family saga not Korean drama show
summary: Singapore's Workers' Party leader Low Thia Khiang questioned the conflicting roles of K Shanmugam, Minister of Law, and Lucien Wong, Attorney General, in the Lee family feud. Low accused the roles of Shanmugam and Wong, who have close ties to the Lee family, of affecting the country's credibility. He asked for clarification on their positions and the line between private and public roles to be restored. This is not seen as a "Korean drama show" but rather a serious issue affecting the government's credibility.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: 3CNergy warrants - new and interesting
summary: 3CNergy warrants, issued by a Singapore-based property firm, were listed on May 31, just over a month ago. The warrants, part of a one-for-three rights issue, have a three-year life span and can be exercised at any time. With the underlying shares trading at S$0.053, the warrants are "out-of-the-money" and early exercise is unlikely. Despite a high gearing of 10.6 times, the warrant price of S$0.005 offers a large 98.1% conversion premium, making it a potentially attractive investment opportunity, especially if the underlying shares move to the upside.

site_title: Japan's 2016 land prices up, led by big gains in cities: govt survey
summary: Japan's average land price rose 0.4% in 2016, the second consecutive year of growth, driven by demand for hotels and retail space as tourism hit a record 24 million. Major cities like Tokyo and Osaka saw significant increases, with Tokyo's Ginza district experiencing a 26% rise to 40.3 million yen per square meter. Osaka's growth slowed due to rising land values.

site_title: Family businesses need to innovate through the ranks
summary: Family businesses need to innovate across all levels of staff, not just senior personnel, to stay competitive in a rapidly changing market. Research by KPMG Singapore found that two-thirds of family businesses' innovation takes place within the management team, while 53% do not have an existing plan to build a culture of innovation. Experts emphasize the need for leaders to set the tone for innovation, empower employees to think creatively, and adopt a decentralized decision-making model. By doing so, family businesses can drive revenue growth and value creation, and stay ahead of disruptive change.

site_title: Seoul: Won slides to 16-week low on heightened North Korea risks
summary: South Korea's won slid to a 16-week low on Tuesday, closing at 1,150.6 to the US dollar, down 0.3% from Monday's close. The decline came after North Korea successfully tested an intercontinental ballistic missile. South Korean shares also fell, with the Kospi index closing down 0.6% at 2,380.52 points. Foreign investors sold 193.6 billion won worth of Kospi shares, contributing to the market's weakness.

site_title: As US retires from world leadership, China and Germany step up
summary: US President Donald Trump's protectionist stance and climate change withdrawal from the Paris Agreement are leading to a shift in global leadership. China and Germany, traditionally allied with the US, are stepping in to fill the void. China's President Xi Jinping and Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel are strengthening their ties, with China investing in German robotics company Kuka AG. The two nations are also working together on climate change, with a joint German-Chinese working group re-committing to implementing Paris Agreement goals. This informal alliance is seen as a response to the US's absence from key global issues, with Merkel acknowledging the dangers of unequal partnerships between countries with different systems and values.

images.alt_text: When world leaders meet in Hamburg on Friday, China and Germany will move in to usurp the US's role.

site_title: Eco-friendly journey of heart and sole
summary: Enviably Me, a Singaporean firm, revamped its business strategy after discovering Brazilian eco-friendly shoe brand Melissa in 2011. The company, now the official distributor of Melissa and EMU Australia in Singapore, has seen significant growth, with Melissa experiencing double-digit growth and Enviably Me's revenue increasing by 20% in 2016. The launch of Melissa's largest flagship store in Singapore showcases the brand's focus on consumer-oriented retail experiences and differentiation. Enviably Me's omni-channel strategy has also helped it navigate the retail slump, with its website being its fastest-growing channel.

images.alt_text: Terence Yow, MD and founder of Enviably Me, at the official launch of MDREAMS, Melissa's largest flagship store in Singapore. Melissa is a Brazilian eco-friendly plastic shoe brand.
Melissa shoes are made using the patented Melflex plastic, a hypoallergenic and flexible PVC material that is 100% recyclable.

"There appears to be a huge resistance against e-commerce among physical retailers. Many people seem to think that the two channels are in conflict with each other; however, I believe that they are complementary rather than competing channels." - Terence Yow, founder of Enviably Me, which distributes Melissa shoes (above), a brand that celebrates female empowerment and individualism.

site_title: Slowing inflation rains on India's parade of strong growth
summary: India's economy is struggling with record low inflation, a widening output gap, and short-term uncertainty, potentially forcing the Reserve Bank of India to lower interest rates. This comes after the country's strong growth record, and investors are reminded of the risks of putting money in India. The economy's slowdown may be a result of a uniform sales tax introduction and a shift in monetary policy bias.

images.alt_text: Amid slowing growth and a drop in food prices, economists also lowered their consumer price inflation forecasts for the 2018 and 2019 fiscal years to 4 per cent and 4.75 per cent, respectively, from 4.5 per cent and 5 per cent in May's survey.

site_title: UBS Wealth recommends buying gold near US$1,200 for insurance
summary: UBS Wealth recommends buying gold near US$1,200 due to the expected sideways movement of real interest rates, which will counterbalance the pickup in nominal rates. This would result in a short-term trading range of US$1,200 to US$1,300 per ounce. The recommendation is not driven by a bullish or bearish bias, but rather a tactical approach to capitalize on the expected interest rate dynamics.

images.alt_text: Gold will probably trade in a range of US$1,200 to US$1,300 an ounce in the short-term as the metal tracks US real interest rates, according to UBS Group AG's wealth management unit.

site_title: Boxing: Pacquiao wants review of 'unfair' Horn loss
summary: Philippine boxing legend Manny Pacquiao has called for a review of the "unfair decision and officiating" in his recent loss to Australian Jeff Horn, citing the "twilight of a 22-year pro career" and a desire to uphold sportsmanship. The Philippines' Games and Amusement Board has also requested a review, and the WBO has responded, stating that the referee's decisions cannot be reversed unless there was fraud or a law violation. Pacquiao had initially called for a rematch but now considers retirement.

images.alt_text: Philippine boxing legend Manny Pacquiao on Wednesday urged the World Boxing Organization (WBO) to review the "unfair decision and officiating" after losing his welterweight title to Australia's Jeff Horn.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dive on technology retreat
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index plummeted 1.53% on Tuesday, led by a technology sell-off, despite energy firms rising due to recovering oil prices. The index fell to 25,389.01. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined, with the Shanghai Composite Index dropping 0.41% and the Shenzhen Composite Index falling 0.46%.

site_title: Indian debt funds swell to record size as they gorge on risk
summary: Indian debt funds have swelled to a record size, with assets under management in credit opportunities funds rising 65% to 1.09 trillion rupees in the year to April. This surge in risk appetite has helped lower-rated firms tap the debt market, with debt private placements of AA-rated issuers nearly tripling to 867 billion rupees. However, regulators warn that investors could be hit hard if there are sharp rating downgrades, citing recent examples of investors losing money due to credit risks.

images.alt_text: Franklin Templeton Asset Management sold its entire Jindal Steel and Power holdings at a loss last year after ratings downgrades.

site_title: PM Lee says anti-trade sentiments can hurt hundreds of millions, urges G-20 leaders to redistribute benefits of trade
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged G-20 leaders to redistribute the benefits of trade to combat anti-trade sentiments, which could hurt hundreds of millions of people. He emphasized the importance of multilateral trade models, such as the European Union and Asean Economic Community, to support workers and unions. Lee argued that countries should work together to address domestic policies and adjust packages to mitigate the negative impacts of trade. He also highlighted the need for small countries to band together to make their collective voice heard.

site_title: Monte Paschi looks to leave "emergency room" and return to profit
summary: Italy's oldest bank, Monte dei Paschi di Siena, has unveiled a 5-year restructuring plan to exit the "emergency room" and return to profit. The bank expects a net profit of over 1.2 billion euros in 2021, down from a loss of 3.2 billion euros last year. As part of the plan, the bank will sell 28.6 billion euros of bad loans and reduce its headcount to 20,000. The plan has been approved by European authorities, clearing the way for a state bailout that will remove the biggest threat to Italy's financial stability.

images.alt_text: Italian bank Monte dei Paschi di Siena set out plans to get out of the "emergency room" and return to profit on Wednesday, clearing the way for a state bailout that should remove the biggest threat to the country's financial stability.
